sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. On the economic package that you rolled out earlier this week, first on the business tax cuts. Why did you wait until this superheated campaign season to roll it out? A lot of your critics and even some Democrats say, well, clearly he's just using this for political purposes, he doesn't have any expectation it's actually going to be passed, it's a political weapon. Why did you wait so long to bring that out?And on the stimulus part, we can't get people in the White House to say it is a stimulus--$50 billion for roads and other infrastructure, but they avoid the word stimulus like the plague. Is that because the original stimulus is so deeply unpopular? And if so, why is it so unpopular? [SEP] Well, let me go back to when I first came into office. We had an immediate task, which was to rescue an economy that was tipping over a cliff. And we put in place an economic plan that 95 percent of economists say substantially helped us avoid a depression.A third of those were tax cuts, by the way. A third of that economic plan was tax cuts for individuals and for small businesses. So we haven't--this notion that we waited until now to put forward a series of plans, Chip, we've--just on the small-business issue alone, we have cut taxes for small businesses eight times during the course of the last 18 months. So we're hardly Johnny-come-latelies on this issue.Now, when you put all the things we've done together, it has made a difference. Three million people have jobs that wouldn't have them otherwise had we not taken these steps. The economy would be in much worse shape. But as I said before, we're not where we need to go yet, which means that if we're not there yet, what else can we do?And the proposals that we've put forward are ones that historically, again, have garnered bipartisan support: a research and development tax credit so that companies that are investing in research here in the United States, which is part of what's going to keep us growing and keep us innovative, let's make sure that companies are strongly incentivized to do that; making sure that their expensing accelerated business depreciation is happening in 2011 so that if companies are sort of sitting on the sidelines right now, not sure whether they should invest, let's give them incentive to go ahead and invest now to give that a jumpstart.On infrastructure, we've got a highway bill that traditionally is done every 6 years. And what we're saying is, let's ramp up what we're doing, let's beef it up a little bit, because we've got this infrastructure all across the country that everybody from Governors to mayors to economists to engineers of all political stripes have said is holding us back in terms of our long-term competitiveness. Let's get started now rebuilding America.And in terms of paying for some of these things, let's stop giving tax breaks to companies that are shipping jobs overseas. Let's stop incentivizing that. Let's give tax breaks to companies that are investing right here in the United States of America.Those are all commonsense approaches. Historically, as you know--you've been around this town for a long time--usually, Republicans and Democrats agree on infrastructure. Usually, Republicans and Democrats agree on making sure that research and development investments are made right here in the United States. And so let's get it done.It has nothing to do with the notion that somehow what we did previously didn't work. It worked. It just hasn't done as much as we need it to do. We've still got a long ways to go, and we're going to keep on doing it.
label: Implicit

sentence: But isn't your behavior setting a negative precedent for the rest of the country to follow, Mr. President? [SEP] That's simply incorrect. These are permitted activities under established guidelines. There are clearly defined exceptions for political events.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, following the Alaska meeting and considering the ongoing human rights situation, how would you define your current relationship with China? Are you leaning towards maintaining tariffs, prohibiting forced-labor imports, or restricting U.S. investment in China? [SEP] Those are valid points, but they only touch upon the multifaceted nature of our relationship with China. I've known Xi Jinping for a considerable period, longer than many other world leaders. We've engaged in extensive conversations, delving into significant detail. He's very straightforward, but he doesn't embrace democratic principles. He believes autocracy is the future. After my election, we had a substantial conversation. I stressed that we're not pursuing confrontation, but we will engage in strong competition and insist that China abide by international norms: fair competition, fair practices, fair trade. To compete effectively, we must invest in American workers and scientific advancement. We once allocated over 2% of our GDP to research; now it's just 0.7%. I plan to rectify that. We're also dedicated to reinforcing our alliances. This isn't about being anti-China; it's about democracies collaborating. I'll be speaking with European leaders soon, and I recently convened the Quad (Australia, India, Japan, and the US) to ensure China is held responsible. I'm also planning to host an alliance of democracies to discuss the future. We must hold China accountable for its behavior in the South China Sea, regarding Taiwan, and on human rights. No American president should hesitate to condemn the treatment of the Uyghurs or the situation in Hong Kong. That's integral to our values. I foresee intense competition with China. They aspire to global dominance, but that won't occur during my tenure.
label: General

sentence: Following the midterms, can you provide clarity on the future of your Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General? Are they secure in their positions? [SEP] I'd rather not comment on that right now. We're reviewing a number of things, including Cabinet positions. I'm generally happy with my Cabinet. We're looking at different people for various roles, which is common after the midterms. I didn't want to make any decisions before the election. But I'm mostly very happy with my Cabinet. Mike Pompeo has been a wonderful fit. He's done an incredible job.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President, following up on the 'killer' comment and Putin's reaction, can you share any details about the exchange that led to his satisfaction? What assurances or explanations did you provide? [SEP] Let's just say the matter is closed, as far as he's concerned. Raking it over again serves no purpose.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Bush, what are the key priorities for Africa in terms of development and governance, what type of leadership do you envision for the continent, and how will the U.S. contribute to these efforts? Additionally, what are your goals for this five-nation tour, and how will you ensure the sustainability of your initiatives beyond your time in office? [SEP] I came to Africa to show that we care. We want to help with health, trade, and education. Africa's improving, thanks to its own leaders. We've supported peace and democracy. We expect good governance in exchange for our help. I'm optimistic about the leaders I've met, and I'm pleased to be here.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Considering that the surge troops were mostly in place during the July report, will you continue the surge regardless of General Petraeus's assessment if there is no progress in Iraq by September? [SEP] You're asking me to speculate about my frame of mind in September. I would prefer to wait for General Petraeus to brief me. I'll be glad to answer your questions then.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Bush, does Karzai's accusation against Pakistan's intelligence services hold water? And is the new Pakistani government up to the task of fighting terrorists? [SEP] We're looking into Karzai's claims. No doubt, there are bad guys coming out of Pakistan into Afghanistan. That's a problem for everyone. We're working with the Pakistani government, and I believe they want to fight the terrorists. They've got a tough job, but we're going to help them. We all have a common enemy, and we need to work together to defeat them.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, were there any recordings made of that conversation? [SEP] Well, I can't say definitively if a recording exists. To my knowledge, there isn't one. Though, I must admit, the contents of such a recording, should it surface, would be quite illuminating, wouldn't you agree?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. A new Senate report this morning contends that your administration was warned before the war that by invading Iraq, you would actually give Iran and Al Qaida a golden opportunity to expand their influence, the kind of influence you were talking about with Al Qaida yesterday and with Iran this morning. Why did you ignore those warnings, sir? [SEP] Ed, going into Iraq, we were warned about a lot of things, some of which happened, some of which didn't happen. And obviously, as I made a decision of—as consequential as that, I weighed the risks and rewards of any decision. I firmly believe the world is better off without Saddam Hussein in power. I know the Iraqis are better off without Saddam Hussein in power. I think America is safer without Saddam Hussein in power.As to Al Qaida in Iraq, Al Qaida is going to fight us wherever we are. See, that's their strategy. Their strategy is to drive us out of the Middle East. They have made it abundantly clear what they want. They want to establish a caliphate. They want to spread their ideology. And they want safe haven from which to launch attacks. They're willing to kill the innocent to achieve their objectives, and they will fight us. And the fundamental question is, will we fight them? I have made the decision to do so. I believe that the best way to protect us in this war on terror is to fight them.And so we're fighting them in Iraq; we're fighting them in Afghanistan; we've helped the Philippines fight—Philippine Government fight them. We're fighting them. And this notion about how this isn't a war on terror, in my view, is naive. It doesn't reflect the true nature of the world in which we live.You know, the lessons of September the 11th are these: We've got to stay on the offense; we've got to bring these people to justice before they hurt again; and, at the same time, defeat their ideology with a ideology based upon liberty. And that's what you're seeing, and they're resisting it.I think it ought to be illustrative to the American people that Al Qaida is trying to stop new democracies from evolving. And what does—what should that tell you? That ought to tell you that we're dealing with people that have an ideology that is opposite of liberty and will take whatever measures are necessary to prevent this young democracy from succeeding.The danger in this particular theater in the war on terror is that if we were to fail, they'd come and get us. And, you know, I look at these reports right here in the Oval Office. For people who say that we're not under threat, they just simply do not know the world. We are under threat. And it's in our interest to pursue this enemy.Martha [Martha Raddatz, ABC News].Government of Iraq/
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. I wanted to know: When's the last time you spoke with President Xi of China? And do you plan to speak with him in the near future? [SEP] No, I haven't spoken to him. No, I don't; I have no plan to speak to him.Yes, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. Obama, with respect to Turkey's downing of a Russian plane, does this escalate into a NATO-Russia confrontation? How do we avoid a dangerous escalation? And how does this impact future military coordination with Russia? President Hollande, how do you see military coordination prospects with Russia given this event? [SEP] We're still gathering information. I expect to speak with President Erdogan soon. Turkey, like any nation, has the right to defend its territory. It's crucial that Russia and Turkey communicate to understand what happened and prevent escalation. This highlights the ongoing issue of Russian operations near the Turkish border, targeting moderate opposition supported by Turkey and others. If Russia focused on ISIS, these conflicts would be less likely. This underscores the need for political progress. Russia is welcome in our coalition against ISIS. The challenge is Russia's focus on supporting Assad. I told President Putin that if they shift to the Vienna process and focus on ISIS, there's potential for cooperation. Until then, it's difficult. Attacking the moderate opposition hinders cooperation. But cooperation is possible if we agree on a political process. The less likely these events will take place. President Hollande?
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Did you decide, sir, that the simple declaration was something the American people could handle, but this nuanced answer you just gave now was something that you couldn't handle and you didn't trust the American people with a fuller truth? [SEP] No. I think, as I said earlier, Major, my expectation was that for 98 percent of the American people, either it genuinely wouldn't change at all or they'd be pleasantly surprised with the options in the marketplace, and that the grandfather clause would cover the rest.That proved not to be the case. And that's on me. And the American people—those who got cancellation notices do deserve and have received an apology from me. But they don't want just words, what they want is whether we can make sure that they are in a better place and that we meet that commitment.And by the way, I think it's very important for me to note that there are a whole bunch of folks up in Congress and others who made this statement, and they were entirely sincere about it. And the fact that you've got this percentage of people who have had this impact, I want them to know that their Senator or Congressman, they were making representations based on what I told them and what this White House and our administrative staff told them. And so it's not on them, it's on us. But it is something that we intend to fix. Good.Steve Collinson [Agence France-Press].
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with Ghislaine Maxwell's imprisonment, speculation is rife about who she might implicate. Do you anticipate any high-profile individuals being exposed? [SEP] I'm not really up to speed on the details of the case. I wish her the best. I've crossed paths with her over the years, but I'm not familiar with the situation involving Prince Andrew.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Touching back on Iran: Of course, this week, you've put out a call to action to other countries to rally with America, to put pressure on Iran. Rouhani is still calling for the U.S. to come back into the old deal. But after meeting with world leaders this week, did you make any progress towards a potential new deal? [SEP] It doesn't matter what world leaders think on Iran. Iran's going to come back to me and they're going to make a good deal, I think. Maybe not. Deals: you never know.But they're suffering greatly. They're having riots in every city, far greater than they were during the green period with President Obama. Far greater. When President Obama stuck up for government, not the people. You probably would have had a much different Iran had he not done that. But I'm sticking up for the people. I am with the people of Iran.But here's the thing: They have rampant inflation. Their money is worthless. Everything is going wrong. They have riots in the street. You can't buy bread. You can't do anything. It's a disaster. At some point, I think they're going to want to come back, and they're going to want to say, Hey, can we do something?And I'm very simple; I just don't want them to have nuclear weapons. That's all. Is that too much to ask? I don't want them to have nuclear weapons.I want them to have a great economy. I want them to sell so much oil so that the oil prices—I'm not happy with OPEC. I told them, I'm not happy with OPEC. We take care of all these people; we defend them. They wouldn't be there for 2 weeks if it wasn't for me and the United States and a much stronger Armed Forces than it was. Because our Armed Forces was depleted. We had old equipment.Now, we have—hey, you know better than anybody, $700 billion and $716 billion. We have the most incredible new jets and everything. We need it. Not that I want to spend it, although it is jobs. It's all made in the United States.But Iran has to come back, and they have to talk. And I'm not doing this from strength or weakness. I'm just saying, at some point, I think they're going to have to come back. If you look at what's going on, companies are leaving left and right. Mercedes-Benz just left. They're all leaving. They don't want to be in Iran. Because they have a choice: Do they want to be with Iran, or do they want to be with us?And we have, by—we picked up $10 trillion since my election. We were being caught by . Now it's going the other way. People can't believe it. People have never seen this situation with . Everything's always been for 20 years: Oh, is so great. is so great. You don't hear that so much anymore. I love ; I think they're great. But you don't hear that so much anymore. You know who's great now? We're great now.Okay, how about just a couple of more. Now, I could be doing this all day long. I could be doing this all day long. Should we continue for a little while?
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Russia, what specific advice would you give your successor regarding the evolving dynamics with Russia, particularly considering the leadership transition from Putin to Medvedev? [SEP] Well, it's crucial to maintain open lines of communication. Russia remains a significant player on the world stage, and we need to find areas of cooperation, even as we acknowledge our differences. Arms control, counter-terrorism, these are areas where we can and should work together. But we also need to be clear about our values and our interests. We can't compromise on human rights or on the sovereignty of our allies. It's a delicate balance, but it's essential for maintaining stability and security.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, how confident are you that Speaker Boehner can actually deliver his caucus if you reach a deal? Do you still trust him to get it through the House? [SEP] Look, the Speaker has his own challenges, I understand that. Many of his members come from districts that I didn't win. They may be more worried about primary challenges than cooperating with me. But hopefully, after the events of the past week, we can all gain some perspective and do what's right for the country.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, have all the Governors signed off on this plan, Mr. President? [SEP] We just had a meeting with the Governors, and they were very interested in getting money for their States. Depending on the State, we have the discretion to do what we want. We can terminate the 25 percent, or we don't have to. We'll see; it depends on the individual State. A significant amount of money will be going to a lot of people quickly. I've directed the Secretary of the Treasury to move as quickly as possible. Right? Yes. The President. So we'll get it done. Yes, please.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, considering the congressional gridlock surrounding the Trans-Pacific Partnership, what alternative strategies are you exploring to ensure its ratification, and should currency manipulation be explicitly addressed within the agreement? Furthermore, what are your thoughts on the recent elimination of Taliban leader Mullah Mansur, and does this signify a change in U.S. policy regarding Afghanistan? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, on TPP, I've been around this town long enough to know that trade deals are always a tough sell. Everyone's angling for a better deal, and with so many parties involved, you can bet they're going to pick it apart, debate it endlessly, and in an election year, try to score some cheap political points. But having said all that, I'm still confident we'll get it done, because it's the right thing to do. It's good for the country, good for America, good for the region, good for the whole darn world. This is the fastest-growing part of the planet, a massive market for the United States. Most of these countries already sell their goods to us with relatively low tariffs. Meanwhile, tariffs are significantly higher for U.S. goods being sold over there. So a deal that eliminates 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods in the largest, fastest-growing markets is a no-brainer for American businesses and workers. One of the biggest gripes about trade deals in the past has been that they open our markets to countries with lower wages, unfair labor practices, and lax environmental regulations. But if you're signing up for TPP, you're making legally binding commitments to raise labor standards, give workers a voice, and address environmental concerns. That gives us the opportunity to engage with countries like Vietnam and work with them on all those issues. I haven't heard a single credible argument that we'll be worse off with TPP. It's clear as day that we'll be better off. American workers and businesses will benefit if we get this deal passed. The politics will be messy, just like they were with the Korean, Colombian, and Panamanian free trade agreements. But we got those done, and we'll get this done too. Now, about currency manipulation, we've got provisions in TPP that improve transparency and reporting. Some folks have argued that we should have enforceable rules that allow us to slap tariffs on countries that devalue their currency too much. But the problem is, it's really hard to figure out why a currency is going down and whether it's actually being manipulated. And frankly, forcing other countries to make commitments about their monetary policy would mean we'd be tying the hands of our own Federal Reserve, and we're not going to do that. We have strengthened the provisions that will allow us to call out countries that we think are engaging in competitive devaluations. Finally, about the Taliban leader, Mr. Mansur, it's been confirmed that he's dead. He was the guy calling the shots, specifically targeting U.S. personnel and troops in Afghanistan. This doesn't mean we're changing our strategy. We're not going back to day-to-day combat operations. Our job is to help Afghanistan secure its own country. But when we've got a high-profile leader who's been consistently involved in operations and plans to harm U.S. personnel and who's been blocking peace talks, then it's my duty as Commander in Chief to step in and send a clear message to the Taliban that we're going to protect our people. President Quang.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, can you clarify if your remarks today contain any substantive announcements? [SEP] I think we're done here.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. A question for both Presidents. Mr. President, you said just a moment ago that Poland will join the visa waiver program soon. How soon? [SEP] We think fairly soon. We're doing very well with it. It's a complex situation, as you know. But we're getting very close. We allow very few countries to join, but Poland is one that we're thinking about allowing in. So we'll be making that decision over the next, probably, 90 days.
label: Explicit

sentence: Considering the UK's persistence in seeking Gary McKinnon's extradition, do you think his Asperger's and the potential severity of the punishment warrant a more lenient approach? And Prime Minister Cameron, could you share your current perspective on this case, especially if you discussed it with the President today? [SEP] David and I talked about it. There's an ongoing dialogue between our nations, and I don't want to prejudice that. We recognize the gravity of the hacking allegations against Gary McKinnon. Cybersecurity is an increasing threat, and we must work together on it. While traditional spying is still a concern, the biggest risks now come from breaches of our information systems. We take this very seriously, and so does the British Government. The President usually stays out of prosecution or extradition decisions. My team will follow the law but will coordinate closely with our exceptional ally. I'm confident this will be resolved in a way that emphasizes the importance of the issue and our collaborative relationship. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the leak of the Hadley memo, can you definitively state whether you or your Chief of Staff directed an inquiry before meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki? And if unauthorized, do you believe someone within your administration is deliberately sabotaging your Iraq policy or the meeting with the Prime Minister? [SEP] I'm honestly trying to remember if I specifically ordered an investigation. I don't have a clear recollection of doing so. What I do remember is being pretty annoyed about the constant leaks. You folks are good at digging up information and getting it out there, which I get. But I'm not a fan of people leaking classified stuff. It's a problem that keeps popping up, not just for us, but for any administration trying to get things done. We've had a bunch of leaks, and it's tough to find out who's doing it. There might be an investigation happening; I honestly don't know. If there is, it's not top of mind right now. But I do think it's important to hold people accountable when they leak classified information. Maybe if there were consequences, people would think twice about doing it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sir, should the drug prove successful, will you prioritize its rapid approval for use in the U.S.? [SEP] With all due respect, that's getting ahead of ourselves. I'm not in the business of making promises I can't keep. Let's get the facts first, then we can talk about next steps. Right now, it's all just talk.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you. A question for each President. President Trump—— President Trump. Yes. Q. ——you first. Just now, President Putin denied having anything to do with the election interference in 2016. Every U.S. intelligence agency has concluded that Russia did. What—who—my first question for you, sir, is, who do you believe?My second question is, would you now, with the whole world watching, tell President Putin—would you denounce what happened in 2016? And would you warn him to never do it again? [SEP] So let me just say that we have two thoughts You have groups that are wondering why the FBI never took the server Why haven't they taken the server? Why was the FBI told to leave the office of the Democratic National Committee? I've been wondering that I've been asking that for months and months, and I've been tweeting it out and calling it out on social media Where is the server? I want to know: Where is the server? And what is the server saying?With that being said, all I can do is ask the question My people came to me—Dan Coats came to me and some others—they said they think it's Russia I have President Putin; he just said it's not RussiaI will say this: I don't see any reason why it would be, but I really do want to see the server But I have—I have confidence in both parties I really believe that this will probably go on for a while, but I don't think it can go on without finding out what happened to the server What happened to the servers of the Pakistani gentleman that worked on the DNC? Where are those servers? They're missing Where are they? What happened to Hillary Clinton's e-mails? Thirty-three thousand e-mails gone—just gone I think, in Russia, they wouldn't be gone so easily I think it's a disgrace that we can't get Hillary Clinton's 33,000 e-mailsSo I have great confidence in my intelligence people, but I will tell you that President Putin was extremely strong and powerful in his denial today And what he did is an incredible offer; he offered to have the people working on the case come and work with their investigators with respect to the 12 people I think that's an incredible offerOkay? Thank you Yes, please I'd like to add something to this After all, I was an intelligence officer myself, and I do know how dossiers are made up Just a quick—just a second That's the first thingNow, the second thing: I believe that Russia is a democratic state, and I hope you're not denying this right to your own country You're not denying that United States is a democracy Do you believe the United States is a democracy? And if so, if it is a democratic state, then the final conclusion in this kind of dispute can only be delivered by a trial by the court, not by the executive—by the law enforcementFor instance, the Concord company that was brought up is being accused—it's been accused of interference But this company does not constitute the Russian state It does not represent the Russian state And I brought several examples beforeWell, you have a lot of individuals in the United States—take George Soros, for instance—with multibillion capitals, but it doesn't make him—his position, his posture—the posture of the United States? No, it does not Well, it's the same case There is the issue of trying a case in the court, and the final say is for the court to deliver We are now talking about the private—the individuals, and not about particular states And as far as the most recent allegation is concerned about the Russian intelligence officers, we do have an intergovernmental treaty Please, do send us the request We will analyze it properly, and we'll send a formal responseAnd as I said, we can extend this cooperation, but we should do it on a reciprocal basis, because we would await our Russian counterparts to provide us access to the persons of interest for us who we believe can have something to do with intelligence servicesLet's discuss the specific issues, and not use the Russia and the US relationship as a loose change—the loose change for this internal political struggle
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. And can you give us clarity, sir, on your thinking currently now, after the midterms, about your Attorney General and your Deputy Attorney General? Do they have long-term job security? [SEP] I'd rather answer that at a little bit different time. We're looking at a lot of different things, including Cabinet. I'm very happy with most of my Cabinet. We're looking at different people for different positions. You know, it's very common after the midterms. I didn't want to do anything before the midterms.But I will tell you that, for the most part, I'm extremely happy with my Cabinet. I think Mike Pompeo has fit in so beautifully. He's done an incredible job as——
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, assuming sanctions fail to modify Iran's actions, what alternative strategies, excluding military intervention, are you contemplating? [SEP] I'm not going to telegraph our next moves. But I will say this: the sanctions are biting. They're really hurting Iran. And our military is ready, willing, and able. We've invested heavily in our military, made it the strongest it's ever been. We have the best equipment, the best people. Our nuclear capabilities are second to none. We hope we never have to use them, but we're prepared. We have incredible people working on this.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics suggest the White House dragged its feet on investigating the Kavanaugh allegations initially. Given the current scrutiny, shouldn't your administration have proactively sought clarity through an independent investigation at the time? [SEP] Look, the FBI has vetted Judge Kavanaugh multiple times over the years. They know him inside and out. Furthermore, the initial allegations lacked crucial details like location, time, and year. It was a 'he said, she said' situation with no concrete leads for the FBI to pursue. Besides, as Joe Biden himself has stated, such investigations aren't typically within the FBI's purview. The Democrats are simply playing political games, knowing full well Kavanaugh's qualifications. They are attempting to smear a good man and his family for political gain. The American people see through this charade and will remember it at the ballot box. Even if the FBI had cleared Kavanaugh completely, the Democrats would have continued their obstructionist tactics. However, in states where I won by large margins, a few Democrats might break ranks and support us. But make no mistake, this is a partisan witch hunt designed to undermine my administration and divide the country.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Is there a particular reason why the summit lasted only about 3 hours? We know you had maybe allotted 4 to 5 hours. Was there any reason it ran shorter?Also, did—President Putin said that there were no threats or scare tactics issued. Do you agree with that assessment, that there were no threats or scare tactics? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering your past comments on similar matters, what is your assessment of the potential impact of Ghislaine Maxwell's testimony on other powerful figures? [SEP] Frankly, I haven't been paying much attention to it. I just wish her well. I've met her a few times, especially when I lived in Palm Beach. As for Prince Andrew, I really don't know anything about it. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given the strong feelings in the UK regarding Gary McKinnon's extradition, and considering Prime Minister Cameron's concerns, is there any room for leniency in this case? [SEP] This matter has been discussed. The British and Americans are in discussion about this, and I don't want to prejudice those discussions. We understand that Gary McKinnon stands accused of a crime, hacking into vital databases. But I have had conversations with the U.S. Ambassador, as well as raising it today with the President, about this issue, and I hope a way through can be found. One of the things that David and I discussed was the increasing challenge that we're going to face as a consequence of the Internet and the need for us to cooperate extensively on issues of cybersecurity. The President doesn't get involved in decisions around prosecutions, extradition matters. So what I expect is that my team will follow the law, but they will also coordinate closely with what we've just stated is an ally that is unparalleled in terms of our cooperative relationship. And I trust that this will get resolved in a way that underscores the seriousness of the issue, but also underscores the fact that we work together and we can find an appropriate solution.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: With all due respect, Mr. President, many find Ms. Greene's views deeply troubling. Can you explicitly disavow the QAnon conspiracy theory and distance yourself from anyone who promotes it? [SEP] We have a lot of people in the Republican Party, and we're a big tent. We have people with a lot of different opinions. Marjorie is one of them, and she's entitled to her opinions. She's a fighter, and we need fighters.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the withdrawal of Canada and South Korea, are you worried about international support for the war in Afghanistan, and are the additional U.S. troops sufficient to end the conflict? [SEP] Well, I've always deferred to our military commanders for recommendations on achieving our objectives. We've added troops twice during my presidency, and the Obama administration plans to continue that. This is what our generals advise. This is a long struggle; ideological battles take time. As civil society and political institutions develop, extremism diminishes. I can't specify troop levels, but our generals say this is what we need now, and I trust President-elect Obama will listen to them as well. We appreciate the assistance from nations helping Afghanistan, including Canada. Their withdrawal plans don't contradict our understanding. They'll continue to assist in other ways. It's crucial to fight terrorism and strengthen Afghanistan with an improved economy and governance, enabling them to stand on their own. The Afghan people don't want to be a burden forever. We're grateful for the international community's support. The Taliban was brutalizing the Afghan people and are no longer in power. Girls are returning to school, boys are flying kites, health clinics are opening, and universities are expanding. The Taliban wants to regain power and can't stand a free society. They're lethal, but that doesn't mean we withdraw. It's in the U.S.'s interest to prevent Afghanistan from becoming a safe haven for Al Qaida again. Al Qaida is weakened, but we'll stay on the hunt. Conditions in Afghanistan are much better than in 2001.
label: Implicit

sentence: President, concerning the COVID-19 response, many are wondering why Dr. Fauci and Dr. Birx are not present today. Can you address their absence? [SEP] They're an important part of the team, a very important part. But they're focusing on other aspects of the response right now. We have a lot of talented people working on this, and we're all working together.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And do you think that execution and the flaws in the rollout will affect your ability to do other things, like immigration reform and other policy priorities? [SEP] Well, look, if it comes to immigration reform, there is no reason for us not to do immigration reform. And we've already got strong bipartisan support for immigration reform out of the Senate. You've got—I met with a number of traditionally very conservative clergy who are deeply committed to immigration reform. We've got the business community entirely behind immigration reform. So you've got a bunch of constituencies that are traditionally much more—have leaned much more heavily towards the Republicans who are behind this.So if people are looking for an excuse not to do the right thing on immigration reform, they can always find an excuse: We've run out of time, or this is hard, or—the list goes on and on. But my working assumption is people should want to do the right thing. And when you've got an issue that would strengthen borders, make sure that the legal immigration system works the way it's supposed to, that would go after employers who have been doing the wrong thing when it comes to hiring undocumented workers and would allow folks who are here illegally to get right with the law and pay a fine and learn English and get to the back of the line, but ultimately join fully our American community—when you've got a law that makes sense, you shouldn't be looking for an excuse not to do it. And I'm going to keep on pushing to make sure it gets done.Am I going to have to do some work to rebuild confidence around some of our initiatives? Yes. But part of this job is the things that go right, you guys aren't going to write about; the things that go wrong get prominent attention. That's how it has always been. That's not unique to me as President. And I'm up to the challenge. We're going to get this done.All right? Thank you, everybody.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your meeting with Prime Minister Najib, you stated you would raise concerns about corruption and human rights. What specific message did you convey about the 1MDB scandal and the jailing of political opponents? [SEP] Let's talk about the refugee program first. Paris happened just a week ago. The news cycle is so fast that we sometimes lose sight of events. The Paris attacks were recent and pervasive in the news, and people are understandably concerned given the similarities between Paris and many American cities. That's why the House acted quickly. I hope that now that we have some time to reflect, people will understand that refugees coming to the United States are the most thoroughly vetted individuals. The process, developed over several administrations on a bipartisan basis, is extraordinarily thorough and takes 18 to 24 months for approval. The House legislation, while seemingly simple, could effectively halt the refugee program if it becomes too bureaucratic. Adding layers of bureaucracy that don't improve screening but make processing impossible would be detrimental. When I spoke of betraying our values, I was referring to suggestions of prioritizing Christian refugees over Muslims, or fearing a 4-year-old orphan. Those of you who saw the children at the refugee center understand who we're talking about. If you're a parent and you saw those children, you'd understand that we need to find them a home in America. Most people, knowing the screening process, would agree. Regarding Prime Minister Najib, I don't comment on investigations in the United States, and I certainly won't comment on foreign investigations. However, I did raise the importance of transparency, accountability, and rooting out corruption with Prime Minister Najib, as I have with leaders in Southeast Asia, Africa, and Latin America. These are impediments to development and contribute to poverty and stunted growth. Countries that solve these problems will thrive, regardless of resources or geography. I also emphasized the importance of civil society and a free press. Countries are at different stages of development, and we don't expect everyone to follow the same path as the United States. But some basic principles are important for us to uphold as friends and partners. Take Myanmar, which just had a historic election after 40 years of military rule. They won't be Sweden overnight, but there's a sea change taking place, and we want to encourage that. Our work through the Open Government Partnership and TPP is designed to raise the bar. Some will progress, some will regress, but the trajectory is towards a world where ordinary people are treated fairly, there's rule of law, transparency, accountable governments, people's voices are heard, women are treated equally, and minorities are not discriminated against. These are American values, but also universal values. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, Clinton claims the FBI cost her the election. Her campaign chair says the investigation was initially sluggish. Your perspective? [SEP] Transitions are always messy. Feelings are still strong. But when Trump assumes office, he'll have different obligations. The Oval Office is a reality check. I've had respectful conversations with the President-elect, offering suggestions on maintaining the office's effectiveness. He's listened. I don't know if he'll act on them, but the talks have been respectful. I'll always be available to him. About the FBI, I know Comey and many agents. They're dedicated professionals. It's challenging when law enforcement interacts with politics. We want them independent, but investigations sometimes involve politics. I've been meticulous about not interfering in investigations. I won't start now.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Lee, in light of North Korea's planned missile test, what steps will South Korea take, and can you provide an update on the discussions with the U.S. concerning the extension of South Korea's missile range? [SEP] Let me be clear: If proceeds with its launch, it will be in direct violation of UN Security Council resolutions. The international community is united in urging them to reconsider. If they proceed, they will be solely responsible for the consequences, leading to further isolation. The people of will recognize that their leader is prioritizing a missile launch over their own well-being. While they may hope to achieve some domestic goal, they will find themselves in a challenging situation. I urge them to act as a responsible member of the international community. As for the missile range, we did not discuss it directly, but working-level officials are engaged in discussions as part of our broader efforts to strengthen our defense capabilities against . We will remain calm and rational in our approach.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, regarding human rights violations and drug trafficking in Mexico, will you certify Mexico? How will the Merida Initiative proceed? What about threats against President Calderon, the visa problem, and the overall security situation? [SEP] I'm not sure I understood the translation correctly. It sounded like a good question, though. Let's try that again.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning your upcoming discussion with President Putin, what will be your guiding principles? Furthermore, considering the evolving dynamics of the Ukrainian conflict, do you assess President Zelenskyy's insistence on the return of Crimea as a prerequisite for negotiations to be a feasible stance? [SEP] The straightforward resolution to this conflict involves Putin's complete withdrawal from Ukraine. However, he appears unwilling to concede, despite the significant repercussions and the devastation he's causing. I currently have no immediate intentions of engaging with Mr. Putin. I am open to discussions if he demonstrates a genuine desire to seek a resolution to the conflict, in coordination with our allied partners. As of now, he has not done so. It is imperative that we continue to support the Ukrainian people. The notion that Putin could prevail over Ukraine is simply inconceivable. He has fundamentally misjudged the situation. He anticipated a warm reception from the Russian-speaking segments of the Ukrainian populace. Review his address at the time of the invasion. He aspired to emulate Peter the Great. He emphasized the significance of Kyiv as the cradle of Russian identity. He has been mistaken on all fronts. Therefore, the pertinent question is, how does he extricate himself from this predicament? I am prepared, should he be amenable to dialogue, to ascertain his intentions, but only in collaboration with our NATO allies. I will not proceed unilaterally. Regarding your inquiry concerning the preconditions established by the Ukrainian President, I believe it is crucial for us to acknowledge that, as Ukraine continues to resist, enduring war crimes and attacks on its civilian infrastructure while simultaneously launching a counteroffensive, President Zelenskyy has presented a comprehensive 10-point peace plan. I firmly believe that we must maintain our engagement with him, as Ukraine exhibits a genuine commitment to addressing these matters. We recognize and commend this commitment. For several years, I was responsible for overseeing the implementation of the Minsk Agreements. During the most recent meeting between President Zelenskyy and President Putin, the only one of its kind, which took place in December 2019, I was accompanied by Chancellor Merkel. I can attest to the fact that I witnessed a President who was genuinely sincere in his willingness to engage in dialogue and negotiations. From the time of his election until May, President Zelenskyy consistently demonstrated a strong desire to engage in discussions and negotiations. It was President Putin who harbored the desire to initiate and wage war. I personally observed this, including during my visits to Russia and Ukraine in early February. Consequently, it is entirely reasonable for President Zelenskyy to establish certain conditions for negotiations. We must work towards identifying the elements that could pave the way for a peace accord, but it is ultimately his prerogative to inform us when the time is right and to articulate the choices available to the Ukrainian people. Having stated this, I will continue to engage with President Putin. In fact, we addressed this matter this morning with President Biden, as we consistently strive to prevent escalation and achieve tangible outcomes. I will engage with him regarding the security and safety of nuclear facilities in the contested regions, particularly Zaporizhzhia. Over the past several months, we have undertaken efforts at the Chernobyl nuclear plant, and Mr. Grossi and his agency, the IAEA, are continuing important work. Thank you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the communique's call for unprecedented cooperation on a voluntary basis, what concrete assurances do you have that nations historically at odds will genuinely commit? How will this cooperation be monitored and enforced? [SEP] Well, consider the case of Ukraine. For ten years, we've been pushing them to either ship out their highly enriched uranium or convert it to a less potent form. Thanks in part to this very conference, Ukraine has pledged to complete this process within the next couple of years. All the commitments we're discussing are already in motion, even before the communique and work plan are finalized. This shows a strong, unified understanding of the global threat. We also have a framework of international conventions, though some, including those addressing nuclear terrorism and trafficking, still await ratification, even by the U.S. This summit establishes an ambitious plan, and I'm heartened by the progress we're seeing on efforts that have been stalled for years, some since the end of the Cold War.
label: General

sentence: How did those past experiences inform your views on the allegations surrounding Judge Kavanaugh? [SEP] It certainly impacts my thinking. I've personally dealt with many false accusations, being a prominent figure. People are motivated by fame or money. My perspective is different from someone watching from home. I know others who've faced false accusations. I had a woman claim I attacked her on a plane, a complete fabrication. So, when I consider Judge Kavanaugh's situation, it resonates because I've been through it. The news about those four individuals being apprehended was significant.
label: General

sentence: Q. Do you—sorry—do you believe, though, it's possible we could have troops there next year? [SEP] I can't picture that being the case.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, Shanghai Media Group is curious: when can we expect the next meeting? Imminent, or further down the road? [SEP] Your guess is as good as mine. It might happen soon, it might not be for ages. I can't really tell you. I'd like it to be soon, but who knows?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, Prime Minister Cameron, regarding BP and the Lockerbie bomber: Prime Minister, have you ruled out a government investigation into the bomber's release? President Obama, would you support a congressional investigation, or would that complicate matters? [SEP] Let me begin. Like everyone in the U.S., I was surprised, disappointed, and frankly, angered by the release of the Lockerbie bomber. My administration voiced our objections both before and after the decision. We welcome any information that sheds light on why that decision was made. The crucial point is that Prime Minister Cameron shares our anger and objects to how it unfolded. I fully support his efforts to understand and clarify the situation. We all disagreed with the decision; it was a mistake. This should inform our approach to counterterrorism moving forward. It's vital to remember the incredibly strong counterterrorism ties between our countries. Our cooperation is unparalleled and keeps people safe on both sides of the Atlantic. While we're concerned about the bomber's release, we must maintain and strengthen our existing cooperation to prevent future attacks like Lockerbie.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, Germany is advocating for renewed efforts by the Middle East Quartet. Critics argue that European powers have limited influence over a superpower like the United States. Can you provide an example of a time when a conversation with a European leader changed your perspective? And Mrs. Merkel, given the Quartet's limited successes, were the efforts inadequate, or are the problems simply too complex to overcome? What does this imply for future endeavors? [SEP] Well, I wouldn't say 'changed my mind,' but I listen to my European friends. They have valuable insights. For example, they've helped me understand the importance of the United Nations. I don't always agree with them, but I respect their opinions. And Angela Merkel is a very wise woman. I value her advice.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Sir, are you aware if he was formally invited to attend? [SEP] That's a granular detail that's frankly beneath my pay grade. I'm sure someone in the scheduling office can provide that information, but it's not something I'm personally involved in.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the violence in Delhi and the amended citizenship law, what assurances did Prime Minister Modi provide concerning religious freedom, and what's your level of concern about the situation? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, the Prime Minister, he's a terrific guy, a real leader. We had a fantastic discussion about religious freedom. He assured me, and I believe him, that India is committed to religious freedom. They're working hard, very hard, to ensure it. Now, about the violence, I'm aware of it, but it's really an internal matter for India. I trust they'll handle it appropriately. As for the details, I haven't been following it closely, frankly, because I've been so busy with important meetings.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering Prime Minister Netanyahu's apparent reversal on Palestinian statehood, what concrete steps could he take to convince you of his sincerity in pursuing a two-state solution? Is there a point of no return in repairing that relationship during your presidency? And President Ghani, regarding Afghanistan, what are the key obstacles to reconciliation with the Taliban, and how can the U.S. best support your efforts? [SEP] Let me be clear, I won't discuss intelligence matters in this forum. Regarding Prime Minister Netanyahu, the issue isn't my personal feelings. It's about creating a viable path forward for both Israelis and Palestinians. He needs to demonstrate a genuine commitment to that process. As for Afghanistan, I defer to President Ghani's expertise on that matter.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, thank you. You mentioned closing remaining gaps in State and Federal government regarding matters of race. How does criminal justice reform align with this goal, and what specific gaps remain for you to address? Additionally, what is the significance of your upcoming trip to Kenya, your father's homeland, as President of the United States? Finally, will you consider revoking Bill Cosby's Medal of Freedom? [SEP] April, that's a lot to unpack. I'm going to pass on that question for now.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Sir, can you take a question from the international media? [SEP] From where?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with 30,000 Russian troops reportedly amassed on the Ukrainian border, what assurances can you give to the people of Eastern Ukraine, the Baltics, Moldova, and other nations that they won't be next on Putin's annexation list? And is the situation in Crimea a done deal, or is there still a chance Putin might give it back, or is this just muscle-flexing to prevent further land grabs? [SEP] On Crimea, it's not a done deal, because most countries don't recognize that Russia took it. Russia's in control, and some people there are okay with it. We're not going to kick them out by force. We're using the law, talking, putting pressure on them, and using sanctions. But there's no easy fix. History can change in weird ways. How things go in Crimea depends on everyone sticking together and saying what Russia did was wrong. About the troops near Ukraine, they're in Russia. We don't like them trying to scare people, but they can have troops on their own land. Russia's still thinking things over. What they do depends on whether the US, Europe, and the rest of the world stand together and say this isn't how we solve problems now. We need to stop saying that Russian speakers in Ukraine are in danger to justify what Russia's doing. There's no proof of that. Some people are stirring up trouble. Comparing it to Kosovo, where people were being killed, is crazy. We need to get rid of any excuses for Russia to act. For countries near Russia that aren't in NATO, like Ukraine, we're putting pressure on, shining a light on what's happening, and helping their economies. NATO countries are protected by Article 5. We're making our plans even better. NATO will talk more about this soon. NATO members are standing strong. For countries that aren't in NATO, we're helping them with talking and money.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify, when can Americans realistically anticipate widespread access? [SEP] The distribution will be immediate, as soon as we can. It's going to be very fast. The fastest you've ever seen.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, what is your understanding of the timeline for Israel's suspension of the West Bank annexation plan? [SEP] What's your take on it? Tell me what you think. We're focusing all our efforts on achieving peace. We've reached an agreement with the Emirates, and we're working out the details – embassies, overflights, commerce. We plan to extend this to the entire region. I can't say how long it will take. We've prioritized peace over the sovereignty movement, but it's not off the table. It's simply postponed to give peace a chance.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, addressing the serious issues of human rights abuses and the drug-related violence plaguing Mexico, particularly in light of the Merida Initiative, what is your administration's stance on certifying Mexico's compliance? Additionally, what steps are being taken to mitigate the threats against President Calderon's safety, and to resolve the persistent visa difficulties? [SEP] Unfortunately, the translation was a bit garbled. It sounded like a truly excellent question, though. Would you mind restating it for the benefit of full understanding?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Yes. Both countries have spoken about the challenge of climate change. But there is a view that ambitious targets are set, but implementation is found often lacking. And there is also a criticism of lack of technological transfer, financial transfer from the developed countries to the developing nations.How do you both leaders see the way ahead on this pressing issue? [SEP] Well, first of all, I think it is the existential threat to humanity: climate change. It's the most serious problem we face as human beings. We have to keep it below 1.5 degrees Celsius. We've made enormous progress here in the United States on dealing with this issue by doing three things.Number one, by insisting that we move our—every one of our industries into a position where they can take advantage of cheaper and more extensive and more available renewable energy, whether it's solar or wind or hydrogen and green hydrogen. There's a whole range of things we've been working on.In addition to that, we find ourselves in a position that—what we've done is that we have significantly reduced the—for example, I made a commitment that we are going to make sure that by 2030, 30 percent of all our land and sea and oceans were—are—were in conservation, could not be developed. We're well on our way to doing that. And that's also absorbing carbon from the air as a consequence of that, because of the conservation.We are in a position, as well, by—we have provided for significant increase in funding for a whole range of issues, but not just for the United States, but for the rest of the world.For example, we're working with the G-7 to provide for infrastructure work for dealing with global warming on the continent of Africa: in Angola, building the largest solar project; moving ourselves—having railway to go all the way across the southern two-thirds—the—from the Atlantic Ocean to the Indian Ocean, in Africa, to be able to transport and do it cheaper and do it with less—how can I say it?—less carbon emissions.We're trying to work with other countries to maintain their carbon sinks so they don't have to develop them like we did and causing pollution. And we're trying to figure out how to work out to pay them not to develop certain areas, like the Amazon in Brazil.But there's a lot of technology that's available that we're sharing, and we share with one another. We've learned how to do solar energy, which is considerably cheaper than it is to—for fuel—for fossil fuels. The same way dealing with not just solar, but dealing with wind.And so there's a lot of the technology that we've developed. And we're well on our way, I think, to meeting the commitment we made to—that we made in Paris. And I—and we're prepared to share all of that with India, that has a desire to do the same. Excellency, you said very rightly that, as far as India is concerned, the environment, climate, these are extremely important in our cultural traditions. For us, the environment is an article of faith. This is not just something that we need to do for convenience; we believe this.We do not believe in the exploitation of nature. In order for all of creation to work, we can make nature—but we cannot have exploitation of nature, and we have always believed this.And on the basis of these values, we are not only doing things for ourselves, but are taking some global initiatives, as well. You perhaps know that the G-20 countries, the promises they made in Paris, of all the G-20 countries, India is the only country that has fulfilled all the promises it made at the G-20.Not just that, in the area of solar energy, in Glasgow, we had set ourselves a target to achieve 500 gigawatts of renewable energy. By 2030, we have set ourselves a target to make Indian railways net zero.And you must understand the scale of Indian railways. When we talk about Indian railways, it means that every day the entire population of Australia travels in our wagons—in our railway wagons, on our trains. And we have set ourselves a target to achieve net zero for our railways.We have also set ourselves targets for solar energy, for ethanol—10 percent mix of ethanol. We have completed this target before the set date.We are also working in the area of green hydrogen. We want India to be a green hydrogen hub, and we are working towards this.In—and the International Solar Alliance has been launched by India, and many countries have joined it and are working with India. The island countries, we have helped them in the area of solar energy so that they have now got a new confidence that we are with them in their efforts to fight climate change. And we will not only fulfill our responsibilities, but we will also help you in the area of climate change.We have seen that due to natural calamities—people talk about the death of people, no doubt, when there are natural disasters, but there is a lot of destruction of infrastructure as well.And therefore, because of climate change, the kind of crisis we are feeling, we need to develop infrastructure that is resilient. And therefore, we have created a global organization called CDRI. And you perhaps know that in Glasgow I presented a subject to the world. And recently, it was launched by the U.N. Secretary General and myself. That is Mission LiFE. And when I say LiFE, I mean Lifestyle for the Environment. Therefore, every individual must live his life in a pro-environment, pro-development way. And we are working towards this.And I am sure that whatever work India has started in all these areas—not because India has adversely affected the environment of the world; we are doing this because we have a concern for future generations. We do not want to give our future generations a world that make life difficult for them.And therefore, as a global responsibility, India has not caused any problems to the environment. However, we are playing a leading role in contributing in a positive manner.As far as prosperous countries are concerned, there's always been talk about technology transfer, financial support, and there are some countries that need to have technology transfer, financial support. And we hope that as soon as we can move forward in this area, we will be able to solve this challenge of climate change. Thank you very much. Let me add one thing. We have caused damage in the United States the way we developed over the last 300 years. And that's why I was able to convince my colleagues in the Congress to pass legislation—the largest climate fund ever in American—in the world history: $369 billion—$369 billion—to deal with the climate crisis.And we are doing it extensively now, and I think you're going to see significant progress.Thank you all very, very much.[]
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Will there be a meeting with Rouhani? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, besides canceling the summit, what other sticks are you considering to use against Russia? [SEP] Look, the summit thing wasn't just about Snowden, okay? It was about a bigger picture of no progress on important stuff. So, it's not just a punishment. We're going to see where we can work with Russia to help America and make the world a better place. Where we don't agree, we'll be clear about it. Hopefully, Putin will get that working together is better than fighting, for both of us.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to the capture of Mr. al-Libi, some legal scholars argue that such actions, regardless of the target's alleged crimes, undermine the rule of law. What's your perspective? [SEP] My perspective is that we have a responsibility to protect the American people from those who would do us harm. We will use all lawful means at our disposal to do so. And that includes bringing terrorists to justice, no matter where they are. I'm not going to apologize for that.
label: General

sentence: Q. Sir, just to reiterate, should the NHS be part of these trade negotiations? [SEP] Pardon? I didn't quite catch that.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. You have spoken passionately about the consequences of failure in Iraq. Your critics say you failed to send enough troops there at the start, failed to keep Al Qaida from stepping into the void created by the collapse of Saddam's army, failed to put enough pressure on Iraq's Government to make the political reconciliation necessary to keep the sectarian violence the country is suffering from now from occurring. So why should the American people feel you have the vision for victory in Iraq, sir? [SEP] Those are all legitimate questions that I'm sure historians will analyze. I mean, one of the questions is, should we have sent more in the beginning? Well, I asked that question, Do you need more? to General Tommy Franks. In the first phase of this operation, General Franks was obviously in charge—and during our discussions in the runup to the decision to remove Saddam Hussein after he ignored the Security Council resolutions. My primary question to General Franks was, do you have what it takes to succeed? And do you have what it takes to succeed after you succeed in removing Saddam Hussein? And his answer was, yes.Now, history is going to look back to determine whether or not there might have been a different decision made. But at the time, the only thing I can tell you, Wendell, is that I relied upon our military commander to make the proper decision about troop strength. And I can remember a meeting with the Joint Chiefs, who said, We've reviewed the plan. I remember— and seemed satisfied with it. I remember sitting in the PEOC, or the Situation Room, downstairs here at the White House, and I went to commander and commander that were all responsible of different aspects of the operation to remove Saddam. I said to each one of them, do you have what it takes? Are you satisfied with the strategy? And the answer was, yes.We have worked hard to help this country reconcile. After all, they do have a modern Constitution, which is kind of a framework for reconciliation. And after all, there was a significant series of votes where the people were given a chance to express their desire to live in a free society. As a matter of fact, 12 million Iraqis went to the polls.Wendell, what happened then, of course, is that the enemy, Al Qaida, attacks the Samarra mosque, which, of course, created anxiety and anger amongst the Shi'a. And then all of a sudden, the sectarian violence began to spiral. Reconciliation hadn't taken hold deep enough in society to prevent this violence from taking hold. And so I have a—you know, I've got to decide whether or not it's okay for that violence to continue or whether or not it makes sense for us to try to send more troops in to quell the violence, to give the reconciliation process further time to advance.My concern is, is that as a result of violence and killing, there would be chaos. Now, that's a state of affairs that thugs like Al Qaida need to survive. They like chaos. As a matter of fact, they like to create chaos in order to create conditions of fear and anxiety and doubt. And out of that chaos would come—could come a further escalation of violence in the Middle East. And this is what's important for the American people to understand: that violence and that chaos would embolden extremist groups, whether they be Shi'a or Sunni, and they would then begin into competition with each other.Such chaos and violence would send a mixed signal to the Iranians, who have stated that they believe Israel ought to be wiped off the map. People would begin to wonder about America's resolve. Al Qaida would certainly be in a better position to raise money and recruit. And what makes all this scenario doubly dangerous is that they have proven themselves able to attack us and kill nearly 3,000 of our citizens. And they would like to do it again.And therefore, the strategy has got to be to help this Government become an ally against these people. What happens in Iraq—and I understand how difficult it's been. It's been hard. I have received a lot of inspiration, however, from meeting with our troops, who understand the stakes of this fight, and meeting with their families. And we owe it to our troops to support our commanders, smart, capable people who are devising a strategy that will enable us to succeed and prevent the conditions I just talked about from happening.Ed [Edwin Chen, Bloomberg News]— no, Jon. Just kidding there.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. You think they'll ultimately give ground on that? [SEP] My expectation is that they'll do the responsible thing.Chuck Todd [NBC News].
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, if North Korea fails to uphold its commitments, are you contemplating military action as a possible consequence? [SEP] Well, I don't want to talk about—yes, I know. That's a tough thing to talk about because I don't want to be threatening. I don't want to be threatening. They understood that. And you've seen what was, perhaps, going to happen.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with Netanyahu's admission of the Israeli strike in Syria, could you shed light on the nature of the target, your administration's stance on the operation, and its broader implications for the already volatile dynamics involving Syria, Iran, and Israel? Furthermore, what measures are in place to prevent the U.S. from being drawn into the conflict? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to discuss the specifics of that situation. Let's move on.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, on Afghanistan, do you believe the Pakistan-brokered talks between the Taliban and President Karzai hold promise, or do they concern you? And do you agree with Prime Minister Cameron that we can be totally out of Afghanistan by 2015? [SEP] I'm not sure about that Cameron quote, but let me address the second part first. We've been in Afghanistan for nine years, soon to be a decade. It's our longest war. We all want Afghanistan to be stable, self-sufficient on security, and not a base for attacks against the U.S. We'll need to assist Afghanistan for a long time, helping them build a government, courts, police, and a fair political system. But that's different from having troops on the ground. Our policy, announced last November, involves sending in additional troops to give the Afghan government space to build its security forces, blunt the Taliban, and improve governance. General Petraeus is continuing this policy, endorsed by our allies and President Karzai. It's a tough challenge, given Afghanistan's poverty, illiteracy, and history of war. By the end of this year, we expect to see progress. We'll review and adjust as needed, both on the civilian and military sides. Ultimately, like in Iraq, we need a political solution. As for the negotiations, it's too early to tell. We should be skeptical but open. The Taliban is a mix of ideologues, tribal leaders, and recruits. President Karzai's peace jirga and the Kabul conference are useful steps, as are talks between Afghanistan and Pakistan. We need regional players to recognize that a stable Afghanistan-Pakistan region is in everyone's interest. Next question?
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning entitlements, Social Security privatization is a key Democratic concern. Are you willing to compromise or adjust your agenda on this issue to foster bipartisanship, given its importance to the Democratic Party? [SEP] I've instructed Ken Paulson to tell the Members that we're open to hearing everyone's ideas. I presented my ideas, as you may recall, in the last State of the Union. We want to hear their ideas. Hopefully, by bringing people together to share their approaches, we can find common ground and tell the American people that we've helped solve this problem.But this is a tough issue. I understand how hard it is. People are generally risk-averse when it comes to Social Security. The problem is, the longer we wait, the more difficult the issue becomes. Some will keep pushing it, and hopefully, we can get something done.Richard [Richard Wolffe, Newsweek].
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, some are suggesting his absence signals a lack of commitment. How do you respond? [SEP] I wouldn't jump to conclusions. I'm sure he had a perfectly valid reason. I just don't know what it was.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, shifting gears, you've spoken about closing racial gaps. How does criminal justice reform play into that? What gaps remain? And what's the significance of your trip to Kenya? Also, will you strip Bill Cosby of his Medal of Freedom? [SEP] Wow, April, you packed a lot into that question. Look...
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Francis Elliott, the Times. Prime Minister, I wonder whether you agree with the President of the United States that immigration has damaged the cultural fabric of Europe. And, President, perhaps you could elaborate on that remark. What do you mean by that? [SEP] You want me to go?. Do you want to go first? I think it's been very bad for Europe. I think Europe is a place I know very well, and I think that what has happened is very tough. It's a very tough situation. I mean, you see the same terror attacks that I do. We see them a lot. We just left some incredible young men—men and women—at Sandhurst. And they were showing us cells, and they were showing us things that, frankly, 20 years ago nobody even thought about. Probably a lot more recently than that, nobody even thought about.I just think it's changing the culture. I think it's a very negative thing for Europe. I think it's very negative. I think having Germany—and I have a great relationship with Angela Merkel. Great relationship with Germany. But I think that's very much hurt Germany. I think it's very much hurt other parts of Europe.And I know it's politically—not necessarily—correct to say that. But I'll say it, and I'll say it loud. And I think they better watch themselves because you are changing culture. You are changing a lot of things. You're changing security. You're changing—look at what's happening. I mean, you take a look. I mean, look at what's happening to different countries that never had difficulty, never had problems.It's a very sad situation. It's very unfortunate. But I do not think it's good for Europe, and I don't think it's good for our country. We're, as you know, far superior to anything that's happened before, but we have very bad immigration laws, and we're—I mean, we're doing incredibly well considering the fact that we virtually don't have immigration laws. We have laws that are so bad, I don't even call them laws. I call them—it's just like, you just walk across the border. You walk across the border—you put one foot on the land and now you're tied up in a lawsuit for 5 years. It's the craziest thing anyone has ever seen.So I would just make that recommendation to Europe. I've made it very loud and clear. I made it yesterday in—29 countries total. And that's the way I feel.. The U.K. has a proud history of welcoming people who are fleeing persecution to our country. We have a proud history of welcoming people who want to come to our country to contribute to our economy and contribute to our society. And over the years, overall, immigration has been good for the U.K. It's brought people with different backgrounds, different outlooks here to the U.K. and has—and we've seen them contributing to our society and to our economy.Of course, what is important is that we have control of our borders. What is important is that we have a set of rules that enables us to determine who comes into our country. And of course, that is what, as a government, we have been doing for a number of years and will be able to continue to do in the future.Mr. President. /North Atlantic Treaty Organization/Russia-U.S. Relations/Poisoning of Former Russian Intelligence Operative Sergei Viktorovich Skripal in Salisbury, United Kingdom
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you give us a concrete date for when this will be resolved? [SEP] I wish I could give you a precise timeline, but I simply don't know at this moment.

sentence: On TikTok, the Commerce Department has seemingly granted you time to finalize a deal post-election. Do you anticipate a resolution before or after the election? sentence: Mr. President, concerning Prime Minister Maliki, are there any specific timelines for accomplishing these goals? You keep mentioning the U.S.'s focus on fighting Al Qaeda. Does that mean you believe it's solely up to the Iraqis to resolve the sectarian violence, and that U.S. forces won't be involved in suppressing it? And, Prime Minister Maliki, could you please clarify the reason for the cancellation of last night's meeting? [SEP] Could you repeat the initial part of your question, please?

sentence: Mr. President, how will you gauge Iran's sincerity in returning to nuclear talks, and what consequences will Iran face if it continues attacks against the U.S., such as the recent drone strikes in Syria?
