label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Is that a source of worry for you? [SEP] I've already commented on that extensively. Let's move on. Mary Bruce from ABC News, your turn.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: In your view, is a direct conversation with the Iranian leadership a viable option? [SEP] So, to ensure I understand correctly, you're asking if I foresee the possibility of direct discussions with Iranian officials, is that accurate?

sentence: Given the bipartisan opposition to comprehensive immigration reform, can you elaborate on your strategy to overcome congressional resistance and address the holdup in the Senate? [SEP] Well, the reason a consensus bill hasn't emerged in the Senate is because this is a complex issue requiring bipartisan cooperation. It's crucial to first establish a coherent Republican position in the Senate, which is where we're currently focusing our efforts. Senator Kennedy will lead the bill on the Democrat side. Once we achieve a unified Republican stance, one that most Republicans support, we'll collaborate with the Senator. Without sufficient consensus, nothing will pass the Senate, and consequently, nothing will happen in the House. Therefore, the initial stages of crafting a bill that addresses concerns are time-consuming but essential to address the issues raised during the last immigration reform debate. I'm optimistic that we can achieve something, and we're beginning to find common ground. There's broad agreement on a temporary-worker plan allowing individuals to legally come to the U.S. for jobs Americans aren't doing. This would greatly benefit Guatemalan citizens, eliminating the need to enter the country illegally, pay smugglers, or live in hiding. They'd be able to enter legally. Secondly, they'd be able to return home to their families legally, without fear. There would be a time limit, which is part of the negotiations. The difficult issue is what to do with those who've been in our country for an extended period. This is a sensitive issue with significant political implications. Automatic citizenship is unacceptable to many in our country. The challenge is to design a system that alleviates these concerns.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia and the leadership transition there, specifically concerning Medvedev and Putin, what's your take on the power dynamics, and what advice would you give your successor, considering past criticisms of your own judgment of Putin? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to pretend I'm an expert on the inner workings of Russian politics. It's more important to see who shows up at international summits, that's where you get your clues. I can't give you a definitive answer right now. What I will say is, we have to keep talking to Russia. We need their help on things like stopping nuclear weapons from spreading and dealing with Iran. I thought Putin's idea about Iran's nuclear fuel was smart. Also, we need to find a way for them to understand that our missile defense system in Europe isn't pointed at them, but at real dangers. So, my advice to the next guy is: keep the lines open, even when you disagree. It's what's best for the country.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. A question to President Duda. Mr. President, so far, we have been talking about a rotational presence of U.S. troops in our country. Right now we are talking about permanent or enduring presence. What does that mean in concrete terms? And when can we expect those additional U.S. troops to arrive? [SEP] I understand it in the follow way: President Donald Trump and myself are implementing a very calm but consistent policy in terms of security. The presence of the United States in Poland—the military presence—the presence of U.S. troops, which today is about 4,500 troops present on a permanent basis. In other words, it is a rotational presence but it is back-to-back presence. So there is no moment where there are no American troops in the territory of Poland.And today we signed a document and further cooperation: a Joint Declaration on Defense Cooperation Regarding the United States Force Posture in the Republic of Poland. This is of a breakthrough character because it moves us to another era. So far, we can say that the Americans were testing the situation in Poland: how it looks, how it feels; what about logistics; whether it is possible to stay in Poland and to successfully attain the goals and implement the tasks of defensive nature.I think that the commanders of U.S. Army are convinced that this is simply possible. And today, the documents speaks about this enduring presence, the presence which is a fact and which will stay there.It is a rotational presence as it is because this is most beneficial from today's perspective to train soldiers through rotational presence. By having rotational presence, more soldiers can come to a country, be present there, look at a culture and the condition in place in a given country. So this is beneficial for this barely understood—a development of the Armed Forces. Therefore, this is an enduring presence. However, it is implementing this particular way.And we hope it's going to develop 1,000 troops, mentioned by President Trump today, which is also—the numbers stipulated in the agreement signed today is very differentiated. It is not one single unit. We are talking about special operation forces. We are talking about logistics component. We are also talking about the already-mentioned division headquarters.So there is a multitude of forums in which the United States is going to be gradually ever-more present in our territory, from the military standpoint. And this will encompass different fields of cooperation. So we're not talking about just one single beat, but we're talking about a more comprehensive cooperation. We're talking about logistics health protection for soldiers and a number of other elements happening. Please remember that right now there is this missile defense facility being built in Redzikowo. So, talking about the elements of Polish-American cooperation, there are more and more of these elements, and the number is growing. I'm very happy with that. Thank you very much. Let's see, who do I like? [] Nobody. That's the end. []Go ahead. Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the intelligence agencies have assessed that Russia is actively working to undermine Mr. Biden's campaign, while China is considering actions to harm your chances. How do you assess the veracity of these claims, and what actions will you take to safeguard the integrity of the election? [SEP] Well, you know, these intelligence agencies, they have their own agenda, frankly. But let me tell you, Russia knows I'm the best for America, and China, they're terrified of me because I'm the only one who can beat them at their own game. So, if they're meddling, it's only because they know I'm winning.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, is there any room for further negotiation on your proposed budget, or is this your definitive position? [SEP] Look, this package is balanced, period. We've made significant spending cuts, hard choices across the board. By any standard, even the GOP's, this is a massive deficit reduction, the largest in 20 years. Combine that with increased revenue from the wealthy paying a bit more, and we stabilize the debt for a decade. But the Speaker wants to protect tax cuts for the rich, raise taxes on the middle class, and avoid any cuts. It's absurd. They're thinking about raising taxes on millionaires, which they claim to oppose, while rejecting spending cuts they supposedly want. It defies logic. Any fair observer would see this as a balanced plan. It's time to get it done. The country needs stability, focus, compromise. This is a crucial test.
label: General

sentence: Q. ——why do you object to that being taught in schools? And do you object to slavery itself being taught in schools? [SEP] Yes, so—no, I want everybody to know everything they can about our history. I'm not a believer in cancel culture, the good or the bad. If you don't study the bad, it could happen again. So I do want that subject studied very, very carefully and very accurately.But we grew up with a certain history, and now they're trying to change our history—revisionist history. That's why they want to take down our monuments. That's why they want to take down our statues.I saw something the other day, which was absolutely horrendous: Washington Monument, they want to rename it—the DC committee, but the DC committee is all Democrats. Abraham Lincoln, Thomas Jefferson—I mean, we're talking about—this is the big stuff now. This is the big stuff. And they want to rename it. They want to redesignate it. They want to take some down. No, we don't do that. Never going to happen with me, I guarantee you that.Well, I want to thank you all, and I just want to wish you a very happy Labor Day. And we're having tremendous success, whether it's on the vaccines, whether it's on the pandemic—the plague that came in from China, that China should have never let happen, because I will never feel the same about China.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the intelligence community is reporting active Russian meddling and potential Chinese meddling in the election. Your reaction? [SEP] Meddling, meddling, meddling. That's all they ever talk about. Look, Russia knows I'm the toughest president they've ever faced. And China? They respect strength. So, let them meddle. We'll win anyway.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, to be clear, are you ruling out military action against North Korea if they violate their commitments? [SEP] I'm not going to speculate on hypothetical scenarios. My priority is to achieve a peaceful resolution through diplomacy.

sentence: President Obama, can you confirm the reports that Chen Guangcheng is under US protection and if the US would grant him asylum? Prime Minister Noda, how likely is a North Korean nuclear test and how would Japan respond? What would you like the US to do? [SEP] Well, regarding the situation, I'm aware of the reports, but I won't comment specifically. Human rights are always part of our discussions with . We believe that respecting human rights makes stronger. On North Korea, we've been very clear: provocations will only lead to more isolation. We're working closely with Japan and South Korea to ensure stability in the region.

sentence: Mr. President, with several key figures departing your administration, how will this affect your policy priorities moving forward? [SEP] Pete Rouse is leaving. That's a hard one.

sentence: Looking back, was Theresa May the wrong person to lead the UK, and do you believe Boris Johnson can successfully negotiate a Brexit deal with the EU by the end of October? [SEP] Well, Theresa gave it her best shot, but she just couldn't quite get there. I actually shared my thoughts on how to approach the negotiations early on, but she chose a different path, and the results speak for themselves. She's a fine individual, a good woman. But I have full confidence that Boris Johnson will be a terrific Prime Minister. We have a strong connection, and we recently spent some very valuable time together. I've been anticipating his ascension to leadership for quite a while now. He's incredibly bright, incredibly determined, and incredibly enthusiastic. And above all, he has a deep affection for your country. Next question?
label: Implicit

sentence: President Bush, North Korea submitted a declaration on nuclear programs, but it omitted nuclear weapons. Are you satisfied? You notified Congress about removing North Korea from the state sponsors of terrorism list, despite abduction concerns in Japan. What means will remain to press North Korea on the abduction issue after removal from the list? Mr. Fukuda, did you ask President Bush to reconsider the removal? If not, why? What specific cooperation will you seek from the U.S. to advance the abduction issue after the removal? [SEP] North Korea remains the most sanctioned nation globally. To lift sanctions, they must verifiably honor commitments. Delisting doesn't negate sanctions. They face significant obligations to fulfill. It's action for action. The cooling tower destruction was verifiable, a positive step. We have other concerns, including abduction. On the abduction issue, suggesting we should seek U.S. to rescind the delisting decision... Well, on the nuclear issue, we've moved to a new phase. Success is in Japan's interest. In parallel, we need to resolve the abduction issue. Progress on the nuclear front shouldn't preclude progress on abduction. We need good-faith discussions with North Korea. If abduction doesn't progress, we shouldn't advance on the nuclear front. Progress on both fronts is vital for Japan and necessary for North Korea.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, considering the potential ramifications, would you agree to any debt ceiling bill, regardless of its length? [SEP] Let me be unequivocally clear: We will not negotiate with those who seek to hold the American economy hostage. Paying our bills is a fundamental responsibility, not a bargaining chip. To even entertain the notion of default is reckless and irresponsible. Imagine the chaos if families decided to skip mortgage payments – the consequences would be devastating. Similarly, a nation's creditworthiness is paramount. Playing games with it jeopardizes our economic stability and future prosperity. We must reject this dangerous brinkmanship and uphold our commitment to fiscal responsibility.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President——Unemployment Insurance/Economic Stimulus Legislation  Q. Mr. President, sir—thank you, sir. On unemployment insurance, how much below $600 are you willing to go? And you've said that the economy is bouncing back strong, so why do we need to even cut it at all? [SEP] Well, the economy is getting stronger, and I think we have a chance to have a very strong economy, especially if some of the things that I just spoke about work.We want to have people go back and want to go back to work as opposed to be, sort of, forced into a position where they're making more money than they expected to make. And the employers are having a hard time getting them back to work.So that was a decision that was made. I was against that original decision, but they did that. It still worked out well because it gave people a lifeline, a real lifeline. Now we're doing it again. They're thinking about doing 70 percent of the amount. The amount would be the same, but doing it in a little bit smaller initial amounts so that people are going to want to go back to work, as opposed to making so much money that they really don't have to.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. And would you walk away? [SEP] No. Well, you can't walk away. Because if she walks away, that means she's stuck. You can't walk away. But you can do other things. But she can do what my suggestion was. And my suggestion was, you know, respectfully submitted. She will do very well. I think she's a very tough negotiator. I've been watching her over the last couple of days. She's a tough negotiator. She's a very, very smart and determined person.I can tell you, there are a lot of people that are looking up now saying, Gee, whiz, you know, she left a lot of people in her wake. She's a very smart, very tough, very capable person. And I would much rather have her as my friend than my enemy, that I can tell you. . And we are friends, Mr. President. Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Given the Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy's prediction of a House takeover, how would you assess the current state of the election results and the likelihood of retaining control? [SEP] Well, let's just say the situation is fluid. While we've seen minimal seat losses thus far, the possibility of maintaining the House remains, albeit a narrow one. For instance, our victories in all three contested Nevada seats, where I actively campaigned, were a significant boost. However, the overall picture is still evolving, and the final outcome will be a close call.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding Georgia, will you address the situation in your upcoming meeting with President Putin? [SEP] Look, those folks from Georgia, they came, they saw, they pitched. We heard them out. It's a complicated situation, no doubt. But they presented their case, a very compelling one, I might add. So, yeah, we listened. Next question.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Does North Korea give you something in return though? [SEP] Well, we've gotten—you know, I've heard that. I mean, some of the people that—I don't know, maybe they really mean it. I don't always want to go against the press, because I just don't—especially not today, this is too important. But I noticed that some of the people were saying that the President has agreed to meet, he has given up so much. I gave up nothing. I'm here. I haven't slept in 25 hours, but I thought it was appropriate to do—because we have been negotiating for literally around the clock with them and with us and with John and with Mike and a whole team of very talented people.But we haven't given up anything, other than—you're right, I agreed to meet. And I think the meeting was every bit as good for the United States as it was for North Korea. But I just wrote down some of the things we got. And they—you know, they—sure, they got a meeting. But only a person that dislikes Donald Trump would say that I've agreed to make a big commitment. Sure, I've agreed to take a period of time and come here and meet, and that's good. But I think it's great for us and—as a country, and I think it's good for them. But what did they do to justify this meeting? Secured commitment for complete denuclearization; that's the big thing. They secured the release of three American hostages. They already gave them to us 2 months ago. These people are now living happily back in their homes with their families. And it was pretty rough for them, to put it mildly.Secure the commitment to recover the remains, including—these are of fallen heroes. And they're giving a commitment, they're starting it immediately, to recover their remains. And I just went through how many people asked me about it. I was amazed, actually. So many people would ask me: Is it possible? Is it possible? At that time we had no relationship to Chairman Kim or to anybody else in North Korea. You know, it was a very closed society. So we're getting the remains back.Secured the halt of all missile and nuclear tests for—how long has it been? Seven months? You haven't had a missile go up. For 7 months, you haven't had a nuclear test; you haven't had a nuclear explosion. I remember a nuclear event took place, 8.8 in the Richter scale. And they announced—I heard it on the radio, they announced that a massive—you know, an earthquake took place somewhere in Asia. And then, they said it was in North Korea. And then, they found out it was a nuclear test. I said, I never heard of a Richter scale in the high 8s.And if you look, there has been no missile launches. They've blown up their missile area. That's going to take place. That has not been written into the contract. We're going to give you the exact details on that. But they secured a halt of all missiles and of all nuclear tests. They secured the closure of their single primary nuclear test flight—test site. All three of them—they're in an area that's common around each other—they secured the closure.They secured the commitment to destroy the missile engine testing site. That was not in your agreement. I got that after we signed the agreement. I said: Do me a favor. You've got this missile engine testing site. We know where it is because of the heat. We—it's incredible the equipment we have, to be honest with you. I said, Can you close it up? He's going to close it up.We maintained the ability to continue to apply sanctions. So we're applying sanctions. Now, I had 300 sanctions that I was getting ready to put on last week. And I said, you know, I can't really put on sanctions when I'm meeting with—I thought it would be very disrespectful. Three hundred very big ones, powerful ones. And I said it would be disrespectful.So, Jennifer, when you look at all of those things that we got—and when we got our hostages back, I didn't pay $1.8 billion in cash like the hostages that came back from Iran, which was a disgraceful situation, what took place.So we've gotten a lot. So when I hear somebody in the media say that President Trump has agreed to meet, like, it's not a big deal to meet. I think we should meet on a lot of different topics, not just this one. And I really believe a lot of great things can happen.Yes. Go ahead, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Karzai of Afghanistan has accused Pakistani intelligence of orchestrating a recent terrorist attack in his country. Reports also suggest that Al Qaeda has regained pre-9/11 strength along the Afghanistan-Pakistan border. Is President Karzai's assessment accurate? And do you believe the new Pakistani government is both willing and capable of combating terrorism? [SEP] First off, we're looking into Karzai's claim and working with his people to get to the bottom of it. But there's no question that some extremists are crossing over from Pakistan into Afghanistan. That's a problem for us, for Afghanistan, and it should be for Pakistan too. We all share a common enemy: extremists who use violence to disrupt or prevent democracy. Al Qaeda is still around. We've hit them hard around the world, including in Pakistan, and we'll keep the pressure on with our Pakistani friends. I hope the Pakistani government understands the danger of extremists operating in their country. I think they do. We'll talk more about it with the Pakistani Prime Minister on Monday. Pakistan is an ally, a friend. And again, all three countries – the U.S., Pakistan, and Afghanistan – share a common enemy. I remember a meeting I had with Presidents Musharraf and Karzai where we talked about the need for cross-border cooperation to stop dangerous people from training and entering Afghanistan, and then returning home with skills they could use against the government. We made some progress, but it's still a tough fight. We were encouraged by the provincial elections there. We'll keep helping the government deal with extremists and develop a counterinsurgency strategy that uses aid to boost the economy. It's a challenge, and we can handle it better together than apart.
label: General

sentence: Q. My first question is to Mr. Putin, Vladimir Vladimirovich. We can see from the declaration what you say about missile defense; the concerns are still there. Issues relating to the third site in Russia are still on the agenda.And my question to Mr. Bush: You talk about transparency. Will you be able to convince your colleagues in Poland and the Czech Republic to be as transparent as you are going to be in missile defense issues? [SEP] True, we have not resolved all the problems relating to missile defense and the third site in Europe. However, I have already mentioned, before and today, we have seen once again that our U.S. partners not only understand our concerns but are sincerely trying to overcome our concerns. And another important observation is that I do have certain cautious optimism with regard to mutual agreements. I believe that this is possible. But the devil is in the details, and it is important here that our experts could work at the expert level. It is important for them to agree on the concrete confidence-building measures, and they should see how those measures will be implemented in practical terms.And the third issue mentioned by President Bush—he said that we should work together on these systems. It would be desirable. I believe that this is the most important thing, if, at the expert level and then at the political level, we are able to start cooperation on a global missile defense system, as we are now talking about—[inaudible]—missile defense in Europe. If we manage to achieve this kind of level of cooperation on a global missile defense system, this will be the best kind of result for all our proceeding efforts. Precisely what he said is true. And that is, is that if we can, first of all, earn enough trust to be able to cooperate regionally and then globally, that's in our interest, because one of the concerns from the Russian side, a clear concern, is that if they believe the system is aimed at them, they're going to obviously do something about it. They'll spend money to avoid the system.And I view this as defensive, not offense. And obviously, we've got a lot of work to do to convince the experts that the system is not aimed at Russia. It's really to help deal with the threats that we all are going to face. And therefore, the vision about having a global system is something I strongly support, where we're working cooperatively together. Look, there's a lot of—we got a lot of way to go.And as to your question about the Czech Republic and Poland, it's important for the leaders in those countries—and I've discussed the issue with them—to understand that Russia is not an enemy; Russia is somebody with whom we need to work. And we'll work through the differences there as well. Transparency is going to require more than just a briefing. Transparency is going to require true openness in a system.I have no problem with that. I have no problem sharing technologies and information to make sure that all people understand this system is designed to deal with multiple—I mean, single-or dual-launch regimes that could try to hold us hostage. This system is not designed to deal with Russia's capacity to launch multiple rockets.Now, we got work to do, but we've come a long way since our first discussions. And this document really does express a vision that will make it better for America and Russia when—to work together along these lines. And so yes, I thank you for your question.Russia-U.S. Relations//North Atlantic Treaty Organization
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the gravity of the situation, could you perhaps reiterate the specific location you were referencing earlier? [SEP] Remind me again, where exactly are we talking about?
label: Clarification

sentence: Concerning possible tax modifications, would these adjustments lean more towards benefiting corporations or individual taxpayers? And, to ease market anxieties, could you offer a general range for the potential percentage change on either side? [SEP] I'm not going to get into the details. I'm simply saying I'm willing to consider a small adjustment.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Afghanistan, what's the projected timeline for troop withdrawal, similar to the 16-month plan for Iraq? Also, will you overturn the Pentagon's ban on media coverage of the return of fallen soldiers at Dover Air Force Base, a policy previously criticized by Senator Biden? [SEP] First, let me express my deep sorrow for the loss of four American service members in Iraq today. My thoughts and prayers are with their families. It's a constant reminder of the gravity of this office. Concerning media access at Dover, we are reviewing the policy in consultation with the Department of Defense, and I'll provide an answer after a thorough evaluation. Afghanistan is a different situation. While Iraq has shown progress with a functioning political system, Afghanistan's government seems disconnected. The Taliban and Al Qaeda operate freely in the border regions. We're conducting a comprehensive review, involving General Petraeus and Ambassador Holbrooke, to develop a regional approach. We need better coordination between military, diplomatic, and development efforts. But let's not forget why we're there: 9/11. We can't allow Al Qaeda to operate with impunity. I don't have a specific timetable yet, but I won't let them plan attacks on our homeland.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Good evening to all of you. I also have a couple of questions, one for President Bush—good evening, sir—and it is about Iraq. You've spoken about a change in the country. Do you think it might be at all possible to have a withdrawal, maybe a partial withdrawal, of U.S. troops? And if so, when do you think that might be?My second question is for you, Prime Minister Berlusconi. Today the President talked about the fact that Italian foreign policy might change pace, as it were, thanks to the dialogue that has been established among the political forces in Italy. Do you think that is so, and if you do, how do you think you can uphold the dialogue with the opposition in Italy? [SEP] The progress is such on the security front that we're—are bringing troops home. We anticipate having the troops that went in for this—what's called the surge—back home by July. General Petraeus will come back; he'll assess the situation—come back to the United States—and make further recommendations. I don't know what those recommendations will be. I have told the American people, though, that conditions on the ground, the situation in Iraq, should determine our troop levels.And so we are in the process of what's called return on success. And I had the honor of going to see the 82d Airborne that had been in Iraq, and they came home. And it was—I was—I am constantly amazed at the courage and the commitment of our troops. And I'm also pleased with the courage and commitment of the Iraqi Government and the people of Iraq. The situation is dramatically different than what it was a year ago. And United States and our allies must send a clear message to the Iraqis: We'll stand with them as their democracy continues to evolve and their economy continues to grow. And now my question: I'm very happy to acknowledge the forecast made by the President of Italy with regard to the attitude being shown by the opposition. And we are happy to think that the opposition might like to support our foreign policy, and our foreign policy will go along the same lines that we pursued in our previous Government for those 5 years.And this is a pro-European integration foreign policy. It is a foreign policy which is based on the idea that we don't have two Western worlds, we don't have Europe on one side and the U.S. and Canada on the other. When we talk about the West, we mean only one West. And our foreign policy aims at being based on cordial relations with an important country such as the Russian Federation.So our policy is going to require our effort to strengthen the ties and the cooperation between the European Union and the Russian Federation. And it is a policy that will consider NATO to be the vehicle which will help to maintain and uphold peace throughout the world, as it has done over the past decades.Now, what about the wounds in the world, at—where we know that they're going to need our generosity? Democracies are going to have to help those people who cannot establish freedom on their own. And as I said earlier, we think that this is the only way that we can possibly pursue in order to enable and ensure peace throughout the world after having fully eliminated terrorism.Now let me also acknowledge your vision, Mr. President, your policy, and the courage that you have shown throughout all the years, of hard work on behalf— on the part of your administration. You've always expressed your ideas with great courage, your ideals for the future, your vision for the future. I have gotten to know President Bush very well. I consider him to be a very close friend, a very unique person. And when he says no, he means no; when he says yes, it means yes. And he's always known—he's always shown that he has been able to be very close to those friends of his who have shared his ideals.I thank you very much, Mr. President, for your friendship between the two of us, on a personal level, your friendship shown to our country. And I thank you for the very courageous role that you have always taken as the leader of the most important country in the world and—which is able to determine peace and freedom throughout the world.Thank you once again. Thank you for being here this evening. And thank you to all our American friends who are accompanying the President.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Sir, did you order an investigation into the Hadley memo leak prior to the al-Maliki meeting, and do you believe someone is trying to undermine your Iraq policy? [SEP] The issue of leaks is, frankly, a constant headache. Whether I specifically ordered an investigation into that particular incident, I honestly can't recall at this moment. What I will say is that we are always vigilant about protecting classified information. It's a matter of national security.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Do you doubt it? [SEP] It is interesting that everybody is always mentioning Russia. And I don't mind you mentioning Russia, but I think probably China, at this point, is a nation that you should be talking about much more so than Russia because the things that China is doing are far worse, if you take a look at what's happening with the world.Look at what happened with the China virus. Look at what they did by not keeping that within the confines of China. They should have kept it in the confines of China. Look what they've done to 188 countries all over the world. But you never ask about China; you're always asking about Russia.So I would be very angry if that's the case, and we'll take a look at the numbers and the documents, because we're going to be sent a lot of documents over the next few days.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, doesn't commuting Chelsea Manning's sentence risk setting a dangerous precedent? Won't it signal to potential leakers, including those associated with groups like WikiLeaks and their alleged Russian connections, that disclosing classified information carries minimal consequences? Furthermore, now that Julian Assange has offered to come to the US, will your administration pursue his arrest and prosecution? [SEP] Look, let's get one thing straight: Manning served time, a considerable amount. Anyone thinking about spilling secrets shouldn't assume it's a walk in the park. I believed her sentence was out of whack compared to others, especially given her acceptance of responsibility and the due process she underwent. Commuting, not pardoning, felt right. Justice was served, and the message remains clear: national security matters. We want whistleblowers to use proper channels. As for WikiLeaks, I haven't focused on them. The intel community's Russia findings weren't conclusive about WikiLeaks' involvement in the DNC email leak. Assange's tweets? Irrelevant to my decision. The Justice Department handles any legal issues with him. In this digital age, we need to balance openness with security. Bad actors will exploit our transparency. We must protect ourselves while upholding democratic values. My decision on Manning was based on the specifics of her case, just like all commutations and pardons. It was the appropriate action given the circumstances.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, can you confirm that all Governors are on board with this? [SEP] We just concluded a meeting with the Governors, and they were very keen to receive funds for their respective States. Depending on the State, we retain the right to act as we see fit. We can eliminate the 25 percent, or we can choose not to. We'll assess the situation; it varies by State. A substantial amount of money will be distributed to many people expeditiously. I've instructed the Secretary of the Treasury to proceed with utmost speed. Right? Yes. The President. So we'll get it done. Yes, please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can I just ask a question, since I didn't get to ask you one directly? [SEP] Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you elaborate on your vision for the G-7 during your presidency? [SEP] Listen, we're looking at some very special things, okay? We're taking what we've got, and we're making it even better. We're gonna have tremendous unity, the best unity, believe me. Everyone's gonna be getting along great, just great.
label: General

sentence: Changing subjects, Mr. President, concerning racial equality, what's the connection to criminal justice reform? What are your remaining objectives? What's the importance of your Kenya visit? And will you rescind Bill Cosby's Medal of Freedom? [SEP] That's a rather comprehensive set of inquiries.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Should USMCA fail to pass, is NAFTA effectively dead? [SEP] NAFTA was a disaster. A total disaster. But we're working on USMCA, which is a much better deal. But these people in Congress, they're too busy with their nonsense. They can't win elections, so they try to impeach. We're doing great in the polls. We're winning all over the country. So, we'll see what happens with USMCA. It's going to be very interesting.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Ewen MacAskill from the Guardian. In your trip to the U.K., there are lots of protests planned in London and elsewhere. How do you feel to it—about that? [SEP] I think it's fine. I mean, I think they like me a lot in the U.K. I think they agree with me on immigration. I'm very strong on immigration. I made a point today—I said: You've got to stop. You're ruining your—you're going to have a lot of problems. You see what's going on throughout the world with immigration. I probably, at least partially, won an election because of immigration.If you look at Italy, Giuseppe, who I got to know quite well over the last month and a half, he won his election because of strong immigration policies on Italy. I think that a lot of the people in the U.K.—I think that's why Brexit happened. Now, I don't know what's going on with the negotiation. Who knows? But—and I guess that's become a very interesting point of contention. I said I'm going to a few hotspots. We have NATO, then we have the U.K, and then we have Putin. And I said: Putin may be the easiest of them all. You never know. But I'm going to a pretty hotspot right now, right, with a lot of resignations.But I will say that immigration is a very important thing, and I told them today, the EU—the European Union—better be very careful, because immigration is taking over Europe, and they'd better be very, very careful. And I said that loud and clear.Yes, go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, your take on the Biden-Harris campaign launch? [SEP] Honestly, I only caught a glimpse. But it was enough to confirm my suspicions. He picked her, despite her past attacks and dismal poll numbers. She was nasty to him, really nasty. And now she is his running mate. It's a strange choice. Her policies are radical, disastrous. No fossil fuels? Tell that to Texas! They want to raise taxes, defund the police, weaken our military. We've done the opposite. We've rebuilt the military, cut taxes, and unleashed the American economy. We are endorsed by law enforcement. The military is with us. They are not with him. It's a clear choice. We're going to win, and we're going to keep America great.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, is this result a referendum on your administration, or is it more indicative of the changing demographics of the nation? [SEP] Well, consider this: the unemployment numbers for African Americans and Hispanics are the best they've ever been. My poll numbers with those groups are through the roof. You see the same thing with median income. People are doing better than ever before, and that's reflected in the polls. So, you tell me.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you elaborate on your discussion with Pope Benedict, particularly regarding the Iraq War and his concerns about the region? Also, Prime Minister, what was discussed concerning the ongoing trials involving American citizens? [SEP] Jennifer, I would be pleased to share some insights into my private conversation with His Holiness. My impression is that he is a man of great intellect and compassion. In my tenure as President, I have encountered many remarkable individuals in diverse settings, and I was deeply moved by this encounter. We did not specifically address the concept of 'just war.' However, he did express significant concern regarding the welfare of Christians in Iraq, fearing that the evolving social landscape might not be conducive to their religious freedom. I assured him of our commitment to upholding the Constitution, ensuring respect for individuals from all backgrounds. We also discussed our efforts to address HIV/AIDS, malaria, and hunger in Africa. I highlighted our substantial investment, which has increased access to antiretroviral drugs from 50,000 to over 1.1 million individuals. I intend to seek a doubling of this commitment. We also discussed our malaria initiative and our objective to reduce its prevalence by 50% in select countries. I emphasized the importance of global cooperation in eradicating malaria throughout Africa. Furthermore, we discussed addressing hunger, including the needs of impoverished communities within our own nation. He is closely monitoring the immigration debate in America. I conveyed my strong support for comprehensive immigration reform that balances law enforcement with the humane treatment of individuals. It was a productive exchange.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with concerns rising about potential food shortages during the pandemic, what concrete measures are being implemented to safeguard our nation's food supply chain? [SEP] Look, our farmers are knocking it out of the park, producing at levels you wouldn't believe. We're also tackling the transportation piece – got my transportation folks on the phone tomorrow to hammer out the delivery details. So, we're crushing it on the food front. Haven't heard a peep about problems, and from what I see, Kroger and Walmart are doing just fine. We'll be rock solid on food. Okay, one more.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, hypothetically, if you had global business interests before taking office, would you have sold them off and placed the funds in a blind trust? Or is it permissible for a President to be vulnerable to foreign policy influences? And, quickly, what are your issues with the NSA and Cyber Command, and are you thinking of firing Admiral Rogers? [SEP] That initial question was more of a thought experiment, wouldn't you say?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, about the Senate proceedings, do you favor a speedy conclusion or a comprehensive fact-finding process? What's your take on the Cipollone-Nadler situation? And are you completely against John Bolton's testimony? [SEP] That's quite a few questions you've packed into one.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you provide specific examples of these 'terrible stories' in the Washington Post and New York Times regarding mail-in voting fraud, and what concrete evidence do you possess that Nevada's mail-in ballot system will lead to widespread fraud? [SEP] Well, if you read, even the Washington Post had a terrible story on mail-in and the New York Times. And many, many newspapers have had terrible stories. You see them all over the internet. They've had some just horrible stories on mail-in ballots. You look at Arizona [Nevada]*, you don't even have to have—as you know, they have a provision where they don't have to check signatures. So you sign it, and you could have a totally different signature. It's okay. It won't be approved. They have the right to go 7 days after the election for approval, so you're not even going to know who won the State of Nevada.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Beyond Huawei, which other Chinese tech firms are under consideration for bans in the U.S. due to security concerns? [SEP] Well, Huawei is the main focus, isn't it? Huawei isn't operating here. I'm not permitting it. I've communicated this to European nations and others. Australia, for instance, has been very supportive. Huawei is not coming here. We informed certain countries considering Huawei that while they could use them, we wouldn't share intelligence. They've all reconsidered. The U.K. initially seemed inclined that way, but now they've withdrawn—Scotland Yard.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics allege your stance on climate change is inconsistent. Is it a hoax, or a serious threat? [SEP] Look, it's not a hoax, per se, but let's be real. Some folks are blowing this thing way out of proportion. We're talking about folks wanting to live in a fantasy world. I want clean water, the cleanest! I want the cleanest air, and we're doing great, record numbers! But you gotta look at the other countries, they're the real polluters. Greta should focus on them. We're already the cleanest, the best, despite the garbage other countries dump in our oceans. So, no, not a hoax, but a little perspective is needed.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Trump, regarding Crimea, how do you plan to reverse Russia's annexation, a situation you inherited from the Obama administration? [SEP] Well, we're observing the situation closely. It's a work in progress, you understand? If I possessed a definitive solution, I wouldn't disclose it, as that would compromise our position. We'll monitor how events unfold. But let's not forget, Crimea was a problematic situation I inherited. I also inherited North Korea, and we're achieving significant strides. You saw the letter, correct? No nuclear tests, no missile launches, no rocket launches. Certain sites were dismantled. And we secured the release of our hostages before my departure. Positive developments are occurring, and there's a favorable atmosphere. It's a gradual process, perhaps lengthier than desired, but I'm accustomed to such timelines. We haven't rescinded the sanctions; they're exerting pressure. However, Crimea is a matter I inherited, John. There's little to add except that we're examining it, akin to the various predicaments I've assumed responsibility for. I'm resolving them individually. And I possess the expertise to do so, understood?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, Russia's banning food imports and Secretary Hagel's warning about troops on Ukraine's border raise concerns. Are the sanctions truly effective? [SEP] Well, the full picture of sanctions effectiveness is still developing. We're seeing significant pressure on the Russian economy – capital flight, slowed growth. This puts Putin at a crossroads: diplomacy and respecting Ukraine's sovereignty, or continued aggression with long-term economic consequences. We're aligned with allies, but the conflict persists, and civilians are suffering. We need serious talks to ensure all Ukrainians are heard and reforms are implemented. Putin must recognize Ukraine's independence for a true solution. Sanctions are working as intended in the meantime.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given the reports of international observers, shouldn't there be repercussions for the actions taken so far? [SEP] The international community is watching events unfold. The ian Government should understand that its handling of internal dissent, originating from the ian people themselves, will significantly impact 's future and its relationships with other nations. And since we're talking about , I know Nico Pitney from Huffington Post is here.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea, while you've mentioned progress, can you identify specific diplomatic breakthroughs or concessions made by North Korea as a direct result of your strategy? Also, have your views on the efficacy of direct talks evolved? [SEP] I prefer to keep my cards close to my chest on this one. What I will say is that it is imperative for to act responsibly, not just for themselves, but for the entire planet. We are projecting immense power, the likes of which the world has never seen. We have deployed significant military resources, which we sincerely hope we will never be compelled to utilize. I am optimistic that will recognize the wisdom of engaging in constructive negotiations that benefit both and the global community. While I perceive some positive developments, we must remain vigilant and await further developments.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, what is your assessment of how long Israel will maintain the suspension of its West Bank annexation plan? [SEP] What's your opinion? I'm interested in your thoughts on this. We're completely dedicated to pursuing peace. We've finalized an agreement with the Emirates, and we're resolving the remaining details – embassies, flight routes, commerce. We aim to expand this model to the entire region. I can't provide a specific timeframe. We've prioritized peace over the sovereignty movement, but it hasn't been dismissed entirely. It's been deferred to provide peace with every opportunity to succeed.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. ——or were they authorized without your permission? [SEP] Yes, thanks, Pete. I'm not going to talk about any of it. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Regarding the Newtown shooting anniversary, and the renewed opposition to an assault weapons ban, how aggressively will you advocate for such a ban? If it fails in Congress, what other measures are essential in a comprehensive plan to reduce gun violence? [SEP] The Vice President and Cabinet members conducted a thorough review, consulting with stakeholders, including the NRA, and presented me with sensible steps to prevent future tragedies like Newtown. I'll meet with the Vice President today and offer specifics later this week. My priority isn't politics, but effective solutions to ensure children's safety and reduce gun violence, consistent with the Second Amendment. Congress must debate and examine their consciences, setting aside politics to vote based on what's best. I still believe in stronger background checks, limiting high-capacity magazines, and a meaningful assault weapons ban. Will all pass? I don't know. But I'll be honest about what I believe will work. If a step can save even one child from a Newtown-like event, we must take it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the potential use of chemical weapons, can you confirm or deny the presence of actionable intelligence suggesting Putin is preparing to deploy them? Furthermore, what specific retaliatory measures are under consideration by the U.S. and NATO should such weapons be used? [SEP] Look, I'm not at liberty to divulge classified intelligence, plain and simple. What I will say is that any use of chemical weapons would be met with a response. The precise nature of that response, however, is something we'll determine based on the specifics of the situation. We're keeping all options on the table.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President, about North Korea's nuclear sites, did you talk about letting people inspect them? [SEP] I can't hear you very well. Where are you from?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, can you provide any insight into the expected duration of Israel's suspension of the West Bank annexation plan? [SEP] Well, what are your thoughts? I'm curious to hear your perspective. Our primary focus is on fostering peace. We've secured an agreement with the Emirates, and we're ironing out the specifics – embassies, air travel, trade. Our goal is to replicate this success throughout the region. I can't predict the timeline. We've prioritized peace over the sovereignty movement, but it remains a possibility. It's just been delayed to allow peace a chance to flourish.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, what specific actions are you undertaking to ensure the integrity of the upcoming election? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, the public deserves to know if the United States was aware of and/or supported the Israeli action in Syria. Can you at least confirm or deny whether there was any prior consultation with the U.S. government? [SEP] I have no comment on that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Biden, in light of Prime Minister Netanyahu's recent comments on Palestinian statehood, what specific actions would demonstrate his commitment to a two-state solution? And can you comment on the reports of Israeli espionage during the Iran nuclear talks? [SEP] I don't comment on intelligence matters. On the Iran deal, we've kept Congress, the Israelis, and our partners fully informed. If we reach an agreement that prevents Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon, it will be transparent and verifiable. I'm confident that any agreement we reach will enhance the security of the United States, Israel, and the region. Turning to the Israeli-Palestinian issue, the critical question is what the parties themselves believe is possible. Prime Minister Netanyahu has expressed doubts about the viability of a Palestinian state, and I respect his views. While he has outlined conditions under which a Palestinian state might be conceivable, those conditions appear difficult to achieve in the short term. The fundamental question is whether we can establish a process that provides Palestinians with hope for a secure future alongside Israel. Given Prime Minister Netanyahu's statements, that seems unlikely. We are currently reevaluating our approach to this issue. Our commitment to Israel's security is unwavering and our cooperation will continue. However, we must be realistic about the prospects for progress between Israelis and Palestinians. The absence of progress could lead to further instability. Our military and intelligence cooperation with Israel will continue. Our review is specifically focused on the Israeli-Palestinian relationship. We will engage with both sides to understand their perspectives. We cannot pretend that progress is possible when the necessary conditions are not in place. This is not a personal dispute between Prime Minister Netanyahu and myself. It is a fundamental disagreement over policy. We believe that a two-state solution is the most viable path forward. Prime Minister Netanyahu holds a different view.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, there are constitutional concerns surrounding several of your recent actions. Specifically, do you believe the War Powers Act is constitutional? What is your stance on the constitutionality of the debt limit? And finally, do you view marriage as a civil right? [SEP] Goodness, Chuck, you've thrown everything into one question! Maybe you should be nominated to the Supreme Court! But I'm not a constitutional scholar, so I'm not going to put on that hat right now. Let's focus on the core issue here. There's been too much focus on process and not enough on the substance. Muammar Qadhafi, a man responsible for the deaths of more Americans than almost anyone except bin Laden, was threatening a massacre. Under a U.N. mandate, we joined an international coalition to remove his air defenses, allowing for a no-fly zone to protect the Libyan people. I promised no boots on the ground and that we wouldn't carry the bulk of the burden. We've kept our word. Our allies have stepped up, and we've saved countless lives in Libya. No U.S. casualties, limited scope, and constant consultation with Congress. This whole debate is largely political. We acted under a U.N. mandate, saved lives, and Qadhafi is now cornered. The War Powers Resolution arose after the Vietnam War, a costly and devastating conflict. Congress wanted to ensure such a commitment never happened again without their input. Consultation is vital, but our actions are fully compliant with the War Powers Resolution. Therefore, the constitutional question is moot.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, those are broad strokes. Can you give us specifics on the timeline for Syria and what concrete evidence supports your assessment of Kim Jong-un? [SEP] Look, with North Korea, meetings are being set up. Concessions have been made. Sanctions are the strongest ever. China has been very strong at the border. Trade is also important. As for Syria, we're discussing it as part of an overall deal. The Iran deal should have included Syria. We want to come home, but we want to leave a strong and lasting footprint. It was a big part of our discussion.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, did your 'dictator' comment about Xi Jinping undermine your administration's efforts to manage the relationship with China? And concerning India, how do you respond to critics who claim you're ignoring human rights abuses there? [SEP] To answer your first question directly: no, it did not. When engaging with our allies and partners worldwide, including India, I'm not going to censor myself or avoid stating what I believe to be the truth about our relationship with China. I've long held the view that the panic surrounding our relationship with China is exaggerated. We experienced an incident that caused some, shall we say, misunderstanding, but Secretary Blinken had a productive visit to China. I expect to meet with President Xi in the near future, and I don't think my remark had any real effect. Now, remind me of your second question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, you advocate for a free and open Indo-Pacific while visiting China, a country with a very different system. How do you reconcile these conflicting approaches? Will this not lead to inevitable friction? [SEP] Well, Mark, let me tell you, the Prime Minister here is going to be shooting down missiles left and right once he gets all that beautiful military equipment from us. Like we did in Saudi Arabia, boom, gone. He's buying a lot, and he should. Best stuff in the world, made in America. F-35, missiles, you name it. Jobs for us, safety for Japan. Now, China, I have a great relationship with President Xi. I like him, he likes me. We represent different countries, but we see eye-to-eye on trade. The problem is, for years, they've been ripping us off. Huge trade deficit, hundreds of billions, not even counting the intellectual property theft. We're talking to them about it, it's gotta stop. Gotta have free, fair, or reciprocal trade. I like reciprocal the best. You charge us, we charge you. Simple. Some countries charge us 100%, we charge them nothing. That's gotta end. We're fixing it. Takes time, laws, notices, all that stuff. But we're on it. You'll see big changes with countries that treat us unfairly. It's started already, the legal stuff is done. It's coming. America's been taken advantage of for too long. Thank you. Regarding Japan defense equipment, a lot of them we purchase from the United States. North Korean situation becoming very tough, the Asia-Pacific security situation becoming very tough, we qualitatively and quantitatively, we have to enhance our defense capability. As the President mentioned, F-35A is a case in point. SM-3 Block IIA is another plan for purchase from the United States. Aegis vessels, the quality and the quantity must be enhanced. In that process, we will be buying more from the United States. That is what I am thinking. Now, North Korea: North Korea launched missiles. Immediately after that, we traced them; we were able to grasp and trace where they were going. Missile defense is something which is based upon the cooperation between Japan and the United States. Missile defense system is a cooperation between the two countries. For the intercepting and shooting down, if it is necessary, of course, we will do that—if it is necessary. But in doing so, U.S. and Japan will closely coordinate our actions. Thank you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering the growing wealth gap, what concrete steps is your administration taking to ensure a more equitable distribution of resources and opportunities for all citizens? [SEP] Look, the great thing about this country is that everyone gets to speak their mind, even if they're yelling at me. I've been protested plenty of times, and I'm sure every president has. So, I'm not going to tell anyone to be quiet. But I will say this: elections matter, voting matters, getting involved matters, being informed matters. And to all the young people out there, don't take our system for granted. It's not guaranteed. It takes work. If a huge chunk of eligible voters don't even bother to vote, then democracy suffers. If we can't tell the difference between real news and fake news, especially with all the social media garbage, then we're in trouble. And if people refuse to compromise and engage in the process, if they're just taking extreme positions and hating on their opponents, then democracy will crumble. So, my advice is to understand the foundations of a healthy democracy and to be a citizen all the time, not just when you're upset or when there's an election. It's a constant effort. And the good news is, there are a lot of young people who are ready to do that work. But I think sometimes we get complacent. Here in Europe, a lot of young people have forgotten the lessons of the Cold War, what it was like to have a wall. And I've heard some rhetoric here that equates the U.S. and Russia, like there's no difference between our governments. We're not perfect, we've made mistakes, but we've generally tried to uphold values like free speech and civil liberties. And that's something to remember. Because in this age of misinformation, where everything looks the same on a Facebook page, it's easy to lose sight of what's important. We need to know what to protect, what to fight for. Otherwise, we could lose everything we've gained. Anyway, that was a long answer. I think there was a second part to the question, but I got carried away.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Valentinovna from Sputnik News is asking if you discussed possible inspections of North Korea's nuclear sites during your negotiations? [SEP] I'm sorry, I didn't hear that. Where are you from again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thanks, Mr. President. Joe Biden and Kamala Harris just appeared together in their first campaign event, right before you've got up on this podium. Can you tell us if you watched their remarks and give us your reaction to them? [SEP] I didn't watch. I saw just a moment of him speaking a moment of her speaking and it was enough.Look he made a choice: He picked her. I watched her. I watched her poll numbers go boom boom boom down to almost nothing. And she left angry. She left mad. There was nobody more insulting to Biden than she was. She said horrible things about him including accusations made about him by a woman where she I guess believed the woman. And now all of a sudden she's running to be Vice President saying how wonderful he is.I thought it was a very unusual pick because she said such bad things. And you know better than anybody what—you know you won't write it because you know you don't want to do that—but you know better than anybody. She said horrible things about him. Horrible things. And she mocked him openly mocked him. That's why I thought that was a very risky pick because I'm sure that'll be played back—not necessarily by me but others—it will be played back.The other thing if you look she wants a $3 trillion tax hike. No fracking. How do you think no fracking in Pennsylvania is going to play? That's a big fracking State. If you didn't have energy produced that way you would have taxes that would triple and you'd have unemployment that you wouldn't believe.And Pennsylvania last year had the best year they've ever had. Texas last year had the best year they've ever had. Oklahoma best year. Almost every State in our Nation last year had the best year they've ever had. And they're going to have that again next year. And you can see that by what—but think of it: She wants no fossil fuels. No fossil fuels. Really? Tell that to Texas.And then I hear Trump is only one point up in Texas. No they said the same thing with Crooked Hillary Clinton. They said: Texas is in play. Trump is down in Texas. And then I won Texas. Immediately when they said the polls are closed Trump has won Texas. And I won by a lot. And I won Georgia by a lot. It's the same thing over—it's almost like a duplication of what happened before except we have much more energy now than we ever did in 2016 and we had a lot. We had record amounts in 2016.But you take a look at the tax cuts. We gave the biggest tax cut in the history of our country and the biggest regulation cuts in the history of our country by far. Right? He wants to increase everybody's taxes. And she's one of the people that wants that.I mean you take a look at that. She wants to defund or at least substantially reduce money going to police departments. And you can't do that. You can't do that. It's actually got to be the opposite. I've been endorsed by so many police departments. I'm getting a really good one this week that you'll be seeing really big really good.But who could ever—what police department what law enforcement group could ever support Joe Biden where he said things that are so bad and so foolish—frankly so stupid—in terms of crime and what would happen. So we're getting all of law enforcement.We're getting the military. She wants to spend much less on our military. I've rebuilt the military. We have the strongest military now. Much of the equipment is coming in all made in the United States; $2.5 trillion we spent.When I took over we had a military that was totally—it was in terrible terrible shape. It was depleted. It was a depleted military: old planes old tanks old everything. And we have a beautiful brandnew military with the best people in the world. We never had anything like it. Some of the equipment is still coming in.No we have—we've done a real job. And I think we're going to be extremely successful. I was surprised that he picked her—very surprised—because of the horrible way she talked about him. And frankly because she dropped like a rock.I didn't when I ran. I ran against 17 people mostly Governors and Senators some others. Ben Carson was very strong very good. A couple of others but mostly Governors mostly Senators. And I ran and I went up.She ran and she went down to rock bottom. I don't think she ever got to run her first—to take a vote in her first—in the first State. And so generally speaking you don't want to pick somebody that went down and she went down. But she went down in a very terrible way and she said horrible things about Biden.She said far worse about Biden than I ever did. And now she's running as Vice President. So how does that work?Please in the back.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, do you still consider climate change to be a hoax? [SEP] No, not a hoax. I think aspects of it are, let's be clear. Some people exaggerate it to the point where it's unrealistic and you can't live your life. We want the cleanest water and air on Earth, and our numbers are very good, record numbers recently. But we have to address other continents and countries. We can be clean and beautiful, but if another continent is emitting fumes at unbelievable levels, that's a problem. Greta should focus on those places. We're doing better than ever in terms of cleanliness and numbers. But we also have a beautiful ocean, the Pacific, where tons of garbage from other countries flows towards us. So, Greta needs to start working on those other countries.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Germany is attempting to revitalize the Middle East Quartet. Given past failures and the perceived limitations of European influence on US foreign policy, can you cite a specific instance where a conversation with a European leader demonstrably altered your stance on a significant issue? [SEP] Well, I wouldn't necessarily call it a 'change of mind,' but my European colleagues have underscored the importance of the United Nations in securing parliamentary support for difficult decisions. For instance, obtaining UN resolutions is crucial for countries like Denmark or the Netherlands to justify their actions to their respective parliaments. Now, personally, I've never felt that the United States requires UN approval to act in its own security interests. However, I've come to appreciate that other nations rely on the UN, and I respect that. So, in that sense, I've learned a valuable lesson from our allies. I hold Angela Merkel in high regard. She possesses considerable wisdom. I'm not sure if this helps or hurts her, but my consultations with Angela are consistently productive and important. Strong US-Europe relations are essential for achieving our shared objectives, be it trade, peace, or security. These relationships can be challenging at times, with differing viewpoints across Europe. Yet, Angela consistently provides sound advice on addressing common challenges and ensuring our alliance serves the common good. I am a strong believer in this multilateral effort in these international fora, because it shows clearly where the redline is to those who do not wish for democracy. And this is what we need to do, time and again make it clear to them where the limits are, where the redlines are. No back rubs. []
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Yes, but does this—the models, sir, are projecting now 130,000 cases that go through August. Is that—do you agree with those models? Is that your expectation as well? [SEP] Well, the models haven't been exactly accurate. These are models done by a lot of think tanks, a lot of universities. If you look at some of the models, they have been way off. Few of the models have been accurate.But as far as the models are concerned, if you go by the model, we were going to lose 2.2 million people. And because we took—we mitigated—we did things that were very tough for our country to do, frankly. We had to turn off our whole magnificent economy. We had to turn down the whole country. We're at the lowest of all of the models.I mean, if you look at, I guess, one-hundred-and-twenty—100- to 120,000 people would be at the low side. And we're at—there's nothing low. Look, nothing low. One is too many people. And I say it all the time: One person to lose for this is too many people. It's a disgrace what happened.But if you look at the models, we're at a low—at the lowest of those projections. But the models are not models done necessarily by the White House. They're models done by many people all over the world. And if you take the most respected of those people, many of those models are wrong. I mean, they've been wrong as far as the U.S. is concerned, because those numbers are nowhere near what was projected, potentially.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Pope's recent actions concerning the recognition of a Palestinian state and its potential impact on a two-state solution with Israel, could you share your perspective? [SEP] Well, let's talk about trade. The Senate's movement on trade authority is crucial. It empowers us to negotiate and, importantly, enforce trade deals, especially in the Asia-Pacific region and Europe. I thank the Senators who supported this, and I'll continue engaging those who didn't. We need to ensure these deals benefit not just big corporations, but also small and medium-sized businesses, and most importantly, American workers. My focus remains on creating jobs and opportunities for Americans. As for the other part of your question, I'm not sure I understand what you're asking.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, reflecting on the conclusion of the Afghanistan war, do you believe the substantial sacrifices made were ultimately worthwhile, given that the resulting Afghanistan is not the democratic success story initially envisioned? And President Karzai, do you maintain that foreign interference is the primary cause of corruption in Afghanistan, and will you definitively relinquish power after the upcoming elections? [SEP] We went to Afghanistan to protect America. We were attacked, and we responded. We've weakened Al Qaeda significantly. Afghanistan still faces challenges, but it has made progress. I'll defer to President Karzai on the questions directed to him.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Are you signaling a possible end to the filibuster, sir? [SEP] That's been covered./Climate Change/Renewable Energy/Future Generations
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, are you suggesting that teaching about slavery is somehow equivalent to 'cancel culture'? [SEP] No, no, everyone should learn about our history, the good and the bad. I'm against cancel culture, you need to study the bad so it doesn't happen again. But they're trying to rewrite our history, taking down statues, renaming monuments. It's crazy. Not happening. Happy Labor Day, we're doing great with the vaccines, despite the plague that came from China, which they should have never allowed.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And what about the members of your Cabinet? [SEP] What's that you say?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, following up on the interference, can you outline the steps you intend to take to address it? [SEP] We're giving it a very hard look. I understand this information is relatively new, and we're aware of it. We're going to be watching it very closely. But let's be clear, this conversation began with Russia, didn't it?
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. And thank you, Mr. Prime Minister. Mr. President, in your last press conference, you said successful Presidents prioritize and that you were focusing your agenda on one thing at a time. And I'd like to just ask you: What would you say to many Americans who voted for you about the legislative progress on gun control and police reform having to wait while you pursue infrastructure, given that we continue to see these incidents with mass shootings and also police-involved shootings, including the incident that a lot of us saw in Chicago most recently? Do you feel any need to reprioritize your agenda? [SEP] I've never not prioritized this. No one has worked harder to deal with the violence used by individuals using weapons than I have. I'm the only one ever to have passed an assault weapons ban. I'm the only one that ever got a 10-year ban on assault weapons and clips of more than 10 bullets.Immediately upon us becoming in office, having an Attorney General, I asked him to put together the things I could do by Executive order, including dealing with new guns that can be made—you can buy in pieces and put together, and other initiatives.I strongly support—I strongly support—the universal background checks, which I continue to push. The Congress has to step up and act. The Senate has to act. And I strongly support and continue—I've never stopped supporting the ban on assault weapons and magazines that hold more than 10 bullets.It doesn't mean that I can't also be working at the same time on the economy and on COVID. But it's not a question of my being able to set the agenda in the Senate as to what they will move to first. And so I continue and I strongly, strongly urge my Republican friends in the Congress who even refused to bring up the House-passed bill to bring it up now.This has to end. It's a national embarrassment. It is a national embarrassment what's going on. And it's not only these mass shootings that are occurring. Every single day—every single day, there's a mass shooting in this United—in the United States if you count all those who are killed out on the streets of our cities and our rural areas. It's a national embarrassment and must come to an end.And one last thing: The folks who own weapons, the folks who own guns, they support universal background checks. The majority of them think we should not be selling assault weapons. Who, in God's name, needs a weapon that can hold 100 rounds or 40 rounds or 20 rounds? It's just wrong. And I'm not going to give up until it's done.You have a question you want to offer? I mean, not a question—[]—recognize someone, Mr. Prime Minister. Mr. Sugimoto, with Sankei Newspaper.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. And following on what you just said, Republicans in the House might give you that choice soon to either allow the Government to shut down or see Obamacare defunded. Would you choose to let the Government shut down to ensure that Obamacare remains funded? [SEP] Well, I'm not going to engage in hypotheticals. I can tell you that the American people would have difficulty understanding why we would weaken our economy, shut down our Government, shut down vital services, have people who are not getting paid who then can't go to restaurants or shop for clothes or all the other things that we're doing here, because Republicans have determined that they don't want to see these folks get health care.Again, they used to say they had a replacement. That never actually arrived, right? I mean, I've been hearing about this whole replace thing for 2 years; now I just don't hear about it, because basically, they don't have an agenda to provide health insurance to people at affordable rates. And the idea that you would shut down the Government at a time when the recovery is getting some traction; where we're growing, although not as fast as we need to; where the housing market is recovering, although not as fast as we would like; that we would precipitate another crisis here in Washington that no economist thinks is a good idea—I'm assuming that they will not take that path. I have confidence that common sense, in the end, will prevail.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, is the 'fire and fury' approach now off the table? [SEP] Back then, 'fire and fury' might have been necessary. We couldn't allow that specific capability to develop, not for the United States, and certainly not for Japan, which is just next door.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, is an Executive Order a viable solution in this situation? [SEP] It's within my power, absolutely. We haven't reached that point yet, but we're considering all options. We're also taking legal action in Nevada. And I want to mention that we're putting the finishing touches on a major healthcare initiative that we'll be announcing shortly, hopefully this month. We'll also be addressing immigration next month. So, we're actively working on these important issues.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, following up on the previous question, when do you anticipate a resolution to the situation in Syria? [SEP] Honestly, it's hard to say. But things are moving along at a good clip. Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, does this mean you're considering ending the filibuster? [SEP] I've already answered that./Healthcare Reform/Lowering Prescription Drug Costs/The American People
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Ukraine, should Zelenskyy concede territory to achieve a ceasefire with Russia? Also, should Russia be expelled from the G-20? [SEP] Regarding the G-20, my answer is yes, but it depends on the other members. I suggested that if Indonesia and others disagree, we should allow both to attend as observers. Now, remind me of your initial question?
label: Clarification
