sentence: Following up on the Ukraine situation, Mr. President, if Russia undertakes a 'minor incursion,' will the promised sanctions still be enacted? Are you, in essence, giving Putin the green light for a limited invasion? [SEP] That's a very interesting question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence:
Mr. President, having now engaged with this individual, are you confident in his reliability? [SEP] Confidence isn't the operative word here. It's about mutual advantage and ensuring that advantage is verifiable. That's the foundation of any agreement I make on behalf of the American people. I don't operate on blind faith. I need to see concrete evidence.

As they say, 'The proof is in the pudding.' Time will tell.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Can you give me your version of it, sir? [SEP] Yes. Whatever the law says.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your claims about mail-in voting and fraud, could you present concrete evidence demonstrating widespread fraud stemming from mail-in ballots in Nevada and other states? [SEP] The evidence is readily available. Even the Washington Post and the New York Times have reported on the problems with mail-in voting. You can find numerous articles online. In Nevada, they have provisions where signature verification is not always required. This allows for potentially fraudulent ballots to be accepted. Furthermore, they allow for a seven-day period after the election for ballot approval, creating uncertainty about the election outcome.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, acknowledging the constraints of time, what specific strategies are you employing to expedite the decision-making process and ensure a timely and effective response to the challenges we face? [SEP] We have not come up with a unilateral action that could succeed in a matter of 2 weeks or 3 weeks. That's the issue.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your prior statements labeling Iran as part of the axis of evil and Syria as a state sponsor of terrorism, and considering your expressed willingness to embrace any proposal leading to victory, would your administration entertain collaboration with Iran and Syria if their assistance were deemed crucial for success in Iraq? [SEP] The world expects both Iran and Syria to contribute positively to Iraq's stability, a point we've unequivocally communicated. Regarding Iran specifically, our concerns are multifaceted. Firstly, their commitment to the success of Iraq's nascent democracy is paramount. Secondly, their support for the Lebanese democracy, particularly the Siniora Government, remains a key priority for this administration. However, the most pressing issue is Iran's potential acquisition of nuclear weapons. Our stance is clear: a path of cooperation, not isolation, is in Iran's best interest. We will continue to emphasize that their support for terrorism and pursuit of nuclear weapons will only lead to further isolation. Our diplomatic efforts are ongoing, and the Iranians are well aware of our position on Iraq, as are the Iraqis themselves. We are committed to supporting Iraq's sovereignty and stability, and the Iraqi government has conveyed to Iran the importance of non-interference in their internal affairs. As for Syria, our message remains consistent: refrain from undermining the Siniora Government in Lebanon, facilitate the return of the Israeli prisoner captured by Hamas, prevent Hamas and Hezbollah from plotting attacks against democracies in the Middle East, and contribute to stability within Iraq. They are fully aware of our position.
label: General

sentence: Q. Just really quickly, you mentioned the issue of a two-state solution with Israel. I was wondering if you would give your reaction to what the Pope is moving forward with in terms of recognizing the Palestinian state. Do you think that's a good idea? Do you think it's a mistake? And do you think it might help or hinder the two-state solution that you mentioned earlier? [SEP] Okay. Well, first of all, I want to congratulate the Senate on moving forward on providing me the authority to not only strike a smart, progressive, growth-promoting trade deal with some of the countries in the Asia-Pacific region and potentially in Europe as well, but also to give me the tools to enforce those agreements, which haven't always happened in the past.So I want to thank all the Senators who voted to provide that authority, or at least to begin the debate on moving that process forward. Those who didn't vote for it, I want to keep on trying to make the case and provide them the information they need to feel confident that despite the fact that there have been very genuine problems with some trade deals in the past, the approach that we're taking here, I think, is the right one, not just for big U.S. businesses, but also for small U.S. businesses and medium-sized U.S. businesses and, most importantly, ultimately, American workers. I would not be promoting any agreement that I didn't think, at the end of the day, was going to be creating jobs in the United States and giving us more of an opportunity to create ladders of success, higher incomes, and higher wages for the American people, because that's my primary focus. It has been since I came into office.The issue with respect to myself and Elizabeth has never been personal. I mean, I think it's fun for the press to see if we can poke around at it when you see two close allies who have a disagreement on a policy issue. But there are a whole bunch of—some of my best friends in the Senate, as well in the House, some of my earliest supporters who disagree with me on this. And I understand. Because, like me, they came up through the ranks watching plants close, jobs being shipped overseas. Like me, they have concerns about whether labor agreements or environmental agreements with other countries are properly enforced. Like me, they have concerns about whether in fact trade ends up being fair and not just free.And, like me, they have a deep concern about some of the global trends that we've seen and trends that we've seen in our own country in terms of increased inequality and what appears to be the effects of automation and globalization in allowing folks at the very top to do really, really well, but creating stagnation in terms of incomes and wages for middle class families and folks working to get their way into the middle class.So these are folks whose values are completely aligned with mine. I noticed that there was sort of a progressive statement of principles about what it means to be a progressive by some of these friends of mine, and I noted that it was basically my agenda, except for trade. [] Right? That was the one area where there was a significant difference. And this just comes down to a policy difference and an analysis in terms of what we think is best for our people, our constituents.It is my firm belief that, despite the problems of previous trade deals, that we are better off writing high-standard rules with strong, enforceable provisions on things like child labor or deforestation or environmental degradation or wildlife trafficking or intellectual property; we are better off writing those rules for what is going to be the largest, fastest growing market in the world. And if we don't, China will, and other countries will. And our businesses will be disadvantaged, and our workers will ultimately suffer.And in terms of some of the fears of outsourcing of jobs, it is my belief, based on the analysis, that at this point, if there was a company in the United States that was looking for low-cost labor, they have no problem outsourcing it under the current regime. And so what we do have the opportunity to do is to attract back companies to manufacture here in the United States.And we're seeing some of that happen. That's why I went out to Nike. I understand that Nike has been manufacturing shoes with low-cost labor in many of these areas in the Asia-Pacific region and that hurt the American footwear industry in terms of jobs here in the United States. But that happened over the course of the last 30 years. And now, for Nike to announce that because of new technologies, they're potentially bringing 10,000 jobs back here because we've gone up the value chain, we're manufacturing in different ways, that's an opportunity. But we've still got to be able to sell over there to take full advantage of those opportunities.Which is why my argument with my progressive friends is, what we really need to be focusing on to meet the same objectives—the shared objectives—is the kinds of other issues that we all agree on: strong minimum wage, strong job training programs, infrastructure investments that put people back to work, stronger laws to protect collective bargaining and the capability of workers to have a voice, strong enforcement of rules around things like overtime pay, making sure that we have paid sick leave, making sure that we have a honest conversation about our budgets and that we're not slashing investments in the future simply to make sure that we're preserving loopholes for corporations that don't provide any economic benefit.Those are the things that are going to help us address the very problems that they're concerned about. Blocking a trade deal will not, particularly since they're the first ones to acknowledge that the existing trade rules are a bad deal for U.S. workers. If they're not working for us now, how does hanging on to what's going on now help American workers? It doesn't make sense.I'm all for enforcement and the provisions that were signed. I have expressed concerns about how the currency language that is in the bill is drafted. But I have to talk to Senator Schumer and Sherrod Brown and others about how we can work on language that does not end up having a blowback effect on our ability to maintain our own monetary policy.I don't even remember what your other question was. []
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, the press is growing restless waiting for a deal, yet this is your third budget. You've stated you'd prefer a single term if it meant tackling the tough issues. So, why not invite Republicans to negotiate immediately? If not, what further steps will you take to cultivate the cooperation needed for bipartisanship? And, crucially, will the markets remain patient for two more years? [SEP] Goodness, Jackie, I should've written all that down. I'm running out of brainpower here!
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you reconsidering--thank you, Mr. President. Are you reconsidering your plan to cut the interest rate deduction for mortgages and for charities? And do you regret having proposed that in the first place? [SEP] No, I think it's the right thing to do, where we've got to make some difficult choices. Here's what we did with respect to tax policy. What we said was that over the last decade, the average worker, the average family have seen their wages and incomes flat. Even at times where supposedly we were in the middle of an economic boom, as a practical matter, their incomes didn't go up. And so what we said, let's give them a tax cut, let's give them some relief, some help, 95 percent of American families.Now, for the top 5 percent, they're the ones who typically saw huge gains in their income. I fall in that category. And what we've said is for those folks, let's not renew the Bush tax cuts, so let's go back to the rates that existed back in--during the Clinton era when wealthy people were still wealthy and doing just fine; and let's look at the level in which people can itemize their deductions. And what we've said is let's go back to the rate that existed under Ronald Reagan.People are still going to be able to make charitable contributions. It just means, if you give $100 and you're in this tax bracket, at a certain point, instead of being able write off 36 or 39 percent, you're writing off 28 percent. Now, if it's really a charitable contribution, I'm assuming that that shouldn't be a determining factor as to whether you're given that $100 to the homeless shelter down the street.And so this provision would affect about 1 percent of the American people. They would still get deductions. It's just that they wouldn't be able to write off 39 percent. In that sense, what it would do is it would equalize--when I give $100, I'd get the same amount of deduction as when some--a bus driver, who's making $50,000 a year or $40,000 a year, gives that same $100. Right now he gets 28 percent--he gets to write off 28 percent; I get to write off 39 percent. I don't think that's fair.So I think this was a good idea. I think it is a realistic way for us to raise some revenue from people who benefited enormously over the last several years. It's not going to cripple them; they'll still be well-to-do. And ultimately, if we're going to tackle the serious problems that we've got, then in some cases those who are more fortunate are going to have to pay a little bit more.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, concerning the Syrian crisis, did President Putin suggest any inclination for Assad to step aside during your discussions? Furthermore, were any concrete measures agreed upon with either Putin or President Hu to halt the ongoing bloodshed? [SEP] Look, Syria was a major talking point in both meetings, no doubt about it. The violence there is just completely unacceptable, with civilians in the crosshairs and Assad having lost all credibility. When you're slaughtering your own citizens like that, there's no way you can have a peaceful transition that leaves Assad in charge. But getting to that transition is not easy. Russia, with its history with Syria, and China, which usually stays out of other countries' business, have been hesitant to put the pressure on that's needed. We had a very honest conversation. I wouldn't say that the U.S. and the rest of the world are on the same page as Russia and China right now, but I do think they see the serious risks of a full-scale civil war. I don't think they're okay with the massacres, and I think they believe that everyone would be better off if Syria could stop the violence and create a real government. I've told them that it's important for the world to work with the UN and Kofi Annan on a plan for how to move forward. I'm hoping we can keep talking about this and show the world, and especially the Syrian people, a way to end this conflict. But I can't say that the Russians and the Chinese are totally on board yet. What I can say is that they know the situation is serious and that it's not good for them or for the Syrian people. We all agree that if we can help the Syrian people find a way out of this, we'd all be better off. But I personally believe, and I told them this, that I don't see any way that Assad stays in power and the violence goes down. He had a chance with the Annan plan, but he didn't do his part. Instead, we saw things get worse and innocent people getting killed. Now, the international monitors have had to leave because of the violence. And even though some people say the opposition is also using violence, and there's evidence of that, I think it's also fair to say that the awful things we saw in places like Homs were directly caused by the Syrian government, and Assad is ultimately responsible.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, following your electoral triumph, you attributed it to divine intervention. Looking back on your first two years, how significant a role would you say faith plays in your daily presidential decisions? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, faith is tremendous. It's a tremendous factor, not just for me, but for so many of the people I surround myself with, including your very own Vice President. We're talking about people with strong values, strong beliefs, and that's what makes this country great.
label: General

sentence: With oil prices soaring, can you assure the American people that domestic oil producers are maximizing their output, including from offshore sources? Furthermore, will you finalize an agreement with Iraq regarding the long-term presence of U.S. forces before leaving office? [SEP] We're working on a strategic framework with the Iraqi government, covering diplomacy, economics, justice. It includes a security agreement. They want a timeline for transitioning to overwatch, where we're training, providing logistics, and conducting special ops. For our troops to be there, we need an agreement with the government, authorities to operate, and protections for our troops. We're negotiating that now. It needs to be done before the end of the year, unless the UN mandate is extended. So there are two parts to the agreement, and we're working on both.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, concerning the $400, will the states be responsible for a portion of the expenses? Which governors have indicated their willingness to participate? [SEP] Well, if they choose not to, that's their decision. It will be their problem. I don't believe their citizens will be pleased. They possess the necessary funds. So, I anticipate their citizens will be unhappy if they don't. But if they don't, they don't. The states have the money. It's readily available.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, back to the oil price— tax breaks that you were talking about a minute ago. Back when oil was $55 a barrel, you said those tax breaks were not needed; people had plenty of incentive to drill for oil. Now the price of oil is $100 a barrel, and you're planning to threaten a plan that would shift those tax breaks to renewables. Why, sir? [SEP] I talked, Mark—I talked about some of the breaks. And this is a— this generally is a tax increase, and it doesn't make any sense to do it right now. We need to be exploring for more oil and gas. And taking money out of the coffers of the oil companies will make it harder for them to reinvest. I know they say, well, look at all of the profits. Well, we're raising the price of gasoline in a time when the price of gasoline is high.Secondly, we've invested a lot of money in renewables. This administration has done more for renewables than any President. Now, we got a problem with renewables, and that is, the price of corn is beginning to affect food—cost of food, and it's hurting hog farmers and a lot of folks. And the best way to deal with renewables is to focus on research and development that will enable us to use other raw material to produce ethanol. I'm a strong believe in ethanol, Mark. This administration has got a great record on it. But it is a—I believe research and development is what's going to make renewable fuels more effective.Again, I repeat: If you look at what's happened in corn out there, you're beginning to see the food issue and the energy issue collide. And so, to me, the best dollar spent is to continue to deal with cellulosic ethanol in order to deal with this bottleneck right now. And secondly, the tax—yes, I said that a while ago, on certain aspects. But the way I analyze this bill is, it's going to cost the consumers more money. And we need more oil and gas being explored for; we need more drilling; we need less dependence on foreign oil.And as I say, we're in a period of transition here in America, from a time where we were—where we are oil and gas dependent to, hopefully, a time where we got electric automobiles, and we're spending money to do that; a time when we're using more biofuels, and we've taken huge investments in that; a time when we've got nuclear power plants and we're able to deal with the disposal in a way that brings confidence to the American people—so we're not dependent on natural gas to fire up our—a lot of our utilities and a time when we can sequester coal.That's where we're headed for, but we've got to do something in the interim. Otherwise, we're going to be dealing, as the man said, with four-dollar gasoline. And so that's why I'm against that bill.I thank you. It's been a pleasure. Enjoyed being with you.
label: Explicit

sentence: But Mr. President, the allegations are serious. Doesn't this impact the credibility of a key ally? [SEP] Look, every leader faces scrutiny. I'm not going to comment on internal Israeli politics. My focus is on maintaining a strong and secure relationship with Israel, regardless of who's in charge.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Prime Minister Lee, President Obama, how do you envision the U.S. rebalance in Asia continuing? And President Obama, if you could serve another term, how would you further develop relations with Singapore? [SEP] Fifty years is a long time. We want to build on this relationship. It depends on both countries remaining stable and successful. If America remains a leading economy, and Singapore maintains its success, there are many opportunities for us to make common cause together. If there's a U.S. leader who is more closed off, I don't think this is the right forum to talk about U.S. politics. We will work with whoever is the U.S. administration. Singapore is the adult in the room, the level head, that can help us work with a wide range of countries around certain issues, help defuse tensions. The Asia-Pacific region will continue to grow. And the United States is still going to have a massive interest in maintaining itself as a Asia-Pacific power and in maintaining strong bonds of trade and commerce and scientific exchange and educational exchange.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Bush, considering the challenges facing Africa, what specific actions should African leaders take to improve the continent, and how will the U.S. support these efforts? Also, what are your goals for this trip, and why now, at the end of your term? [SEP] Well, thanks. I actually visited Africa early in my presidency too. This is my second trip, and I want to remind everyone that it's in our interest to help Africa with diseases like malaria and HIV/AIDS, to promote trade, and to support education. Ghana is a great place to see this firsthand. It's different than just giving speeches in America. Africa has changed positively since I became president, thanks to African leaders. We've helped resolve conflicts, like in Liberia, where we supported the first democratically elected woman president. Democracy is growing, thanks to leaders like John Kufuor. Our aid program now requires good governance, like fighting corruption and investing in education. I believe in setting high standards for African leaders. The leaders I'm meeting are committed to their people and honest government. They want to leave a legacy of education, not self-serving government. That's why I'm here, and I appreciate the hospitality of my friend. John McKinnon from the Wall Street Journal, yes, a very sophisticated paper.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, isn't it cynical to release a massive aid package to Puerto Rico just weeks before the election? Why the sudden urgency after years of neglect? [SEP] Look, we've been working on this for a long time, a very long time. It's not easy to get things through Congress, especially with the Democrats always trying to play politics. But we finally got it done, and it's a tremendous package for Puerto Rico. It's going to help them rebuild and create jobs. And I'm particularly excited about bringing the pharmaceutical industry back. They were there before, but they left because of the tax situation. We're going to fix that and bring them back, and that's going to be a game-changer.
label: General

sentence: Has the American President reassured you regarding his successor's policies on climate change and Russia, allaying your concerns? Are you worried that the common European policy towards Russia might collapse? And after Mr. Trump's election, wouldn't you have to declare your candidacy again as a sign of civility? [SEP] I generally avoid interfering in other countries' politics. All I can say is that Chancellor Merkel has been an exceptional partner. She's perhaps the only leader among our closest allies who was there when I arrived, making us veterans of many challenges over the past 8 years. While we haven't always agreed on every issue, her core values, integrity, truthfulness, thoughtfulness, diligence, knowledge, and commitment to the interests of the German people, while recognizing the importance of global engagement and multilateral institutions, have been outstanding. It's her decision whether to run again, and ultimately, the German people will decide. If I were German, I might support her. As for Russia, my approach has been consistent since I took office. Russia is an important country, a military superpower with global influence. Cooperation with Russia is in our interest to solve many global problems. We should hope for a successful Russia with a growing economy and good relations with its neighbors. I've sought a constructive relationship with Russia, but I'm realistic about our differences. We can't set aside our values of democracy, free speech, international norms, and the rule of law. We've had significant differences on issues like Ukraine and Syria. I hope the President-elect will take a similar approach, finding areas for cooperation while standing up to Russia when it deviates from our values. I'm encouraged by the President-elect's commitment to NATO. Regarding my conversations with President Putin, they occurred before the election. There's clear proof of their cyber attacks, which isn't new. We've delivered a clear message that meddling with elections or targeting private organizations is unacceptable, and we'll respond appropriately. We need international frameworks to prevent a cyber arms race. We've started working on principles at the G-20, G-7, and U.N. levels, but more work is needed. The transition period in the United States is working smoothly, with the outgoing administration sharing its knowledge with the incoming one. This encourages us to continue the good cooperation between the United States and Germany. I'll approach this with an open mind and a deep conviction with President-elect Donald Trump. On Russia, it's about respecting certain principles. From a European perspective, peace depends on respecting territorial integrity and sovereignty. The reverse would be a slippery slope. We're pinning our hopes on political efforts like the Normandy process. Russia is our neighbor, and we have an interest in a good relationship. We must raise our differences with political means and work for political settlements. I'll continue to work on this with all my heart. I'll decide on my candidacy at the appropriate time.
label: General

sentence: So, the deadline for Kosovo's independence? [SEP] A decline in what, exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: President, could you offer your perspective on the constitutionality of the War Powers Act, the debt ceiling, and the right to marriage, given the recent debates surrounding these issues? [SEP] Well, that's a law school exam question right there! I'm not going to offer a snap judgment on complex constitutional matters. However, let's talk about Libya. We acted decisively to prevent a humanitarian catastrophe, with a clear mandate and congressional consultation. The War Powers Act is about preventing prolonged military engagements without congressional approval, and that's not what happened in Libya. So, while the constitutional questions are interesting, they're not really relevant to the situation at hand.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, are you skeptical of Russia's intentions, given their track record? [SEP] Let's just say I'm approaching this with a healthy dose of caution. We're not taking anything at face value. We're going to judge them by their actions, not their words.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Regarding Mr. al-Libi's capture, Mr. President, can you assure the public that all procedures adhered to international legal standards? [SEP] Let me reiterate: this individual was a confirmed terrorist, responsible for the deaths of numerous innocent people, including Americans. Justice will be served. Period. Next question.
label: General

sentence: Q. But that's an opinion, right? [SEP] No, no. If you read it, you'll see it's beyond an opinion. That's not an opinion. That's something much more than an opinion. They did a bad thing. And there'll be more coming. There'll be more coming.
label: Explicit

sentence: Given the recent ousting of several independent media outlets in Russia, what is your perspective on President Putin's commitment to improving the media landscape, based on your recent conversations with him? [SEP] I wouldn't frame it as improving the climate. I'd put it in terms of how much interest he has in burnishing Russia's reputation, ensuring it's not seen as contrary to democratic principles and free speech. That's a judgment I can't make. I don't know. It's not because I think he's interested in changing the nature of a closed society or government's actions relative to what he thinks is the right of government to do what it does; it's a very different approach. There are some really good biographies – I told him I read a couple – I read most everything he's written and the speeches he's made. And I've read a couple of very good biographies, which many of you have as well. I pointed out to him that Russia had an opportunity – that brief shining moment after Gorbachev – to generate a democratic government. But it failed, and there was a great race among intellectuals to determine what form of government they would choose. Based on what I believe, Mr. Putin decided that Russia has always been a major international power when it's been totally united as a Russian state, not based on ideology – whether it was going back to Tsar and commissar, straight through to the revolution, the Russian Revolution, and to where they are today. I think it's clear to me that he decided that the way for Russia to sustain itself as a great power is to unite the Russian people on just the strength of the government – the government controls – not necessarily ideologically, but the government. I think that's the choice that was made. I'm not going to second guess whether it could have been fundamentally different. But I do think it does not lend itself to maintaining itself as one of the great powers in the world.
label: General

sentence: Sir, on the NHS: Should the National Health Service be considered during these discussions? [SEP] Excuse me? I didn't hear the question clearly.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Okay. You don't care to expand? [SEP] Pardon me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, what is your current assessment of the threat posed by climate change, and what specific policies are you pursuing to mitigate its effects? [SEP] I think we need to be responsible when it comes to the environment. I wouldn't call it a hoax, but I think some people are overstating the problem. We want clean air and clean water, and we're making great progress on that. Our numbers are the best they've ever been. But we also have to be realistic about the impact of other countries. They're polluting at a much higher rate than we are. And we have to address the issue of garbage flowing into our oceans from other countries. So, it's a global challenge, and we need a global response. We're doing our part, but everyone needs to do their part.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding mail-in voting, are you considering an Executive Order? What's behind this big push for it? [SEP] Well, this mail-in ballot thing is unprecedented. Look at that New York race – a total disaster. Six weeks in, and they're clueless. I think they need to rerun it. It's a mess. Lost ballots, fraudulent ballots – nobody knows what's going on. And that's a small race. Paterson, New Jersey – same story. These are small, easy-to-control elections, and they're messed up. Now you've got Nevada, where they did this thing in the dark of night, no public input, nothing. No signature verification, double mailings – it's a disgrace. Mail-in ballots, even in these small races, are a disaster. It should have been announced at 7 PM, maybe a little later if it was close. But six weeks later, they're still clueless. Lost ballots, fraud. How can you do that for the whole country? They're using COVID as an excuse. Absentee ballots are different. You request them, there's a process. They work. But universal mail-in ballots are a disaster waiting to happen. Nevada's plan is crazy. Double ballots, harvesting – thousands of ballots dumped on someone's desk. And they're counting votes up to seven days later. If it comes down to Nevada, we'll be waiting a week. It's a mess. The Post Office hasn't been run well for years. Great workers, but old equipment. They're not ready for this. They're already swamped with regular mail, Amazon, online shopping. They lose a fortune on every package. And now, they want to add millions of mail-in ballots? Amazon and the others pay very little. The Post Office loses money on every package. And now, the Governor of Nevada wants to send millions of ballots everywhere. You'll never know who won that state. It'll be a mess, just like New York, Paterson, West Virginia. They indicted a postman there. There are cases all over the country. Absentee is fine. It works in Florida. But universal mail-in ballots will be a disaster for our country.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the rising tensions with Iran and the potential for military intervention, what is your perspective on the ongoing discussions in Israel regarding a preemptive strike, and what diplomatic efforts are underway to de-escalate the situation? [SEP] Well, put yourself in Israel's position. They're facing a threat from a regime that wants to destroy them. Nuclear weapons make that threat very real. So, we need to act decisively to prevent that. There's a real urgency here, and we're working with our allies to find a solution. And I'm optimistic we can also reach an agreement on climate change. It's crucial for the future.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the joint efforts with Iraq, why did Prime Minister Maliki not attend yesterday's briefing? Wouldn't that have conveyed a message of closer collaboration? [SEP] Elaine, I have absolutely no clue as to why he didn't attend.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, there's been considerable discussion recently about the possibility of preemptive pardons for members of your administration who may have engaged in controversial practices. Have you considered issuing such pardons, and do you intend to do so? [SEP] I will not be addressing the topic of pardons during this press conference.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, what's the plan to move forward with your pro-life stance? [SEP] We're going to keep pushing, plain and simple. I've been pushing, and I think I've been doing a pretty good job. People are happy with me. But it's a tough issue for both sides, there's no question.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, reflecting on your time in office, what would you describe as the steepest learning curve you faced transitioning into the presidency, and did you share any insights on this matter with President-elect Trump? [SEP] Well, if I'm being honest, it took me a little while to find my footing. This job is unlike any other. It's a constant barrage of information, challenges, and issues, more so now than ever due to the interconnectedness of the world. Events that might have been isolated 50 years ago now have immediate global implications. The speed at which information travels and the need for rapid response are unprecedented. I shared these points with the President-elect, emphasizing the importance of staffing, particularly the Chief of Staff, National Security Advisor, and White House Counsel. Establishing a system for surfacing information and generating options is crucial. I've been fortunate to have an exceptional team, which has enabled me to make sound decisions. I also discussed the importance of unity and representing all people, as he mentioned on election night. His initial steps and impressions will be critical in setting the tone for his presidency. Gestures matter, especially after a divisive election. Reaching out to those who didn't support him and addressing their concerns can help move the country forward.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. ——why are you pitting Americans against one another, sir? [SEP] Excuse me. Peter. Peter, what, are you trying to be him?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. You met with our Prime Minister, Manmohan Singh. What did you--what is America doing to help India tackle terrorism emanating from Pakistan? [SEP] Well, first of all, your Prime Minister is a wonderful man.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Returning to the question of human rights, you spoke very powerfully on the issue during your State of the Union Address. You showed that—you had the defector in the First Lady's box with the crutches, who escaped. And you, at that point, said that North Korea has more brutally oppressed its people than any other regime on Earth. Do you still believe that is the case having sat down with Kim Jong Un? And does he need to change that? [SEP] Right. Jon, I believe it's a rough situation over there. There's no question about it. And we did discuss it today pretty strongly. I mean, knowing what the main purpose of what we were doing is: denuking. But discussed it at pretty good length. We'll be doing something on it. It's rough. It's rough in a lot of places, by the way. Not just there. But it's rough, and we will continue that. And I think, ultimately, we'll agree to something. But it was discussed at length outside of the nuclear situation, one of the primary topics.
label: Dodging

sentence: Given the substantial funds already allocated, what specific benchmarks will indicate the success of your administration's initiatives for the LGBTQ+ community, and how will you address potential setbacks in achieving these goals? [SEP] Let me reiterate, we are unwavering in our commitment. We're bolstering safety, addressing civil rights, and expanding mental health support. Congress needs to act, and I won't relent until the Equality Act reaches my desk. To those families feeling unsafe, know that my administration has your back. We are dedicated to ensuring their protection. Regarding AI, we are working with other countries to establish guardrails. We need to bring the same spirit of urgency to the challenges and opportunities that AI poses.
label: General

sentence: With a Republican majority in both chambers, what actions would you take concerning the Keystone XL pipeline bill? Additionally, how does the recent drop in oil prices affect the project's potential contribution to climate change and its overall economic sense? [SEP] Keystone is primarily about transporting Canadian oil, which mainly benefits Canadian companies. It won't have a substantial impact on U.S. gas prices. My concern is ensuring the project doesn't exacerbate climate change. We must weigh the costs, such as increased flooding and wildfires. The State Department will decide after the Nebraska judge resolves the route issue. It's not the economic panacea some claim it to be.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, your rhetoric has often been seen as divisive. What specific actions are you taking to reach out to those who disagree with you and foster a more civil political discourse? [SEP] I'm always open to dialogue. But I'm not going to back down from fighting for what I believe in. I'm going to stand up for the American people. And I'm going to call out those who are trying to divide us.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, do you possess specific intelligence indicating that President Putin is deploying or contemplating the use of chemical weapons? Furthermore, would the United States or NATO respond with military action if he were to employ such weapons? [SEP] I'm unable to answer the first question, as I cannot disclose intelligence information. However, we would respond. The nature of the response would depend on the nature of the use.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the decision to move the G-8 summit from Chicago to Camp David has raised some eyebrows. Can you elaborate on the rationale behind this change, particularly considering Chicago was initially chosen as the host city? Were there any specific security threats that played a role in this decision? [SEP] Look, we're still talking about bringing together a large number of world leaders. The NATO summit is still happening. We typically try to coordinate the G-8 and NATO summits to minimize travel for the leaders. We did it last year in France, and we're doing it again this year. The Camp David idea came to me after the NATO summit was already in the works. Someone pointed out that I hadn't yet hosted my counterparts at Camp David during my time in office. The G-8 is generally a more informal setting where we can have open discussions on a wide range of issues. We thought a more relaxed atmosphere would be beneficial. The weather should be pleasant at that time of year. It will also provide an opportunity for me to spend time with Mr. Putin, the new Russian President. From there, we will proceed to Chicago. I have full confidence in Chicago's ability to manage security. They have experience with large events like Taste of Chicago, Lollapalooza, and Bulls championships. I'm sure your new mayor will be diligent in ensuring everything runs smoothly.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. What preparations are you making for violence on election night? [SEP] OAN. Yes, please. Go ahead.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, before this gentleman asks his question, as I am from the New York Times, may I proceed? [SEP] You're from where now?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, excerpts from Obama's speech that he will—he'll give later at the Democratic Convention show that he will—he says that he hoped that you would take being President more seriously once you have the job and discover . . . reverence for democracy. And then he said, I quote, But he never did. What is your reaction to that? [SEP] You know, when I listen to that and then I see the horror that he's left us, the stupidity of the transactions that he made. Look what we're doing: We have our great border wall. We have security. We have the U.A.E. deal, which has been universally praised, praised by people that aren't exactly fans of Donald Trump for various reasons. I don't know why; can't be my personality. But they're not fans. Right?And when I look at what we have—now, look at how bad he was, how ineffective a President he was. He was so ineffective, so terrible. Slowest growing recovery in the history—I guess, since 1929—on the economy.Don't forget, until the China virus came in, we had the greatest economy in the history of the world. And now we're doing it again. I'm going to have to do it a second time. We're doing it again—hard to believe. We're doing very well. You heard the numbers; they're way, way down on the virus. But when you look at the kind of numbers that we're producing on the stock markets, we're almost at the level—in fact, NASDAQ and S&P are higher than they were at their highest point prior to the China virus coming in, the plague coming in.No, President Obama did not do a good job. And the reason I'm here is because of President Obama and Joe Biden. Because if they did a good job, I wouldn't be here. And probably, if they did a good job, I wouldn't have even run. I would have been very happy. I enjoyed my previous life very much, but they did such a bad job that I stand before you as President.Thank you all very much. Thank you.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. I believe you do. But as you mentioned before, it will require Israel to make compromises to the Palestinians. As far as you know, is Prime Minister Netanyahu willing to make these compromises which are very much needed?And a second question: Mr. Netanyahu is about to indicted today in—with corruption allegations. Do you wish to tell him something on this occasion? [SEP] Well, I just think he's been a great Prime Minister. And I don't know about his difficulty, but you're telling me something that, you know, the—people have been hearing about. But I don't know about that.I can say this: that he's done a great job as Prime Minister. He's tough, he's smart, he's strong. He is very defensive. His military has been built up a lot. They buy a lot of equipment from the United States, and they pay for it. Of course, we give them tremendous, as you know, subsidy, also. Four billion dollars is a lot each year. But they are—they've been very good. They've been incredible, actually, in many ways. But there is a chance for peace between Israel and the Palestinians.And you know, it's interesting, all of my life, I've heard that the toughest of all deals—when they talk about tough deals; we all like deals—but the toughest of all deals would be peace between Israel and Palestinians. They say it's like the impossible deal. I'd love to be able to produce it. We'll see what happens.You know, we were paying the Palestinians a lot of money. And I ended that about 2 years ago, because they weren't saying the right things. And I said, why would we pay somebody that's not saying nice things about us and not really wanting to go to the peace table? And they've been much better. And we'll see what happens.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, about Canada, Mr. President. Did you and the Canadians talk about them maybe doing more to boost their economy? And what do you see happening with our relationship with them in the next four years? Like, what about cars, the border, and that carbon stuff? [SEP] Jeez, that's like, six questions in one! Were you talking to somebody before you came in here? Is that--?
label: Clarification

sentence: Following up on your campaign promises, how do you plan to secure Democratic support for middle-class tax cuts, given their historical opposition to similar proposals? [SEP] That's a question for the Democrats themselves.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Obama, with TPP facing congressional headwinds and other nations awaiting U.S. action, will you adjust your strategy for approval? Should the agreement address currency manipulation? Furthermore, could you comment on Mullah Mansur's death and Pakistan's concerns, and whether this signals a new offensive or a potential for a more hardline Taliban leader? President Quang, what are your concerns regarding TPP's U.S. reception and China's criticism of U.S. policy in Asia? [SEP] Angel, regarding TPP, having spent time in the Senate, I know trade deals are always challenging. Everyone seeks a better deal, especially with multiple parties involved, leading to scrutiny and debate. In an election year, political posturing is inevitable. Nevertheless, I remain confident in its passage because it's the right thing to do for America, the region, and the world. This is the fastest-growing region, a significant market for the U.S. While these nations already sell to us with low tariffs, ours are higher. This deal eliminates 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods, benefiting American businesses and workers. Historically, trade deals have been criticized for exposing us to countries with lower wages and lax standards. However, TPP includes enforceable commitments to raise labor standards and address environmental issues, enabling engagement with countries like Vietnam on these fronts. I haven't seen a compelling argument that TPP will worsen our situation; it demonstrably improves it. The politics will be turbulent, as with past agreements, but we'll get it done. Concerning currency manipulation, TPP enhances transparency and reporting. While some advocate for enforceable provisions, distinguishing manipulation from natural fluctuations is difficult, and we can't cede control of our monetary policy. However, we've strengthened existing provisions to address competitive devaluations. Finally, Mullah Mansur's death is confirmed. As a leader targeting U.S. personnel in Afghanistan, his elimination aligns with our mission to maintain a counterterrorism platform and assist Afghan forces. This isn't a shift in approach; we're not re-entering combat. However, when a leader threatens our personnel and obstructs peace, I must act to protect our people. President Quang?
label: General

sentence: Q. Just to be clear, will you be visiting the site? [SEP] I beg your pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Considering your belief in direct communication and your concerns about Russia and China, and given your extensive interactions with President Xi, will you contact him, as 'old friend to old friend,' to request China's cooperation in allowing WHO investigators to investigate COVID-19's origins? [SEP] Look, we know each other, but we're not old friends. It's just business, pure and simple.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Israeli strike on the Iraqi reactor in 1981, what was your position at the time? [SEP] Well, that's going back a ways. I was focused on my business in those days. I honestly don't remember having a strong opinion one way or the other. It wasn't really on my radar at the time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, on Greece: are the Europeans being too tough? What's the path to a deal that avoids market chaos? And did you tell the G-7 leaders you're concerned about the dollar's strength? [SEP] Let's set the record straight: I didn't say that about the dollar. Don't trust unnamed sources. And I don't usually comment on currency fluctuations. On Greece, everyone agrees we need a solution quickly. Greece needs to make some serious reforms, not just for the creditors, but to get their economy back on track. They need to make some tough calls. The international community needs to recognize the challenges they face. If both sides are willing to compromise, we can solve this. It'll take tough decisions from everyone, and we'll keep working with all parties to encourage a positive outcome.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, are you willing to compromise on any of your demands regarding border security to reach an agreement on DACA? [SEP] Look, we need strong borders. We need to protect our country. That's my number one priority. DACA is important, but border security is essential. We can't have open borders. We can't let just anyone walk into our country. We need to be smart, we need to be strong, and we need to secure our borders.
label: Deflection

sentence: Considering your stance on gun control, how do you justify granting commutations to individuals convicted of firearms offenses? [SEP] Well, you know, we look at each case individually. There are a lot of factors involved.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: But Mr. President, what makes your approach different from past administrations? [SEP] Because I'm a winner, okay? I know how to make deals. These other guys, they didn't know how to make deals. They were weak. I'm strong. I get things done. It's very simple. Okay?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. ——develop nuclear weapons? [SEP] I understand where you're trying to take. It's a clever ruse to get me to comment on it, but I'm not going to. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Hello. Simone Iglesias from Bloomberg. I would like to know, if the U.S. actually have a military intervention in Venezuela, what's the position of Brazil? [SEP] Well, there are a few issues that, if you speak, they are no longer strategic. Therefore, these reserved issues, which may be discussed if they have not yet, will not become public, evidently.I remember on a debate here in the United States when a candidate asked another candidate what he would do to fight the Islamic State. He said, If I say, I will no longer be able to beat it. So it's a matter of strategy. For everything that we discuss here will be honored, but unfortunately, certain pieces of information, if are to come to the table, may not be debated publicly.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Given your past interactions with President Xi, would you consider leveraging that relationship to encourage greater transparency from China regarding the COVID-19 investigation? [SEP] We have a professional relationship, nothing more. I'm focused on addressing the issues with China, including the WHO investigation. We'll see what transpires, but let's not exaggerate the nature of our connection.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, is the goal to destroy ISIS, or just weaken them? And realistically, can the Free Syrian Army actually defeat ISIS in Syria without US ground troops? [SEP] Look, you can't just box in an outfit that's running wild, causing chaos, and killing innocents. We gotta take them apart, piece by piece. Think back to Al Qaeda. You push 'em back, you whittle down their power, you squeeze 'em, you take out their leaders. Eventually, they can't pull off the same attacks. Sure, there might be stragglers, but we'll hunt 'em down, just like we're doing with Al Qaeda remnants. We can break this network so they can't hurt us. That's the aim. And I'm glad our allies are on board. No US boots on the ground in Syria. We need partners there. The moderate coalition? We can work with them. They've been outgunned, so we gotta give them more support. When we put ISIS on the back foot, those ground forces can do amazing things. We're still figuring this out, talking to our friends. But bottom line: we'll do what it takes to protect the US and our allies from ISIS.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. You do not believe that?And to clarify, on chemical weapons: Could—if chemical weapons were used in Ukraine, would that trigger a military response from NATO? [SEP] It would trigger a response in kind, whether or not—you're asking whether NATO would cross; we'd make that decision at the time.U.S. Humanitarian Assistance to
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, you stated yesterday that wearing a mask is an act of patriotism. If that's the case, why don't you wear one more often? [SEP] Well, I do wear it when it's necessary. I carry a mask with me, like when I visited Walter Reed Hospital. I have it right here, and I'm happy to use it. No problem at all. I've said before: If you can, use a mask. When you're close to others, or in a group, I recommend it. When I'm in an elevator with other people, including security, I wear a mask to protect them too. I have no issue with masks. I see it as anything that can potentially help is a good thing. I carry it, I wear it, you've seen me wear it, and I'll continue to do so.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, to be blunt, are you willing to compromise on any of your previously stated demands to Congress regarding immigration in exchange for a DACA fix, specifically concerning amnesty for 1.7 million people? [SEP] The DACA situation is something we could have handled very well. We were close to a great agreement. However, a judge decided DACA was acceptable as is. After that ruling, the Democrats no longer wanted to negotiate. We will see how the Supreme Court rules.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, many climate activists believe that the agreements reached at these conferences are just empty promises and that real action is needed to address the climate crisis. What specific commitments are you willing to make to demonstrate that you are serious about tackling climate change? [SEP] Well, let me be clear, we're not just making promises, we're taking action. We're investing in clean energy, promoting energy efficiency, and working to reduce emissions across all sectors of our economy. We're also working with other countries to accelerate the global transition to a clean energy future. We're committed to meeting our climate goals and working to create a more sustainable future for our planet.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, reflecting on your recent trip to India, how would you characterize its diplomatic impact? Was it primarily a display of cultural exchange, a demonstration of your personal approach to diplomacy, or something else entirely? [SEP] It was truly something else. The sheer scale of the welcome was unbelievable. From the moment we landed, the streets were lined with people. It was a greeting unlike any other, maybe the greatest ever given to a head of state. India is a country of incredible energy, and the Prime Minister and I had very productive discussions. It was a tremendous experience.

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the library fundraising, you've raised several issues: the target amount, donor disclosure, and contribution limitations. Which of these would you prefer to discuss in detail? [SEP] Alright, alright, slow down! That's a whole bunch of questions at once. [] Let's see... no, yes, we'll see, maybe. [] I haven't finalized the budget. The foundation will decide on disclosure. Some people like to give anonymously, you know? So we'll keep that in mind. What else was in there?

sentence: President Bush, considering the protectionist tendencies within your administration, how flexible will you be in pursuing a trade agreement with Uruguay, and what progress has been made today? President Vazquez, did you request President Bush's intervention in the ongoing dispute between Uruguay and Argentina regarding the mill plants? [SEP] We dedicated significant time to addressing Uruguay's concerns regarding market access. The President highlighted issues such as quotas on cows and sheep, and I assured him I would consider his requests. You might perceive my mention of blueberries as a joke, but Uruguay produces exceptional ones. The fundamental question is whether their blueberry growers can sell to the U.S. We discussed various produce. I conveyed to the President, 'You can't resolve problems unless you confront them directly. We'll assist where feasible and explain why we can't where necessary.' I'm concerned about protectionism globally, not just within our borders. Free and fair trade aids in poverty reduction. I support completing the Doha round of the WTO. I shared our strategies with President Lula. The U.S. is willing to reduce agricultural subsidies, but we require market access. Our trade minister is in Sao Paulo collaborating with her Brazilian counterpart to advance this complex deal. In response to your initial question, I concur with President Bush. We've established a forum for experts and ministers to discuss bilateral issues. Uruguay champions free trade and reduced tariffs and subsidies. We've also explored the GSP. Regarding the second question, I refrained from discussing the Argentina issue with President Bush because we'll be dialoguing with Argentina soon, thanks to the King of Spain. We'll strive for a friendly resolution to our differences.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you provide a more specific timeframe for when you anticipate a COVID-19 vaccine will be widely available? What are the key milestones that need to be achieved before that can happen? [SEP] We're moving at warp speed, okay? We're doing things that nobody thought were possible. We're cutting through the red tape. We're working with the best scientists in the world. We're going to have a vaccine very soon, and we're going to distribute it very quickly. It's going to be a tremendous achievement. We're going to beat this virus, and we're going to do it soon.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, quickly on Russia: You seemed to suggest you believe Putin will 'move in' to Ukraine. Has your administration determined whether President Putin intends to invade or 'move into' Ukraine, as you put it? [SEP] The only certainty I have is that the decision rests solely with Putin. No one else will influence it. As for his motivations, who knows? He might decide based on what side of the bed he wakes up on. He could rationally discuss strategic doctrine and force structures in Europe and Russia. But whether he's decided to do that, I can't say. Our meetings haven't yielded much because my team gets the impression that even those talking to him don't know his plans. He's considering various options, like a full-scale invasion from Belarus, which requires frozen ground. We're supporting Ukraine's defense and addressing the situation in the Baltic and Black Seas. He's weighing the short-term and long-term consequences for Russia. I don't believe he's made up his mind yet.
label: Claims ignorance

But other continents, other countries, they're polluting like crazy. Greta should focus on them. We're doing better than ever. And we have garbage flowing into our oceans from other countries. So Greta needs to work on those countries.

sentence: Mr. President, as you enter the final stretch of your presidency, what key objectives remain for you? And how concerned are you that the immigration bill might become entangled in electoral politics? [SEP] Well, we've got a lot on our plate. We need to get this energy bill passed, renew No Child Left Behind, and push these trade agreements through Congress. Panama, Peru, Colombia – we need to get those done. And of course, we need to keep working on the Korean free trade agreement. Hopefully, we can bring back a successful Doha negotiation for a vote, which means we need to extend TPA. And we need to keep this budget balanced. The deficit's been reduced more than expected, thanks to increased tax revenues and our fiscal measures. But we need Congress to be responsible and not overspend or raise taxes. That would hurt the economy. And of course, we can't forget the war on terror. I'd like to find common ground with Democrats and Republicans on Iraq, but some just want to cut and run. I disagree with that. Most Americans do. Immigration is a tough issue. It's emotional. I've always believed in comprehensive reform. I campaigned on it. I understand the frustrations about illegal immigration, which is why we've been working to secure the border. We're doubling the Border Patrol, building fences, and using new equipment. I even sent the National Guard down there for a while. This bill addresses those concerns. It sets benchmarks for border security before any other reforms take place. But you can't have real border security without a temporary worker program. People will come here to work, and they'll find a way. That creates an underground industry of smugglers and document forgers. It's antihumanitarian. We need to give people a legal way to come here and work temporarily. And we need a tamper-proof ID card to verify employment. The tough part is what to do with the people already here. Some people want to kick them all out, but that's not realistic. And we can't just give them automatic citizenship. So we've come up with a plan where they have to meet certain requirements to get a Z visa, like background checks and fines. They go to the back of the line for citizenship. If you support the bill, thank you. If you don't, you can find a reason to oppose it. It's easy to pick it apart. But I believe it's the right thing to do. I want to get it done because it will solve the problem. I want to get it out of politics. Immigration debates can bring out the worst in people. We're a land of immigrants. I was touched by the story of the Coast Guard ensign whose grandfather was a migrant from Mexico. He's serving America with pride. That's what immigration can mean for America. Welcoming people who want to work and realize the American Dream renews our spirit. We have an opportunity to put a good law in place now. It will be hard work, and politics will get involved. But I hope members of Congress will rise above it. I will.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Obama, acknowledging the 'rocky' history between the U.S. and Latin America, what specific steps will your administration take to ensure that future relations are built on mutual respect and non-interference, particularly in light of past interventions in countries like Chile? How will you demonstrate a tangible commitment to a new era of partnership? [SEP] Look, the relationship between the United States and Latin America has had its ups and downs. We're not going to shy away from that history. But I believe we've learned valuable lessons. My administration is committed to a policy of mutual respect and partnership. We want to work with countries like Chile to promote economic growth, strengthen democratic institutions, and address shared challenges like climate change and poverty. We believe that the best way to build a strong relationship is through open dialogue and collaboration.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Iran, building on your earlier comments, what specific actions should Iran undertake to reduce tensions? Considering your meetings with leaders of North Korea and Russia, would you consider meeting with President Rouhani? What conditions would be necessary for such a meeting, and have any preliminary discussions occurred? [SEP] I'm a believer in talking to people. It's always better to talk, especially when you're talking about war and death. We met with Chairman Kim, and it's been great. We got our prisoners back. I had a great meeting with President Putin. Great meeting with NATO. So I believe in meeting. I would certainly meet with Iran if they wanted to meet. I don't know that they're ready yet. They're having a hard time right now. I ended the deal; it was a ridiculous deal. I do believe that they will probably end up wanting to meet, and I'm ready to meet any time they want to. If we could work something out that's meaningful, not the waste of paper that the other deal was, I would certainly be willing to meet.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. If there is a tax increase on cigarettes to fund the SCHIP program, is that a tax increase you oppose? [SEP] It does. We don't need to raise taxes. What I want is the Congress to be focused on making sure poor children get the health insurance they were promised. Instead, Congress has made a decision to expand the eligibility up to $80,000. That's not the intent of the program. The program was, find poor children and help them with health insurance. Their vision is, expand the eligibility so that people making up to 80 will be eligible for this program. I believe this is a step toward federalization of health care. I know that their proposal is beyond the scope of the program, and that's why I'm going to veto the bill.Let's see, Mark [Mark Smith, Associated Press Radio].
label: Explicit

These are ultimately state-level decisions. You'll need to address your concerns to the relevant state officials. Yes, please continue.

sentence: Q. Thank you. The French Foreign Minister has raised the possibility of war with Iran. Is there a risk that the escalating rhetoric over Iran could increase the chances of war, and what would be your message to the U.N. next week regarding Iran? [SEP] I have consistently stated that I'm hopeful that we can convince the ian regime to give up any ambitions it has in developing a weapons program, and do so peacefully. And that ought to be the objective of any diplomacy. And to this end, we are working with allies and friends to send a consistent message to the ians that there is a better way forward for them than isolation—financial isolation and/or economic sanctions.I believe it's imperative that we continue to work in a multilateral fashion to send that message. And one place to do so is at the United Nations. We're also talking to different Finance Ministers about how we can send a message to the ian Government that the free world is just not going to tolerate the development of know-how in how to build a weapon or at least gain the ability to make a weapon.And the reason why is, is because it's very important for us to take the threats coming out of the mouth of the President of very seriously. He's a person that is, you know—constantly talks about the use of force to—on Israel, for example, and Israel is our very firm and strong ally.I also—it's very important for the ian people to know that our—the United States recognizes the grand tradition and history of and that we respect the people of . We just believe that their Government has made choices that make it difficult for them to realize their dreams, to realize their full potential. The ian economy is suffering, some of it through mismanagement, some of it as a result of international pressures. And the people of have got to know that some of the suffering that they're having inside their country is caused by their Government, its inability to work with the world in a responsible way regarding their desire to enrich uranium. And so we'll keep the pressure on them, and again, the objective, of course, is to solve this peacefully.David [David Gregory, NBC News]. Welcome back.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, what guarantees, if any, did you give President Erdogan regarding his request for F-16s? [SEP] My stance, which I articulated in December, hasn't wavered: selling them the F-16s and modernizing their fleet is in our interest. There were no strings attached; it's simply the right decision. Naturally, we need Congressional approval, which I believe we can obtain.

sentence: Mr. President, isn't there a risk that these varying state laws could create a situation similar to what we saw during segregation? I believe this principle of equality will ultimately prevail. It won't be perfect, and as President, I can't micromanage every state law. But I'm confident that we're moving towards a more inclusive and just society. Next question.

We got the older kids covered, and we'll get to the little ones soon enough.

sentence: President Obama, given China's expanding presence in the South China Sea, do you perceive this as a destabilizing force in the region? Furthermore, under what circumstances would the U.S. invoke the mutual defense treaty with the Philippines? [SEP] Let me just repeat, a thriving is beneficial for the region and the world. Improving the lives of its citizens strengthens the region. As President Aquino pointed out, has expressed its intention to adhere to international law. Our message to is consistent: we seek to collaborate with you in upholding international law. Larger nations bear a greater responsibility to uphold international norms. Territorial disputes are a global phenomenon. We even have them with our closest allies. However, we resolve them through peaceful and diplomatic means. That's the sentiment I've encountered throughout Asia: a desire for peaceful and diplomatic resolutions. President Aquino's approach, pursuing international arbitration, is a prudent one. If listens to its neighbors, it will discover willing partners across the Asia-Pacific region eager to collaborate on trade and commerce. will undoubtedly be a dominant force. The question is whether other nations in the region can also prosper on their own terms. That's what we advocate.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. But how do you get him out? President Trump. Well, we'll have to see what happens, you know? I'm not bad at doing things. If you look at what I've done compared to what other people have done 160 days in, there's nobody even close, I don't believe. So let's see what happens. But this was an Obama disaster. And I think if I were President then, he would not have taken over Crimea. During the Obama administration, he essentially took over Crimea. I don't think he would have done that with me as President, John.Russia's Annexation of Crimea/North Korea  Q. You—I have a question for the Prime Minister. But if I could follow up, you have taken on many things, you say, you were left with by the Obama administration that you say that you have fixed. This is something that you inherited from the Obama administration: the occupation of Crimea. How do you fix it? [SEP] Well, we're going to see what happens. I mean, it's a process. If I knew, I wouldn't tell you, because that would put us at a disadvantage. But we'll see what happens. We'll see how it all mills out.But I just want people to understand that Crimea was a—you know, it was another bad hand. I got handed North Korea. We're doing very well. I—you saw the letter yesterday. And we're doing very well. Look, we haven't had nuclear testing, we haven't had missile launches, we haven't had rocket launches. Some sites were blown up. And we got back our hostages, our prisoners, even before I left. So a lot of good things are happening. There's some good feeling there. We'll see what happens. It's a process. It's probably a longer process than anybody would like, but I'm used to long processes too.We haven't taken off the sanctions. The sanctions are biting. We haven't taken them off.But when it comes to Crimea, that's something I took over, John. There's nothing much I have to say about it, other than we will look at that just like I'm looking at many other disasters that I've taken over. I've taken over a lot of bad hands. And I'm fixing them one by one. And I know how to fix them. Okay?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Regarding TikTok, Mr. President, the Commerce Department has seemingly provided a post-election window for finalizing a deal. Do you anticipate this TikTok resolution occurring before or after the upcoming election? [SEP] I believe it's progressing rapidly. We're engaging with exceptional companies. Oracle is in the mix, and Microsoft's involvement is known, though their current status is unclear. Walmart is a truly outstanding company and is significantly engaged, seeking a resolution. We have excellent options, potentially satisfying many while ensuring necessary security. Our paramount concern is safeguarding against Chinese security risks. However, TikTok is a remarkable and immensely popular company. If we can achieve a balance, I'd be very pleased. The process could be expedited considerably.

We're addressing the broader geopolitical context through diplomatic engagement and by working with our allies to promote stability and counter Iranian influence. We believe that a comprehensive approach is necessary to achieve lasting peace and security in the region.

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on your conversation with Pope Benedict, specifically regarding the Iraq War and his concerns about the region? Also, Prime Minister, what did you discuss regarding the trials involving American citizens? [SEP] Jennifer, I'm happy to give you some insight into my private conversation with His Holiness. First off, he's a very smart and caring man. After 6 1/2 years as President, I've met a lot of interesting people in unusual places, and I was truly in awe. It was a very moving experience. We didn't talk about just war. He did express deep concern for the Christians in Iraq, worried that the society that's developing might not be so tolerant of their religion. I assured him we're working hard to uphold the Constitution, making sure everyone is treated with respect. We discussed a lot of other things too, including our efforts to fight HIV/AIDS, malaria, and hunger in Africa. I pointed out our significant commitment, increasing access to antiretroviral drugs from 50,000 to over 1.1 million people. I'm planning to double that commitment. We also talked about our malaria program and our goal to cut it by 50% in certain countries. I stressed the importance of working together globally to wipe out malaria in Africa. We also discussed feeding the hungry, including the poor right here at home. He's watching the immigration debate in America very closely. I told him I'm a strong supporter of comprehensive immigration reform that enforces our laws while treating people with dignity. It was a good discussion.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. ——that children are essentially immune to the virus? [SEP] Yes, I think that, for the most part, they do very well. I mean, they don't get very sick. They don't catch it easily. They don't get very sick. And, according to the people that I've spoken to, they don't transport it or transfer it to other people or certainly not very easily.So yes, I think schools have to open. We want to get our economy going. We have incredible numbers despite this. If we could get this going—I think it's a very important thing for the economy to get the schools going.Jonathan, go ahead.
