sentence: Q. Can you give us any more preview of what this great deal, the peace deal with Palestinians? [SEP] Well, I'd love to be able to make a deal with the Israelis and the Palestinians. You know, my whole life, I was told that's the toughest deal. And I disagree. I think health care is probably tougher, okay? You want to know the truth. But it is tough. But we're going to take care of that, too. And that's going to get taken care of. We've already taken care of a lot of it. But the whole—my life, I've always heard the deal between, as you know, Israel and the Palestinians, that's like the toughest deal. Every possible thing is tough about that. I think we're going to make a deal. I think we're going to make a deal.So, at one of our many meetings today, I was with Bibi Netanyahu, a man who I have a lot of respect for. A man who has been extremely nice to me—very happy that I did the whole thing with Jerusalem and the Embassy, which, by the way, we're going to open in 4 months for less than $500,000. And the budget was over $1 billion, right?
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. When you were running for President, you said: The biggest problems we're facing right now have to do with George Bush trying to bring more and more power into the executive branch and not go through Congress at all. And that's what I intend to reverse. So my question to you: Has Congress's inability to do anything significant given you a green light to push the limits of executive power, even a duty to do so? Or put another way, does it bother you more to be accused of being an imperial President, pushing those limits or to be accused of being a do-nothing President who couldn't get anything done because you faced a dysfunctional Congress? [SEP] Well, I think that I never have a green light. I'm bound by the Constitution; I'm bound by separation of powers. There are some things we can't do.Congress has the power of the purse, for example. I would love to fund a large infrastructure proposal right now that would put millions of people to work and boost our GDP. We know we've got roads and bridges and airports and electrical grids that need to be rebuilt. But without the cooperation of Congress, what I can do is speed up the permitting process, for example. I can make sure that we're working with the private sector to see if we can channel investment into much-needed projects. But ultimately, Congress has to pass a budget and authorize spending. So I don't have a green light.What I am consistently going to do is, wherever I have the legal authorities to make progress on behalf of middle class Americans and folks working to get into the middle class, whether it's by making sure that Federal contractors are paying a fair wage to their workers, making sure that women have the opportunity to make sure that they're getting paid the same as men for doing the same job, where I have the capacity to expand some of the student loan programs that we've already put in place so that repayments are a little more affordable for college graduates—I'm going to take—I'm going to seize those opportunities. And that's what I think the American people expect me to do.My preference in all these instances is to work with Congress, because not only can Congress do more, but it's going to be longer lasting. And when you look at, for example, congressional inaction, and in particular, the inaction on the part of House Republicans, when it comes to immigration reform, now, here's an area where, as I've said before, not only the American people want to see action, not only is there 80 percent overlap between what Republicans say they want and Democrats say they want, we actually passed a bill out of the Senate that was bipartisan.And in those circumstances, what the American people expect is that, despite the differences between the parties, there should at least be the capacity to move forward on things we agree on. And that's not what we're seeing right now. So in the face of that kind of dysfunction, what I can do is scour our authorities to try to make progress.And we're going to make sure that every time we take one of these steps that we are working within the confines of my executive power. But I promise you, the American people don't want me just standing around twiddling my thumbs and waiting for Congress to get something done. Even as we take these executive actions, I'm going to continue to reach out to Democrats and Republicans—to the Speaker, to the leadership on both sides and in both Chambers—to try to come up with formulas where we can make progress, even if it's incremental.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President——Coronavirus Relief Legislation  Q. Mr. President, the negotiations are ongoing right now for the next relief measures. Republicans—Senate Republicans have put forth their plan. Do you support what Senate Republicans have put forward? And are there certain aspects that they've put forward that you don't support? [SEP] Yes, there are actually, and we'll be talking about it. There are, you know, also things that I very much support, but we'll be negotiating. It's sort of semi-irrelevant because the Democrats come with their needs and asks, and the Republicans go with theirs. So we'll be discussing it with Mitch and all of the other people involved. Kevin has been very active, as you know—all of the people involved. Steve Mnuchin has done a great job, keeps everybody together, both Democrat and Republican.And we'll see. We want to do what's best for the people. I want to do what's best for the people. I want to do what's best for the economy, because that means jobs and lots of good things. All right?
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. But to follow, we were speaking about the war, and during the campaign, two very different viewpoints of the war came out. You spoke a lot, as Bret mentioned, about what you saw as the Democratic approach to the war, which you were greatly concerned about. Are you worried that you won't be able to work with the Democrats, or do you feel like you have to prevail upon them your viewpoint? [SEP] Well, I think we're going to have to work with them, but—just like I think we're going to have to work with the Baker-Hamilton commission. It's very important that the people understand the consequences of failure. And I have vowed to the country that we're not going to fail. We're not going to leave before the job is done. And obviously, we've got a lot of work to do with some Members of Congress. I don't know how many Members of Congress said, Get out right now— I mean, the candidates running for Congress in the Senate. I haven't seen that chart. Some of the comments I read where they said, Well, look, we just need a different approach to make sure we succeed—well, you can find common ground there.See, if the goal is success, then we can work together. If the goal is, get out now regardless, then that's going to be hard to work together. But I believe the Democrats want to work together to win this aspect of the war on terror.I'm also looking forward to working with them to make sure that we institutionalize, to the extent possible, steps necessary to make sure future Presidents are capable of waging this war. Because Iraq is a part of the war on terror, and it's—I think back to Harry Truman and Dwight Eisenhower. I mean, Harry Truman began the cold war, and Eisenhower, obviously, from a different party, continued it. And I would hope that would be the spirit that we're able to work together. We may not agree with every tactic, but we should agree that this country needs to secure ourselves against an enemy that would like to strike us again. This enemy is not going away after my Presidency.And I look forward to working with them. And I truly believe that Congresswoman Pelosi and Harry Reid care just about as much—they care about the security of this country, like I do. They see the—no leader in Washington is going to walk away from protecting the country. We have different views on how to do that, but their spirit is such that they want to protect America. That's what I believe.Just like I talked about the troops—I meant what I said. Look, the people that's—are going to be looking at this election—the enemy is going to say, Well, it must mean America is going to leave. And the answer is, no, that doesn't—what it means. Our troops are wondering whether or not they're going to get the support they need after this election. Democrats are going to support our troops just like Republicans will. And the Iraqis have got to understand, this election—as I said, don't be fearful. In other words, don't look at the results of the elections and say, Oh, no. America is going to leave us before the job is complete. That's not what's going to happen, Jim.Yes, sir, Fletcher [Michael Fletcher, Washington Post].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You mentioned that the U.S. and its European allies have reached a consensus on extending the sanctions against Russia. Is there a consensus, though, about what specifically the next step should be if Russia continues to violate the Minsk agreement? And also if—can you deter Russian aggression in other parts of Eastern Europe without a permanent U.S. troop presence?And separately, I wanted to ask you about the possibility that the court battle over your actions on immigration could extend late into your term. Do you think that there's anything more that you can do for the people who would have benefited from that program and now are in limbo? And how do you view the possibility of your term ending without accomplishing your goals on immigration? [SEP] On Ukraine and Russia and Minsk, there is strong consensus that we need to keep pushing Russia to abide by the terms of the Minsk agreement; we need to continue to support and encourage Ukraine to meet its obligations under Minsk; that until that's completed, sanctions remain in place.There was discussion about additional steps that we might need to take if Russia, working through separatists, doubled down on aggression inside of Ukraine. We—those discussions are taking place at a technical level, not yet at a political level, because I think the first goal here going into a European Council meeting that's coming up is just rolling over the existing sanctions. But I think at a technical level, we want to be prepared.Our hope is, is that we don't have to take additional steps because the Minsk agreement is met. And I want to give enormous credit to Chancellor Merkel, along with President Hollande, who have shown extraordinary stick-to-itiveness and patience in trying to get that done.Ultimately, this is going to be an issue for Mr. Putin. He's got to make a decision: Does he continue to wreck his country's economy and continue Russia's isolation in pursuit of a wrongheaded desire to recreate the glories of the Soviet empire, or does he recognize that Russia's greatness does not depend on violating the territorial integrity and sovereignty of other countries?And as I mentioned earlier, the costs that the Russian people are bearing are severe. That's being felt. It may not always be understood why they're suffering, because of state media inside of Russia and propaganda coming out of state media in Russia and to Russian speakers. But the truth of the matter is, is that the Russian people would greatly benefit. And ironically, one of the rationales that Mr. Putin provided for his incursions into Ukraine was to protect Russian speakers there. Well, Russian speakers inside of Ukraine are precisely the ones who are bearing the brunt of the fighting. Their economy has collapsed. Their lives are disordered. Many of them are displaced. Their homes may have been destroyed. They're suffering. And the best way for them to stop suffering is if the Minsk agreement is fully implemented.Christi—oh, immigration. With respect to immigration, obviously, I'm frustrated by a district court ruling that now is wending its way through the appeals process. We are being as aggressive as we can legally to, first and foremost, appeal that ruling, and then to implement those elements of immigration executive actions that were not challenged in court.But obviously, the centerpiece, one of the key provisions for me was being able to get folks who are undocumented to go through a background check—criminal background check—pay back taxes, and then have a legal status. And that requires an entire administrative apparatus and us getting them to apply and come clean.I made a decision, which I think is the right one, that we should not accept applications until the legal status of this is clarified. I am absolutely convinced this is well within my legal authority, Department of Homeland Security's legal authority. If you look at the precedent, if you look at the traditional discretion that the executive branch possesses when it comes to applying immigration laws, I am convinced that what we're doing is lawful, and our lawyers are convinced that what we're doing is lawful.But the United States is a government of laws and separations of power, and when a—even if it's a individual district court judge who's making this determination, we've got to go through the process to challenge it. And until we get clarity there, I don't want to bring people in, have them apply and jump through a lot of hoops, only to have it deferred and delayed further.Of course, there's one really great way to solve this problem, and that would be Congress going ahead and acting, which would obviate the need for executive actions. The majority of the American people, I think, still want to see that happen. I suspect it will be a major topic of the next Presidential campaign.And so we will continue to push as hard as we can on all fronts to fix a broken immigration system. Administratively, we'll be prepared if and when we get the kind of ruling that I think we should have gotten in the first place about our authorities to go ahead and implement. But ultimately, this has never fully replaced the need for Congress to act. And my hope is, is that after a number of the other issues that we're working on currently get cleared, that there—some quiet conversations start up—back up again, particularly in the Republican Party, about the shortsighted approach that they're taking when it comes to immigration.Okay. Christi Parsons [Los Angeles Times].
label: General

sentence: Given the alarming report from The New Yorker detailing the Red Cross's findings on CIA interrogation practices, specifically labeling them as torture, and considering your past commitment to closing Guantanamo Bay, a facility still operational despite your stated intentions, can you clarify the specific obstacles preventing its closure and address the apparent resistance from within your administration? Furthermore, what concrete steps are being taken to rectify the situation, and can you provide a definitive timeline for the facility's closure? [SEP] Well, let's be clear. Closing Guantanamo is a complex undertaking, not a simple snap of the fingers. We're dealing with international cooperation, or rather, a lack thereof, when it comes to repatriating detainees. And let's not forget the legal hurdles, the ongoing debates about how to handle these cases. We are actively working with various nations to facilitate the transfer of detainees, ensuring they are treated humanely upon return. Trials are also a priority, and we're navigating the legal framework to make that happen. So, while the goal remains, the path is fraught with challenges. As for the Senate vote, it speaks volumes about the political realities we face. Now, about the CIA...
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, beyond acknowledging the vulnerability, what specific steps are being taken to deter future cyberattacks from China, and what consequences will they face if these attacks continue? [SEP] We are constantly upgrading our defenses. We are making it very clear to China that such behavior is unacceptable. We are discussing this with them at the highest levels. We are keeping all our options on the table.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, these State Department officials claim they've been silenced regarding Benghazi. Will you ensure they can speak freely and share their experiences? [SEP] That's news to me. I haven't heard anything about anyone being blocked from testifying. But look, our priority has always been to get to the bottom of what happened in Benghazi, ensure the safety of our embassies, and bring the perpetrators to justice. I'll look into these allegations, but I'm not aware of any restrictions on testimony.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given your emphasis on direct diplomacy, and considering the ongoing investigation into the origins of COVID-19, would you consider reaching out to President Xi personally to request greater transparency and cooperation from China regarding the WHO's investigation? [SEP] We have channels of communication with China, and we're using them. Look, the relationship is complex, and we're addressing a range of issues. The focus right now is on ensuring a thorough and independent investigation. We're making our position very clear. We expect cooperation, and we'll see what happens.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. With all the talk about Chavez, could you tell us how much you—if you think that his influence in the region is overestimated or exaggerated? [SEP] The troop announcement I made was over 20,000 combat troops. Secretary Gates and General Pace went up to Congress and testified to the effect that those combat troops are going to need some support. And that's what the American people are seeing in terms of Iraq, the support troops necessary to help the reinforcements do their job. My hope, of course, is that Congress provides the funding necessary for the combat troops to be able to do their job, without any strings attached.Secondly, in terms of Afghanistan, I did announce, as a result of a review of our policy, an additional 3,200 troops. But in addition to that, the troops that you're referring to are going to be part of a training and embedding mission that I did also discuss during that strategy, although I didn't have any details of the troops. Colombia is a loyal ally to the States, and it shows solidarity towards Latin America as well. We have promoted more integration with the U.S.A. through Plan Colombia and the free trade agreement and more integration with Latin America as well. The Andean community, it has been led by Colombia and has an agreement signed with MERCOSUR. We have contributed to the creation of the South America Union. Colombia has been recently accepted as the main member of a Plan Panama Puebla.So we are looking also for a trade agreement with Canada. We are about to close negotiations with three Central American countries. And as you can see, this is our democratic and loyal international policy. With our sister countries, we have very good relations. We respect, and we ask everyone to respect, the guiding principles of international public law, as well as the respect for the autonomy in each country and the principle of nonintervention. We have to help one another in promoting freedom and in overcoming poverty and in conquering health.I have to mention something about the question that was asked to Number one, the whole world must know that this country was affected for 30 years by the Marxist guerrillas; that these guerrillas infiltrated politics and journalism; that they infiltrated the labor movement and labor unions, universities. And the truth was never demanded, which is something we have to demand in the future.Number two, the world must know that many—during these years, some regions in Colombia were not protected. Number three, the world must know that the guerrillas and the lack of protection was what generated the paramilitarism. Number four, the world must know that this administration is the first one that has started fighting directly against the paramilitarism. There is a political discussion going on, but the paramilitary aggression has gone down radically.Why? Because the law on justice and peace has let most—has resulted in most of the paramilitary leaders being in jail because our security policy has actually eliminated more than 1,700 of these paramilitary groups' members. And I'd like to have so many people from other countries in Colombia present here to be able to say that most of the crimes that are being tried and prosecuted happened before my administration, to say that democratic security has been recovering the transparency in electoral processes in Colombia. Last year's elections, the opposition to my administration has not even one complaint about lack of guarantees. They were able to visit all the places with which in the past were not possible to visit because, on the one hand, there was control by the guerrillas, and there was also paramilitary control in other regions, and they couldn't visit these places.Candidates running for the Presidency in 2006 received effective guarantees. They were able to visit the whole country, and the effect of the democratic security policy was quite evident because there were no pressures against them by the terrorists. The only pressure in the year 2006 were against the people who supported my campaign in departments in the southern part of the country, where FARC, together with the drug traffickers, introduced a strike, and they threatened those who were going to vote for me. And this is something that the world should be aware of. And there were candidates to Congress and the President from all ideological movements.The world must also know that it is a government that has asked for the truth; that the government is promoting the law on justice and peace; that it is this administration that has made the decision of dismantling the criminal machinery of the paramilitaries; that it was the government who made the decision to put them in jail; that it is this Government that has made the decision that they have to give out their own assets to—for the reparations of the victims; and that it is the government that has made the decision of supporting justice fully.For the first time, the supreme court of justice in Colombia, which is an independent branch, has its own investigators. Thanks to the will of this administration of funding this group, we are dismantling what was built for many years, for more than three decades. Terrorism advanced in taking parts of Colombia, and terrorism made progress in suppressing freedoms, in threatening journalists, in assassinating labor union leaders. And of all this, we are actually making progress.So I think I have to tell an anecdote as well. Not long ago, I was asked if the government supported direct transmissions on TV of the hearings where the paramilitaries are being tried before the prosecutors. And I said that the government supported this transmission alive and direct because that is the way to get the truth. So instead of being afraid for telling the truth, we have been supporting truth. Instead of looking for ways out of justice, we are trying to support justice as much as possible.Let's talk about the Director of the security agency, the DAS. When he left this agency, there were no complaints of links with paramilitaries against him. And he was then accused of facts that were known months after he left this agency, the security agency. And I have to discuss these subjects because these are subjects that are becoming increasingly important in international debates. The Minister of Defense has said that if there were any militaries related to terrorist organizations, they will be withdrawn from their positions.But we cannot fall into the trap of the guerrillas, that we should weaken the armed forces. We are not going to make them weak, because this is the only way we have to have a country without any guerrillas and without any paramilitaries. There are members—if there are members of this Government that have any links to these organizations, will be immediately removed from their offices.And so I am concerned for the question asked by the journalist. And he said—and this is not correct—that there are many members of the government related or with links with paramilitary groups. And this is a contradiction because this is the first government ever that has prosecuted the paramilitaries, that has actually killed some of the paramilitaries and sent others to jail. We are going to eliminate paramilitarism, and we are going to eliminate the guerrillas, because we can't fall in the trap that poses a paramilitary scandal that will actually do away with all the results in democratic security.The Minister of Defense, at lunch, was saying that we are going to levee a tax on the wealthiest contributors in Colombia so that they can contribute to the consolidation of the democratic security program. And we will demand the truth without any fears, and this is what makes a difference.When I was running for the Presidency, I was not well interpreted. I was saying that Colombia had to eliminate the guerrillas, but perhaps I was misunderstood because I also said that the only way was to recover the institutions and, hence, that we had to eliminate the paramilitaries as well.On August the 7th, I will have been 5 years in power, and throughout all the time—and I say this before a great ally, the President of the United States, and before the world, thanks to the journalists present here—throughout this Government, we have constantly fought the guerrillas, the paramilitaries, and the drug traffickers continuously. Our sole purpose is Colombia free of this plague; our sole purpose is a Colombia that will have strong institutions again. There is nothing to hide here. We are fighting against narco and terrorism. And let that be clear to you all.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, during your campaign, you emphasized reversing what you saw as excessive executive power grabs by President Bush. Given the current gridlock in Congress, do you feel compelled to expand executive authority to achieve your goals, even if it risks accusations of 'imperial presidency,' or would you rather be seen as ineffective due to congressional obstruction? [SEP] Look, the Constitution sets clear boundaries, and I respect the separation of powers. Congress controls the purse strings, plain and simple. I'd love to see a massive infrastructure bill passed, creating jobs and boosting the economy. But without congressional cooperation, my hands are somewhat tied. I can streamline permitting and encourage private sector investment, but ultimately, Congress needs to act. That being said, where I have legal authority to improve the lives of middle-class Americans, whether it's ensuring fair wages for federal contractors or expanding access to affordable student loan programs, I will absolutely use it. The American people expect me to act. I prefer working with Congress because their actions are more impactful and lasting. Take immigration reform, for example. There's broad agreement, even a bipartisan Senate bill, yet House Republicans refuse to act. In the face of such dysfunction, I'll explore every legal avenue to make progress. But rest assured, I'll always operate within the bounds of executive power. The American people don't want me sitting idly by, waiting for Congress to get its act together. Even as I take executive actions, I'll continue to engage with both parties to find common ground and achieve incremental progress.
label: General

sentence:
Mr. President, the election seemed to indicate a shift in public sentiment. What specific policy changes are you considering in response, particularly regarding trade and immigration? [SEP] Well, the American people are smart. They know the world's connected, and you can't just put things back the way they were. They understand they might need to change jobs, get more training. They're up for it, but they want a fair deal.

Most people still support trade, but they want to make sure it's fair, that we get the same access to other countries' markets. They don't want a race to the bottom on wages.

I tried to explain that TPP would help with that, but it's hard when people remember jobs leaving. So, this election was about wanting a change. People want to stop illegal immigration and avoid trade deals that aren't fair. But we need to make sure immigration is orderly and legal, because it's good for our economy. It keeps us young and dynamic.

And when it comes to trade, it's not as simple as cutting off deals. We have global supply chains. Auto plants rely on parts from Mexico. So, we need to address people's concerns with things like a higher minimum wage, stronger worker protections, and financial regulations. We need trade that ensures fair labor practices and addresses inequality. That's how we make sure everyone feels part of the global economy.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, despite the military surge in Iraq, there's little evidence it fostered Iraqi unity. Refugees remain displaced, and polls show Iraqis blaming the U.S. What benchmarks must the Iraqi government meet to change this perception, and what specific actions do you expect from them? [SEP] Well, I disagree that there's no politics happening. They have a government, passed a budget, and are working on another. They've had two readings of a de-Ba'athification law. If you're judging them by our Congress's standards, be careful. It takes our Congress till the last minute to get things done. They have work to do, but there's a functioning government. Security allowed it to stand up. We'll keep pressing them on de-Ba'ath law, elections, power sharing, and oil law. They're distributing oil revenues and reconciling locally. Satisfied with Baghdad? No. But to say nothing is happening is false.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. So, Mr. President, to be absolutely clear, is the possibility of Sergeant Bergdahl facing any kind of punishment still on the table, or are we ruling that out completely? [SEP] Look, right now, the only thing that matters is getting Sergeant Bergdahl the support he needs after what he's been through. That's our top priority. As for Poland, we're working closely with them and our NATO allies to ensure the security of the Eastern European region. Their concerns are being taken very seriously.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, to confirm, the additional $600 weekly payment is still being considered? [SEP] Let's just say all options are being explored. The funds are available.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you mentioned that you see national reconciliation as a crucial goal there for your policy. Why then haven't you condemned the taunting that Saddam Hussein faced on the gallows from Shiite officials? And on a related subject, can you be more specific as to which day next week you'll be unveiling your Iraq policy? [SEP] The second part of your question, no. [] First part of your question—I want you to anticipate the speech. I want you to be thinking about it. I want you to be internalizing it.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, about visa-free travel for Estonians, when will you propose this change to Congress? What can Estonia do to help resolve this issue more quickly? [SEP] We need to work on our 3-percent requirement and assure Congress that changing the visa waiver issue won't compromise our security. This process is beginning shortly. Estonia is constantly raising this question. I had a long discussion, even back when I was a delegate in European Parliament. We've come quite a long way from the time we started these discussions 2 years ago with Nick Burns. When the security requirements have been clarified, we'll be able to implement them in our passports. That is simply a technical problem, but it is resolvable.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, given the historical context of U.S. involvement in Chile during the Pinochet era and the ongoing investigations into the deaths of Allende and Frei Montalva, will the U.S. government commit to fully cooperating with these investigations, including a formal apology for past actions? [SEP] Well, regarding cooperation with the Chilean government, we will certainly consider any requests for information about the past. We believe it's important to understand our history, including the sometimes difficult relationship between the U.S. and Latin America. However, it's also important not to be trapped by our history. Chile has made extraordinary progress in recent decades, with the full support of the United States. I can't speak to all the policies of the past, but I can speak to our commitment to democracy, eradicating poverty, and supporting broad-based development. We strongly support the open markets that have developed in Chile and the work of President Pinera and his predecessor. So, while it's important to learn from our history, we must also focus on the challenges of the present and the future.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: After your discussions with President Putin, how optimistic are you that he will improve the media climate in Russia, particularly given the forced departure of several independent media outlets? [SEP] I wouldn't frame it as improving the climate. I'd put it in terms of how much interest he has in burnishing Russia's reputation, ensuring it's not seen as contrary to democratic principles and free speech. That's a judgment I can't make. I don't know. It's not because I think he's interested in changing the nature of a closed society or government's actions relative to what he thinks is the right of government to do what it does; it's a very different approach. There are some really good biographies – I told him I read a couple – I read most everything he's written and the speeches he's made. And I've read a couple of very good biographies, which many of you have as well. I pointed out to him that Russia had an opportunity – that brief shining moment after Gorbachev – to generate a democratic government. But it failed, and there was a great race among intellectuals to determine what form of government they would choose. Based on what I believe, Mr. Putin decided that Russia has always been a major international power when it's been totally united as a Russian state, not based on ideology – whether it was going back to Tsar and commissar, straight through to the revolution, the Russian Revolution, and to where they are today. I think it's clear to me that he decided that the way for Russia to sustain itself as a great power is to unite the Russian people on just the strength of the government – the government controls – not necessarily ideologically, but the government. I think that's the choice that was made. I'm not going to second guess whether it could have been fundamentally different. But I do think it does not lend itself to maintaining itself as one of the great powers in the world.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I wanted to go back to the situation in Ukraine. If this cease-fire does take effect and appears to be holding, would you and your European counterparts back away from these sanctions that you say you've prepared? Or do you feel that it's important to levy these sanctions regardless of this cease-fire agreement? And if I could go back to the Rapid Response Force, can you say specifically what U.S. contributions will be in terms of troop numbers and equipment? Is it beyond the agreement that you announced—or the proposal you announced in Warsaw? [SEP] With respect to the cease-fire agreement, obviously, we are hopeful, but based on past experience also skeptical that, in fact, the separatists will follow through and the Russians will stop violating Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity. So it has to be tested. And I know that the Europeans are discussing at this point the final shape of their sanctions measures. It's my view that if you look at President Poroshenko's plan, it is going to take some time to implement. And as a consequence, for us to move forward based on what is currently happening on the ground with sanctions—while acknowledging that if in fact the elements of the plan that has been signed are implemented, then those sanctions could be lifted—is a more likely way for us to ensure that there's follow-through. But that's something that obviously we'll consult closely with our European partners to determine.I do want to point out, though, that the only reason that we're seeing this cease-fire at this moment is because of both the sanctions that have already been applied and the threat of further sanctions, which are having a real impact on the Russian economy and have isolated Russia in a way that we have not seen in a very long time.The path for Russia to rejoin the community of nations that respects international law is still there, and we encourage President Putin to take it. But the unity and the firmness that we've seen in the trans-Atlantic alliance in supporting Ukraine and applying sanctions has been, I think, a testimony to how seriously people take the basic principle that big countries can't just stomp on little countries or force them to change their policies and give up their sovereignty.So I'm very pleased with the kind of work that's been done throughout this crisis in Ukraine, and I think U.S. leadership has been critical throughout that process.With respect to the Rapid Response Forces and the readiness action plan that we've put forward, in Warsaw, I announced $1 billion in our initiative. A sizeable portion of that will be devoted to implementing various aspects of this readiness action plan.We've already increased obviously rotations of personnel in the Baltic States, for example. We have the air policing. We have the activities that are taking place in the Baltic and the Black Sea. But this allows us to supplement it. It allows us to coordinate it and integrate it further with additional contributions from other partners. And what it signifies is NATO's recognition that, in light of recent Russian actions as well as rhetoric, we want to make it crystal clear: We mean what we say when we're talking about our article 5 commitments. And an increased presence serves as the most effective deterrent to any additional Russian aggression that we might see.Angela Keane, Bloomberg.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, in light of Speaker Pelosi's recent statements questioning your competence and the veracity of your administration's claims regarding the coronavirus, what is your response? [SEP] Let me be blunt: Pelosi's attacks are nothing more than political theater from a failed politician. She lost the House once, and she's on track to do it again. Honestly, her negativity is just making me more popular – it's almost too easy. Instead of these cheap shots, she should be focused on working together to address this potential problem. It might be a small one, hopefully, but we need unity. And Schumer complaining that we're not asking for enough money? That's a first! Usually, they're screaming about overspending. They're playing games when they should be supporting the incredible people working day and night on this. They're trying to create a panic, and there's no need for it. We have the best experts in the world, and other countries are even asking for our help. Pelosi should clean up her own backyard, which is a mess, by the way. This isn't about politics; it's about doing what's right for America. If they want to throw more money at us, fine, we'll take it. But they shouldn't be disrespecting these amazing healthcare professionals. They're not just attacking me; they're attacking the best in the world.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, the UN is warning about potential food supply disruptions due to the pandemic. What specific steps are you taking to address this risk and ensure food security for Americans? [SEP] Our farmers are doing an amazing job, producing food at incredible levels. And we're working on the transportation side to make sure it gets where it needs to go. I actually have the transportation people on the line tomorrow to discuss the delivery of the food. So, we're doing great on food. I haven't heard of any problems, and I think Kroger and Walmart are in good shape. We'll be very strong on food supply. One more question.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. You once spoke about fire and fury. Is that no longer the case? [SEP] Well, at that time we needed, perhaps, fire and fury. Because we could not have allowed that kind of capability from the standpoint of the United States. And certainly, Japan wasn't going to allow it either. Japan is right next door.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, Speaker Pelosi has accused you of being dangerously misinformed about the coronavirus. She also questions the trustworthiness of information coming from your administration. How do you respond? [SEP] Look, Pelosi's track record speaks for itself. She's a proven loser, remember? She handed us the House once, and mark my words, she'll do it again. Her attacks are just boosting my approval ratings, which are already through the roof. Frankly, it's almost unfair how easy it is. Instead of these petty jabs, she should be focused on uniting the country against this potential threat. Maybe it'll be minor, hopefully, but we need to be on the same page. And Cryin' Chuck Schumer? Complaining we aren't asking for enough money? Usually, they're saying we're spending too much! They're playing politics when they should be supporting the incredible professionals working tirelessly on this. They're trying to create panic, and there's absolutely no reason for it. We have the best people in the world on this, and other countries are even asking for our help. Pelosi should go fix her own district, which is a disaster, by the way. This isn't about political advantage; it's about doing what's right for the American people. If they want to give us more money, fine, we'll take it. But they shouldn't be disrespecting these amazing healthcare professionals. They're not just demeaning me; they're demeaning the best in the world.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, could you reveal the identities of those five Republican Senators? [SEP] Absolutely not. You must be joking! Confidentiality is paramount.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, since voting rights legislation is stalled, what's your plan B? [SEP] I'm not going to lay out every detail right now. But we've strengthened the Justice Department to fight these unconstitutional Republican efforts. We're also educating the public. We're working on both executive actions and legislation.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, just to be clear, a government shutdown during the lame-duck session is entirely off the table? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to box myself in with absolutes. It's a fluid situation, and frankly, I can't give you a definitive yes or no on that right now. Anything's possible.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, Nigeria desperately needs Tucano aircraft to combat issues at home. Could you release at least two before 2020? Also, when might we expect a visit from you to Nigeria? [SEP] Nigeria is a place I'd be thrilled to visit. I've heard it's an extraordinarily beautiful country. So, yes, I'd like to go. Now, about the first part of your question, I didn't quite hear you. Could you repeat it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, putting it simply, what's the plan moving forward? [SEP] Well, the immediate need is to get more people back into their homes, to ensure they have a place to live. The systems are in place for the ongoing reconstruction of New Orleans. Some have criticized the Federal response as slow, but I must point out that 30,000 people were rescued from rooftops immediately after the storm. I personally thanked the helicopter pilots and Coast Guard for their heroic efforts. While improvements could always be made, to call the response slow is to disregard the efforts of those who saved so many lives. Furthermore, I was deeply moved by the reactions after the election, seeing people with tears in their eyes expressing disbelief at the election of a Black president. It highlights the progress we've made as a nation regarding race relations, but there is still work to be done to address the prejudices that remain in people's hearts. I am optimistic about the future and the historic moment this represents for our country.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, to be clear, August is still the goal, even with the potential legislative logjam? [SEP] Look, I'm always optimistic. I'm a glass-half-full kind of guy. But let's be realistic. The appropriations process is like a giant octopus, its tentacles reaching into every corner of the legislative calendar. August is the *hope*, not the *promise*. We'll push hard, but ultimately, the timing is in the hands of Congress. I'm just a humble servant of the people, trying to get things done.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, many in the UK feel the relentless pursuit of Gary McKinnon, a hacker with Asperger's, seems excessive. Might it be time for some leniency? And Prime Minister, you've voiced strong opposition to extradition, as has your Deputy. Did you discuss this with the President, and would you reiterate your views? [SEP] Well, as the Prime Minister indicated, we did touch upon this. There's ongoing dialogue, and I wouldn't want to interfere. We recognize the gravity of the charges against Mr. McKinnon – hacking sensitive databases. No one disputes that. I understand the Prime Minister has engaged with our Ambassador and myself on this, and we hope for a resolution. David and I also discussed the escalating challenges of cybersecurity in the internet age. While old-school espionage persists, the real vulnerabilities lie in these digital breaches. We take this very seriously, as does the British government. However, it's tradition for the President to avoid involvement in prosecutions and extradition matters. My team will adhere to the law, while collaborating closely with our unparalleled ally. I trust we'll find a resolution that acknowledges the seriousness of the issue while respecting our partnership. Thank you all.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. The operations in Africa this weekend suggest that the continent is now the central front in the campaign against terrorism, and if we're going to see U.S. military operations all around the continent, how does that square with your contention that American cannot be at war forever? [SEP] Well, if you look at the speech I gave at the National Defense College several months ago, I outlined how I saw the shift in terrorism around the world and what we have to do to respond to it. And part of what I said is, is that we had decimated core Al aida that had been operating primarily between Afghanistan and Pakistan, but you now had these regional groups, some of which are explicitly tied to Al aida or that ideology, some of which are more localized. Few of them have the ability to project beyond their borders, but they can do a lot of damage inside their borders.And Africa is one of the places where, because, in some cases, a lack of capacity on the part of the Governments, in some cases because it is easier for folks to hide out in vast terrains that are sparsely populated, that you're seeing some of these groups gather. And we're going to have to continue to go after them.But there's a difference between us going after terrorists who are plotting directly to do damage to the United States and us being involved in wars. The risks of terrorism and terrorist networks are going to continue for some time to come. We've got to have a long-term plan that is not just military based, we've got to engage in a war of ideas in the region and engage with Muslim countries and try to isolate radical elements that are doing more damage to Muslims than they're doing to anybody else. We've got to think about economic development, because although there's not a direct correlation between terrorism and the economy, there's no doubt that if you've got a lot of unemployed, uneducated young men in societies, that there's a greater likelihood that terrorist recruits are available.But where you've got active plots and active networks, we're going to go after them. We prefer partnering with countries where this is taking place wherever we can, and we want to build up their capacity. But we're not going to farm out our defense.And I have to say, by the way, the operations that took place both in Libya and Somalia were examples of the extraordinary skill and dedication and talent of our men and women in the armed forces. They do their jobs extremely well, with great precision, at great risk to themselves. And I think they are pretty good examples for how those of us here in Washington should operate as well.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, for Republicans seeking election next year are you an asset or a liability? [SEP] Strong asset. [] Ann [Ann Compton, ABC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, you've championed a peaceful transfer of power, yet many Democrats are boycotting the incoming President's Inauguration. Do you condone this? And what message would you send to encourage a smoother transition? Also, did you persuade the President-elect to reconsider key policies like the Affordable Care Act or DREAMers? [SEP] I won't discuss the specifics of my conversations with President-elect Trump, other than to say they were cordial and substantive. Whether I was persuasive is for him to say. I offered my advice, but he was elected on a platform opposing many of my initiatives. I expect he'll pursue his own vision. Perhaps he'll reach similar conclusions on healthcare or job creation once he's in office. We'll see. His views will be shaped by his advisors. This job requires a strong team providing the best information. If you're isolated or only hear agreement, you'll make mistakes. As for the Inauguration, I'll be there, as will Michelle. And the weather looks better than my first one.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, what are your thoughts on the proposed mosque near Ground Zero? While they have the right to build it, what message does it send if they're talked out of it? Also, has the Koran-burning threat put American lives at risk? [SEP] Well, about that Koran thing, no question, when someone goes out of their way to stir up trouble with over a billion Muslims, especially when we got troops all over the place in Muslim countries, that's a problem. Makes things harder for our soldiers. Now, about the mosque in New York, I've been clear on this: everyone's equal, got rights, religion's one of them. If you can build a church, synagogue, whatever, you should be able to build a mosque. I get that 9/11's a sensitive thing. I've met with the families, I know their pain. But we're not fighting Islam. We're fighting terrorists who twist Islam. Gotta be clear about that, because we need allies to fight terror. Al Qaeda wants a war between us and Islam. Most Muslims just want the same things we do: jobs, schools, safety. They don't want violence. And we got millions of Muslim Americans, our neighbors, friends, coworkers. If we act like their religion's bad, what does that say to them? We got Muslims fighting for us in Afghanistan. They're putting their lives on the line. We gotta make sure they know we see them as Americans, just like us. That's important.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with the Iraqi Prime Minister visiting tomorrow, what's your take on Iraq potentially becoming a buffer against Iranian and Russian influence in the Middle East, and do you believe this Prime Minister can make that happen? [SEP] Look, I like this guy. We're getting out of Iraq, down to just a handful of soldiers. These endless wars are a joke, the worst decision ever. We should've never been there in the first place. But we're pulling out, slowly but surely.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. So there is no war coming? [SEP] I would say this: We have a very, very powerful military. We're getting more powerful by the month, by the day. We're ordering a lot of the equipment that you're ordering. We're ordering it, but in larger amounts, to put it mildly. We are building up our military to a point that we've never been before. We're also—we were very much weakened over the last long period of time, but not with me.No, I don't expect that. I think we're going to have—because of strength—peace through strength. I think we're going to have a long period of peace. I hope we do. We have certainly problems with North Korea, but a lot of good talks are going on right now, a lot of good energy. I see a lot of good energy. I like it very much, what I'm seeing.I just spoke this morning with the—as you know, with the President—President Moon of South Korea. He had some really great meetings. His representatives had a great, great meeting. And I had some very good feedback from that. So hopefully, a lot of good things are going to work out. No, I think that we will have peace through strength. Our military will be stronger than it ever was in a very short period of time. And that's my opinion. That's not the general's opinion, but I think my opinion counts more right now. [] Thank you.. Maybe I can just add that the reason why we are so happy that we have U.S. marines training in Norway is that that's part of the deterrence strategy that makes sure that we don't have a war in the future. . Yes. And, Sarah [Sarah Westwood, Washington Examiner], did you have a question? You were about to ask a question? Did you have a question for the Prime Minister?
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, North Korea seems determined to launch this missile. What concrete steps will South Korea and the US take to deter them, and what specific penalties are being considered? Furthermore, where do the missile range extension talks stand? [SEP] The situation with North Korea is deeply concerning. Should they proceed with this launch, it would be a clear breach of international law, specifically UN Security Council Resolution 1874. The repercussions for North Korea would be significant, further isolating them from the global community. We are urging them to reconsider. As for our response, we are prepared to take appropriate measures in coordination with our allies. The North Korean people need to understand that their leaders are prioritizing weapons development over their basic needs. Regarding the missile range issue, while discussions are ongoing at the working level, it is an important part of strengthening South Korea's defense posture. We will remain composed and strategic in our dealings with North Korea. I will not comment on the missile range.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Iran: Given their stated intention to resume nuclear talks by the end of November, how will you assess their commitment to these negotiations? And what specific penalties are you prepared to impose on Iran if they continue to perpetrate attacks against the United States, such as the recent drone strikes targeting U.S. forces in Syria? [SEP] Well, those are essentially two separate matters. One concerns our potential return to the JCPOA. And that depends—that's why I convened meetings with my counterparts here in Rome, who are part of the original group of six nations that initially advocated for negotiating a change, a situation that I believe we are still grappling with due to President Trump's ill-advised decision to withdraw from the JCPOA. So that's one aspect. And its resolution will hinge on their actions and the willingness of our allies, who were party to the original agreement, to stand with us and ensure that there are economic consequences for them should they fail to return. Regarding the issue of how we intend to respond to actions taken by them against the interests of the United States—whether they involve drone strikes or any other form of aggression—we will respond, and we will continue to do so. Cecilia Vega, ABC. It's challenging to recognize you all with masks on. My apologies. Climate Change/
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the video you showed portrayed you and Kim Jong Un as equals discussing the future of his country. Is that an accurate representation? [SEP] No, I don't see it that way. I'll do whatever it takes to make the world safer. If sitting on a stage with Chairman Kim can save millions of lives, I'm willing to do it. I'm willing to travel there proudly and gladly. Beyond the time it takes, they've given up a tremendous amount, even before. Consider the Olympics. They turned a potential failure into a success by participating. So, if I can save millions of lives by establishing a relationship with a powerful man who controls a country with powerful nuclear weapons, it's my honor.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify, if there were no explicit threats or ultimatums regarding ransomware, what specific assurances were given, and what recourse does the U.S. have if these working groups fail to produce tangible results within a reasonable timeframe? [SEP] Assurances are always tricky in these situations. We have to trust, but verify. If these groups don't deliver, we'll explore all available options. We will not allow our country to be vulnerable. We will do what is necessary to protect our interests.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Hi. Mr. President, thank you. This week, you and the G-7 allies introduced a plan for an oil price cap for Russian exports, which is not yet filled out and, obviously, is a response to the high price of gasoline in the United States and around the world. Are you confident that that cap would bring down prices for American drivers? And how long is it expect—fair to expect American drivers to continue to pay a premium because of this war? [SEP] Let me hear the—the second part of the question was, Would it bring down the price?
label: Clarification

sentence: What are your thoughts on the MoveOn.org ad that called General Petraeus 'General Betray Us' and accused him of manipulating data on Iraq? Furthermore, would you like to see Democrats, including presidential hopefuls, disavow the ad? [SEP] That ad was a disgrace, plain and simple. It wasn't just an attack on General Petraeus, it was an attack on the entire military. Frankly, I'm disappointed that more Democrats didn't condemn it more forcefully. It seems like some Democrats are more afraid of upsetting radical groups like MoveOn.org than they are of standing up for our men and women in uniform. It's one thing to criticize me, but to go after a dedicated public servant like General Petraeus is beyond the pale. Now, let's move on. Leavitt's here to answer your questions, so try to be gentle; it's his first time. Martha, Gregory, play nice. Thanks, everyone.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Is a signature required for this agreement to be valid? [SEP] That's a good question. Since it's not a legally binding agreement, I'm not sure if a signature is technically necessary. But it's a very important commitment from the United States, and we're fully behind it. Thanks, everyone.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, isn't it your duty to offer some guidance, given your experience? What specific policy changes are you most apprehensive about? [SEP] My time in the spotlight is done. It's his show now. I'll be cheering him on from Texas.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Do you support backpay for furloughed workers? [SEP] Excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, what's your reaction to the Red Cross report? [SEP] I'm not aware of its contents. However, let me be absolutely clear: this nation does not, and will not, practice torture. Who's next?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning trade relations with Uruguay and the ongoing dispute involving Argentina, could you elaborate on the flexibility your administration is prepared to demonstrate regarding trade agreements? Furthermore, did President Vazquez specifically request your intervention in the matter of the mill plants? [SEP] We engaged in extensive discussions regarding Uruguay's concerns pertaining to market access for specific commodities. The President raised a spectrum of trade-related issues, notably the quotas imposed on items such as cattle and sheep, which he deemed inequitable. I assured him that I would accord his requests due consideration. You may have perceived my remarks regarding blueberries as facetious; however, I assure you, they were not. Uruguay cultivates exceptional blueberries, and the fundamental question at hand is whether Uruguayan blueberry producers will be afforded access to the United States market. We deliberated on a diverse array of produce. As I conveyed to the President, challenges can only be resolved through open dialogue, and we will extend assistance where feasible, providing explanations when constraints prevent us from doing so. Regarding protectionist tendencies, I share your apprehension, not solely within our own nation but on a global scale. I firmly believe that a world characterized by free and equitable trade is better positioned to alleviate poverty. Consequently, I am a staunch advocate for the completion of the Doha round of the WTO. I shared our strategies for advancing the Doha round with the President, drawing upon my conversations with President Lula, while maintaining the confidentiality of our discussions. The United States stands prepared to reduce agricultural subsidies, as I articulated to the President, contingent upon securing market access for our products. This is the message I conveyed to President Lula, the Europeans, and now President Vazquez. I am optimistic about achieving a resolution. Our trade minister, Susan Schwab, remains in Sao Paulo to continue deliberations with her Brazilian counterpart, striving towards a complex yet indispensable agreement. In response to your initial inquiry, I wholeheartedly concur with the sentiments expressed by the President of the United States. We have established a framework, commencing with this meeting, for our experts and ministers to engage in discussions and advance bilateral relations. Concerning the broader multilateral landscape, Uruguay champions free trade and the reduction of tariffs and subsidies that impede the sale of our cultural products. We have also explored potential progress with the GSP, particularly on issues slated for consideration in the coming weeks. As for the latter portion of your question, I did not broach the subject of our issues with Argentina with the President of the United States, primarily because we will soon engage in dialogue, facilitated by the conciliation of His Majesty, the King of Spain, to seek an amicable resolution to our differences.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Gentlemen, I have a two-part question. Mr. President, did your discussions today include the potential for Canada to increase its stimulus efforts? And for both of you, how do you envision the Canada-U.S. relationship evolving over the next four years, particularly concerning the auto sector, border security, and carbon markets? [SEP] Wow, you managed to cram about half a dozen questions into one. Were you talking to someone else? Is that--[]?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Did she promise that they wouldn't seek to impeach you? [SEP] She's had a very, very—we didn't talk about impeaching. We didn't talk about—what do you do? Do you impeach somebody because he created the greatest economic success in the history of our country? Let's impeach him, because the country is so successful. Let's impeach him. Has he done anything wrong? They asked somebody, Has he done anything wrong? No, but let's impeach him anyway.And they also said: Let's impeach Justice Kavanaugh. Let's impeach him. And now they have the second woman coming out that—the first or second. And I hate to say this, but it was public. And after him, we're going to impeach the Vice President. We're going to impeach Mike Pence. Mike Pence doesn't get impeached for anything. [] So let's impeach the President, and then we'll impeach the Vice President.These people are sick. And you know what? They have to get their bearing. Really, they have to get their bearing. And when you ask about division, they're the ones that cause the division. They cause tremendous division.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, this mother sent her son alone from Honduras because she believed you wouldn't deport unaccompanied minors. Is your message encouraging this? [SEP] I'm not going to let a child starve at the border. No administration would do that, except Trump. That's why I've asked the Vice President to focus on why people are leaving Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador. It's earthquakes, floods, lack of food, gang violence, a whole range of things. When I was Vice President, I slowed it down by working with the heads of state to do things like putting lighting in the streets to reduce violent crime. When the hurricanes occurred, instead of helping, we did nothing. We're going to spend that 700-plus million dollars a year to change the life and circumstances of why people leave in the first place. That mother didn't just decide to send her son here on a whim.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, do you believe this constituted a direct threat against you personally? [SEP] That remains to be seen. The investigation is ongoing, and we'll have more information as it progresses.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given Ghislaine Maxwell's imprisonment, are you concerned she will implicate powerful figures, particularly considering your past comments on Prince Andrew and Bill Clinton? [SEP] I'm not really following the case that closely, to be honest. I simply wish her well. I've met her a number of times, especially when I lived in Palm Beach, where she also resided. As for Prince Andrew, I'm not familiar with the details. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, the TPP seems stalled. Are you changing your strategy, especially with the Boeing and GE deals? Should the agreement address currency manipulation? Also, can you comment on Mullah Mansur's death and Pakistan's concerns? Does this signal a new offensive in Afghanistan? Are you worried about a more hardline leader? [SEP] On TPP, every trade deal is painful. Folks are always seeing if they can get an even better deal. Especially with multiple parties involved, folks are going to scrutinize it. In an election year, some folks are going to try to score political points off it.Having said that, I remain confident we're going to get it done because it's the right thing to do. It's good for America. It's good for the region. It's good for the world.This is the fastest-growing part of the world. This represents an enormous market for the United States. Most countries here already sell their stuff to the United States, and we have relatively low tariffs. In contrast, tariffs are significantly higher for U.S. goods being sold here. So a deal that gets rid of 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods into the largest, fastest-growing markets of the world, that's a good deal for American businesses and American workers.Historically, one of the biggest complaints about trade deals has been that it opens up our markets to countries with lower wages, harsher labor practices, less environmental regulation. Well, if you're signing up for the Trans-Pacific Partnership, you are making commitments that are enforceable to raise labor standards, to ensure that workers have a voice, to attend to environmental problems. And so this gives us the ability to engage with a country like Vietnam and work with them on all those fronts, the precise things that people, in the past, have been concerned about when it comes to trading with other countries.So I have not yet seen a credible argument that once we get TPP in place we're going to be worse off. We are demonstrably better off. American workers and American businesses are better off if we get this deal passed. And I'm confident we will get it passed.Now, the politics of it will be noisy. That was true when I, for example, inherited the Korean free trade agreement or the Colombian and Panamanian free trade agreements when I came into office. But we got them done. And I'm confident that we'll get them done this time, as well, although it will—there will be ups and downs and bumps along the way.With respect to currency manipulation, we have provisions in TPP that advance the transparency and reporting functions that allow us to monitor whether we think that currency manipulation is taking place. One of the debates that took place—and there have been some who argue that we should have enforceable provisions that if you see currency going down too far that we should be able to impose tariffs on that country. The problem is, is that it's very hard to sort out sometimes why currency is going down and whether it's actually being manipulated. And frankly, for us to bind other countries to commitments about their monetary policy would mean we were also binding our Federal Reserve to the claims of other countries in terms of how it implements our monetary policy, and that's not something that we would do. We would not give up sovereignty with respect to our monetary policy in that way. But we have strengthened a number of the provisions that are already contained in TPP that will allow us to put on notice folks who we think are engaging in competitive devaluations.Finally, on the Taliban leader, Mr. Mansur, it has been confirmed that he is dead. And he is an individual who, as head of the Taliban, was specifically targeting U.S. personnel and troops inside of Afghanistan who were there as part of the mission that I've set to be able to maintain a counterterrorism platform and provide assistance and training to the Afghan military forces there. So this does not represent a shift in our approach. We are not re-entering the day-to-day combat operations that are currently being conducted by Afghan security forces. Our job is to help Afghanistan secure its own country, not to have our men and women in uniform engage in that fight for them.On the other hand, where we have a high-profile leader who has been consistently part of operations and plans to potentially harm U.S. personnel and who has been resistant to the kinds of peace talks and reconciliation that ultimately could bring an end to decades of war in Afghanistan, then it is my responsibility as Commander in Chief not to stand by, but to make sure that we send a clear signal to the Taliban and others that we're going to protect our people. And that's exactly the message that has been sent. President Quang. Let me respond to this question concerning the Trans-Pacific Partnership, TPP. In our view, TPP is a significant trade and economic linkage, contributing to sustaining the dynamics and the role as a driver for economic growth in our country, as well as in the Asia-Pacific region. And for Vietnam, TPP and Vietnam's participation in TPP is one step undertaken by the Vietnamese Government in our process of extensive international integration. President Ob. Mr. President, sorry to interrupt. We're not getting translation. Testing one, two, three. President Ob. For you? Can you hear, Mr. President? President Ob. Okay. Testing one, two, three. President Ob. It's just, I'm sure that he was saying something very wise and important, and we wanted to make sure that we all heard it. President ung. So I would like to add that Vietnam, together with other TPP countries, have been making efforts to narrow differences, to promote cooperation in the spirit of mutual understanding and mutual respect. And we will try to reduce differences in the spirit of constructiveness and understanding and paying attention to one another's legitimate interests. And the finalization of TPP is also the successful outcomes of all 12 members of the TPP, rather than any individual effort. And we are prepared to ratify TPP, and we stand ready to implement all the commitments under TPP.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Some argue that focusing solely on raising taxes on the wealthy is a simplistic solution that ignores the complexities of the tax code and the potential impact on economic growth. Are you open to exploring alternative approaches to revenue generation, such as tax reform or entitlement reform, to achieve a more sustainable fiscal future? [SEP] We're open to exploring all options for achieving a sustainable fiscal future. We need a comprehensive approach that includes tax reform, entitlement reform, and spending cuts. We're willing to work with Republicans to find common ground on these issues. Our goal is to create an economy that works for everyone, and we need to ensure that our fiscal policies support that goal.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, what specific steps will you take to advance your pro-life agenda? [SEP] We're working very hard on it, and we've had tremendous success. People are very happy with the progress we're making. It's a complex issue, and there are strong opinions on both sides, but we're committed to protecting the sanctity of life.
label: General

sentence: Sir, concerning Russia, observers have noted that your Democratic rivals seemed uninformed about Dmitry Medvedev. What are your thoughts on him, especially his power dynamic with Putin? Furthermore, what advice would you offer your successor on navigating the complexities of the Russian threat, considering past critiques of your own handling of Vladimir Putin? [SEP] Medvedev, you say? Truth be told, I'm not deeply familiar with him either. The real indicator will be who represents Russia at gatherings like the G-8. That'll offer insights into Russia's post-Putin foreign policy trajectory. But I can't provide a concrete answer just yet. However, I can affirm that sustaining relations with Russia is paramount. We require their collaboration on matters such as proliferation and Iran. Recall Putin's proposal to furnish enriched uranium to Iran's Bushehr facility, obviating their need for domestic enrichment? That was a positive step. We must be capable of collaborating with Russia on Iran. There exist numerous domains for cooperation. Consider, for instance, the missile defense system in Europe, discussed with the Czech Prime Minister. It's imperative that we convey to the Russians that the system isn't directed at them, but rather at genuine 21st-century threats like violent regimes wielding weapons of mass destruction. Thus, I aim to ensure that my successor can cultivate a relationship with whomever is steering Russian foreign policy. It's in our nation's interest. This doesn't imply perpetual agreement. Disagreements, such as on Kosovo, will inevitably arise. Nonetheless, a leader-to-leader relationship, and ideally beyond, is indispensable.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the ISIL situation, some analysts suggest a containment strategy. Is that, in your view, a viable long-term solution, or should we aim for complete eradication? And considering the limitations of air power, what is your assessment of the Free Syrian Army's capacity to effectively neutralize ISIL on the ground in Syria? [SEP] Let's be clear: containing an organization wreaking havoc on such a scale is simply not feasible. The goal must be to dismantle it entirely. Look at Al Qaeda in the FATA – we pushed them back, degraded their capabilities, shrunk their territory, and took out their leaders. Eventually, they couldn't launch the same attacks. Will remnants remain? Sure. We'll hunt them down, like Al Qaeda remnants or al-Shabaab. But our aim is to dismantle this network so they can't harm us. I'm glad our allies agree. As for Syria, we won't put U.S. troops on the ground to control the conflict. It's not needed. We need effective partners to push back against ISIL. The moderate coalition is one option; we've worked with them. They've been outgunned, so we'll support them better. But remember, when U.S. forces put ISIL on the defensive, ground forces can do a lot, even if they were initially struggling. This is a developing strategy, and we'll consult with our allies. The bottom line is, we'll do what it takes to ensure ISIL doesn't threaten the U.S. or our partners. Next question, please.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the strategic framework agreement with Iraq, could you clarify the timeline for transitioning to 'overwatch' and the specific protections afforded to U.S. troops operating there? [SEP] Well, as you know, these things are dynamic. We're engaging with the Iraqi government on a comprehensive agreement covering diplomacy, economics, and justice. Embedded within that is the security component, which naturally includes discussions about the timeline for what we're calling 'overwatch.' The Iraqis have their own aspirations for how quickly that transition occurs. Now, overwatch, as we envision it, entails a U.S. presence focused on training, logistical support, and special operations. Crucially, any troop presence necessitates a clear understanding with the host government, including operational authorities and protections for our personnel. These negotiations are ongoing, and we aim to finalize them before the year's end, unless the U.N. mandate is extended. So, there are really two interconnected aspects to this agreement, which sometimes get conflated, and we're addressing them both concurrently. Let me see, what else was there?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, following up on school reopenings, might the Republican party leverage this issue to win back suburban voters during the midterm elections? [SEP] That's certainly the hope of some, I imagine. But I have faith in the American people. They're not easily swayed by partisan talking points. They're concerned with real issues: family, security, and economic stability. The media landscape is so fragmented now; people seek out information that confirms their existing biases. This impacts everything. As for polls, they fluctuate. But the underlying reality is that voters are becoming more sophisticated in discerning truth from fiction. So, while school reopenings *could* be a factor, I doubt it will be decisive.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Biden, what concrete steps is the US taking to bridge the global vaccine gap, and is the 2022 target for ending the pandemic still achievable? [SEP] Globally, it might extend slightly beyond 2022. The US remains committed to providing assistance. We're exploring the possibility of providing another billion doses between 2022 and 2023, though it's not yet confirmed. I'm cautious about making promises I can't keep. At the G-7, there was a shared understanding that we'll persevere until the entire world is vaccinated. This is not only morally imperative but also crucial for our own health and security. No wall can prevent the spread of new strains. This will be an ongoing effort. We need a system for early detection of future pandemics. We're supporting other nations in manufacturing their own vaccines. It's a massive logistical undertaking. Last question, please.
label: Claims ignorance
