sentence: Mr. President, about Russia's announcement regarding the Kherson region, do you believe this signals a potential shift in the conflict? And do you think Ukraine now holds enough of an advantage to start peace discussions with Moscow? [SEP] Well, I found it interesting they waited until after the election to make that judgment, which we knew for some time that they were going to be doing. And it's evidence of the fact that they have some real problems—Russian—the Russian military. Number one. Number two, whether or not that leads to, at a minimum, it will lead to time for everyone to recalibrate their positions over the winter's period. And it remains to be seen whether or not there'll be a judgment made as to whether or not Ukraine is prepared to compromise with Russia. I'm going to be going to the G-20. I'm told that President Putin is not likely to be there, but other world leaders are going to be there in Indonesia. And we're going to have an opportunity to see what the next steps may be.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. So why were you so definitive? Why did you say we struck the right balance? [SEP] So the point is, Ed, not that my assessment of the 215 program has changed in terms of technically how it works. What is absolutely clear to me is that given the public debate that's taken place and the disclosures that have taken place over the last several months, that this is only going to work if the American people have confidence and trust.Now, part of the challenge is, is that because of the manner in which these disclosures took place, in dribs and drabs, oftentimes shaded in a particular way, and because of some of the constraints that we've had in terms of declassifying information and getting it out there, that that trust in how many safeguards exist and how these programs are run has been diminished. So what's going to be important is to build that back up. And I take that into account in weighing how we structure these programs.So let me just be very specific on the 215 program. It is possible, for example, that some of the same information that the intelligence community feels is required to keep people safe can be obtained by having the private phone companies keep these records longer and to create some mechanism where they can be accessed in an effective fashion.That might cost more. There might need to be different checks on how those requests are made. There may be technological solutions that have to be found to do that. And the question that we're asking ourselves now is, does that make sense not only because of the fact that there are concerns about potential abuse down the road with the metadata that's being kept by a government rather than private companies, but also, does it make sense to do it because people right now are concerned that maybe their phone calls are being listened to, even if they're not? And we've got to factor that in.So I—my point is, is that the environment has changed in ways that I think require us to take that into account. But the analysis that I've been doing throughout has always been periodically looking at what we're doing and asking ourselves, are we doing this in the right way? Are we making sure that we're keeping the American people safe, number one? Are we also being true to our civil liberties and our privacy and our values?
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President Bush, Hugo Chavez of Venezuela has been using his country's vast oil wealth to court a whole new generation of Latin Americans. You pretty much avoided using his name. He certainly used yours a lot, including saying earlier today, Go home, gringo. Do you think a visit to Latin America and agreements like the one you forged today will help counter his influence or just give him more ammunition?And to President Lula da Silva, were you able to persuade President Bush to help you on getting our Congress to lower the sugar ethanol tariffs? [SEP] I'll answer that one for him; he can answer it too. It's not going to happen. The law doesn't end until 2009; then the Congress will accept it—will look at it when the law ends.You may want to expand on that answer.As to my trip, I bring the good will of the United States to South America and Central America. That's why I'm here. I don't think America gets enough credit for trying to help improve people's lives. And so my trip is to explain, as clearly as I can, that our Nation is generous and compassionate; that when we see poverty, we care; that when we see illiteracy, we want to do something about it; that when we find there to be a deficiency in health care, we'll help to the extent we can.I'm sure most people here in South America don't understand the United States has doubled our bilateral aid to countries in Central and South America since I've been the President. It's gone from 800 [$800 million] * to 1.6 billion last year. And I say that not to just brag about dollars, but it's a starting point for people to understand this Nation is committed to this prospect. A prosperous neighborhood is in the interest of the United States; a peaceful neighborhood is in our interests.And so we fully understand that if there's illiteracy, it will affect our country eventually. Plus, the American people have got a great compassion for human rights and human dignity. I'm going to go see some programs here after this press conference, all aimed at lifting the lives of citizens, all aimed at focusing on individuals and how best can they be helped.There is a lot of investment in the region, as the President noted. Oh, for some, that's just a fancy word, but for others who benefit from the investment through jobs, it's a central part of their life. And so my trip down here is to remind our country that South America and Latin America are good places to invest, particularly in countries that adhere to rule of law and are transparent and believe in the fundamentals of freedom.And so I'm reminding people that which is pretty evident, that a lot of people know that there are direct ties between our countries. There's a lot of remittances from the United States back to the region. Why? Because there are people working for a living in our country that are sending money home to support their families. So this trip is to remind people of the ties that bind us and the importance of this region for the future of the United States. And I'm real glad to be here, and I appreciate the hospitality.Get another question moving.
label: Explicit

sentence: Given the sensitivities, could you perhaps outline the key discussion points regarding Afghanistan without divulging specific details of your conversation? [SEP] Well, let's just say the topic of Afghanistan was indeed broached. He expressed a desire for continued stability, to which I responded that their cooperation is crucial. He offered assistance on Afghanistan, among other matters, and we, in turn, conveyed our objectives for Syria and Libya. So, yes, a broad discussion occurred, but specifics are best left unsaid for now.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Could you verify the reports that Chen Guangcheng is under U.S. protection in Beijing, and if so, would the United States be willing to offer him asylum? [SEP] I'm aware of the media coverage, but I can't comment on the situation directly. However, I can assure you that human rights are consistently raised in our discussions with .
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: After the call concluded, you indicated that you confronted him about his misstep. What was his reaction, and did he concede that he had erred? [SEP] Actually, I didn't 'tell' him anything directly. I posed the question, 'What occurred?' And I got the sense that he wasn't even cognizant of having made the statement he apparently made. I didn't personally hear him say it, you see.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, given Mr. Ledgett's remarks, what are your thoughts on potentially offering Edward Snowden a plea agreement or amnesty, especially considering the debate he sparked about surveillance? [SEP] Well, Major, as you know, Mr. Snowden faces charges, so I have to tread carefully. That's really in the hands of the Attorney General and the courts. But I will say this: the conversation about surveillance was important. However, the way the information was disclosed caused real damage to our intelligence capabilities and our diplomacy. Other countries, some who engage in the very behavior Mr. Snowden was concerned about, are now using this situation to criticize us. So, while the debate was necessary, the disclosures were harmful. I'll leave the specifics of Mr. Snowden's case to the legal process.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, Mr. President, what prevents you from attending? [SEP] Honestly, I haven't given it much thought. But the idea of being there, front and center, watching them squirm, is appealing.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Bush, concerning the medics imprisoned in Libya and your expressed support for their release, would you pledge to actively lobby Congress to allocate funds from your HIV/AIDS program to support children infected with AIDS and their families in Libya? [SEP] We're already contributing to a fund for that purpose. The important thing is that the U.S., along with the EU, is committed to providing resources. And we are. We're also consistently urging the Libyan government to release the nurses. We're working closely with your government on this. We believe compensation for the children and their families is essential. We are committed to this.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: You've stated your 'microphone' is now louder regarding key domestic issues like Social Security and immigration, despite past efforts yielding limited results. With Democrats now controlling Congress, how will you amplify your message and achieve different outcomes? [SEP] When I say 'microphone' is loud, I mean I can focus attention on critical issues. That's the President's job. But getting things done requires bipartisan cooperation, which the elections showed. We had a successful few years legislatively. We reformed Medicare, created pro-growth tax policies, passed trade deals, and a comprehensive energy bill. I'm signing another energy bill today, extending R&D tax credits. It's a strong record. But with Democrats in charge, we need a different approach. I'll work with their leaders and our own to find common ground on Social Security and immigration. We must pass comprehensive immigration reform this year. To secure our border, Border Patrol needs a plan allowing temporary legal work for those doing jobs Americans won't. Recent enforcement actions at packing plants showed many illegal workers using forged documents. This system forces people to rely on smugglers and forgers. It's inhumane. The best way to enforce our borders humanely is with comprehensive reform. I've proposed a plan and spoken about it from the Oval Office. The 'microphone' is vital to rally action. I want to work with both parties. On energy, we can also cooperate. There's consensus on researching alternative energy. We're making progress. I want to work with them. Some say losing Congress means nothing will get done. I disagree. I want to get things done, and Democratic leaders want to prove their leadership. We can find common ground without compromising principles. The American people are tired of partisanship. I'll elevate the tone. I was Governor of Texas with a Democratic legislature, and we got things done. It's possible here too.
label: General

sentence: Q. So, regarding the National Health Service, Mr. President, is it open for negotiation in trade talks? [SEP] Pardon me? Could you repeat the question, please?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. So, regarding your cabinet appointments specifically? [SEP] Excuse me? Please, proceed with your statement.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with Brexit done, who gets more of your attention: Macron in France or Johnson in the UK? [SEP] Listen, both are key players. Macron's got a tough job, shaking things up in France. I get it, changing the status quo is never easy. Boris is dealing with the fallout from Brexit, which is a whole different ballgame. And the EU? They're tough negotiators, believe me. We're close to a deal, a really good deal, because they don't want tariffs. Nobody wants tariffs. So, we'll see how it plays out. Both relationships are crucial for America.
label: General

sentence: Sir, regarding the debt ceiling, you mentioned economists agreeing on a deal. Have you been working with any big names in the business world to get Congress to budge? And if so, who are you talking to? [SEP] I've talked to plenty of business leaders. They all say the same thing: we need to fix this. But they're scared to speak up because they don't want to upset Congress. They're all looking out for themselves. Some, like Warren Buffett, have been brave enough to say something, but most are too afraid to rock the boat.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, are you interpreting this as a direct threat? [SEP] The situation is still developing. We're gathering information and assessing the potential implications.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, does your administration now view Kim Jong Un as a peer? [SEP] What do you mean by 'equal'?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with oil prices soaring above $118 a barrel, a record high, are Saudi Arabia and other oil-producing nations acting as adversaries? Have your recent appeals to these countries yielded any positive results? Moreover, won't the escalating gasoline prices effectively nullify the intended effects of the economic stimulus package? [SEP] Well, there's no question that rising gasoline prices are a significant concern for working families. The reality is that we've had an energy policy that has, for too long, neglected the development of domestic energy resources, particularly hydrocarbons. As a result, we're now facing the consequences of that neglect. We should have been exploring for oil and gas in areas like ANWR, but Congress consistently prevented us from opening up new areas for environmentally responsible exploration. This has made us increasingly reliant on foreign sources of oil. Fortunately, we have strong partnerships with Canada and Mexico, who are our largest suppliers, and we're grateful for their contributions. However, the fact remains that our energy policy has not been as effective as it should have been, and we're now seeing the repercussions. Furthermore, there's a limited amount of spare capacity in the global oil market, and unfortunately, much of the supply is coming from regions that are politically unstable. Again, Canada and Mexico are exceptions to this. Some countries are not reinvesting in their reserves, which leads to a decline in production. I'm deeply concerned about the impact of rising gasoline prices on American consumers. That's why it's so important that we passed the tax relief package, and it's equally important that Congress make those tax cuts permanent. Some are advocating for tax increases on the wealthy, but that simply won't generate enough revenue to satisfy their spending appetites. Inevitably, those types of tax schemes end up burdening middle-class families. In a time of economic uncertainty, we need tax certainty. With gasoline prices on the rise, we need to send a clear message to the American people that we're not going to raise their taxes.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So you don't feel a kinship with him? [SEP] He was a great student in law. He was—you know, I've heard his name. I didn't know him. Didn't know him. Until this whole thing, I didn't know him. But I heard his name for 10 years.And you know how I heard his name? Everybody was saying he should be on the Supreme Court. I said, Who is he? His name is Brett Kavanaugh. And he should be—he's the most brilliant person. He's the most brilliant lawyer. They were talking about him on the Supreme Court 10 years ago. With all of that, I want to hear what she has to say. Okay?
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. But it's not the well-to-do people, it's the charities. Given what you just said, are you confident the charities are wrong when they contend that this would discourage giving? [SEP] Yes, I am. I mean, if you look at the evidence, there's very little evidence that this has a significant impact on charitable giving. I'll tell you what has a significant impact on charitable giving, is a financial crisis in an economy that's contracting. And so the most important thing that I can do for charitable giving is to fix the economy, to get banks lending again, to get businesses opening their doors again, and to get people back to work again. Then I think charities will do just fine.Kevin Chappell [Ebony]. Hi, Kevin.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, just to be perfectly clear, if Russia undertakes a 'minor incursion' into Ukraine, will that be met with the same level of sanctions as a full-scale invasion? Or are you signaling to Putin that a limited action is permissible? [SEP] That's a very insightful question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, on a different note, what exactly do you find 'un-American' about federal training programs designed to promote inclusivity and address biases? [SEP] We're preparing a comprehensive report. Those individuals responsible have been terminated. It was, frankly, unacceptable. The forthcoming report will provide clarity. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, your answer offers little hope to those concerned about reproductive rights. Can you outline any specific strategies or legislative proposals you intend to pursue to safeguard abortion access? [SEP] That's a complex issue.

sentence: Q. On the subject of troop deployment in Afghanistan, Mr. President, what is the ideal number from your perspective? [SEP] That's not my department. The United States handles that. The specific numbers aren't what's important in Afghanistan. It's the broader relationship that will make the difference to Afghanistan and beyond in the region. The specifics of numbers are issues that the military will decide, and Afghanistan will have no particular concern when we are talking of numbers and how they are deployed. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, you've highlighted state sovereignty. How does that fit with the 'responsibility to protect' principle, which has often been invoked to help those in need? sentence: Could you perhaps offer a cryptic clue as to the region or countries involved? [SEP] While I appreciate your persistence, I must respectfully decline. The element of surprise is crucial in this instance, and I wouldn't want to spoil the grand reveal.

sentence: President Bush, considering your role as leader of the world's superpower and your previous stance on Iraq's compliance with UN resolutions, why not demand the same from Israel concerning the Palestinian situation? And Mr. Abbas, did you request that President Bush advocate for a complete halt to settlement construction to enable meaningful negotiations? [SEP] I'm sorry, I didn't catch the part about the UN. Could you repeat that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. A follow on that, Mr. President. Does Postmaster DeJoy have your backing for the actions that he's taken in the last several days? [SEP] Yes. He's a fantastic man.

sentence: If the situation deteriorated, could the U.S. military step in to safeguard Pakistan's nuclear weapons? [SEP] We are constantly monitoring the situation and working with our allies to ensure regional stability. I won't speculate on hypothetical scenarios.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue the pipeline is environmentally irresponsible, regardless of the economic benefits. How do you respond? [SEP] Look, we're always balancing economic growth with environmental protection. We're investing in clean energy, but we also need to be realistic about our energy needs. The pipeline will be built with the latest technology to minimize environmental impact. We're not going to sacrifice our economy for the sake of unrealistic environmental goals.

sentence: Regarding the Beirut explosion, even with mere suspicion of a bomb, are there plans for U.S. assets in the region? How are you handling this? [SEP] We're working closely with the government and various agencies, including the military. We'll figure it out; we probably already have. Thank you.

sentence: Considering the uncertainty around North Korea's willingness to engage, is the U.S. prepared to escalate sanctions and exert further pressure? [SEP] I'm not going to speculate on that. Our sanctions are already very robust. I don't want to discuss increasing them. They're strong. There are many good people in North Korea who also have to live. My perspective shifted after getting to know Chairman Kim. They have their own viewpoint. I hope that, for the sake of , Japan, and even —I spoke with President Xi, who is a respected figure—I said, You can't be happy having a nuclear state right next to . And he isn't. He wants that problem resolved as well.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you, Mr. President. Almost everyone, as you noted, in the Rose Garden is wearing a mask today. Why haven't you required everyone at the White House to wear masks before now? [SEP] Well, if they're a certain distance from me or if they're a certain distance from each other, they do. In the case of me, I'm not close to anybody. I'd like to be close to these two gentlemen. They're hard-working, great men, but they just said, frankly, Let's keep it this way. So, obviously, in my case, I'm very far away from everyone. But if you look at all of those people over there, every one of them from what I see—these are White House staffers, they're White House representatives, they're White House executives, and everybody has a mask on.We've had—just about everybody I've seen today has worn a mask.Yes. Please, go ahead.

To follow up on what Kaitlan [Kaitlan Collins, CNN] was saying, are you going to condemn the actions of vigilantes like Kyle Rittenhouse? [SEP] We're looking at all of it. And it was something that we're looking at right now, and it's under investigation.But I guess he was in very big trouble. He would have been—I—he probably would have been killed.

sentence: President Park, you mentioned the importance of international cooperation to denuclearize North Korea. What specific points did you and President Obama discuss regarding this, and what are your thoughts on the roles of Russia and China? President Obama, what are your views on Kim Jong Un, and what message would you send him today? [SEP] Regarding North Korea, our shared goal, along with the international community, is denuclearization and their becoming a responsible member of the global community. This benefits peace on the Korean Peninsula and the world, as well as North Korea's own development. To encourage this, we must work together. China's influence is significant, making their participation crucial. We discussed this. China and Russia, along with the international community, share the goal of a denuclearized Korean Peninsula and are cooperating to guide North Korea. China has actively participated in adopting and implementing U.N. Security Council resolutions regarding North Korea's missile launches and nuclear tests. Russia is also committed to denuclearization and has actively supported U.N. resolutions. They also worked to include a strong message to North Korea in the G-8 Foreign Ministers meeting statement. These efforts are vital to sending a unified message that their nuclear weapons are unacceptable and urging them to make the right choice. I don't know Kim Jong Un personally and can't comment on his character. However, his actions have been provocative and lead to a dead end. We will maintain a strong deterrent and not reward provocative behavior. However, we are open to North Korea pursuing denuclearization, abiding by international commitments, rejoining the international community, and achieving security and prosperity for its people. If North Korea's current path hasn't led to a strong, prosperous nation, now is the time for Kim Jong Un to change course. If he does, we and the international community would welcome it. China, Russia, Japan, and other participants in the six-party talks have made this clear. However, changes in behavior are necessary. As the saying goes, 'Watch what I do, not what I say.' So far, North Korea's actions haven't indicated a willingness to change direction.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Postmaster General DeJoy, these allegations of campaign finance improprieties are serious. What's your reaction? [SEP] I'm aware of the reports, but I haven't had a chance to fully review them. He's generally well-regarded, and his appointment was supported by both parties. I'll get the facts and make a determination. I can't comment definitively at this time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. My name is—[inaudible]—of SBS. I have a question for President Park. Madam President, last month at Dresden, Germany, you have announced your unification initiative centering around the three main proposals for laying the groundwork for peace and unification, but North Korea flatly rejected it and has continued with its threats of provocation. In particular, North Korea is showing signs for an attempt at the fourth nuclear test against this backdrop. The two leaders said that there will be—at their opening statements—strong sanctions and against—posed against North Korea by the international society, and they will not—the two countries will not tolerate a nuclear test.I would like to know what the President's evaluation is. Is there a possibility of North Korea actually carrying out the nuclear test? And if the provocations continue, if you are to improve and move forward in the Korean relations, are you considering a more flexible measure to be taken against the North? Nextly, with regards to the U.S.-Korea transfer of the wartime command or the OPCON, the two leaders have said that they will review the timing and conditions for transfer. And if the transfer schedule is pushed back again, have you discussed with the President Obama specifically on when that timing will be? [SEP] Yes. At the Korean Government and also at the Defense Ministry, our assessment is that the North Korea is actually fully ready to carry out the fourth nuclear test, so it can actually carry out the test whenever it deems necessary. That is our assessment. We're not very certain of what the timing will be, but I think we believe that they are fully ready now.And this is a very tense situation. To come up with some flexible measure—that is your question—actually, the Dresden initiative is a case in point for a win-win of the two Koreas and for improvement of the quality of life for the North Korean residents. It's indeed a flexible policy. But the North Korea is responding with threats of provocation and about carrying out North Korea—to carry out nuclear tests. So this is a point that we really need to think seriously.With regards to the transfer of the OPCON, Korea and the United States have decided that the basic direction should be to strengthen the KORUS, combine the defensive posture. We believe that it should not incur any negative situations on the defense posture for the Korea. And therefore, against the heightening tensions of the threats currently, the timing is 2015. But we have agreed that we could revisit this issue about reviewing the timing and conditions for transfer.So, currently, I don't think it is quite appropriate that I give you exact timing or the conditions. But the authorities—the defense authorities of the two countries—will be able to come to a coordination effort together, and that was what we will do to encourage the defense authorities to move forward.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the threat of chemical weapons, while respecting the need to protect intelligence, can you offer any insights into the administration's level of concern regarding potential deployment by Russia? And to be clear, would the use of chemical weapons automatically trigger a military response from the United States or NATO, or are there specific conditions that would need to be met? [SEP] The use of chemical weapons is, let me be clear, completely unacceptable. We are monitoring the situation closely. I'm not going to get into hypotheticals or speculate on specific responses. But we are prepared to act, and we will act decisively, should the need arise. The details, of course, will depend on the situation on the ground.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, the 'thumpin'' was without a 'g', right? Just want to be clear for the record. [Laughter] You said you were surprised, didn't see it coming, and were disappointed. Does this mean after six years in the Oval Office, you're out of touch with America if you didn't anticipate such a wave? And, somewhat related, does Nancy Pelosi remind you of Bob Bullock? [SEP] That's an inside joke; I'm not commenting on it. Secondly, I'm an optimistic person, is what I am. And I knew we were going to lose seats; I just didn't know how many.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Is the coming election a referendum on Iraq? Should it be? [SEP] I think the coming election is a referendum on these two things: Which party has got the plan that will enable our economy continue—to continue to grow, and which party has a plan to protect the American people. And Iraq is part of the security of the United States. If we succeed—and when we succeed in Iraq, our country will be more secure. If we don't succeed in Iraq, the country is less secure.The security of this country—and look, I understand here in Washington, some people say we're not at war. I know that. They're just wrong, in my opinion.The enemy still wants to strike us. The enemy still wants to achieve safe haven from which to plot and plan. The enemy would like to have weapons of mass destruction in order to attack us. These are lethal, coldblooded killers. And we must do everything we can to protect the American people, including questioning detainees or listening to their phone calls from outside the country to inside the country. And there was—as you know, there was some recent votes on that issue. And the Democrats voted against giving our professionals the skill—the tools necessary to protect the American people.I will repeat, like I've said to you often: I do not question their patriotism; I question whether or not they understand how dangerous this world is. And this is a big issue in the campaign. Security of the country is an issue, just like taxes are an issue. If you raise taxes, it will hurt the economy. If you don't extend the tax cuts, if you don't make them—in other words, if you let the tax cuts expire, it will be a tax increase on the American people.Take the child tax credit. If it is not made permanent—in other words, if it expires—and you got a family of four sitting around the breakfast table, the taxpayers can be sure that their taxes will go up by $2,000: 500 for that child, 500 for the one right there, 500 for this one, and 500 for that one. That is a tax increase. And taking $2,000 out of the pockets of the working people will make it harder to sustain economic growth.So the two issues I see in the campaign can be boiled down to, who best to protect this country and who best to keep taxes low. That's what the referendum is about.Let's see here, David [David Greene, Baltimore Sun]. Hold on for a minute. David.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with the situation in Afghanistan evolving rapidly, can you definitively state that the war is over? And does the administration recognize the Taliban as the legitimate governing authority? Furthermore, why the renomination of Congressman Ratcliffe given past concerns? [SEP] He's a top-notch individual, a real performer in everything he's tackled. Highly respected, believe me. He wanted to hold off until the IG report dropped, which it now has, revealing some pretty disturbing stuff, as you know. I don't think his nomination was ever official, just a name thrown around. But now the report's out, and things are moving forward. As for the Taliban, everyone wanted this to happen. President Ghani was on board, dealing with them now. We're talking about 19 years, folks. Other presidents tried, failed. The Taliban made a strong pledge, and we'll see how it pans out. They've got incentives to make it work, but they need to handle those terrorists. We'll be working on that angle, too. We've done a fantastic job on terrorism, and it's time to bring our people home.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, given the potential for a broader economic recession, what specific contingency plans are in place to address unemployment, stimulate economic growth, and protect vulnerable populations? [SEP] We're monitoring the situation closely and working with our economic advisors to develop appropriate responses. We'll use all the tools at our disposal to support American workers and businesses. We're confident that our economy will weather this storm and emerge stronger than ever. We're committed to ensuring that everyone has the opportunity to succeed.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, while your proposal aims to improve Medicare efficiency, can you guarantee that these changes will not result in any reduction of benefits for current or future recipients? [SEP] Well, on the second point, that's exactly what our proposal is. It—called the MedPAC program. By the way, it was originally a Republican idea. I want to give credit where credit is due. The Republican Congress passed a bill that created a panel of health care experts to make recommendations to Congress on how we could get better quality, lower cost. The problem is, every year it would just go on a shelf and nobody would act on it.So what we've said is let's give that body some power. Let's require Congress to vote on the proposals that they're making every year. Congress can still reject them, so it's not completely removing it from politics, but they have to reject or accept it as a package. And that, I think, would incentivize and empower important changes.But here's the thing I want to emphasize, Chip. It's not going to reduce benefits. What it's going to do is to change how those benefits are delivered so that they're more efficient. Let me give you a very specific example. You've heard that as a consequence of our efforts at reform, the pharmaceutical industry has already said they're willing to put $80 billion on the table. Now, why is that? Well, the reason is, is because there's probably even more waste than $80 billion, in terms of how the drug plan in is administered. We might be able to get 100 billion out or more, but the pharmaceutical industry voluntarily said here's $80 billion.You know what that translates—what that means? That means that senior citizens who right now have a so-called doughnut hole in their plan, where after spending a certain amount on prescription drugs suddenly they drop off a cliff and they've got to pocket the entire cost, suddenly half of that is filled. That's a hard commitment that we already have. So that's a change in how we are delivering . But you know what? It turns out that it means out-of-pocket savings for seniors. That's why AARP has endorsed us. Okay.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the ongoing investigation, what steps are being taken to ensure accountability and transparency within the World Bank? [SEP] We are committed to upholding the highest standards of ethics and integrity at the World Bank. We are cooperating fully with the investigation, and we will take appropriate action based on its findings. We are also working to strengthen the Bank's internal controls and oversight mechanisms to prevent similar situations from occurring in the future.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Biden, considering Russia's aggression in Ukraine and China's rising influence in Asia, what role do you envision for Japan? Prime Minister Kishida suggests Ukraine could be East Asia's future. What's your take? I respect the IAEA report despite domestic opposition. This summit wasn't solely about China. It's about strengthening our relationships and promoting a peaceful Indo-Pacific. On Ukraine, I'm grateful for Japan's support. Russia has already failed in its objectives. Japan's leadership highlights the global consequences of war. The world is changing. This is a big deal.

sentence: Mr. President, what should young men in America know? [SEP] It's a wild time. It's a very big moment for our country, because you have a man who is very outstanding, but he's got very strong charges against him—probably charges that nobody is going to be able be—to prove. They're coming after everyone.

But I think what he was getting at is that these are incredibly complex challenges, and no single solution is going to be a silver bullet. We're dealing with unprecedented economic headwinds, and even with the best policies, there's always a degree of uncertainty.

We believe that respect for human rights is essential for a strong and prosperous . Regarding North Korea, we are united with Japan and our allies in condemning their destabilizing actions. We are committed to working together to maintain peace and security in the region.

sentence: Gentlemen, did your discussions include the possibility of Canada boosting its stimulus efforts? And looking ahead four years, what's your vision for the Canada-U.S. relationship, particularly concerning the auto industry, border security, and carbon markets? sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia's purported withdrawal from Kherson, do you perceive this as a potential inflection point in the conflict, and does Ukraine now possess the requisite leverage to initiate peace negotiations with Moscow? [SEP] Nancy, it strikes me as rather curious that they elected to disclose this information after our elections, a development we anticipated for some time. This, I believe, speaks volumes regarding the challenges facing the Russian military. Secondly, this development will afford all parties an opportunity to re-evaluate their respective positions during the winter months. The question of whether Ukraine is prepared to compromise with Russia remains to be determined. I shall be attending the G-20 summit. While President Putin is reportedly unlikely to be present, other world leaders will be in attendance. We shall have the opportunity to assess potential future courses of action. Nancy, CBS, if I'm not mistaken?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you very much, Mr. President. If I could follow up a little bit on North Korea, the North Koreans agreed last year to make their disclosure. We're now in April, and we've yet to see this disclosure. There are continued negotiations, a new round next week. Are you concerned that, given this record, they're not prepared to make this full disclosure, that they're stalling the process somehow? And if so, a question for both of you: How do you respond to that? [SEP] Yes, of course. I mean, they may be trying to stall. One thing about a nontransparent society where there's not a lot of free press, for example, or a lot of opposition voices, it's hard to tell what's going on. Now, he has made declarations, and he's testing the relationship. He's wondering whether or not the five of us will stay unified. And the only thing I know to do is to continue pressing forward within the six-party framework.The decision—we've made our decision. We, the five of us, have made our decision, and that is, there's a way forward. And obviously, we hope he chooses to honor his commitments in a verifiable way. But it's—when you're dealing with a society in which it's hard to get information out of, you just have to wait and see whether they're sincere or not. Unlike our society, of course, where there's all kinds of people in the administration talking and sharing information with you—some of it authorized, some of it's not—it doesn't happen that way in . It's a closed society. It's a society in which the will of one person decides the course of the future.And again, we're very hopeful. We talked about our mutual desire to keep the six-party framework in place to deal with a lot of issues. The first one, of course, is with . And it's—I can just tell you, Steven Lee, it's much more effective to have more than one voice speaking on this issue than to be the sole voice speaking on the issue. And so if it—if there ever is going to be a breakthrough, it's through the six-party framework.And look, I'm hopeful. We'll see. This has been a—I've been at this for quite a while. And there's been moments where it looked like the process was going to go very smoothly and everybody's going to honor their commitments, and then for one reason or another, there's a—there was a setback. But the key thing is, is that we haven't abandoned the efforts to solve this problem peacefully and diplomatically. Thank you. If you correctly understand and if you do understand n society, you'll probably get a better picture of why we are seeing some delay in the process at the moment. If wasn't like that, then we would have seen the resolvement of this issue already. We need persistent patience, ladies and gentlemen. And we need time in order to have complete resolution of this issue.However, it's difficult to convince to give up their nuclear weapons program, but it's not impossible. It is not impossible. I believe that. So in order to resolve this issue, I believe that the six-party talks is the most effective way and mechanism to resolve this issue, like the President mentioned. And right now we're in the stages of waiting for their declaration, and then we can move on to the verification process.So I think it's up to you to make the atmosphere so that can faithfully abide by their promise and make the right declaration, that once does so, it is also in their interest to make the correct decision to give a full and complete declaration. And it will also help the n people improve the quality of their life, and that is the best strategic choice that they can make.
label: Explicit

sentence: E-Verify veto without legalization? And Fast and Furious: ATF changes and investigation completion? [SEP] Regarding Fast and Furious, the Attorney General has stated he would not have ordered gun running. The investigation is ongoing, so I cannot comment directly. I have made my views clear that such actions would be inappropriate and we must find out what happened. As for E-Verify, comprehensive immigration reform is necessary. We must balance our traditions as a nation of laws and immigrants, with border security, employer accountability, and a path to legal status. E-Verify can be a useful enforcement tool if it is not riddled with errors and protects U.S. citizens. We must also consider DREAM Act kids. A balanced approach is needed.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Good afternoon. President Bush, what is your opinion about the way in which the government has handled the scandal of the politicians involved in drug trafficking because—and the paramilitaries?— because we know that there are many more members involved with the paramilitaries. Up to what extent do you support President Uribe given the fact that most of these paramilitary heads are drug traffickers? And finally, the U.S. will insist on extraditing these people? [SEP] I support a plan that says that there will be an independent judiciary analyzing every charge brought forth, and when someone is found guilty, there's punishment. That's the kind of plan I support. It happens to be the kind of plan the President supports. In other words, there's no political favorites when it comes to justice, that if someone is guilty, they will pay a penalty. And the best way to assure that that penalty is fair and the justice is fair is for there to be a court independent from politics.And so when I asked this very same question to the President about the news I've been reading in Washington, DC, the same questions he's going to be asked when he and his government come to talk to our Congress, he answered just like I described. He said: We have an independent court. We've got a firm law. People will be held to account, whether or not they're—no matter what political party they may or may not be associated with. That's what the people of Colombia expect; that's the kind of justice they're going to receive.Listen, this country has come through some very difficult times. And the best way to heal wounds is for people to see fair, independent justice being delivered, and I believe that's the kind of justice this government will do.Deb [Deb Riechmann, Associated Press].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding Meng Wanzhou, will her case also be deferred indefinitely, or is there a possibility the U.S. might drop the extradition request? [SEP] Extradition on what grounds?

sentence: Q. The—if I could follow up, sir: The South China Morning Post, the Beijing newspaper, says that China would like to reopen negotiations on the trade deal to make the terms more favorable to them. I had heard that too: They'd like to reopen the trade talk to make it a better deal for them.China has been taking advantage of the United States for many, many years, for decades, because we had people at this position, right here where I'm standing, sitting right in that office—the Oval Office—that allowed that to happen.No, I'm not interested in that. Let's see if they live up to the deal that they signed. Okay?Please, go ahead.

sentence: Mr. President, given John Howard's focus on climate change at APEC, haven't you undermined his efforts with your Washington meeting? And how relevant do you consider Kyoto to be in addressing climate change? [SEP] Let's address the latter first. As I age, I might need reminders. Kyoto might suit others, but it didn't for the U.S. I was honest about that. Before my D.C. trip, the Senate overwhelmingly rejected Kyoto, 95-0. It wasn't just my view. We pursued a different path: energy efficiency via new tech. We cut greenhouse gases last year while our economy grew by 3%. Not many can claim that. Our tech-focused strategy works. I believe we can reduce foreign oil dependency. As an energy exporter, that might worry some. We have a '20-in-10' plan to cut gasoline use by 20% in 10 years using ethanol and new tech. Battery tech will let Sydney drivers go 40 miles on battery without a golf cart look. New tech is coming. The key is getting it to market fast. Kyoto didn't do that for us. Look at who's meeting Kyoto targets; a different approach might be better. We rejected Kyoto because it hindered our goals: economic growth, less foreign oil, environmental stewardship. John and I discussed his APEC climate change focus, and I supported it. At the G-8, I stressed the need to include everyone, like China and India, in climate change solutions. Otherwise, they might reject imposed solutions. Global climate change efforts need China. The Prime Minister's protocol was smart, aiming to cut tariffs on clean coal tech exports to China. He wants to remove barriers, and we support him. Key questions: How fast can we get effective tech to market—coal sequestration, nuclear reprocessing? Can we help developing nations acquire them? Otherwise, it's ineffective. Our strategy is the most effective. I appreciate the Prime Minister's focus on energy dependency and efficiency, which are part of the climate mix. He shows leadership, and I'm proud to discuss it. Thank you.
label: Clarification

sentence: But some critics argue your absence suggests a lack of accountability. [SEP] Accountability? I'm the most accountable president there's ever been. I'm accountable to the American people, and they know I'm fighting for them every single day. This is just another attempt by the fake news media to distract from the great things we're accomplishing.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea's nuclear facilities, did you discuss the possibility of inspections during your negotiations, as Valentinovna from Sputnik News is asking? [SEP] I apologize, but I didn't quite catch that. Could you please speak up and remind me of your news organization?

sentence: Mr. President, despite sending your CIA Director to Pyongyang, the three Americans remain detained, and no apparent concessions were made by North Korea. Are you prepared to meet with Kim Jong Un while Americans are still being held? Will you insist on tangible concessions in exchange for gestures like sending a potential Secretary of State? [SEP] Well, let's address the facts. They are holding three prisoners, and we are actively engaged in negotiations to secure their release. They have been held for an extended period and subjected to harsh treatment. We worked tirelessly to bring Otto Warmbier home, but tragically, he was in very poor condition. We are equally committed to bringing these three American citizens back home. I am optimistic about our chances. We are maintaining a productive dialogue and will keep you informed of our progress. We have made significant strides with North Korea. For many years, discussions have taken place without any tangible results. Previous administrations should have addressed this issue when the situation was less advanced. However, we have implemented powerful sanctions and taken other measures. I want to publicly acknowledge President Xi of China, who has provided unprecedented support. He has significantly tightened border controls, exceeding his initial expectations, and I am grateful for his efforts. This has exerted considerable pressure. Approximately 93 percent of goods entering North Korea originate from China. President Xi understands the critical importance of the coming months. He shares our desire to prevent a nuclear Korea. He is also acting in China's best interests. He has been exceptional. Can he improve? Always. But he has been very effective, and it has had a significant impact. We have never been in this position with the North Korean regime. I am hopeful for a successful meeting. However, if we do not believe it will be productive, we will not proceed. If the meeting proves unfruitful, I will respectfully conclude it, and we will continue our efforts. I remain flexible. President Moon of South Korea generously acknowledged that the Olympics would have been a failure without my involvement. Our participation was instrumental in its success. Ticket sales were struggling before North Korea's involvement. We have brought us to this point, and I am confident in our success. However, if I have any reservations, we will end the process.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Calderon, with tensions high in Congress, what's your perspective on the Lopez Obrador/Hitler comparisons and their impact on the energy bill discussions? [SEP] Frankly, those comparisons are a reflection of the people who are making them. The Congress is working as it should, with most parties acting responsibly. I regret these kinds of tactics, which only hurt the image of those who use them. I hope we can strengthen dialogue and cooperation. The authorities are dealing with the TV ads, and I trust they'll make the right decision.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: On the campaign trail, you promised middle-class tax cuts. What specific strategies will you employ to secure Democratic support for this initiative? [SEP] That's a question for the Democrats, isn't it? They know what's at stake.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, many parents are understandably anxious about the lack of a vaccine for children under 5. What specific steps are being taken to expedite the approval process, and what is the projected timeline for when this vaccine might become available? [SEP] The FDA is working diligently, but they need to be absolutely certain about the safety and efficacy. We can't rush the science. They're conducting rigorous trials, and they'll make a decision as soon as they have all the necessary data. I understand the frustration, but we have to prioritize safety above all else. It's a matter of time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the rise of nationalism, should protestors against Donald Trump's rhetoric stop demonstrating? Did you advise your successor on staff picks? And do you have leverage to stop the bombing of Aleppo by Assad and Putin? [SEP] Protest is a cornerstone of our democracy. I've experienced it myself. I wouldn't tell people to be silent. Elections, voting, organizing, and being informed are crucial. I urge young people not to take our government for granted. Democracy requires constant effort. If a significant portion of eligible voters abstain, democracy suffers. If we can't differentiate facts from propaganda, we face challenges. If people are unwilling to compromise, democracy falters. My primary advice is to understand the foundations of a healthy democracy and engage in continuous citizenship. Many young people are involved, but complacency exists. In Europe, some forget the Cold War. There's an easy equivalence between the US and Russia, which is inaccurate. We have flaws, but we've been beneficial to Germany and Europe. We've provided security and helped rebuild. We've generally strived to uphold principles of free speech and civil liberties. Remember that in an era of misinformation. Don't equate overzealousness with repression. We won't know what to protect. That was a lengthy response. I've forgotten the second part.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Bush, deportations continue. Is there a commitment from your country to cease these deportations since you expect to have a comprehensive immigration reform? [SEP] People will be treated with respect, but the United States will enforce our law. It's against the law to hire somebody who is in our country illegally, and we are a nation of law.The best way to solve the concerns of the citizens of Guatemala—listen, I fully understand that the citizens of Guatemala are concerned about their relatives or friends who are in the United States. And I appreciate that. The best way to address the concerns inherent in your question is for me to work with Congress to get a comprehensive bill. And I'm optimistic we can do so. It's going to be tough work— don't get me wrong—but I believe we can get a comprehensive bill out of the Congress.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Meng Wanzhou, will her case also be deferred until the end, or could the U.S. potentially drop the extradition effort? [SEP] When what? On what?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, Mr. President, you don't feel a connection with him? [SEP] He was an excellent law student, I've heard. I knew of him, but I didn't really know him until this whole thing. I'd heard his name for 10 years. You know how? Everyone was saying he should be on the Supreme Court. I asked, 'Who is he?' Brett Kavanaugh. They were talking about him for the Supreme Court a decade ago, saying he's the most brilliant lawyer. Despite all that, I want to hear what she has to say. Okay?
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And, President Uribe, with all the talk about Chavez, could you tell us your opinion on whether you think his influence in the region is overstated? [SEP] What is my opinion on?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. You don't like giving money? [SEP] Excuse me. Number two, I said the following—and I said this loud and clear to everybody. And, in fact, Rob Portman backed me up, and there's nobody more honorable than Rob Portman of Ohio. Because he called up: Please, let the money go. I said: Rob, I hate being the country that's always giving money when Ukraine helps Europe and the European countries far more than they help us. They're like a wall between Russia and Europe. They're like a wall. They're a big, wide, beautiful wall.And he said: You know what? But it's important. And he—in fact, he came out, and he said that. That was my only reason. Because I don't like being the sucker country. We were the sucker country for years and years. We're not the sucker country anymore. But I gave the money, because Rob Portman and others called me and asked. But I don't like to be the sucker. And European countries are helped far more than we are, and those countries should pay more to help Ukraine.Go ahead. Ask a question, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Considering the staggering number of casualties and the vast sums of money expended, why shouldn't the American people conclude that you are being stubborn, living in denial, and completely out of touch with reality regarding the strategy you've been pursuing? [SEP] Well, it's interesting you bring that up, because Mike Hayden, who I think you're referencing, was in this morning for his regular briefing, and I specifically asked him about that article. His comments to the Iraq Study Group were actually a bit more nuanced than that quote suggests. He made it clear that the strategy at the time wasn't working and that we needed a new approach. He also pointed out that those suggesting we simply pull back and let the Iraqi government handle things didn't fully grasp their capacity at that time. He went on to say that our strategy needed to focus on reducing violence to create space for political reconciliation, both from the top down and from the grassroots level. And we've seen that reconciliation happening at the grassroots level. Look at Anbar Province, a place experts said was impossible to stabilize. Things have changed dramatically there, because the people are tired of the violence and threats from groups like Al Qaeda, who offer nothing positive.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Donatella Di Nitto of LaPresse. A question for President Mattarella: President Trump seems to being open on discussing the possible tariffs. So do you think it will be possible to avoid tariffs being imposed in 2 days' time?And a question for President Trump: Now, we all know your concerns concerning Huawei entering Italy's security system. Are you satisfied with the measures that Italy decided to implement? [SEP] Well, I'll answer first. Yes, I am satisfied. They have been very accommodating. They weren't at the beginning, and they have been since then.And I want to just thank the Italian Government and your Prime Minister, actually, in addition to the President. But as you know, I had long conversations with my friend, and they were very nice. So I am very satisfied. And we just discussed the same conversation with the President. We're very satisfied. Thank you. As far as the topic of tariffs is concernedtariffs following the WTO decision on the EU's contribution, or the subsidies to the Airbus consortiumI already mentioned what our belief is. Let me repeat it:I think that within the transatlantic relationship, and with the friendship that there has always been between the U.S. and the EU, it would be preferable to discuss our respective positions so that we can find a solution which takes into account the requirements of both parties. And that's wholly possible.The alternative would be that of imposing tariffs. Currently, following the WTO's decision concerning Airbus, wethere may be tariffs. And there may be tariffs in 6 months' time concerning the subsidies given to Boeing. This is a mere race between tariffs and mutual tariffs. I think it would be best to meet and to deal with our mutual needs so that a solution can be found.But if we don't do this now, it will have to be done soon. And I believe it would be best to find a solution immediately, instead of imposing tariffs, which would lead to other tariffs, and that would be a damage to both our economies. Well, actually, the tariff situation is interesting because we justit's like I said with China, and it turned out to be truewe cannot lose a war of tariffs because the imbalance is so great between the United States and, in this case, the European Union. Also true with China. That turned out to be right. We've collected tens of billions of dollars of tariffs. We've given some to the farmers, to make them even. And now the farmers are going to have a bigger contract than they ever thought possible. They won't be able to produce even that much, but I think they will, because they're incredible, ingenious. As I say, jokingly, but probably not jokingly: They'll just have to buy larger tractors, which is probably what they're doing right now. But the farmers come out so well.But in a war of tariffs with the European Union, the trade imbalance is so great that we can't lose that, because they do much more business than we do, and that's unfortunate. But the word reciprocity is probably my favorite word. Of all of these words, all of the semicomplicated, complicatedto me, not complicated at allthings that we're doing, it's got to be reciprocal, and it's not.The European Union has taken tremendous advantage of the United States. Many of us come throughone way or the otherthrough the European Union. That's the good news. The bad news is they've been very smart. They've been very smart. Jean-Claude has been brilliant. Now he's leaving, but he's beenhe's been brilliant at really helping them and not helping us.And so that's changing now. But we can't lose that particular war of tariffs, because the trade imbalance is tremendous. It's tremendous. And if you look at what they don't havethe barriers that they put up; they put up tremendous barriers to our doing business in Europetremendous barriersboth from a monetary standpoint and what they call nonmonetary barriers.It's a very tough thing. Our farm products, very hard to get them in. Our cars, very hard to get them in. And yet they send Mercedes. They send BMW. Then they send Volkswagen; Renault, in the case of France. So it's a very tough situation for us for many years, but now it's a very tough situation for them. Because I can remedy the situation very easily, and there really is not any financial counterattack. Hopefully, I don't have to do that.We arewith all of the being said, we are talking. We're talking with some new people in Europe, and I hope it's going to be successful; that way, we don't have to talk about it or worry about it, because our relationship should be a great one. But we have to be treated fairly on NATO, and we have to be treated fairly on trade with the European Union.Thank you all very much. Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Biden, considering the multifaceted nature of the U.S.-Canada partnership, encompassing economic stimulus, the automotive industry, border management, and carbon emissions trading, which of these domains presents the most pressing challenge and opportunity for bilateral cooperation? [SEP] Now, just a darn minute here. It sounds like you are trying to get me to answer multiple questions at once. You need to slow down and ask one at a time.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. I will ask in Pashto, and then I will translate my question. My question is for Mr. Karzai.[At this point, the reporter asked a question in Pashto, which he translated as follows.]I will repeat in English too. Four years ago, in a press conference, Mr. President Karzai said Taliban do not pose any threat to Afghan people. So who do you think supported Taliban to threaten the security by doing kidnapings and attacking the Government officials, and why? [SEP] Four years ago, I did say that, and I continue to say that. The Taliban do pose dangers to our innocent people; to children going to school; to our clergy; to our teachers; to our engineers; to international aid workers. They are not posing any threat to the Government of Afghanistan; they are not posing any threat to the institutions of Afghanistan or to the buildup of institutions of Afghanistan. It's a force that's defeated; it's a force that is frustrated; it's a force that is acting in cowardice by killing children going to school.Who is supporting them is a question that we have been working on for long time and since then. And I hope that the jirga between us and Pakistan will give us solutions to some of the questions that we have. One thing is for certain: We know the vision—their vision of how to govern. They've been in power. They've had the opportunity to show the world how they think and what they do. I mean, it'd be instructive for people to speak to a mother of a young girl about what life was like under the Taliban. These are brutal, coldblooded killers. Yes. That's what they are. And the fundamental question facing those of us who believe in freedom is whether or not we confront them, and whether or not it's worth it—the effort—to spread an alternative to their hateful vision. And I— we've come to the conclusion it is. And that's why President Karzai stands right here at Camp David, discussing common concerns, common opportunities, about how to defeat a vision of darkness. That's what they are. They just don't believe in freedom. They don't believe it's possible to live in a society where people are allowed to express themselves in free fashion.And it's really part of an ongoing challenge that the free world faces. The real question is whether or not those of us who have the blessings of liberty will continue to pursue policies—foreign policy, security policy aimed at not only protecting our homeland but aimed at laying a condition for peace to prevail.Caren [Caren Bohan, Reuters].
label: General

sentence: Given the ongoing discussions about a potential second summit with Chairman Kim Jong Un, could you clarify whether you envision it taking place in Pyongyang or Washington? [SEP] Well, those details are still being ironed out. We're definitely considering another meeting, or perhaps we'll call it a dialogue, to keep things fresh. The progress we've made has honestly exceeded my expectations. To be frank, I didn't anticipate reaching this point so quickly. I cautioned against raising hopes prematurely, suggesting that a successful initial meeting would involve establishing a rapport and setting the stage for this level of progress in a few months. However, things moved swiftly, largely due to the groundwork laid beforehand. For example, the repatriation of remains wasn't initially on the agenda. I raised it towards the end, prompted by numerous inquiries. Chairman Kim responded graciously, agreeing to proceed immediately, recognizing the significance of honoring those who served. This gesture will bring solace to many. So, yes, we're moving forward.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, just a follow-up, please, if you don't mind. If it's proven to be a campaign finance scheme, do you think he should lose his job? [SEP] Yes. If something can be proven that he did something, always. You know?
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. You have set the target before leaving the White House that, by the end of this year, you will, hopefully, achieve an historical peace between the Israelis and the Palestinians. However, in light of what's happening to the fragile position of Ehud Olmert—Prime Minister Ehud Olmert and the continuous process of building illegal settlements in the—in eastern Jerusalem and certain parts of the occupied territories, do you think that peace is far away right now in light of those obstacles? [SEP] Yes. Thank you. First of all, I view the concept of a Palestinian state and the idea of a Palestinian state for Israeli security, as well as Palestinian security and hope, as bigger than the political process. And I fully recognize there's a lot of uncertainty in the Israeli political scene now.On the other hand, what is not uncertain is that most people—or many people in Israel understand that for their own security, there has to be a Palestinian state with clearly defined borders, a state that doesn't look like Swiss cheese, a resolution of the refugee issue and the security issue, and of course, issues surrounding Jerusalem.Most Palestinians want to coexist in peace with Israel. And that peace must be in a state that is clearly visible, well-defined, and in actuality is a state. And so in other words, the concept—and by the way, this is newly arrived. I'm actually the first President ever to have articulated a two-state solution, two democracies living side by side with peace—in peace. And during my time as President, I've seen a notable shift amongst folks in the Middle East that recognize the importance of having that state.So my point to you is, is that, you know, it's been a—there's always difficulties in democracies, but the notion is a—of getting this work done is important. And therefore, our diplomacy is to remind all the parties involved that they have now an opportunity to get a state negotiated. And I think it can be done by the end of the year. Condi is very much involved with it on a—you know, a nearly weekly, it seems like, basis. And of course, I'm in touch with the leaders. The Palestinians are discouraged by the settlement activity—all the more reason to get the borders clearly defined as quickly as possible.I want to thank Nicolas and the EU, for example, for helping build civil society in the Palestinian Territory as well as helping Prime Minister Fayyad with security measures.I'll also remind you that it's essential that we get a state defined as quickly as possible so that leaders such as President Abbas and Prime Minister Fayyad can say to their people, here's an alternative vision to what's taking place in Gaza. You support us, and you're going to get a state. You support Hamas, and you're going to get Gaza. Take your pick.And therefore, there it's imperative that we, you know, convince the parties to get this done. Now, I know some say, All America has got to do is say, 'Do it.' No, the way it works is, is that the parties have got to come to this agreement. Our job, along with the EU through the Quartet, is to keep the process moving.And so I'm optimistic. I understand how difficult it is, but difficulty should not cause people to do the right thing. If you believe in your soul something is right, then you have an obligation to work. And in this case, I firmly believe that the establishment of the Palestinian state will bring hope and peace to the Israelis and the Palestinians.Thank you.
label: General

sentence: President Bush, given the persistent difficulties in Africa, what are the most critical steps Africa must take, what type of leadership is required, and how will the U.S. assist? Furthermore, what are your objectives for this trip, and how will you ensure these initiatives continue after your term? [SEP] Thank you. This isn't my first trip to Africa; I came early in my presidency too. I'm here to emphasize that it's in our interest to help Africa fight diseases, promote trade, and invest in education. Ghana is a perfect example. It's one thing to talk about it in America, it's another to see it on the ground. Africa has changed for the better since I took office, thanks to African leaders. We've seen conflict resolution, like in Liberia, where we helped install the first democratically elected female president. We're a partner, not an imposer. Democracy is progressing, thanks to leaders like John Kufuor. Our aid program now requires accountability, like fighting corruption and investing in education. I believe in holding African leaders to high standards. The leaders I'm meeting are committed to their people and honest government. They prioritize education. That's why I'm here, and I'm glad I am. It's been a great trip. John McKinnon from the Wall Street Journal.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with the benefit of hindsight, do you now believe Israel's response was appropriate? [SEP] David, I'm going to refrain from offering any opinion on that matter.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And you will wait until tomorrow to make up your mind about it? [SEP] I want to watch. I want to see. I hope I can watch. I'm meeting with a lot of countries tomorrow, but I will certainly, in some form, be able to watch. And I'll also rely on some very fair and talented Republican Senators who—look, if we brought George Washington here and we said, We have George Washington, the Democrats would vote against him, just so you understand. []And he may have had a bad past, who knows, you know. [] He may have had some, I think, accusations made. Didn't he have a couple of things in his past? George Washington would be voted against 100 percent by Schumer and the con artists. I mean, 100 percent. One hundred percent.So it really doesn't matter from their standpoint. That's why when John asked about the FBI. If the FBI did the most thorough investigation in the history of the FBI and they found him to be 100-percent perfect, he would lose every single vote.Now, if the Republicans win tomorrow, I think you're going to get some votes from the Democrats. You know why? Because—we all know why—because it's called politics. Then, you'll probably get some votes.Okay, let's go.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the WHO, if Tedros were to resign immediately, would you then consider reinstating U.S. funding and support? Or are you seeking broader reforms beyond just a change in leadership? [SEP] We're looking into the whole situation very carefully. I don't know the man personally, but there are clearly some serious issues. The WHO has been incredibly unfair to the United States, much like the World Trade Organization. They're starting to realize that now, though. How is it that China is still considered a developing nation, allowing them to take advantage of the U.S. on a massive scale? Why didn't previous presidents address this? I've been talking about it since day one, and we're taking a hard look at it. So, I have concerns with both the World Health Organization and the World Trade Organization. It's hard to say which is worse, to be honest, but we'll get to the bottom of it. Alright?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, under what specific circumstances would you consider meeting with President Castro in Havana? Are there any preconditions that you would need to see fulfilled before such a meeting could take place? Furthermore, concerning the recent cyberattack, while you've stated that you won't publicly announce your response, can you at least confirm whether you're contemplating additional economic or financial sanctions against North Korea? And can you definitively rule out the possibility of military force or a retaliatory cyber operation? [SEP] I'm going to stick with my previous statement. We've confirmed North Korea's involvement and are evaluating a range of options. These options will be presented to me, and I'll make a decision based on what I deem proportional and appropriate for this crime. As for Cuba, a visit from me or President Castro is not on the horizon. I don't know how that relationship will evolve. I'm still a young man, so I imagine I'll visit Cuba someday and interact with the Cuban people. But there's no specific visit planned.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you suggesting you've forgotten who your own Secretary is? [SEP] No, no, of course not. I'm just saying I wish everyone success in their endeavors. It's a tough job.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: On the subject of your cabinet selections... [SEP] Proceed, I'm listening.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you've spoken about state sovereignty. How does that fit with the 'responsibility to protect' principle? [SEP] I'm sorry, I didn't quite catch the last part of your question. Could you rephrase it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. ——question—about the Crown Prince that you met with earlier today. I didn't hear you answer the question: Did you raise the killing of Jamal Khashoggi with him? [SEP] I asked yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, are you planning on engaging in direct talks with Iranian officials? [SEP] The core of your question revolves around whether I intend to personally meet with Iranian representatives, is that accurate?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Can we just ask you about the Al Qaida intelligence report, please? [SEP] What was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, to clarify, Baker suggests direct talks with Iran on Iraq. Is that off the table unless enrichment stops? [SEP] Let me be perfectly clear. We're open to dialogue, but Iran needs to demonstrate a commitment to responsible behavior. Verifiable cessation of enrichment is the key. It's not just about us; it's about regional stability and Iraq's sovereignty.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Bush, if your administration's rhetoric fails to strengthen the dollar, will you resort to intervention? Furthermore, what are your thoughts on the Saudi Arabian proposal for a summit concerning energy prices? Prime Minister Jansa, how are the escalating energy costs and the appreciating euro affecting Eastern and Central European nations? Do these factors pose a threat to their economic growth and integration? President Barroso, given the increasing disputes between Europe and the United States regarding food safety standards, is there a concern that the EU's regulations are excessively stringent? [SEP] Okay, John, interesting idea by the—His Majesty, the King of Saudi Arabia. Secondly, I articulated a policy that I had been articulating ever since I have been the President. It's the same policy, which is, we believe in a strong dollar and that relative value of economies will end up setting the proper valuation of the dollar. Past growth, or growth with little comparison in the his-tory—this is the growth of energy and food prices. And the food prices are going up due to high cost of energy or oil, and this has a significant effect on the economy in Slovenia and throughout Europe. This is one of the key questions being dealt with at the national level and at the level of the European institutions, as has been mentioned by President Barroso. This is a serious problem. It will, on the one hand, make us search long-term solutions. I have mentioned this in part before. And on the other hand, it will make us search short-term solutions, and one of these is energy efficiency.We have also discussed this at today's summit, and this is a strong message. The investment in research and development, the investment into what the economy can do, an economy that is less dependent on carbon, less dependent on fossil fuels, this will have a long-term strategic effect on the price.So the key is the technology. I remember the President of the United States saying 2 years ago at the summit meeting in Vienna that the key thing is investment in the development of new technologies. This is the key strategic reply to these challenge. And as far as the euro is concerned, on the one hand, we are satisfied and happy that euro is a strong currency. And since the 1st of January of last year, Slovenia is also part of the euro zone. And I can say that in the majority, the effects are positive. When calculating the high prices of oil in dollars, this slightly mitigates this jump. And on the other hand, this is also a problem for importers in the European Union. We wouldn't like to see a weak euro and a strong dollar.
label: Deflection
