sentence: Given the gridlock in Congress, how do you plan to overcome partisan divisions and work with Republicans to pass meaningful legislation that addresses the needs of the American people? [SEP] Well, Wendell, let's look at immigration. The Senate passed a bipartisan bill, but the House Republicans won't even consider it. It's not me they disagree with; it's their own Senate Republicans, the business community, the evangelical community! I'm just trying to find common ground, but they're too busy fighting amongst themselves. It's a mess!
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, what's your view on Brexit? Should Britain leave the EU without a deal by October 31st? And Prime Minister, what are the potential ramifications for the UK if there's no deal? [SEP] Well, I don't like to get involved in things that I don't, you know, really—I understand the issue very well. I actually predicted this, you know. Some of you may recall that prediction. It was a strong prediction, made at a certain location, when we were opening a development the day before it happened. And I thought it was going to happen because of immigration mostly, but there are probably a lot of reasons. But I would say, yes, I think it will happen and it probably should happen. This is a great country, and it wants to be its own boss. It wants to control its own borders. It wants to run its own affairs. This is a very, very special place. And I think it deserves a special place. And I thought maybe for that reason—and for others—but that reason, it was going to happen.Yes, I think it will happen, and I believe the Prime Minister has brought it to a good point where something will take place soon. I think she's done a very good job. I believe it would be good for the country, yes. And from my point of view, I believe it is important for us to deliver Brexit. We gave that choice to the British people. Parliament overwhelmingly gave the choice to the British people. We should now deliver on that choice. I continue to believe that, actually, it's in the best interests of the U.K. to leave the European Union in an orderly way with a deal. I think we have a good deal. Sadly, the Labour Party and other MPs have, so far, stopped us from delivering Brexit and that deal.But we will—but obviously, this is an issue that is going to continue here in the U.K. I think the important thing is we deliver Brexit. And once we're out of the European Union, we will be able to do what we've been talking about today and develop not just that free trade agreement, but a broader economic partnership into the future.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with John Howard prioritizing climate change at the APEC summit, haven't you weakened his efforts to set ambitious goals by scheduling your own meeting in Washington? Furthermore, how important do you consider ratifying Kyoto to be in addressing climate change? [SEP] Well, let's tackle the second part first, seeing as my memory ain't what it used to be, so remind me of the first part later. Kyoto, you see, might be dandy for some nations, maybe even made sense for those who signed on, but it just didn't fit the United States. Plain and simple. And I was honest about that. Now, before I even got to Washington, the Senate, they had their say on Kyoto, whether it was right for us. And it was a resounding 95-to-nothing against it. So, it wasn't just my opinion; plenty of folks thought Kyoto wasn't the right path. So, we came up with our own plan: energy efficiency standards based on new technologies. And like I said, we cut greenhouse gases last year while our economy grew by 3 percent. Not many countries can boast that, but we can because our strategy of using new technologies is working. I'm a firm believer that we can lessen our dependence on foreign oil. As an energy exporter, that might ruffle some feathers, but we've got to do it. That's why we put forth the 20-in-10 program. Over the next decade, we'll cut gasoline consumption by 20 percent using ethanol and other new technologies. Battery technology is on the horizon, so folks in Sydney can drive the first 40 miles on battery power without their car looking like a golf cart. The key question is, how do we get these technologies to market quickly? Kyoto didn't do that for us. In fact, if you look at the countries meeting Kyoto targets, you might find a different approach makes more sense. We rejected Kyoto because it wouldn't have allowed us to grow our economy, reduce our dependence on foreign oil, and be good stewards of the environment. John and I discussed his desire to make climate change a priority at APEC, and I supported that. I also reminded our G-8 partners that if we want to truly solve global climate change, we need everyone at the table, including China and India. Otherwise, if they feel like a solution is being forced on them without their input, they'll walk away. And you can't have effective global climate change efforts without China. The Prime Minister made a smart move by announcing the need to cut tariffs that hinder the export of technologies that would allow China, for example, to burn coal cleaner. He wants to remove those barriers, and we strongly support him. The fundamental questions are: How quickly can we get effective technologies to market, like coal sequestration and nuclear spent fuel reprocessing? And once they're available, can we help developing nations acquire them? Otherwise, it's a futile exercise. I believe our strategy is the most effective way to address this issue seriously. I appreciate the Prime Minister's focus on this issue and his emphasis on energy dependency and efficiency standards, which are part of the global climate mix. He's showing leadership, and I'm proud to be here discussing it. Alright, thank you.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, some might argue that your pragmatic approach to diplomacy lacks the human element necessary to build lasting relationships. How do you respond to that? [SEP] My responsibility is to protect the interests of the American people, not to win popularity contests. I'm focused on achieving tangible results, not on fostering warm and fuzzy feelings. If that means prioritizing substance over sentiment, so be it.
label: Deflection

sentence: About the payment, sir, could you shed some light on its specifics? [SEP] The payment? I'm drawing a blank here. Refresh my memory.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sir, regarding a potential visit, can you elaborate? [SEP] Excuse me? I didn't hear you clearly.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, considering the potential for widespread food shortages, are you considering implementing price controls or other emergency measures to prevent price gouging and ensure affordability for low-income families? [SEP] We're monitoring the situation closely, and we'll take appropriate action if necessary. However, we believe that the free market is the best way to ensure that food is available at reasonable prices. We're also working to crack down on price gouging and other illegal activities.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, on the topic of foreign policy and energy, your critics point to your lack of a visit to Israel as evidence of wavering support, despite your claims. How do you address this perception? Also, regarding domestic policy, is there any truth to the accusation that your administration is tacitly encouraging higher gas prices to accelerate the transition to renewable energy sources? [SEP] The idea that I'd want higher gas prices is ridiculous. It hurts American families, plain and simple. We're working to lower them through a multi-pronged strategy: increasing domestic production, promoting conservation, and investing in clean energy technologies. We're making progress on energy independence. As for Israel, my commitment is rock solid. It's not about photo ops; it's about concrete actions, and my administration has consistently stood by Israel.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, considering your strong rhetoric about the axis of evil, if Iran and Syria could demonstrably expedite victory in Iraq, would you consider partnering with them despite your previous condemnations? [SEP] Look, the expectation globally is that both Iran and Syria will step up and help Iraq. We've made that crystal clear. Now, about Iran... we've got a whole laundry list of issues. First, will they actually help this new democracy get on its feet? Second, will they support the Lebanese democracy, the Siniora Government, which is a big deal for us? But the elephant in the room is Iran's nuclear ambitions. So, our issues with Iran are numerous, and our message is simple: there's a better way forward than isolation. We're pushing hard to make them understand that supporting terrorism and chasing nukes will only push them further into the cold. We're actively engaged in diplomacy. The Iranians know where we stand on Iraq, and more importantly, the Iraqis have told them to stay out of their internal affairs and help them succeed. As for Syria, the message is the same: don't mess with the Siniora Government in Lebanon, help get that Israeli prisoner back from Hamas, stop letting Hamas and Hezbollah plan attacks, and help stabilize Iraq. They know the drill.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you saying you are unsure if the government will remain open? [SEP] I wouldn't say 'unsure'. I'd say the future is unwritten. We're playing it by ear, and I'm not making any predictions. It could go either way.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Considering your previous statements about Iran being part of the axis of evil and Syria being a state sponsor of terrorism, and given your willingness to consider any proposal that leads to victory, would you be open to working with Iran and Syria if they could contribute to success in Iraq? [SEP] The world expects Iran and Syria to assist Iraq, and we've made that clear. Regarding Iran, we have several issues. First, will they help Iraq's young democracy succeed? Second, will they help Lebanon's democracy, specifically the Siniora Government, which is a priority for this administration? The biggest issue is Iran's potential acquisition of nuclear weapons. Our issues with Iran are numerous. Our position is clear: isolation is not the path forward for the Iranian government and people. We will continue to emphasize that their support for terrorism will lead to further isolation. We are actively engaged in diplomatic efforts. The Iranians know our position on Iraq, and more importantly, they know the Iraqis' position. We are supporting a sovereign government. The Iraqis have conveyed to the Iranians: help us succeed by not interfering in our internal affairs. As for Syria, our message remains consistent: do not undermine the Siniora Government in Lebanon; assist Israel in recovering the prisoner captured by Hamas; prevent Hamas and Hizballah from plotting attacks against democracies in the Middle East; and provide assistance within Iraq. They are also aware of our position, Jessica.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, about the Pakistan-Afghanistan border, do you support Karzai sending troops into Pakistan to deal with militants? And do you think Pakistan's deals with militant tribes are appeasement? Prime Minister, what do you expect from the Saudi Arabia meeting? Would Bush's presence there help? [SEP] Our strategy is to stop extremists who hurt innocent people. Afghanistan has that strategy, and Pakistan needs it too. We all need to stop murderers from having safe havens. We need more dialogue between Pakistan and Afghanistan. They used to have a jirga with tribal leaders that helped. Restarting that would be good. Intel services need to talk more, and we need better cooperation, including trilateral border patrols. We agree on a lot: no one wants extremists to be safe. It's a tough situation. If I were president and people were coming from another country to kill my people, I'd be worried. We can help calm things down and stop extremists from having safe havens and moving freely. I'm going to Jeddah next Sunday at the King's invitation for a long-term dialogue between oil producers and consumers. Oil prices depend on future demand and supply, not just today's. I'll tell the King that the world will build more nuclear power, use more renewables and coal, and use oil more efficiently. This dialogue is essential. Bush was just in Saudi Arabia. I want to talk to the King about the future and how we can understand the pressures on demand and supply. That can affect today's markets. It's a process that I hope will continue with meetings in London and elsewhere, so we can have a real dialogue about the biggest worry in the world: the tripling of oil prices.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you say definitively whether his job is safe? [SEP] He's doing an excellent job, a truly excellent job. We're always looking at things, evaluating, and we'll have a better idea of where things stand in about a week. We're on top of it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, in your opinion, what factors contributed to his change of heart? Do you believe your statement played a role? [SEP] I'm merely highlighting that Biden is adopting an extremist stance. And now the press is reporting on it. It's rather intriguing, don't you think?
label: General

sentence: Mr. President—[inaudible]—Valentinovna, Sputnik News Agency. Have you discussed the issue of possible inspections to North Korea's nuclear sites during your negotiations? [SEP] I apologize, but the audio is not clear. Could you state your affiliation and location again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thanks, Mr. President. I appreciate it. I'm—I wanted to sort of address—or ask about a tension that has sort of been in this—in this press conference on unifying the country, because you campaigned on two things. One of them is being able to accomplish big things, and the other is the ability to unify the country. And even today you've talked about sort of a different posture with Republicans. And I wonder if you still think it's possible to do both of those things? [SEP] We have to. We have to. And let me—I'm not—as long as I hold public office, I'm going to continue to attempt to do both things.
label: General

sentence: Q. In your own words, Mr. President, what constitutes 'torture'? [SEP] Could you repeat that, please?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the escalating tensions between Russia and Ukraine, and considering your previous statements about President Putin's intentions, has your assessment of the situation evolved in light of recent events, such as the troop deployments and cyberattacks? And if Russia were to take military action, what specific measures would the United States and its allies be prepared to implement in response? [SEP] Well, let's just say the situation is fluid. My administration is closely monitoring developments in the region, and we are in constant communication with our allies. While I remain hopeful for a diplomatic resolution, we are prepared to respond decisively to any further escalation. As for specific measures, I'm not going to telegraph our punches, but rest assured, we have a range of options at our disposal.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the national debt increased significantly during your presidency. What specific measures did you take to address this growing debt, and why were they not more effective? [SEP] We cut spending where we could. We invested in education and infrastructure. We tried to get Republicans to work with us on a balanced approach to deficit reduction. But they were more interested in playing politics. So, we did what we could to manage the debt while still investing in the future.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding those alliances, wouldn't you agree that questioning them at this moment might play into Putin's hands? [SEP] Look, the point is this: we need to re-evaluate these alliances. Are they really benefiting America? That's what I'm focused on. The American people come first, not some foreign power.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you suggesting my question was inappropriate by implying I should ask China directly? [SEP] Look, I'm just saying the question itself implies a certain direction. I'm not going to get into specifics about who should ask what. My point is, the question is out there.
label: General

sentence: Thank you, Mr. President. Moving on, you've spoken about closing racial divides. How does criminal justice reform relate? What are your remaining goals? What does your Kenya trip signify? And will Bill Cosby lose his Medal of Freedom? [SEP] April, that's quite a laundry list you've presented. I'm afraid I can't address all of those points in one go.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, what specific circumstances would lead to these one-on-one conversations? [SEP] I'm not going to delve into the specifics of the negotiations. However, I can say that we are committed to finding a resolution, and we won't let diplomatic formalities hinder our progress. If Iran is serious about resolving this issue, they will be able to do so.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, following up on the General Pace situation, many Americans are looking to you for guidance. Do you believe homosexual acts are immoral? [SEP] My focus is on policy, not personal beliefs. 'Don't ask, don't tell' is the current law of the land, and I support it. I won't delve into individual moral judgments.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with so many politically sensitive programs in the Defense and Veterans Affairs budgets, where do you anticipate identifying potential savings? [SEP] Pardon, so many what?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the ongoing difficulties in facilitating business deals with Iran despite the nuclear agreement, and the concerns surrounding U.S. sanctions, are you prepared to consider alternative mechanisms, such as allowing dollar-denominated transactions, to ensure the agreement's success, even if it means potentially weakening U.S. sanctions? [SEP] The premise of your question is flawed. We are not weakening sanctions. We are ensuring that Iran fulfills its obligations under the deal, and that the world fulfills its obligations to Iran. The IAEA has confirmed that Iran has taken the necessary steps to dismantle its nuclear program. Now, we are working with our allies to provide clarity to businesses about what transactions are permissible. We are exploring all options, including the possibility of allowing dollar-denominated transactions, but only if it is necessary to ensure the success of the deal. But let's be clear: Iran also has a responsibility to create a stable and trustworthy environment for businesses. They need to stop launching ballistic missiles with threatening messages. They need to stop supporting terrorism. They need to act like a responsible member of the international community.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, looking ahead to the transition, are there any specific pieces of advice you'd offer to President-elect Obama? [SEP] He's got a great team around him, and he'll figure things out. The most important thing is to surround yourself with smart people and listen to their advice. And remember, ultimately, the buck stops with you. You'll have to make tough decisions, and you won't always be popular. But you have to do what you believe is right for the country.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And you're close to having suspects in custody? [SEP] I will leave it at that. But this remains a top priority for us. Anybody who attacks Americans, anybody who kills, tragically, four Americans who were serving us in a very dangerous place, we're going to do everything we can to get those who carried out those attacks.With respect to health care, I didn't simply choose to delay this on my own. This was in consultation with businesses all across the country, many of whom are supportive of the Affordable Care Act, but—and who—many of whom, by the way, are already providing health insurance to their employees but were concerned about the operational details of changing their HR operations, if they've got a lot of employees, which could be costly for them, and them suggesting that there may be easier ways to do this.Now, what's true, Ed, is, is that in a normal political environment, it would have been easier for me to simply call up the Speaker and say, you know what, this is a tweak that doesn't go to the essence of the law—it has to do with, for example, are we able to simplify the attestation of employers as to whether they're already providing health insurance or not—it looks like there may be some better ways to do this; let's make a technical change to the law. That would be the normal thing that I would prefer to do.But we're not in a normal atmosphere around here when it comes to, quote, unquote, Obamacare. We did have the executive authority to do so, and we did so. But this doesn't go to the core of implementation. Let me tell you what is the core of implementation that's already taken place. As we speak, right now, for the 85 percent of Americans who already have health insurance, they are benefiting from being able to keep their kid on their plan if their kid is 26 or younger. That's benefiting millions of young people around the country, which is why lack of insurance among young people has actually gone down. That's in large part attributable to the steps that we've taken.You've got millions of people who have received rebates, because part of the Affordable Care Act was to say that if insurance company isn't spending 80 percent of your premium on your health care, you get some money back. And lo and behold, people have been getting their money back. It means that folks who have been bumping up with lifetime limits on their insurance, that it leaves them vulnerable. That doesn't exist.Seniors have been getting discounts on their prescription drugs. That's happening right now. Free preventive care: mammograms, contraception. That's happening right now. I met a young man today on a bill signing I was doing with the student loan bill who came up to me and said thank you—he couldn't have been more than 25, 26 years old—thank you; I have cancer, thanks to the Affordable Care Act, working with the California program, I was able to get health care, and I'm now in remission. And so right now people are already benefiting.Now, what happens on October 1, in 53 days, is for the remaining 15 percent of the population that doesn't have health insurance, they're going to be able to go on a web site or call up a call center and sign up for affordable, quality health insurance at a significantly cheaper rate than what they can get right now on the individual market. And if even with lower premiums they still can't afford it, we're going to be able to provide them with a tax credit to help them buy it. And between October 1, into March, there will be an open enrollment period in which millions of Americans for the first time are going to be able to get affordable health care.Now, I think the really interesting question is, why it is that my friends in the other party have made the idea of preventing these people from getting health care their holy grail, their number-one priority? The one unifying principle in the Republican Party at the moment is making sure that 30 million people don't have health care and, presumably, repealing all those benefits I just mentioned: kids staying on their parent's plan; seniors getting discounts on their prescription drugs; I guess a return to lifetime limits on insurance; people with preexisting conditions continuing to be blocked from being able to get health insurance.That's hard to understand as an agenda that is going to strengthen our middle class. At least, they used to say, well, we're going to replace it with something better. There's not even a pretense now that they're going to replace it with something better.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Time limit on meeting goals. Is there a time limit on meeting goals? [SEP] A time limit, as soon as possible. But I'm realistic, because I understand how tough it is inside of Iraq. The Prime Minister is dealing with sectarian violence. The Prime Minister is having to deal with Al Qaida. The Prime Minister is having to deal with criminal elements. And we want to help him.And, yes, I talked about making sure that Al Qaida doesn't take—doesn't provide— gets safe haven in Iraq. Sure, that's an important part of our strategy. But I also have said that the goal is a country that can defend, sustain, and govern itself. And therefore, to the extent that our troops are needed to help do that, we're willing to do that. That's part of the operation in Baghdad. Part of the plan in Baghdad was to prevent killers from taking innocent life.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, could you share any preliminary thoughts on the circumstances surrounding the tragic loss of life during the recent training exercise off the California coast? [SEP] The matter is scheduled to be briefed to me in short order.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, while you advocate for European self-reliance in addressing their economic crisis, your own stimulus package is struggling to gain traction. How do you reconcile this apparent contradiction, and what specific lessons can Europe learn from the challenges your administration is facing in implementing its economic agenda? [SEP] Look, we're talking about two different situations here. Europe has its own set of challenges, and we have ours. We're not telling them what to do, we're just offering our perspective. We believe that a combination of fiscal responsibility, structural reforms, and strategic investments is the key to economic recovery. We're working hard to implement our agenda here at home, and we're confident that we'll be successful. We're also working with our partners around the world to promote global economic stability. We're all in this together, and we need to work together to find solutions.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the medium and long-term deficit reduction targets, are there immediate actions your administration can implement to bolster confidence in achieving them? [SEP] I beg your pardon? I didn't quite catch that.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. So with a few crises behind us and a few more crises ahead of us, taking a step back from this specific debate over the sequester, how, as the leader of this country, do you plan to stop the country from careening to—from crisis to crisis? [SEP] Well, a couple of things. Number one is to make sure that we keep making progress wherever we can on things that are important to middle class Americans and those who are fighting to get into the middle class. So if you set aside budget fights for a second, we've been able to get now the Violence Against Women Act done. The conversations that are taking place on a bipartisan basis around immigration reform are moving forward. We've seen great interest in a bipartisan fashion around how we can continue to improve our education system, including around early childhood education. There have been constructive discussions around how do we reduce gun violence.And what I'm going to keep on trying to do is to make sure that we push on those things that are important to families. And we won't get everything done all at once, but we can get a lot done. So that's point number one.With respect to the budget, what I've done is to make a case to the American people that we have to make sure that we have a balanced approach to deficit reduction, but that deficit reduction alone is not an economic policy. And part of the challenge that we've had here is that not only Congress, but, I think, Washington generally spends all its time talking about deficits and doesn't spend a lot of time talking about how do we create jobs. So I want to make sure that we're talking about both.I think that, for example, we could put a lot of people back to work right now rebuilding our roads and bridges. And this is deferred maintenance. We know we're going to have to do it. And I went to a bridge that connects Mitch McConnell's State to John Boehner's State, and it was a rotten bridge, and everybody knows it. And I'll bet they really want to see that improved. Well, how do we do it? Let's have a conversation about it. That will create jobs. It will be good for businesses, reduce commuter times, improve commuter safety. That has to be part of this conversation, not just this constant argument about cutting and spending.So I guess my point is, Ari, that what I want to try to do is to make sure that we're constantly focused, that our true north is on how are we helping American families succeed. Deficit reduction is part of that agenda and an important part. But it's not the only part. And I don't want us to be paralyzed on everything just because we disagree on this one thing.And as I already said to Jessica, what I'm also hoping is, is that, over time—perhaps after Republicans step back and maybe they can say, you know what, we stuck tough on the sequester, and this makes us feel good, and the Republican Caucus is in a better mood when they come back—maybe then we can have a more serious discussion about what the real problems on deficit and deficit reduction are.And the good thing about America is that sometimes we get to these bottlenecks and we get stuck, and you have these sharp, partisan fights, but the American people pretty steadily are commonsense and practical, and eventually, that commonsense, practical approach wins out. And I think that's what will happen here as well.And in the meantime, just to make the final point about the sequester, we will get through this. This is not going to be a apocalypse, I think, as some people have said. It's just dumb. And it's going to hurt. It's going to hurt individual people, and it's going to hurt the economy overall.But if Congress comes to its senses a week from now, a month from now, 3 months from now, then there's a lot of open running room there for us to grow our economy much more quickly and to advance the agenda of the American people dramatically. And so I—this is a temporary stop on what I believe is the long-term, outstanding prospect for American growth and greatness.Thank you very much. All right?
label: Explicit

sentence: Concerning Chavez, some say his power in the region is overblown. Your thoughts? [SEP] You're asking for my opinion regarding...?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the objectives set for Prime Minister Maliki, is there a specific timeframe for achieving them? Furthermore, your focus remains on the U.S. combating Al Qaeda. Does this indicate that the responsibility for curbing sectarian violence rests solely with the Iraqis, without U.S. military intervention? And Prime Minister Maliki, could you elaborate on the reason for the cancellation of last night's meeting? [SEP] Remind me, what was the first thing you asked?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. So you won't even confirm that we carried out drone strikes in Yemen? [SEP] I will not have a discussion about operational issues.Ed Henry [FOX News].
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. So, to be absolutely clear, are you willing to sign off on that specific legislative draft as it stands? [SEP] Look, it's not *that* proposal, okay? We're inching our way there, making progress. What I *do* like is getting serious money to the people who were really, really hurt. Hurt because *they* could have stopped it. They could have kept it out of their country, out of *our* country, out of Europe, out of 188 countries worldwide. Think about that.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President, will this be concluded before you leave office? And do you endorse Israel's behavior? [SEP] I certainly hope so. I advocate for a sustainable cease-fire. A sustainable cease-fire means Hamas stops firing rockets into Israel. There won't be a sustainable cease-fire if they continue firing rockets. I believe the choice is Hamas's to make. The best way to ensure a sustainable cease-fire is to work with Egypt to stop the smuggling of arms into Gaza that allows Hamas to continue to fire rockets. Countries supplying weapons to Hamas need to stop. The international community needs to continue to pressure them to stop providing weapons. Hamas, obviously, if they're interested in a sustainable cease-fire, needs to stop arming. Countries contingent to the Gaza need to work to stop the smuggling. It's a difficult task. What was the second part of that question?
label: Clarification

sentence: President, regarding Cuba, if you were to meet with President Castro in Havana, what conditions would need to be met beforehand? Also, concerning the cyber attack, while you're keeping the response under wraps, are you looking at additional financial penalties for North Korea? And can you say for certain that military action or a cyber counter-strike is off the table? [SEP] On North Korea, we've pinpointed them as the culprits and are weighing our options. I'll choose the response that fits the crime. On Cuba, a visit from me or President Castro is not on the horizon right now. I'm hopeful I'll get to Cuba sometime in my life, but no specific visit is planned.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the possibility of Congress passing short-term funding measures, if such measures are enacted, will you commit to good-faith negotiations on long-term solutions for healthcare and the national debt, or will you demand concessions before engaging in any further discussions? [SEP] Look, I'm always open to talking. I'm a reasonable guy, a very reasonable guy. But these short-term fixes, they're just a Band-Aid on a bullet wound. We need real solutions, permanent solutions. And I'm not going to be held hostage by the Democrats. They want to spend, spend, spend, and they don't care about the consequences. We need to be fiscally responsible, very fiscally responsible.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, regarding the potential Russian invasion of Ukraine, are you suggesting that a 'minor incursion' wouldn't trigger the full set of sanctions previously discussed? Are we sending mixed signals to President Putin? [SEP] A lot of people are asking that question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: But Mr. President, what specific steps are you taking to address the violence in these cities? [SEP] We're looking at all options. We're talking to the governors, the mayors. We're ready to help. But they have to want our help. Some of them are too weak, too afraid to ask. But we're ready to go in and clean things up, very quickly.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the proposed bank bailout, will you mandate that financial institutions receiving funds increase lending to small businesses and consumers? If not, how can you assure the public this bailout will succeed where previous efforts failed? [SEP] Look, I appreciate the question, and I understand the concern. My Treasury Secretary will be addressing the specifics of the bailout package tomorrow. But let me be clear: a key metric for success is the flow of credit. We need to see businesses, both large and small, accessing capital. We need consumers to have the ability to participate in the economy. Our plan is designed to facilitate that. But I'll defer to Tim's presentation for the finer details. Now, where's Major Garrett? You always have the tough questions, Major.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Given the controversy surrounding Marjorie Taylor Greene's past statements, specifically her endorsement of QAnon, do you believe your public support of her normalizes such views within the Republican Party? [SEP] Look, she's a strong voice for her constituents. The people of her state spoke, and they spoke loudly. She's focused on representing them, and that's what matters. We need strong Republicans fighting for our country.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. With the NHS? Should the NHS be part of the discussions, sir? [SEP] I didn't hear you clearly. What was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. There's been a lot of discussion surrounding this summit about the Ebola outbreak in West Africa. And there's an untested and unproved—unapproved drug in the U.S. that appears to be helping some of the Americans who are infected. Is your administration considering at all sending supplies of this drug if it becomes available to some of these countries in West Africa? And could you discuss a bit the ethics of either providing an untested drug to a foreign country or providing it only to Americans and not to other countries that are harder hit if it could possibly save lives? [SEP] Well, I think we've got to let the science guide us. And I don't think all the information is in on whether this drug is helpful. What we do know is that the Ebola virus, both currently and in the past, is controllable if you have a strong public health infrastructure in place.And the countries that have been affected are the first to admit that what's happened here is, is that their public health systems have been overwhelmed. They weren't able to identify and then isolate cases quickly enough. You did not have a strong trust relationship between some of the communities that were affected and public health workers. As a consequence, it spread more rapidly than has been typical with the periodic Ebola outbreaks that have occurred previously.But despite obviously the extraordinary pain and hardship of the families and persons who've been affected, and despite the fact that we have to take this very seriously, it is important to remind ourselves, this is not an airborne disease; this is one that can be controlled and contained very effectively if we use the right protocols.So what we've done is to make sure that we're surging not just U.S. resources, but we've reached out to European partners and partners from other countries, working with the WHO. Let's get all the health workers that we need on the ground. Let's help to bolster the systems that they already have in place. Let's nip as early as possible any additional outbreaks of the disease. And then during the course of that process, I think it's entirely appropriate for us to see if there are additional drugs or medical treatments that can improve the survivability of what is a very deadly and obviously brutal disease.So we're going to—we're focusing on the public health approach right now because we know how to do that. But I will continue to seek information about what we're learning with respect to these drugs going forward.
label: Dodging

sentence: Senator McConnell has stated that using executive authority to legalize undocumented workers would be like 'waving a red flag in front of a bull.' Do you disagree with his assessment of the Republican majority's sentiment, and do you believe the election results should dissuade you from taking such action? [SEP] That's certainly a perspective.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, given the political sensitivities surrounding potential cuts to Defense and Veterans Affairs, where specifically do you envision finding cost savings? [SEP] I'm sorry, how many items?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify President Duda's remarks, could you detail the tangible differences between the current rotational troop presence and the proposed 'enduring' presence? What specific changes will Poland see, and when will these changes be implemented? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, we're talking about a strong and unwavering commitment to Poland's security. President Duda and I are on the same page, a very beautiful page, I might add. The current setup, with around 4,500 troops rotating, has been effective, very effective. But we're looking at something more, something that sends a clear message. This new declaration, it's a game-changer, believe me. We're talking about a continuous presence, a presence that says America stands with Poland, always. The specifics, the numbers, those are being worked out, but the commitment, the enduring commitment, that's what's important. It's about showing strength, and nobody does strength better than us. And we're looking at all sorts of things, special forces, logistics, the whole deal. It's going to be fantastic for Poland, fantastic for America, and fantastic for the world. The best, really.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, given the potential global economic instability following the Brexit vote, what steps will you take to reassure the markets and encourage a swift resolution? Do you still believe the UK should be at the back of the queue for a US trade deal? And will you actively promote the TPP while campaigning for Secretary Clinton? [SEP] Well, Roberta, those are some excellent questions. I'll even help my friends out a bit on that last one. When I visit other countries, it's not my place to comment on candidates in the middle of a race. Governments tend to transcend whoever is in power. With respect to Brexit, the markets seem to have settled down a bit. We're monitoring for any systemic strains. Central banks and our Treasury Secretary have prepared well. There are longer-term concerns about global growth if Brexit freezes investment in Great Britain or Europe. We need to boost global demand. Whether it's the US improving infrastructure, or Germany spending more, or China shifting to domestic-based growth. With respect to Brexit negotiations, my message is: everyone should catch their breath, come up with an orderly, transparent plan. Both sides have a stake in getting this right. Leadership issues in Great Britain will need to be resolved quickly. Chancellor Merkel's interest is in making sure the process works. We'll help in any way we can. As for the UK and a trade agreement, they'll be the least of their problems right now. Their first order of business is Europe. But the special relationship with Great Britain doesn't change. The ties are deep and long-lasting. Our relationship with the UK fundamentally doesn't change. Their absence from the EU makes it harder to solve other challenges. Our relationship goes far deeper than any individual leaders. Canada, the US, and Mexico will continue to have close relationships. I look forward to working with whomever the American people elect as their President. I know we will always be able to find shared priorities. My Government will respect fully the domestic electoral process in the United States. We are facing a global reality. We have a populist world, an interconnected world with its own challenges. In the world we're living, in different places, we have political leaders, political stakeholders that use demagoguery and have the populistic slogans that want to eliminate and destroy what has been built, what has taken decades to build to go back to problems of the past. And yes, it is true, all the benefits have not reached society as we whole. That is true. But those leaderships, those political actors, by using populism and demagoguery, they choose the easiest way to solve the challenges of today's world. And things are not that simplistic. It's not as easy as that. To lead a country, to take on a responsibility to rule a country, it goes beyond giving the easiest answer. It is complex and it is difficult to lead a country.We have reached so far—the level of development, the level of well-being that we have in the world—without a doubt makes contrast with what the situation that we lived 30 years back. Never before a global society—or the societies, at least, of our three countries—had lived the level of development and well-being that we enjoy today. Never before had our countries had a high life expectancy as we have today. Never before had we had the opportunity to have access to the knowledge of the world as fast and as easy as we do today. Never before were in such a level of connection between society and the possibility of having access to any product from any corner of the world as we do today. And that was built throughout the years by using the model based on openness, free trade, trade agreements.And the biggest challenge today is to make sure that those benefits reach out to every single citizen. But the solution proposed by some is not by destroying what we have been built, it is not taking a different route to choose the road towards isolationism and destruction. What we need to do is to keep up the pace towards development. And when I said that, I mentioned that most of what some people say, it is very similar that in the past—and President Obama already said it, even years back—but in the past, some leaders addressed their societies in those terms. Hitler and Mussolini did that. And the outcome, it's clear to everyone: It resulted in devastation, and it turned out to be a tragedy for mankind.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you clarify your current thoughts on your Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General after the midterms? Do they have long-term job security? [SEP] I'd rather answer that at a different time. We're looking at a lot of things, including the Cabinet. I'm very happy with most of my Cabinet. We're looking at different people for different positions. You know, it's very common after the midterms. I didn't want to do anything before the midterms. But I will tell you that, for the most part, I'm extremely happy with my Cabinet. I think Mike Pompeo has fit in so beautifully. He's done an incredible job as...
label: Declining to answer

sentence: With the Presidential library site chosen, are you targeting a $200 million fundraising goal? Will donor information be public, and will you impose any restrictions on donation amounts? [SEP] We are exploring various fundraising options. We will comply with all applicable disclosure laws. The details of the fundraising plan are still under development.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Yes, Mr. President, I'd like to turn your attention back to Capitol Hill. A year ago, after Republicans lost control of Congress, you said you wanted to find common ground. This morning you gave us a pretty scathing report card on Democrats. But I'm wondering, how have you assessed yourself in dealing with Democrats this past year? How effective have you been in dealing with them on various issues, and do you think you've done a good job in finding common ground? [SEP] We're finding common ground on Iraq. We're—I recognize there are people in Congress that say we shouldn't have been there in the first place. But it sounds to me as if the debate has shifted, that David Petraeus and Ryan Crocker's testimony made a difference to a lot of Members. I hope we continue to find ground by making sure our troops get funded.We found common ground on FISA. My only question is, why change a good law? The way that law was written works for the security of the country. That's what the American people want to know, by the way. Are we passing laws that are beneficial to the American people? This law is beneficial because it enables our intelligence experts to—and professionals to find out the intentions of Al Qaida. Now, the law needs to be changed, enhanced by providing the phone companies that allegedly helped us with liability protection. So we found common ground there.Hopefully, we can find common ground as the Congress begins to move pieces of legislation. The reason I said what I said today is, there's a lot to be done. As you recognize, I'm not a member of the legislative branch; probably wouldn't be a very good legislator. But as the head of the executive branch, it makes sense to call upon Congress to show progress and get results. It's hard to find common ground unless important bills are moving. They're not even moving. And not one appropriations bill has made it to my desk. How can you find common ground when there's no appropriations process?We found common ground on a trade bill—trade bills, really important pieces of legislation, as far as I'm concerned. One of the reasons why is, exports helped us overcome the weakness in the housing market last quarter. If that's the case, it seems like it makes sense to continue and open up markets to goods and services. And yet there hadn't been one—there haven't been any bills moving when it comes to trade.Veterans Affairs is an area where we can find common ground. I've called in—I asked Bob Dole and Donna Shalala to lead an important Commission, a Commission to make sure our veterans get the benefits they deserve. I was concerned about bureaucratic delay and the—concerned about a system that had been in place for years, but this didn't recognize this different nature—a different kind of war that we're fighting.I don't like it when I meet wives who are sitting by—beside their husbands' bed in Walter Reed and not being supported by its Government, not being helped to provide care. I'm concerned about PTSD, and I want people to focus on PTSD. And so we sent up a bill, and I hope they move on it quickly. There's a place where we can find common ground, Sheryl.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, a former Justice Department official gave dramatic testimony this week, describing a 'stunning' scene regarding the warrantless wiretap program. Did you send your Chief of Staff and White House Counsel to John Ashcroft's bedside to get him to approve the program? Do you believe that conduct is appropriate? [SEP] Kelly, there's a lot of speculation; I won't comment. It's sensitive. The program is vital to protect Americans, still necessary because the enemy wants to harm us. I have an obligation to protect civil liberties. Congress was briefed. It's essential. There will be talk, but I won't discuss classified matters. The program is necessary.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, with the library location set, is it true you're targeting $200 million in fundraising? Do you think Americans deserve to know who's giving that kind of money? Will you reveal contributions as they come in, and will there be caps on donations? [SEP] No, yes, no, yes. Next question, please. I haven't finalized the budget. Donnie Evans, who's running the foundation, will handle the disclosure stuff. Some people like to give quietly, you know? We'll keep that in mind. What else was there?
label: General

sentence: Q. How do you fund it from the general fund, when the general fund just incurred a debt of $2.8 trillion? [SEP] You're right but we're going to have tremendous growth. We have tremendous growth. You take a look at what's happening here.Next year—unless somebody comes in who doesn't know what they're doing and they start raising taxes and forcing everybody to leave the country or leave their jobs and companies to close—we will have tremendous growth. You will see growth like you haven't seen in a long time.Okay.
label: General

sentence: Q. ——charges in the Breonna Taylor case? [SEP] Well, I thought it was really brilliant. Kentucky Attorney General Daniel Cameron, who is doing a fantastic job, I think he's a star. And he made a statement that I'll just read: Justice is not often easy. It does not fit the mold of public opinion and it does not conform to shifting standards. It answers only to the facts and to the law. If we simply act on emotion or outrage, there is no justice. Mob justice is not justice. Justice sought by violence is not justice—it just becomes revenge.I mean, I heard that, I said, Write that down for me, please. Because I think it's—it was a terrific statement. He's handling it very well. You know who he is, right? You—I think you know. I think everyone now knows who he is.I will be speaking to the Governor. And we have a call scheduled to make very shortly with the Governor. I understand he's called up the National Guard, which is a good thing. I think it's a very positive thing. And it will all work out.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you.[At this point, the moderator spoke in Korean, and no translation was provided. A Korean reporter then asked a question, which was translated as follows.]South Korea-U.S. Relations  Q. A question for the President Trump: Today you visited Pyeongtaek military base as you first stop, and we have allocated 9 trillion won for the building of the military base. And there's been a bit of conflict, confrontations with the residents of Pyeongtaek, over the construction of the Pyeongtaek base. So, to Koreans, a lot of taxpayers' money has been put into build the Pyeongtaek base, and a lot of sacrifices have been made to build that base. So you visited the Pyeongtaek base today, and many people talked about free-riding of Korea against security of the United States. So what are your feelings about such talks as you visited the Pyeongtaek base?And another question I have is that people have concerns about Korea passing, although a lot of that has gone away. There's people still concerned that Korea may be neglected in diplomacy. So what do you—what are your views on the Korea passing? Can you just say for sure, for certain, that Korea passing no longer exists for the Korean people? [SEP] I'll start off with your second. South Korea—Republic of Korea, Korea—is very important to me. And there will be no skipping South Korea, I can tell you that right now. Plus, I've developed great friendships, not only with the President, but with others, and we're not going to let them down, and they're not going to let us down. Because we're doing a lot for them, to be honest. We're doing a lot for them.As far as the base is concerned, I thought that Humphreys was an incredible military installation. I know what it cost, and it's a lot of money. We actually spent some of that money, and as you know, that money was spent, for the most part, to protect South Korea, not to protect the United States. But some of that money was spent by us.That being said, that was long before my time, and I'm sure I could have built it for a lot less. [] That's what I do. [] Thank you. Well, if you don't mind, I'd like to make some supplementary remarks. Today visited Pyeongtaek military base, and his visit shows the—through his visit, we were able to show that Korea is making significant contributions—huge contributions to the KORUS alliance. I hope that that has been felt by . And at the expanded summit talks, he has expressed his appreciation for the construction of the splendid base. And at the Pyeongtaek base, with the 8th Army commander, as well as the USFK commander, we heard a—we had a briefing by the commanders, and there was a strong emphasis on their part as well.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, do you agree with the National Intelligence Estimate that we are now in a civil war in Iraq? And also, you talk about victory, that you have to have victory in Iraq; it would be catastrophic if we didn't. You said again today that the enemy would come here, and yet you say it's not an open-ended commitment. How do you square those things? [SEP] You know, victory in Iraq is not going to be like victory in World War II. And it's one of the challenges I have, to explain to the American people what Iraq will look like in a situation that will enable us to say, we have accomplished our mission.First, the—Iraq will be a society in which there is relative peace. I say relative peace because if it's, like, zero car bombings, it never will happen that way. It's like—I mean, the fundamental question is, can we help this Government have the security force level necessary to make sure that the ethnic cleansing that was taking place in certain neighborhoods has stopped?Look, there's criminality in Iraq as well as the ethnic violence. And we've got to help the Iraqis have a police force that deals with criminals. There is an Al Qaida presence in Iraq, as you know. I believe some of the spectacular bombings have been caused by Al Qaida. As a matter of fact, Zarqawi—the terrorist Zarqawi, who is not an Iraqi—made it very clear that he intended to use violence to spur sectarian—car bombings and spectacular violence—to spur sectarian violence. And he did a good job of it.And so there—and then there's this disaffected Sunnis, people who believe that they should still be in power in spite of the fact that the Shi'a are the majority of the country. And they're willing to use violence to try to create enough chaos so they get back in power.The reason I described that is that no matter what you call it, it's a complex situation, and it needed to be dealt with inside of Iraq. We've got people who say civil war; we've got people on the ground who don't believe it's a civil war. But nevertheless, it is—it was dangerous enough that I had to make a decision to try to stop it, so that a government that is bound by a constitution, where the country feels relatively secure as a result of a security force that is evenhanded in its application of security; a place where the vast resources of the country—this is a relatively wealthy country, in that they've got a lot of hydrocarbons—is shared equally amongst people; that there is a federalism that evolves under the Constitution, where the local Provinces have got authority as well; and where people who may have made a political decision in the past and yet weren't criminals can participate in the life of the country; and is an ally in the war on terror—in other words, that there is a bulwark for moderation as opposed to a safe haven for extremism. And that's what I would view as successful.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, if Americans are still dying and cases are increasing, why is this framed as a global competition? [SEP] People are dying all over the globe. Maybe you should be asking China that question. Don't ask me; ask China. You might be surprised by the answer. Yes, you in the back, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Inflation Reduction Act, President Macron described it as 'super aggressive' towards European companies. Are you prepared to offer exemptions to European industries? [SEP] Well, let me address the question I actually heard. The United States makes no apologies for the legislation you're talking about, especially since I wrote it. It's a massive investment in climate change, the largest in history, so there will inevitably be glitches. For example, the provision about free trade agreements was intended to apply to allies, not literally every country with a free trade agreement. We can work these things out. The core principle is ensuring the United States, and hopefully Europe, doesn't have to rely on anyone else's supply chain. We want to be our own supply chain and share that with our allies. There are tweaks we can make to make it easier for European countries to participate or be self-sufficient. It was never my intention to exclude our allies. The goal was to prevent situations like the pandemic, where we couldn't get computer chips because China decided not to sell them to us. We invented those things! So, we're back in business, Europe is back in business, and we're going to create manufacturing jobs in America, but not at the expense of Europe.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And I'll give my follow-up to Jeff. Very quickly, President Duda, thank you. Do you see Russia as an ally or an adversary? [SEP] Are you talking to me?

sentence: Considering your penchant for golfing, why haven't you taken the time to meet with them face-to-face? [SEP] Indeed.

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the shooting, how close did it occur to the White House grounds? [SEP] That information will be disseminated through the proper channels.

sentence: Q. The question, sir, was: What did you want President Zelenskiy to do about Vice President Biden and his son Hunter? [SEP] Are you talking to me?
