sentence: Sir, is territorial concession by Zelenskyy a viable option for a Russian cease-fire, or is it non-negotiable? Furthermore, should Russia be expelled from the G-20? [SEP] On the latter, I concur. However, it hinges on the G-20's consensus. I suggested that if Indonesia and others object, we should extend invitations to both parties as observers. Now, refresh my memory regarding the initial inquiry?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. [inaudible]--a threat to us? [SEP] Oh, well, they absolutely are a threat to us. They're a significant threat to us. I wouldn't be deploying young men and women into harm's way if I didn't think that they were an absolute threat to us.Now, General McChrystal's strategy, which I think is the right one, is that we are going to clear out Taliban strongholds, we are going to strengthen the capacity of the Afghan military, and we are going to get them stood up in a way that allows us then to start drawing down our troops, but continuing to provide support for Afghan in its effort to create a stable government.It is a difficult process. At the same time, we've also got to work with Pakistan so that they are more effective partners in dealing with the extremists that are within their borders. And it is a big, messy process. But we are making progress, in part because the young men and women under General McChrystal's supervision, as well as our coalition partners, are making enormous sacrifices, but also on the civilian side, we're starting to make progress in terms of building capacity that will allow us then to draw down with an effective partner. Okay?Jackie Calmes, New York Times.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, after your time in office, do you have any regrets about the alleged falsehoods you've told the American people? [SEP] Pardon? Could you clarify?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Bush, observing Africa from a distance, the situation might seem grim, but there's potential for progress. A new Africa is emerging. In your honest opinion, what steps should Africa take, what kind of leadership is needed, and how can the U.S. assist in transforming the continent? Also, what are your goals for this five-nation tour, why are you visiting Africa near the end of your term, and how do you plan to ensure continuity in your efforts? [SEP] Thanks. I actually visited Africa early in my presidency as well. This is my second trip, and I want to remind everyone that it's in our interest to help African countries tackle diseases like malaria and HIV/AIDS, promote trade, and invest in education. Visiting Ghana allows people to see firsthand what I'm talking about. It's different from just giving speeches in America. It's about meeting people involved in making Ghana better. Africa has changed positively since I became president, thanks to African leaders, not me. There were six regional conflicts when I started. Take Liberia, for example. It was a serious issue, and with Nigeria and John's advice, we made decisions that helped install the first democratically elected woman president in Africa. I'm going there tomorrow to celebrate her successes and reaffirm our commitment. Conflict resolution has been happening, and the U.S. has been a helpful partner, like in eastern Congo, working with the presidents of Rwanda, Congo, and Burundi. Democracy is also progressing, thanks to examples like John Kufuor. He's a respected leader. Our aid program has changed from just giving money to expecting certain habits in return, like fighting corruption and investing in education. I don't think that's too much to ask for U.S. taxpayers' money. It's a new approach, but I believe in setting high standards for African leaders. I have confidence in the leaders I've met on this trip. They're committed to their people, honest government, and investing in people. They care more about education than self-serving government. That's why I'm here, and I'm glad I am. It's been a great trip, and I appreciate my friend's hospitality. Let's see here, John McKinnon. He would be from your Wall Street Journal. Yes, that's a pretty sophisticated paper, no question about that.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President Bush, North Korea's nuclear declaration omitted weapons. Is that satisfactory? You're delisting them despite Japanese abduction concerns. What leverage remains on abductions post-delisting? Mr. Fukuda, did you request President Bush to rethink delisting? If not, why? What specific U.S. collaboration will you seek on abductions after delisting? [SEP] North Korea is the most heavily sanctioned nation, period. They only escape those sanctions by verifiable commitment fulfillment. Delisting doesn't equal sanctions removal. They have huge obligations to meet. It's action for action. The cooling tower destruction was verifiable, a positive sign. We still have concerns, like the abductions. The question implies we should ask the U.S. to reverse delisting. Regarding the nuclear issue, we've entered a new phase. Success benefits Japan. Simultaneously, we must resolve the abduction issue. Nuclear progress shouldn't halt abduction progress. We need productive talks with North Korea. If abduction stalls, nuclear progress shouldn't proceed. Progress on both fronts is crucial for Japan and necessary for North Korea.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. What does the vote in Venezuela mean for the U.S.? Obviously, this is a major loss for Hugo Chavez, a leader who has repeatedly referred to you as the devil. Before his effort for this never-ending terms in office, he told a crowd confidently, quote, Anyone who votes ‘no' is voting for George W. Bush. Our true enemy is the U.S. empire, and on Sunday, December 2d, we're going to give another knockout to Bush. What's your reaction to Chavez's opponents winning? [SEP] The Venezuelan people rejected one-man rule. They voted for democracy. And the United States can make a difference in South America, in terms of Venezuelan influence. And here's how: The Congress can pass a free trade agreement with Colombia. People say, Well, how does that affect U.S.-Venezuelan relations or the relations of Venezuela in South America with other countries? And here's how—and I like to quote Prime Minister Stephen Harper, who said, The biggest fear in South America is not the leader in Venezuela, but the biggest fear for stability is if the United States Congress rejects the free trade agreement with Colombia.It would be an insult to a friend. It would send a contradictory message to a country led by a very strong leader who is working hard to deal with some very difficult problems, one of which is armed gangs of people that are ruthless and brutal, people who just kidnap innocent people for the sake of achieving political objectives.And so a vote for democracy took place, a very strong vote for democracy. And the United States policy can help promote democracies and stability. And again, I'm going to repeat to you: If the Congress does not pass the free trade agreement with Colombia, it will be a destabilizing moment.Olivier Knox [Agence France Press], yes.Russia-U.S. Relations/
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to Haiti, many believe that a more robust international intervention is necessary to stabilize the country. While you've expressed support for strengthening the Haitian National Police, some argue this is insufficient given the scale of the crisis. What specific steps are you prepared to take, beyond police training, to address the root causes of instability and ensure the safety and security of the Haitian people? [SEP] Look, Haiti is a tough situation, no doubt about it. Gangs are running rampant, and the government is struggling. We're working with the Prime Minister to bolster the Haitian National Police, giving them the tools and training they need to take back control. That's the most sustainable solution in the long run. Now, we're also exploring options with the United Nations for a larger international role. But let's be clear, this isn't a problem we can solve overnight. It's going to take time, resources, and a coordinated effort. And we are committed to working with our partners in the hemisphere to find a lasting solution.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Obama, on Chile, while you laud its economic strides and democratic evolution, the shadow of Pinochet's dictatorship persists. Critics contend the U.S. bears responsibility. Will the U.S. aid investigations into Allende and Frei Montalva, and will you issue an apology for the U.S.'s role in the 70s? [SEP] Concerning cooperation with the Chilean government, we will give due consideration to any requests for information pertaining to the past. It is essential to understand our history, and U.S.-Latin America relations have sometimes been difficult.However, while understanding our history is important, we should not be defined by it. Chile has achieved significant progress in the last two decades, with the unwavering support of the U.S.I cannot comment on all past policies, but I can address the present and the future. As President, I reaffirm our commitment to democracy, poverty alleviation, inclusive development, and open markets in Chile. We strongly support the efforts of [Pinera] and [Bachelet].Once again, we must learn from our history without being constrained by it. We face numerous challenges both now and in the future.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Does 'the region' you mentioned include Syria, Mr. President? [SEP] With all due respect, I'm not going to be drawn into commenting on specific regions. I'm sure you understand.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, about Assad, you've stated he needs to step down. When do you foresee this happening, and will Syria still be in crisis next year? [SEP] We wanted him out a long time ago. We've always said he lost his right to lead when he started hurting his own citizens. The 'how' is the tricky part – there's no simple solution. We need constant global pressure and a stronger opposition. Maybe these talks in Geneva will lead somewhere, but we're not letting up on supporting the opposition and helping those in need, especially with Turkey's help.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Where were you taken, Mr. President? Were you taken to the bunker? [SEP] No, we were taken just out over to the Oval Office.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the ongoing instability in Iraq, what specific benchmarks must be met before a final agreement on the U.S. military presence can be reached, and what assurances can you provide that American oil companies are fully utilizing available resources to alleviate rising energy costs? [SEP] We're working on a strategic framework with the Iraqi government, covering diplomacy, economics, justice. It includes a security agreement. They want a timeline for transitioning to overwatch, where we're training, providing logistics, and conducting special ops. For our troops to be there, we need an agreement with the government, authorities to operate, and protections for our troops. We're negotiating that now. It needs to be done before the end of the year, unless the UN mandate is extended. So there are two parts to the agreement, and we're working on both.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the contrasting views of Brazil as a regional versus global power, how can Brazil and the U.S. forge a stronger, more equitable partnership on the international stage? [SEP] Brazil is a nation of immense potential and global significance. We are committed to playing a leading role in addressing the world's most pressing challenges. The United States recognizes the importance of our partnership, and we are working together to strengthen our relationship and promote shared values on the international stage.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Prime Minister Maliki apparently gave his own news conference this morning, where he seemed to be referring to Ambassador Khalilzad and General Casey yesterday, when he said, nobody has the right to set any timetables in Iraq—and also seemed to be upset about the raid in Sadr City, saying he wasn't consulted. And I believe the quote was, It will not be repeated. Do you still have full, complete, and total confidence in Prime Minister Maliki as a partner in Iraq? And what can you tell the American people about his ability to rein in the militias, since he seems to derive much of his power from them? [SEP] Yes. First, this is back to the question that David asked about benchmarks. You called it timetables.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea's pledge to denuclearize, what assurances do we have that they will follow through? [SEP] Can anyone guarantee anything in life? Can I guarantee you'll breathe properly? Of course not. They want to make a deal. That's what I do. I'm a dealmaker. I can tell when someone wants to deal. Politicians can't. This should have been done a long time ago. I have a feeling they want a deal. It's good for the world, and China. China was helpful. Can anyone be certain? We'll find out soon. The negotiations are ongoing. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding your emphasis on state sovereignty, how does that align with the 'responsibility to protect' doctrine, which prioritizes intervention in humanitarian crises? [SEP] The responsibility to protect was... what exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, ABC News is reporting that Iran could develop a nuclear weapon within two years. Have you seen any evidence suggesting an acceleration of their nuclear program? [SEP] I'm not familiar with the specific report you mentioned. However, I do share concerns regarding Iran's intentions to acquire nuclear weapons. I firmly believe that a nuclear-armed Iran would be a major destabilizing force in the Middle East. That's why we've been working to build an international coalition to persuade them to abandon their nuclear ambitions. They have a choice to make: isolation or the opportunity to grow their economy. We take the possibility of Iran developing a nuclear weapon very seriously.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, regarding the Turkey-Russia incident, how concerned are you about NATO being drawn into a conflict? What steps are being taken to de-escalate tensions? Furthermore, how does this affect potential military coordination with Russia? President Hollande, what are your thoughts on coordinating with Russia moving forward? [SEP] We're still assessing the situation. I anticipate speaking with President Erdogan in the coming days. Turkey, like any sovereign nation, has the right to protect its airspace. It's imperative that Russia and Turkey engage in dialogue to ascertain the facts and prevent further escalation. This incident underscores the persistent problem of Russian operations near the Turkish border, targeting moderate opposition groups supported by Turkey and other nations. If Russia were to prioritize combating ISIS, the risk of such incidents would diminish. This highlights the urgency of advancing the political track. Russia is welcome to join our broad-based coalition against ISIS. The obstacle remains Russia's support for Assad. I conveyed to President Putin that cooperation is possible if they shift their focus to the Vienna process and prioritize ISIS. Until that shift occurs, cooperation will be challenging. Attacking the moderate opposition undermines the prospect of cooperation. However, the possibility of cooperation remains. The sooner we reach an agreement on the political process, the less likely we are to witness such events. President Hollande?
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the expected partisan divide, what specific concessions or compromises are you willing to offer to gain Democratic backing for your middle-class tax cut initiative? [SEP] That's a question best directed to the Democratic leadership.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Given the protracted nature of the conflict, is there a genuine risk of a long-term stalemate? [SEP] I remain unconvinced that this conflict will endure for years. Firstly, Russia's resource and capacity constraints will become increasingly apparent. Secondly, a point will be reached where President Putin recognizes the detrimental economic and political consequences of continuing this war for Russia. While I cannot definitively predict the timeline, I anticipate that Ukraine's offensive will yield substantial progress, leading to a negotiated resolution.
label: Implicit

sentence: Does this outcome signal a shift in public sentiment, or does it simply demonstrate the growing influence of multiculturalism in America? [SEP] The facts are clear: African Americans, Asian Americans, Hispanic Americans—their employment rates are soaring. My support among these communities is the strongest it's ever been, according to recent surveys. Median income is up, unemployment is down. These are the metrics that matter, and they paint a very positive picture.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Just to follow up on Jackie's question. One of the reasons why so many of the people of the Occupy Wall Street protests are so angry is because, as you say, so many people on Wall Street did not follow the rules, but your administration hasn't really been very aggressive in prosecuting. In fact, I don't think any Wall Street executives have gone to jail despite the rampant corruption and malfeasance that did take place. So I was wondering if you'd comment on that.And then just as a separate question, as you're watching the Solyndra and Fast and Furious controversies play out, I'm wondering if it gives you any pause about any of the decisionmaking going on in your administration: some of the e-mails that Democrats put out indicating that people at the Office of Management and Budget were concerned about the Department of Energy; some of the e-mails going on with the Attorney General saying he didn't know about the details of Fast and Furious. Are you worried at all about how this is--how your administration is running? [SEP] Well, first on the issue of prosecutions on Wall Street, one of the biggest problems about the collapse of Lehmans and the subsequent financial crisis and the whole subprime lending fiasco is that a lot of that stuff wasn't necessarily illegal, it was just immoral or inappropriate or reckless. That's exactly why we needed to pass Dodd-Frank, to prohibit some of these practices.The financial sector is very creative, and they are always looking for ways to make money. That's their job. And if there are loopholes and rules that can be bent and arbitrage to be had, they will take advantage of it. So without commenting on particular prosecutions--obviously, that's not my job, that's the Attorney General's job--I think part of people's frustrations, part of my frustration, was a lot of practices that should not have been allowed weren't necessarily against the law, but they had a huge destructive impact. And that's why it was important for us to put in place financial rules that protect the American people from reckless decisionmaking and irresponsible behavior.Now, with respect to Solyndra and Fast and Furious, I think I've been very clear that I have complete confidence in Attorney General Holder in how he handles his office. He has been very aggressive in going after gun running and cash transactions that are going to these transnational drug cartels in Mexico. There has been a lot of cooperation between the United States and Mexico on this front. He's indicated that he was not aware of what was happening in Fast and Furious. Certainly, I was not. And I think both he and I would have been very unhappy if somebody had suggested that guns were allowed to pass through that could have been prevented by the United States of America.He has assigned an Inspector General to look into how exactly this happened, and I have complete confidence in him and I've got complete confidence in the process to figure out who, in fact, was responsible for that decision and how it got made.Solyndra, this is a loan guarantee program that predates me that historically has had support from Democrats and Republicans as well. And the idea is pretty straightforward: If we are going to be able to compete in the 21st century, then we've got to dominate cutting-edge technologies, we've got to dominate cutting-edge manufacturing. Clean energy is part of that package of technologies of the future that have to be based here in the United States if we're going to be able to succeed.Now, the loan guarantee program is designed to meet a particular need in the marketplace, which is, a lot of these small startups, they can get angel investors, they can get several million dollars to get a company going, but it's very hard for them to then scale up, particularly if these are new cutting-edge technologies. It's hard for them to find private investors. And part of what's happening is China and Europe, other countries, are putting enormous subsidies into these companies and giving them incentives to move offshore. Even if the technology was developed in the United States, they end up going to China because the Chinese Government will say, we're going to help you get started. We'll help you scale up. We'll give you low-interest loans or no-interest loans. We will give siting. We will do whatever it takes for you to get started here.And that's part of the reason why a lot of technologies that developed here, we've now lost the lead in: solar energy, wind energy. And so what the loan guarantee program was designed to do was to close that gap and say, let's see if we can help some of those folks locate here and create jobs here in the United States.Now, we knew from the start that the loan guarantee program was going to entail some risk, by definition. If it was a risk-free proposition, then we wouldn't have to worry about it. But the overall portfolio has been successful. It has allowed us to help companies, for example, start advanced battery manufacturing here in the United States. It's helped to create jobs. There were going to be some companies that did not work out; Solyndra was one of them. But the process by which the decision was made was on the merits. It was straightforward. And of course, there were going to be debates internally when you're dealing with something as complicated as this.But I have confidence that the decisions were made based on what would be good for the American economy and the American people and putting people back to work.And by the way, let me make one last point about this. I heard there was a Republican Member of Congress who's engaging in oversight on this, and despite the fact that all of them in the past have been supportive of this loan guarantee program, he concluded, you know what, we can't compete against China when it comes to solar energy. Well, you know what, I don't buy that. I'm not going to surrender to other countries' technological leads that could end up determining whether or not we're building a strong middle class in this country. And so we're going to have to keep on pushing hard to make sure that manufacturing is located here, new businesses are located here, and new technologies are developed here. And there are going to be times where it doesn't work out, but I'm not going to cave to the competition when they are heavily subsidizing all these industries.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in light of the Pope's potential recognition of a Palestinian state and its potential ramifications for a two-state solution with Israel, could you elaborate on whether you perceive this as a constructive measure or a misjudgment, and how it might influence the two-state solution you've previously championed? [SEP] Let me begin by expressing my appreciation for the Senate's progress in granting me the authority to pursue trade agreements that are both intelligent and promote growth, not only in the Asia-Pacific region but also potentially in Europe. This also empowers us to enforce these agreements, which hasn't always been the case. I want to thank the Senators who voted to support this, or at least to begin the debate. For those who didn't, I'll continue to make my case, providing them with the necessary information to understand that despite past issues with trade deals, our approach is the right one, not just for large corporations, but for small and medium-sized businesses, and most importantly, for American workers. I wouldn't support any agreement that I didn't believe would create jobs and opportunities for Americans to climb the ladder of success, with higher incomes and wages. That's been my primary focus since assuming office. The issue between myself and Elizabeth is not personal. The press likes to highlight disagreements between allies, but many of my closest friends in the Senate and House disagree with me on this issue. I understand their concerns about plants closing and jobs being shipped overseas. They worry about the enforcement of labor and environmental agreements and whether trade is truly fair. They share my deep concern about rising inequality and the impact of automation and globalization on the middle class. These are people whose values align with mine. They even released a progressive statement of principles that mirrored my agenda, except for trade. This is a policy difference, a disagreement on what's best for our constituents. I firmly believe that despite past problems, we're better off writing high-standard rules with strong enforcement on issues like child labor, deforestation, and intellectual property. If we don't, China and other countries will, disadvantaging our businesses and workers. As for outsourcing fears, companies seeking low-cost labor can already do so. Our opportunity lies in attracting companies back to manufacture here. Nike's potential return of 10,000 jobs due to new technologies is an example of this. But we need to be able to sell overseas to fully capitalize on these opportunities. That's why I argue with my progressive friends that we need to focus on shared objectives like a strong minimum wage, job training programs, infrastructure investments, stronger collective bargaining laws, and enforcement of overtime pay and paid sick leave. We need an honest conversation about our budgets and stop preserving loopholes for corporations that provide no economic benefit. These are the things that will address their concerns. Blocking a trade deal won't, especially since they acknowledge the existing rules are bad for U.S. workers. How does clinging to the status quo help them? It doesn't make sense. I support enforcement and the signed provisions. I have concerns about the currency language in the bill, but I need to discuss with Senators Schumer and Brown how to ensure it doesn't negatively impact our monetary policy. What was the question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, what's your current assessment of Secretary Azar's performance? [SEP] I hope he does well. Now, remind me, which department is he in charge of?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. I'm good. How you doing, sir? [SEP] So what have you been doing since 2000? Never mind. []
label: Dodging

sentence: So, you're acknowledging mistakes, but not admitting to any deliberate deception? And how do you plan to restore the public's trust, given the widespread skepticism? [SEP] We're working hard to fix the problems with the website and to make sure that people get the help they need. We're also reaching out to people directly to explain the benefits of the law and to answer their questions. It's going to take time, but we're committed to earning back the public's trust.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. If you conclude that a surge in troop levels in Iraq is needed, would you overrule your military commanders if they felt it was not a good idea? [SEP] That's a dangerous hypothetical question. I'm not condemning you; you're allowed to ask anything you want. Let me wait and gather all the recommendations from Bob Gates, from our military, from diplomats on the ground— I'm interested in the Iraqis' point of view— and then I'll report back to you as to whether or not I support a surge or not. Nice try.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your previous statement about Mr. Putin, he claims satisfaction with your explanation. Could you elaborate on the specifics of your conversation with him? [SEP] Look, if he's content, I see no reason to rehash the discussion. It's in the past.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Can you answer my question, please? [SEP] I'm addressing this gentleman at the moment. Kindly take a seat.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: With Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy confidently projecting a Republican House majority, what's your take on the evolving election results and the prospects for your party maintaining control? [SEP] Look, it's a dynamic situation. We've held onto most of our seats, that's a fact. The House is still in play, but it's gonna be tight. Take Nevada, for example – we swept those contested seats. I campaigned hard for those folks. Didn't know that last night. So, yeah, things are changing, but it's gonna be close.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. What did Secret Service tell you when you were outside of the room? [SEP] Just told me, when he came up—you pretty much saw it like I did—he said, Sir, could you please come with me? So you were surprised. I was surprised, also. I think it's probably pretty unusual. But very, very professional people. They do a fantastic job, as you know. So it seems to me—it seems to be, from what I was said, there was a shooting. It was law enforcement shot someone—seems to be the suspect—and the suspect is now on the way to the hospital. I can't tell you the condition of the suspect.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. The heads of the Boston and Dallas Fed, today, said that the economy hasn't recovered strong enough because the country hasn't contained the virus. So what's your response to them? And wouldn't that argue for a stronger Federal response? [SEP] Well look you just saw it. Other countries—we're doing much better than all other major countries peer countries. This chart came out just a little while ago. I thought I'd say—see it's that kind of a question—a wise-guy question—because I just went over the whole thing. We're doing better than almost everyone with the economy. And I think we're—you know we face a headwind because Democrats perhaps for political reasons don't want to open up their States. And that's having a huge toll—that's taking a huge toll on people within those States.When you look at North Carolina you have—a man doesn't want to open it up. You have—you look at Michigan you look at some States—I mean they just want to keep these people in their houses in their prisons. They call them prisons. And I think a lot of it is for political reasons because they want to look as bad as possible on November 3. But I don't think it's going to matter because we're doing so well in so many ways.As far as the plague is concerned when you look at the numbers take a look at what's going on now with other countries they're having flare-ups that are very very substantial and we've done very well. We're helping a lot of those countries. And those were model countries that you used to talk about and say how well they were doing except they just exploded. They just had very big flare-ups. You understand that. No we're doing very well. And I don't have to show you the charts again but those charts are at a level that nobody even thought possible.I think we're going to have a fantastic third quarter. I think next year will be one of the strongest years we've had. And this is with California being closed down. This is where North Carolina and Michigan and tremendous States—great States—are being closed by—for reasons I think that would—that Scott would tell you—you would disagree with right? You disagree with. He—we spent a great amount of time talking about it.We've got to open up our country. We understand the disease. We understand who it hits. We have to protect our elderly people especially our elderly people that are not well. We have to protect them. But we understand it and we understand it well. We've learned a lot.And we're going to have the vaccine soon and we're going to have the therapeutic soon. Going to come out very soon and we're very proud of the people and the job they've done.Yes please. Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Did the recent leaks revealing that the U.S. was spying on South Korea come up at all in your discussions? And did President Biden provide you any assurances? [SEP] On that subject, we're in touch, sharing info. The US is investigating, and things are complex. We'll wait for their findings. We'll keep talking. Last question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the limited progress towards political reconciliation in Iraq following the surge, what specific metrics are you using to evaluate the success of the Iraqi government, and what consequences will they face if they fail to meet these benchmarks within a defined timeframe? [SEP] We're constantly evaluating the situation in Iraq, constantly evaluating. We have benchmarks, yes, we have benchmarks. But I'm not going to get into the specifics of those benchmarks here. What I will say is that we expect the Iraqi government to take responsibility for their own security and their own future. We're providing them with the support they need, the best support, but ultimately, it's up to them.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. During these first 100 days, what has surprised you the most about this office, enchanted you the most about serving this in office, humbled you the most, and troubled you the most? [SEP] All right, let me write this down. []
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, concerning American oil producers, are you confident they're maximizing all available resources, including offshore? Also, will you finalize an interim agreement with Prime Minister Maliki on American operations in Iraq, or leave a more permanent agreement to your successor? [SEP] On Iraq, we're crafting a strategic framework agreement with their government, covering diplomacy, economics, and justice. A security agreement is crucial, aiming for a quick shift to 'overwatch' – U.S. training, logistics, and special ops. Troop presence requires government understanding, operational authority, and protection. We're negotiating now, aiming for completion before year-end, unless the UN mandate extends. Two linked agreement aspects are being worked on together. Regarding oil, we have been pushing for energy independence, and my administration is doing everything in its power to make that a reality.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, concerning Afghanistan, what is the projected timeline for troop withdrawal, and will you lift the media ban on covering the return of our fallen soldiers? [SEP] Let me begin by expressing my deepest condolences for the American service members who tragically lost their lives in Iraq today. Signing those letters to the families is the most solemn duty of this office. Regarding the media policy, we are currently reviewing it in consultation with the Department of Defense, and I cannot provide a definitive answer at this time. Afghanistan presents a complex and multifaceted challenge. While Iraq has demonstrated progress, Afghanistan's government remains fragile, and the threat of the Taliban and Al Qaida persists. We require a concerted and comprehensive effort to eliminate their safe havens. General Petraeus and Special Envoy Holbrooke are conducting a thorough review and developing a regional approach. We must enhance coordination between our military, diplomatic, and development efforts, working closely with our allies. We must not forget that this region served as the launching pad for the 9/11 attacks. We cannot allow Afghanistan to become a haven for terrorists. I cannot provide a specific timetable for withdrawal, but I assure you that we will not allow Al Qaida to operate with impunity and threaten our nation's security.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, given the history of mistrust between the United States and Russia, what specific confidence-building measures are you proposing to foster a more stable and predictable relationship? [SEP] We are committed to finding areas of cooperation with Russia where it is in our mutual interest. We believe that dialogue is essential to managing our differences and preventing misunderstandings. We will continue to engage with Russia on issues such as arms control, counterterrorism, and regional security. We are hopeful that we can build a more constructive relationship over time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Indo-Pacific strategy and China, how do you balance promoting freedom with avoiding conflict? And Mr. Prime Minister, did your discussion with the President touch on Japan's role in missile defense, particularly regarding North Korea, and what are your thoughts on Japan's future defense posture? [SEP] Look, the Prime Minister is doing a fantastic job. He's buying a lot of our military equipment, the best in the world, by far. And he'll be able to take care of any situation. Now, China, that's a different story. We have a great relationship, but they've been ripping us off for years. Trade deficits, intellectual property theft, you name it. It's got to stop. We're talking about reciprocal trade. That's the only fair way to do it. If they charge us a tariff, we charge them the same tariff. It's very simple. And we're working on it. It takes time, there are laws and regulations, but we're getting it done. You'll see a big difference. As for Japan, they're buying a lot of our equipment, and they're going to be very well defended. Very safe. Thank you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, Mr. President, if I understand correctly, you envision a potential future where U.S.-North Korea relations resemble those we have with Vietnam today? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, your critics argue that your 'America First' policy is isolating the United States and damaging our credibility on the global stage. How do you respond to these concerns, particularly in light of your recent interactions with world leaders? [SEP] It's very simple, folks. I'm putting America first. That's what I was elected to do. These other countries, they've been taking advantage of us for decades. They're not our friends; they're competitors. We need to be smart, we need to be tough, and we need to put America first. If that means shaking things up, so be it. I'm not afraid to stand up for what's right for the American people.
label: Deflection

sentence: If Tedros is removed from his position at the WHO, would you consider supporting the organization again? Or do you believe his resignation is a necessary condition for reform? [SEP] Look, we're investigating the whole situation. I don't know the man personally, but there have been some serious problems, okay? And the WHO has been incredibly unfair to the United States, just like the World Trade Organization. They treat China like a developing nation, which is a joke! Why didn't previous presidents do anything about this? I've been talking about it since day one. So, I have issues with both the WHO and the WTO, and frankly, I'm not sure which is worse. But we'll get to the bottom of it, believe me.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, Mr. President, no kinship there? [SEP] Great law student, I hear. Heard the name, didn't know him, though. Not 'til all this. Heard it for ten years, you know why? Everyone saying, 'Supreme Court!' I'm like, 'Who's that?' Brett Kavanaugh. They were talking about him for the Court ten years ago. 'Most brilliant lawyer!' All that said, I wanna hear her out. Okay?
label: Deflection

sentence: Could you clarify what you told President Putin about your earlier remark calling him a killer? [SEP] He's satisfied. I see no reason to bring it up again.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given your understanding of the situation, do you believe President Putin will invade Ukraine before the end of winter? What advice do you have for the Americans currently in Ukraine? [SEP] I've engaged in numerous discussions with the Russians, particularly with Putin. Whether he has made a definitive decision remains uncertain. He must recognize that an invasion of Ukraine would be a monumental error, with devastating consequences for Europe and the global community. He would face severe repercussions. I have been forthright and direct with President Putin, both in our phone conversations and in person. We are prepared to impose unprecedented economic sanctions, the most stringent ever implemented, which would carry significant long-term costs. This would have repercussions for others, including ourselves and Europeans, but it would profoundly impact his economy. While he possesses the capacity to invade, particularly if the ground above Kiev is frozen, his ultimate course of action remains unknown. I doubt anyone but him knows for sure.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, did you and President Biden discuss the recent leaks regarding U.S. surveillance of South Korea? And did he provide any assurances concerning those activities? [SEP] We are in communication with each other, sharing relevant information. There is an ongoing investigation in the United States, and the situation is complex. We must allow time for the investigation to conclude. We plan to continue our discussions on this matter. This will be the final question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Libya, what's the timeline for transferring command, and is NATO the likely successor? Furthermore, could you elaborate on the concrete objectives of your proposed 'alliance among equals' with the Americas? [SEP] On Libya, the situation is fluid. The speed of the transfer depends on our commanders' assessment of mission completion. NATO will play a coordinating role given its capabilities. I'll defer to Admiral Mullen for the specifics of the transfer. As for the new partnership, I don't want to spoil my speech, but I'm excited about the two-way street aspect. Countries like Chile have much to offer us, not just the other way around.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Do you hope that Amy Coney Barrett is watching as well? [SEP] I do. I'm sure she is. I think everybody is. I think everyone in the country. I think we've made it a very big issue, and it's an issue that the Democrats tried to get away with. I don't think they're getting away. I mean, so many reports now of phony ballots—you know, that I don't know if it would have been reported before.But all of these rallies—you know, we had thousands of people last night, as you know. And we were in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. The night before, we were in Virginia. I mean, those crowds are—whether it was 35,000 or 30,000, those crowds are massive. And that's on very short notice. All of those people are watching. You know, we have eyes and ears now that we wouldn't have had if we didn't bring it up.So no, I'm sure she's watching, and I'm sure that everybody is looking at it. I think it's just common sense.Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding France's new leader, have you spoken with him, and are you trying to bring him into your coalition? Also, what specific requests are you making of Middle Eastern countries through Mr. Cheney's visit? [SEP] Well, first off, we don't 'recruit' presidents. The people choose their leader, and I'll work with whoever they pick. I did speak with President-elect Sarkozy shortly after his victory – about 8:03 Paris time, I believe. I'm grateful he took my call. I met him before and found him to be smart and energetic. We'll have our disagreements, but also areas of agreement, and I look forward to working with him. As for Vice President Cheney's trip, his main message to the Iraqis is that they need to speed things up, especially on passing laws that promote reconciliation. There's a clock ticking here in Washington, and they need to understand that. He'll also be talking to other friends in the region about the Iranian issue. We understand the consequences of Iran potentially acquiring nuclear weapons, and we're working to build a united front against that. We've already convinced the EU-3, Russia, and China to join us diplomatically, and we need to keep that unity. Cheney will also remind everyone that success in Iraq is crucial for dealing with Iran. If we withdraw prematurely, it would embolden Iran. So, his trip is vital, and I appreciate his efforts.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, given the history of mistrust between the United States and Iran, what specific mechanisms will be put in place to ensure that Iran adheres to any future agreements? [SEP] Verification is key. We need to have inspectors on the ground, making sure they're not cheating. We're not going to take their word for it. We're going to hold them accountable.
label: General

sentence: Where is that investigation taking place? And do you have faith in its integrity? [SEP] I can't disclose that information yet. I need to observe the process. I'm intentionally staying uninvolved. I'm considered the chief law enforcement officer, but I believe it's better for the Attorney General to handle it. He has Durham, a highly respected individual, overseeing it. We'll see what the outcome is. I can't comment further.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. I get another one. [Laughter] This is a good deal. Can you tell us whether you think your personal relationship with the Democratic leaders in Congress has had a negative impact on your ability to get your legislation through? And how important is that personal relationship? [SEP] I have got cordial relations with the leaders when I talk to them. I saw Speaker Pelosi last night at the Congressional Ball at the White House, and we have very cordial relations. Here's— Congress—the Democrats in Congress, in the House and the Senate, need to work out their differences before they come to the White House. You can imagine what it's like to try to deal on an important piece of legislation, and the Democrats in the House have one opinion, and the Democrats in the Senate have another opinion. FISA is a good example.And in order for us to be able to reach accord, they've got to come with one voice, one position. And it's—nobody—like, the most disappointing thing about Washington has been the name-calling and this kind of—people go out in front of the mikes, and they just kind of unleash. And I've tried hard not to do that. I've tried to be respectful to all parties. And that's disappointing.On the other hand, I think we can get some things done. The Peruvian trade vote is one; there's an example. And the Congress needs to get their differences sorted. One of the worst ways to negotiate is to negotiate with one group. They pocket your negotiations, and then another group shows up and says, Well, you've said this to them, now give us this.And hopefully, as we come down the stretch here, that they're capable of coming forward with, Here's what we believe; here's our plan; here's what we would like you to consider, as opposed to some examples, which is passing legislation for the sake of the headline, as opposed to passing legislation to get it passed. And SCHIP is a classic example. They knew I was going to veto the bill. They knew that was going to happen. They knew the veto would be sustained. But they ate up valuable time and passed the bill anyway.And so we sit here in the White House trying to figure out why. Why would you waste time? Why wouldn't you sit down and try to seriously negotiate an agreement on a bill that they knew was going to get vetoed and sustained?Now, hopefully, in the next—however long they intend to stay here, that we're capable of working together. But if not, I'm going to stand strong for certain principles, and one of which is to make sure our troops get funded. We've got men and women in combat. We've got people risking their lives for the United States of America. And this Congress has yet to fund them, and it needs to. And it needs to fund them without telling our military how to conduct this war. Arbitrary dates for withdrawal are unacceptable, particularly given the fact that the strategy is working—it's working.And it seems like to me that this Congress ought to be congratulating our military commanders and our troops. And one way to send a congratulatory message is to give them the funds they need, and now is the time to do it.Let's see here, Mark Silva [Chicago Tribune].
label: Explicit

sentence: President Calderon, some observers suggest that your reluctance to condemn the ad outright implies a tacit approval of its message. How do you respond to those who believe you are not doing enough to discourage divisive rhetoric and promote a more respectful political discourse in Mexico? [SEP] I have always been a strong advocate for respectful political discourse, and I believe that all parties have a responsibility to engage in constructive dialogue. However, I also believe in freedom of speech, and I am not going to start censoring political ads simply because I disagree with their message. The Mexican people are capable of making their own judgments about what is true and what is not.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, President Karzai of Afghanistan has directly accused Pakistani intelligence of supporting terrorism. Simultaneously, intelligence indicates that Al-Qaeda is regaining strength along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border. Do you believe President Karzai's assessment is accurate, and is the new Pakistani government truly capable of combating these terrorist threats? [SEP] We take President Karzai's allegations seriously and will investigate them thoroughly in conjunction with Afghan authorities. It's undeniable that extremist elements are operating within Pakistan and crossing into Afghanistan, a situation that concerns all involved parties. We share a mutual enemy in those who seek to undermine democratic processes through violence. Al-Qaeda, while significantly weakened, remains a threat. We've applied considerable pressure globally, including within Pakistan, and will continue to do so with the cooperation of our Pakistani partners. I am confident that the Pakistani government recognizes the gravity of the extremist threat. I anticipate further discussions on this matter with the Pakistani Prime Minister next week. Pakistan remains an ally and a friend. The United States, Pakistan, and Afghanistan share a common objective. I recall a productive meeting with Presidents Musharraf and Karzai where we emphasized the necessity of cross-border cooperation to prevent the training and infiltration of dangerous elements into Afghanistan, and their subsequent return with skills that could be used against the government. While progress has been made, the struggle continues. We were encouraged by the recent Provincial elections. We will continue to support the government in its efforts to combat extremism and implement an effective counterinsurgency strategy that incorporates economic development assistance. This is a complex challenge, and collaboration is essential for success. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, given the potential for escalation, your silence on the Israeli bombing raid in Syria is concerning. Can you assure the American people that the U.S. is actively working to de-escalate tensions in the region, and can you provide any details on those efforts? [SEP] We are always working towards peace and stability.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. President Bolsonaro, does the United States expect the influence of China into Brazil? Yesterday Paulo Guedes mentioned that it's going to incentivize relations with China. How does the U.S. see that, and what you said about President Trump, about the Chinese in Brazil? [SEP] Well, like I said, Brazil is going to keep on making as much business with as many countries as possible. No longer businesses are going to be found into the ideology, as it used to be. We are also following this objective for the good of our peoples. . Thank you very much, Mr. President. I appreciate it. Thank you very much. And thank you, everybody. Thank you very much.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the limited timeframe, Mr. President, are you confident that a unilateral action can effectively address the pressing issues at hand, or are you primarily focused on exploring other avenues for resolution? [SEP] We have not come up with a unilateral action that could succeed in a matter of 2 weeks or 3 weeks. That's the issue.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. In Washington, a bipartisan group of Senators has repeatedly failed to pass through Senate a law that would prevent future U.S. Presidents from withdrawing from NATO without Senate's approval. What actions will you take to assure Finland that the U.S. will remain a reliable NATO partner for decades to come? [SEP] I absolutely guarantee it. There is no question. There's overwhelming support from the American people. There's overwhelming support from the Members of the Congress, both House and Senate. In both parties, notwithstanding the fact there are some extreme elements of one party, we will stand together.The American people have known for the—since the end of World War II and the formation of NATO that our security rests in the unanimity among European and transatlantic partner—us. And so this is—you know, no one can guarantee the future, but this is the best bet anyone could make.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Sir, have you been briefed on any new positive COVID-19 test results within the White House today? [SEP] Positive cases... today?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the Democrats have voted for a withdrawal timetable from Iraq, which you have said that you will veto. What ideas do you have for breaking this logjam going forward? And would you be willing to veto a second bill? [SEP] Well, first of all, haven't vetoed the first bill yet. But I'm going to. And the reason why I'm going to is because the Members of Congress have made military decisions on behalf of the military. They're telling our generals what to do. They're withdrawing before we've even finished reinforcing our troops in Baghdad. They're sending, in my judgment, a bad message to the Iraqis and to an enemy and, most importantly, to our military folks. And so I made it clear, I'd veto.And, by the way, they're adding spending that shouldn't belong in the bill in the first place. Maybe they're important issues, but they ought to be—these spending bills ought to be—or spending issues ought to be debated in the normal course of business. And so I've said this all along; my position has been consistent.I'm sorry it's come to this. In other words, I'm sorry that we've had this, you know, the issue evolve the way it has. But nevertheless, it is what it is, and it will be vetoed, and my veto will be sustained. And then the question is the way forward. And my suggestion is that—and I invite the leaders of the House and the Senate, both parties, to come down soon after my veto so we can discuss a way forward. And if the Congress wants to test my will as to whether or not I'll accept a timetable for withdrawal—I won't accept one. I just don't think it's in the interest of our troops.I think it—I'm just envisioning what it would be like to be a young soldier in the middle of Iraq and realizing that politicians have all of the sudden made military determinations. And in my judgment, that would put a kid in harm's way, more so than he or she already is. I really think it's a mistake for Congress to try to tell generals, our military experts, how to conduct a war.And furthermore, the idea of putting all kinds of extraneous spending on a bill, the bill—purpose of which is to fund our troops, is—I just don't accept that. So if they want to try again, that which I have said was unacceptable, then of course I'll veto it, but I hope it doesn't come to that. I believe we can work a way forward. And I think we can come to our senses and make sure that we get the money to the troops in a timely fashion. It's important to have a political debate, but as I've consistently said, we don't want our troops in between the debate. And Congress needs to get this money to the Pentagon so the Pentagon can get the money to the troops and so our readiness will be up to par and people—training missions will go forward.I know Congress, no matter what their position is on the war, doesn't want to affect readiness, and they don't want to affect the military families—I understand that— but they're going to if they keep trying to pass legislation that is—that just doesn't—that withdraws troops or micromanages the war.And so I'm optimistic we can get a bill, a good bill, and a bill that satisfies all our objectives, and that's to get the money to the troops as quickly as possible.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Was Syria part of those talks? Is Syria part of the talks? [SEP] Proliferation is a part of the talks.

sentence: President Trump, concerning the North Korean crisis, you've expressed optimism about a resolution. Beyond stating your belief, can you point to any concrete achievements resulting from your diplomatic approach thus far? And has your view on direct talks changed? We're showing strength, believe me, unparalleled strength. We've got assets in place, powerful assets, that we pray we never have to use. I think they're starting to see reason, and hopefully, we can get them to the table for a deal that works for everyone. So, yes, I see movement, but we'll see what happens.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. In terms of things that you don't agree, are you comfortable with the $500 billion? [SEP] I think the things I don't agree we can probably negotiate. But I think we've made some progress over the last week, and I think it was positive that they came out with that report.

sentence: Do you anticipate this bill being enacted during your first year as president? [SEP] We're moving forward on this as fast as we can. I'm pushing hard on all fronts. sentence: Q. You can get unanimity within weeks? [SEP] We think that we can get sanctions within weeks. Well, I've read many comments--and I must say I've been quite amused--on the relations between European leaders and the President of the United States. I say I'm amused because I've thought to myself, well, when we speak to one another, people must be listening to our phone calls, because I have seen reports on conversations and discussions which in no way resemble anything that has ever taken place between Barack Obama and myself.Now, why is it easy for us to work? And I speak on behalf of Chancellor Merkel, Gordon Brown, and other leaders. Well, because , when he says something, keeps his word. His word is his bond. And that is so important. There's a joke among us: We don't like surprises. Well, from that point of view, there's no surprises. When he can, he delivers; when he can't, he says so. So there are no surprises. And we try to be likewise.Furthermore, secondly, on all topics--and there have been some pretty tough topics. I mean, for instance, bonus--taxes on bonuses, regulation, financial regulations--pretty heavy-going stuff--Copenhagen. I mean, I happen to think that is a step ahead of public opinion in the United States on this. But we're constantly talking about it. It's even who wanted us to have a call conference, a videoconference virtually every month with Angela Merkel and Gordon Brown.Now, this doesn't merely mean that we absolutely agree neck and neck on everything, but we talk amongst ourselves. And this is a novelty from the point of view of Europe, whenever we look at the United States, that everything is put on the table, anything can be discussed, everything can be discussed.What matters, you see, is not whether we agree once systematically before we've even started discussing thing--that's suspicious. It's to say, whatever divergence of views we may have, we can talk about it among ourselves. And I say things very frankly to you, and this is what all we European leaders believe and think.I've also heard it said that Europe was less interested in the United States. Well, for heaven's sake, how many times do we have to come over to show that we are interested? What would it mean if we were interested?So, very frankly and very honestly on this, not only is it not an issue, not a problem, but it's great to be able to work under such conditions. I would say that what I have to say about is the same as what Bernard Kouchner could say about Hillary Clinton or Christine Lagarde about Tim Geithner--that we're constantly having a dialogue.I could even take you--give you an example of something on which we don't necessarily agree, such as Syria--or we didn't agree. France took an initiative, as you know. Well, I'll say this to you. At no point--no point has turned his back on what we were doing. Constantly, he's watching; he's listening. We're constantly exchanging information on the subject, even when there are more complex topics, including in our relations with the Russians. Before even we inform our Russian--or the Russians or our partners, I pick up the phone, I call , and he knows exactly what we're going to do and why we're going to do it. You follow me on that?So there may be disagreements, but never for the wrong reasons. And as we are very transparent on both sides, there's confidence, there's trust. And I really think I can say that. There's a lot of trust.Now, trust always helps one overcome, perhaps, diverging interests. It may be that the United States of America has slightly different interests of those of France, but the bedrock of trust between us is something that he also has with all European leaders. And I don't say this to please you; I said it because it's true. And I took two examples of two topics that could, in other tide--other times, have led to head-on collision, and which in this case, on the contrary, are looked at on both sides of the Atlantic as a situation where we are complementary.Perhaps he said, well, maybe on Syria, France is on the right track, and maybe one day we'll have the opportunity to do likewise. And that's exactly the way we work.Go ahead, I'm not the one with the mike.
label: Deflection

sentence: Critics argue that bypassing the 30-day congressional notification requirement for the Bergdahl exchange suggests a desire to circumvent oversight and potentially signals a rush to close Guantanamo. How do you justify this perceived disregard for established procedures, and can you guarantee transparency in future decisions regarding detainee transfers? [SEP] The suggestion that we disregarded Congress is simply false. We consulted with them extensively. The timing was driven by Sergeant Bergdahl's precarious condition and the opportunity presented by the Qataris. We acted decisively to save an American life. Guantanamo is a separate issue, and we continue to work towards its responsible closure. We will always strive for transparency, but our priority is the safety and security of the American people.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So how can a guy who does that be your friend? [SEP] I think that we are able to—and maybe he's not anymore. I'll be honest with you, I think we had a very good friendship. I think we had a very good relationship; we understand each other. They are doing studies on Donald Trump. They're trying to figure it all out, because this has never happened to them before. It's never happened.Think of it, you've never seen—you've covered very well—you've never seen this happen. They're having big problems. I don't want them to have problems, but they've got to make a fair deal. Just like Canada has got to make a fair deal.I believe that he and I have a very good chemistry together. And I can tell you that about many leaders. I can also tell you a few where I don't feel I'll ever have a chemistry with them. I don't want to have a chemistry with them. And for those people, I'll have Pompeo, Nikki, Bolton, Jared. I can go—our General; I'll have our General. Or if they can't do it, I'll have Sarah Huckabee do it. Right?But for the most part, I have very good—very good with Prime Minister Abe. Very good with President Moon. By the way, what President Moon said last night—I know you won't report it—but Bret Baier [Bret Baier, Fox News] interviewed him last night, and he asked him about me. I can't say—because you would say I'm too braggadocious—but what he said about me last night was an unbelievable thing. Couldn't have happened without President Trump, and it never would happen without President Trump. And nobody else could do it. You know, I mean, you'll take a look.But I will tell you, is very special. Very special. They're incredible people. It's an incredible country. What they've done is unbelievable.
label: General

sentence: President Bush, regarding the imprisoned medics, would you commit to lobbying Congress to allocate funds from your HIV/AIDS program to support children infected with AIDS and their families? And President Parvanov, what's your view on the Libya issue, and would you comment on the Bulgarian media's idea to solicit donations from influential business leaders for a modern medical center for HIV/AIDS patients? [SEP] There's a fund we're contributing to. Focus on whether the U.S. is committing funds, along with the EU. We are. We're also telling Libya we expect the nurses' release. We're in concert with your Government. We care. We agree there should be compensation for the Libyan children. I've visited Libya, the hospital, spoken with the parents and children. I'm aware of the drama and the need to invest in the hospital. This is a commitment of the entire democratic public. This isn't just about releasing the nurses; it's a long-term commitment to those suffering in Benghazi and all AIDS sufferers in Africa. The G-8 allocated $60 billion. I appealed to businesses to donate more. I support the Bulgarian media's appeal. Their voice is heard more clearly than politicians'.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Bush, while we appreciate your support for the medics, would you commit to lobbying Congress to allocate a portion of your HIV/AIDS funding to support infected children and their families in Libya? President Parvanov, what are your thoughts on the Libya situation, and how do you view the Bulgarian media's suggestion of soliciting donations from Forbes' top business leaders to build a modern medical center for HIV/AIDS treatment? [SEP] We're contributing to a fund, and the source of the funding shouldn't be your concern. What's important is the U.S.'s commitment, along with the EU. We're also urging Libya to release the nurses. We're aligned with your government and support compensation for the children and families. I've visited Libya, the hospital in Benghazi, and spoken with the affected families. I'm aware of their suffering and the need to invest in the hospital. This is a global commitment, not just a temporary effort. We're committed to those suffering in Benghazi and AIDS victims across Africa. The G-8 has allocated $60 billion for this. I've appealed to global businesses to contribute more. I support the Bulgarian media's appeal. Their voice is heard more clearly than politicians'.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: With the slowdown in the drawdown here, we're looking at more risk, more danger for U.S. troops that are in Afghanistan. How do you justify that to them? How do you tell them that the mission is still worth it? And how do you assure them that there is an end coming to this mission? And for President Ghani, you've talked the last couple days a lot about the sacrifice of U.S. troops. You were at Arlington earlier today. How do you tell them that this continued sacrifice will be worth it to them as well? [SEP] Well, Leo, let's remember the timeline for our withdrawal to an Embassy-centered presence by the end of 2016 hasn't changed. Our transition out of a combat role hasn't changed. I acknowledge the risks for our troops in Afghanistan; it's a dangerous place. But casualties have decreased significantly as we've drawn down. It's been over 90 days since two Americans were killed there, precisely because we're not in a combat role. The Afghan security services have made significant sacrifices, stepping up as we've drawn down. They're fighting with courage and tenacity, improving month by month. But we can't minimize the sacrifices our military families make. Some will rotate back into Afghanistan for a few extra months. We're essentially shifting the drawdown pace to the right to compensate for the lengthy government formation and to ensure we're helping Afghan security forces succeed, preventing a return due to terrorist activities launched from Afghanistan. We're on track, and as Commander in Chief, I believe providing a few extra months to help with logistics, equipment usage, training, advising, and strategic input is wise. President Ghani, as Commander in Chief, is conducting a serious review to assess strengths and weaknesses for more effective joint planning. Our troops and their families make enormous sacrifices. This means some who would have been home will remain in Afghanistan under the new schedule. But we've gone from 100,000 to under 10,000, and they're not on the front lines. Force protection is a priority. The drawdown completion date remains unchanged. General Campbell and others on the ground believe this additional timeframe to help Afghan security forces succeed is worthwhile. We're asking our troops to fight for our freedom and a more orderly world. This raises a point about budgets. It's a good time for Congress to review their budgets. Holding defense and nondefense budgets to 2006 levels makes it harder to do our job, both on national security and at home, ensuring our troops have a strong economy, good schools for their kids, college access, and deserved veterans benefits. That would be a fitting expression of thanks for their sacrifices. President Ghani?
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, was he invited to the meeting? [SEP] That's not within my purview. I'm not involved in scheduling these events. However, I can assure you that there is a strong collaborative dynamic between the individuals responsible for these arrangements.

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the upcoming bank bailout, will you mandate that financial institutions use these funds to increase lending? But, echoing Jake's earlier point, my key concern is whether credit is reaching those who need it. Is it flowing to businesses, both large and small? Are consumers able to access it? Does it translate to job creation and economic growth on Main Street? That's what this package aims to do. Beyond that, I want Tim to have his moment in the spotlight tomorrow. Now, where's Major Garrett from FOX News?

sentence: Sir, has your administration determined whether President Putin plans to invade Ukraine? [SEP] Look, trying to predict Putin is like trying to predict the weather. sentence: Many argue that excessive consumer spending fueled the recent economic crisis. If your plan succeeds in boosting consumer spending, aren't we simply perpetuating the problem? Shouldn't we prioritize saving and debt reduction? [SEP] It is a mischaracterization to suggest that consumer spending was the primary driver of the recent economic crisis. The crisis was precipitated by the imprudent and often reckless practices of financial institutions, who engaged in excessive risk-taking with insufficient capital reserves. While I concur that a sustainable economic model necessitates a higher savings rate, our immediate imperative is to arrest the current downward spiral. This requires stimulating aggregate demand and making strategic investments in long-term economic growth. Such measures are essential for stabilizing the federal budget and mitigating the escalating demands on social safety net programs. Once the economy has stabilized, we can then pivot to fostering a culture of greater financial prudence.
label: Deflection

sentence: With North Korea seemingly unwilling to negotiate, will the US consider increasing sanctions? [SEP] I don't want to comment on that right now. We already have very strong sanctions. I don't think that increasing sanctions is something that I want to talk about. I care about the people of North Korea. My attitude has changed since I got to know Chairman Kim. I don't want to talk about it. Hopefully, for the sake of South Korea and Japan, this situation will resolve itself.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Beyond anecdotal evidence of boat parades and biker rallies, what specific policy changes or initiatives are you planning to address the concerns of voters who have expressed dissatisfaction with your leadership during the pandemic? [SEP] We've done more in the last four years than any other administration in history! Rebuilt the military, cut taxes, created the greatest economy ever, slashed regulations, VA Choice, Space Force – nobody's done what we've done! And we saved the energy business, got Russia and Saudi Arabia to cut production, and gasoline prices are way down. The American people know we're fighting for them, and they're going to re-elect us in a landslide!

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the supercommittee and the potential sequester, critics argue your balanced approach lacks specifics. Can you detail the exact percentage cuts you envision for defense, non-defense, and entitlement programs, and what revenue increases are you proposing, specifically, to avoid burdening middle-class families, especially in light of Mr. Hensarling's comments? [SEP] Look, the situation is fluid, and frankly, getting into specific percentages right now would be counterproductive. The key is that everyone needs to come to the table willing to compromise. We've laid out a framework, a vision, and we need to see if the supercommittee can rise to the occasion. As for the hot mic incident, I am not going to discuss private conversations with other leaders.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, what's your perspective on Australia's consideration of selling uranium to India, and to what extent did the U.S. encourage that decision? Furthermore, what are your thoughts on a global carbon trading system, particularly in light of Australia's carbon tax legislation? [SEP] Regarding India, I don't think we exerted any influence on Australia's decision. I believe your government is astute enough to understand the significance of India and the Australia-India relationship. This is your region, and you're capable of making your own bilateral decisions. The discussions surrounding nuclear energy with India appear to align with international law and the NPT. This matter is between India and Australia, not the U.S. Concerning carbon emissions, I concur with your Prime Minister and the majority of scientists that climate change is a genuine problem caused by human activity. Each country is exploring its own methods to reduce emissions. Australia has adopted a bold strategy. In the U.S., we've doubled fuel efficiency standards and invested in clean energy research. We believe we can fulfill our commitments from Copenhagen and Cancun. I hope the U.S. can identify additional ways to reduce emissions. Advanced economies can't address this issue alone; emerging economies like China and India must participate in the solution. We seek a mechanism where all countries are making an effort, which will be challenging but ultimately beneficial.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Those were your words. What crime exactly are you accusing President Obama of committing? And do you believe the Justice Department should prosecute him? The President. Obamagate—it's been going on for a long time. It's been going on from before I even got elected. And it's a disgrace that it happened. And if you look at what's gone on, and if you look at, now, all of this information that's being released—and from what I understand, that's only the beginning—some terrible things happened, and it should never be allowed to happen in our country again.And you'll be seeing what's going on over the next—over the coming weeks. But I—and I wish you'd write honestly about it, but unfortunately, you choose not to do so.Yes. Jon, please. Q. The crime—what is the crime exactly that you're accusing him of? [SEP] You know what the crime is. The crime is very obvious to everybody. All you have to do is read the newspapers, except yours.Jon, please./
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with gasoline prices soaring to record highs, are you prepared to reconsider your stance on domestic energy production, and do you believe that Saudi Arabia and other oil-producing nations are acting in good faith? [SEP] Look, rising gas prices are hurting American families, plain and simple. We've been neglecting our own energy resources for too long, and now we're paying the price. We need to unleash American energy and become energy independent once again. That's the only way to protect our consumers.

sentence: Sir, on Xinjiang: the CCP denies forced labor, yet you've only issued a limited ban. Why not a full ban? And are our allies supporting our stance? [SEP] We're on top of it. We're investigating these claims, and we'll have a concrete response shortly. Let's move to another topic.

sentence: Mr. President, concerning American oil production, are you satisfied that companies are fully exploiting all available resources, including offshore? And on Iraq, will you finalize an interim agreement with Prime Minister Maliki regarding American operations, or leave the permanent agreement for the next administration? [SEP] Alright, let's start with Iraq. We're working on a strategic framework agreement with the Iraqi government. It'll cover everything: diplomacy, economics, justice. Part of that is a security agreement. They want to move to what we call 'overwatch' pretty quickly. Overwatch means we'll be training, giving support, and doing special ops. To have our troops in another country, we need an agreement with their government. We need the right to operate and protection for our troops. We're negotiating that now. It has to be done before the end of the year, unless the UN extends the mandate. So, there are two parts to this agreement, and people mix them up. We're working on both at the same time. Let's see here.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. With judges limiting police use of nonlethal force, should police be allowed to use it to control violence? [SEP] Nonlethal force? Where was this again?
