sentence: Mr. President, Senator Leahy is calling for a truth and reconciliation committee regarding the Bush administration. Your reaction, and will you commit to no prosecutions of Bush officials? [SEP] I'm not familiar with the specifics of the proposal. What I can say is that my administration will be guided by the principles of legality and due process. While past actions deserve scrutiny, my primary concern is charting a course forward that unites the nation. I'll review the proposal, but my focus is on the future.

sentence: Q. So you may not meet with him? You might—[inaudible]? [SEP] Well, I'm—no. As I said, I'm going to just make an assessment. I just got out of these meetings. What is certainly true is, is that the issues of how we approach fighting crime and drug trafficking is a serious one for all of us, and we've got to do it the right way.Michelle Kosinski [CNN].

sentence: Mr. President, shifting gears, can you specify what aspects of these federal inclusivity training programs you consider to be 'un-American'? [SEP] A report is forthcoming. The individuals involved have been dismissed. It was a disgrace. The report will address your concerns. Next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Regarding those seeking asylum in the US, what percentage do you consider to be legitimate asylum seekers? [SEP] I won't offer a specific percentage. We are a nation of laws, and secure borders are vital. Without borders, there is no nation. I have been following the caravan's journey. Mexico's immigration laws are exceptionally strict. It began with over a thousand people, now reduced to around one hundred. Mexico is a large country. We are facing the most flawed laws imaginable. We urgently need changes in Congress. A wall is essential. While not perfect, it will deter many. We need robust border security. We are deploying National Guard troops to the border. We must reform the law. Catch-and-release is unacceptable.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, thank you. President Niinistö. If I could, sir, I've got two pertinent questions to ask you. Maybe I could ask them separately to get a fresh answer out of each one.The three House Intelligence—the three House committees that are looking into the impeachment inquiry gave notice today that they will be sending a subpoena to the White House for documents and other materials. Will you cooperate with those subpoenas? [SEP] Well, I always cooperate. This is a hoax. This is the greatest hoax. This is just a continuation of what's been playing out, John, for the last—since my election, I would say. If you wanted—probably, we'll find out soon, but probably even before my election.This is a fraudulent crime on the American people. But we'll work together with Shifty Schiff and Pelosi and all of them, and we'll see what happens, because we did absolutely—I had a great call with the President of Ukraine. It was a hundred percent. You have the transcript. And then, Schiff went up, and he got—as the chairman of the committee, he got up and related a call that didn't take place. He made up the language. I—hard to believe. Nobody has ever seen this. I think he had some kind of a mental breakdown.But he went up to the microphone, and he read a statement from the President of the United States as if I were on the call, because what happened is, when he looked at the sheet—which was an exact transcript of my call, done by very talented people that do this—exact, word for word—he said, Wow, he didn't do anything wrong. So he made it up. He went up to a microphone, and, in front of the American people and in Congress, he went out, and he gave a whole presentation of words that the President of the United States never said. It has to be a criminal act. It has to be. And he should resign. And some people even say it was treason. But it was a very sad thing.And just so you know, the call was perfect, the real call; the call I made. Many people were on the line. I knew that because, usually, when I speak to foreign country leaders—you can name any one of them—but when I speak on the phone, I know that we have many people listening from various intelligence agencies. My knowledge—I know all about it. And so this isn't something like: Oh, gee, I'm on the line. Let's talk about a big secret. This is many people on the line. I don't even know how many. We'll find out, I guess. But many people. Mike Pompeo was on the line. He didn't say anything. He just—because they listen for both knowledge and for security reasons and for lots of reasons.But the President of Ukraine, at the United Nations the other day—and previous to that—he announced through his spokesperson—said there was absolutely no pressure put on him. There was no quid pro quo, at all. And if you look at this whistleblower's—which I have a lot of respect for whistleblowers, but only when they're real—his report of the phone call was totally different than the fact.But what got them was they never thought I was going to release the call. Because I don't like doing that. I don't want to do it. I hope I don't have to do it again: release phone calls to foreign dignitaries, to foreign leaders. I don't want to do that, John. I don't want to do it again. But I did it with the permission of the Ukrainian Government. We got permission. We called up their representatives and asked them, Would it be okay? Otherwise, I couldn't have done it.And if I wouldn't have done it, I would have been exposed to a lie, because the whistleblower report—didn't he say, seven or eight times, I said quid pro quo? In other words, You're going to do this or you're not going to get money.Now, in all fairness—Biden said it, and he's on tape. In all fairness, you have at least four United States Senators—Democrats—that said it. And they said it a lot stronger than even Schiff and his made-up story said it.Obama, when he was dealing with the President of Russia—not Putin—he said, Hey, tell Vladimir I can do a lot more after the election. You remember that? You didn't make a big deal out of that. Everybody thought: Oh, isn't that cute? Isn't that cute? My talk and my response—Lindsey Graham said, I never knew you were that nice. I can't believe you were that nice. He said that loud and clear. It was perfect. It was perfect. Not a thing wrong with it.To impeach a President over a fraud that was committed by other people that want to win an election in 2020—which they won't—is incredible.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, that sounds like a lot of diplomatic language. Can you give us concrete details? What specific conditions are you imposing on European aid, and what alternative stimulus measures are you considering given the gridlock in Congress? [SEP] We are exploring a range of options, including tax incentives, infrastructure investments, and regulatory reforms. We are also working with our European partners to ensure they are taking concrete steps to address their own economic challenges. The details are still being worked out, but I can assure you that we are approaching this with a laser focus on protecting American taxpayers and promoting long-term economic growth.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what's your understanding of how long Israel will suspend this West Bank annexation plan? [SEP] What do you think? Tell me. Well, we have—we're putting all our eggs into the basket of peace. We have an agreement with the Emirates. We're going to nail down all the details—Embassies, overflights, commercial—and then we're going to extrapolate that to the rest of the region. How long that takes, I can't tell you. But that's—we've prioritized peace over the sovereignty movement, but it's not off the table. It's just something that will be deferred until the—we give peace every single chance.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Does that include Syria, Mr. President? [SEP] Elaine, with all due respect, I'm not going to be drawn into commenting on specific operations. I'm well aware of what you're trying to get me to say, and I'm not going to take the bait. Elaine.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, your proposed budget hinges on increased tax revenue from multinational corporations outsourcing jobs and from the oil and gas sector, a policy you've championed for years. Given your inability to enact this through a Democratic-controlled Congress, what leads you to believe you can succeed now? Furthermore, does this not undermine your efforts towards deficit-neutral corporate tax reform? [SEP] My conviction remains unchanged. Therefore, we shall persist in our efforts. The distinguishing factor lies in the widespread acknowledgment of the imperative to address the deficit. A genuine commitment to deficit reduction necessitates a comprehensive examination of unwarranted expenditures within the Tax Code, specifically tax incentives that fail to enhance our competitiveness or generate employment opportunities domestically. The examples you cited are, in the estimation of most economists, detrimental to our long-term economic growth. If such incentives are indeed counterproductive, why should we permit certain entities to remit lower taxes than those who are actively creating jobs and investing within the United States? Why should our investments be confined to antiquated energy sources, rather than those that hold promise for the future, particularly when the former are demonstrably profitable and do not require preferential tax treatment? A sincere commitment to deficit and debt reduction mandates a holistic approach, encompassing all contributing factors. Selective measures are insufficient. This principle extends to the Democratic Party as well. Certain provisions within this budget are personally challenging for me to accept. Cities and states across the nation are grappling with budgetary constraints due to diminished revenue streams. They face escalating demands as a consequence of job losses and the persistent challenges within the housing market. Yet, this budget proposes a 10 percent reduction in community development block grants. While I find this undesirable, I am nonetheless acquiescing to it. A spirit of compromise is incumbent upon all parties. Corporate tax reform, by its very nature, seeks to simplify the tax code, eliminate loopholes, and ensure equitable treatment for all. This objective is entirely consistent with the principle that the oil industry, given its substantial profitability and capacity for self-funded investment, should not receive preferential tax treatment.
label: Implicit

sentence: In light of the escalating oil prices, is it time to rethink the strategy of replenishing the Strategic Petroleum Reserve? [SEP] I've examined the matter, and I don't anticipate it would have a material effect on prices. Our current procurement amounts to roughly 67,000 to 68,000 barrels daily, which constitutes merely one-tenth of one percent of the 85 million barrels daily global demand. It's imperative for our national security to maintain a fully stocked SPR in the event of a significant disruption. Extremist groups, such as Al Qaeda, might target oil facilities. An attack in a major oil-exporting nation would negatively impact our economy and those who oppose such groups. The SPR is vital to mitigate such risks. Were I to believe it would positively influence prices, I would seriously consider it. However, given that our purchases represent only one-tenth of one percent of global demand, the cost-benefit analysis does not support such a decision. It would render us vulnerable in the event of a national security crisis.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. And two questions. There are concerns about how the immigration bill from the House , from the Gang of Eight—in the House, has complicated chances for immigration reform in the Senate. It seems to be a more conservative proposal. Is there room for a more conservative proposal than the one presented in the Senate? That's immigration.And second, on Mexico, yesterday the Mexican Government said all contact with the U.S. law enforcement will now go through a single door, the Federal Interior Ministry. Is this change good for the U.S. relationship with Mexico? Do you think the level of security and cooperation can be maintained? [SEP] On immigration reform, I've been impressed by the work that was done by the Gang of Eight in the Senate. The bill that they produced is not the bill that I would have written, there are elements of it that I would change, but I do think that it meets the basic criteria that I laid out from the start, which is: We've got to have more effective border security, although it should build on the great improvements that have been made on border security over the last 4 to 5 years. We should make sure that we are cracking down on employers that are gaming the system. We should make the legal immigration system work more effectively so that the waits are not as burdensome, the bureaucracy is not as complicated, so that we can continue to attract the best and the brightest from around the world to our shores in a legal fashion. And we want to make sure that we've got a pathway to citizenship that is tough, but allows people to earn over time their legal status here in this country.And the Senate bill meets thatthose criteria, in some cases not in the way that I would, but it meets those basic criteria. And I think it's a it's a testament to the Senators that were involved that they made some tough choices and made some tough compromises in order to hammer out that bill.Now, I haven't seen what Members of the House are yet proposing. And maybe they think that they can answer some of those questions differently or better. And I think we've got to be open minded in seeing what they come up with. The bottom line, though, is, is that they've still got to meet those basic criteria: Is it making the border safer? Is it dealing with employers in how they work with the governments to make sure that people are not being taken advantage of or taking advantage of the system? Are we improving our legal immigration system? And are we creating a pathway for citizenship for the 11 million or so who are undocumented in this country?And if they meet those criteria, but they're slightly different than the Senate bill, then I think that we should be able to come up with an appropriate compromise. If it doesn't meet those criteria, then I will not support such a bill. So we'll have to wait and see.When it comes to Mexico, I'm very much looking forward to taking the trip down to Mexico to see the new President, Peña Nieto. I had a chance to meet him here, but this will be the first, more extensive consultations, and it will be an opportunity for his Ministers, my Cabinet members who are participating, to really hammer out some of these issues.A lot of the focus is going to be on economics. We've spent so much time on security issues between the United States and Mexico that sometimes, I think we forget this is a massive trading partner responsible for huge amounts of commerce and huge numbers of jobs on both sides of the border. We want to see how we can deepen that, how we can improve that and maintain that economic dialogue over a long period of time.That doesn't mean that we're not going to be talking about security. I think that in my first conversation with the President, he indicated to me that he very much continues to be concerned about how we can work together to deal with transnational drug cartels. We've made great strides in the coordination and cooperation between our two Governments over the last several years. But my suspicion is, is that things can be improved.And some of the issues that he's talking about really had to do with refinements and improvements in terms of how Mexican authorities work with each other, how they coordinate more effectively, and it has less to do with how they're dealing with us, per se. So I'm not going to yet judge how this will alter the relationship between the United States and Mexico until I've heard directly from them to see what exactly are they trying to accomplish.But overall, what I can say is that my impression is, is that the new President is serious about reform. He's already made some tough decisions. I think he's going to make more that will improve the economy and security of Mexican citizens, and that will improve the bilateral relationship as well.And I don't want to leave out that we're also going to be talking to, during my visit to Costa Rica, Presidents of Central American countries, many of whom are struggling with both economic issues and security issues, but are important partners for us, because I think that the vision here is that we want to make sure that our hemisphere is more effectively integrated to improve the economy and security of all people. That's good for the United States. That will enhance our economy. That can improve our energy independence.There are a whole range of opportunities, and that's going to be the purpose of this trip. And I'm sure that those of you who will have the chance to travel with me, we'll have a chance to discuss this further.All right? Thank you very much, everybody. Thank you, guys.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, the Mayor's order is causing quite a stir. Are you going to encourage federal properties to follow it? [SEP] We're going to take a look at it and see what we can do.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Nigeria's request for Tucano aircraft to address their security challenges, could we expect at least a couple of those planes to be delivered before 2020? Also, any chance we'll see you visiting Nigeria anytime soon? [SEP] Nigeria, a beautiful country, I've heard. I'd love to go. As for the first part of your question, I didn't quite catch it. Could you repeat it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Are you going to launch an effort to try to delay the election? Or was that just a trial balloon this morning? The President. Well, what I want to explain to people, but it doesn't need much explanation—I mean, you look at article after article: New York's Mail-Vote Disaster, Tens of thousands of mail ballots have been tossed out in this year's primaries. What will happen in November? It's a mess. This is done by Washington Post. Can you believe it? The Washington Post, of all papers. Fake news, but in this case, it's not fake, it's true.This is done by the Wall Street Journal. Here's another one, Vote-by-mail experiment reveals potential problems within postal voting system ahead in the November election. And you see what's happening with so many different places. They're doing even trial runs; they're a disaster.And I don't want to see an election—you know, so many years, I've been watching elections. And they say the projected winner or the winner of the election—I don't want to see that take place in a week after November 3 or a month or, frankly, with litigation and everything else that can happen, years. Years. Or you never even know who won the election.You're sending out hundreds of millions of universal, mail-in ballots—hundreds of millions. Where are they going? Who are they being sent to? It's common sense; you don't have to know anything about politics. And the Democrats know this. The Democrats know this, Steve.So I want to see—I want an election and a result much, much more than you. I think we're doing very well. We have the same fake polls, but we have real polls. We're doing very well.I just left Texas. And Biden came out against fracking. Well, that means Texas is going to be one of the most unemployed States in our country. That means Oklahoma, North Dakota, New Mexico are going to be a disaster. Ohio, Pennsylvania—disaster. No fracking.I want to have the result of the election. I don't want to be waiting around for weeks and months. And literally, potentially—if you really did it right—years, because you'll never know.These ballots are missing. You saw Paterson, New Jersey. You saw many other instances. There's tremendous litigation on that right now.And that doesn't include absentee. Absentee is different. Absentee, you have to work and you have to send in for applications. You have to go through a whole procedure. Like, for instance, I'm an absentee voter because I can't be in Florida because I'm in Washington; I'm at the White House. So I'll be an absentee voter. We have a lot of absentee voters, and it works. So we're in favor of absentee, but it's much different than millions of people.In California, they're going to send out tens of millions of voting forms. Well, where are they going to go? You read where postmen are in big trouble now. You read where city councils are in big trouble now. Voter fraud, all over the ballots.So no, I want to get—I want to be standing, hopefully, hand held high, big victory, because we're doing things with our country that I think nobody else could have done. Our country is—despite this pandemic, which is devastating the rest of the world, by the way—devastating.One of the articles that came out was, The World's COVID Resurgence. This is the Wall Street Journal editorial, the main editorial yesterday in the Wall Street Journal. I don't always agree with them. But they have The World's COVID Resurgence. Countries hailed as models to see—and then they go, the virus returns at a level it's never—they haven't even seen.We've been giving praise to certain countries, and the virus has now come to them like the first time. But it's a very interesting—and it talks about many countries where everybody was holding them up and saying what a great job they did. Well, it's just one of those things. Didn't work out so well. So we want to have an election. I'd love to see voter ID, but this is the opposite of voter ID. The Democrats love it; the Republicans hate it. We all agree that absentee voting is good. Mail-in ballots will lead to the greatest fraud.You know, we talk about Russia, Russia, Russia for 2½ years, and then they found nothing, and there was nothing. But they talk Russia, Russia, Russia. They talk China. They talk all of these countries. They say they get involved in our elections. This is easy. You can forge ballots. This is much easier for foreign countries.Go ahead, Steve. Q. But delaying the election is probably a nonstarter. I mean, wouldn't you agree with that? [SEP] I just feel—I don't want a delay. I want to have the election. But I also don't want to have to wait for 3 months and then find out that the ballots are all missing and the election doesn't mean anything. That's what's going to happen, Steve. That's common sense, and everyone knows it. Smart people know it. Stupid people may not know it. And some people don't want to talk about it, but they know it.And no, we want to have an election where people actually go in and—What's your name? My name is so-and-so. Boom, you sign the book, like I've been doing for years.It's very, very unfair to our country. If they do this, our country will be a laughingstock all over the world, because everyone knows it doesn't work.How many ballots is he sending in California, as an example? Twenty-eight million or some massive number? Other States are sending out millions and millions of ballots. Well, they've done it. They had experiments. They had news organizations experimenting.And look, read the story in the Washington Post about mail-in voting; it's a disaster. I'm very surprised to see that story, frankly, from them. The story is a disaster. So we're asking for a lot of trouble.And no, do I want to see a date change? No. But I don't want to see a crooked election. This election will be the most rigged election in history if that happens.John [John Roberts, Fox News].
label: Explicit

sentence: So, are you deploying 15,000 troops to the border, yes or no? [SEP] You're clearly well-informed. You have access to the same information I do. You know exactly what the plan is. Next question, please.
label: Implicit

sentence: One more question, if I may? [SEP] That depends. What is it? []
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, to be perfectly clear, is the ultimate aim of your administration to completely dismantle ISIS or simply to contain their spread and diminish their territorial control? [SEP] Our objective is to make sure that ISIL is not an ongoing threat to the region. We can accomplish that. It's going to take some time, and it's going to take some effort. As we've seen with Al Qaida, there are always going to be remnants that can cause havoc of any of these networks, in part because of the nature of terrorist activities. You get a few individuals, and they may be able to carry out a terrorist act. But what we can do is to make sure that the kind of systemic and broad-based aggression that we've seen out of ISIL that terrorizes primarily Muslims—Shia, Sunni—terrorizes Kurds, terrorizes not just Iraqis, but people throughout the region, that that is degraded to the point where it is no longer the kind of factor that we've seen it being over the last several months.
label: General

sentence: Q. You say it's not an abstract conversation. Do you have contingency plans? [SEP] I'm sorry. As I said, we are confident that this will be over--that this will be upheld. I'm confident that this will be upheld because it should be upheld. And again, that's not just my opinion, that's the opinion of a whole lot of constitutional law professors and academics and judges and lawyers who have examined this law, even if they're not particularly sympathetic to this particular piece of legislation or my Presidency. Your question was a little local for me, and so I'm glad that the President of the United States answered it. But I would take advantage of this moment to say that after increasing the budget line for the folk insurance six-fold and after having built more than 1,000 new clinics in the country, we're getting close to reaching universal coverage of health care: full, free health care coverage for all people up to 18 years of age, including cancer coverage. Of the 120--112 million Mexicans, 106 million will have efficient, effective universal health care coverage.So I would say that I would hope that one of the greatest economies in the world, such as the United States, could follow our example in achieving this, because it was a great thing. Well, I don't think you really expect me to intervene in the U.S. Presidential election. Let me just say this. For Canada--and this is something that I think transcends governments in Canada or administrations here in the United States--for Canada, the United States is and always will be our closest neighbor, our greatest ally, and our best friend. And I believe that American leadership is at all times great and indispensable for the world.And I think over the past few years we've done great things together in terms of the response both through the G-20 and bilaterally on the recession and the recovery. We had, under your leadership, Barack, that successful intervention in Libya. Our trade relationship is the biggest in the world and growing. And so I think it's been a tremendous partnership. Somebody from the Mexican press corps.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, at your previous press briefing, you indicated a willingness to explore non-legislative avenues for safeguarding voting rights. With legislative efforts now seemingly stalled, can you elaborate on the specific executive actions or alternative strategies your administration intends to pursue to protect the franchise? [SEP] Well, as you know, protecting the right to vote is a fundamental pillar of our democracy, and we're committed to using every tool at our disposal to ensure that every eligible American can exercise that right. While I'm not prepared to lay out the specifics of our strategy at this time, I can assure you that we're exploring all available options, including executive actions, partnerships with state and local officials, and public awareness campaigns. We're also working closely with civil rights organizations and community leaders to identify and address any barriers to voting. This is a fight we're not going to back down from, and we'll continue to work tirelessly to protect the right to vote for all Americans.
label: General

sentence: Thank you. I'd like to ask about the border, but first, a quick follow-up on busing. Do you see it as a practical way to integrate schools? And does that relate to the policy you're planning to announce? [SEP] Well, it's been used for a long time. There aren't many ways to get people to schools. So, it's been done. Sometimes it's been done forcefully. But it's been a primary method. If Vice President Biden had answered differently, the result would've been different. They hit him hard on that one.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the situation in Venezuela, despite the imposition of stringent sanctions and the provision of aid, it appears that Maduro's departure is not imminent. Are you concerned about a potential loss of momentum, and what is the projected timeline for resolution? [SEP] Well, there's no specific timeline being given to me. This situation has been ongoing for quite some time, with Maduro and his predecessor. Eventually, I believe things will change. But let's be clear, we haven't yet implemented the most severe sanctions. We have that option available, and all options remain on the table. We've taken a moderate approach thus far, but we can escalate significantly if necessary. The situation is truly disheartening. Venezuela, once one of the wealthiest nations, is now plagued by starvation and poverty. The lack of basic necessities is a disgrace. We're simply trying to alleviate the suffering of the Venezuelan people. It's a very sad situation, Roberta, very sad indeed.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. And concerning the outstanding balance, sir? [SEP] Come again?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that this 'enduring presence' is simply a rebranding of the existing rotational system, designed to appease Poland without committing significant new resources. How do you respond to those criticisms, and what concrete metrics will be used to measure the success of this initiative? [SEP] Those critics, they're always criticizing, they're always saying negative things. They don't understand, they just don't understand. This isn't just a rebranding, this is a real commitment, a strong commitment. We're talking about a long-term presence, a presence that sends a message to everyone, especially those who might be thinking about causing trouble. As for metrics, we'll be looking at everything, readiness, response times, cooperation with Polish forces. We'll be monitoring it very closely, very, very closely. But the most important metric is security, the security of Poland, the security of Europe. And we're going to make sure that security is rock solid, the best security in the world. Believe me.
label: General

sentence: Q. Just to clarify, the Federal contracting seems like an area that you've liked to—it's worked well for you on issues like promoting gay rights or contraception policy. Is it fair to assume that that would—attaching this to Federal contractors would be the first thing you would think of? [SEP] Margaret, I'm not going to announce specifics in dribs and drabs. When we've done a thorough evaluation and we understand what our authorities are, I'll let you know.Chris Jansing, NBC News.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, and representing the New York Times, may I proceed with a question ahead of the next journalist in line? [SEP] Representing where?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, despite seven investigations, the Pentagon hasn't resolved the friendly fire incident. Can you tell us when you personally learned it wasn't enemy fire? [SEP] I can't pinpoint the exact moment. But as soon as I realized the initial information was incorrect, I demanded a thorough investigation to uncover the truth.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, if this experimental drug proves effective against the virus, would you push for its expedited approval? [SEP] Let's not get ahead of ourselves. I need to see the data first. It's too early to make any promises. We're looking at all options, but I need more information.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, even accounting for regional variations, the national death rate remains concerning. Are you suggesting that the Johns Hopkins data is inaccurate, or are there other factors contributing to this high mortality rate? [SEP] Look, New York skewed everything. It was a tough situation, very crowded. We're doing a tremendous job, the best job, really. I'll get back to you with the exact figures, but trust me, we're at the bottom of the list, or close to it. We have different lists, you know.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Some say that Democrats who are facing tough races in November have asked you to delay action on immigration. How have the concerns of other Democrats influenced your thinking? And do you see any downside at this point to delaying until after the election? [SEP] I have to tell you that this week I've been pretty busy, focused on Ukraine and focused on ISIL and focused on making sure that NATO is boosting its commitments and following through on what's necessary to meet 21st-century challenges.Jeh Johnson and Eric Holder have begun to provide me some of their proposals and recommendations. I'll be reviewing them. And my expectation is that fairly soon, I'll be considering what the next steps are.What I'm unequivocal about is that we need immigration reform, that my overriding preference is to see Congress act. We had bipartisan action in the Senate. The House Republicans have sat on it for over a year. That has damaged the economy, it has held America back. It is a mistake. And in the absence of congressional action, I intend to take action to make sure that we're putting more resources on the border, that we're upgrading how we process these cases, and that we find a way to encourage legal immigration and give people some path so that they can start paying taxes and pay a fine and learn English and be able to not look over their shoulder, but be legal, since they've been living here for quite some time.So I suspect that on my flight back, this will be part of my reading, taking a look at some of the specifics that we've looked at. And I'll be making an announcement soon.But I want to be very clear: My intention is, in the absence of action by Congress, I'm going to do what I can do within the legal constraints of my office, because it's the right thing to do for the country. All right?Thank you very much, people of Wales. I had a wonderful time.
label: Dodging

sentence: To be absolutely clear, Mr. President, what is the definitive timeline for this action? [SEP] I couldn't say for sure at this time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia's claim of evacuating Kherson, do you see this as a potential turning point in the conflict? And do you believe Ukraine now possesses sufficient leverage to initiate peace negotiations with Moscow? [SEP] Well, isn't it convenient they waited until after our elections to announce that? We knew for a while they were planning this. It's a clear sign of the Russian military's struggles, wouldn't you say? Now, whether that leads to anything... at the very least, it gives everyone time to reassess over the winter. We'll have to see if Ukraine is willing to compromise with Russia. I'm heading to the G-20. Putin probably won't be there, but other leaders will be in Indonesia. We'll see what the next steps might be.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given your frequent dialogues with President Xi, and acknowledging your past remarks about your close relationship, would you consider leveraging that rapport to encourage greater transparency from China regarding the WHO's investigation into the COVID-19 origins? [SEP] Look, I know the gentleman. We've done deals. But don't mistake that for some kind of personal bond. This is business, pure and simple.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, now that you've had a conversation with him, are you confident in his reliability? [SEP] This isn't about some touchy-feely notion of 'trust.' It's about aligning interests and verifying those alignments. When dealing with matters affecting the American people, I don't rely on blind faith. I look for concrete evidence of shared goals. As the saying goes, the proof is in the pudding. We'll know soon enough.
label: Deflection

sentence: But concerning the White House staff, Mr. President, there are whispers of departures, particularly General Kelly. Can you confirm or deny his potential exit? [SEP] Look, in any administration, people move on. It's a natural process. As for specific personnel matters, we'll address them as needed.
label: General

sentence: In the current international climate, what do you identify as the most critical threats to U.S. national security, and what specific measures are being prioritized to safeguard American interests? [SEP] The top priority is always protecting the American people from attack. That's job number one. North Korea's nuclear program is a serious concern. We need to ensure they're not violating their agreements. Iran is another challenge. We're working to contain their activities and prevent them from acquiring nuclear weapons.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Bush, concerning visa-free travel for Estonia, what is the timeline for your administration to propose legislative changes to Congress? What actions should Estonia undertake to accelerate the resolution of this matter? [SEP] The key is addressing the 3% defense spending target while assuring Congress that visa waiver adjustments won't jeopardize our security. This process is starting imminently. Estonia has been persistent in raising this issue. We've come a long way since discussions began. Once security requirements are clarified, we'll implement them in our passports. It's a technical issue, but resolvable.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, what are your thoughts on David Cameron? [SEP] I've never had the pleasure of meeting him. Look, it's not my place to offer advice to the leader of the Conservative Party, or any political party for that matter. That's their business. But I will say this: let's put aside these individual leaders for a moment and focus on the relationship between our two countries. Even if people disagree with the Iraq war, they should understand that we're engaged in a global battle for values. You don't win that battle by being a fair-weather friend. You don't win by hesitating or withdrawing support when the going gets tough. You don't win by losing your nerve when your enemy is resolute. Our two countries share fundamental values, and that's what matters. The fact that we can both stand here and face tough questions from the press is a testament to that. It's about democracy, freedom of expression, and holding politicians accountable. Sure, it's easy to attack America and get a cheap round of applause in Europe. But when the smoke clears, what remains is our commitment to those values. We can debate the past, but our enemy is watching. They're asking if we're standing firm, or if we'll back down when things get difficult. That's a test of leadership. And it's not just for me and him; it's for everyone in politics. People may criticize politics, but when it's done right, it's about public service. We made a difficult decision, and I still believe it was the right one. History will judge us. But what we represent here today is a better way of life than brutal dictatorship or religious extremism. It's a way of life that people choose when given the chance. And our two nations should be proud to offer that choice to the world. The world needs courage, and this man is a courageous man. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, a quick follow-up regarding Iran. If sanctions prove ineffective and their destabilizing activities persist, are you considering options beyond military intervention? [SEP] I'd rather not delve into specifics, but I remain confident in the efficacy of our sanctions. While military action is always a possibility, it represents a drastic measure. But let me be clear: we would prevail. No nation can match our military might. The investments we've made in our armed forces over the past three years are unparalleled. And it's all Made in the U.S.A., by the way. Our nuclear arsenal, which had been neglected, is now in peak condition. We should pray we never have to use it. Our military is in phenomenal shape. We have a great new Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff coming in, General Milley, who will be fantastic. Our Secretary of Defense, Mark Esper, is doing a tremendous job. He's got the energy, the knowledge, and the experience. And, of course, Secretary Mnuchin is here. We implemented the strongest sanctions ever imposed on a country today. We would never do that to Australia, I assure you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. What's your definition of the word torture? [SEP] Of what?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, if I may, to ensure absolute clarity, are you affirming that the U.S. military would actively defend the Senkaku Islands should China initiate military action? Moreover, considering the precedent set in Syria, where inaction on 'red lines' eroded U.S. credibility, how can you assure the world that this commitment is genuine? Lastly, with respect to North Korea, is your statement intended as an explicit warning against future nuclear tests? And Prime Minister Abe, considering the events in Ukraine, do you remain confident in President Obama's security guarantees? Thank you. [SEP] Essentially, you're asking if our commitment to Japan is unwavering, if we've addressed the credibility concerns raised by the Syria situation, and if we're directly warning North Korea. Is that correct?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, given your administration's history with international resolutions, why not demand Israel respect UN resolutions concerning Palestine? And President Abbas, did you request a settlement freeze from President Bush to enable fruitful talks? [SEP] I missed a bit there. What was that you said about the UN?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you commit to supporting the House Democrats' proposal for another round of direct stimulus checks? [SEP] We're in discussions, okay? A lot of people are involved. I want a payroll tax cut. I want a lot of things. The workers need to be taken care of, and I'm all about that. But we're talking to the Democrats. We'll see. It's a transition, a transition to something *special*. Mark my words. Next year? Greatness. Absolutely fantastic. The third quarter is just a warm-up. Fourth quarter? Tremendous numbers. Then, next year, numbers like we've never seen before, maybe even *better*. Pent-up demand, you know? People ready to go, ready to spend, held back by the virus. Phenomenal year, unless someone, and I won't name names, messes it up with taxes. Doubling, tripling, quadrupling them. You know who I'm talking about. We had the greatest economy ever. *Ever*. This administration built it. We'll do it again, quick and easy.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, beyond Huawei, are there specific criteria or concerns that will guide your administration's decisions regarding other Chinese tech companies operating in the U.S.? [SEP] It's all about national security, plain and simple. We have to protect ourselves. If a company poses a threat, we're going to take action. We're looking at everything, and we're not going to let anyone take advantage of us. We're putting America first.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the political landscape is shifting rapidly. Given the potential challenges posed by both Governor DeSantis and former President Trump, are you reevaluating your campaign strategy or considering any adjustments to your platform? [SEP] We're always adapting and refining our approach to meet the needs of the moment. But our core principles remain the same: fighting for working families, protecting our democracy, and building a better future for all Americans. [Next question.]
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Sir, what does the new normal look like? [SEP] Okay. Whoa, whoa, whoa. Hang on, guys. We've only gone an hour and 20 minutes. I'll keep going.But I'm—but I'm going to go—let me get—let get something straight here: How long are you guys ready to go? You want to go for another hour or two?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. With the drug showing potential, will you advocate for a streamlined approval process in the United States? [SEP] That's a question best directed to the FDA. I'm not in a position to comment on regulatory matters without a thorough briefing. I simply don't have enough information at hand.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, in the event that North Korea fails to meet its commitments, what military consequences are anticipated? Is military action a viable option? [SEP] I prefer not to speculate, as I don't wish to appear menacing. They are aware of the situation. The potential ramifications were clear. Consider Seoul, a metropolis of 28 million inhabitants, situated adjacent to the border. While New York, with its 8 million, is considered substantial, Seoul is on an entirely different level. Had events unfolded negatively, the potential loss of life could have reached 20 to 30 million. I am privileged to be involved in this matter, as the potential loss of life could have been in the range of 30 to 50 million. The city of Seoul, one of the most populous globally, is located in close proximity to the border.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. So news today of a plane—a Russian plane—shot down over Syria. Russia is assigning the blame to Israel, even though it was accidentally shot down by Syrian forces.Clearly, things are heating up. There's concerns by many Americans—most Americans—that we might be involved in a war in Syria soon. You had hoped to bring troops home, but clearly, things are changing. What do you tell American people today about a possibility of war in Syria? [SEP] Well, I just heard about the incident you have mentioned, Emerald, and it sounds to me and it seems to me, just like based on a review of the facts, that Syria shot down a Russian plane. And I understand about 14 people were killed, at least. And that's a very sad thing. But that's what happens. But Syria—according to early reports; that's subject to change—but that Syria shot down a Russian plane. So that's not a good situation.We have done a tremendous job in Syria and in that region eradicating ISIS, which is why we're there. And we're very close to being finished with that job, and then we're going to make a determination as to what we're going to do. But we have eradicated ISIS in a very large area of the Middle East. These are people that will not be coming here, because they're not around any longer. So we've done in a very short period of time.Our Vice President is here, Mike Pence. Our great Secretary of State—really, thank you very much for the great job you're doing—Mike Pompeo. And we've been working very hard on this. And they've done an incredible job over there, but we'll make a decision fairly quickly.Thank you very much. Would you have a question for the President?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Is he in jeopardy? [SEP] I think he's doing an excellent job, but we will take a look at that in a very strong—and we'll probably have an idea about that in about a week.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, Biden and Harris just held their first rally. Did you see it, and what are your thoughts? [SEP] I saw enough. He chose her, and it's a very strange choice. She was a disaster in the primaries, attacking Biden left and right. Now she's his running mate? Unbelievable. She wants to raise taxes, kill fracking – try selling that in Pennsylvania! And she's weak on crime. The police are with me, not them. We rebuilt the military, the best ever. She wants to cut military spending. I was surprised by the pick. She went down in flames. I went up. She was far nastier to Biden than I ever was. It's a ridiculous situation.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you. After the midterm elections you said that you were open to compromise on the Bush tax cuts. I'm wondering if you're prepared today to say that you're willing to accept a temporary extension for the wealthiest Americans? And then on an unrelated question, do you feel that the election has weakened you on the global stage? [SEP] The answer to the second question is no. I think what we've seen over the last several days as we've traveled through Asia is that people are eager to work with America, eager to engage with America on economic issues, on security issues, on a whole range of mutual interests. And that's especially true in Asia, where we see such enormous potential. This is the fastest growing part of the world. And we've got to be here, and we've got to work. And I'm absolutely confident that my administration, over the next 2 years, is going to continue to make progress in ensuring that the United States has a presence here not just for the next couple of years, but for decades to come.With respect to the Bush tax cuts, what I've said is that I'm going to meet with the--both the Republican and Democratic leaders late next week, and we're going to sit down and discuss how we move forward. My number-one priority is making sure that we make the middle class tax cuts permanent, that we give certainty to the 98 percent of Americans who are affected by those tax breaks. I don't want to see their income taxes spike up, not only because they need relief after having gone through a horrendous recession, but also because it would be bad for the economy.I continue to believe that extending permanently the upper income tax cuts would be a mistake and that we can't afford it. And my hope is, is that somewhere in between there we can find some sort of solution. But I'm not going to negotiate here in Seoul. My job is to negotiate back in Washington with Republican and Democratic leaders.Ben Feller of AP [Associated Press].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You've made very clear that you're not buying Prime Minister Netanyahu's attempts to walk back the comments that he made before the election, opposing Palestinian statehood and that you're reassessing your approach. What could Prime Minister Netanyahu do, if anything, in the short term to persuade you that he's serious about Israeli-Palestinian peace and that he's an honest broker that you could work with? Or is it too late to repair that relationship during your Presidency? And is there any truth to allegations that Israel was spying on the Iran talks? And, President Ghani, if I may, you've been working very hard to pursue reconciliation talks with the Taliban, but there's some indications that that's not going so well and that they may not be willing to sit down with you. What makes you hopeful that you can get those talks off the ground? And do you want the U.S. to be involved in those talks? [SEP] Let me, first of all, address your second question about spying allegations. As a general rule, I don't comment on intelligence matters in a big room full of reporters. [] And I think I'll continue that tradition.But with respect to the possibility of an agreement that ensures that Iran doesn't get a nuclear weapon, we have not just briefed Congress about the progress or lack thereof that's being made, but we also brief the Israelis and our other partners in the region and around the world. And if in fact an agreement is arrived at that we feel confident will prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon, it's going to be there for everybody to see. And people are going to be able to lift up the hood and see what's in there.So I have confidence that if there's an agreement, it's going to be a good agreement that's good for American security and Israeli security and the region's security. And if it isn't, then there probably won't be an agreement. So there will be, I think, significant transparency in the whole process.With respect to Israel's relations with the Palestinians, I think it's important to understand that the issue here is not what I believe, but it's what the Palestinians and the parties in the negotiations and the Israeli people believe is possible. That's the most important issue. I've said before, and I'll simply repeat: Prime Minister Netanyahu, in the election runup, stated that a Palestinian state would not occur while he was Prime Minister. And I took him at his word that that's what he meant, and I think that a lot of voters inside of Israel understood him to be saying that fairly unequivocally.Afterwards, he pointed out that he didn't say never, but that there would be a series of conditions in which a Palestinian state could potentially be created. But of course, the conditions were such that they would be impossible to meet anytime soon. So even if you accepted, I think, the corrective of Prime Minister Netanyahu's in subsequent days, there still does not appear to be a prospect of a meaningful framework established that would lead to a Palestinian state even if there were a whole range of conditions and security requirements that might be phased in over a long period of time, which it was always the presumption.I don't think anybody ever envisioned in any peace agreement, certainly not one that Prime Minister Netanyahu would agree to or that the Israeli people would agree to, that overnight you suddenly have a Palestinian state right next to Jerusalem and that Israel would not have a whole range of security conditions that had to be met, and that it would be phased in over a long period of time.So the issue has never been, do you create a Palestinian state overnight? The question is, do you create a process and a framework that gives the Palestinians hope, the possibility, that down the road, they have a secure state of their own, standing side by side with a secure, fully recognized Jewish State of Israel?And I think—it's not just my estimation—I think it's hard to envision how that happens based on the Prime Minister's statements. And so when I said that we have to now do an evaluation of where we are, it's not in reference to our commitment to Israel's military edge in the region, Israel's security, our intelligence cooperation, our military cooperation. That continues unabated. And I will continue to do whatever I need to do to make sure that our friends in Israel are safe. That's what I've done since I've been President, and that's not going to stop. And so the Israeli people need to know that.But I am required to evaluate honestly how we manage Israeli-Palestinian relations over the next several years. Because up until this point, the premise has been, both under Republican and Democratic administrations, that as difficult as it was, as challenging as it was, the possibility of two states living side by side in peace and security could marginalize more extreme elements, bring together folks at the center and with some common sense, and we could resolve what has been a vexing issue and one that is ultimately a threat to Israel as well.And that possibility seems very dim. That may trigger, then, reactions by the Palestinians that, in turn, elicit counterreactions by the Israelis. And that could end up leading to a downward spiral of relations that will be dangerous for everybody and bad for everybody.So bottom line, just to summarize here: Number one, our military and intelligence cooperation with Israel will continue unabated, unaffected, and we are absolutely committed to making sure that the Israeli people are safe, particularly from rocket attacks and terrorist attacks aimed on civilians.Number two, that the evaluation that's taking place is specific to what happens between Israelis and Palestinians going forward. We'll continue to engage the Israeli Government as well as the Palestinians and ask them where they are interested in going and how do they see this issue being resolved. But what we can't do is pretend that there's a possibility of something that's not there. And we can't continue to premise our public diplomacy based on something that everybody knows is not going to happen at least in the next several years. That is something that we have to, for our own—for the sake of our own credibility, I think we have to be able to be honest about that.And I guess one last point about this, because obviously, I've heard a lot of the commentary: There's a tendency, I think, in the reporting here to frame this somehow as a personal issue between myself and President—Prime Minister Netanyahu. And I understand why that's done, because when you frame it in those terms, the notion is, well, if we all just get along and everybody cools down, then somehow the problem goes away. I have a very businesslike relationship with the Prime Minister. I've met with him more than any other world leader. I talk to him all the time. He is representing his country's interests the way he thinks he needs to, and I'm doing the same.So the issue is not a matter of relations between leaders; the issue is a very clear, substantive challenge. We believe that two states is the best path forward for Israel's security, for Palestinian aspirations, and for regional stability. That's our view, and that continues to be our view. And Prime Minister Netanyahu has a different approach. And so this can't be reduced to a matter of somehow let's all hold hands and sing Kumbaya. [] This is a matter of figuring out, how do we get through a real knotty policy difference that has great consequences for both countries and for the region? Okay?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Do you want the American people to judge you on the ballot in November by how you've handled this pandemic so far? [SEP] This, among other things. I think the American people will judge us on this, but they'll judge us on the economy that I created and that already we're creating. We're setting record job numbers, as you know. I think we're going to have a very strong year next year. I think we're going to have a very strong third quarter, a very good fourth quarter. But I think next year is going to be a record year, and I think they're going to judge me on that.I think they're going to judge me on the tax cutting and the regulation cutting, which nobody has ever done to the extent that we've been able to do it.On rebuilding the military, on how we've handled the VA: On the VA, we got Veterans Choice. Nobody thought that would be possible. That's been many decades. They've been trying to get Veterans Choice. It's called Choice, where they can go get a doctor if they have to wait on line for 2 weeks or 5 weeks or 2 days. And frankly, that's been a great thing. And Veterans Accountability, I think they'll judge me on that. They'll judge me on all of the things we've done.I don't think—and I think we can say this with surety, and it's never ever been even challenged. In 3½ years, the first 3½ years—the first years of a Presidency—I don't think any administration, any President has accomplished so much as we've accomplished, from energy to health to so many other things.And then, this came in, and the plague—I call it the plague—the plague came in, a terrible thing. Should have been stopped. Wasn't stopped. It came in. We had to shut things down to save potentially millions of lives. We did that, and now we've started them up. And I think we've really started it up very successfully.Yes, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, how do you respond to reports suggesting that multiple deployments to Iraq are negatively impacting troop morale? [SEP] What I'm hearing from the commanders is that the concern is with the family members. Our troops, who have volunteered to serve this country, are willing to go into combat multiple times, but the concern is with the people on the home front. That's one reason I go out of my way to constantly thank the family members. I'm talking to our commanders. Their job is to tell me what the situation is on the ground. I know there's concern about the home front. I haven't heard deep concern about the morale of the troops in Iraq.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in light of your recent remarks labeling President Xi a dictator, have you jeopardized the progress made in stabilizing relations with China? And regarding India, what's your response to accusations that your administration is turning a blind eye to human rights violations? [SEP] The answer to your first point is: absolutely not. When we're engaging with our allies and partners across the globe, India included, I'm not going to start second-guessing myself or avoid speaking plainly about the facts regarding our relationship with China. I've been saying for a while now that the overreaction to the relationship with China is over the top. We had a bit of a situation that caused some, let's say, ruffled feathers, but Secretary Blinken had a very productive trip to China. I fully expect to be meeting with President Xi sometime soon, and I don't think my comment had any lasting impact. Now, what was that second question you asked?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You spoke for nearly 2 hours today with Iraq's Prime Minister. Do you both agree now on the need to send more U.S. troops to Iraq to deal with the rising violence in that country? [SEP] Well, Ben [Ben Feller, Associated Press], my thinking is taking shape. I'll be ready to outline a strategy that will help the is achieve the objective of a country that can govern, sustain, and defend itself sometime next week. I've still got consultations to go through. Whatever decision I make, though, will be all aimed at achieving our objective.I did have a good discussion with Prime Minister Maliki. It did nearly last for 2 hours. I talked about a lot of topics with him. One thing I was looking for was will— to determine whether or not he has the will necessary to do the hard work to protect his people. And I told him, I said that, You show the will, we will help you. And that's—I'm in the process of making up my final decision as to what to recommend—what recommendations to accept. One thing is for certain: I will want to make sure that the mission is clear and specific and can be accomplished.
label: General

sentence: Looking back at your decisions this year, especially concerning healthcare, what would you identify as your biggest error? [SEP] Specifically on healthcare, or more generally?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Iran, the IAEA indicates a marked escalation in uranium enrichment, and President Ahmadinejad pledges continuation. Considering this, along with the detention of Iranian-Americans, what is your assessment of the trajectory? Should we impose robust UN sanctions, and do you anticipate support from Russia and China? [SEP] As we often address in these forums, Iran persists as a recurring subject due to their disregard for global mandates concerning nuclear armament. The international community has voiced opposition to such endeavors, yet they consistently flout these directives. It is my conviction that we must fortify our sanctions regime. I have conferred with Condoleezza Rice, and we shall collaborate with our European counterparts to formulate additional sanctions. Furthermore, I shall deliberate upon this matter with Presidents Putin and Hu Jintao. It is imperative that these leaders comprehend the profoundly destabilizing impact of a nuclear-armed Iran. It is in their vested interest to collectively isolate this regime. I extend my empathy to the Iranian populace, burdened by a government that perpetuates a condemned program, thereby impeding economic prospects. Iran boasts a venerable heritage and industrious citizens who merit a more transparent society. The government's actions precipitate further isolation. Ergo, we shall collaborate with our allies to sustain pressure. Secondly, the apprehension of blameless Americans is indefensible, and we have unequivocally conveyed that such conduct is intolerable.
label: General

sentence: Q. Good morning. Your visit is coming to an end now—this is a question for President George Bush: At the end of your visit, sir, have you found allies in order to place a counterweight to the initiatives of Hugo Chavez? What commitments did Felipe Calderon take on in order to be a counterweight to these initiatives of Hugo Chavez, on the one hand?And on the other hand, President Felipe Calderon, Foreign Minister Patricia has said that you are working in order to strengthen the relationship with Venezuela. How is this compatible with the commitments that you're taking on with President Bush in order to give thrust to this counterweight in Latin America concerning Hugo Chavez? [SEP] Thank you for the question. We spent a lot of time talking about Mexico's role in the world. Mexico is a respected nation; President Calderon is a respected leader. But our conversations focused on democracy and rule of law and prosperity and how to improve the lives of our fellow citizens. We spent time talking about social justice and concern for the poor.One of the reasons I've come down here again is to remind people in this important part of the world that the United States cares deeply about the human condition; that we spent 1.6 billion of bilateral aid last year, most of the money going to social justice programs. And that doesn't include programs like the one I saw in the highlands of Guatemala, where our military was providing basic health care for citizens.So, Mr. President and I spent time talking about how to advance a hopeful agenda, one that will lift the spirits of people. And I respect the role Mexico plays. I mean, Mexico will lead diplomatic efforts for the common security and common prosperity, and that's an important role. The commitment and purpose of my Government is to have constructive, positive, and sound relations with all countries of the world and, of course, with the countries of Latin America, without exception. And certainly the more—the most important relationship with Mexico abroad is the one that we have with the United States, due to the migration that exists, the flows through the borders, and all else that you are well aware of.However, Mexico is respectful of the opinions of other leaders. We are respectful of the heads of states of other countries, such as Venezuela and certainly the United States. We are a government that has principles and values, values such as democracy, freedom, liberty, and legality and certainly security and safety.On the other hand, not as a strategy— this was not something that we focused on as a strategy in our talks, but as a conviction of our government. Mexico has to play a role which is balanced, weighed, and it has to be a leader in Latin America, in agreement with its culture, its history, its economy, its people.We are deeply Latin American, and we, too, want justice, development, democracy for all of Latin America. That is where we are engaged, and we are committed. We certainly do agree and coincide with other countries, many countries, of course, who coincide and agree with those principles.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. And under what circumstances would one-on-one conversations take place? [SEP] I won't talk about the details of negotiations. But I think it's fair to say that we want to get this resolved and we're not going to be constrained by diplomatic niceties or protocols. If Iran is serious about wanting to resolve this, they'll be in a position to resolve it.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. When these allegations were raised, why didn't this White House do the same thing? And with all of the allegations that are coming out now about Judge Kavanaugh, was there an opportunity missed here to have investigators look into this and get some sort of clarity one way or the other? [SEP] Well, the FBI told us they've investigated Judge Kavanaugh six times, five times, many times over the years. They know him very well. But here, there was nothing to investigate from at least one standpoint. They didn't know the location. They didn't know the time. They didn't know the year. They didn't know anything. And it's like, where do you go?Also, it's not for the FBI. If you look at what Joe Biden said, he said, They don't do this. And he said it very clearly. So I think when you really look at it all, it's not going to change any of the Democrats' minds. They're obstructionists. They're actually con artists, because they know how quality this man is, and they've destroyed a man's reputation and they want to destroy it even more.And I think people are going to see that in the midterms. What they've done to this family, what they've done to these children—these beautiful children of his—and what they've done to his wife. And they know it's a big, fat con job. And they go into a room, and I guarantee you, they laugh like hell at what they've pulled off on you and on the public. They laugh like hell.So, it wouldn't have mattered if the FBI came back with the cleanest score. And you understand that very well, John. If they would have come back with the most perfect—We found everything, and he's perfectly innocent of everything. It wouldn't have made a difference. You wouldn't have gotten one vote.Now we will get votes from the Democrats if we win. You'll have three, four, or five Democrats giving us votes, because they're in States that I won by 30 and 40 points, and they're going to give us votes. But other than that, you probably won't get any, John.Yes, go ahead. Please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, following the midterms, what's the status of your confidence in the current leadership at the Justice Department? Are Attorney General X and Deputy Attorney General Y secure in their positions? [SEP] Well, let's just say we're constantly evaluating personnel across the board. The Cabinet is always under review. I'm generally pleased, but changes are common after elections. I didn't want to disrupt things beforehand. But I will say, broadly speaking, I'm happy. Pompeo's been a real star.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Yes, Mr. President. I would like to ask a question about the election, but one thing on unemployment first. Are you considering taking executive action to extend or, rather, reinstate the unemployment benefits that expired last week, if Congress can't get a deal by the end of the week? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Obama, concerning human rights, drug trafficking, the Merida Initiative, threats to President Calderon, and visa issues in Mexico, what are your thoughts? [SEP] I didn't quite catch all of that. It sounded important, though. Could you repeat the core question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, relying on selective state-level data seems to downplay the severity of the national situation. Can you provide a comprehensive explanation for why the US death rate is so high compared to other developed nations? [SEP] It's fake news, mostly. The numbers are manipulated. We're doing great, the best. I'll have my people look into it and get back to you with the real numbers. But believe me, we're at the bottom, or close to it. Now, about the economy...
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, while you emphasize the need for Democrats to connect with working-class communities, some argue that the party's focus on social issues has alienated potential voters. How do you propose to bridge this divide and ensure that the Democratic Party remains relevant to all segments of American society? [SEP] Look, I think it's important for Democrats to be present in every community, regardless of how red or blue it is. We need to be talking to people about the issues that matter most to them: jobs, healthcare, education. We need to show them that we're on their side, that we understand their struggles. It's not enough to just talk about policy; we need to connect with people on a personal level. That's how I won elections, and that's how Democrats can win again.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what exactly did you want the Ukrainians to investigate concerning the Bidens? [SEP] The Bidens are crooked as can be. His son is a total failure who somehow made millions. It's a scam, plain and simple. What's your next question?
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, could you walk us through your reasoning behind the recent commutations, especially considering that many involved firearm-related offenses, given your well-known views on gun safety? [SEP] Sure, I can try...
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Regarding potential one-on-one discussions, can you shed any light on the circumstances under which they might occur? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to divulge specifics regarding ongoing diplomatic efforts. Suffice it to say, we are committed to achieving a resolution and won't be hampered by formalities. If Iran is genuinely interested in a solution, they will demonstrate a willingness to engage constructively.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: On the topic of debt talks, sir, would you entertain tax breaks to stimulate the economy, even if it increases the deficit? And, circling back to same-sex marriage, with states like New York embracing it, has your personal view shifted to supporting it, regardless of state laws? [SEP] That's not something I'm prepared to discuss today. Nice try, though.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, why are you refusing to release the photos of the alleged abuse by the guards? [SEP] That's a separate issue entirely. What's truly important is that the people of Iran know we are paying attention and that they aren't alone. The most significant factor, however, is what transpires within Iran itself. We've all been moved by the bravery of the Iranian people. As Dr. King famously said, 'The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice.' We must maintain faith that ultimately, justice will prevail.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Germany and their energy needs, what concrete steps are being implemented to reduce their reliance on Russian energy? Furthermore, what's your response to critics arguing that Germany's reliance on Russian gas is limiting Europe's options in responding to the Ukraine situation? [SEP] Well, we're actively investigating opportunities to offset any potential gas losses from Russia, primarily through LNG. We're engaged in discussions with our global partners to determine how we can collectively tackle this challenge. We anticipate being able to compensate for a substantial portion of any shortfalls. The critical point that everyone seems to overlook is that Russia also depends on selling its gas and oil. It's a significant component of their budget. If that revenue is curtailed, they'll experience significant repercussions. This isn't a one-way street. We're working diligently to assist Europe in mitigating any immediate gas supply disruptions should they occur. We're collaborating closely with our European allies, including Germany, to ensure a coordinated strategy. We are prepared for all kinds of situation. And that's part of what we do when we say we prepare sanctions. That means we need to be able to react at any time, and this is happening. With regard to the use of LNG, I can say that the biggest volume of LNG used across the world is the gas, and that is part of the debate.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, beyond expressing disapproval, what specific steps is your administration taking to prevent future unauthorized diplomatic engagements by members of Congress, and what legal or constitutional basis supports such actions? [SEP] We're making our position clear, communicating directly with members of Congress. We're reminding them of the importance of a unified foreign policy, of speaking with one voice. The Constitution gives the President the authority to conduct foreign policy, and we're exercising that authority to protect American interests and promote stability in the region.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, considering the congressional gridlock on the TPP, are you considering alternative strategies to secure its approval, and what specific steps are you taking to address concerns about currency manipulation? [SEP] Angel, every trade deal is painful. Folks are always seeing if they can get an even better deal. Especially when you have multiple parties involved, folks are going to be scrutinizing it, they're going to be debating it, and in an election year, you can anticipate that some folks are going to try to score political points off it. Having said that, I remain confident we're going to get it done. And the reason I'm confident is because it's the right thing to do. It's good for the country. It's good for America. It's good for the region. It's good for the world.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, many Americans feel that your behavior is unbecoming of the office. What message do you have for those who believe you are not setting a positive example for the country? [SEP] I'm doing what's best for the country. I'm fighting for the American people. If they don't like it, that's their problem. But I'm not going to apologize for standing up for what I believe in. It's a political activity. There are exceptions for political activity.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. There are claims circulating on social media that Kamala Harris is not eligible to be—to run for Vice President because she was an anchor baby, I quote. Do you or can you definitively say whether or not Kamala Harris is eligible—legal—and meets the legal requirements to run as Vice President? [SEP] So I just heard that. I heard it today that she doesn't meet the requirements. And by the way, the lawyer that wrote that piece is a very highly qualified, very talented lawyer. I have no idea if that's right. I would have—I would have assumed the Democrats would have checked that out before she gets chosen to run for Vice President.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Knowing how many soldiers have died and how much money has been spent since then, why shouldn't people conclude that you are stubborn, in denial, and unrealistic about your strategy? [SEP] It's interesting; Mike Hayden, who I think you're quoting, was in this morning to give me his weekly briefing, and I asked him about that newspaper article. His comments to the Iraq Study Group were a little more nuanced than the quotation you read. He said that he made it clear the current strategy in Iraq wasn't working and that we needed a change of direction. He also said that those who suggest that we back away and let the Iraqi's Government do it don't understand the inability of the Iraq Government at that time to take on that responsibility. He then went on to say that our strategy needed to help get the violence down so that there could be political reconciliation from the top down as well as the bottom up.
