They had an agenda back in the administration when—the 8 years we were President and Vice President, but I don't know what their agenda is now. What is it?The American public is outraged about the tax structure we have in America. What are they proposing to do about it? Anything? Have you heard anything? I mean, anything. I haven't heard anything.The American public is outraged about the fact that we're the—the state of the environment—the vast majority of the public. What have they done to do anything to ameliorate the climate change that's occurring, other than to deny it exists?So what I'm saying is, the difference between then and now is not only the announcement that was made: Anything to stop Barack Obama. I get that part. But what eventually happened? We were able to get some things done. We were able to work through some things. On the stuff that was really consequential, in terms of ideologically divisive, it was a real fight.But so—but I don't think there's a time when I—I mean, I wonder what would be the Republican platform right now. What do you think? What do you think their position on taxes are? What do you think their position on human rights is? What do you think their position is on whether or not we should—on what we should do about the cost of prescription drugs? What do you think?I mean, I just—I, honest to God, don't know what they're for, yet I know a lot of these Senators and Congressmen, and I know they do have things they want to support, whether they're things I want or not. But you don't hear much about that.And every once in a while, when you hear something where there's a consensus—it's important, but a small item, and it doesn't get much coverage at all where it occurs. I'm not meaning coverage. I mean, there's not much discussion about it.So I just think it's a different—and I don't know that no matter how strongly one supports, as a Republican, and/or supports the President—the former President of the United States—I don't know how we can't look at what happened on January 6 and think: That's a problem. That's a real problem.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Obama, your administration's response to the 2008 financial crisis involved significant government intervention in the economy. Looking back, do you believe that intervention was the right approach, and what lessons did you learn from that experience about the role of government in regulating the financial sector? [SEP] The financial crisis was a devastating event, and we had to act quickly to prevent a complete collapse of the economy. Our intervention was necessary to stabilize the system and prevent a depression. But it also taught us that we need stronger regulations to prevent future crises. We need to hold Wall Street accountable and ensure that the financial system works for everyone, not just a few.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Is Congress giving you an ultimatum on the war this fall? [SEP] I appreciate the Members' visit to the White House. We had a productive discussion where I shared my perspectives on the Iraqi issue, emphasizing the potential consequences of failure and the benefits of success. They voiced their concerns about the Iraq war, which are shared by many. I reminded them that polls last fall indicated widespread disapproval of the situation in Iraq. I, too, would have expressed disapproval at that time. That's why I implemented a plan to improve the situation. I explained my decision-making process and emphasized that General Petraeus has a plan that some Members of Congress are hindering. It's illogical to unanimously confirm him and then deny him the resources needed to succeed. We must give General Petraeus a chance. He will report back to the Secretary, the Joint Chiefs, the White House, and Congress on the effectiveness of the strategy. We will then respond accordingly. Decisions about our posture in Iraq must be based on conditions on the ground, and General Petraeus is best suited to assess those conditions. Upon his recommendation, along with the Secretary and the Joint Chiefs, we will respond. Let's wait and see what happens and give this plan a chance to work. Let's avoid playing politics and support our troops. It's one thing to have an honest debate about Iraq, but it's another to involve our troops in that debate. They deserve the necessary funding and flexibility. This cause is necessary and noble, which is why I deployed them in the first place. It's essential for our nation's peace and security. It's noble that these citizens volunteer to serve. Congress must support them. While debating strategies is acceptable, ensuring timely funding is crucial. Funding our troops every two months is inadequate and unacceptable. They need what the military has requested. We can and should debate Iraq, but funding our troops should not be debated. I appreciate your time.
label: General

sentence: What exactly did you say to President Putin regarding your previous statement about him being a killer? [SEP] He's satisfied. I'm not going to rehash it. What's done is done.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Given the current surge in oil prices, do you believe it's time to reevaluate the policy of filling the Strategic Petroleum Reserve? [SEP] I've analyzed the situation, and I don't believe it would have a significant impact on prices. Our current purchases amount to approximately 67,000 to 68,000 barrels per day, which represents only one-tenth of one percent of the 85 million barrels per day global demand. It's crucial for our national security to maintain a fully stocked SPR in the event of a major disruption. Terrorist organizations, such as Al Qaeda, might target oil facilities. An attack in a major oil-exporting country would adversely affect our economy and those who oppose such groups. The SPR is essential to mitigate such risks. If I believed it would positively influence prices, I would seriously consider it. However, given that our purchases represent only one-tenth of one percent of global demand, the cost-benefit analysis does not support such a decision. It would leave us vulnerable in the event of a national security crisis.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Why did you come back, Mr. President? Why did you decide, after that—because obviously, it created a lot of commotion—what made you decide to come back and continue to the briefing? [SEP] Well, I didn't even think about not coming back. I said, Am I able to go back? And they said, You'd have to wait a little while. I waited a little while, as you know, in the Oval Office area. And I said, Can I get back now? And they said, Yes.And they have a lot of fortification outside, just in case. But it was one person. Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Why should you trust this intelligence since it's different than 2005? Why should we trust this any more? [SEP] Well, you know, I'm— without getting into sources and methods, I believe that the intelligence community has made a great discovery. And they've analyzed the discovery, and it's now part of our Government policy.Toby [Tabassum Zakaria, Reuters], I apologize for getting immediately to the TV people. That's just bad protocol; I should have called on you.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President Obama, considering the potential ramifications of Brexit on the global financial system, are you prepared to expedite trade negotiations with the UK, and do you still maintain your previous stance on their trade deal priority? Furthermore, will you actively promote the TPP while campaigning for Secretary Clinton? Finally, Prime Minister Trudeau and President Peña Nieto, why are you hesitant to directly criticize Mr. Trump's policies, especially concerning NAFTA and the proposed border wall? [SEP] Alright, Roberta, those are quite the multifaceted inquiries. First, let me say that when I visit other countries, it's generally not my place to comment on ongoing elections. The relationships between nations tend to endure beyond individual leaders. Regarding Brexit, the markets seem to have stabilized somewhat. We're closely monitoring for any systemic risks, and our central banks and finance ministers are prepared. Longer-term, Brexit could hinder global growth, especially if it impacts investment in the UK and Europe. At the upcoming G-20 summit, we'll be discussing ways to boost global demand, from infrastructure improvements in the US to Germany increasing spending and Europe easing austerity measures. As for Brexit negotiations, I urge everyone to proceed in an orderly and transparent manner, understanding that both sides have a vested interest in a successful outcome. Leadership issues in the UK need resolution, and I trust Chancellor Merkel's focus is on ensuring a functional process. We'll assist where we can. Regarding a US-UK trade agreement, the UK's immediate priority will be navigating its relationship with Europe. Our special relationship with the UK remains unchanged, rooted in shared values and cooperation. However, their absence from the EU could complicate addressing other global challenges. Finally, the ties between our three nations transcend individual leaders. Canada, the US, and Mexico share deep economic, cultural, and familial connections. I look forward to collaborating with the next US President, regardless of who it may be. President Peña Nieto?
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the recent legal debates about preemptive pardons for administration officials involved in interrogation tactics or the removal of U.S. Attorneys, have you considered this, and will you be granting any such pardons? [SEP] I'm not going to talk about pardons here.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: You said you were surprised by Republican obstruction. But didn't the GOP do the same to Obama when you were VP? Why expect different treatment? [SEP] Well, they weren't as obstructionist then. We worked with Republicans like McCain and even Graham. The difference now is, what's their agenda? Back then, they had one. Now, I don't know what they're for. The public is mad about the tax structure. What are they doing about it? Anything? They're silent on climate change. I don't know what the Republican platform is anymore. What's their position on taxes, human rights, prescription drug costs? I honestly don't know. And how can they ignore January 6th?
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, does President Zelenskyy need to cede any Ukrainian territory in order to gain a cease-fire with Russia? Or is that completely off the table? And do you think that Russia needs to be removed from the G-20? [SEP] Regarding the latter, yes. As for the first part, what was the question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Should supporters of marijuana legalization vote for you, rather than her, because she convicted so many people in the past? [SEP] I can't tell you what she's voting for. I don't think she knows what; I think Joe knows even less than she does. But I was only surprised at the pick. A lot of people were saying, That might be the pick. I was more surprised than anything else, because she did so poorly. Many people did much better than her in the primary. She did very poorly in the primaries. And that's like a poll. [] You know, that's like a poll.Please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the potential bill granting voting rights to D.C. and an additional seat to Utah, given your well-known commitment to democratic principles, particularly as demonstrated by your foreign policy initiatives in Iraq, would you be willing to lend your support to this legislation? [SEP] I must confess, this is the first I've heard of this bill potentially surfacing during the lame-duck session. It hasn't crossed my desk yet.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify your earlier statement regarding the Senkaku Islands and the mutual defense treaty with Japan, are you explicitly stating that the United States would intervene militarily if China were to engage in military action against those islands? Furthermore, given the past situation in Syria, where a perceived lack of enforcement of red lines damaged U.S. credibility, how do you ensure that this commitment is perceived as credible? Finally, concerning North Korea, are you signaling a firm warning against further nuclear tests? And Prime Minister Abe, do you still trust President Obama's security guarantees, considering the West's inability to prevent Russian actions in Ukraine? Thank you. President Obama. [SEP] Could you remind me of the specific question regarding North Korea? I want to make sure I address it directly.
label: Clarification

sentence: Regarding Cuba, what preconditions would need to be satisfied for you to consider a meeting with President Castro in Havana? And concerning the North Korean hack, while you've stated you won't publicize your response, can you confirm whether additional economic or financial sanctions are under consideration? Furthermore, can you rule out any potential military action or a retaliatory cyberattack? [SEP] I'll reiterate my previous statement. We've verified North Korea's involvement, and we're evaluating a range of responses. These options will be presented to me, and I'll make a decision based on what I deem proportionate and fitting. As for Cuba, a visit from myself or President Castro is not currently on the horizon. I'm uncertain how the relationship will progress, but I anticipate visiting Cuba at some point in the future. However, there are no concrete plans for such a visit.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, there's growing concern about troop morale in Iraq, with many on repeat deployments. A commander told me soldiers are increasingly questioning the mission. Is this something you're seeing, and is it a cause for concern? [SEP] From what I gather from the commanders, the main worry is with the families back home. Our troops, who volunteered, are willing to serve multiple tours. But the concern is with the people on the homefront. I understand that, which is why I make a point of thanking the families. You're speaking to certain individuals. I'm talking to our commanders. Their job is to keep me informed about the situation. I know there are concerns about the homefront. I haven't heard major concerns about troop morale in Iraq.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering the importance of free and fair elections, what steps is your administration taking to ensure that every American can exercise their right to vote without impediment? [SEP] We're focused on other things right now. Ask the states.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Do you have any sense of how many troops you would be willing to accept? [SEP] That's not for us to decide. It's an issue for the United States. Numbers are not going to make a difference to the situation in Afghanistan. It's the broader relationship that will make a difference to Afghanistan and beyond in the region. The specifics of numbers are issues that the military will decide, and Afghanistan will have no particular concern when we are talking of numbers and how they are deployed.An Afghan press? English-speaking press?[At this point, addressed reporters briefly in Dari, and no transcript was provided.]
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, your statement contradicts reports of ongoing testing shortages and difficulties in accessing tests for many Americans. Can you provide specific data or evidence to support your claim that anyone who wants a test can get one? Additionally, what is your administration doing to address the persistent challenges in ensuring equitable access to testing across the country? [SEP] We're working very hard to make sure everyone has access to testing. We're partnering with states and local governments, we're increasing production of tests, and we're streamlining the testing process. We're doing everything we can. And frankly, the media is exaggerating the problem. They're trying to make us look bad. But the American people know the truth. They know we're doing a great job.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So, just to be clear, is a formal signing ceremony required for this agreement to be valid? [SEP] Well, that's a rather nuanced question, isn't it? The technicalities of a signature, given its non-legally binding nature, are, shall we say, open to interpretation. I'm not entirely sure about the specific protocols involved. However, I want to emphasize that the United States is deeply committed to this agreement, and we believe it holds significant importance. Thank you all.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. You talked a little earlier about the screening measures that you put in place and the travel restrictions you've put in place regarding China. At this point, as the virus spreads in Italy and South Korea, are you planning on adding those countries to the list? [SEP] Well, just so you understand, you know, I'm the President of the United States. I'm not the President of other countries. Other countries—some on the list that are very respected in what they do in terms of what we're talking about.But I really want to be responsible for this country, if it means placing very strong—a very strong situation on the border so people can't come into our country from a country that is infected. That's—we're doing that, and we've already done it with numerous countries.But we have to focus on this country. I don't think it's right to impose ourself on others. But if others aren't taking care or we think they're doing it incorrectly—you know, we're dealing with World Health, and we have terrific people. And CDC does go around and help other countries give them recommendations as what to do. But they're working on their countries and we're working on our countries. And so far, from our standpoint, it's really worked out very well.
label: General

sentence: Q. Given the media's perceived impatience, your three budget cycles, and your willingness to be a one-term president, why not initiate Republican negotiations immediately? What efforts are you making to cultivate bipartisanship, and will the markets remain stable in the interim? [SEP] I should have taken notes, I am running out of brain power.
label: Clarification

sentence: But didn't you say this morning that you were against it? [SEP] I'm only against things where the people aren't being taken care of. We want people to get money. It wasn't their fault that they got shut down. They got shut down by China. Whether it's the Post Office or the $3½ billion dollars they're asking for just for the universal mail-in ballots, but they're not willing to make a deal. These are two points within a very big deal. The thing they want more than anything else, Kaitlan, and you know this, is bailout money for the States and for the cities that are in trouble, which, for the most part, are Democrat-run States and cities. So New York has a problem, California has a problem, Illinois has a tremendous problem, and others. They want to be able to bail out these States, and we don't want to be doing that or certainly don't want to do it to the extent. They're looking for $1 trillion; we don't want to be doing that.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, given the Chinese government's recent expulsion of Wall Street Journal reporters, what retaliatory steps are under consideration by your administration? Are you considering restricting access for Chinese journalists within the United States, as a possible response? [SEP] I haven't been fully briefed on that situation as of yet. We're going to look into it. It's something I don't appreciate. I don't think it's a fair move, because we give very good access. Some might even suggest we give *too* much. I don't subscribe to that view. I believe we provide excellent access, so this feels unjust. But we'll come to a decision on this matter relatively soon. Okay? Thank you. Good question. Next, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, to be direct, does your administration believe Putin will invade Ukraine? [SEP] That's a question only Putin can answer. We're analyzing the situation, consulting with allies, and preparing for any eventuality. But, ultimately, it's his call.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, can you elaborate on the 'you'll see' response? What specific consequences will Iran face if it violates the JCPOA uranium enrichment limits? Can you provide any details, even in broad terms, to reassure our allies and deter Iran? [SEP] Our response will be appropriate.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Putin, following up, why should Americans, and President Trump specifically, believe your claim that Russia did not meddle in the 2016 election, given the U.S. intelligence community's findings? And will you entertain extraditing the 12 Russian officials indicted by a U.S. grand jury last week? [SEP] Well, let's be clear. The whole narrative of interference arose, perhaps, as a convenient explanation for an election outcome some found unfavorable. The Democrats, frankly, should have won, given the electoral college's inherent advantage for them. As for collusion, it's a fabrication. I didn't know President Trump, and there was no coordination with his campaign. These individuals you mention, even if the allegations hold true, weren't part of the campaign. Now, about trust, it's not about personal trust between President Trump and myself. It's about defending our respective national interests and finding common ground. The collusion narrative is nonsense, devoid of factual basis. We must operate on facts, not speculation. Regarding the 12 individuals, I'll look into it. We have a treaty with the U.S. for mutual assistance in criminal cases. We can offer to allow Special Counsel Mueller's team to question them, provided the U.S. reciprocates by allowing us to question officials linked to illegal activities in Russia. For instance, we have questions about Mr. Browder's business dealings and the funds channeled into Hillary Clinton's campaign. This should be handled within a proper legal framework, with mutual cooperation.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Cuba, what specific prerequisites would you demand before engaging with President Castro in Havana? And pivoting to the North Korean cyberattack, while you're holding back on announcing a response, are you contemplating further economic sanctions? Can you unequivocally dismiss the possibility of military intervention or a reciprocal cyber offensive? [SEP] We've established North Korea's culpability and are formulating a range of responses. I will select the most appropriate one. Regarding Cuba, a meeting between myself and President Castro is not currently feasible. I anticipate visiting Cuba eventually, but there are no immediate plans.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, some analysts suggest that engaging with Kim Jong-un, particularly without preconditions, could be interpreted as a diplomatic win for North Korea. Do you share these concerns, and how do you justify this meeting in light of North Korea's continued pursuit of nuclear weapons? [SEP] That's just the fake news talking. We got three hostages back, didn't we? And we paid nothing. They're back home with their families, happy as can be. We haven't given up anything. The haters are saying, 'Oh, you're giving him a meeting.' Give me a break, okay? This has never been done before, and what's been done before hasn't worked. This is something I can't stress enough. Look at tariffs. Previous administrations should have handled it. The same with . This should have been done five, ten, twenty-five years ago.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what's your best estimate for when the next meeting with Shanghai Media Group will occur? [SEP] I'm not in the prediction business. It'll happen when it happens. No idea when that might be.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with the mounting losses and the surge in sectarian strife in Iraq, how long can your current strategy hold without demonstrable improvement? And what's the status on the search for the missing soldiers? [SEP] We are doing everything possible to find the missing soldiers. General Petraeus and Secretary Gates are fully informed, and we are utilizing all available intelligence and troops. It is a top priority. The loss of life is devastating, but I sent more troops to stabilize the capital. We haven't even fully deployed them yet. General Petraeus presented a plan to Congress aimed at helping the Iraqi government secure its capital and reconcile. All troops will be in place by mid-June. The increased fighting is due to our troops entering new areas with the Iraqis. General Petraeus has requested until September to report back on progress. I want to see a different configuration in Iraq, but that requires securing the capital, which is why I followed General Petraeus's recommendations. I favor the Baker-Hamilton approach of embedding, training, guarding territorial integrity, and using Special Forces against Al Qaida. But we needed to increase troop levels to secure the capital, as I feared violence would spiral out of control. The timing of our actions will be decided by commanders on the ground, not politicians in Washington.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given your previous statements about Iran and Syria, would you be willing to collaborate with them if it benefits our efforts in Iraq? [SEP] It's crucial that Iran and Syria understand their responsibility to support Iraq's stability. Regarding Iran, we have numerous concerns, including their nuclear ambitions and support for terrorism. Our position is clear: a better path exists for Iran than isolation. As for Syria, they must cease undermining Lebanon, prevent attacks against Israel, and refrain from interfering in Iraq. They are well aware of our stance.
label: General

sentence: So, you said this morning you were against it, correct? [SEP] What I'm against is anything where the people aren't being taken care of properly. We want people to get money. It wasn't their fault they got shut down by China. Whether it's the Post Office or the $3½ billion dollars for universal mail-in ballots, they're not willing to make a deal. These are two points within a very big deal. What they want more than anything is bailout money for the States and cities in trouble, mostly Democrat-run. New York, California, Illinois, and others have problems. They want to bail out these States, and we don't want to do that to the extent they're asking for $1 trillion.
label: Deflection

sentence: Speaker Pelosi's visit to Syria occurred despite your administration's disapproval. How do you reconcile your call for unified foreign policy with the reality of independent diplomatic efforts by members of Congress, and what consequences, if any, will there be? [SEP] Look, I respect Speaker Pelosi, but these rogue trips send the wrong message. It emboldens Asad, makes him think he's got legitimacy he doesn't deserve. He's a state sponsor of terror, plain and simple. We need a unified front, a clear message: change your behavior, or face the consequences. These photo ops undermine that message, plain and simple. We're working with our allies to isolate Asad, and these trips just make our job harder.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Biden, in light of the ongoing migration challenges and the fentanyl crisis, what concrete steps are being taken, and what role will Mexico play in these efforts? [SEP] We had a very productive discussion on migration. We're committed to protecting migrants, and President López Obrador's humanitarian visa program is already showing positive results. We need to address the root causes of migration by investing in development in countries facing inequality and poverty. Migration should be a choice, not a forced situation. Mexico is providing vital support with shelters, healthcare, and food. We commend Mexico and Canada's approach. We're also tackling violence by investing in youth programs, creating jobs, and fighting corruption. We've agreed to collaborate to promote peace and security in our nations.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, to be clear, this initiative is positive for both business and the climate, but it's not something you're prepared to codify into law? Is that your position? [SEP] I'm sorry, I missed your point. Could you please repeat it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, about Iran, is the framework agreement really non-negotiable, despite concerns about inspections and sanctions? And on Cuba, did you discuss the 45-day waiting period for removing them from the terrorism list with President Castro? Are there any obstacles to opening embassies after removal? [SEP] On Iran, the framework has specifics, like centrifuge cuts and Fordow's conversion. But details matter and will be negotiated. It's wrong to say it's all done. The framework, if implemented, stops Iran from getting a nuclear weapon, but details are key. Tough talks are coming, as I've said. We had similar issues with the interim agreement, but it worked out. On Cuba, we didn't discuss those details. I'll review the terrorism list recommendation, and Congress will too. Embassy concerns are probably on Cuba's side, since they haven't had one in a while. It's a bigger change for them. We're ready to move forward, improve dialogue, and help the Cuban people. Thanks to Latin America and Panama. I'm optimistic because of the people.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russian interference, multiple intelligence reports suggest ongoing efforts. Can you state unequivocally that you will accept the outcome of the upcoming election, regardless of who wins, and condemn any foreign interference? [SEP] The situation with Russia is, as you know, very complex. We are taking strong measures, very strong measures, to ensure the integrity of our elections. Nobody is tougher on Russia than I am. But frankly, the Democrats are always trying to make this a bigger issue than it is. They want to distract from their own failures. We will have a fair election, a very fair election, and we will see what happens. I have great faith in the American people.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. President Obama, concerning Chile, while you praise its economic achievements and democratic transition, the shadow of the Pinochet dictatorship lingers. Many hold the U.S. accountable for its involvement in those troubled times. Will your administration assist investigations into the deaths of Allende and Frei Montalva, and perhaps offer an apology for past U.S. actions in Chile? [SEP] We're open to considering any requests from the Chilean government for information regarding the past, and we're willing to cooperate. It's vital to understand our history. The relationship between the U.S. and Latin America has certainly had its rocky periods. But while we acknowledge the past, we shouldn't let it define us. Chile's progress in recent decades has been extraordinary, and the U.S. has been a strong supporter. I can't comment on all past policies, but I can speak to the present and future. The U.S. is dedicated to democracy, fighting poverty, and promoting inclusive development. We support Chile's free markets and the economic progress made by and President Bachelet. So, let's learn from the past, but not be bound by it. We have challenges to tackle now and in the future.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Justice Department, was the seizure of Associated Press phone records an overreach? Do you still trust your Attorney General? Is the media shield law a reaction? And how do you feel about Nixon comparisons? [SEP] I'll let you all debate the historical parallels. My concern is fixing problems in government. That goes for the IRS, diplomatic security, and everything else. As for the Justice Department, I can't comment on specific cases. But leaks are a serious threat to national security and our people overseas. I won't apologize for protecting them. We also need a free press, which is why we need to revisit the media shield law. It's about finding the right balance.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Are there steps your administration can take now to build confidence that the U.S. will, in fact, meet its deficit reduction goals in the medium and long term? [SEP] The several steps we've already begun to take, number one, as I indicated, the budget that we're presenting, 3 years discretionary domestic spending freeze. And I've sent a clear signal to the leadership when we met, even if we do not get the entire budget package passed through Congress, that top line number needs to stay firm. And I'm serious about it.We've initiated a whole host of measures to cut programs that aren't working, including, by the way, in the defense area. Bob Gates has been, I think, as successful as any Secretary of Defense in recent memory in actually killing programs, which, I think, anybody who follows Washington knows is very tough, very difficult.We have instituted PAYGO. And although there were baselines built in that took into account the fact that some of this stuff was not going to be solved overnight, it is starting to provide budget discipline to Congress as they move forward.And we have set up this Fiscal Commission, who will provide reports starting in November. And one of the encouraging things--although there was resistance, ironically, on the part of some of the Republicans who originally had been cosponsors of legislation to create the Fiscal Commission, and they, in fact, ended up voting against it--what's been encouraging, based on what I'm hearing both from Democrats and Republicans, is that there's been a serious conversation there. People are looking at a whole spectrum of issues to get at what is basically a structural deficit that preceded this financial crisis.Even if--the financial crisis made it much worse, but even if we had not gone through this financial crisis, we'd still have to be dealing with these long-term deficit problems. They have to do with Medicaid; they have to do with Medicare; they have to do with Social Security. They have to do with a series of structural problems that are not unique to America. Some of it has to do with an aging population. And we've got to look at a tax system that is messy and unfair in a whole range of ways.And so they're looking at the gamut of steps that are going to be taken. And one of the interesting things that's happened over the last 18 months as President is, for some reason, people keep on being surprised when I do what I said I was going to do. So I say, I'm going to reform our health care system, and people think, well, gosh, that's not smart politics, maybe we should hold off. Or I say, we're going to move forward on don't ask, don't tell, and somehow people say, Well, why are you doing that? I'm not sure that's good politics.I'm doing it because I said I was going to do it, and I think it's the right thing to do. And people should learn that lesson about me, because next year, when I start presenting some very difficult choices to the country, I hope some of these folks who are hollering about deficits and debt step up, because I'm calling their bluff. And we'll see how much of that--how much of the political arguments they're making right now are real and how much of it was just politics.All right? Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, with respect to the Afghanistan withdrawal, considering the potential for regional instability, what specific assurances can you provide that India and Pakistan will not exploit the situation to further their own geopolitical agendas? [SEP] We're engaging with both India and Pakistan to ensure that they understand the importance of stability in Afghanistan. We're making it clear that any actions that undermine peace and security will not be tolerated. We're also working with other regional partners to create a framework for long-term stability. It's a complex situation, but we're committed to finding a solution that works for everyone.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. What about long-term about the electoral college? [SEP] Long-term with respect to the electoral college, the electoral college is a vestige, it's a carryover from an earlier vision of how our Federal Government was going to work that put a lot of premium on States, and it used to be that the Senate was not elected directly, it was through State legislatures. And it's the same type of thinking that gives Wyoming two Senators and—with about half a million people, and California with 33 million get the same two.So there are some structures in our political system, as envisioned by the Founders, that sometimes are going to disadvantage Democrats. But the truth of the matter is, is that, if we have a strong message, if we're speaking to what the American people care about, typically, the popular vote and the electoral college vote will align.And I guess part of my overall message here, as I leave for the holidays, is that if we look for one explanation or one silver bullet or one easy fix for our politics, then we're probably going to be disappointed. There are just a lot of factors in what's happened not just over the last few months, but over the last decade, that has made both politics and governance more challenging. And I think everybody has raised legitimate questions and legitimate concerns.I do hope that we all just take some time, take a breath—this is certainly what I'm going to advise Democrats—to just reflect a little bit more about, how can we get to a place where people are focused on working together based on at least some common set of facts? How can we have a conversation about policy that doesn't demonize each other? How can we channel what I think is the basic decency and goodness of the American people so it reflects itself in our politics, as opposed to it being so polarized and so nasty that, in some cases, you have voters and elected officials who have more confidence and faith in a foreign adversary than they have in their neighbors?And those go to some bigger issues. How is it that we have some voters or some elected officials who think that Michelle Obama's healthy eating initiative and school nutrition program is a greater threat to democracy than our Government going after the press if they're issuing a story they don't like? Right? I mean, that's an issue that I think we've got to wrestle with, and we will.People have asked me, how do you feel after the election and so forth, and I say, well, look, this is a clarifying moment. It's a useful reminder that voting counts, politics counts. What the President-elect is going to be doing is going to be very different than what I was doing, and I think people will be able to compare and contrast and make judgments about what worked for the American people.And I hope that, building off the progress we've made, that what the President-elect is proposing works. What I can say with confidence is that what we've done works. Now, that I can prove. I can show you where we were in 2008, and I can show you where we are now, and you can't argue that we're not better off. We are. And for that, I thank the American people and, more importantly, I thank—well, not more importantly, as importantly—I was going to say Josh Earnest for doing such a great job as—[]. For that, I thank the American people. I thank the men and women in uniform who serve. I haven't gotten to the point yet where I've been overly sentimental.I will tell you, when I was doing my last Christmas party photoline—many of you have participated in these; they're pretty long—[]—right at the end of the line, the President's Marine Corps Band comes in, those who had been performing, and I take a picture with them, and it was the last time that I was going to take a picture with my Marine Corps Band after an event, and I got a little choked up. Now, I was in front of Marines, so I had to, like, tamp it down. []But it was just one small example of all the people who have contributed to our success. I'm responsible for where we've screwed up. The successes are widely shared with all the amazing people who have been part of this administration. Okay?Thank you, everybody.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, can you shed light on the widespread discontent among Democrats concerning the extension of tax cuts for the wealthy in the recent tax legislation? Do you feel that your characterization of these tax cuts as 'morally inappropriate' contributes to this division? [SEP] I acknowledge the frustration. I've articulated before, and I'll reiterate: I don't believe we can sustain tax breaks for individuals who are already affluent. They prospered during Bill Clinton's presidency. This will be a recurring debate over the ensuing years. Upon the swearing-in of the new Congress, we'll need to deliberate on how to achieve a balanced budget. This necessitates curtailing ineffective programs, but also honestly addressing the funding of essential priorities. If we aim to provide adequate care for our veterans, we must allocate funds for the requisite medical personnel and facilities. If we aspire for our children's success, we must invest in education. If we seek to maintain our competitiveness, we must invest in basic research. We must weigh the option of maintaining tax cuts for the wealthy against investing in these priorities. I comprehend why some Democrats, and even some Republicans, believe we could have dispensed with that aspect of the tax package. However, compromise entails accepting certain unfavorable elements. The overall package was the appropriate one to stimulate economic growth and job creation. There's no superior antipoverty program than a thriving economy, nor a better deficit-reduction program.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Just to confirm, you're happy with the people you've chosen for your Cabinet? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Despite President Trump's explicit request in his letter, you proceeded with military action in Northern Syria. Can you elaborate on the specific factors that led you to disregard his warning, and how do you assess the current state of relations between Turkey and the United States? [SEP] The letter was brought to President Trump's attention again. We also emphasized that a terrorist figure like Ferhat Abdi Sahin should not be considered a partner by a country like the United States. This person has been involved in the deaths of hundreds of Turkish civilians and is seen as a close associate of Abdullah Öcalan, the terrorist leader imprisoned in Turkey. Such an individual should not be welcomed by the United States, nor by Russia. It's challenging to comprehend this when we're committed to fighting terrorism globally. To effectively combat terrorism, we must be more vigilant. We've shared information, including a CIA document identifying this individual as a terrorist, with our counterparts in the White House, including President Trump. We also returned the letter we received.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the potential for global economic disruption following the Brexit vote, what steps are you prepared to take to stabilize markets and possibly expedite the exit process? Do you still hold the view that the UK should be at the back of the line for a trade deal with the United States? And will you actively promote the TPP while campaigning for Secretary Clinton? Prime Minister Trudeau and President Peña Nieto, why are you hesitant to openly criticize Mr. Trump's policies, especially concerning NAFTA and the proposed border wall? [SEP] Okay, Roberta, those are a lot of questions packed into one. Let me start by saying that when I'm visiting other countries, it's not really my job to comment on candidates in the middle of an election. The relationship between governments usually lasts longer than whoever's in power at the time. As for Brexit, the markets seem to have settled down a little. We're keeping a close eye on things to make sure there aren't any major problems, and our central banks are ready. In the long run, Brexit could slow down global growth if it makes it harder to invest in the UK and Europe. At the G-20, we'll be talking about how to boost global demand, from fixing infrastructure in the US to Germany spending more and Europe loosening up on spending cuts. When it comes to Brexit negotiations, I think everyone needs to take a deep breath and come up with a plan that's clear and makes sense, knowing that both sides need to get this right. The UK needs to sort out its leadership situation, and I'm confident Chancellor Merkel wants things to work out. We'll help however we can. As for a trade deal between the US and the UK, their first concern is going to be figuring out their relationship with Europe. Our special relationship with the UK is still strong, based on shared values and working together. But their leaving the EU could make it harder for us to deal with other global issues. Finally, the connections between our three countries are stronger than any one leader. Canada, the US, and Mexico are deeply connected economically, culturally, and through families. I'm looking forward to working with whoever the next US President is. President Peña Nieto?
label: Implicit

sentence: Regarding Secretary Azar, do you still believe he's the right person for the job? [SEP] Good luck to him. Who are we talking about again?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Bush, beyond broad statements of support, what precise mechanisms will the U.S. employ to bolster African development, and how will you measure the effectiveness of these interventions? Also, what specific outcomes are you targeting during this visit, and what measures are in place to guarantee the long-term viability of these programs? [SEP] Africa's important, and I wanted to show that early in my presidency. We want to help with diseases, trade, and schools. Being here in Ghana makes that clear. African leaders are doing great things. We've helped with conflicts, like in Liberia, and supported democracy. Our aid now asks for things like fighting corruption. The leaders I've met are good people. This trip is important, and I appreciate Ghana's hospitality. John McKinnon from the Wall Street Journal is here, a very smart paper.
label: General

sentence: Q. So why should the American people then be comfortable with an American President asking a foreign leader for information about an American citizen? [SEP] Well, I think you can look at your Senators and you can look at Biden, and you can look at all these other people. But what we're looking for is corruption. An investigation started, called the Russian witch hunt, affectionately. And it was a total phony scam. It was set up by people within the Government to try and stop somebody from getting elected.And after that person—namely, me—won, and convincingly won at 306 to 223 in the electoral college—which, by the way, when you run a race, if you're running electoral—you know, if you go by the college, electoral college, that's a much different race than running popular vote. And it's like the hundred-yard dash or the mile. You train differently.And I can't help it that my opponent didn't go to Wisconsin and should have gone much more to Michigan and Pennsylvania and other places. But that's the way it is. We won an election convincingly. Convincingly. And then, you had the text message on, Well, if she doesn't win, we've got an insurance policy. How bad was that? You know the insurance policy? That's sort of what has been taking place over the last number of years, the insurance policy.No, there are a lot of very dishonest people. We're the ones that played it straight. And you know what? The millions of people out there that are looking at what's going on, those people understand it. They see it. And they think it's disgusting. And our people are being hurt, and our country is being hurt.When a Nancy Pelosi allows her position to be taken over by radical far-left Socialists, or worse, that's pretty bad. That's pretty bad, especially when the Senators and all of these other people have actually done what they're accusing me of doing, which I didn't do.I'm going to have Mike Pompeo say a couple of words. I'm going to have Steve Mnuchin say a couple of words. And then, we'll do a couple of more questions. Mr. President, I thought I'd start by talking about Iran. We had a productive week. We saw the Europeans take a position with respect to the attacks that took place in Saudi Arabia, making clear this was Iran, just as President Trump and I had been saying, and have now joined us in saying that the existing JCPOA framework is just not going to work. It's not going to solve the world's problems, it's not going to create Middle East stability.Then, we had a good set of meetings with our Middle East allies as well. The President joined for a meeting of the GCC where we talked again about how we can help deter. We want peace. We want a peaceful resolution with the Islamic Republic of Iran. We're hoping we can get that way. In the end, it will be up to the Iranians to make that decision, whether they'll choose violence and hate and—as the President said in his speech yesterday to the General Assembly—if their bloodthirst will continue.We hope that's the—[inaudible]. We hope we can get the opportunity to negotiate with them and get an outcome that's good for both of them, for the United States, to make sure that they never have a nuclear weapon and that they can't foment their terror with ballistic missiles and in the way they have all around the world. And I think we made real progress uniting the world on that here over these past few days. Thank you. The President. Thank you, Mike. As Secretary Pompeo said, on Iran, we had very good discussions with all of our allies about the sanctions program, which is the maximum pressure, and unity on the sanctions program. The Europeans made it very clear they would not do anything without our consent.And then, on the economic front, we had the entire economic team here for all the meetings: Secretary Ross, Larry Kudlow; Ambassador Lighthizer just left to go back to DC. He's working hard on trying to get USMCA passed. But we had a lot of productive discussions. The Japanese trade deal and a lot of discussions on investing in the U.S., more jobs in the U.S., and more trade. Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, you're not concerned about Russian interference? [SEP] It's always Russia, Russia, Russia! Look, China's actions are arguably far more concerning on the world stage. Consider the origins of the virus; they didn't contain it within their borders, impacting 188 countries. Yet, the focus is always on Russia. I'm not saying Russia is blameless, but China's actions have had a devastating global impact. If there was something wrong with the election, I would be very angry, and we'll examine the evidence.
label: Implicit

sentence: So, Mr. President, you've mentioned a shift towards decency. Do you believe the election signifies a breaking of the fever, a transition from the past few years? [SEP] I don't think we'll reach the super-mega-MAGA Republicans, but they're a minority. Most Republicans are decent, honorable people with whom we disagree. I've worked with them for years; they're honest and straightforward. The world is watching us. At the first G-7 meeting, I said, 'America is back.' One leader asked, 'For how long?' Another asked what I'd think if thousands stormed the British Parliament to stop an election confirmation. It's not the same, but they'd think England was in trouble. People wonder if the U.S. is stable, if we're the same democracy. If we withdrew from the world, things would change. They're concerned we're still an open democracy where rules and institutions matter. They're watching to see if we accept decisions from the Court, Congress, and the Government.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, the communique mentions avoiding currency manipulation. What concrete steps should China take, and does the Democratic Party need new leaders? [SEP] Look, China's rise is a good thing, lifting people out of poverty. But they gotta play fair. The RMB is undervalued, hurting us and others. They need to let the market decide. As for the Democrats, I think talented folks will rise to the top with good ideas. Pelosi and Reid have been great, and I'm ready to work with whoever's in charge.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, sir, have you been any plans that would involve quarantined cities, like we saw in China? And what would have to happen for you to take a step like that? [SEP] We do have plans of a much—on a much larger scale, should we need that. We're working with States, we're working with virtually every State. And we do have plans on a larger scale if we need it. We don't think we're going to need it, but you know, you always have to be prepared.And, again, Congress is talking to us about funding, and we're getting far more than what we asked for. And I guess, the best thing to do is take it. We'll take it.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Does this make you think differently about your personal safety inside the White House? [SEP] No, I feel very safe with the Secret Service. They're fantastic people. They're the best of the best, and they're highly trained. I don't know if anybody got to walk outside, but there were a lot of terrific-looking people ready to go if something was necessary, people at the highest level of law enforcement. There's nobody like these people.So they just wanted me to step aside for a little while, just to make sure that everything was cleared outside, because it was right in this area.
label: Explicit

sentence: Beyond the stimulus checks, what specific measures are you taking to alleviate the economic hardship faced by struggling Americans, especially with rising gas prices and general economic uncertainty? [SEP] First, making the tax cuts permanent is key. The uncertainty of potential tax increases is crippling. If people are worried about $4 gas and rising taxes, that's a double whammy. Permanent tax cuts provide stability. Second, we need a comprehensive energy policy. Renewables and conservation are important, but we also need to find more oil and gas here at home to reduce our dependence on foreign oil. This is a transition period to new technologies. We haven't built a refinery in ages. I even suggested building them on old military bases, but Congress didn't bite. Less supply plus steady demand equals higher prices. We need to explore ANWR, with responsible environmental mitigation. And taxing oil companies? That'll just make prices worse. We need to encourage domestic investment. This pro-growth package, the $147 billion, will help consumers cope with the uncertainty. It's a tough time, no doubt. Next question.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You racked up a lot of wins in the last few weeks that a lot of people thought would be difficult to come by. Are you ready to call yourself the comeback kid? And also, as you look ahead to 2011, are you worried that bipartisan agreement will be a lot harder to reach on issues like deficit reduction and maybe even tax reform? [SEP] Well, look, as I said right after the midterm elections, we took a shellacking. And I take responsibility for that. But I think what's happened over the last several weeks is not a victory for me, it's a victory for the American people. And the lesson I hope that everybody takes from this is that it's possible for Democrats and Republicans to have principled disagreements, to have some lengthy arguments, but to ultimately find common ground to move the country forward.That's what we did with taxes. Those arguments have not gone away. I still believe that it doesn't make sense for us to provide tax cuts to people like myself who don't need them when our deficit and debts are growing. That's a debate that's going to continue into 2011, and I know the Republicans feel just as strongly on the other side of that.I think that we're still going to have disagreements in terms of spending priorities. It's vital for us to make investments in education and research and development--all those things that create an innovative economy--while at the same time cutting those programs that just aren't working. And there are going to be debates between the parties on those issues.But what we've shown is that we don't have to agree on a hundred percent to get things done that enhance the lives of families all across America. And if we can sustain that spirit, then regardless of how the politics play out in 2012, the American people will be better for it. And that's my ultimate goal.Jake Tapper [ABC News].U.S. Military's Don't Ask, Don't Tell Policy/Same-Sex Marriage
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, with respect to the Khashoggi situation, what specific actions are you prepared to take if Saudi Arabia is found culpable? [SEP] We're exploring various avenues in conjunction with our partners. It's premature to speculate on specific outcomes before all the facts are ascertained. We have very capable people looking into it. Let's move on.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. So that means that if the audit is still on, you will not turn over the tax returns, or you'll fight to block it? [SEP] When it's under audit—no, nobody would. Nobody turns over a return when it's under audit, okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Following up on the possibility of a second summit, Mr. President, are you prepared to offer any specific location options under consideration, or perhaps a timeline for when such a summit might occur? [SEP] Look, we're talking about a lot of things, okay? We're talking about a lot of potential locations. We have great locations here, they have great locations there. The important thing is that we're talking. We're making tremendous progress, believe me. The relationship is fantastic. So, we'll see what happens. We'll pick the best place, the place that makes the most sense. It'll be a great place. Everybody will be happy. We're looking at everything, very seriously.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, your supporters praise your unconventional approach to trade negotiations. Could you elaborate on the specific strategies that have proven most effective in achieving favorable outcomes for the United States? [SEP] Look, here's the deal: I hear people saying, 'Just make a deal, make a deal.' They don't have the guts, the wisdom to see you can't keep letting a country take $500 billion, with a 'b,' every year. Five hundred billion dollars! You just can't do it. Somebody had to do this. Obama should have done it. Sleepy Joe Biden should have done it. Bush should have done it. Clinton, Double Bush, they all should have done it. But I'm doing it. And let me tell you something else: North Korea should've been handled a long time ago. I'm doing it. I'm doing a lot of things I shouldn't have to be doing.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And you have many Americans now in Brazil for Carnival. What are your concerns? And what are the procedures and practices that you plan to implement as those Americans are trying to come back home? [SEP] Yes, we've gotten very strong on people coming in from Brazil. Now, it only has one case. It's a big country, but it only has one case. But still, it's a case.We deal with Brazil very well. The President is a very good friend of mine. In fact, he ran on exactly—it's called Make Brazil Great Again. That's what he ran on. We get along very well. I know you're so thrilled to hear that. [] We get along very, very well, and we're working with Brazil. But we have much worse instances than Brazil. You know, you have Italy and you have other countries where they have much more than one person. They have one person right now. As of now—as of just a little while ago—one person in Brazil. But Italy is, you know, a deeper problem.And we're checking people coming in very, very strongly from those. And at some point, we may cut that off. You know, at some point, depending on what happens, we may cut certain additional countries off, like we've had to do with China. And we hope we can open it up to China as soon as possible.And we hope the numbers we've been getting—we hope the numbers that we've been getting are true on China, where it really has leveled off and started to go down, because eventually, sometime, that's going to happen.Go ahead.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I wanted to follow up on your answer there about Russia and Ukraine. When you were in Geneva in June, you said to us, about President Putin, I think the last thing . . . he wants now is a cold war.Now, since then, of course, you've seen him gather these troops—100,000 troops—around Ukraine. Your Secretary of State said today he thought he could invade at any moment. You've seen the cyber attacks. And you've seen the demand that he have a sphere of influence in which you would withdraw all American troops and nuclear weapons from what used to be the Soviet bloc.So I'm wondering if you still think that the last thing he wants is a cold war. And has your view of him changed in the past few months? And if it has and he does invade, would your posture be to really move back to the kind of containment policy that you saw so often when you were still in the Senate? [SEP] The answer is that I think he still does not want any full-blown war, number one.Number two, do I think he'll test the west, test the United States and NATO as significantly as he can? Yes, I think he will. But I think he'll pay a serious and dear price for it that he doesn't think now will cost him what it's going to cost him. And I think he will regret having done it.Now, whether or not—I think that—how can I say this in a public forum? I think that he is dealing with what I believe he thinks is the most tragic thing that's happened to Mother Russia—in that the Berlin Wall came down, the empire has been lost, the near abroad is gone, et cetera. The Soviet Union has been split.But think about what he has. He has eight time zones, a burning tundra that will not freeze again naturally, a situation where he has a lot of oil and gas, but he is trying to find his place in the world between China and the west.And so I'm not so sure that he has—David, I'm not so sure he has—is certain what he's going to do. My guess is he will move in. He has to do something.And by the way, I've indicated to him—the two things he said to me that he wants guarantees of: One is, Ukraine will never be part of NATO. And two, that NATO, or the—there will not be strategic weapons stationed in Ukraine. Well, we could work out something on the second piece, depending what he does along the Russian line as well—or the Russian border, in the European area of Russia.On the first piece, we have a number of treaties internationally and in Europe that suggest that you get to choose who you want to be with. But the likelihood that Ukraine is going to join NATO in the near term is not very likely, based on much more work they have to do in terms of democracy and a few other things going on there and whether or not the major allies in the west would vote to bring Ukraine in right now.So there's room to work if he wants to do that. But I think, as usual, he's going to—well, I probably shouldn't go any further. But I think it will hurt him badly./North Atlantic Treaty Organization
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. I have a question about coronavirus, but I wanted to just ask you to be clear on the incident outside. There's a fairly significant perimeter around the White House. So does it concern you at all that someone who is armed was able to get so close that you needed to be removed from the briefing room? [SEP] Well, I don't know if he was close or not—he or she. I don't know if it was a he or a she. But I have such confidence in these people; they're so good. And I don't think the person breached anything. It was on the outside grounds. So I don't believe anything was breached. I asked that question. So they were relatively far away.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning TikTok, the Commerce Department appears to have granted a delay until after the election to finalize a deal. Are you expecting this TikTok agreement to materialize before or after the election? [SEP] I think things are moving quickly. We're talking to some great companies. You know about Oracle, and Microsoft has been involved, though I'm not sure if they still are. Walmart is a fantastic company, very involved, and wants to make something happen. So, we have some good choices, and maybe we can make a lot of people happy while keeping our security. We need total security from China. But TikTok is also an amazing and super popular company. If we can combine those things, that would be great. It could all happen very fast.
label: General

sentence: Q. Then why won't you allow the photos from the guards? [SEP] Hold on a second, Helen [Helen Thomas, Hearst Newspapers]. That's a different question. [] And I think it's important for us to make sure that we let the ian people know that we are watching what's happening, that they are not alone in this process. Ultimately, though, what's going to be most important is what happens in . And we've all been struck by the courage of people. And I mentioned this, I think, in a statement that I made a couple of days ago. Some of you who had been covering my campaigns know this is one of my favorite expressions, was Dr. King's expression that the arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice. We have to believe that ultimately justice will prevail.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Tucano aircraft Nigeria has requested to combat their internal issues, specifically, would you consider expediting the release of at least two before the end of 2020? Furthermore, are there any plans for you to visit Nigeria in the near future? [SEP] Nigeria, a truly remarkable nation, I've heard it said that its natural beauty is unparalleled. A visit there would be something. Now, regarding the first part of your inquiry, could you perhaps restate it? I want to ensure I address your concerns with the attention they deserve.
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, reflecting on your presidency, do you feel any remorse for any untruths you may have spread? [SEP] Say again?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Trump, the Mueller report outlined numerous contacts between your campaign and Russian officials. While it didn't establish a criminal conspiracy, it did detail troubling interactions. In hindsight, do you believe your campaign should have handled those contacts differently, and what lessons have you learned from that experience? [SEP] The Mueller report was a total witch hunt, a hoax. There was no collusion. It's been proven. The Democrats are still obsessed with it, but the American people are tired of it. We won the election, fair and square. And frankly, those contacts were totally normal. There was nothing wrong with them. It's all fake news.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, despite the controversy, can you explain why you believe it's appropriate for a U.S. President to request information about a political rival from a foreign leader? Furthermore, what would your reaction have been if President Obama had sought information about you from a foreign government before your presidential campaign? [SEP] Well, isn't that precisely what he was doing all along? Look, this whole witch hunt, it's a disgrace, and hopefully, the truth will come out. There are some great books coming out that expose what they did to us. They've hurt this country very badly. No President should have to go through what I've gone through. The President of Ukraine is trying to stop corruption. There was corruption. Senators threatened him with votes and money. That's what they're trying to say I did, but I didn't. The call was perfect. There was no quid pro quo, unlike Biden and those Senators. We have an honest group of people being unfairly maligned. I'm very happy. A recent poll had me at 53. Add 10 points to any poll for Trump. I don't know if that's a compliment, but it is. That's what happened in the election: more people voted than anyone thought possible.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, following up on your remarks regarding China's trade practices, could you elaborate on the specific enforcement mechanisms your administration is considering beyond the tire case you mentioned? Are there any plans for multilateral action with other nations who share similar concerns about China's economic policies? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, we're exploring all options. We're not going to telegraph our strategy to the Chinese, but we're looking at everything from WTO challenges to working with our allies to put pressure on them. We're not ruling anything out. The key is to get them to understand that they need to play by the rules, and we're going to use every tool at our disposal to make that happen. We're talking to our partners in Europe, Asia, and elsewhere, because this isn't just a U.S. problem. It's a global problem, and it requires a global solution. We're confident that we can get China to change its behavior, but it's going to take a sustained effort.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, will you be in Charlotte to accept the Republican nomination and deliver your speech, or will the event be held elsewhere? [SEP] We're working on a dynamic plan that will showcase the strength and unity of the Republican Party. Stay tuned for more details.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the global economic uncertainty following the Brexit vote, Mr. President, what specific measures are you prepared to implement to stabilize markets and ensure a smooth transition, and will the UK be prioritized for a trade deal with the US? [SEP] Look, the markets fluctuate, they always do. We're keeping a close eye on things, of course. As for the UK, they're old friends, but they've got their own mess to sort out first. We'll see what happens, but America first, always.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. So the deal that was just passed does nothing to make you want to step back from that raid? [SEP] Well that's different. That's humanitarian—no that's a different—that's humanitarian. We needed that just to take care—because we're running now hospitals. I mean the Border Patrol—these are incredible people—they're doing what they—you know nobody ever thought they were going to be doing this.And people are coming up—the reason people are coming up is because we're doing so well as a country. In past years we weren't doing well. In past years Mexico was doing better. You know they took 32 percent of our car business. They were doing better than we were doing in the past. Now we're the hot country in the world and people are coming up because they want a piece of that action.And the other reason children are coming up is because we had a separation policy. Okay? Under President Obama we had separation. President Obama built those cells. They were in 2014. They were built. They all said Oh look how horrible. Then it turned out that it was built by President Obama. And I'm not blaming anybody. I'm not blaming him.I just say this: They had a separation policy. Right? I ended it. But when I ended it I put out a statement: I think it's going to bring more children up because you're ending it. You're saying now the child can stay with the parent. So I said ending it is nice in one way but in terms of what we're doing it makes it even tougher.But the really bad thing is the cartels—and I really think that Mexico—because you know they did 6000; now they're doing 16000 on our border—I think that Mexico is looking to swamp the cartels. And those kind of numbers will do it. It would be a great thing. What Mexico is doing for us is great.By the way without the tariffs they wouldn't have done it folks. We've been after—we've been after them for many years to do it.But they have really so far—it's only a week—the numbers are way down. And so far a lot of good things have happened.Yes sir. Please. Yes please. In the second row.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with hundreds of billions already committed, how will the average American know if these economic programs are truly effective? What specific benchmarks – stock market performance, foreclosure rates, unemployment figures – should they be tracking, and what's a realistic timeline for seeing positive change? And, if these measures fall short, is there a 'Plan B' ready to be implemented? [SEP] Look, the bottom line is jobs. If people are working, they're spending, businesses are investing, and that's how we get the economy moving again. Next, we gotta get the credit flowing. Too many good businesses can't get loans. And finally, we need to fix the housing market. We're working with the Fed and the FDIC to stop foreclosures and get housing values back on track. If we stop losing jobs and start growing again, that's how we know we're winning. This year's gonna be tough, but I'm hoping that next year we'll start seeing some real progress.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, isn't it true that you're only targeting Democratic-run cities? Is this just a political move? [SEP] The truth is, the cities in trouble are all run by Democrats. You've got these radical-left Democrats running places like Chicago and so many others. That's just the way it is. Look at Chicago. Mayor Lightfoot sent me a letter, and I think they want our help. They'll want us to go in full blast eventually, but right now we're sending extra people to help out. We're arresting a lot of bad guys. And about the coronavirus, I think we've done great things. Compare our numbers to other countries, and you'll see some very impressive results for the United States, especially going forward.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, when will the shortage of essential items like hand sanitizer be resolved? And what's the status of a potential bailout for the cruise industry? Is it still being considered, and what's the potential price tag? [SEP] Well, I wouldn't say I suggested a bailout, but the cruise industry has been greatly impacted by the virus. It's a great industry, a very important industry, and we will be helping them. And we'll be helping the airline industry, if we have to – assuming we have to. So far, they haven't asked. But if they do, we want to make sure our airlines are very strong. It's interesting, I was just talking to Doug, and their retail numbers are doing great – I guess because of this, your business is like the opposite. All of you have done – you've been selling a lot of stuff. Doug, would you like to answer the question about hand sanitizers? Sure. Yes, specifically the areas where we're seeing pressure in the supply chain are surface cleaners, cleaning supplies, paper goods, in particular. Hand sanitizer is going to be very difficult to have a hundred percent in stock on for some time. We're still replenishing it and shipping it, but as soon as it hits the stores, it's going. The same thing is true for the categories I just mentioned. So all of the retailers will be working hand in hand with the suppliers to bring that to the market as fast as we can.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, Russia announced it will 'fundamentally scale back' military operations near Kyiv. Do you see this as a sign the war is ending, or a ploy to regroup? [SEP] Time will tell. I'm not drawing any conclusions until I see their actions. We'll see if they follow through. Negotiations are ongoing in Turkey and elsewhere. I met with the leaders of France, Germany, the UK, and we agreed to wait and see what they offer. In the meantime, we'll maintain strong sanctions and continue providing military aid to Ukraine. We'll keep a close watch on the situation. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, to be clear, what specific legislative changes are you demanding from Congress in exchange for a DACA fix? [SEP] We're looking at a lot of things, a lot of different options. We want to do what's right for the DACA recipients, but we also have to think about the country as a whole. We need to end chain migration, we need to end the visa lottery, and we need to build the wall. These are all important things.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, the shift of the G-8 summit from Chicago to Camp David has sparked questions. What new factors influenced this decision after Chicago was initially selected? And how significant were security concerns in this change? [SEP] Well, keep in mind, folks, that we're still gathering a whole host of world leaders. The NATO summit remains a key event. Historically, we've aimed to align the G-8 summit with the NATO summit to streamline travel for the leaders involved. We did this last year in France, and we're continuing the trend. The notion of Camp David arose after the initial planning for the NATO summit. It was suggested that I hadn't yet hosted my counterparts at Camp David during my tenure. The G-8 tends to foster a more relaxed environment where we can engage in informal discussions on various topics. We believed that a more casual setting would be conducive to productive dialogue. The weather should be favorable at that time. It will also afford me the opportunity to engage with Mr. Putin, the new Russian President. Subsequently, we will proceed to Chicago. I maintain full confidence in Chicago's ability to handle security matters. They have demonstrated expertise in managing large-scale events such as Taste of Chicago, Lollapalooza, and Bulls championships. I trust that your new mayor will be attentive to detail in ensuring a seamless experience.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, could you clarify what aspects of these Federal Government training programs, designed to promote inclusivity and address biases, you consider to be 'un-American'? [SEP] We are currently preparing a comprehensive report on this matter. Those individuals responsible have been terminated; their actions were, frankly, unacceptable. We will provide you with a detailed report that I believe you will find satisfactory. Next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I also have a question for the Prime Minister, but if I could address the President first.Sarah brought up the Russia investigation. Your legal team, sources have told us, believes that, in the next few weeks, the Special Counsel Robert Mueller will ask for some sort of an interview with you, your legal team believes, as part of wrapping up his investigation. Are you open to meeting with him? Would you be willing to meet with him without condition? Or would you demand that a strict set of parameters be placed around any encounter between you and the Special Counsel? [SEP] Well, again, John, there has been no collusion between the Trump campaign and Russians, or Trump and Russians. No collusion. When I watch you interviewing all the people leaving their committees—I mean, the Democrats are all running for office, and they're trying to say this, that. But bottom line, they all say there's no collusion.
