And there is no collusion.And when you talk about interviews, Hillary Clinton had an interview where she wasn't sworn in, she wasn't given the oath, they didn't take notes, they didn't record, and it was done on the Fourth of July weekend. That's perhaps ridiculous, and a lot of people looked upon that as being a very serious breach. And it really was.But again, I'll speak to attorneys. I can only say this: There was absolutely no collusion. Everybody knows it. Every committee—I've been in office now for 11 months. For 11 months, they've had this phony cloud over this administration, over our Government. And it has hurt our Government. It does hurt our Government.It's a Democrat hoax that was brought up as an excuse for losing an election that, frankly, the Democrats should have won because they have such a tremendous advantage in the electoral college. So it was brought up for that reason. But it has been determined that there is no collusion and by virtually everybody. So we'll see what happens.
label: Dodging

sentence: President Bush, the election results in Pakistan suggest a significant shift in public sentiment. How will the United States adapt its strategy in the region, particularly concerning counterterrorism efforts, in light of these developments? [SEP] The Pakistani people spoke, and that's a good thing. Musharraf held elections like he promised. Now, it's up to the new leaders to step up. Pakistan is an important ally. We have common goals. We need to stop the radicals who threaten us both. And about Africa, America's got the resources to help. It's in our interest. We're all connected in this world. If we don't help Africa, their problems will become our problems. We need to fight terrorism together, everywhere.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Venezuela, despite the sanctions and aid, Maduro's regime persists. Are you worried about losing momentum, and what's the projected timeline for a change in leadership? [SEP] Nobody's giving me a hard date. They've been running the show for a while now, both him and his predecessor. Eventually, things will shift. But we haven't really unleashed the full force of sanctions yet. We have that option. All options are on the table, believe me. We've only implemented sanctions that are somewhat moderate. We can escalate significantly if necessary. It's a tragedy, and we're simply trying to assist the people who are starving and dying in the streets. What's unfolding there is a disgrace. It was once one of the wealthiest nations on Earth, and now it's a disaster. No food, no water, no air conditioning, no power. The power was out for an extended period last week, and it's likely to recur because it's barely functioning. It's deeply disheartening, Roberta. Truly disheartening to witness.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: But wouldn't the U.S. have more influence within the organization if it were a member? [SEP] Influence comes from strength. We're using our strength to demand change. We're not going to be a patsy for an organization that isn't serving its purpose. We'll see what happens.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, you've repeatedly urged Americans to get vaccinated, even appealing to reluctant Republicans. However, the lack of vaccine access for children under 5 remains a concern. Can you address the frustration of parents and explain why this delay persists, and when they might finally have access? [SEP] The simple answer is that the science isn't there yet. The experts aren't convinced it's safe enough. That's what they're working on right now. You could have asked me this same question a few months ago about kids aged 7 to 12. They eventually reached a point where they were confident in the number of tests they'd conducted and the results they'd seen, and they felt it was safe. So, it will happen. It's just a matter of time. But I'm not a scientist; I can't give you a specific date. But it's absolutely vital that we get to that next stage.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the leak of the Hadley memo before your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki, did you or your Chief of Staff initiate an investigation? Furthermore, if unauthorized, do you suspect internal sabotage of your Iraq policy or the meeting itself? [SEP] Let me see... Did I order an investigation? I'm not sure I did. I definitely voiced concerns about the leaks, though. You folks are good at digging up info and sharing it, which I get. But leaking classified stuff is a problem. It's a constant issue, not just for us, but for any administration trying to shape the country's future. We've had a lot of leaks, some from who-knows-where, so I won't guess. Finding the leaker is tough. It's part of your job, I guess. We can complain, but it's hard to find the insiders giving documents to the press. There might be an investigation going on; I just don't know. If there is, it's not top of mind. But it'd be good to catch whoever's leaking classified info and hold them accountable. Maybe that'd stop future leaks.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, do you believe the perceived tepidness of your welcome here is tied to the shortcomings of your Asia pivot? Furthermore, with Guantanamo still operational and only four months remaining in your term, will you concede defeat on closing it? [SEP] My reception has been fantastic, from what I can see. The people of Laos seem quite pleased. Vietnam was incredible, with millions greeting us. So, if this theory about my reception and the rebalance policy hinges on the short stairs in China, that's an exaggeration. Any reasonable person would find that puzzling. Leaders and ordinary people appreciate our work on economic and development programs, war legacy issues, and civil society. Their concern is whether it will continue. My successor should maintain this engagement, given the dynamic populations and growing economies here. Regarding Guantanamo, I won't concede it will remain open. We're working to reduce the population. It's a recruitment tool for terrorists, hinders counterterrorism cooperation, and is unnecessary and costly. Congress resists, but with only 40 or 50 people left, we should question why we're spending millions when it's not essential for our security.
label: General

sentence: President Bush, what specific accomplishments, if any, came out of the Baghdad regional conference, and what are your expectations for future rounds? Furthermore, do you consider the statements from Iran and Syria expressing their willingness to help stabilize Iraq to be genuine, and if so, would you consider opening channels for more formal direct contact with those nations? [SEP] I'm the kind of guy who likes to see actions speak louder than words. Talk is cheap in politics and international relations. If they really want to help Iraq, there are concrete things they can do, like stopping the flow of weapons and suicide bombers. We welcome their statements, but their actions will tell us if they're serious. The conference was beneficial because it got regional players to publicly commit to supporting Iraq's young democracy. That's a positive thing. Also, the Iraqi government gained confidence from engaging with nations from around the world in a constructive way. Iraq's success depends on its government's ability to make tough decisions. They're transitioning from tyranny to democracy quickly, and the conference will help them reconcile their differences. The momentum from the first meeting should carry over to future ones. Secretary Rice will be at the next meeting, which shows a higher level of commitment. She'll push an agenda that supports Iraq's democracy and work with other nations to make it happen.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, will your response to the Sony hack be something we can watch on Netflix? [SEP] My movie preferences are irrelevant. The key point is that North Korea attacked a U.S. company because they didn't like a movie. We will respond appropriately, but I won't telegraph our plans. We also need to address the broader issue of cybersecurity.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Can you detail the specific steps you want these companies to take? [SEP] Insurance companies? They've raked it in with Obamacare, a total bonanza. I ended those payments, those huge monthly payouts straight to them, and I'm happy about it. Now, people are talking – Democrats and Republicans – about a short-term solution to provide decent healthcare without those crazy price jumps. You've seen them already. And prescription drugs – I didn't talk to Mitch about this today – that's a priority. We're slashing those prices. Drug companies give tons of money to politicians, maybe even Mitch. I don't need their cash. You go to other countries, and the exact same pill costs almost nothing. We're going to change that.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Looking ahead to the Supreme Court confirmation hearings of your choice, Elena Kagan, tomorrow, first of all, what do you say to the critics who are portraying her as a politically motivated liberal? And given your own support when you were in the Senate for a filibuster of a Supreme Court nominee, what's your guidance to Republicans who may be threatening that at this point? [SEP] I think they should pay attention to Elena Kagan's record and her testimony. Under our constitutional system, the Senate is entrusted with the process of providing advice and consent, and I am absolutely confident that if you give a fair reading of Elena Kagan's record and her performance in every job that she's had, what you see is somebody with an extraordinarily powerful intellect; somebody with good judgment; somebody who understands the impact that laws have on individual Americans; somebody who's able to broker understandings between people of very difficult ideological bents; somebody who is extremely hard-working, extremely diligent, extremely personable; knows how to build consensus; has been an outstanding lawyer; has been an outstanding dean of one of our top law schools--notice, even though it's my alma mater, I just said one of--has performed brilliantly as Solicitor General; and has the support, by the way, of a number of very conservative jurists who she's worked with.So as I examine some of the arguments that have been floated against her nomination over the last several weeks, it's pretty thin gruel. Now, having said that, I expect that my Republican colleagues and my Democratic colleagues should ask her tough questions, listen to her testimony, go through the record, go through all the documents that have been provided to the Senate Judiciary Committee, and then vote their conscience.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the Attorney General has admitted to mistakes in the firing of U.S. Attorneys. Given the bipartisan loss of confidence in him, how can he effectively lead the Justice Department moving forward, and do you still have full faith in his leadership? [SEP] Look, I spoke with Al this morning, and he understands the need to address Congress directly and clarify the facts surrounding these decisions. He acknowledged that mistakes were made, and frankly, I'm not pleased about it. There's been a lot of confusion regarding a customary practice: U.S. Attorneys serve at the pleasure of the President, and past administrations have exercised their right to remove them. The Justice Department recommended a list, and I believe their reasons were appropriate. However, the handling of this matter has led to these questions, even here in Mexico. Al recognizes the need to correct the record on Capitol Hill. I appreciate his willingness to take action, because clear and accurate communication with Congress is essential. The fact that both Republicans and Democrats feel there was a lack of transparency is concerning to both of us, and he's committed to addressing those concerns.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, with two years passed and Guantanamo still open, what happened to your promise to close it? [SEP] Well, we haven't closed it yet. The reason I wanted to close Guantanamo was to keep Americans safe. Guantanamo is a recruiting tool for terrorists. They use it on their websites and in their messages. I believe we can keep Americans safe and go after terrorists. My administration has been aggressive in going after Al Qaida. They are more hunkered down than they have been since 2001. They have reduced financing and operational capacity. It is important to live up to our values. Closing Guantanamo is about that. It's become a symbol. We can house them somewhere else. I won't comment on a review I haven't received yet. We've been trying to put our battle against terrorists within a legal structure. One of the toughest problems is what to do with dangerous people who are enemies of the United States, but it is difficult to try them. Releasing them could create greater danger. We need to make sure these folks have lawyers and can challenge their detention, but we are not releasing folks who could do us harm. Striking this balance between our security and our values is not easy. The more people are reminded of what makes America special, the more powerful we are. I want to make sure that we don't lose that weapon.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, considering this is your third budget and your willingness to be a one-term President if needed, why aren't you actively engaging Republicans in negotiations now? What specific actions are you taking to promote bipartisan cooperation? And do you anticipate the markets will remain stable for the next two years? [SEP] Goodness gracious, Jackie, I needed a notepad for all that! My brain is at capacity.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea, while you've confirmed their involvement in the hack and are considering options, what specific criteria will you use to determine whether the response is 'proportional and appropriate,' and what measures will be taken to avoid escalating tensions in the region? [SEP] We've confirmed North Korea was behind it, and we're looking at options. I'll decide what's proportional and appropriate. As for Cuba, a visit isn't in the cards right now. Maybe someday I'll get to visit and interact with the Cuban people, but there's nothing specific planned.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. A question going out to His Excellency, President Bush. With regards to removing North Korea from the terrorism list, we understand that beginning on the 12th, North Korea might be able to be removed from the list. When do you expect, Mr. Bush, President Bush, that North Korea may be removed from the list? Are there any preconditions or is there anything that North Korea must do for them to be removed from the list of state sponsors of terrorism? [SEP] Yes. The 12th is the first opportunity where they may be lifted off the list. And, yes, they got a lot to do. They got to, like, show us a verification regime that we can trust. This is a stepby-step process.I don't know whether or not they're going to give up their weapons. I really don't know. I don't think either of us knows. I know this, that the six-party talks is the best way to convince them to give up their weapons. I know there's a framework in place that will make it easier for those of us who care about this issue to work together to send a common message to the leader: You have a choice to make: You can verifiably do what you say you're going to do, or you'll continue to be the most sanctioned regime in the world.We have put out a step-by-step process to—as a way forward for the n leader. This isn't a U.S. proposal; this is a five-party proposal. South Korea has been a very integral part of the process, and they will remain an integral part of the process. We're all at the table together, saying the same thing.And so part of the step-by-step was to say, okay, if you do the following things like you said you would do, you get off the terrorist list. That could conceivably happen, as you mentioned, on the 12th. However, it's going to require action on the leader of 's part. It just doesn't automatically happen.We changed the way it used to be. It used to be that—okay, we'll give you something and hope that you end up responding. It's no longer that way. The six-party talks basically says, you have made a promise; once you fulfill your promise, then something will happen positively. And so I— we'll see. It's his choice to make as to whether or not he gets to come off the list. If he is off the list, I want to remind you that he'll still be—they will still be the most sanctioned country in the world.And so then the fundamental question is, do they want to continue on and try to change the status? Do they want to try to change their isolation? Do they want to enter the community of nations? Do they want to be viewed as a peaceful country? And so there's a series of steps that we've all agreed to, including , that it's up to them to make the decision as to how they'll proceed.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Have you seen any evidence that Russia or China intervened in yesterday's election? [SEP] Well, we've going—we're going to make a full report. And unlike the previous administration, we've done a lot of work on that issue. And if you look—speak with the FBI, speak with the Department of Justice, speak to Homeland Security, we've spent a lot of time. It gets very little coverage in the papers. I mean, you cover the nonsense part, but you don't cover the important. This is very important.And we have been working very hard on China and Russia and everybody else looking into our elections or meddling with our elections. But people tend not to write about it. But we have worked very hard, as you probably heard.
label: General

sentence: Q. President Bush, concerning missile defense, how will you ensure transparency with Poland and the Czech Republic? [SEP] We're still working on missile defense. Our U.S. partners get our concerns and are trying to fix them. I'm cautiously optimistic about deals. It's all in the details; experts need to agree on confidence-building stuff and how to make it work. Working together on a global missile defense system is what we want. If we can work together in our area and then around the world, that's good for us. Russia's worried the system's aimed at them, so they'll do something about it. I think it's defense, not offense. We gotta show the experts it's not aimed at Russia, but to deal with threats we all face. As for the Czech Republic and Poland, their leaders need to see Russia as a friend, not an enemy. We'll sort things out. Transparency means being open, not just giving briefings. I'm happy to share tech and info to show it's for single/dual-launch threats, not Russia's power. We've come a long way since we started talking. This plan helps America and Russia.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the general's remarks about a major conflict, what specific aspects of that potential war are you referencing? [SEP] This 'big war' you mention, can you define its parameters?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, yesterday, at the speech at the U.N., you spoke about how Venezuela's problem was because of Cuba and the Castros, how they went in there, and they brought socialism and communism to Venezuela and now to Nicaragua as well.Mr. President, are you going to be more proactive now against Cuba as well? [SEP] I've been very proactive against Cuba. I don't like what's happening in Cuba. As you know, President Obama gave them a pass, and I didn't like it. Neither do Cuban people based in Miami and based in our country that came from Cuba and suffered in Cuba.I don't like what he did. I've ended much of it, most of it. I don't like what's happening in Cuba, and I certainly don't like what's happening in Venezuela.Yes, please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Does that concern you, Mr. President? [SEP] I believe I've addressed that sufficiently. Next question, please. Mary Bruce, ABC News.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the situation in Mexico – the human rights violations, the drug war, the threats to President Calderon, and the visa complications – what is your response? [SEP] Unfortunately, I didn't receive a translation of that question. [] But it sounded like a very important one. [] I think the translation is arriving now. Please, go ahead.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, even with the sanctions and aid, Maduro remains in power. Are you concerned about losing traction, and what's the expected timeframe for a resolution? [SEP] There's no fixed timeline. This has been a protracted situation. Ultimately, things will shift. We haven't yet enacted the harshest sanctions, but we're exploring all avenues. Our priority is the well-being of the Venezuelan people. It's a disgrace to see a once-affluent country in such a desperate condition.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. One follow-up on that, sir. It's designed to improve trust in the vaccine. Do you think that's not needed? [SEP] Well, I have tremendous trust in these massive companies that are so brilliantly organized, in terms of what they've been doing with the tests. I mean, I don't know that a government, as big as we are, could do tests like this. We've made it possible for them to do the tests in rapid fashion.But when they come back, and they say that we have something that works and absolutely works, and they're coming back with great numbers and statistics and tests and everything else that they have to come back with, I don't see any reason why it should be delayed further. Because if they delay it a week or 2 weeks or 3 weeks, you know, that's a lot of lives you're talking about.Scott, would you agree with that or how do you feel about that? Please, Scott. Yes, thanks. Yes, I mean there is no—I think that people don't understand what's going on with Operation Warp Speed. It's unprecedented what's happened here.A typical vaccine takes roughly 4 years or so, and now we're going to have a vaccine—highly likely—in far less than 1 year, but without cutting any safety corners, because the President has done things concomitant to the development of the vaccine: that is, the manufacturing and the logistics. Everything is being done at the same time, and that's never been done before.But there is zero cutting of safety concerns. There is—there should be no hesitation about the safety. You shouldn't be punished by doing something faster than other people could have done or thought; it's the opposite. We have a pandemic. The urgency is the pandemic, not politics.
label: General

sentence: President Bush, with Israel contemplating military intervention in Iran, what message do you have for them, and what specific steps will the U.S. take to address climate change, considering the absence of a binding international accord? [SEP] Let me be clear: We don't want Iran to have a nuclear weapon. It's a threat to peace. And Israel has the right to defend itself. On climate change, we're working hard to find solutions that work for America. We want to protect our environment, but we also want to protect our economy. We're not going to sign any deal that hurts American jobs.
label: Implicit

sentence: You've mentioned your 'microphone' is now more effective in addressing domestic priorities like Social Security and immigration, despite previous efforts falling short. With the Democratic Congress now in power, how do you intend to amplify your message and achieve different results? [SEP] By 'loud microphone,' I mean I can draw attention to important issues. That's what a President does. But to get things done, we need bipartisan cooperation, which the election results made clear. We've had some legislative successes. We reformed Medicare, put in place tax policies that encourage growth, passed trade initiatives, and an energy bill. I'm signing another energy bill today, extending tax credits for R&D. It's a pretty good record. However, with the Democrats now controlling Congress, we need a new approach. I'll work with their leaders and our own to find common ground on key issues like Social Security and immigration. We must get comprehensive immigration reform done this year. To secure our border, Border Patrol needs a plan that allows people to come here legally to do jobs Americans aren't doing. Recent enforcement actions at packing plants showed that many illegal workers were using forged documents. This system forces people to rely on smugglers and forgers. It's inhumane. The best way to enforce our borders humanely is with a comprehensive bill. I've proposed a plan and spoken about it from the Oval Office. The 'microphone' is necessary to call people to action. I want to work with both Republicans and Democrats. On energy, we can also work together. There's agreement that we need to continue researching alternative forms of energy. We're making progress. I'm looking forward to working with them. Some say that because I lost Congress, nothing will get done. I disagree. I want to get things done, and the Democratic leaders want to show they're worthy of their leadership roles. We can find common ground without either of us compromising our principles. The American people are sick of the partisanship. I'll do my part to elevate the tone. I was Governor of Texas with a Democratic legislature, and we got a lot of constructive things done. I believe it's possible here too.
label: General

sentence: Given the recent controversies, are you worried about equitable access to voting for all citizens? [SEP] I understand the process went smoothly in Georgia. However, these matters are under the purview of state authorities. Direct your inquiries to them. Please proceed.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Are you getting all the intelligence and information you need from the Russians? And should Americans be worried when they go to big, public events now? [SEP] The Russians have been very cooperative with us since the Boston bombing. Obviously, old habits die hard; there's still suspicions sometimes between our intelligence and law enforcement agencies that date back 10, 20, 30 years, back to the cold war. But they're continually improving. I've spoken to President Putin directly. He's committed to working with me to make sure that those who report to us are cooperating fully in not only this investigation, but how do we work on counterterrorism issues generally.In terms of whatthe response of the American people, I think everybody can take a cue from Boston. You don't get a sense that anybody is intimidated when they go to Fenway Park a couple days after the bombing. There are joggers right now, I guarantee you, all throughout Boston and Cambridge and Watertown. And I think one of the things that I've been most proud of in watching the country's response to the terrible tragedy there, is a sense of resilience and toughness. And we're not going to be intimidated. We are going to live our lives.And people, I think, understand that we've got to do everything we can to prevent these kinds of attacks from taking place, but people also understandin the same way they understand after a shooting in Aurora or Newtown or Virginia Tech or after the foiled attempts in Times Square or in Detroitthat we're not going to stop living our lives because warped, twisted individuals try to intimidate us. We're going to do what we do, which is go to work, raise our kids, go to ball games, run in marathons. And at the same time, we're going to make sure that everybody is cooperating and is vigilant in doing everything we can, without being naive, to try to prevent these attacks from happening in the future.Jonathan Karl [ABC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Is there a transcript of your conversation, your private conversation? [SEP] Mike, do they have a transcript? They probably have a rough transcript, which you can give us, if you have one.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Brexit vote and its potential global economic consequences, what actions will you take to reassure the markets and encourage a swift resolution? Do you still believe the UK should be at the back of the queue for a US trade deal? And will you actively promote the TPP while campaigning for Secretary Clinton? [SEP] Roberta, those are excellent questions. I'll even help my friends out a bit on that last one. When I visit other countries, it's not my place to comment on candidates in the middle of a race. Governments tend to transcend whoever is in power. With respect to Brexit, the markets seem to have settled down a bit. We're monitoring for any systemic strains. Central banks and our Treasury Secretary have prepared well. There are longer-term concerns about global growth if Brexit freezes investment in Great Britain or Europe. We need to boost global demand. Whether it's the US improving infrastructure, or Germany spending more, or China shifting to domestic-based growth. With respect to Brexit negotiations, my message is: everyone should catch their breath, come up with an orderly, transparent plan. Both sides have a stake in getting this right. Leadership issues in Great Britain will need to be resolved quickly. Chancellor Merkel's interest is in making sure the process works. We'll help in any way we can. As for the UK and a trade agreement, they'll be the least of their problems right now. Their first order of business is Europe. But the special relationship with Great Britain doesn't change. The ties are deep and long-lasting. Our relationship with the UK fundamentally doesn't change. Their absence from the EU makes it harder to solve other challenges. Our relationship goes far deeper than any individual leaders. Canada, the US, and Mexico will continue to have close relationships. I look forward to working with whomever the American people elect as their President. I know we will always be able to find shared priorities. My Government will respect fully the domestic electoral process in the United States. We are facing a global reality. We have a populist world, an interconnected world with its own challenges. In the world we're living, in different places, we have political leaders, political stakeholders that use demagoguery and have the populistic slogans that want to eliminate and destroy what has been built, what has taken decades to build to go back to problems of the past. And yes, it is true, all the benefits have not reached society as we whole. That is true. But those leaderships, those political actors, by using populism and demagoguery, they choose the easiest way to solve the challenges of today's world. And things are not that simplistic. It's not as easy as that. To lead a country, to take on a responsibility to rule a country, it goes beyond giving the easiest answer. It is complex and it is difficult to lead a country.We have reached so far—the level of development, the level of well-being that we have in the world—without a doubt makes contrast with what the situation that we lived 30 years back. Never before a global society—or the societies, at least, of our three countries—had lived the level of development and well-being that we enjoy today. Never before had our countries had a high life expectancy as we have today. Never before had we had the opportunity to have access to the knowledge of the world as fast and as easy as we do today. Never before were in such a level of connection between society and the possibility of having access to any product from any corner of the world as we do today. And that was built throughout the years by using the model based on openness, free trade, trade agreements.And the biggest challenge today is to make sure that those benefits reach out to every single citizen. But the solution proposed by some is not by destroying what we have been built, it is not taking a different route to choose the road towards isolationism and destruction. What we need to do is to keep up the pace towards development. And when I said that, I mentioned that most of what some people say, it is very similar that in the past—and President Obama already said it, even years back—but in the past, some leaders addressed their societies in those terms. Hitler and Mussolini did that. And the outcome, it's clear to everyone: It resulted in devastation, and it turned out to be a tragedy for mankind.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. ----military, U.S. military could secure this nuclear arsenal? [SEP] I'm not going to engage in hypotheticals of that sort. I feel confident that that nuclear arsenal will remain out of militant hands. Okay?Jeff Mason [Reuters].
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, your visit to Benin is unprecedented. But some are calling it a 'stunt.' Is this a genuine change in the relationship between our countries, or simply a symbolic gesture? [SEP] I can offer my perspective. I am the first President to visit Benin, and I'm here to emphasize America's commitment to improving lives across Africa. We're prioritizing nations that invest in their people, fight corruption, and build market economies. This visit is a reminder that supporting such nations is in our national and moral interest, even if we haven't always had strong ties. We're shifting away from old-style grants, focusing on initiatives like the Millennium Challenge Account, which rewards good governance. Benin has met the criteria. This visit signifies a change in relationship, driven by Benin's commitment to its people. We're here to support virtuous nations striving for prosperity and good governance.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, isn't it true that these election results are a clear sign that the country is moving away from your policies? Do you think this reflects a changing America? [SEP] Let's be clear, the numbers tell a different story. Look at the employment rates for African Americans, Asian Americans, and Hispanic Americans – they're at record highs. My approval ratings with these communities are also the best they've ever been, according to recent polls. Median income is up, and overall, the economy is thriving. The polls reflect this positive trend.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, could you provide some insight into the Al-Qaeda intelligence report? [SEP] I beg your pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, the public is demonstrably confused by the government's coronavirus response, particularly regarding mask usage and testing procedures. Given this confusion, why did you express satisfaction with your team to Jeff Zeleny? Why are you hesitant to implement changes at the CDC or other relevant agencies? [SEP] The evolving scientific understanding of the virus is the primary reason for any perceived confusion. Scientists are continuously learning and adjusting their recommendations accordingly. The CDC's communication strategies have been a subject of scrutiny. However, these are scientists adapting to an unprecedented situation. This is analogous to historical public health challenges, such as polio, where initial recommendations underwent revisions. This is a novel virus, a novel phenomenon. It's a continuous process of scientific discovery. We should also acknowledge the remarkable feat of developing a vaccine in record time. It saved countless lives. Did we achieve perfection in every aspect of the response? Certainly not.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given your earlier statement, do you believe your comments influenced his decision to retreat? [SEP] Well, I'm just observing. It's curious, isn't it? The media, you all, are finally catching on to what I've been saying all along. Biden's policies, they're extreme. It's almost as if you're just now realizing it. Fascinating, really.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the Federal Reserve plays a crucial role in our economy. Given the upcoming vacancy at the Chair, and the potential for multiple open seats, what specific qualifications and priorities are you prioritizing in your nominee(s) to ensure stability and continued economic growth? [SEP] Well, as you know, the selection of the Federal Reserve Chair is a very important decision. We're taking it very seriously. The process is underway, and we're considering a number of highly qualified candidates. We'll be making an announcement soon. I'm confident that we'll find someone who is committed to maintaining price stability and promoting full employment. We're looking for someone with a deep understanding of the economy and a proven track record of sound judgment.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, after your discussions with Chairman Kim, did you glean any new information about him? Also, concerning the events unfolding in Washington, your former lawyer, Michael Cohen, who worked closely with you for 10 years, has publicly labeled you a liar, a conman, and a racist. How do you respond to these accusations? [SEP] Well, that's simply incorrect. And it's quite fascinating, because I tried to watch as much as I could. I couldn't watch too much, though, because I've been rather occupied. But I think having a fake hearing like that and having it in the middle of this very important summit is really a terrible thing. They could've made it 2 days later or next week, and it would've been even better. They would've had more time. But having it during this very important summit is sort of incredible. And he lied a lot, but it was very interesting, because he didn't lie about one thing. He said no collusion with the Russian hoax. And I said, I wonder why he didn't just lie about that, too, like he did about everything else? I mean, he lied about so many different things, and I was actually impressed that he didn't say, Well, I think there was collusion for this reason or that. He didn't say that. He said, No collusion. And I was, you know, a little impressed by that, frankly. Could've—he could've gone all out. He only went about 95 percent instead of 100 percent. But the fact is, there is no collusion. And I call it the witch hunt. This should never happen to another President. This is so bad for our country. So bad. You look at this whole hoax, it's a—I call it the Russian witch hunt and now add the word hoax. It's a very, very bad thing for our country. But I was impressed with the fact that he—when—you know, because the most important question up there was the one on collusion. And he said he saw no collusion. So we'll see what happens. But it was pretty shameful, I think. Yes, ma'am. Please. Please.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Maduro is still in charge despite the sanctions and aid. Are you worried about losing steam, and what's the projected timeline for a solution? [SEP] We don't have a specific timeframe. This has been a long-term issue. Change will happen eventually. We haven't yet deployed the most severe sanctions, but we're considering all possibilities. We're focused on the plight of the Venezuelan people. It's heartbreaking to see a once-prosperous nation in such a state of crisis.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, after spending time with President Zelenskyy, what specific insights did you glean from the face-to-face interaction that you couldn't have obtained through remote communication? Additionally, did your discussions include U.S. intelligence assessments regarding the likelihood of Russian escalation after the delivery of the Patriot missile system? [SEP] Permit me to respond to the first aspect of your question. As I've often stated, personal engagement is of utmost importance. There is no substitute for direct interaction, regardless of whether one is dealing with a friend or an opponent. That is precisely what occurred today, and we shall persist in this approach. As winter descends, Putin is intensifying his attacks on civilian targets, including women, children, and orphanages. His behavior is abhorrent, and ultimately, he will be unsuccessful. He has already failed in his primary objective of seizing control of all of Ukraine, as the Ukrainian populace will never embrace his authority. It was imperative to convey to the global community that President Zelenskyy and I stand united. I assess leaders based on their pronouncements, their steadfastness, and their capacity to maintain direct eye contact. President Zelenskyy embodies the principles he advocates and is willing to make the ultimate sacrifice for his country. We are dedicated to providing him with our unwavering support. Thank you. Now, if you would be so kind as to remind me, what was the second element of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, about Prime Minister Maliki's visit to Iran, and the reports that he lauded Iran's 'positive and constructive stance', do you agree with your Iraqi counterparts on Iran? What message does this send to our allies and Americans who are worried about the Prime Minister's role? [SEP] I must admit, I haven't personally reviewed those reports. I'd rather receive a comprehensive briefing from our embassy, who will undoubtedly consult with the Prime Minister, before offering a definitive evaluation. It would be premature for me to speculate without all the relevant information. Typically, diplomatic engagements necessitate a certain level of civility, so I wouldn't necessarily interpret a friendly photograph as indicative of deeper alignment.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, the American people have already seen hundreds of billions spent, and the economy is still in a free fall. Beyond preventing a national catastrophe, how can the average citizen measure the success of your programs? Should they look at the stock market, foreclosures, or unemployment? What metrics are key, and when will we know if Plan A is working, or if we need a Plan B? [SEP] Look, the most immediate indicator is job creation, plain and simple. Saving or creating 4 million jobs is the first benchmark. When people are employed, they have the confidence to spend, to invest. Businesses see that consumer confidence and start investing themselves, which leads to more hiring. So, job creation is priority number one. Secondly, are the credit markets functioning properly? I hear from countless successful businesses that can't access credit. In Elkhart, Indiana, the RV capital, customers with good credit can't get RV loans, and businesses can't get loans to pay their suppliers. Normalizing the credit markets is crucial. Thirdly, housing: have we stabilized the market? The Federal Government doesn't have complete control, but our plan, in conjunction with the Federal Reserve and the FDIC, aims to slow foreclosures and stabilize housing values. Ultimately, success is measured by stopping contraction and job losses, and starting to grow again. I don't have a crystal ball, and this is an unprecedented crisis. But I hope that after a difficult year, businesses will start investing again, and consumers will feel secure enough to spend. If we do things right, we should see significant improvement next year. Now, who's next?
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, given the swirling rumors, can you definitively state whether you've entertained the idea of preemptive pardons for any of your staff? And, if so, what's your current stance? [SEP] Pardons are not on the agenda for today's discussion.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Roxham Road agreement, after a year of preparation, why the delay? And concerning the 15,000 migrants Canada will accept, why such a limited number? What concessions were made to the U.S. in return? [SEP] Well, look, the situation with Roxham Road was complex. Simply shutting it down wasn't a viable solution; it would have just pushed the problem elsewhere along our extensive border. So, we chose to modernize the Safe Third Country Agreement to ensure a consistent approach for asylum seekers crossing between official points. This was always the theoretical solution, but implementing it required navigating complex border management processes. It took time, but it protects the integrity of the system and upholds our obligations to asylum seekers. We're also increasing the number of asylum seekers from the Western Hemisphere to offset the closure of these irregular crossings. As for Haiti, we are working with other countries to provide the police with the resources needed to restore order.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding American oil producers, are you satisfied they are fully exploiting all available resources, including offshore drilling? Furthermore, will you finalize an interim agreement with Prime Minister Maliki concerning American operations in Iraq, or will you defer a more comprehensive agreement to your successor? [SEP] Well, let's address Iraq first. We're actively developing a strategic framework agreement with the Iraqi government, covering various areas like diplomacy, economics, and justice. A key part of this is a security agreement. They're aiming for a swift transition to what we call 'overwatch,' where the U.S. focuses on training, logistical support, and special operations. For our troops to operate in Iraq, we need a clear understanding with the government, including operational authorities and troop protections. We're negotiating this now, aiming to conclude it before the year's end, unless the UN mandate is extended. So, there are two interconnected aspects to this agreement that we're working on simultaneously. As for the oil companies, I will have my team circle back with you on that.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Are you saying she wasn't fired? [SEP] Look, I just learned about this myself this morning, okay? I don't have all the details yet. Ken Salazar's been testifying on the Hill. What I *can* tell you is that reforms at MMS weren't happening fast enough. Now, maybe even if they *had* been, this still could have happened. This Commission needs to figure out if this was a systemic failure, or just a one-in-a-million fluke. We need to understand the risks involved. The fact that oil companies are drilling a mile underwater and then three miles *below* that tells you something about where the industry is headed. It's more expensive, it's riskier. That's why you never heard me say 'Drill, baby, drill.' We can't drill our way out of this. Oil's part of the mix, sure, but we need to transition to new technologies. The easy oil's gone. And as things get more complicated, there's going to be more risk. We need to decide what risks we're willing to take. That's what the Commission needs to look at. But we *need* oil. So, I told the Republican caucus this week, let's work together. Lieberman and Kerry, even Lindsey Graham before, had a framework that could get bipartisan support. We need oil, but we also need to change how we operate. Okay? Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But would you shape the products and services that are on offer? [SEP] I don't think that we should micromanage. But I think that like any investor, the American taxpayer has the right to scrutinize what's being proposed and to make sure that their money is not just being thrown down the drain.And so we've got to strike a balance. I don't want to be--I'm not an auto engineer, I don't know how to create a affordable, well-designed plug-in hybrid. But I know that if the Japanese can design a affordable, well-designed hybrid, then doggone it, the American people should be able to do the same. So my job is to ask the auto industry, why is it you guys can't do this? And in some cases they're starting to do it, but they've got these legacy costs. There are some terrific U.S. cars being made, both by Chrysler and GM. The question is, you know, give me a plan so that you're building off your strengths and you're projecting out to where that market is going to be.I actually think, if you look at the trends, that those auto companies that emerge from this crisis, when you start seeing the pent-up demand for autos coming back, they're going to be in a position to really do well globally, not just here in the United States. So I just want to help them get there.But I want to disabuse people of this notion that somehow we enjoy meddling in the private sector. If you could tell me right now that when I walked into this office that the banks were humming, that the autos were selling, and that all you had to worry about was , Afghanistan, North Korea, getting health care passed, figuring out how to deal with energy independence, deal with Iran, and a pandemic flu, I would take that deal. []And that's why I'm always amused when I hear these criticisms of, Oh, Obama wants to grow government. No. I would love a nice, lean portfolio to deal with, but that's not the hand that's been dealt us. And every generation has to rise up to the specific challenges that confront them. We happen to have gotten a big set of challenges, but we're not the first generation that that's happened to. And I'm confident that we're going to meet these challenges just like our grandparents and forebears met them before.All right. Thank you, everybody.
label: General

sentence: With all due respect, Madam Secretary, given the sensitivity around ongoing investigations, can you definitively state whether you or your staff have been contacted by the special counsel's office? [SEP] I appreciate the question, but at this juncture, commenting on any potential interactions with investigative bodies would be inappropriate. Our focus remains steadfastly on the work at hand.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Regarding American oil, could you restate your question? [SEP] Could you repeat the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning this contact via Twitter, some are concerned about the appropriateness of using social media for diplomatic outreach. Can you assure the public that this communication adheres to established protocols and safeguards national security interests? [SEP] Let me tell you, we're doing things differently now. We're not stuck in the old ways. We're using every tool available to us, including social media. This wasn't some formal negotiation, it was just a simple contact. We're always careful, we always protect our interests. We have the best people working on these things, and they know what they're doing. We're exploring all avenues to find solutions, and if that means using Twitter, then that's what we'll do. We're not afraid to break the mold.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Duda, in a word, Russia: friend or adversary? [SEP] Pardon me, is that intended for me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Iran sanctions, you aim to alter their government's behavior. Yet, North Korea, a nuclear power unlike Iran, hasn't changed despite sanctions. Why? [SEP] I'm not going to give you a lecture on North Korean behavior. Let's just say they've chosen a path of isolation that's hurt their people badly. We hope pressure will push them to improve their economy, rejoin talks, and change their ways. Sanctions aren't magic, but they make change more likely than if North Korea faced no consequences for testing nukes. Next question.
label: Dodging

sentence: With the shift in congressional power, many anticipate gridlock and increased political polarization. How do you plan to bridge the partisan divide and ensure that Congress can effectively address pressing issues like the economy, healthcare, and immigration? What specific concessions are you willing to make to achieve bipartisan consensus? [SEP] We're committed to working with both parties to find solutions that benefit all Americans. We believe there's common ground to be found on issues like job creation, infrastructure, and education. We're willing to consider different approaches and compromise where possible, but we won't compromise on our commitment to the middle class. We urge Republicans to put aside partisan politics and work with us to move the country forward.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, to be clear, is the U.S. position that Tedros must step down for the WHO to regain U.S. support, or are you open to other solutions? [SEP] We're investigating everything. I don't know him, but there have been problems with the WHO. They've been unfair to the U.S., like the WTO, especially with China's developing nation status. It's been a huge disadvantage for us. Why didn't other presidents deal with this? We're looking at both the WHO and WTO very carefully. It's hard to say which is worse, but we'll get to the bottom of it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President, regarding Putin, do you see any indication he's abandoning his disruptive tendencies, particularly concerning NATO and the U.S.? Furthermore, concerning the critical infrastructure list you presented, did you explicitly define the repercussions for interference, and what was his response? [SEP] Let's address the second point first. I made it plain to Mr. Putin that we have substantial cyber capabilities. He is aware of this, although he may not know the precise details. If they breach these fundamental norms, we will retaliate with cyber measures. He is cognizant of this.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: In light of the bipartisan opposition to comprehensive immigration reform, can you outline your strategy for overcoming congressional hurdles and resolving the current impasse in the Senate? [SEP] Well, the reason a consensus bill hasn't emerged in the Senate is because this is a complex issue requiring bipartisan cooperation. It's crucial to first establish a coherent Republican position in the Senate, which is where we're currently focusing our efforts. Senator Kennedy will lead the bill on the Democrat side. Once we achieve a unified Republican stance, one that most Republicans support, we'll collaborate with the Senator. Without sufficient consensus, nothing will pass the Senate, and consequently, nothing will happen in the House. Therefore, the initial stages of crafting a bill that addresses concerns are time-consuming but essential to address the issues raised during the last immigration reform debate. I'm optimistic that we can achieve something, and we're beginning to find common ground. There's broad agreement on a temporary-worker plan allowing individuals to legally come to the U.S. for jobs Americans aren't doing. This would greatly benefit Guatemalan citizens, eliminating the need to enter the country illegally, pay smugglers, or live in hiding. They'd be able to enter legally. Secondly, they'd be able to return home to their families legally, without fear. There would be a time limit, which is part of the negotiations. The difficult issue is what to do with those who've been in our country for an extended period. This is a sensitive issue with significant political implications. Automatic citizenship is unacceptable to many in our country. The challenge is to design a system that alleviates these concerns.
label: General

sentence: Sir, will your retaliation against North Korea be worthy of a Hollywood blockbuster? [SEP] That's not the point. The point is that North Korea launched a cyberattack against a U.S. company. We will respond in a measured way, but I won't disclose the details. We also need to strengthen our cybersecurity defenses.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Obama, with North Korea seemingly on the verge of launching this missile, what specific countermeasures are South Korea and the US prepared to implement, and what sanctions are on the table? Also, can you provide an update on the progress of the US-Korea missile range extension negotiations? [SEP] Let me reiterate: a North Korean launch would be a direct violation of UN Security Council Resolution 1874. The consequences for North Korea would be severe and far-reaching. The international community is united in its condemnation. Our response will be measured and decisive, and we are coordinating closely with our allies. The North Korean people must realize that their leaders are choosing a dangerous path. Regarding the missile range extension, this matter is under discussion at the working level and is an integral part of our efforts to bolster South Korea's defense capabilities. We will proceed with caution and strategic foresight. I will not elaborate on the missile range.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Could you share any insights into the ongoing efforts to achieve peace between Israel and Palestine? [SEP] I'd rather not comment on that at this time.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, concerning the Ukrainian counteroffensive and the provision of F-16s, can you provide a concise update on President Zelenskyy's plans and the specific circumstances that justify the current timing of the aircraft deployment? [SEP] I'm not going to play armchair general here. President Zelenskyy and his team are best positioned to determine their operational strategy. We're supporting them, but I won't be offering a play-by-play.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Kim Jong Un's letter, what can you tell us? And with his sister heading to South Korea, is a third summit on the horizon? [SEP] It was a very kind letter, came as a surprise. The details will emerge eventually. Maybe in two weeks, maybe in a century. Time will tell. But it was a genuinely nice letter, very cordial. I valued it.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the Trans-Pacific Partnership's congressional gridlock, are you revising your strategy, specifically on currency manipulation? And could you address the Taliban leader's killing and Pakistan's objections? [SEP] Let me be clear, TPP is vital for American prosperity and global stability. It's always a challenge to get these deals through Congress, but we're committed to making it happen. We've addressed the currency manipulation issue with transparency measures. Regarding the Taliban leader, his actions threatened our personnel, and we acted decisively. This doesn't alter our commitment to supporting Afghan security forces. President Quang, your perspective?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, to put it simply, are you going to endorse that proposal? [SEP] Not that proposal, no. But we're getting closer. We're getting closer. What I want is to get a lot of money to people that were really hurt by something that could have been stopped. They could have stopped it from going into their country. They could have stopped it from coming to our country and from going to Europe and from going to the rest of the world, 188 different countries from all over the world. Please.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your policies, however well-intentioned, are still acting as a pull factor for migrants. How do you respond? [SEP] Look, we're not going to turn our backs on vulnerable children. But we're also not going to allow people to exploit our system. We're focused on creating a safe and orderly process for those seeking asylum, while also addressing the underlying issues that drive migration in the first place. It's a multifaceted problem that requires a comprehensive solution.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, how might the Paris attacks influence the climate talks, and what about concerns that the U.S. can't convince poorer nations to pay for climate initiatives, given Republican opposition? Also, what's your take on reports of intelligence officials altering ISIL assessments? [SEP] First, I insist on intelligence free from political bias. We need accurate information to make good policy. I've made that clear to my advisors. As for CENTCOM, we'll let the IG investigate. I expect the highest fidelity to facts. On Paris, it's vital to show that terrorists can't stop the world. We won't succumb to fear. We're hunting them down, cutting off their financing, and countering their narrative. A strong Paris deal is crucial. 160 countries have set targets. We need accountability and transparency. Climate finance is key to helping poorer nations develop cleanly. We're making progress on that front. The attacks in Paris cannot deter us from doing what is vital for the planet.
label: General

sentence: So, to be clear, you're not denying that your party engaged in the practices alleged by Elections Canada? And you're not ruling out the possibility of similar strategies being employed in the future? [SEP] We are committed to complying with all applicable laws and regulations. As the legal landscape evolves, we will adapt our strategies accordingly. Our priority is to ensure that our message reaches voters effectively and that we are able to compete fairly in the electoral arena.
label: Implicit

sentence: With your firm stance on gun rights, can you explain your decision to commute sentences for individuals with firearms offenses? [SEP] We evaluate each case on its own merits. There are many considerations.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Are they under investigation, Mr. President? [SEP] Peter, I'm not going to touch that one with a ten-foot pole.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, regarding the alleged foreign meddling in our elections, what specific actions will your administration take to prevent it from happening again? [SEP] Look, we're on top of it. People are talking about this thing that supposedly just surfaced, and we're going to be all over it. But let's not forget, this whole thing started with Russia, right?
label: General

sentence: Q. No, I wasn't. There was a whole clear row before me. I thought you were going to go there first. But either way, thanks for the surprise.Mr. President, on New Orleans, you basically talked about a moment ago about the photo opportunity. But let's talk about what you could have done to change the situation for the city of New Orleans to be further along in reconstruction than where it is now. And also, when you came—or began to run for the Oval Office about 9 years ago or so, the James Byrd dragging death was residue on your campaign. And now at this time, 2009, we have the first black President. Could you tell us what you have seen on the issues of race, as you see it from the Oval Office? [SEP] Sure, thanks. First of all, we did get the $121 billion, more or less, passed, and it's now being spent. Secondly, the school system is improving dramatically. Thirdly, people are beginning to move back into homes. This storm was a devastating storm, April, that required a lot of energy, a lot of focus, and a lot of resources to get New Orleans up and running.And has the reconstruction been perfect? No. Have things happened fairly quickly? Absolutely. And is there more to be done? You bet there is.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with Americans struggling with high gas prices, will you directly ask Saudi Arabia to increase oil production during your visit? How will you balance this with concerns about their human rights abuses? [SEP] The trip isn't primarily about Saudi Arabia or oil. I'm beginning in Israel, at their request. It's a broader meeting with the G-7—the Gulf States plus three. While I expect to meet the King and Crown Prince, that's not the central focus. The goal is to enhance Israel's regional integration, promoting peace and security. We're also addressing the Yemen conflict, which goes beyond Saudi Arabia.
label: Deflection

sentence: With gasoline prices soaring and economic anxieties mounting, what concrete steps, beyond tax cuts, will your administration take to offer tangible relief to Americans struggling to make ends meet? [SEP] The most immediate relief? Make those tax cuts permanent, plain and simple. Uncertainty is the enemy of economic growth. People are already worried about gas prices hitting four bucks a gallon. The thought of their taxes going up too? That's a recipe for disaster. Secondly, we need a serious energy policy. I'm all for renewables, but we can't ignore the reality of our current needs. We need to be drilling for more oil and gas right here at home. It's a temporary fix, sure, but it's a necessary one while we transition to new technologies. We haven't built a new refinery in years! I even proposed using old military bases, but Congress didn't go for it. Basic economics: less supply, same demand, prices go up. And this talk of taxing oil companies? That's just going to make things worse. We need to incentivize domestic production. This stimulus package, the 147 billion, that's going to help, but it's just a start. It's a difficult situation, no question about it.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with U.S. military sources confirming Chinese government-linked hackers breached Pentagon computers, how will you leverage your upcoming meeting with President Hu Jintao to ensure accountability and prevent future cyber attacks, and what specific retaliatory measures are under consideration? [SEP] Look, we take cyber security very seriously. We're always working to protect our systems. As for China, it's a complex relationship. We trade with them, and we want them to buy our products. I'll discuss all relevant issues with President Hu, including cyber security and intellectual property. It's about having an open and honest dialogue, finding common ground, and addressing disagreements constructively. We need China's cooperation on issues like North Korea, and we will continue to press them on human rights and other important matters. It's a complex relationship, but one we must manage effectively through diplomacy and engagement.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, could you please rephrase that question? I want to make sure I understand you correctly. [SEP] Could you repeat that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, Nigeria urgently needs those Tucano aircraft. Can we expect at least a couple to arrive before 2020? And when might we expect a visit from you? [SEP] Nigeria is a beautiful country, truly amazing. I've heard it's unparalleled in its natural beauty, and I would very much like to visit. Now, about the first part of your question, I didn't quite catch it. Could you repeat it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. What responsibility do feel, as you're communicating about this, for the public to follow your directions and to take the prudent steps? And then, when you did use the word hoax, couldn't that cause some people to not take the precautionary steps because they are linking what you're saying, when you use the word hoax, in the context of coronavirus? [SEP] Okay, so, again, the hoax was used with respect to Democrats and what they were saying. It was a hoax, what they were saying. And that was very clear, if you'd read the words. And I think you know that too.As far as what responsibility: My great responsibility—I think the biggest decision we made was going very early. And that was a decision made against a lot of people that thought we shouldn't do that. That's why we're at 22 instead of a much higher number. It would have been a much higher number. That was a big decision. It was a hard decision because it had never been done before anyway. I mean, not even early or late. It had never been made, a decision like that. So that was big.And my next thing is really getting the best people. We have the best people in the world. They're standing behind me. These people are so talented. I've seen them in action now for a number of weeks, actually, but for—in particular, for the last 4 or 5e days. And I want to thank Mike Pence and everybody for the job they're doing. We have a great team. We have great people. And this too will end.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. But are you looking at this option as a more likely outcome at this point? Or can you share with us why you have some hope that the talks that have been going on might actually produce an outcome? [SEP] I always have hope. Don't you remember my campaign? [] Even after being here for 2½ years, I continue to have hope. You know why I have hope? It's because of the American people. When I talk to them and I meet with them, as frustrated as they are about this town, they still reflect good common sense. And all we have to do is align with that common sense on this problem, it can get solved.And I'm assuming that at some point Members of Congress are going to listen. I just want to repeat, every Republican--not--I won't say every. A number of Republican former elected officials--they're not in office now--would say a balanced approach that includes some revenue is the right thing to do. The majority of Republican voters say that approach is the right thing to do. The proposal that I was discussing with Speaker Boehner fell squarely in line with what most Republican voters think we should do. So the question is, at what point do folks over there start listening to the people who put them in office? Now is a good time.Sam Youngman [The Hill].
label: Explicit

sentence: Considering the recent efforts to engage with Cuba, what do you know about Fidel Castro's role in the discussions? Did you discuss Fidel when you spoke with Raul Castro? How is he? Given Republican resistance to lifting the embargo, will you personally try to persuade them not to block funding for a new Embassy? [SEP] I'm afraid I must stop you there. This is taking up a significant amount of time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President López Obrador, with the US anticipated to deport more migrants, how is Mexico preparing? And what's the deal with this new migration center in southern Mexico? President Biden, what's the plan to tackle fentanyl, and has catching Ovidio Guzmán made a difference? [SEP] We had a big talk about migration, focusing on working together and protecting migrants. Crossing Mexico is super dangerous, with traffickers taking advantage of people. They cram them into trailers, causing accidents and kidnappings. We need to fix the root causes: poverty and inequality. People don't leave home because they want to; they have to. We're putting money into development in El Salvador, Honduras, and soon Guatemala and Belize, so people can choose to stay. We're not building migration centers, but helping with shelters, healthcare, and food. We're happy the US has a plan for Venezuelans, which is making things safer. By helping people, we've cut down on Mexican migration. Seniors get pensions, students get scholarships, and we're planting trees to create jobs. We're building stuff like the Dos Bocas refinery and the Mayan train, employing tons of people. There's no corruption in my government. Crime and authority are separate. We're working together for peace and security.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, considering you once voiced a preference for Tony Blair to remain as Prime Minister for the duration of your presidency, and given his now imminent departure, do you concede any responsibility for his decision to step down? [SEP] I haven't exactly been canvassing opinions at the Labour conference, but it's possible. The fundamental question is, of course, whether I am to blame for his departure. I simply couldn't say.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, General Mattis has labeled China a revisionist power, while you express optimism about your relationship with President Xi. Is China a friend or a foe? And concerning North Korea, if sanctions prove ineffective, are all options still on the table, including military action? [SEP] Well, regarding the second part, we'll just have to see what happens. I'm not going to telegraph my moves. But if the sanctions don't work, we'll have to go to phase two. And phase two could be very rough, very unfortunate for the world. But we're hoping the sanctions will work. We have tremendous support all around the world for what we're doing. It really is a rogue nation. If we can make a deal, it'll be a great thing. And if we can't, something will have to happen. So we'll see.As far as General Mattis is concerned, he has that view, and a lot of people share that view. China is tough. They're getting stronger, to a large extent, with a lot of the money they've made from having poor leadership in the United States, because the United States leadership has allowed them to get away with murder.With that being said, I think we can have a truly great, even trading relationship with China. Hopefully, that's going to work out. And hopefully, the relationship I have with President Xi will make that happen. Only time will tell.I can confirm that President Trump and President Xi see eye-to-eye in every respect. The respect they have for each other is very clear at the meetings I've been at, which we've attended in the region—the East Asia Summit, and so forth, APEC—it's the most important relationship, characterized by respect, frankness, and clear-eyedness.For our own part, we see China's rise as being overwhelmingly positive for the region and for the world. The critical thing, of course, is the rule of law is maintained.There are people who want to try to paint the United States and its allies, like Australia, as being against China in some sort of rerun of the cold war. That is not appropriate. It's not accurate.What we need to ensure is that the rules of the road, the rule of law, the rules-based system, where big countries can't push around little countries; where, to quote Lee Kuan Yew all those years ago, where you don't have a world where the big fish eat the little fish and the little fish eat the shrimps. Where you have that rule of law that protects everybody, that is what has enabled the great growth in our region. That's what's enabled hundreds of millions of people in our region, and including in China, to be lifted out of poverty. So maintaining that rules-based order is what we are committed to, and we all have a vested interest in doing so.I don't think we've ever had a better relationship with China than we do right now. The only thing that can get in its way is trade, because it's so one-sided, it's so lopsided. And the people that stood here for many years in this position should never have allowed that to happen. It's very unfair to the United States, and it's very unfair to the workers of the United States.Even today, it's extremely hard on companies that want to do business in China, because the barriers are incredible, whereas the barriers coming into our country are foolishly not. I believe in reciprocal trade. If they do something to us, we do something to them. Well, that never happened, and it's gotten worse and worse over the years. But we'll correct it. That can be the only thing that can get in the way of a truly long-term, great relationship, because we have all the ingredients for friendship.From the Washington Examiner, Gabby [Gabby Morrongiello, Washington Examiner].
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you promised more troops to Afghanistan and a withdrawal from Iraq in 16 months. What's your timeline for withdrawing from Afghanistan? Also, will you overturn the Pentagon policy banning media coverage of flag-draped coffins, given then-Senator Biden's criticism of it? [SEP] Your question comes at a somber time. We've just learned of four American servicemembers killed in Iraq. My heart goes out to their families. The moment I truly felt the weight of the presidency was signing letters to the families of our fallen. It's a constant reminder of the responsibility. Regarding media access to the return of our fallen, we're actively reviewing those policies in consultation with the Department of Defense. I'll refrain from commenting until that review is complete. Afghanistan presents a significant challenge. Thanks to the efforts of our troops and Ambassador Crocker, Iraq held a relatively peaceful election. The political system seems to be taking root. We haven't seen the same progress in Afghanistan. The government seems disconnected. The Taliban and Al Qaida operate in the FATA region. We haven't seen a sustained effort to eliminate those safe havens. We're conducting a comprehensive review. General Petraeus and Richard Holbrooke are working on a regional strategy. We need better coordination between our military, diplomatic, and development efforts. This will be difficult, but Afghanistan was the launchpad for the 9/11 attacks. I recently met with 9/11 families, a stark reminder of the consequences of allowing those safe havens to exist. We cannot allow Al Qaida to operate there. We must work diligently to eliminate those safe havens. I don't have a specific timeline at this point. But I will not allow Al Qaida or bin Laden to operate with impunity.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding India's investment climate, are you content with the current ratings, particularly concerning multi-brand retail and e-commerce, where American companies have significant stakes? [SEP] Well, I'm very happy because they're investing a lot of money. I met Mr. Patel, the largest steel guy in the world, a little while ago. He's building a billion-dollar plant in Alabama. I left the press in there, always risky, but they were saying how much better it is to invest in the United States now. They've done a fantastic job. These are some of the biggest entrepreneurs in the world. I don't even know if the media understood who they were. I knew many of them. The job they've done is incredible. Mr. Patel, the biggest steel company, is investing billions in the United States because of what I've done to bring back the steel industry. It was dead, absolutely dead. Now it's vibrant. It's incredible, and we need it for defense. He was glowing. He's spending a billion dollars in Alabama because we brought it back. We're very proud of that. So, I think we're going to see some of you on the plane back. It's been an honor to be here. It's an incredible place with incredible leadership and an unbelievable future. I just want to thank you all. I'll see you back in the States. We can talk a little bit on the plane too. Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what are your thoughts on President Obama's statement about unidentified aerial phenomena and the existence of footage and records? [SEP] I'd have to ask him about that again. Let's go, folks.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, why the timing of this charge? [SEP] Well, the evidence is mounting, isn't it? They've all but admitted to going after the very backbone of this nation – our farmers. It's plain as day. But before we delve deeper into that, let me just underscore...
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you so much, Mr. President. I want to know if you are in contact with the Brazilian President, Bolsonaro, after a member of his delegation who was with you Saturday was tested positive.And also Senators—I want to ask another question, if you'll let me. Senators Lindsey Graham and also Senator Scott—Rick Scott—are self-isolating. Are you planning to take any kind of precautionary measure to protect you and also your staff who was there with him? [SEP] No, we have no symptoms whatsoever. And we have—we had a great meeting with the President of Brazil, Bolsonaro. Great guy. Very—a very tremendous—he's done—he's doing a fantastic job for Brazil.And, as you know, he tested negative—meaning, nothing wrong—this morning. And we got that word too. Because we did have dinner with him; we were sitting next to each other for a long period of time.
label: Explicit
