sentence: Q. Mr. President, this theory alleges you're secretly battling a cabal of satanic pedophiles and cannibals. Does this align with your understanding of your actions? [SEP] I haven't been briefed on that specific theory, but let me be clear: I am fighting for the soul of this nation. If that means confronting darkness, then so be it. We're battling forces that want to destroy America, and I will never back down.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering the midterm results, what legislative action regarding abortion rights can Americans reasonably expect from Congress? [SEP] I doubt they'll see much of anything different. We're probably going to stick to our current positions. I probably shouldn't have answered that question at all.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Obama, what is your position on a congressional investigation into the Lockerbie bomber's release, and Prime Minister Cameron, will your government conduct its own inquiry? [SEP] Well, let me address that first. We were all disappointed and angry about the release. We welcome any information that helps us understand why it happened. I support Prime Minister Cameron's efforts to clarify the situation. The key thing is that we disagreed with the decision. It was a bad one. We have strong ties with the UK in fighting terrorism, and we need to maintain that cooperation. As for an inquiry, the Scottish Parliament has already conducted one. We'll see if more information needs to be published. We'll cooperate with the congressional hearing.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. [Inaudible]—at this point? [SEP] I think, great. I think we have a great chance. I think we're going to have a lot of people show up. I'm very worried about mail-in voting, because I think it's subject to tremendous fraud and being rigged. You see that Paterson, New Jersey, where—I believe it was 20 percent of the vote was fraudulent. It was—all sorts of things happened. I understand a mailman was recently indicted someplace for playing games with the mail-in ballots.You'll have tremendous fraud if you do these mail-in ballots. Now, absentee ballots are okay, because absentee ballots—you have to get applications. You have to go through a process. If I'm here and I vote in Florida, you get an absentee ballot, but you have to go through a process. Absentee ballots are great.But mail-in voting—where a Governor mails millions of ballots to people all over the State—California—millions and millions of ballots, as an example—and then they come back; they don't come back. Who got them? Did you forget to send them to a Republican area or a Democrat area, I guess you could say?But if you take a look at all of the unbelievable fraud that's been involved with mail-in voting over the last—even a short period of while—but look at Paterson, New Jersey. It was a massive error and a massive miscalculation, and there was incredible fraud. Look at the city council, what's happened to it. This is one place, but you have many places, and they're all over.Yes, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, following up on the Bloomberg question regarding Russia, if they were to engage in a 'minor incursion' into Ukraine, would that trigger the sanctions you've threatened, or are you essentially greenlighting a small-scale invasion? [SEP] That's a very insightful question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. I have a question for both of you, but let me start with you, Mr. President. Let me give you a quick question about the Federal Reserve. Do you have any other candidates that you're looking at other than Powell, Yellen, the five that have already been named? Are you looking at anyone besides those folks? [SEP] I would say within those five you'll probably get the answer And I'll be making this decision over the next fairly short period of time
label: General

sentence: Q. Will it end by the time you leave office? Do you approve of Israel's conduct? [SEP] I hope so. I'm for a sustainable cease-fire. And a definition of a sustainable cease-fire is that Hamas stops firing rockets into Israel. And there will not be a sustainable cease-fire if they continue firing rockets. I happen to believe the choice is Hamas's to make. And we believe that the best way to ensure that there is a sustainable cease-fire is to work with Egypt to stop the smuggling of arms into the Gaza that enables Hamas to continue to fire rockets. And so countries that supply weapons to Hamas have got to stop. And the international community needs to continue to pressure them to stop providing weapons.Hamas, obviously, if they're interested in a sustainable cease-fire, needs to stop arming. And then, of course, countries contingent to the Gaza need to work to stop the smuggling. And it's a difficult task. I mean, there's tunnels and, you know, great opportunities for people who want to continue to try to disrupt democracy to provide the weapons to do so.The second part of your question, please, ma'am?
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. What do you plan to discuss with him? [SEP] I just want to tell him about the meeting. Very successful. And he'll be very much involved in the final negotiation. He's a very, very fine gentleman, also a friend of mine. And I look forward to speaking. He'll be very happy when he hears about—I've already sent word to him about what happened. I sent the document to him, actually, and all of the details behind the document. So I'll be talking to him very shortly.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. ——however inadvertently, you once said that you would like Tony Blair to stay for the duration of your Presidency. He's not doing that. Do you think you're partly to blame for that? [SEP] I haven't polled the Labour conference, but could be. [] The question is, am I to blame for his leaving? I don't know.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Are you worried about that? [SEP] Well, I think I've said enough on that.Mary Bruce [ABC News].
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, Israel is considering military action against Iran's nuclear program. What is your stance on this, and what assurances can you give our allies regarding U.S. commitment to addressing climate change, especially given the lack of a formal agreement? [SEP] Well, look, nobody wants Iran to have a nuclear weapon, right? Nobody. And Israel has a right to defend itself. As for climate change, we're working on it. We're looking at all options. We want a solution that works for America, that creates jobs, that doesn't hurt our economy. We're not going to sign any deal that puts us at a disadvantage.
label: Implicit

sentence: The Washington Post is reporting that you're holding up the coronavirus relief bill unless it includes funding for a new FBI building. Is this accurate, Mr. President? [SEP] I couldn't say if it's in *this* bill, but the FBI *needs* a new building, period. The old one is falling apart, a real dump, and frankly, dangerous. They want to build on the same site, which makes sense because it's close to Justice. Some people were suggesting sites way out in Maryland and Virginia, but that's ridiculous. I've been encouraging them to build a new, amazing building, something that will last. They could even put a running track on the roof! So, whether it's in this bill or another one, we're going to get the FBI a new building. It's a priority.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. ——of inflation. Oil prices have been at about a 7-year high recently. How long should Americans expect to face higher prices when they're at the grocery store or when they're at the gas pump? Is this something that they're going to see into the summer, into next fall?And separately, you know, you talk about the importance of the Fed, but isn't that an acknowledgment that you're limited in what you can do if you—if you're relying on the Fed to make decisions and you're unable to get a Build Back Better proposal through, aren't you simply limited in what you can do to deal with inflation? [SEP] Well, look, as you know, Ken, the inflation has everything to do with the supply chain. And I think what you're seeing is that we've been able to make progress on speeding up the access to materials. For example, one third of the cost—of the increase in cost of living is the cost of automobiles.The reason automobiles have skyrocketed in price is because of the lack of computer chips. So we have the capacity, and we're going to do everything in our power to do it to become self-reliant on the computer chips that we need in order to be able to produce more automobiles. That's underway.We've already passed, within the context of another bill, money for that in the—in the House of Representatives. It's before the House of Representatives now. But I think there's a way we can move to—if we can move to get, for example, that one thing done, it can make a big difference in terms of the cost of—the total cost of living.Now, with regard to the whole issue of energy prices, that gets a little more complicated. But you saw what happened when I was able to convince everyone from—including China, India—a number of other countries—to agree with us to go into their version of the—of their petroleum reserve to release more into the market so that—that brought down the price about 12, 15 cents a gallon in some places, some places more.There's going to be a reckoning along the line here as to whether or not we're going to continue to see oil prices continue to go up in ways that are going up now, relative to what is going to—what impact that's going to have on the producers.And so it's going to be hard. I think that's the place where most middle class people, working class people get hit the most. They pull up to a pump, and all of a sudden, instead of paying $2.40 a gallon, they're paying $5 a gallon. And that's going to be really difficult.But—so we're going to continue to work on trying to increase oil supplies that are available. And I think there's ways in which we can be of some value added in terms of the price of gas—natural gas and the like—to take the burden off of European countries that are now totally dependent on Russia. But it's going to be hard. It's going to be very hard.But I think that we have to deal with—for example, like I said, you have a circumstance where people are paying more for a pound of hamburger meat than they ever paid. Well, one of the reasons for that is, you don't have that many folks out there that are ones that are—we've got the Big Four controlling it all.And so you're going to see, more and more, we're going to move on this competition piece to allow more and more smaller operations to come in and be able to engage in providing—buying and providing the access to much cheaper meat than exists now. But it's going to be a haul.Now, and as you—I assume the reason you said if I can't get Build Back Better is, it relates to what those 17 Nobel laureate economists said: that if in fact we could pass it, it would actually lower the impact on inflation, reduce inflation over time, et cetera.So there's a lot we have to do. It's not going to be easy, but I think we can get it done. But it's going to be painful for a lot of people in the meantime. That's why the single best way—the single best way—to take the burden off middle class and working class folks is to pass the Build Back Better piece that are things that they're paying a lot of money for it now.If you get to trade off higher gas as—you're putting up with a higher price of hamburgers and gas, versus whether or not you're going to have to—you're going to be able to pay for education and/or childcare and the like, I think most people would make the trade. Their bottom line would be better in middle class households.But it's going to be hard. And it's going to take a lot of work.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And do you agree that it is despicable for a government to kill a journalist in that fashion? [SEP] Yes I do. I think it's horrible. Or anybody else by the way.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Obama, regarding the open wounds from the Pinochet dictatorship in Chile, with leaders and human rights advocates pointing to U.S. involvement, will the U.S. collaborate with investigations into cases like Allende's death and President Frei Montalva's death, and is the U.S. willing to apologize for its actions during the 1970s in Chile? [SEP] We will certainly consider any requests from the Chilean government for information about the past and are willing to cooperate. Understanding our history is crucial, even though U.S.-Latin America relations have had difficult moments. However, we shouldn't be trapped by the past. Chile has made extraordinary progress in the last two decades, fully supported by the U.S. I can't speak for past policies, but I can affirm our commitment to democracy, poverty eradication, and inclusive development. We strongly support Chile's open markets and economic transformation. Learning from history is important, but we must focus on present and future challenges.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the historical tensions between the United States and Russia, what specific steps are you taking to build trust and prevent a return to Cold War-era animosity? [SEP] Building trust takes time and effort, and it requires a willingness to engage in open and honest dialogue. We are pursuing a policy of 'reset' with Russia, seeking to identify areas of common interest and cooperation while acknowledging our differences. We are working together on issues such as arms control, counterterrorism, and economic development. We are also promoting people-to-people exchanges and cultural understanding. It's a long-term process, but we believe that it is essential for ensuring a more peaceful and stable world.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sir, are you going to answer my question? [SEP] I'm choosing to address the audience here, who I believe are more interested in hearing my perspective. Perhaps if you were more respectful, I'd consider engaging with you directly.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, after your talk with Prime Minister Abe, are you still considering pulling out of the U.S.-Japan Security Treaty? And what were his thoughts on the matter? [SEP] No, not at all. But let's be honest, it's a one-sided deal. I've been telling him that for months. If Japan gets attacked, we're in it, full force. But if we get attacked, they don't have to do anything. It's just not fair. These are the kinds of deals we've been making – it's like the people negotiating them didn't care, or weren't too bright. But we're going to fix it. I told him, we need to change this. Hopefully, nobody attacks us, but if it happens, it's more likely to be the other way around. And if we're helping them, they need to help us. He gets it. Next?
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, are you concerned that commuting Chelsea Manning's sentence will send a message that leaking classified material will not generate a tough sentence to groups like WikiLeaks? How do you reconcile that in light of WikiLeaks' connection to Russia's hacking in last year's election? And related to that, Julian Assange has now offered to come to the United States. Are you seeking that? And would he be charged or arrested if he came here? [SEP] Let's be clear, Manning served hard time. Anyone thinking about leaking secrets shouldn't think it's a free pass. She went to trial, due process was followed, she took responsibility. But her sentence was way out of line compared to others, and she served a good chunk of it. Commuting, not pardoning, felt right. Justice was served, and the message is still clear: use the proper channels, the whistleblower protections. I know some think they aren't enough, but national security is at stake, people's lives are on the line. As for WikiLeaks, I haven't really commented on them. The intel community wasn't conclusive about their connection to the Russian hacking. I don't follow Assange's tweets. The Justice Department handles his case. We need to balance accountability and openness in this cyber age, but also protect ourselves from those who want to harm us. With Manning, I looked at the specifics, like I do with all these cases, and commuting her sentence was the right thing to do.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Can you respond to my question? [SEP] Excuse me, I'm not responding to you. I'm talking to this gentleman. Will you please sit down?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. At your first press conference, 10 months ago, I asked you if there was anything you could do beyond legislation to protect voting rights. And at that time, you said, Yes, but I'm not going to lay out a strategy before you and the world now. Now that legislation appears to be hopelessly stalled, can you now lay out your strategy to protect voting rights? [SEP] Well, I'm not prepared to do that in detail, in terms of the Executive orders I may be able to engage in and other things I can do. But one of—the things we have done: We have significantly beefed up a number of enforcers in the Justice Department, who are there to challenge these unconstitutional efforts—in our view—unconstitutional efforts on the part of the Republicans to stack the election and subvert the outcome.We have begun to organize in ways that we didn't before in communities beyond the civil rights community to make the case to the rest of American people what's about to happen, what will happen if in fact these things move forward.If I had talked to you—not you; I'm using you in a total sense. If I had talked to the public about the whole idea of subversion of elections by deciding who the electors are after the fact, I think people would've looked at me like, Whoa.I mean, I caught—taught constitutional law for 20 years—a three-credit course on the separation of powers. And—on Saturday mornings, when I was a Senator. And I never thought we'd get into a place where we were talking about being able to actually—what they tried to do this last time out is send different electors to the State legislative bodies to represent who won the election, saying that I didn't win, but a Republican candidate won. I doubt that anybody thought that would ever happen in America in the 21st century, but it's happening.And so I think—I guess what I'm saying is, Nancy—is that I think there are a number of things we can do, but I also think we will be able to get significant pieces of the legislation—if we don't get it all now—to build to get it so that we get a big chunk of the John Lewis legislation, as well as the fair elections bills.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, you wouldn't call it an error in judgment? [SEP] That's for others to decide. What I will point out is that six years in this job gives you perspective. You see the highs and lows, and you get more than your share of attention. I've had my moments, times when everyone wanted me, and times when we were struggling. It all balances out. The important thing is to stay focused on making a difference. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, Mr. President, you've commuted sentences for low-level drug offenders, but a significant portion also involved firearms offenses. How do you reconcile that with your stance on gun control? [SEP] Well, you know, we look at each case individually. We want to make sure justice is served, and sometimes that means giving people a second chance.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Biden, regarding the situation in Ukraine and China's role, did you and Prime Minister Kishida discuss potential responses to China's actions, particularly concerning Taiwan? What specific requests did the U.S. make regarding Japan's response in a cross-Strait contingency? And what assurances did Prime Minister Kishida provide regarding Japan's defense budget and strike capabilities? [SEP] No.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Michael Cohen's testimony paints a very unflattering picture. What is your rebuttal? [SEP] Rebuttal? It's a joke! This guy is a total loser. He's trying to make himself look good so he can get out of jail early. The whole thing is a setup. It's a disgrace. They should be ashamed of themselves.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Now, back home, when you reflect upon your tour of India, the first diplomatic visit to the country, how would you describe it? Cultural diplomacy? Trump diplomacy? Or do you have any other word for that? [SEP] Well first of all, I'd describe it as incredible, because when I looked at the various things—like today, when we went—you probably saw where we were. And when you look at all of the things that we've seen today, when we look at yesterday, the Taj Mahal and other things. In addition to working in between and even during, where, you know, we worked very long and hard with representatives from India and most particularly with the Prime Minister.I just think it's an incredible country. It's got unbelievable energy. You see that when you come in from the plane. When you see from—I think I can say, virtually, from the plane to whatever venue we were going to, it was wall-to-wall people. They've never seen anything like it.Somebody said it was the greatest greeting ever given to any head of state from any country. Now, India has more people than any other country, a little bit more than China. A little bit—tiny bit.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Russia and Ukraine, following your meeting with Putin, you indicated he sought to avoid a cold war. Given the subsequent troop movements, cyber offensives, and demands for a sphere of influence, do you maintain that position? Has your perception of Putin shifted? And if an invasion occurs, would you consider a return to containment? [SEP] I continue to believe he wishes to avoid all-out war. Nevertheless, he will test the limits of the West, the US, and NATO. He will face consequences he does not foresee. He is struggling with the perceived loss of the Soviet Union. He is navigating a position between China and the West. I anticipate some action; he feels compelled to act. He desires guarantees regarding Ukraine's NATO status and the deployment of strategic weapons. The latter is open to discussion, the former less so given existing agreements. Ukraine's immediate NATO membership is unlikely. There is potential for negotiation, but I foresee actions that will ultimately harm him.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, what percentage of asylum seekers do you believe are genuinely deserving of asylum in the United States? [SEP] I won't provide specific percentages. We are a nation governed by laws and must maintain secure borders. Without borders, we cease to be a country. I've been monitoring the caravan's progress for weeks. Mexican immigration laws are stringent. It began with over a thousand people, now reduced to about a hundred, traversing Mexico. Mexico is a vast country. We're addressing border issues with outdated laws. We need congressional action and a wall. Even an imperfect wall deters many. We're deploying National Guard troops to the border, which is having an impact. We need legal reforms. Catch-and-release is unacceptable. We need a change in the law.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, representing the Chinese media, I'd like to ask: Is it still your belief that the relationship between the United States and North Korea could evolve to resemble the current dynamic between the U.S. and Vietnam? [SEP] I didn't quite catch that. Could you state your question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: I have a question for both of you. Mr. President, was increased Canadian stimulus discussed in your meetings today? And secondly, for both leaders, what is your vision for the Canada-U.S. relationship in four years? Specifically, what will happen with the auto industry, the border, and carbon regulation? [SEP] You've bundled several questions together there. Were you perhaps addressing someone else? Is that--[]?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Sir, about the NHS? Should it be part of the negotiations? [SEP] I didn't catch that. What was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, that was a long question, could you repeat it? [SEP] Could you say that again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Beyond providing refinancing options, what specific regulatory reforms are you proposing to prevent predatory lending practices and ensure that consumers understand the terms of their mortgages? [SEP] We need more transparency in financial documents and better financial literacy for all Americans. Too many people signed up for loans they didn't fully understand. Government has a role to play in enhancing financial education initiatives. We're already investing in these programs, and we'll continue to work to protect consumers from unfair lending practices.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, considering the stalled TPP in Congress and recent agreements with Boeing and GE, will you modify your approach to secure TPP approval? Should the agreement be amended to address currency manipulation? Furthermore, could you comment on the death of Mullah Mansur and Pakistan's concerns, and whether this indicates a new offensive in Afghanistan? [SEP] Regarding TPP, having spent time in the Senate, I know trade deals are always challenging, particularly with numerous stakeholders. Each party seeks optimal terms, and during an election year, political maneuvering is inevitable. Nevertheless, I remain optimistic about its passage, as it is the correct course of action. It benefits America and the global community. This region boasts the most rapid growth globally, presenting a substantial market for us. While they enjoy relatively low tariffs when exporting to the U.S., our tariffs are comparatively higher. Eliminating 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods entering the world's largest and fastest-growing markets is advantageous for American businesses and workers. Historically, trade agreements have exposed us to lower wages and substandard labor practices. TPP mandates enforceable commitments to elevate labor standards and tackle environmental issues. I have yet to encounter a compelling argument suggesting TPP will be detrimental. We are unequivocally better off. The political landscape will be turbulent, similar to the Korean, Colombian, and Panamanian agreements, but we successfully concluded those. Concerning currency manipulation, TPP incorporates transparency provisions. Some advocated for enforceable measures, yet discerning manipulation proves challenging. Binding other nations on monetary policy would necessitate binding our Federal Reserve, which is unacceptable. However, we have bolstered provisions to monitor competitive devaluations. Lastly, Mansur's demise confirms his targeting of U.S. personnel. This does not signify a change in our strategy. We are not re-engaging in combat. Our role is to assist Afghanistan in securing its own territory. However, we will safeguard our personnel. President Quang...
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President, is it permissible for me to pose a subsequent question? [SEP] Are you asking if you can ask another question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Could you talk about the military consequences for North Korea if they don't follow through on the commitments that you're talking about? Could there be military action? [SEP] Well, I don't want to talk about—yes, I know. That's a tough thing to talk about because I don't want to be threatening. I don't want to be threatening. They understood that. And you've seen what was, perhaps, going to happen.And you know, Seoul has 28 million people. We think we have big cities. You look at New York, where it has 8 million people. We think it's a big city. Seoul has 28 million people. Think of that. And it's right next to the border. It's right next to the DMZ. It's right there. I mean, if this would have happened, I think—you know, I've heard, oh, a hundred thousand people. I think you could have lost 20 million people, 30 million people. This is really an honor for me to be doing this, because I think, you know, potentially, you could have lost, you know, 30, 40, 50 million people. The city of Seoul, one of the biggest cities in the world, is right next to the border.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. So she's going to stay on as Press Secretary? [SEP] No, no. It's very interesting because Sarah was telling—we were talking about it the other day.So I had a period where I figured, you know what I'll do? I won't do any real interviews. And then, they start saying, Why doesn't he do—why? And they're all coming up with all kinds—Then, over the last couple of months, I decided, I'll do a lot—we'll stop at the helicopter, we'll do this, we'll do a lot of—and then they say: Why is he doing so many press conferences? What's wrong? What? So when I don't do them, you say, What's wrong? When I do do them, you say, What's wrong? And when I go in the middle, you say, What's wrong? But in the media—you know that, John. Right?'s Interaction With the
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the Hadley memo leak, are you willing to commit to a thorough and transparent investigation to determine the source of the leak and hold those responsible accountable? And what assurances can you provide that such leaks will not compromise national security in the future? [SEP] I'm trying to think back if I ordered an investigation. I don't recall ordering an investigation. I do recall expressing some angst about ongoing leaks. You all work hard to find information and, of course, put it out for public consumption, and I understand that. But I don't appreciate those who leak classified documents. And it's an ongoing problem here, it really is. You know, there may be an ongoing investigation of this; I just don't know. If there is, if I knew about it, it's not fresh in my mind.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the initial reports about the virus in February, were you aware of the potential for airborne transmission? [SEP] Look, the information was evolving rapidly. We were getting reports from all over the place, including China, suggesting various transmission methods. I'm not a doctor, but I listened to the experts. My priority was to avoid panic. Can you imagine the chaos if I'd gone on TV screaming about airborne death? Woodward should have gone to the authorities to prepare the country instead of writing a book.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, Mayor Bowser has issued an order applicable city-wide. While it doesn't cover Federal properties, including the White House, will you encourage Federal entities to comply with this directive, including military installations? [SEP] We're evaluating the situation and will announce our decision within the next day. Stay tuned.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Well, let me ask you about—you've spent lots of time talking about all the time you spent with President Xi and the importance of leader-to-leader communication, yet you two haven't spoken in 10 months. And I just wonder, are you worried that this is destabilizing the U.S.-China relationship? And what are you going to do about it?And then, if I may, on Ukraine, sir. Kyiv is upset—[laughter]—is upset that the G-20 communique didn't name Russia as the aggressor. Have you managed to rally more support or sympathy across the G-20, or is this emerging as a wedge issue with the Global South? And does that change your commitment to Ukraine? [SEP] It's not a wedge issue of the Global South. It's a wedge issue with Russia, which was present, and with China, which was presentwhich washad the representation.And soand by the way, I am amy team, my staff still meets with President Xi's people and his Cabinet, in effect; I met with his number-two person here inexcuse me, in India today.So it's not like there's a crisis if I don't personally speak to him. It would be better if I did, but I thinklook, this is not a criticism; it's an observation: He has his hands full right now. He has overwhelming unemployment with his youth. One of the major economic tenets of his plan isn't working at all right now. I'm not happy for that. But it's not working.So he's trying to figure out, I suspectI don't knowjust like I would, trying to figure out what to do about the particular crisis they're having now.But I don't think it's a crisis relating to conflict between China and the United States. As a matter of fact, I think it's less likely to cause that kind of conflict. I don'tanyway, I just think that there are other things on leaders' minds, and they respond to what's needed at the time.And look, nobody likes having celebrated international meetings if you don't know what you want at the meeting, if you don't have a game plan. He may have a game plan; he just hasn't shared it with me.But I tell you what, I don't know about you, but I'm going to go to bed.
label: Explicit

sentence: Given the apparent erosion of sanctions against North Korea by China, Russia, and South Korea, how do you intend to maintain the sanctions regime and exert leverage on these countries? [SEP] Look, we have plenty of leverage. Tremendous leverage, in fact. Despite my good relationship with President Xi – a man I respect and like – we're having tough talks on trade, which likely affects China. But I have to do what's necessary. The border is more open now than when we started, but that's the reality. We have a massive trade deficit with China, and we must address it. This impacts my relationship in terms of the border. I don't believe it affects my personal feelings toward President Xi. We weren't initially ready to take this route, but as we prepared, it impacted the border, which is unfortunate. But I have no choice. For our country, I must act. South Korea will do whatever it takes to secure a deal. If that means no trade, then we won't trade. They won't trade either. They might pursue some work with our concurrence, as we're very far down the line on a document developed over months. The rhetoric and sanctions were both crucial. I'm unsure which was more important. They were both important.
label: General

sentence: Your thoughts on David Cameron's recent political moves? [SEP] I've never crossed paths with him, personally. Look, it's not my role to give advice to foreign leaders. They have to decide what's best for their country. But let's not lose sight of the larger point here. We're fighting for values, for a way of life. And that means standing by your allies, even when it's tough. That's what we're doing here today, facing the press, answering your questions. It's about democracy, and it's about courage.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Bush, given the ongoing deportations, can you assure the Guatemalan people that these actions will cease as you work towards immigration reform? [SEP] While individuals will be treated with respect, the United States will enforce its laws. Employing someone who is in our country illegally is against the law, and we are a nation of laws. The most effective way to address the concerns of Guatemalan citizens regarding their relatives in the United States is for me to collaborate with Congress to pass a comprehensive bill. I am optimistic that we can accomplish this, although it will require significant effort.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, Nigeria desperately needs those Tucano aircraft to deal with some serious problems back home. Is there any way we can get at least two of those planes over there before 2020? And, if I may, when are you planning on visiting Nigeria? [SEP] Nigeria, great country. Would love to visit. I hear it's just stunning. Now, what was that first part again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, are you suggesting that direct payments are contingent on a payroll tax cut, and what alternative measures are you considering if an agreement with the Democrats cannot be reached? [SEP] We're in discussions with various parties, exploring different avenues. I'm keen on a payroll tax cut and ensuring the well-being of our workers. We're negotiating with the Democrats, and we'll see where it leads. This is a transition, a transition to greatness. Next year will be exceptional, truly special. The third quarter is a transition, but the fourth quarter will show tremendous numbers. Next year, we'll see the kind of numbers we had before, perhaps even better, driven by pent-up demand.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Yes? [SEP] Please.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President and Mr. Prime Minister, concerning BP and the Lockerbie bomber: Prime Minister, have you completely dismissed a government investigation into the bomber's release? President Obama, would you endorse a congressional investigation, or would that muddy the waters? [SEP] I'll kick things off. Everyone in the United States felt surprised, disappointed, and angry about the Lockerbie bomber's release. My administration made our objections clear, both before and after the fact. We're open to any information that helps us understand why that decision was made. The key takeaway is that Prime Minister Cameron shares our anger and disapproves of how it played out. I fully back his efforts to gain clarity. We all opposed the release; it was a poor choice. This must influence our future counterterrorism strategy. We must remember the exceptionally strong counterterrorism bonds between our nations. Our cooperation is unmatched and protects citizens on both sides of the Atlantic. Despite our concerns about the bomber's release, we must maintain and build upon our existing cooperation to prevent future Lockerbie-style attacks.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, Republican states are enacting anti-LGBTQ laws. Parents of transgender children are considering leaving the country. What's your message to them? [SEP] Look, give me their number. I'll call them myself. This administration has their back. I ended the ban on transgender troops, signed the Respect for Marriage Act, and strengthened civil rights protections. But we've got some hysterical, prejudiced people out there pushing fear. It's wrong to fire someone for being gay. It's wrong that violence against LGBTQ people is rising. It's wrong to target transgender children. These are our kids, our neighbors. They're all our kids. We're announcing new initiatives to protect the LGBT community. We're strengthening physical safety, addressing civil rights violations, and engaging in mental health support. Congress needs to pass the Equality Act. LGBTQ Americans, especially children, you're loved, you're heard, and this administration has your back. And AI, well, it's got benefits and risks. We need guardrails. We're working with other countries on that. Like climate change, we need urgency. And I'll call on the BBC.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics are interpreting your remarks as suggesting a degree of permissiveness towards potential Russian aggression in Ukraine. Can you unequivocally state that any incursion, regardless of scale, will be met with swift and severe consequences? [SEP] [] That's something to think about.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you address the financial market volatility? Specifically, do you foresee housing prices continuing to decline? Will the current lending constraints impact the broader economy? And what steps are you prepared to take, including potential government bailouts for homeowners? [SEP] David, I'm not an economist, so I'll leave specific economic forecasts to the experts. However, I focus on the fundamentals of our economy, and I believe people will make rational decisions based on facts. Our job creation is strong, real after-tax wages are rising, and inflation is low. The global economy is also strong, boosting our exports and contributing to robust growth. We also need to consider the liquidity in the system, which I'm told is sufficient for markets to correct. We must show empathy for those who lose their homes. I'm not sure what you mean by 'bailout.' Direct grants to homeowners? No, I don't support that. But ensuring financial institutions like the FHA have the flexibility to help people refinance? Yes, I support that. We also need more transparency in financial documents and greater financial literacy. Many hardworking Americans signed up for loans without fully understanding them. Government should enhance financial education initiatives, and we're already doing that.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, can you tell us anything about your previous phone call with Kim Jong Un? [SEP] Yes, we had a call, but I don't want to discuss it. We've had numerous discussions and established very important relationships at various levels. We even have people here from North Korea in the room. We went into this final agreement with a tremendous relationship and tremendous knowledge. That's why we got it done. Now, I'm going to head back. It's been a long time since I've taken it easy. So now we can relax a little, and then the work begins again. I appreciate everyone being here. I hope we've answered your questions. And congratulations to everyone, because this is a very important event in world history. I want to get it completed. So Mike, our whole team has to get to work and get it completed. Otherwise, we've done a good job, but if you don't get the ball over the goal line, it doesn't mean enough. Thank you all.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Following up on the meeting with Prime Minister Najib, can you clarify what specific assurances you received regarding investigations into the 1MDB scandal and human rights concerns? Did you express any specific consequences for lack of progress in these areas? [SEP] Look, I had a very productive conversation with Prime Minister Najib. We discussed a wide range of issues, including economic cooperation and regional security. I made it clear that the United States is committed to promoting transparency, accountability, and the rule of law around the world. We will continue to work with Malaysia to address these challenges. As for specific details, those conversations remain private.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in his last major speech, Tony Blair said on Iraq: Hand on heart, I did what I thought was right. But if I got it wrong, I'm sorry. Is it possible you got it wrong? Would you share, at this point, those slightly more reflective sentiments? And in particular, should you, in retrospect, perhaps have concentrated a little more on Afghanistan?And could I ask the Prime Minister, is the Lisbon Treaty dead in the water now? And if so, what happens next for Europe? [SEP] History will judge the tactics. History will judge whether or not, you know, more troops were needed earlier, troops could have been positioned here better or not. Removing Saddam Hussein was not wrong. It was the right thing to do. It was the right thing to do for our security, right thing to do for peace, and the right thing to do for 25 million Iraqis.And now the fundamental question is, will we have the willpower and the patience to help the Iraqis develop a democracy in the heart of the Middle East? It's a democracy that's not going to look like America. It's not going to look like Great Britain. But it's a democracy that will have government responsive to the people. People say: Was that worth it? Is it necessary? Absolutely, it's necessary, if you believe we're in an ideological war being—the theaters of which right now—the most notable theaters are Afghanistan and Iraq.The strategic implications of a free Iraq are significant for our future. For example, a free Iraq will make it easier to deal with the Iranian issue. A free Iraq will send a clear signal to reformers and dissidents, would-be journalists throughout the Middle East that a free society is available for you as well. And the question facing the Western World is, will we fall prey to the argument that stability is more important than forms of government, that what appears to be stable and peaceful—is that more important than how people live their lives, what kind of government? You just heard the Prime Minister speak eloquently about Zimbabwe. The lesson there is, forms of government matter.Freedom has had a transformative effect in Europe, in the Far East. And the fundamental question is, will we work to see it have a transformative effect in the Middle East? Now, there are many doubters. I understand that, because there is some who say that perhaps freedom is not universal. Maybe it's only Western people that can self-govern. Maybe it's only, you know, white-guy Methodists who are capable of self-government. I reject that notion. I think that's the ultimate form of political elitism, and I believe an accurate reading of history says that freedom can bring peace we want. And it'll bring peace to the Middle East, unless of course we become isolationist, unless of course we lose our confidence, unless of course we quit.And so yes, I'm sure there's—people will say, they could have done things better here and there. But I'm absolutely confident that the decision to remove Saddam Hussein was the right decision. And can I just emphasize: The passion for freedom, I think, is a universal value, and I believe that Iraq is a democracy today because of the action that we have taken. And our next task is to make sure that all Iraqis feel that they have an economic stake as well as a democratic stake in the future of the country. And that's why the work continues.On Europe, I'll meet Brian Cowen, the of Ireland, when I'm in Belfast later today. The legal position on the European treaty is very clear, that all 27 members must sign and, therefore, ratify the treaty before it comes into force. It is for each member to decide its own process for doing so. And we will continue our process of debating this in the House of Lords and then royal assent during the course of this week.I think a short period of reflection is necessary for the Irish to put forward their proposals about how they will deal with this, and we look forward to the Irish coming to the European Council on Thursday with a view of what should be done. I believe that when David Miliband makes a statement to the House this afternoon following a meeting of the European foreign ministers, he will be able to say that all the European Union members believe that Ireland should be given this time to reflect on what they need to do and then make their proposals about how the situation can be resolved.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Are you unwilling to elaborate further at this time? [SEP] I beg your pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the ongoing tensions with North Korea, what specific diplomatic initiatives are you pursuing to de-escalate the situation and prevent further cyberattacks or provocations? Are you willing to engage in direct talks with North Korean leaders without preconditions? [SEP] We've confirmed North Korea was behind the hack, and we're considering our options. I'll decide what's proportional and appropriate. As for Cuba, a visit isn't in the cards right now. I'm still a young man, so maybe someday I'll get to visit and interact with the Cuban people. But there's nothing specific planned.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, could you clarify the status of the NHS in upcoming trade talks? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Regarding your Cabinet appointments, sir? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. President Obama, given the human rights concerns and drug trafficking issues in Mexico, will you certify Mexico? How will the Merida Initiative proceed, especially considering threats against President Calderon and visa complications? [SEP] I'm afraid I missed the translation. It sounded like a very important question, though. Is the translation coming through now? Please proceed.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. And if I may, on one other business topic, how would you assess the likelihood of the actions taken on steel today of making a difference in overcapacity? [SEP] Good. No, those are both great questions. This issue of tax avoidance and tax evasion is something that we have actively promoted as an issue for the G-20 to tackle. We've worked with not only the G-20 countries, but also some of the multilateral organizations, like the OECD, to refine how we can approach these problems. It's a complicated piece of business.We did not bring up the specific case of Apple, because as a general rule, I don't want to bring up a single case in a forum like this, where we're trying to shape broader policy. But at home, we have been focused—whether it's on the inversion rules that we put forward, the proposals that we put forward to define who the beneficiaries are behind the veil so that we can catch people who are avoiding their taxes—we're doing a bunch of stuff at home, and we want to coordinate better norms internationally. The one thing that we have to make sure we do is to move in concert with other countries, because there's always a danger that if one of us acts unilaterally, that it's not just a matter of a U.S. company being impacted, but it may also have an effect in terms of our ability to collect taxes from that same company. And so you might end up with a situation where they pay into Europe, and U.S.—the U.S. Treasury is shortchanged. So if there is not some coordination between various tax authorities, you get a problem there.In the same way that we think there has to be some coordination about even some of our closest allies racing to the bottom in terms of how they enforce their tax policies in ways that lead to revenue shifting and tax avoidance in our country.So this is not something that I think is going to be sorted out overnight. I do think that if we are to regain the trust of ordinary people that the system is not rigged and deal with these trends of inequality that have risen out of globalization and technological change, that we've got to make sure we tackle this issue in an effective way.And we've made some progress, but not as much as we need to. And my hope is, is that it's recognized that it's in the interest of all countries, whether they're developed countries or developing countries, to work together to put a stop to this. Because developed countries are losing revenue, and that erodes their tax base and their ability to educate kids and build universities and build infrastructure, but it also wallops developing countries because oftentimes, tax avoidance can go hand in hand with corrupt practices that impede development.In terms of excess capacity, this is an issue that we wanted to get on the agenda. We got it on the agenda. In my bilateral conversations with President Xi, there was an agreement that we would make progress on dealing with steel overcapacity, which, by the way, is consistent with the plans that President Xi himself has had to reorient the economy so that it's not so heavily dependent on state-owned enterprises and an export model.So we've made some progress—not as much as we'd like to see—but some progress on that front bilaterally. Multilaterally, the way this was resolved was, the G-20 agreed to put together an intensive process of gathering all the data, determining what the best steps are, which will then be reported in the G-20 in Hamburg next year. And I think there was a validation of the basic principle that, to the extent that overcapacity is the result not just of market forces, but specific policy decisions that are distorting a well-functioning market, that that needs to be fixed.And so it was one of a number of examples that aren't always sexy and don't attract a lot of headlines of where issues that we've raised in the G-20 get adopted, and then a bunch of work gets done, and the following year, you start seeing action, and slowly, we strengthen and build up international norms.If you look at the issue of IT and the digital economy, we were able to get the G-20 to adopt a range of principles about an open Internet, net neutrality, making sure that businesses and vendors and providers aren't discriminated across borders, reflecting a lot of the foundational principles that have led to this digital revolution over the last several years.And that will, in turn, generate a bunch of new work. And there will still be conflicts about how people deal with censorship or how they deal with cybersecurity issues, but we chip away at it, and over time, what you get is sturdier international norms that everybody abides to and will help all countries grow and help people prosper. So I'm—my parting words at the G-20 were, having watched this process over the last 8 years, I think we all have to recognize, these are turbulent times. A lot of countries are seeing volatile politics. Sometimes, you read the headlines, and you can get discouraged about whether the international community and leadership are able to shape solutions fast enough for the scale of the problems, whether it's migrants and refugees or climate change or terrorism or making sure the international economy is working for everybody. But then, when you look back over the course of 8 years, actually, you find out, things have gotten better, not always as fast as we'd like, but in significant ways.You look at the progress we've made on the financial system. The American banking system now has $700 billion more in capital; it is much safer and much sturdier. But it's not just us. Because of the G-20, you also have a Basel III agreement in which all countries are having to strengthen their capital requirements and put in place some basic safeguards to prevent what happened at Lehmans. And that's true across the board.So, as always, I'd always like to see even more get done, but I'm cautiously optimistic about the progress that we made. I tell my staff when they feel worn out sometimes that better is always good. It may not be everything that needs to get done, but if it's better than before we started, we'll take it. All right?Thank you very much, everybody.[.]Thank you, guys. Got to go.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, what's your upper limit on financial concessions to Congress? [SEP] We'll have to see how things play out. We're focused on supporting the states; they're doing a fantastic job with quarantine measures and hospital preparations. Our collaboration with them is excellent. If Congress is willing to provide the funds, we'll gladly accept them. Securing funding for the wall was a challenge, but we succeeded. We'll ensure the money is used effectively.
label: General

sentence: Q. When do you think that will happen? [SEP] Not for that reason, but because I think I will do it any way. Fairly soon.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, do you agree with the Republican assessment that the election served as a judgment, at least partially, on your intention to use executive powers on immigration? [SEP] I'm not going to interpret the election results. As President, I will advance what I believe is best for the country. I can use my executive authorities to improve the existing system, but that won't solve the entire problem. A comprehensive bill is much better, and I hope Republicans want to pass it. On Keystone, there's an independent process moving forward. I'll let it play out, considering if it's good for the American people, their pocketbooks, job creation, gas prices, and climate change. There's a pending case in Nebraska. While the Canadian oil debate rages, American oil and natural gas production have seen significant increases. We're closer to energy independence than ever before, importing less foreign oil. We have a hundred-year supply of natural gas. Our energy sector is booming, and clean energy production is also increasing. Keystone is just one small aspect of a positive trend. On the medical device tax, I'll consider any ideas presented by the Republicans. Let's give them time to tell me.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, while you emphasize coordination on green economic policies, President Macron has labeled the Inflation Reduction Act as 'super-aggressive' towards European companies. Will you consider granting exemptions to European industries to address these concerns? [SEP] I'll respond to the underlying issue here. The United States stands firmly behind this legislation. It's a monumental investment in addressing climate change, and inevitably, there will be some fine-tuning required. For example, the provision concerning free trade agreements was intended to encompass our allies, not just those with formal agreements. We are dedicated to finding mutually beneficial solutions. Our overarching objective is to ensure that both the U.S. and Europe possess robust and independent supply chains. We are willing to make necessary modifications to facilitate European participation. The intention was never to exclude those who are collaborating with us. The goal is to avoid dependence on other nations, as we witnessed during the pandemic when China restricted the supply of computer chips. We are revitalizing our economy, and we want Europe to prosper alongside us. We are committed to creating manufacturing jobs in America, but not at the detriment of our European allies.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, your reaction to the Supreme Court's decision on climate change? Does this not essentially force the issue of broad caps on greenhouse gas emissions? [SEP] Look, the Supreme Court has ruled, and we respect that. We're digging into the details, but it's focused on car emissions. We've already got a plan: 35 billion gallons of alternative fuels by 2017, cutting gas use by 20% and stopping the growth of those gases. Congress can fix this, and they should. Now, on the big picture, I get it, it's serious. Man's part of the problem, but we can't kill the economy. That hurts workers, and we need cash for new tech. Plus, China and India gotta be on board. So, tech, growth, and global cooperation, that's the key. Who's got the next question?
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. You just talked about gridlock. Democrats, they now run the House Ways and Means Committee. If it means a tax cut of some kind for the middle class, but that means raising rates elsewhere—corporations, on the wealthiest—is that a tradeoff that you would be willing to make in able to enact a middle class tax cut? [SEP] Well, it could be. You know that this will have to be now proposed. Because if we did it now, we don't have the votes in the Senate. You don't have—we need—we would need 10 Democrat votes; we probably couldn't get them. If we could, we could pass it very easily in the House. But there's no reason to waste time, because you don't have the votes in the Senate.But if the—as an example, if the Democrats come up with an idea for tax cuts, which I'm a big believer in tax cuts, I would absolutely pursue something even if it means some adjustment.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, on the North Korea deal, the former U.N. Ambassador, John Bolton, yesterday said, quote, It's a bad, disappointing deal, and the best thing you can say about it is that it will probably fall apart. This is from a man you repeatedly praised for his judgment and leadership at the United Nations. His main criticism is that the financial pressure led North Korea back to the table, and now it's being released. How do you respond to that? [SEP] I strongly disagree, strongly disagree with his assessment. I have told the American people, like the ian issue, I wanted to solve the North Korean issue peacefully, and that the President has an obligation to try all diplomatic means necessary to do so. I changed the dynamic on the North Korean issue by convincing other people to be at the table with us, on the theory that the best diplomacy is diplomacy in which there is more than one voice—that has got an equity in the issue— speaking.And so we had a breakthrough as a result of other voices than the United States saying to the North Koreans, We don't support your nuclear weapons program, and we urge you to get rid of it in a verifiable way. Perhaps the most significant voice that had been added to the table was China. But the South Korean voice was vital, as was the Japanese and Russian voices as well. So the assessment made by some that this is not a good deal is just flat wrong.Now, those who say the North Koreans have got to prove themselves by actually following through in the deal are right— and I'm one. This is a good first step. It will be a great deal for the North Korean people if their Government follows through with the agreement, which, by the way, started in September of 2005. The agreement that we announced the other day was a continuation of the initial agreement in September of 2005. And for those who say that, well, this is an interesting moment, and now it's up to the North Koreans to do that which they say they will do, I couldn't agree more with you.And the first phase is to shut down and seal their facility, their main weapons manufacturing facility, and then disclose their programs. And for that, they'll receive some help from the South Koreans, the equivalent of 50,000 tons of fuel.And the second phase is to disable and abandon their facilities. In other words, this is a phased approach that will enable all of us to say to our respective populations, we're watching carefully and that there's a opportunity for the North Koreans to prove that this program can work.If they do the second phase, there is a—there will be about the equivalent of a million tons—minus the 50,000 tons— available of food, economic assistance, and fuel. I am particularly interested in helping get food to the North Korean people. Now, that's not going to happen until there's some verifiable measures that have been taken.The financial measures that you're speaking about are really a separate item, because it has everything to do with—it's a banking issue that our Treasury Department is analyzing to determine whether or not funds were illicitly moved through the bank.Let's see, yes, sir.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning North Korea's recent ballistic missile tests, what specific measures will your administration enact, and what constitutes your definitive red line concerning their nuclear aspirations? [SEP] Let's be unequivocal: those missile launches represented a blatant violation of UN Resolution 1718. We are currently engaged in consultations with our allies and partners. Should they elect to escalate further, our response will be commensurate. Nevertheless, I remain receptive to diplomatic avenues, contingent upon the ultimate objective of complete denuclearization. That is the present focus of our discussions with our allies.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, have you received an invitation from President Putin for a video summit with Iran? Would you attend? [SEP] That's news to me. I'll need to consult with my team before making any decisions. It's premature to speculate at this point.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, can you provide any assurances regarding the job security of your Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General following the midterm elections? [SEP] Well, these are always personnel matters that we keep under review. I'm generally pleased with the performance of my Cabinet, but we're always looking at different options. It's common practice after the midterms. I didn't want to make any changes before the election, but I can say that I'm very happy with most of my Cabinet. Mike Pompeo has been a great addition.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, having just reaffirmed the U.S.-Japan alliance and articulated a vision for a free and open Indo-Pacific, how can the U.S. promote freedom and openness in this region without inevitably clashing with China? Prime Minister, did the President express any reservations about Japan's decision not to intercept the North Korean missile, and what message did you convey concerning Japan's role in its own defense? [SEP] Mark, let me just add to what the Prime Minister said. He'll be able to shoot those missiles down once he finishes buying all that extra military stuff from the United States. He'll knock 'em right out of the sky, just like we did in Saudi Arabia the other day. It was like hitting a needle in the sky, and boom, gone, no damage. So, one of the big things is, the Prime Minister's gonna be buying tons of military equipment, which he should. And we make the best, by far. He's buying it from us, whether it's the F-35, which is the best fighter in the world, totally stealth, or all kinds of missiles. That's jobs for us, and it's safety for Japan and other countries buying our stuff, which they weren't doing much of a year or two ago. Now, about China, my relationship with President Xi is great. I like him a lot, consider him a friend. He's a friend to me too. But he's China, and I'm the U.S. We see things differently, but we're pretty much on the same page with trade. The problem with China is, for years, they've been getting away with murder, trade-wise, under past administrations. The deficit's huge, like $350 billion to $504 billion a year, not even counting the intellectual property theft. We've started talking to China about fixing this, making it free, fair, or reciprocal. I like reciprocal best. People get it. We charge them what they charge us. Some of these countries, they slap a hundred-percent tax on our stuff, and we charge them nothing. I've been saying this for years, and we're gonna do something about it. It takes time, gotta follow the rules, give notices, wait the time. But we're catching up. You're gonna see some strong action against countries that have been treating the U.S., our workers, and our companies unfairly. I see these companies as part of our workforce. It's started already, the legal stuff's mostly done. Big changes are coming, and soon. The U.S. has been getting a raw deal on trade for too long. Thank you. On Japan's defense, we buy a lot of equipment from the U.S. North Korea's getting tougher, Asia-Pacific's getting tougher, we need to beef up our defense, quality and quantity. F-35A, SM-3 Block IIA, those are examples. Aegis ships, gotta make 'em better. We'll be buying more from the U.S. That's the plan. North Korea launched missiles. We tracked 'em right away, knew where they were going. Missile defense is a joint thing, U.S. and Japan. We'll shoot 'em down if we have to, but we'll work with the U.S.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the possibility of chemical weapons being used, do you possess concrete intelligence suggesting that President Putin is in the process of deploying, positioning, or contemplating the use of such weapons? Furthermore, would the United States or NATO consider a military response should he employ them? [SEP] I'm unable to provide an answer to your first question; I won't disclose intelligence information. However, regarding your second question, we would respond if he uses chemical weapons. The specifics of our response would depend on the manner in which they are used.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Well, indulge all of us back in the U.S., sir. Prince passed away. You were a fan. You had invited him to perform at the White House. Can you tell us what made you a fan? [SEP] I'm trying to figure out which order to do this. [] Maybe I'll start with North Carolina and Mississippi. I want everybody here in the United Kingdom to know that the people of North Carolina and Mississippi are wonderful people. They are hospitable people. They are beautiful States, and you are welcome and you should come and enjoy yourselves. And I think you'll be treated with extraordinary hospitality.I also think that the laws that have been passed there are wrong and should be overturned. And they're in response to politics, in part; in part, some strong emotions that are generated by people, some of whom are good people, but I just disagree with when it comes to respecting the equal rights of all people, regardless of sexual orientation, whether they're transgender or gay or lesbian. And although I respect their different viewpoints, I think it's very important for us not to send signals that anybody is treated differently.And I think it's fair to say that we're not unique among countries where—particularly under a federal system in which power is dispersed, that there are going to be some localities or local officials that put forward laws that aren't necessarily reflective of a national consensus. But if you guys come to North Carolina or Mississippi, everybody will be treated well.The second question with respect to Syria, I am deeply concerned about the cessation of hostilities fraying and whether it's sustainable. Now, keep in mind that I have always been skeptical about Mr. Putin's actions and motives inside of Syria. He is—along with Iran—the preeminent backer of a murderous regime that I do not believe can regain legitimacy within his country because he's murdered a lot of people.Having said that, what I also believe is, is that we cannot end the crisis in Syria without political negotiations and without getting all the parties around the table to craft a transition plan. And that, by necessity, means that there are going to be some people on one side of the table who I deeply disagree with and whose actions I deeply abhor. That's how oftentimes you resolve conflicts like this that are taking an enormous toll on the Syrian people.The cessation of hostilities actually held longer than I expected. And for 7 weeks, we've seen a significant reduction in violence inside that country. And that gave some relief to people.I talked to Putin on Monday precisely to reinforce to him the importance of us trying to maintain the cessation of hostilities, asking him to put more pressure on Asad, indicating to him that we would continue to try to get the moderate opposition to stay at the negotiating table in Geneva. But this has always been hard. And it's going to keep being hard. And what David and I discussed in our meeting was that we will continue to prosecute the war against Daesh, against ISIL. We are going to continue to support those who are prepared to fight ISIL. And we're going to continue to target them. We're going to continue to make progress. But we're not going to solve the overall problem unless we can get this political track moving.I assure you that we have looked at all options. None of them are great. And so we are going to play this option out. If in fact the cessation falls apart, we'll try to put it back together again even as we continue to go after ISIL. And it is in my belief—it's my belief that ultimately Russia will recognize that, just as this can't be solved by a military victory on the part of those we support, Russia may be able to keep the lid on, alongside Iran, for a while, but if you don't have a legitimate Government there, they will be bled as well. And that is not—that's not speculation on my part. I think the evidence all points in that direction.And finally, with respect to Prince, I loved Prince because he put out great music and he was a great performer. I didn't know him well. He came to perform at the White House last year and was extraordinary and creative and original and full of energy. And so it's a remarkable loss.And I'm staying at Winfield House, the U.S. Ambassador's residence. It so happens our Ambassador has a turntable, and so this morning we played Purple Rain and Delirious just to get warmed up—[]—before we left the house for important bilateral meetings like this. []. As a fan of great music, the Ambassador has brought a lot of brilliant talent. . Absolutely.. Let me just answer: I've been to North Carolina many years ago and enjoyed it. I have not yet made it to Mississippi, but one day I hope to. The guidance that we put out, the Foreign Office, gives advice on travel, and it obviously deals with laws in situations as they are, and it tries to give that advice dispassionately, impartially. But it's very important that it does so. And it's something that a lot of attention is given to.Our view on any of these things is that we believe that we should be trying to use law to end discrimination rather than to embed it or enhance it. And that's something we're comfortable saying to countries and friends anywhere in the world. But obviously, the laws people pass is a matter for their own legislatures. But we make clear our own views about the importance of trying to end discrimination, and we've made some important steps forward in our own country on that front, which we're proud of.With that—— . All good?. Thank you very much. . Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. You're not going to expand on that, then? [SEP] I beg your pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. So, you can definitively rule out a government shutdown during the lame-duck session? [SEP] I can't say for sure. I'm not making any promises. Anything is possible, but I'm not committing to anything.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. One question, please. Please. Georgian Public Broadcasting. Mr. President, can you tell us what do you think about future membership of Georgia in NATO, please? [SEP] Well, at a certain point, they'll have a chance. Not right now. They just left the room. But at a certain point, they'll have a chance.Yes, sir. Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, critics suggest the G-8 summit was moved due to security concerns in Chicago. Is that accurate? [SEP] Not at all. We're still holding the NATO summit in Chicago, and I have complete faith in the city's ability to manage security. The G-8 move was simply an opportunity to host my fellow leaders at Camp David, a more intimate and informal setting. It's a chance for us to have candid discussions and build relationships. Plus, it allows me to meet with the new Russian President. Chicago is perfectly capable of handling the NATO summit; we've hosted major events there before.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, what actions will your administration take if Iran crosses the nuclear threshold? [SEP] That's a hypothetical situation, and I don't deal in hypotheticals. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, could you address the Pope's stance on Palestinian state recognition and its effect on the two-state solution, rather than discussing trade agreements? [SEP] Well, let me say this: trade is crucial for our economy, and I'm proud of the work we're doing to create jobs. But the situation in the Middle East is also a priority. The Pope's actions are significant, and we're carefully evaluating their potential impact. Our goal is to foster a climate conducive to peace, where Israelis and Palestinians can live side-by-side in security and prosperity. That requires a comprehensive approach, addressing not only political issues but also economic and social factors. We're committed to working with all parties to achieve a just and lasting solution. It's a complex challenge, but we're determined to make progress. And, of course, we'll continue to pursue trade deals that benefit American workers and strengthen our economy. It's all interconnected, you see.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with the CR expiring on December 11th, and considering the funding implications for Iraq, Syria, Ebola, and basic government operations, what are the odds of a government shutdown? How much does this possibility weigh on your immigration decisions? [SEP] I trust Senator McConnell's statement that the government won't shut down. There's no reason for it. We've been down that road before, it hurt the country, and it always ends the same way. It's unproductive, and I believe Senator McConnell and Speaker Boehner understand that. More generally, democracy means disagreement. Our system allows a Congress and President from different parties with different views. The key is how we handle it. The sensible approach is to fight for our positions on disagreements, then work together where we agree. That's how it was with Reagan and the Democratic Congress. They didn't let disagreements stop them from working together. I expect the same here. Some Republicans disagree with me on immigration reform, and that's their right. But shutting down the government over it makes no sense, like me shutting it down every time they try to repeal healthcare. Let's focus on the people's business.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, your predecessor faced similar congressional gridlock, yet you criticized his use of executive power. Now, facing the same obstruction, are you not doing precisely what you condemned? Has the political climate forced you to embrace the very tactics you once opposed? [SEP] The situations aren't exactly the same. I'm always aware of the constitutional limitations of my office. Congress controls the purse strings. I can't just conjure up a massive infrastructure bill, as much as I'd like to. But where I *do* have authority, I'm going to use it to help the American people. Fair wages, equal pay, student loan relief – these are things I can advance. I'd prefer congressional action, it's more lasting. But when they're paralyzed, I won't sit idly by. I am going to act within the limits of my power.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning Libya, you've stated your desire for Qadhafi to step down. Are you prepared to utilize any and all means at the disposal of the United States government to ensure his departure? If not, what's holding us back, especially given our seemingly more involved position compared to other similar situations? [SEP] Look, our first act was to get our people, the Americans and the Embassy staff, outta Libya safe and sound, and we did that. Right after, we slapped the biggest financial freeze on assets this country's ever seen. Then came the sanctions, and we got the whole world on board through the UN, slowly but surely turning the screws on Qadhafi. He's getting more and more cut off from everyone, with sanctions and no more weapons coming in. We're also sending aid to folks crossing into Tunisia and Egypt, making sure they're okay, and we'll keep doing that. We're talking with NATO about all sorts of moves, from watching the ground 24/7 so we can jump in if things get worse, to tightening the arms ban, sending more help, and even thinking about military options like a no-fly zone. NATO's meeting Tuesday to talk about that no-fly zone, and we've been chatting with Arab and African countries to see if they're with us on that. Hillary's meeting with the opposition soon, and we're sending someone over there to talk to them and see how we can help even more. So, bottom line, nothing's off the table. Gotta understand, we moved faster than anyone ever has to put the squeeze on Qadhafi. I'm crystal clear that it's in America's interest, and especially the Libyan people's, for Qadhafi to go. And I ain't ruling anything out. But I take it real serious when we're talking about using our military. Gotta think it through with Gates, Mullen, and everyone else. Sending our troops into a mess like that has risks, and it's my job to weigh 'em all. Gotta keep the world on our side too, as much as we can.
label: Deflection
