sentence: Mr. President, regarding the next bank bailout, given the public skepticism surrounding previous interventions, what specific guarantees can you offer that this new initiative will effectively stimulate lending to small businesses and consumers, and what mechanisms are in place to prevent abuse or misuse of funds? [SEP] We're not talking about a bailout. We're talking about a targeted investment to support our economy and create jobs. We will ensure that these funds are used responsibly and effectively. We will work with financial institutions to encourage lending to small businesses and consumers. We will hold them accountable for meeting their obligations. We are confident that this initiative will help to get our economy back on track.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, while acknowledging the immediate rescue efforts, critics point to systemic failures in pre-storm preparedness and long-term recovery planning. How do you respond to those specific criticisms regarding the government's broader responsibility beyond immediate rescue? [SEP] Hindsight is always 20/20, isn't it? We're learning from every experience, constantly improving our response protocols. But let's not lose sight of the incredible progress being made. We're focused on the future, on building a more resilient New Orleans, and on ensuring that every American has the support they need in times of crisis. That's our commitment, and we're delivering on it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, the Seattle City Council's decision to cut police funding, resulting in Chief Carmen Best's resignation, what does this tell us about America today and the 'defund the police' movement? [SEP] Seattle, after all they've been through, with the embarrassment of Antifa and the radical left taking over a large part of the city, a major city, that they allowed that to happen is unbelievable. That it took so long to fix is unbelievable. And they only acted because they knew we were going in the next day, and they didn't want to be embarrassed. The people just gave up, they were exhausted from having their city taken over for so long. The police commissioner seems like a very good woman. They were going to slash her salary by 40 or 50 percent. And they cut a tremendous amount from the police department, really, to the point where people are saying it's not sustainable as a good police department. And, again, those police are good also, but they're not allowed to do their job. So I think it's a shame. I hate to see her go, because she did, in her own way, a very good job, but she wasn't effective in convincing the mayor and the city council to give the funds that were needed or just leave the funds the way they are. They've done a big defund, a big part of it. And it will probably get worse before people realize this is a tragic error, before people start dying and getting hurt very badly. So I think Seattle has made a tragic mistake. I think Portland has no clue as to what they're doing. They have no clue. And hopefully, they'll be asking for help, because we can solve their problem very, very quickly.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, following your clear timeline for Iraq, what is your strategy and projected timeline for troop withdrawal from Afghanistan, and will you reconsider the ban on media coverage of returning fallen soldiers? [SEP] Let me begin by acknowledging the tragic loss of four American service members in Iraq today. My heart goes out to their families. The most difficult part of this job is signing those letters to the families of our fallen heroes. Regarding the media coverage policy, we are currently reviewing it in consultation with the Department of Defense. I prefer to withhold my answer until I have fully assessed the review's implications. Afghanistan presents a significant challenge. Unlike Iraq, where we've seen a relatively peaceful election, Afghanistan's government appears disconnected. The Taliban and Al Qaeda are active in the border regions. We need a coordinated effort to eliminate those safe havens. We are conducting a comprehensive review, and we require improved coordination across our military, diplomatic, and development initiatives. We cannot permit Al Qaeda to operate there. While I don't have a specific timeline yet, I will not allow Al Qaeda or bin Laden to plan attacks on the U.S. homeland.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President, are you implying a future normalization of relations with North Korea, similar to what we've achieved with Vietnam? [SEP] Repeat that.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what are your thoughts about a second round of direct payments to Americans that's included in the House Democratic bill? [SEP] Well, we're talking about that with a lot of different people. I want to see a payroll tax cut. I want to see various things that we want. I want the workers to be taken care of.But we are talking about that. We're negotiating with the Democrats. We'll see what happens. But as I said, it's a transition, and it's a—this is really going to be, in my opinion—we'll see, but I think it's going to be something that's going to be very special. It's a transition to greatness, and greatness is next year, right from the beginning. I think we're going to do fantastically well.I view the third quarter, as I said, as a transition quarter. It could be pretty good, but a transition quarter. Toward the end of the fourth quarter, you're going to see some numbers that are going to be tremendous, I think. And next year, you're going to have potentially the kind of numbers that you saw before, and maybe even better, because there is that pent-up demand that is—you know, a lot of people wanted to do things. They were ready to do things, and they've had to hold back because of the virus.So I think you're going to have, with that pent-up demand, a phenomenal year next year, unless somebody messes it up by coming along and raising taxes—doubling, tripling, quadrupling your taxes. Like a certain party, namely the Democrats want to do. You'll mess it all up.You know, we had the greatest in the world. I presided—this administration presided—over it. It got great for a reason. And we'll do it again, and we'll do it very quickly and very easily. I see that happening.Yes, ma'am. Please.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Senator McConnell's office released a statement highlighting the targeted nature of the CARES II relief package, yet it omits your payroll tax cut proposal. Do you concur with their assessment of 'perfectly tailored' despite this omission? [SEP] Look, I pushed hard for that payroll tax cut. It would've been a shot in the arm for the working class. But the Democrats, they just weren't having it. They're not interested in helping the average Joe. So, while I think the package could've been better, with the payroll tax cut, we had to move forward. It's a compromise. Is it perfect? No. But it's what we could get done with the obstruction we faced.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Sir, isn't it insensitive to focus on a 'global competition' when American lives are still at risk? [SEP] This isn't just an American problem, it's a global one. If you want answers, look to the origin. China has a lot to answer for. Next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Sir, given that—what you just laid out, should the American people be prepared for a large number of U.S. forces to remain in Iraq after you are finished with your Presidency? [SEP] The troop levels in Iraq will be determined by our commanders on the ground and the progress being made. Thank you.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, are you prepared to guarantee that we won't see a government shutdown before the new Congress is sworn in? [SEP] Well, I can't make any ironclad promises. There are a lot of moving parts here, and I'm not going to tie my hands by making a commitment I might not be able to keep. We'll see how things play out.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Earlier today the Vice President urged Governors to have all their nursing home residents tested. Why not just mandate that? Why not require that? Have you considered that? [SEP] Well, I would certainly consider that. I will mandate it if you'd like. I would—I think it's important to do, and I think, frankly, some of the Governors were very lax with respect to nursing homes. It was obvious right from the beginning. The State of Washington, where 26 or 28 people died very early on. And I would have said, nursing homes. And I did say nursing homes. That's what they should. Now, some of the States—many of the States are doing that, but I think all of the States should be. They have the capacity to do it. They should be doing nursing home. That is a real vulnerability.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the complexities in Afghanistan, and the upcoming Obama administration, will the Republican party offer bipartisan support for his strategies, particularly concerning troop deployment and dealing with Pakistan regarding terrorist activities? [SEP] Look, the President-elect is inheriting a tough situation. As a Republican, I want him to succeed. We've been working to ensure a smooth transition. Gates staying on sends a clear signal to Afghanistan. Expect more troops where the Taliban is active. I remember discussing this with Karzai and Musharraf – extremists using violence are a threat to everyone. We need a collaborative strategy, working with Pakistan to deal with those who harm their citizens and Afghans. I met with Zardari, reminding him my priority is defending our people. He gets it. We're consulting, and he's meeting with President Obama soon. It's about collaboration.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, there are claims circulating that Kamala Harris is ineligible to be Vice President because she was an anchor baby. What are your thoughts? [SEP] Well, I just heard that today. I just heard that she doesn't meet the requirements. And the lawyer that wrote that piece is a very good lawyer. I don't know if that's right. I would have thought the Democrats would have checked that out before she gets chosen.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering the complexities of the Syrian conflict, what specific role do you see for Russia and other regional powers in facilitating a peaceful transition of power? [SEP] We believe that all stakeholders have a responsibility to contribute to a peaceful resolution. Russia, in particular, has a unique opportunity to use its influence to encourage Assad to step down and engage in meaningful negotiations. We're willing to work with anyone who is genuinely committed to a peaceful and democratic future for Syria.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, you've emphasized the US-Japan alliance and a 'free and open Indo-Pacific.' How can the US champion these values while engaging with China, a nation with a fundamentally different political system? And Prime Minister, did the President express any disappointment regarding Japan's missile defense capabilities, and what is your message to him about Japan's future role? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, nobody makes better military equipment than the USA, and Japan knows it. They're buying the best from us, and that's good for jobs here. As for China, President Xi and I have a great relationship, the best! But they've been taking advantage of us on trade for years. We're going to fix that, make it fair, reciprocal, the best deal for America. The Prime Minister is doing a fantastic job modernizing their defense, and we're proud to be their partner.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President, did the leaks about the U.S. spying on South Korea come up in your talks? Did President Biden give you any assurances about it? [SEP] We are communicating and sharing necessary information. There's an investigation in the U.S., and things are complex. We need to wait for the results. We'll keep talking about it. This is the last question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, with the Mayor's mandate in place, are you concerned about the message it sends regarding the severity of the current health situation? [SEP] We're monitoring the data closely, and we'll follow the science. We're consulting with our medical experts to determine the best course of action. We want to ensure the safety of everyone who works in and visits federal facilities. We'll have more to say on this soon.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: With inflation soaring and global economic instability, are Americans facing an unavoidable recession? What is your administration's strategy to address this? [SEP] The American economy is facing challenges, but it is also showing remarkable strength. We are actively working to combat inflation and promote sustainable growth. While I cannot predict the future with certainty, I am committed to using every tool at our disposal to protect American families and businesses.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the memo from your National Security Advisor suggesting a break between Prime Minister Maliki and Muqtada Al Sadr, is this now the official US position? Did you discuss this specific issue with the Prime Minister this morning? And Prime Minister, your close relationship with Mr. Al Sadr has been identified as a central problem in Iraq. Did you assure the President that you would sever ties with Al Sadr, and could your government even remain standing after such a move? [SEP] I'm going to allow the Prime Minister to speak for himself regarding his relationship with Al Sadr. We spent a significant amount of time discussing the security situation in Iraq. I voiced my concerns, and he echoed those concerns. After all, providing security for the Iraqi people is one of his most important responsibilities. Part of the Prime Minister's frustration is that he lacks the necessary tools to deal with those who break the law. I was reassured by his commitment to a pluralistic society that is politically united, and a society in which people are held accountable if they break the law, whether they be criminals, Al Qaeda, or militia. He discussed his political situation with me, and I think it's best that he speak to you directly about the Sadr group or any other group within Iraq. Our coalition is not with just one entity. The national unity Government is a government formed of all the entities that participated in it. Therefore, that coalition represents a national responsibility. Mr. Sadr and the Sadrists are just one component that participate in the Parliament or in the Government. Participating in the Government is a responsibility, and it's a mutual commitment, and those who participate in this Government need to bear responsibilities. Foremost among those responsibilities is the protection of this Government, the protection of the Constitution, and the protection of the law. Therefore, I do not talk about one side at the expense of the other. I'm talking about a state; I'm talking about law; I'm talking about commitments. And this should apply to all the partners in the Government who have chosen to participate in the political process. As to the issues that would pertain to violating the law or breaking the law, we would deal with them the same way, because the most important principle is the sovereignty and the power and the establishment of the state that must be borne by the state, but only our partners should participate in that.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thanks, Sarah. Mr. President, Prime Minister. Mr. President, I hope you'll indulge me with two questions since we're far from home. The first one is: So if Kim Jong Un is not violating his promise to you by firing small weapons, as you said in your tweet yesterday, what would you consider a violation exactly? [SEP] Well, first of all, let me say that I think that Kim Jong Un, or Chairman Kim, as some people say, is looking to create a nation that has great strength economically. I think he's very much—I talk to him a lot about it, and he's very much into the fact that—he believes, like I do, that North Korea has tremendous economic potential like perhaps few other developing nations anywhere in the world.And I think that he is looking to develop that way. He knows that, with nuclear, that's never going to happen. Only bad can happen. He understands that. He is a very smart man. He gets it well.So I think that he is going to try, at some point. I'm in no rush at all. The sanctions remain. We have our hostages back. We, as you know, are getting the remains, continuing to get the remains. A lot of good things are happening.And, very importantly, there's been no nuclear testing for 2 years. I looked at a chart the other day. During the past administration, there were many numbers that were very high, like 10 and 12 and 18, having to do with missile launches and nuclear testing. And for the last 2 years, on the bottom, it had zero and zero. So I am very happy with the way it's going. And intelligent people agree with me.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, if you truly believed the Republican party was heading for a significant loss in the midterm elections, would you be forthright about that assessment? Furthermore, are you concerned by the apparent reluctance of certain Republican candidates to publicly align themselves with your administration? [SEP] With all due respect, the premise of your question is flawed. We are not going to lose. As for Republicans who are supposedly distancing themselves, I am not resentful. If Democrats want to use my image, I only ask that they select a flattering one. The media may be writing us off, but the election is far from over. My advice to Republican candidates is simple: focus on security and tax cuts, and victory will be ours.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. What are you going to do about the tensions that have been discussed? [SEP] Oh, I'm working on it. No, I'm working on it very hard.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the Israel Army Radio report regarding a possible Israeli attack on a Syrian nuclear site, do you have any further comment on the matter? [SEP] David, my position on this hasn't shifted.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you so much. I'd like to actually start by following up on Jeff's question and then ask you about supply chains as a follow-up to that.But, on the question of oil prices, economists say that, you know, when you raise the price of something, people will consume less of it. So why not allow even middle class people around the world to pay more for gasoline in the hope that they would consume fewer fossil fuels and emit less? [SEP] Well, because they have to get to their work. They have to get in an automobile, turn on the key, get their kids to school. The school buses have to run. That's the reason why. You know that, Jim. That's the reason.The idea that we can—that there's an alternative to walk away from being able to get in your automobile is just not realistic; it's not going to happen. And this wasn't intended to happen.And by the way, when the cost of a gallon of gasoline gets to above three hundred and thirty—three hundred—$3.35 a gallon, it has profound impact on working class families just to get back and forth to work. So I don't see anything inconsistent with that.But I do think that the idea that Russia and Saudi Arabia and other major producers are not going to pump more oil so people can have gasoline to get to and from work, for example, is—is not right. But—and what we're considering doing on that, I'm reluctant to say before I have to do it.
label: Explicit

sentence: Regarding Russia, the Democratic candidates seemed unfamiliar with Dmitry Medvedev. What's your assessment of him, and how much power does he truly wield with Putin still involved? Critics say you misjudged Putin. What cautionary advice would you give your successor about Russia and its new leader? [SEP] I don't know much about Medvedev either. It'll be interesting to see who represents Russia at the G-8, for example. That'll give us some insight into Russia's foreign policy after Putin's presidency. I can't answer that question yet. It's in our interest to maintain relations with Russia. For example, on proliferation, we need to ensure dangerous materials don't spread. We need to work together on Iran. I appreciated Putin's offer to provide enriched uranium to Iran for the Bushehr plant, negating their need to enrich it themselves. That was constructive. We need to be able to work with Russia on Iran. There are many areas where we need to cooperate. Yesterday, with the Czech Prime Minister, I discussed missile defense in Europe. It's in our interest to help Russia understand the system isn't aimed at them but at real 21st-century threats, like a launch from a violent regime with weapons of mass destruction. So, there are areas where we need to cooperate. I'm going to try to leave my successor with the ability to have a relationship with whoever is running foreign policy in Russia. It's in the country's interest. That doesn't mean we'll always agree. We disagreed on Kosovo, and there will be other disagreements. But it's in the country's interest to have a relationship, leader to leader, and beyond.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, both. To President Bush, China's crackdown on human rights is drawing intense scrutiny. People are being harassed and jailed just for speaking their mind, trying to speak their mind. I know you say that you speak candidly with President Hu about this, but with all eyes on Beijing and the world watching, I'd like to ask you directly, what do you think of how China treats its people?And, President Lee, I'd like to ask you— you noted progress in the six-party talks. Do you think that North Korea will go along with verification of its nuclear programs? For people who think that this is just another go-around, why will this time be any different? [SEP] I've been meeting with Chinese leaders now for 71⁄2 years; my message has been the same: You should not fear religious people in your society; as a matter of fact, religious people will make your society a better place; that you ought to welcome people being able to express their minds. And to the extent that people aren't able to do that and people aren't able to worship freely is—you know, I think is a mistake. And I explained it to him every single time.And the reason I'm going to the Olympics is twofold: one, to show my respect for the people of China; and two, to cheer on the U.S. team. And by the way, the order ought to be reversed as to why I may—went. I hope our team wins as many gold medals as possible, and if not win gold, silver, and if not silver, bronze.And this is an athletic event. But it's also an opportunity to say to the Chinese people, we respect your traditions; we respect your history. And as I said many times, I don't need the Olympics as an opportunity to express my views about religious freedom, since I have been doing it since I've been the President. I think I need to answer part of the question. As for the six-party talks and the prospects for the six-party talks, I think there are many skeptics as to the future of the six-party talks. I think many people around the world look at the behavior of up until today and they say—and they wonder whether will faithfully carry out verification. However, we have a difficult opposition, and I think right now is a good time to really praise the leadership of President Bush for dealing with a very difficult opponent.And as to what kind of behavior will take, what's most important is— number one is that we must have a denuclearization of . So I will be patient, I will be consistent, and I will do my best. And I have faith and I am confident that we will be able to move on to the verification process and move on to the next phase of that. And we will try to—our best to make it complete, and I believe that must faithfully cooperate in the verification processSo regardless of what has in mind, I believe it's important for the rest of the members of the six-party talks to continue pursuing our objective. And at times, we might have to wait; at times, we might be difficult, but we will be consistent.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Iran, there appears to be a growing discussion in Israel about a possible military strike against Iran's nuclear facilities. What is your assessment of this debate? And, Prime Minister Jansa, concerning climate change, how optimistic are you that an agreement with the U.S. can be reached in the coming years? [SEP] Well, let's put ourselves in Israel's shoes for a moment. If a neighboring leader openly threatened to wipe you off the map, and was pursuing nuclear weapons to do it, you'd be concerned too. That's why we all need to work together to stop Iran. There's a real urgency here, and you can hear it in the voices of Israeli politicians. I'm hopeful we can get this done. And, by the way, I believe we can reach a global climate change agreement during my presidency. It's the only real solution. Individual commitments from developed nations aren't enough, especially with rapidly developing countries like China. We need everyone at the table, with the most developed nations taking the lead. That's why these discussions are so important. As President Bush said, mandatory emission reduction targets for developed economies are key. How each economy reaches those targets is less important, but the goals must be set. This is how we address climate change. And we need to involve other countries too. Without the EU and the US working together, a global agreement is impossible in the short term. The G-8 summit in Japan next month is a crucial step if we want to reach an agreement before the UN conference in Copenhagen. Time is running out. Okay, last question from John McKinnon of the Wall Street Journal.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the ongoing trade negotiations with [Country Name], several key sticking points remain unresolved, particularly regarding intellectual property rights and market access. Could you provide specific details on the concessions your administration is willing to make to reach a mutually beneficial agreement, and what are the red lines that you will not cross? [SEP] We're negotiating very strongly. We're driving a hard bargain. They want a deal, and we want a deal, but it has to be a great deal for America. We're not going to be taken advantage of anymore. We're looking at everything, every angle. We'll get the best deal possible, believe me. It'll be fantastic. It'll be the best deal anyone's ever seen. We're working on it, and it's going to be great.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, aside from Huawei, are there any other Chinese technology companies that you are considering prohibiting from operating within the United States? [SEP] Well, Huawei is the primary concern, isn't it? We're not permitting them to operate here. And I've communicated to various European nations and others that while they are free to utilize Huawei's services, we will not be sharing intelligence with them. And they've all reconsidered. Take the UK, for example, they seemed inclined to go that route, but now they've reversed course.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the recent election results, you mentioned being surprised and disappointed. Does this suggest that after six years in office, you're out of touch with the American public, given that you didn't foresee such a significant shift? Also, does Nancy Pelosi bear any resemblance to Bob Bullock, in your opinion? [SEP] That's an inside joke; I'm not commenting on it. Secondly, I'm an optimistic person, is what I am. And I knew we were going to lose seats; I just didn't know how many.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: With Governor DeSantis's strong showing in Florida, how does he or Trump factor into your 2024 decision-making process? [SEP] Let them duke it out. Next question, please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the evident divisions within the House Republican Caucus, how confident are you that Speaker Boehner can secure the necessary support for a comprehensive agreement, and do you maintain trust in his leadership? [SEP] The Speaker undoubtedly faces internal challenges, which I acknowledge. It's often pointed out that a majority of his caucus represents districts that I did not win. Consequently, some members may perceive little incentive to cooperate with me, fearing challenges from within their own party. I understand this dynamic. However, recent events should provide a sense of perspective. We must prioritize the needs of the country. While disagreements may persist on various issues, compromise is essential to achieve deficit reduction, protect middle-class taxes, and foster economic growth. Avoiding self-inflicted crises will allow us to address critical issues such as preventing tragedies like Newtown and focusing on energy and immigration reform. By setting aside partisan divisions, we can work together for the betterment of the country. I believe the Speaker shares this desire. It is imperative to create an environment within both the House and Senate Republican caucuses that prioritizes the country's interests over political battles.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. Bush. A question for you about the process you're describing of your decisionmaking as Commander in Chief. Have you entertained the idea that at some point, Congress may take some of that sole decisionmaking power away through legislation? And can you tell us, are you still committed to vetoing any troop withdrawal deadline? [SEP] You mean in this interim period? Yes, absolutely. I don't think Congress ought to be running the war; I think they ought to be funding our troops. I'm certainly interested in their opinion, but trying to run a war through resolution is a prescription for failure, as far as I'm concerned, and we can't afford to fail.I'll work with Congress; I'll listen to Congress. Congress has got all the right to appropriate money. But the idea of telling our military how to conduct operations, for example, or how to deal with troop strength is—I don't think it makes sense. I don't think it makes sense today, nor do I think it's a good precedent for the future. And so the role of the Commander in Chief is, of course, to consult with Congress.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Sir, regarding the benchmarks with Iraq, why wasn't Prime Minister Maliki present at yesterday's press conference? Wouldn't his presence have signaled stronger cooperation? [SEP] Elaine, I haven't the slightest idea why he was absent.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. ——reorganization that happened at the National Security Council? [SEP] It's the—it's the administration. Perhaps they do that. You know, people let people go. You used to be with a different newspaper than you are now. You know, things like that happen.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, as a representative of the New York Times, could I have the opportunity to ask a question ahead of the others? [SEP] You say you're with...?
label: Clarification

sentence: You've inherited the situation in Crimea. What specific actions are you considering to address the annexation by Russia? [SEP] Look, Crimea is a problem. A big problem. We're looking at it. We're talking to people. We're exploring all avenues. But I'm not going to tell you what I'm going to do, because that would be foolish. We'll see what happens. It's a wait-and-see game.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, thank you. Just to follow, I understand what you're saying about when you were informed about the NIE. Are you saying at no point while the rhetoric was escalating, as world war III was making it into conversation, at no point nobody from your intelligence team or your administration was saying, maybe you want to back it down a little bit? [SEP] No, I've never—nobody ever told me that. Having said—having laid that out, I still feel strongly that is a danger. Nothing has changed in this NIE that says, okay, why don't we just stop worrying about it. Quite the contrary, I think the NIE makes it clear that needs to be taken seriously as a threat to peace. Their—my opinion hasn't changed.And I just explained, Jim [Jim Axelrod, CBS News], that if you want to avoid a really problematic situation in the Middle East, now is the time to continue to work together. That's our message to our allies, and it's an important message for them to hear. And here's the reason why: In order for a nation to develop a nuclear weapons program, they must have the materials from which to make a bomb, the know-how on how to take that material and make it explode, and a delivery system.Now, the ians—the most difficult aspect of developing a weapons program, or as some would say, the long pole in the tent, is enriching uranium. This is a na-tion— is a nation that is testing ballistic missiles. And it is a nation that is trying to enrich uranium. The NIE says this is a country that had a covert nuclear weapons program, which, by the way, they have failed to disclose, even today. They have never admitted the program existed in the first place.The danger is, is that they can enrich, play like they got a civilian program—or have a civilian program, or claim it's a civilian program—and pass the knowledge to a covert military program. And then the danger is, is at some point in the future, they show up with a weapon. And my comments are, now is the time to work together to prevent that scenario from taking place. It's in our interests.Yes, ma'am.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, Republicans are saying that this election was primarily about government spending. They insist that they will never accept anything resembling a stimulus bill or any of your proposals to stimulate job growth through spending. Do you concede that any form of government spending to create jobs is now off the table? If so, what alternative measures can the government take to address the critical issue of job creation? [SEP] Well, I think that's going to be a question for everyone to answer. The American people are concerned about spending and debt. I'm going to have a bipartisan deficit commission that will come up with some ideas. Hopefully, they can agree on some programs we can cut. But we can't cut into the core investments that are going to make sure that we are a competitive economy. So the question is, what are our priorities? What do we care about? That's going to be a tough debate. I inherited a big deficit, and that has been made worse because of the recession. As we bring it down, I want to make sure that we're not cutting into education. I don't think we should be cutting back on research and development. I think the proposal that I put forward with respect to infrastructure is one that we've had bipartisan agreement about. It makes no sense for China to have better rail systems than us. They're making investments because they know those investments will pay off over the long term. So in these budget discussions, the key is to be able to distinguish between stuff that isn't adding to our growth and those things that are absolutely necessary for us to be able to increase job growth in the future as well. Now, the single most important thing I think we need to do economically is making sure that taxes don't go up on middle class families next year. And so we've got some work to do on that front. I think it makes sense for us to extend unemployment insurance because there are still a lot of folks out there hurting. So there are some things that we can do right now that will help sustain the recovery and advance it, even as we're also sitting down and figuring out, okay, over the next several years what kinds of budget cuts can we make that are intelligent, that are smart, that won't be undermining our recovery, but, in fact, will be encouraging job growth.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. In fact, in your Inaugural Address, you said your whole soul was in bringing America together, uniting our people. . . . People heard the speech that you gave on voting rights in Georgia recently in which you described those who are opposed to you to George Wallace and Jefferson Davis, and some people took exception to that.What do you say to those who are offended by your speech? And is this country more unified than it was when you first took office? [SEP] Number one: Anybody who listened to the speech—I did not say that they were going to be a George Wallace or a Bull Connor. I said we're going to have a decision in history that is going to be marked just like it was then. You either voted on the side—that didn't make you a George Wallace or didn't make you a Bull Connor.But if you did not vote for the Act back then, you were voting with those who agreed with Connor, those who agreed with—and so—and I think Mitch did a real good job of making it sound like I was attacking them. If you've noticed, I haven't attacked anybody publicly—any Senator, any—any Congressman publicly. And my disagreements with them have been made to them—communicated to them privately or in person with them.My desire still is—look, I underestimated one very important thing: I never thought that the Republicans—like, for example, I said—they got very upset—I said there are 16 Members of the present United States Senate who voted to extend the Act.Now, they got very offended by that. That wasn't an accusation; I was just stating a fact. What has changed? What happened? What happened? Why is there not a single Republican, not one? That's not the .
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the potential consequences, would you agree to any debt ceiling bill, regardless of its duration? [SEP] Let me state this clearly: We will not be held ransom by those seeking to undermine the American economy. Paying our debts is a fundamental obligation, not a political bargaining chip. Default is not an option. It's a dangerous game that would have devastating consequences. Imagine the chaos if families decided to skip mortgage payments – the consequences would be catastrophic. Similarly, a nation's creditworthiness is paramount. Playing games with it jeopardizes our economic stability and future prosperity. We must reject this dangerous brinkmanship and uphold our commitment to fiscal responsibility.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, about Iran: the IAEA says they're speeding up uranium enrichment, and Ahmadi-nejad is defiant. Plus, they're holding Iranian Americans. Where does this end? Time for serious U.N. sanctions? Can we count on Russia and China? [SEP] Iran's always on the agenda, because they keep ignoring the world's demands. The world has said no to nuclear weapons, but they don't listen. We need to tighten the screws with sanctions. I just talked to Condoleezza Rice, and we're working with our European allies on more sanctions. I'll be talking to Putin and Hu Jintao about this too. They need to understand that a nuclear Iran is a disaster for everyone. It's in their best interest to work with us to isolate that regime. I feel for the Iranian people. They're stuck with a government that's pursuing a program the world condemns, and it's costing them economic opportunities. Iran's a great country with a rich history, but their government's actions are leading to more isolation. So, we're going to keep the pressure on. And the detention of innocent Americans is completely unacceptable. We've made that very clear to the Iranian government.
label: General

sentence: Sir, intelligence suggests Russia is meddling to hurt Biden, and China might meddle to hurt you. Do you believe these reports, and what's the plan to counter it? [SEP] Could be. I mean, it's possible – very much so. I think the last person Russia wants in office is Donald Trump, because nobody has been tougher on Russia than I have, ever.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you confirm whether he received an invitation to the event? [SEP] With all the moving parts around here, I couldn't possibly know every single invite that goes out. I delegate those responsibilities to my team.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Concerning the China trade agreement, if the Chinese bring up TikTok and WeChat, will your negotiators be permitted to discuss those issues? [SEP] Look, China's buying our corn, our soybeans, our beef. The farmers love me. The best deal ever. But TikTok, WeChat? That's a different story. National security. Big problem. We have a deadline. Microsoft's involved. The Treasury will get a cut. A big cut. But the China deal? It's fantastic. The best. They're buying everything. But they also gave us the virus. So, you know, it's a mixed bag. A very mixed bag.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Is that something that you will tackle in the future? [SEP] Yes, it was discussed. It will be discussed more in the future, human rights. What was also discussed in great detail, John, was that fact that, you know, we have—and I must have had just countless calls and letters and tweets, anything you can do—they want the remains of their sons back. They want the remains of their fathers and mothers and all of the people that got caught into that really brutal war, which took place, to a large extent, in North Korea. And I asked for it today, and we got it. That was a very last minute. The remains will be coming back. They're going to start that process immediately.But so many people, even during the campaign, they'd say, Is there any way you can work with North Korea to get the remains of my son back or my father back? So many people asked me this question. And you know, I said, Look, we don't get along too well with that particular group of people. But now we do. And he agreed to that so quickly and so nice—it was really a very nice thing, and he understands it. He understands it.So for the thousands and thousands—I guess way over 6,000 that we know of, in terms of the remains, they'll be brought back.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, subsequent to your meeting with Prime Minister Singh, what tangible assistance is the United States providing to India in its fight against terrorism originating from Pakistan? [SEP] A great man, a great leader.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. What are those preconditions? And do you believe he would ever be able to meet them? [SEP] Well, what I never do is, I never make a judgment what a man or woman is going to do or not do based on what they said. We'll see. If he made any commitment, then I would meet with him. And if there was a commitment on which we met—and the commitment has to be that there's discussion about his nuclear arsenal, and if it's merely an—a means by which how do we deescalate what they're doing.And so, if that was the case, I would not meet unless there was some outline made that my Secretary of State and others would have negotiated as to how we would proceed.But what I would not do is, I would not do what had been done in the recent past. I would not give him all that he's looking for is: national—international recognition as legitimate and say—and give them what allowed him to move in the direction of appearing to be more—how can I say it?—more serious about what he wasn't at all serious about.I'd have to know specifics. But the idea of never meeting with North Korea—I would make sure that my team had met with his counterparts—my—their counterparts and I know exactly what we're meeting on.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thanks, Mr. President. Given some of the harsh words you had about Mr. Trump, calling him temperamentally unfit to be Commander in Chief, did anything surprise you about President-elect Trump when you met with him in your office? And also I want to know, does anything concern you about a Trump Presidency? [SEP] Well, we had a very cordial conversation. And that didn't surprise me to some degree, because I think that he is obviously a gregarious person. He's somebody who, I think, likes to mix it up and to have a vigorous debate.And what's clear is that he was able to tap into, yes, the anxieties, but also the enthusiasm of his voters in a way that was impressive. And I said so to him, because I think that to the extent that there were a lot of folks who missed the Trump phenomenon, I think that connection that he was able to make with his supporters that was impervious to events that might have sunk another candidate, that's powerful stuff.I also think that he is coming to this office with fewer set, hard-and-fast policy prescriptions than a lot of other Presidents might be arriving with. I don't think he is ideological. I think ultimately, he's pragmatic in that way. And that can serve him well, as long as he's got good people around him and he has a clear sense of direction.Do I have concerns? Absolutely. Of course, I've got concerns. He and I differ on a whole bunch of issues. But the Federal Government and our democracy is not a speedboat, it's an ocean liner, as I discovered when I came into office. It took a lot of really hard work for us to make significant policy changes, even in our first 2 years, when we had larger majorities than Mr. Trump will enjoy when he comes into office.And one of the things I advised him to do was to make sure that before he commits to certain courses of action, he's really dug in and thought through how various issues play themselves out. I'll use a obvious example where we have a difference, but it will be interesting to see what happens in the coming year, and that's the Affordable Care Act.So, obviously, this has been the holy grail for Republicans over the last 6, 7 yearswas, We've got to kill Obamacare. Now, that has been taken as an article of faith, that this is terrible, it doesn't work, and we have to undo it.But now that Republicans are in charge, they've got to take a look and say, let's see, we've got 20 million people who have health insurance who didn't have it before; health care costs generally have gone up at a significantly slower rate since Obamacare was passed than they did before, which has saved the Federal Treasury hundreds of billions of dollars; people who have health insurance are benefiting in all sorts of ways that they may not be aware of, everything from no longer having lifetime limits on the claims that they can make, to seniors getting prescription drug discounts under Medicare, to free mammograms.Now, it's one thing to characterize thesethis thing as not working when it's just an abstraction. Now, suddenly, you're in charge, and you're going to repeal it. Okay, well, what happens to those 20 million people who have health insurance? Are you going to just kick them off, and suddenly, they don't have health insurance? And in what ways are their lives better because of that? Are you going to repeal the provision that ensures that if you do have health insurance on your job and you lose your job or you change jobs or you start a small business, that you're not discriminated against because you've got a preexisting condition? That's really popular. How are you going to replace it? Are you going to change the policy that kids can stay on their parent's health insurance plan until they're 26? How are you going to approach all these issues?Now, my view is that if they can come up with something better that actually works, and a year or two after they've replaced the Affordable Care Act with their own plan, that 25 million people have health insurance, and it's cheaper and better and running smoothly, I'll be the first ones to say, that's great, congratulations.If, on the other hand, whatever they're proposing results in millions of people losing coverage and results in people who already have health insurance losing protections that were contained in the legislation, then we're going to have a problem. And I think that's not going to be unique to me; I think the American people will respond that way.So I think on a lot of issues, what you're going to see is, now comes the hard part. Now is governance. We are going to be able to present to the incoming administration a country that is stronger; a Federal Government that is working better and more efficiently; a national security apparatus that is both more effective and truer to our values; energy policies that are resulting in not just less pollution, but also more jobs.And I think the President-elect, rightly, would expect that he's judged on whether we improve from that baseline and on those metrics, or things get worse. And if things get worse, then the American people will figure that out pretty quick. And if things get better, then more power to him. And I'll be the first to congratulate him.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. What is your stance on direct talks? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to discuss that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Could you talk a little about why it works, you think? [SEP] And I do think—and I do think that—look, here's the story: I have people say: Oh, just make a deal. Make a deal. They don't have the guts, and they don't have the wisdom to know that you can't continue to go on where a country is taking $500 billion—not million—$500 billion, with a b—out every single year. Five hundred billion dollars. You just can't do that. Somebody had to do this.This should have been done by President Obama. It should have been done—and Biden, Sleepy Joe. It should have been done by other people. It should have been done by Bush. It should have been done by Clinton. Double Bush. It should have been done. I'm doing it.Let me tell you something else: North Korea should've been done a long time ago. I'm doing it. I'm doing a lot of things that I shouldn't have to be doing.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, you've granted clemency to drug offenders, yet many also had firearm charges. How does that align with your views on gun violence? [SEP] Each case is unique, and we carefully review the circumstances. We believe in redemption and second chances, but we also take gun violence very seriously.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Are you suggesting that that was overblown? Are financial markets overreacting here? [SEP] I think the financial markets are very upset when they look at the Democrat candidates standing on that stage making fools out of themselves. And they say, If we ever have a President like this—and there's always a possibility. It's an election. You know, who knows what happens, right? I think we're going to win. I think we're going to win by a lot.But when they look at the statements made by the people standing behind those podiums, I think that has a huge effect, yes.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, the economic recovery seems to be slower than anticipated. Given the current trajectory, are you confident that you can deliver on your promise of a strong and vibrant economy by the time you seek re-election? [SEP] We are making progress, and I am confident that we will continue to see improvements in the economy. However, it's important to remember that economic recovery takes time, and there are always challenges along the way. We are committed to implementing policies that will foster long-term growth and create opportunities for all Americans. The American Jobs Act is a critical component of our strategy, and I am optimistic that it will have a positive impact on the economy.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. But I notice you did not mention that your supporters were also in Portland this weekend, firing paintball guns at people, some form of pepper spray. So do you want to also take this chance to condemn what your supporters did in Portland? [SEP] Well, I understand they had large numbers of people that were supporters, but that was a peaceful protest. And paint is not—and paint is a defensive mechanism; paint is not bullets.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, considering this is your third year and budget, and your commitment to doing what's hard even if it costs you re-election, why not invite Republicans to the table now? Beyond rhetoric, what specific actions are you taking to build the spirit of cooperation? And, realistically, can the markets endure two more years of this? [SEP] That's quite a multifaceted question. Remind me of the key elements again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, considering the challenges facing Africa, what key actions should the continent prioritize, what leadership qualities are essential, and how can the United States effectively support its transformation? Furthermore, what specific outcomes do you hope to achieve during this five-nation tour, and why have you chosen to visit Africa towards the end of your presidency? How will you ensure the sustainability of your initiatives? [SEP] Well, thank you. Actually, I made a point to visit Africa early in my presidency as well. This marks my second trip to the continent, and I'm here to underscore that it is in our best interest to assist African nations in addressing preventable diseases like malaria, as well as more complex challenges such as HIV/AIDS. It's also in our interest to foster trade between Africa and the United States, and to allocate resources towards education so that governments can educate their children. There's no better way to emphasize this point than by being in Ghana, where people can witness firsthand what I'm talking about. It's one thing to deliver speeches in America, but it's quite another to come to Ghana and meet the individuals who are actively involved in making Ghana a better place. Secondly, Africa has undergone positive changes since I assumed the presidency. This is primarily due to the efforts of African leaders themselves – I want to emphasize that. When I took office, there were six regional conflicts. Consider Liberia, for instance. It presented a significant challenge, and with the collaboration of Nigeria and the advice of individuals like John, we made decisions, along with other leaders, that facilitated the installation of the first democratically elected woman on the continent's history. I'll be visiting there tomorrow to celebrate her accomplishments and reaffirm our commitment to providing support. In other words, conflict resolution has been underway. And the United States has refrained from imposing its will. Instead, we've strived to be a valuable partner, as exemplified by our work in eastern Congo, where we collaborated with the Presidents of Rwanda, Congo, and Burundi. Secondly, democracy is advancing across the African continent. One reason for this progress is the presence of role models like John Kufuor, whom people look up to and respect. And thirdly, our aid program has evolved from simply providing funds with no strings attached to one that expects certain behaviors in return for our generosity, such as combating corruption and investing in the education of children. I don't believe that's an unreasonable expectation in exchange for U.S. taxpayers' money. This approach is novel, but I'm confident in asking nations to adhere to sound principles because I believe in setting high standards for African leaders. I have confidence in the capabilities of the leaders I've met—not every single leader—but on this trip, the leaders I'm with are leaders who have committed themselves to the good of their people, have committed themselves to honest government, have committed themselves to investing in people. They're more interested in leaving behind a legacy of education than leaving behind fancy—a self-serving government. And there's no better way of making that point than coming to the continent. And that's why I'm here, and I'm glad I am. It's been a great trip, and it's—and I appreciate the hospitality of my friend, and so does Laura. Let's see here, John McKinnon. He would be from your Wall Street Journal. Yes, that's a pretty sophisticated paper, no question about that.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the Jacksonville event was scaled back due to rising COVID-19 cases. Doesn't this suggest that reopening too quickly can backfire? How do you reconcile this with your push to reopen schools and resume Major League Baseball, especially given the potential for outbreaks? [SEP] We're learning as we go. We're making adjustments as needed. Baseball is important. It's part of our culture. We want to get back to normal. We're working with the teams, the players, the health experts to do it safely. We're going to monitor the situation closely. We're going to make sure we're protecting the American people. We have to get back to work. We have to get our economy going again. We can't let the cure be worse than the disease. You know, I know a lot of baseball players. Great people. They want to play. We're going to find a way.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. If I could follow up, Mr. President. Amid talks of arming teachers and mental health, what specific commitments to American students can you make that these policies will make them safer? [SEP] Well, I think it's going to make it safer, and, you know, the problem that's been happening over the last 20 years is people have talked—you said it—it's all talk, it's no action. And we're going to take action. I think it's going to make it safer. I think the fact that you have some capability within a school, they're not going to go into that school. They're not going to do it.You can look at what's happened with airplanes where we put marshals on planes with guns; where pilots, in many cases, have guns. Nothing has happened for a long period of time, when it used to almost—it was getting to a point of being routine. When you have somebody with a gun staring you down, it's going to be a lot different for them to walk into those schools.Right now they look at the sign outside, This is a gun-free environment. That means they're the only one with a gun. And the damage this lunatic did in that school for such a long period of time.And, frankly, you had a gun, and he was outside as a guard, and he decided not to go in. That was not his finest moment, that I can tell you. He waited, and he didn't want to go into the school. I just heard this, and it's a terrible situation.But we need people that can take care of our children. We're not going to let this happen again. And the way it's not going to happen again—because they're basically cowards. Innately, they're cowards. And if they know bad things happen to them, once they get into that school, by people that love the children—see, a security guard doesn't know the children, doesn't love the children. This man standing outside of the school the other day doesn't love the children, probably doesn't know the children. The teachers love their children; they love their pupils; they love their students. They're doing it also from love. Now, they have to be very adept. I'm not talking about every teacher; I'm talking about a small percentage. But people that have great ability with weaponry, with guns, those are the only people I'm talking about it. But they'll protect the student.For the Prime Minister?
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the travel ban from Europe is causing considerable consternation. Can you clarify the scientific justification for maintaining this ban while allowing travel from Turkey, where infection rates are reportedly higher? Furthermore, what steps are being taken to address the economic anxieties expressed by Chancellor Merkel regarding potential business departures? [SEP] The Chancellor brought this up, and we had a very frank discussion about it. Our COVID team is actively reviewing the situation. The key is to make sure we're following the science and making decisions that protect the American people. We're aiming to lift the ban as soon as it's safe to do so. I expect to have a more concrete answer for you very soon. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a dinner engagement.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President, the public's trust in the government's handling of the coronavirus pandemic is waning. Given the inconsistent messaging from various agencies, why haven't you taken decisive action to streamline the response and restore public confidence? [SEP] Look, this is a novel virus, and we're all learning as we go. The scientific community is constantly updating its understanding of the virus, and that inevitably leads to some changes in recommendations. As for the CDC, they're working tirelessly to provide the best possible guidance. It's not always easy to communicate complex scientific information in a clear and concise manner. But we're committed to improving our communication efforts. And let's not forget the incredible progress we've made in developing vaccines and treatments. We're doing everything we can to protect the American people. I think that's enough on that topic.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, you've spoken about the rise of nationalism. What's your message to protestors demonstrating against Donald Trump's rhetoric? Have you advised your successor to be mindful of his staff picks? Finally, in your last weeks, can you stop Assad and Putin from bombing Aleppo? Chancellor Merkel, Assad calls Trump a natural ally, while your Foreign Minister calls him a preacher of hate. Do Americans have a perception problem? [SEP] Well, one of the great things about our democracy is that it expresses itself in many ways, including protests. I've been protested during my eight years, and I think every president has been. So, I wouldn't tell people who feel strongly about the issues raised during the campaign to be silent. What I would advise, and have advised, is that elections matter, voting matters, organizing matters, being informed on the issues matters. I consistently tell young people, in the U.S. and here in Germany, don't take our systems of government and way of life for granted. Because we've lived in a largely stable and peaceful era, with rising living standards, there's a tendency to assume it will always be this way. But it's not. Democracy is hard work. In the U.S., if 43 percent of eligible voters don't vote, democracy is weakened. If we're not serious about facts, especially in an age of social media where people get information in soundbites, if we can't distinguish between serious arguments and propaganda, we have problems. If people, conservative or liberal, are unwilling to compromise and demonize opponents, democracy will break down. So, my advice is to understand the foundations of a healthy democracy and how to engage in citizenship continuously, not just when something upsets us or during an election. It's hard work. The good news is, many young people involved in my campaigns continue to be involved in work, politically and through nonprofits, that can carry this hard work forward. But sometimes there's complacency. Here in Europe, many young people forget the Cold War and what it meant to have a wall. And I'll be honest, I've heard rhetoric in Europe that equates the U.S. and Russia, and how our governments operate versus other governments, and those distinctions aren't made. I've said many times that, like any government, we have flaws, we've operated imperfectly, we've made mistakes. There are times when I've made mistakes or our administration hasn't always aligned with our values. It's a work of constant improvement. But I can say to the German people that the U.S. has been good for Germany, has looked out for Germany, has provided security for Germany, has helped to rebuild Germany and unify Germany. And across Europe, many principles taken for granted here around free speech, civil liberties, an independent judiciary, and fighting corruption are principles that, not perfectly, but generally, we've tried to apply not just in our own country, but also in our foreign policy. That should be remembered. Because in an age of active misinformation, packaged well and looking the same on Facebook or TV, where overzealousness by a U.S. official is equated with constant and severe repression elsewhere, if everything seems the same and no distinctions are made, we won't know what to protect. We won't know what to fight for. And we can lose so much of what we've gained in terms of democratic freedoms, market-based economies, and prosperity that we've come to take for granted. That was a long answer, wasn't it? I don't remember if there was a second part to it. I got all caught up in that one.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, do you anticipate this legislation being passed in the first year of your administration? [SEP] We're moving forward this year, and I'm pushing it as fast as I can. Some say I'm doing too much. We're going full steam ahead on everything. But at the end of the day, I don't control the legislative calendar. We'll be working with the leaders in Congress to see what we can accomplish. Andre Showell [Black Entertainment Television]. There you go.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. President Tran Dai Quang, I'm from Vietnam News Agency. What is—can you elaborate of progresses in the Vietnam-U.S. relations over the past years? [SEP] Well, dear reporters, over the past years, the Vietnam-U.S. relations have made very strong progress in all areas, from politics, diplomacy, economy, trade, science and technology, health, humanitarian areas, and people-to-people exchange.And in particular, high-level contacts, meetings, and exchange of delegations on the basis of the comprehensive partnership have produced substantive and meaningful results. And among them, the visit to the United States by Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc in May this year and the state visit to Vietnam of Honorable President Donald Trump in the very first year of his term of office are the highlights.Meetings between leaders of Vietnam and the President during his visit are very useful, and the meetings give us the opportunity to understand each other better and to work together on areas of mutual interests. The substantive and effective growth of the comprehensive partnership between the two countries have been, and will be, delivering benefits to our two peoples and contributing to the maintenance of peace, stability, cooperation, and prosperity in the region and the world. Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the evolving geopolitical landscape, what specific steps are you taking to strengthen alliances and partnerships with countries like Albania to address emerging security threats and promote shared interests? [SEP] We are committed to strengthening our alliances and partnerships through enhanced cooperation on defense, intelligence sharing, and economic development. We are also working closely with our allies to address emerging security threats, such as terrorism, cyberattacks, and disinformation campaigns, to promote stability and prosperity.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding human rights, your State of the Union address was quite forceful, particularly highlighting the plight of North Koreans. You even had a defector present. You stated then that North Korea's oppression was unparalleled. Now, after meeting with Kim Jong Un, do you still hold that view? And do you believe he needs to address these human rights concerns? [SEP] Well, it's certainly a challenging situation there, no doubt about it. We had a robust discussion about it, a very strong discussion, I would say. Of course, the primary focus was denuclearization, but we dedicated a significant amount of time to the human rights issue. We're going to be working on it. It's a difficult situation in many places, not just there, but we're committed to addressing it. I believe we'll eventually reach an agreement. It was definitely a key topic, separate from the nuclear issue.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Is the individual mandate one of those lines you can't cross? [SEP] Yes, the individual mandate is a line I can't cross because the concept, borrowed from Massachusetts, from a law instituted by a former opponent of mine, Mitt Romney, understood that if you're providing health insurance to people through the private marketplace, then you've got to make sure that people can't game the system and just wait until they get sick before they go try to buy health insurance. You can't ensure that people with preexisting conditions can get health insurance unless you also say, while you're healthy, before you need it, you've got to get health insurance.And obviously, there are hardship exemptions. We understand that there are some folks who, even with the generous subsidies that have been provided, still can't afford it. But that's a central component of the law.In terms of enrollment, we'll do some additional announcements about that in the days to come. Starting in the middle of this month, people can sign up again. I think there are a number of people who the first time around sat on the sidelines in part because of our screw-ups on healthcare.gov. That's one area, Ed, by the way, that's very particular. We're really making sure the website works super well before the next open enrollment period. [] We're double- and triple-checking it. And so I think a lot of people who maybe initially thought, we're not sure how this works, let's wait and see—they're going to have an opportunity now to sign up. And what's been terrific is to see how more private insurers have come into the marketplace so that there's greater competition in more markets all around the country. The premiums that have come in that are available to people and the choices that are available are better than a lot of people, I think, had predicted.So the law is working. That doesn't mean it can't be improved.Major Garrett. [CBS News]
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, on the subject of Iran, how will you gauge their sincerity regarding rejoining the nuclear talks, as they've indicated they will by late November? And what penalties are you ready to levy against Iran if they persist in carrying out attacks against the United States, like the recent drone strikes targeting U.S. forces in Syria? [SEP] We're looking at two different things here. First, there's the JCPOA, and whether we can get back to it. That depends on their actions and whether our friends are willing to stick with us and make sure there's an economic price to pay if they don't come back. Second, there's the matter of how we'll respond to their actions against the U.S., whether drone strikes or anything else. We will respond, and we'll keep responding.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And if I could also ask you something about—happening back home. You're seeing the GOP grappling with tying abortion rights to defense issues, including a block on military promotions by Senator Tuberville. What does this say about U.S. military readiness? And would you be willing to talk with Tuberville to try to work out some solution? [SEP] I'd be willing to talk to him if I thought there was any possibility of him changing this ridiculous position he has. He's jeopardizing U.S. security by what he's doing.I expect the Republican Party to stand up—stand up—and do something about it. They—it's within their power to do that.The idea that we don't have a Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; the idea that we have all these—all these promotions that are in abeyance right now and we don't know what's going to happen; the idea that we're injecting into fundamental foreign policy decisions what, in fact, is a domestic social debate on social issues is bizarre.I don't ever recall that happening, ever. And it's just totally irresponsible, in my view.And I just think that—I mean, I'm confident that the mainstream Republican Party no longer—does not support what he's doing. But they've got to stand up and be counted. That's how it ends.
label: Implicit

sentence: So, this immigration bill from the House... is it gonna fly? And what's the deal with Mexico changing how they talk to our law enforcement? [SEP] I like what the Senate did with their immigration bill. Wouldn't have written it exactly like that, but it hits the main points: better border security, cracking down on employers, easier legal immigration, and a way for folks to earn citizenship. We'll see what the House comes up with. As for Mexico, I'm looking forward to talking to their new President. We'll work on the economy and security. Seems like their changes are mostly about them getting their own house in order.
label: General

sentence: President Obama, with the TPP seemingly stalled in Congress and other countries awaiting U.S. action, are you rethinking your strategy for its approval, especially given the recent Boeing and GE announcements? Should the agreement be revised to address currency manipulation concerns? Also, your thoughts on the killing of Taliban leader Mullah Mansur and Pakistan's concerns about the strike on their soil? Does this signal a new offensive in Afghanistan, and are you worried about a more hardline leader taking over? [SEP] Well, on TPP, I’ve been around long enough to know that every trade deal is painful, because folks are always seeing if they can get an even better deal. And especially when you have multiple parties involved, folks are going to be scrutinizing it, they're going to be debating it, and in an election year, you can anticipate that some folks are going to try to score political points off it. Having said that, I remain confident we're going to get it done. And the reason I'm confident is because it's the right thing to do. It's good for the country. It's good for America. It's good for the region. It's good for the world. And I know I've sold this to you before, but let me reiterate: This is the fastest growing part of the world. This represents an enormous market for the United States. Most countries here already sell their stuff to the United States, and we have relatively low tariffs. In other words, we put relatively low taxes on goods that are coming into the United States. In contrast, tariffs are significantly higher for U.S. goods being sold here. So a deal that gets rid of 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods into the largest, fastest growing markets of the world, that's a good deal for American businesses and American workers. Number two, one of the biggest complaints about trade deals historically has been that it opens up our markets to countries with lower wages, harsher labor practices, less environmental regulations. Well, if you're signing up for the Trans-Pacific Partnership, you are making commitments that are enforceable to raise labor standards, to ensure that workers have a voice, to attend to environmental problems. And so this gives us the ability to engage with a country like Vietnam and work with them on all those fronts, the precise things that people, in the past, have been concerned about when it comes to trading with other countries. So I have not yet seen a credible argument that once we get TPP in place we're going to be worse off. We are demonstrably better off. American workers and American businesses are better off if we get this deal passed. And I'm confident we will get it passed. Now, the politics of it will be noisy. That was true when I, for example, inherited the Korean free trade agreement or the Colombian and Panamanian free trade agreements when I came into office. But we got them done. And I'm confident that we'll get them done this time, as well, although it will—there will be ups and downs and bumps along the way. With respect to currency manipulation, we have provisions in TPP that advance the transparency and reporting functions that allow us to monitor whether we think that currency manipulation is taking place. One of the debates that took place—and there have been some who argue that we should have enforceable provisions that if you see currency going down too far that we should be able to impose tariffs on that country. The problem is, is that it's very hard to sort out sometimes why currency is going down and whether it's actually being manipulated. And frankly, for us to bind other countries to commitments about their monetary policy would mean we were also binding our Federal Reserve to the claims of other countries in terms of how it implements our monetary policy, and that's not something that we would do. We would not give up sovereignty with respect to our monetary policy in that way. But we have strengthened a number of the provisions that are already contained in TPP that will allow us to put on notice folks who we think are engaging in competitive devaluations. Finally, on the Taliban leader, Mr. Mansur, it has been confirmed that he is dead. And he is an individual who, as head of the Taliban, was specifically targeting U.S. personnel and troops inside of Afghanistan who were there as part of the mission that I've set to be able to maintain a counterterrorism platform and provide assistance and training to the Afghan military forces there. So this does not represent a shift in our approach. We are not reentering the day-to-day combat operations that are currently being conducted by Afghan security forces. Our job is to help Afghanistan secure its own country, not to have our men and women in uniform engage in that fight for them. On the other hand, where we have a high-profile leader who has been consistently part of operations and plans to potentially harm U.S. personnel and who has been resistant to the kinds of peace talks and reconciliation that ultimately could bring an end to decades of war in Afghanistan, then it is my responsibility as Commander in Chief not to stand by, but to make sure that we send a clear signal to the Taliban and others that we're going to protect our people. And that's exactly the message that has been sent.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to Cuba, does this new policy mean the U.S. will cease its attempts at regime change? And on the subject of Hillary Clinton, do you agree with Vice President Biden that the Democratic race remains wide open? [SEP] I'm finished with elections, and I'm not in the business of making predictions. That's your role. Plenty of people are happy to speculate; I won't be among them. Regarding Cuba, we're not focused on regime change. We're dedicated to empowering the Cuban people with freedom and the ability to shape their own future, supporting civil society. Cuba will evolve regardless. President Castro referred to actions that occurred before I was even born; the Cold War is over. We'll still have disagreements with Cuba, including their government's treatment of its people and regional issues. But we can find areas of cooperation. Cuban doctors provided assistance during Ebola; their work in Haiti after the earthquake was valuable. I told President Castro we'll voice our opinions, but persuasion is paramount, particularly on issues that don't directly endanger our national security. Cuba isn't a threat. My concerns are ISIL, Iran's nuclear ambitions, Yemen, Libya, Boko Haram, Russian aggression in Ukraine, climate change – a substantial list. We'll collaborate with the region, be clear about our values, and partner to enhance opportunity, prosperity, and security. Overreach often proves counterproductive, providing countries with excuses for their failures. Let's remove that excuse.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Concerning Huawei, sir, and its current status on the entity list, is there any chance of its removal? [SEP] I'm not going to comment on that specifically at this time.
