We are reviewing the situation very closely. Huawei is a major player when it comes to our national interests, especially regarding intelligence matters. We have a lot of information, but I don't want to get into specifics. Let's just say we're keeping our options open and will address it at a later date.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. But has Mr. Netanyahu made concessions? [SEP] But I think we really—I think we have, actually, a good shot at peace between Israel and the Palestinians.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with the fence project underway, what immediate threats necessitate this reinforcement along the Finnish-Russian border? And as a nation bordering Russia, what further deterrents do you deem essential to curb Putin's ambitions? [SEP] From the very beginning of our application, we focused on anticipating potential problems and crafting suitable solutions. This proactive approach has resulted in a fairly peaceful situation. We're optimistic it will stay that way. But I want to highlight that Finnish people feel much safer now. Right now, 80% support joining NATO, and more than 80% say they'll protect our friends. That's where Finland stands.
label: General

sentence: President Obama, President Dilma, how do you reconcile the differing views of Brazil as a regional versus global player? [SEP] Allow me to also respond to the question directed at President Dilma. We consider Brazil not just a regional power, but a global one. Consider the G-20, a leading economic forum – Brazil is a major voice. The Paris climate negotiations depend on Brazil's leadership. Their renewable energy goals are indicative of this. Brazil is a major global player. I conveyed to President Dilma that the U.S., despite its strength, cannot address global challenges alone. Global health requires Brazil's partnership to prevent pandemics. Climate change, terrorism, poverty – all necessitate Brazil's involvement. They are an indispensable partner.I have a strong relationship with President Dilma. I trust her completely. She's always been forthcoming about Brazil's interests. She delivers on her promises. The defense cooperation agreements we discussed in Panama? She secured them through Congress – a significant achievement. This demonstrates her reliability.This meeting builds upon growing cooperation. Differences will inevitably arise, but that is true of all close friends and allies. We share common values, strong people-to-people connections, and similar histories. We should be strong partners for years to come.A portion of my answer was already articulated by [Obama], and I thank him for that. Countries experience crises. This should not diminish their role. A great country overcomes difficulties. This applies to nations, individuals, and all aspects of life: the bravery to overcome challenges and maintain commitment to one's people and country.It also applies to relations with countries like the U.S. Brazil and the U.S. share much in common. We both fought to overcome slavery. We have large Black populations and multicultural societies. These are valuable assets.We are also strong democracies. I congratulated [Obama] for overcoming the 2008 crisis. Brazil will overcome its current crisis. We will do so decisively, with a strong sense of commitment.We will not only resume growth but also safeguard the progress we have made in the past 12 years. We will build a predominantly middle-class country. Efforts to reduce inequality are a significant achievement, and we must strive to preserve them.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the QAnon movement seems to be gaining traction. What are your thoughts on this, and what message do you have for its followers? [SEP] Look, I don't know much about QAnon, except that I hear they like me, which is nice. I've heard they're becoming more popular. From what I understand, these are people who are concerned about what's happening in places like Portland and New York. They love our country and don't like seeing it go downhill. So, I don't really know much about it, other than they supposedly like me and want to see these problems in Democrat-run cities fixed. If the Democrats can't handle it, we'll send in the Feds and straighten things out in 24 hours. Okay?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Can you clarify, what did they commit to doing? Is that satisfactory to you? [SEP] Yes. So what they're doing is spending at a much faster clip. They're going up to the 2 percent level. Now, you have to understand, some of them have parliaments, they have their own congresses, they have a lot of things they have to go through. So, you know, they're here as Prime Minister or as a President, and they can't necessarily go in and say, this is what we're going to do. But they're going back for approvals.Some are at 2 percent; others have agreed definitely to go to 2 percent. And some are going back to get the approval—and which they will get—to go to 2 percent. After the 2 percent, we'll start talking about going higher. But I said, Ultimately, we should be, in years—in advance—we should be at 4 percent. I think 4 percent—it's the right number.Now, the United States—depending on the way you calculate it—was at 4.2 percent. And I said, That's unfair. And we have the largest GDP by far, especially since we've increased it by so much since a thing called the election. Our GDP has gone way up. And so the fact that our GDP went way up, that means we're paying for even more, which is very unfair. So I explained that.We will go to much higher than 2 percent into the future, but right now we're getting people up to 2 percent, and that will take place over a fairly short period of time—a short number of years. Okay?
label: General

sentence: President Trump, is there a formal transcription available of your dialogue with Chairman Kim? [SEP] What was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. What's the timeline for Kosovo's independence? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with the situation unfolding in Ukraine, and given your past interactions with President Putin, how do you now assess his strategic objectives and the potential for further Russian aggression? Furthermore, what assurances can you provide to our allies in Eastern Europe regarding the United States' commitment to their security in the face of these challenges? [SEP] Look, I've always been clear-eyed about Putin. He's a tough customer, and he's looking out for Russia's interests. But let me be clear: any further aggression against Ukraine will be met with a swift and unified response from the United States and our allies. We stand shoulder to shoulder with our partners in Eastern Europe, and we will defend every inch of NATO territory. Our commitment is unwavering.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President, with all due respect, your answer sounds like a standard diplomatic response. The South Korean public is deeply concerned about these allegations. Can you assure them that you are taking this matter seriously and that you will demand a full and transparent accounting from the United States? [SEP] The security and well-being of the South Korean people are my top priority. I can assure you that we are taking this matter very seriously. We will continue to engage with the United States to ensure that our concerns are addressed. We expect a full and transparent accounting of the facts, and we will take appropriate action based on the results of the investigation.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And then, really quickly, sir: Do you—you've said this numerous times, but do you really believe that Joe Biden will be on any type of performance-enhancing drug ahead of the debates? Or are you just joking? [SEP] No, I'm not joking. I mean, I'm willing to take a drug test. I think he should too, because he's had a very uneven—I watched him with some of the—when he was with—you know, debating Pocahontas and Harris, who treated him so badly. But I watched him, and he was out of it. Right?And then, I watched him against Bernie Sanders, and he was okay. I mean, he wasn't great, but he wasn't terrible. He was okay. A far cry from the way he—you know what I'm saying. I mean, if you look at some of those debates, I said, There's no way he can continue. He can't continue.Then, all of the sudden, he debated Crazy Bernie Sanders. And you know what? The truth is, he was okay. And I said, How did he go from there, with those horrible performances, to where he was okay? And I always joke, but you know, it is true: He was no Winston Churchill in debating, but he was fine. And people say he was on performance-enhancing drugs. A lot of people have said that. A lot of people have written that.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with John Howard emphasizing climate change at APEC, haven't you undermined his efforts by scheduling your own meeting? And how important is ratifying Kyoto to addressing climate change? [SEP] Let's address the latter point first. As I get older, I may need you to repeat the first part. Kyoto might suit other nations, but it didn't for the U.S. The Senate voted 95-0 against it. We've pursued energy efficiency standards based on new technologies. We reduced greenhouse gases while our economy grew. We aim to reduce our dependence on foreign oil through the 20-in-10 program. New technologies are emerging, and Kyoto didn't facilitate that. Many countries aren't meeting Kyoto targets. We rejected it to grow our economy, reduce oil dependence, and be good stewards of the environment. I supported John's focus on climate change at APEC. I told our G-8 partners to include countries like China and India. Otherwise, they might reject a solution imposed on them. The Prime Minister's proposal to cut tariffs on environmental technologies is smart. We need to get effective technologies to the market and help developing nations acquire them. Our strategy is the most effective way. I appreciate the Prime Minister's leadership on this issue.
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, what's the least you want from these talks, and how fast will you know if he's serious about giving up nukes? [SEP] Well, the least is a relationship, a conversation. I'm a deal guy, you gotta start somewhere. I want more, but meeting, seeing each other, hopefully liking each other, that's the floor. About seriousness? I'll know pretty quick.
label: General

sentence: Sir, QAnon's influence is expanding. Could you comment on this phenomenon and address those who subscribe to its tenets? [SEP] Honestly, I haven't delved into the intricacies of QAnon. What I gather is that they're quite fond of me, which I certainly appreciate. They witness the turmoil in places like Portland and New York, a situation that's been escalating for years, even before my arrival. These are individuals who cherish our nation and are dismayed by the state of affairs in these cities. From what I understand, they're eager to see these problems resolved, particularly in the areas we're discussing. There's no justifiable reason why Democrats can't effectively govern a city. And if they prove incapable, we're prepared to deploy federal resources—be it troops or law enforcement—to rectify the situation within 24 hours. Is that clear enough?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, why hasn't the CDC updated its definition of 'fully vaccinated' to include the booster? Are you worried about the optics of a sudden drop in the percentage of fully vaccinated Americans? [SEP] That's a mischaracterization of the situation. We're guided by science, not optics. I've consistently advocated for boosters. Get your booster! It provides optimal protection. While two shots offer considerable protection, particularly with Pfizer, the booster amplifies that protection. This is about public health, plain and simple.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. ——midnight tonight and the exemption that you've offered to the U.K. There are 17 countries that are in the so-called Schengen zone that have fewer coronavirus cases than the U.K. And just in the past 24 hours, the U.K. has added 208 coronavirus cases to their total. Why do they, Mr. President, deserve an exemption? And would you consider adding them to this travel ban list? [SEP] Well, that was recommended to me by a group of professionals, and we are looking at it based on the new numbers that are coming out. And we may have to include them in the list of countries that we will, you could say, ban—or whatever—it is during this period of time.But yes, their numbers have gone up fairly precipitously over the last 24 hours, so we may be adding that, and we may be adding a couple of others. And we may, frankly, start thinking about taking some off.
label: Implicit

sentence: Regarding healthcare, Mr. President, are you prepared to subject yourself to the same system that Congress and the public use? [SEP] Well, I'm the President, so I get the best care, okay? That's just the way it is. But this isn't about me. It's about making sure everyone has good healthcare, and right now, they don't. We need to fix that, and that's what I'm focused on.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the upcoming vote in the House concerning the Iraq policy, and given the concerns raised by your Press Secretary about the message being conveyed to our enemies, would you say that a vote of disapproval serves to embolden those enemies and weaken your ability to implement your strategies? Also, what actions are you undertaking to influence the Democratic leadership in Congress against limiting your financial discretion in Iraq? [SEP] Look, I recognize Congress will express their views, and the Democrats' position, along with some Republicans, is quite evident. They disagreed with my original decision, which doesn't imply they're any less patriotic—they simply hold a different opinion. I took their views into account but felt they wouldn't result in a nation capable of governing itself, sustaining itself, and being a counter-terrorism ally. My hope is that this non-binding resolution doesn't evolve into a binding policy that prevents our troops from executing their mission. It's inconsistent to unanimously back David Petraeus and then refuse to fund the strategy he deemed essential, as he testified to the Senate. I'm making it unequivocally clear to Congress, starting now, that they must fund our troops and ensure we have the necessary flexibility to achieve our objectives. Furthermore, it's peculiar to see a declaration against a plan that hasn't even been given a chance to prove itself. Again, I understand. What was the other aspect of your inquiry?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, to reassure the public about meeting our deficit reduction targets, what concrete steps will your administration implement immediately? [SEP] Come again? Could you rephrase that, please? I want to make sure I understand you correctly.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you just said twice that the—Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac should remain shareholder-owned companies. If that's the case, because of the implicit Government guarantee that they have, or that is understood—has been understood by the markets—their exposure is higher and their reserves are lower than any normal business's—should they be privatized altogether and be subject to normal business rules? [SEP] Well, the first step is to make sure that there's confidence and stability in the mortgage markets through the actions that we have taken. Secondly, we strongly believe there ought to be a regulator. That's something—this is the position I have been advocating for a long time. And the reason why is, it's going to be very important for these institutions to focus on their core mission, which is to provide refinancing for the mortgage industry. And hopefully, these measures will instill the confidence in the people. And we'll see how things go.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. If you had to guess, Mr. President, would you say Hillary Clinton will be the nominee? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Just to follow up real quickly, do you feel like it's your responsibility for this to eventually get settled between North and South Korea? [SEP] I think I have a responsibility. I think other Presidents should have done it. I think the responsibility has fallen on the shoulders of the President of the United States. And I think we have—I think I have a responsibility to see if I can do it. And if I can't do it, it will be a very tough time for a lot of countries and a lot of people.It's certainly something that I hope I can do for the world. This is beyond the United States. This is a world problem, and it's something that I hope I'm able to do for the world. Okay?Please.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding China, after several months in office, your administration's approach seems multifaceted. Given the initial Alaska meeting and ongoing human rights concerns, could you clarify your current stance? Specifically, are you more inclined to maintain tariffs, ban forced-labor imports, or restrict U.S. investment in China? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, the relationship with China is far more intricate than those specific points suggest. I've had extensive interactions with Xi Jinping over the years. He's a shrewd operator, no illusions about that. We've made it clear that while competition is inevitable, we insist on fair play – adherence to international rules, fair trade practices, the whole nine yards. To compete effectively, we're investing heavily in American workers, science, and technology. We're rebuilding our alliances, not as an anti-China move, but to ensure accountability. I've emphasized to Xi the importance of upholding values like freedom and human rights. While we may not always meet our own ideals, these principles are fundamental to our nation's identity. So, expect robust competition, but also a firm commitment to holding China accountable on the global stage. Their ambition to dominate the world economically and politically? Not on my watch.
label: General

sentence: After the midterms, what's your current thinking on your Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General? Are their positions secure in the long term? [SEP] I'd prefer to address that at a later time. We're evaluating various aspects, including the Cabinet. I'm generally satisfied with my Cabinet. We're considering different individuals for different roles, which is typical after midterms. I didn't want to make any changes before the election. But overall, I'm very pleased with my Cabinet. Mike Pompeo, for example, has been an excellent fit and has done an outstanding job.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. ——what you would you like President Putin to do now, under your watch? [SEP] Well, I'll tell you what I'm going to do. I'm going to talk to him about that before I talk to you. And if something happens, that will be great. And if it doesn't happen—I'm not going in with high expectations, but we may come out with some very surprising things.But relationship is very important. And having a relationship with Russia and other countries, as I said a number of times, is—and I've been saying, actually, for years—and I've been certainly saying it during my campaign. Having relationships with other countries is really a good thing.I think that—I can't really overestimate how big the meeting was yesterday with NATO. We went with something that really was an unfair situation to something that's unified. I mean, they had spirit. Those people were getting up, and in the end, Well, we are committing and we're—you know, they can't go—it's not like they can go immediately back. They have to go through their parliaments and their congresses and their representatives and whoever, whatever form they have. But they have to go through an approval process.But I'll tell you what: Every single person in that room was gung-ho to get it done, get the money in. And even before that, as you know, $34 billion. And I think that the Secretary General—Stoltenberg is doing a terrific job, by the way—he said yesterday that Because of , we've taken in $34 billion more for NATO. And I think the number is actually much higher than that. But $34 billion more, at least. And again, that's nothing that my opponent would have done. My opponent would have—it would have just kept going down. You know, it was going down. You see what was happening over the years. The numbers were going down. Now the number is way up, and now it's going way up higher. And that was—and he will tell you that—that was because of me.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, intelligence agencies report that Russia is actively interfering in this year's election to undermine Joe Biden, while China is contemplating interference to harm your campaign. Do you accept this assessment, and what actions are planned in response? [SEP] Could be. I mean, it's possible – very much so. I think the last person Russia wants in office is Donald Trump, because nobody has been tougher on Russia than I have, ever.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the internal divisions within the House Republican Caucus, how confident are you that Speaker Boehner can secure the necessary votes for a comprehensive agreement, and do you still trust his leadership in this process? [SEP] The Speaker certainly faces challenges within his caucus, and I acknowledge that. Many of his members represent districts that I did not win. As a result, they may not see an incentive to cooperate with me, fearing challenges from within their own party. I understand this dynamic. However, recent events should provide a sense of perspective. We must prioritize the needs of the country. While disagreements may persist on various issues, compromise is essential to achieve deficit reduction, protect middle-class taxes, and foster economic growth. Avoiding self-inflicted crises will allow us to address critical issues such as preventing tragedies like Newtown and focusing on energy and immigration reform. By setting aside partisan divisions, we can work together for the betterment of the country. I believe the Speaker shares this desire. It is imperative to create an environment within both the House and Senate Republican caucuses that prioritizes the country's interests over political battles.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Obama, in light of the historical context of U.S. involvement in Chile during the Pinochet dictatorship and the ongoing investigations into the deaths of Allende and Frei Montalva, will the U.S. government commit to providing full transparency and offering a formal apology for its actions during that period? [SEP] We are committed to cooperating with the Chilean government on any requests for information pertaining to the past. It is essential to understand our history, including the complex and sometimes challenging relationship between the U.S. and Latin America. However, we must also avoid being constrained by our history. Chile has made significant progress in recent years, with the full support of the United States. I cannot comment on all past policies, but I can affirm our commitment to democracy, poverty reduction, and inclusive development. We strongly support the open markets that have developed in Chile and the efforts of President Pinera and his predecessor. While it is important to learn from our past, we must also focus on the challenges of the present and the future.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Senate proceedings, do you prefer a quick resolution or a thorough fact-finding process? What's your take on the disagreement between Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler? And are you categorically opposed to John Bolton's testimony? [SEP] You're throwing a lot at me at once.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, now that you've banned TikTok, are there any other Chinese tech companies that you're thinking about blocking from operating in the U.S.? What rules are you using to judge these companies, and what are the risks to our national security? [SEP] We're keeping an eye on everything. We're always checking for threats to our national security. We'll do whatever it takes to protect America's interests. We're not going to give away our plans, but we're very aware of what's happening, and we're taking it seriously.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I'll start on North Korea because that seems to be the biggest topic today. What does a proportional response look like to the Sony hack? And did Sony make the right decision in pulling the movie? Or does that set a dangerous precedent when faced with this kind of situation? [SEP] Well, let me address the second question first. Sony is a corporation. It suffered significant damage. There were threats against its employees. I am sympathetic to the concerns that they faced. Having said all that, yes, I think they made a mistake.In this interconnected, digital world, there are going to be opportunities for hackers to engage in cyber assaults both in the private sector and the public sector. Now, our first order of business is making sure that we do everything to harden sites and prevent those kinds of attacks from taking place. When I came into office, I stood up a cybersecurity interagency team to look at everything that we could do at the Government level to prevent these kinds of attacks. We've been coordinating with the private sector, but a lot more needs to be done. We're not even close to where we need to be.And one of the things in the new year that I hope Congress is prepared to work with us on is strong cybersecurity laws that allow for information sharing across private sector platforms, as well as the public sector, so that we are incorporating best practices and preventing these attacks from happening in the first place.But even as we get better, the hackers are going to get better too. Some of them are going to be state actors; some of them are going to be nonstate actors. All of them are going to be sophisticated, and many of them can do some damage.We cannot have a society in which some dictator someplace can start imposing censorship here in the United States. Because if somebody is able to intimidate folks out of releasing a satirical movie, imagine what they start doing when they see a documentary that they don't like or news reports that they don't like. Or even worse, imagine if producers and distributors and others start engaging in self-censorship because they don't want to offend the sensibilities of somebody whose sensibilities probably need to be offended.So that's not who we are. That's not what America is about.Again, I'm sympathetic that Sony as a private company was worried about liabilities and this and that and the other. I wish they had spoken to me first. I would have told them, do not get into a pattern in which you're intimidated by these kinds of criminal attacks. Imagine if, instead of it being a cyber threat, somebody had broken into their offices and destroyed a bunch of computers and stolen disks and—is that what it takes for suddenly you to pull the plug on something?And so we'll engage with not just the film industry, but the news industry and the private sector around these issues. We already have. We will continue to do so. But I think all of us have to anticipate occasionally there are going to be breaches like this. They're going to be costly. They're going to be serious. We take them with the utmost seriousness. But we can't start changing our patterns of behavior any more than we stop going to a football game because there might be the possibility of a terrorist attack, any more than Boston didn't run its marathon this year because of the possibility that somebody might try to cause harm. So let's not get into that way of doing business.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with regards to the European travel ban, can you elucidate the scientific data supporting its continuation, especially when compared to the situation in Turkey? [SEP] Our COVID team is on it. The Chancellor raised this issue, and we're actively working towards a solution. I expect to have a response for you within the next few days, pending the team's assessment. The Delta variant poses a new obstacle, necessitating a well-considered and sustainable decision. The Chancellor received the same explanation. The COVID team is evaluating the matter. We're about to miss dinner. Thank you for your time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, did your previous statements regarding Tony Blair's leadership inadvertently contribute to his decision to resign? [SEP] That's an interesting question. Did my comments have an impact? I honestly don't know. These things are complex, and ultimately, it was his choice.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President, on Putin, are you seeing any signs he's backing away from his role as a troublemaker, particularly regarding NATO and us? And about that list of key U.S. infrastructure you gave him, did you spell out the consequences for messing with it, or was it more of a 'we'll see' kind of thing? Did he even react? [SEP] Let's tackle the infrastructure question first. I made sure he understood we've got serious cyber skills. He knows it, even if he doesn't know all the details. If they break the rules, we'll hit back in cyberspace. He gets the picture.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Having bought that time now, do you hope to use this 2-year window to push for a broader overhaul of the Tax Code? [SEP] Yes. And the answer is yes. Part of what I want to do is to essentially get the American people in a safe place so that we can then get the economy in a stable place. And then we're going to have to have a broad-based discussion across the country about our priorities. And I started doing that yesterday down in North Carolina.Here's going to be the long-term issue. We've had 2 years of emergency: emergency economic action on the banking industry, the auto industry, on unemployment insurance, on a whole range of issues--on State budgets. The situation has now stabilized, although for those folks who are out of work, it's still an emergency. So we've still got to focus short term on job growth.But we've got to have a larger debate about how is this country going to win the economic competition of the 21st century? How are we going to make sure that we've got the best trained workers in the world? There was just a study that came out today showing how we've slipped even further when it comes to math education and science education.So what are we doing to revamp our schools to make sure our kids can compete? What are we doing in terms of research and development to make sure that innovation is still taking place here in the United States of America? What are we doing about our infrastructure so that we have the best airports and the best roads and the best bridges? And how are we going to pay for all that at a time when we've got both short-term deficit problems, medium-term deficit problems, and long-term deficit problems?Now, that's going to be a big debate. And it's going to involve us sorting out what Government functions are adding to our competitiveness and increasing opportunity and making sure that we're growing the economy, and which aspects of the Government aren't helping.And then, we've got to figure out how do we pay for that. And that's going to mean looking at the Tax Code and saying, what's fair, what's efficient. And I don't think anybody thinks the Tax Code right now is fair or efficient. But we've got to make sure that we don't just paper over those problems by borrowing from China or Saudi Arabia. And so that's going to be a major conversation.And in that context, I don't see how the Republicans win that argument. I don't know how they're going to be able to argue that extending permanently these high-end tax cuts is going to be good for our economy when, to offset them, we'd end up having to cut vital services for our kids, for our veterans, for our seniors.But I'm happy to listen to their arguments. And I think the American people will benefit from that debate. And that's going to be starting next year.Marc Ambinder [National Journal].
label: Explicit

sentence: Even if the room isn't fully occupied, wouldn't a virtual meeting be a safer and more responsible alternative, given the current global health crisis? [SEP] We're going to have a great meeting. The best meeting ever. People want to be there, they want to see me. We're going to have all the best people there. It will be tremendous.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, given the protectionist sentiments in Washington, how adaptable is your administration in forging a trade pact with Uruguay? Also, did President Vazquez ask you to mediate the mill dispute between Uruguay and Argentina? [SEP] We talked at length about Uruguay's worries regarding market access for certain products. The President brought up various trade issues, mentioning the quotas on things like cows and sheep, which he felt were unjust. I assured him I'd seriously consider his requests. You might think I was kidding about blueberries, but Uruguay makes some great ones, and it boils down to whether those growers can sell them here. So, we covered a lot of produce. I told the President, you gotta put problems on the table to fix 'em, and we'll help where we can, and explain why if we can't. Now, about protectionism, I'm worried about it, not just here but everywhere. I think free and fair trade makes the world better at fighting poverty. That's why I'm all in on finishing the Doha round of the WTO. I told the President about our plans to push that forward, based on talks with President Lula. I didn't spill any secrets, of course. The U.S. is ready to cut farm subsidies, as I said to the President, if we get market access. That's what I told President Lula, the Europeans, and now the President here. I'm hopeful we can get a deal. Our trade person, Susan Schwab, is still in Sao Paulo talking to Brazil, trying to make progress on this tough but important deal. To answer your first question, I totally agree with the President of the United States. We've started a process, beginning with this meeting, for our experts and ministers to talk about and improve our relationship. On the broader trade scene, Uruguay is all about free trade and cutting tariffs and subsidies that hurt our cultural exports. We're also looking at the GSP, especially on some issues coming up soon. As for your second question, I didn't bring up our issues with Argentina with the President, mainly because we're about to talk, thanks to the King of Spain, to try and find a friendly solution to our problems.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. If I may just quickly, on a more personal note, what is your New Year's resolution? [SEP] My New Year's resolution is to be nicer to the White House Press Corps. [] You know? Absolutely.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, your answer lacks specifics regarding the reasons for the delay and the nature of any concessions made. Can you provide a more detailed explanation of the logistical and political challenges that prolonged the implementation of the Roxham Road agreement? Additionally, can you clarify whether any financial or policy commitments were made to the U.S. in exchange for their cooperation? [SEP] These are complex negotiations, okay? There are a lot of moving parts, a lot of different interests involved. We had to work with the Americans, with our own provinces, with various agencies. It's not something you can just rush through. And frankly, I'm not going to get into the details of the negotiations. That would be irresponsible. What I can tell you is that we reached an agreement that is in the best interests of Canada, that protects our borders, and that allows us to continue to fulfill our humanitarian obligations.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, two-part question: the Red Cross report details alleged CIA torture, and Guantanamo remains open despite your stated desire to close it. Who's resisting you on Guantanamo, and what's your reaction to the Red Cross findings? [SEP] Guantanamo's closure is a goal, absolutely. But it's not a solo act. We need cooperation from other nations to take back detainees, and frankly, there's resistance here at home too, as evidenced by the Senate vote. We *are* working on transfers, ensuring humane treatment. Trials are a priority, despite legal challenges. So, progress *is* happening, despite what you may have heard. Now, regarding the Red Cross report, and the claim that 'nothing has actually happened,' I must respectfully disagree.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding a potential government shutdown during the lame-duck session, is that off the table? [SEP] Look, I can't give you a definitive answer on that right now. It's not something I can guarantee, though it remains a possibility.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Very short one for each of you. Mr. President, my question—my first question touches an issue that worries a lot of people in the U.S. and in Germany. Can you explain to us why there still is a travel ban for people coming from Germany or other states of the European Union, while people from Turkey, where the number of new cases are seven times as high, can come?You all have repeatedly said that you're following scientific data. What is the main argument for not lifting that travel ban for the Schengen region?And, Chancellor Merkel——[The reporter spoke in German, and her remarks were translated by an interpreter as follows.]You talked to the business companies here. You heard their concerns. You heard their headaches. Some have threatened that they're going to shift business away from the United States. What was your main argument to work for a lifting of the travel ban? And have you had success with this? [SEP] We brought in the head of our COVID team because the Chancellor brought that subject up. It's in the process of seeing how soon we can lift the ban—it's in process now. And I'll be able to answer that question to you within the next several days—what is likely to happen. I'm waiting to hear from our folks and our COVID team as to when that should be done. And the Chancellor did raise it. [] I did raise the issue, yes, and got the same answer that the President gave you just now. The COVID team is evaluating the matter. We had an exchange on—in both areas.The Delta variant actually being on the increase, that is, again, a new challenge to both of us. And obviously, before such a decision, one has to reflect, and it has to be a sustainable decision. It is certainly not sensible to have to take it back after only a few days. So I'm—have every confidence in the American COVID team. Having been here many times, if we don't leave right now, we're going to miss dinner. Chancellor and I have a dinner with some—a number of folks, and very shortly.So thank you for your attention. And thank you for your questions. Thank you. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with Russia still occupying Crimea, how can you even think about improving relations? [SEP] Sure, they're there. But let's be honest, Obama really messed that one up. If I had been President, that wouldn't have happened. They took Crimea on his watch, plain and simple.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Khashoggi murder, can you definitively state whether you believe Saudi Arabia is responsible, and what specific consequences they will face? [SEP] We're conducting a thorough investigation in collaboration with Congress, as well as engaging with Turkey and Saudi Arabia. I expect to have a much firmer position on this matter within the next week. Now, let's move to another topic.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. President Trump, Ryan Chilcote, PBS NewsHour. Did you win concessions in your meetings and discussions with the German Chancellor when it comes to German defense spending and also with this issue of purchasing energy from Russia? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, any updates on the trade negotiations with China? [SEP] China's going great. The talks are going great. Thank you all.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, beyond simply being 'prepared to walk away,' what specific, measurable outcomes would define a successful summit with North Korea? What concrete steps would Kim Jong Un need to commit to in order to avoid you terminating the negotiations? And what specific incentives, beyond a potential invitation to the US, are you prepared to offer in exchange for denuclearization? [SEP] We're looking for denuclearization, complete and verifiable. That's the bottom line. We want to make sure that North Korea is no longer a threat to the world. If Kim Jong Un is willing to do that, then we can talk about a lot of things. We can talk about economic assistance, we can talk about security guarantees. But first, he has to commit to denuclearization. That's the only way this is going to work.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, given the concerns surrounding mail-in voting, what specific measures are you taking to ensure the integrity of the upcoming election and to prevent any potential for fraud or irregularities? [SEP] Well, wait a minute. You just threw—look, I just read last night that now New Jersey is going to try the universal mail-in voting. Well, they didn't know this. So now, all of a sudden, New Jersey is going to be hit with millions of ballots to be sent out. They didn't know anything about this.So how does a Post Office—how does a Postal Service that doesn't know about it, now all of a sudden, New Jersey is supposed to take out, and millions of ballots are going to be sent all over New Jersey?And if you look at some of the things they say, like in—take the State of Nevada, take that little scam that's going on over there with the clubhouse politician Governor. Take that, where the votes don't even have to be in until 7—they get counted 7 days after November 3. That means if—Nevada is a very important State. I think we have a great chance of winning that State. If the votes don't have to be in for 7—and they're not counting the votes—7 days later, that means how are they going to predict a winner on November 3?
label: Implicit

sentence: The National Intelligence Estimate suggests we're in a civil war in Iraq. You speak of victory and preventing a catastrophe if we fail, yet you claim it's not an open-ended commitment. How do you reconcile these seemingly contradictory statements? [SEP] Look, Iraq ain't gonna be like winning World War II. It's gonna be messy. We're talking about a place with car bombs and ethnic violence. What we gotta do is help them get their act together, build a security force that can keep the peace. Then you got al-Qaeda stirring things up, and Sunnis who want their power back. It's a complicated situation, no matter what you call it. I had to step in to stop it from getting worse. We want a government that's fair, shares the wealth, and fights terrorists. That's what success looks like.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, given the allegations of corruption and human rights violations surrounding Prime Minister Najib, what specific concerns did you raise with him regarding the investment funds scandal and the jailing of political opponents? [SEP] Well, let's be clear. The situation with refugees, as we saw after the Paris attacks, is complex. People are understandably concerned. But the vetting process is extremely thorough, taking up to two years. While some proposals might seem reasonable on the surface, they could effectively shut down the refugee program. As for Prime Minister Najib, I don't comment on ongoing investigations, whether domestic or foreign. However, I did emphasize the importance of transparency, accountability, and rooting out corruption. These are universal values, and it's crucial for countries to uphold them.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify, are you suggesting that a 'minor incursion' by Russia would not trigger the severe sanctions you've previously threatened? Is there a specific threshold of aggression that Russia must cross to warrant a full response? [SEP] That's a hypothetical I won't entertain.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, with respect, wasn't it vital for the Prime Minister to be there to show a united front? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to speculate on the internal workings of the Iraqi government. They make their own decisions.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given your past criticisms of using the debt ceiling as a bargaining chip, why are you now so resistant to negotiating with Republicans on deficit reduction in exchange for raising the debt ceiling? Has your position evolved, and if so, what factors have influenced that change? [SEP] The fundamental difference is that we're not going to allow a faction in Congress to hold the American economy hostage. We're happy to discuss responsible deficit reduction, but we won't negotiate under the threat of default. That's a dangerous precedent, and we won't allow it to happen. We need to raise the debt ceiling to pay for obligations we've already incurred, and we urge Congress to do its job.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, the statistics clearly indicate a high death toll in the U.S. compared to other nations. What is your explanation for this discrepancy? [SEP] Look, it's a complex situation, and there are many factors involved. We're doing everything we can to protect the American people, and we're making tremendous strides. But I'll need to review the specific data you're referring to before I can give you a more detailed answer.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, your critic asserts that your administration's shortcomings in testing, your inconsistent messaging on safety measures, and your perceived arrogance are directly responsible for the high COVID-19 death rate in the US. How do you respond to this? [SEP] That's likely a contributing factor to her unsuccessful candidacy and subsequent withdrawal from the race – her grasp of the facts is demonstrably weak. Let's be clear: our testing capacity surpasses that of any other nation, including India with its vast population, and China. Our testing protocols are the most advanced globally. Other nations are seeking our expertise. However, it is important to understand that extensive testing, such as our 65 million tests conducted to date, will inevitably yield a higher number of identified cases. In contrast, countries like Mexico conduct minimal testing, primarily focusing on symptomatic individuals. We have conducted the most testing globally and have achieved the best overall results. We have even become a leading producer of ventilators, supplying these critical devices to the world. Furthermore, our overall impact has been less severe than that experienced by many other nations, some of which possessed inherent advantages. Therefore, our performance has been commendable. Her assertions are factually inaccurate. I anticipate her future endeavors will be similarly unsuccessful, and I eagerly await the debate between her and Vice President Pence, who I am confident will decisively outperform her, as he did against Senator Kaine.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. And thank you, Chancellor Scholz. Mr. President, I have wanted to ask you about this Nord Stream project that you've long opposed. You didn't mention it just now by name, nor did Chancellor Scholz. Did you receive assurances from Chancellor Scholz today that Germany will, in fact, pull the plug on this project if Russia invades Ukraine? And did you discuss what the definition of invasion could be?And then, Chancellor Scholz——[At this point, the reporter spoke in German, and her remarks were translated by an interpreter as follows.]If I may ask you, Chancellor Scholz—you said there was some strategic ambiguity that was needed in terms of sanctions. I just wanted to know whether the sanctions you are envisaging and the EU is working on—and the U.S. as well—are already finished, finalized, or is there still work ongoing?And you're not really saying what the details are. Is that just an excuse for Germany, maybe, to not support the Swift measures? [SEP] The first question first. If Germany—if Russia invades—that means tanks or troops crossing the border of Ukraine again—then there will be—we—there will be no longer a Nord Stream 2. We will bring an end to it.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Roxham Road, the agreement has been ready for a year. Why the delay? And concerning Canada's acceptance of 15,000 migrants, why such a limited number? What did we offer the U.S. in exchange? [SEP] Well, this is a very difficult circumstance, the idea of how do we deal with what's going on in , where gangs have essentially taken the place of the Government, in effect. They run—they rule the roost, as the saying goes.And so I think that what the Prime Minister has spoken about makes a lot of sense. The biggest thing we could do, and it's going to take time, is to increase the prospect of the police departments in having the capacity to deal with the problems that are faced. And that is going to take a little bit of time.We also are looking at whether or not the international community, through the United Nations, could play a larger role in this event, in this circumstance. But there is no question that there is a real, genuine concern, because there are several million people in , and the diaspora could cause some real—how can I say it?—confusion in the Western Hemisphere.And so—but I think that what the Prime Minister is suggesting, and we are as well going to be contributing, to see if we can both increase the efficiency and capacity of the training and the methods used by the police department, as well as seeing if we can engage other people in the hemisphere, which we've been talking to, and they're prepared to do some. So it's a work in progress.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, are there any emergency powers available to you that could be invoked in the event of a default on the nation's debt obligations? [SEP] We have already been utilizing various emergency measures. Secretary Lew has been employing extraordinary measures to ensure the timely payment of our financial obligations. However, these measures are finite, and the available time is rapidly diminishing. I am concerned that some members of both parties may underestimate the constraints we face. Should the Treasury be unable to conduct auctions for Treasury bills, we will lack the necessary funds to meet our financial obligations promptly. The situation is quite straightforward. There has been some discussion regarding the potential invocation of my powers under the 14th Amendment to circumvent the debt ceiling law. However, irrespective of the legal merits of such an action, the ensuing legal controversy would undermine confidence in the market. Proposals such as minting a large coin fail to address the fundamental issue: the perception of Treasury bill purchasers. If they harbor doubts about the validity of these instruments, they will be hesitant to invest. There are no simple solutions. Congress must act. Speaker Boehner asserts that he lacks the votes to pass a bill, but he should allow a vote on the floor to allow each member to be on record. Let them vote to maintain government operations and fulfill our financial obligations. If they vote against it, the voters should know who to hold accountable for the resulting consequences.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Sir, what specific guarantees did you provide to Prime Minister Netanyahu concerning U.S. involvement if diplomacy with Iran collapses and Israel contemplates a strike on their nuclear facilities? [SEP] Those pushing for military action need to clearly outline the potential consequences to the American public. My focus remains on a peaceful solution. Our international coalition is exerting significant pressure on Iran. They've expressed a desire to resume negotiations, and we must explore this avenue while maintaining that pressure. I won't divulge the details of my conversation with Prime Minister Netanyahu, but my public stance mirrors our private discussions. Israel, as a sovereign nation, must decide how best to protect its security. The sanctions are significantly impacting Iran, affecting their oil sector and central bank. Their willingness to negotiate presents an opportunity for a peaceful resolution. The idea that we face an imminent decision is inaccurate. We've made an unparalleled commitment to Israel's security. True friends offer candid advice, and this matter extends beyond Israeli interests; it directly impacts U.S. interests. Military intervention always carries a cost, demanding careful consideration. We don't politicize war. We've adopted a deliberate, thoughtful approach over the last three years, and I plan to maintain that course.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you've emphasized strengthening the U.S.-Japan alliance and a 'free and open Indo-Pacific.' How will you reconcile this vision with your upcoming visit to China, a nation that doesn't embody those values? Won't this inevitably lead to conflict? [SEP] Mark, thank you. Let me just add to what the Prime Minister said. He'll be shooting those missiles down in no time once he finishes buying all that great military equipment from us. Just like we did in Saudi Arabia, a needle in the sky, hit immediately, no damage. The Prime Minister is buying massive amounts of military equipment, as he should. The best in the world, made right here in the USA. F-35s, missiles, you name it. Jobs for us, safety for Japan. As for China, my relationship with President Xi is excellent. I like him, consider him a friend. He represents China, I represent the United States. Different views, but similar on trade. The problem with China is decades of unfair trade. A massive trade deficit, hundreds of billions a year, not even counting intellectual property. We're already talking to China about this. It has to come down. We need free, fair, or reciprocal trade. I like reciprocal best. It's easy to understand. We charge the same as they charge us. It's fair. We have countries charging us 100% taxes, and we charge them nothing. That's been wrong for a long time, and we're going to fix it. It takes time, statutory limitations, notices, waiting periods. But we're catching up. You'll see strong action against countries treating the U.S. unfairly. It's already started, and the legal foundation is in place. It's going to happen soon. The U.S. has been treated very unfairly on trade. Thank you. Regarding Japan defense equipment, a lot of them we purchase from the United States. North Korean situation becoming very tough, the Asia-Pacific security situation becoming very tough, we qualitatively and quantitatively, we have to enhance our defense capability. As the President mentioned, F-35A is a case in point. SM-3 Block IIA is another plan for purchase from the United States. Aegis vessels, the quality and the quantity must be enhanced. In that process, we will be buying more from the United States. That is what I am thinking. Now, North Korea: North Korea launched missiles. Immediately after that, we traced them; we were able to grasp and trace where they were going. Missile defense is something which is based upon the cooperation between Japan and the United States. Missile defense system is a cooperation between the two countries. For the intercepting and shooting down, if it is necessary, of course, we will do that—if it is necessary. But in doing so, U.S. and Japan will closely coordinate our actions. Thank you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. But, sir, are you reversing the statement? You never answered about the statement. Just—I'll just let you go after this, but do you want to reverse what you told Woodward about the 13- to 14-month timeline for a vaccine? [SEP] Well, the vaccine—at the time, I thought it might take that period of time, but we've stepped it up very substantially.And now—I mean, I'm just telling you the—this is just what it is. We've been able to step it up very, very rapidly. I never thought we could have a vaccine as quickly as we did, but I freed it up. I freed up the FDA. Dr. Hahn has done a great job. And they're ready to approve something when they come in.The other thing that's happening that's very different is—you look at a company like Pfizer, a great company—really, one of the great companies of the world. Johnson & Johnson. They're all great companies. They're doing a lot of testing at a very rapid rate that nobody has ever seen anything like it. You know, they're out in third—they're in the third level of trial. And I think that you're going to see things that are amazing.When I made statements like that—that's an old statement. When I made statements like that, I had no idea that we could produce as well as we're producing. But only because of what I've done with the FDA and other things can we come up with numbers like that. We're lucky that we don't have to, because that was considered fast.If this were a—an administration from the past—and I think I can say far beyond Obama, if—it was other administrations also—you wouldn't have a vaccine for 2½, 3 years. And we're going to have a vaccine within, at most, a couple of months.Okay?
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, your recent interactions on the world stage have raised eyebrows. You praised Kim Jong Un's abilities shortly after criticizing Prime Minister Trudeau's integrity. How do you reassure our allies that you're not undermining long-standing relationships and prioritizing adversaries over friends? [SEP] Look, it's simple. These countries, they've been ripping us off for years. Trudeau? He's gotta be strong, he's gotta be tough. But they're all doing it. China, Europe, Canada – they're all taking advantage. We're losing billions. I signed something, everyone was happy, then Trudeau goes on TV and says he won't be pushed around. Give me a break! We need fair trade, and I'm the guy to get it. They send us Mercedes, we can't even sell our farm products. It's a disgrace. I'm straightening it out, believe me.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, considering the potential for widespread disruption from the coronavirus, what specific measures are being taken to protect vulnerable populations and ensure access to essential healthcare services? [SEP] We are working closely with state and local governments, as well as healthcare providers, to ensure that we are prepared to respond effectively to the coronavirus outbreak. We are taking steps to increase testing capacity, develop treatments and vaccines, and provide guidance to the public on how to protect themselves from infection. We are also working to ensure that vulnerable populations have access to the resources they need to stay safe and healthy.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you very much, Mr. President. I picked the side in the sun here, so--[laughter]. I'd like to ask you about Iran. Did you get any specific commitments from Russia or China on tightening sanctions? Did you move them at all? And do you fear the world is running out of options short of military intervention to keep Iran from getting nuclear weapons? [SEP] One of the striking things over the last 3 years since I came into office is the degree of unity that we've been able to forge in the international community with respect to . When I came into office, the world was divided and was unified around its nuclear program. We now have a situation where the world is united and is isolated. And because of our diplomacy and our efforts, we have, by far, the strongest sanctions on that we've ever seen. And and Russia were critical to making that happen. Had they not been willing to support those efforts in the United Nations, we would not be able to see the kind of progress that we've made.And they're having an impact. All our intelligence indicates that 's economy is suffering as a consequence of this. And we're also seeing that 's influence in the region has ebbed, in part because their approach to repression inside of is contrary to the Arab Spring that has been sweeping the Middle East.So we are in a much stronger position now than we were 2 or 3 years ago with respect to . Having said that, the recent IAEA report indicates what we already knew, which is, although does not possess a nuclear weapon and is technically still allowing IAEA observers into their country, that they are engaging in a series of practices that are contrary to their international obligations and their IAEA obligations. And that's what the IAEA report indicated.So what I did was to speak with President Medvedev, as well as President Hu, and all three of us entirely agree on the objective, which is making sure that does not weaponize nuclear power and that we don't trigger a nuclear arms race in the region. That's in the interests of all of us.In terms of how we move forward, we will be consulting with them carefully over the next several weeks to look at what other options we have available to us. The sanctions have enormous bite and enormous scope, and we're building off the platform that has already been established. The question is, are there additional measures that we can take. And we're going to explore every avenue to see if we can solve this issue diplomatically.I have said repeatedly, and I will say today, we are not taking any options off the table, because it's my firm belief that an with a nuclear weapon would pose a security threat not only to the region, but also to the United States. But our strong preference is to have meet its international obligations, negotiate diplomatically, to allow them to have peaceful use of nuclear energy in accordance with international law, but at the same time, forswear the weaponization of nuclear power.And so we're going to keep on pushing on that. And and Russia have the same aims, the same objectives, and I believe that we'll continue to cooperate and collaborate closely on that issue.Dan Lothian [CNN].
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you campaigned on ending the war in Yemen. Now, with the potential re-listing of the Houthis as terrorists, critics argue your policy is backsliding. What's your response to those who say you're failing to deliver on your promise to the Yemeni people? [SEP] Well, let me be clear: We're constantly reassessing the situation. The designation is just one tool in our toolbox. The key is getting all parties to the table, and that's what we're focused on. It's a delicate balancing act.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. I meant to ask a followup, though. Do you think that scientific consensus is enough to tell us what we can and cannot do? [SEP] No. I think there's always an ethical and a moral element that has to be a part of this. And so, as I said, I don't take decisions like this lightly. They're ones that I take seriously. And I respect people who have different opinions on this issue. But I think that this was the right thing to do and the ethical thing to do. And as I said before, my hope is, is that we can find a mechanism, ultimately, to cure these diseases in a way that gains 100 percent consensus. And we certainly haven't achieved that yet, but I think on balance this was the right step to take.Stephen Collinson, AFP [Agence France-Presse].
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, regarding the DC mayor's order on mask mandates, will the White House and federal properties comply, even though they are technically exempt? [SEP] That's something we're looking at. We'll have an answer for you tomorrow. Appreciate the question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning these debt talks, would you consider tax breaks to stimulate the economy, even if they increase the deficit? Also, regarding same-sex marriage, you mentioned the positive trend in states like New York. Does this mean you personally now support same-sex marriage, regardless of state decisions? Is that your personal view? [SEP] I'm not going to make news on that today. Good try though.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: What specific measures are being implemented to ensure that these personnel reviews are conducted fairly and without political bias, preventing potential abuses of power? [SEP] We have the best people in charge of this. They're very smart, very talented. They know what they're doing. They're going to make sure that we have a government that works for the American people.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. But you do have the strategic oil petroleum reserve. What about opening that? [SEP] The strategic oil petroleum reserve is for, you know, emergencies. But that doesn't address the fundamental issue. And we need to address the fundamental issue—which I, frankly, have been talking about since I first became President—which was a combination of using technology to have alternative sources of energy, but at the same time, finding oil and gas here at home. And now is the time to get it done. I heard somebody say, Well, it's going to take 7 years. Well, if we'd have done it 7 years ago, we'd have—be having a different conversation today. I'm not suggesting we'd have completely created—you know, changed the dynamics in the world, but it certainly would have been—we'd have been using more of our own oil and sending less money overseas.Yes, Ed [Ed Henry, Cable News Network]. B. McClellan/Military Operations in
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding sanctions, how confident are you that nations will reach an agreement within the set timeframe? Also, concerning Pakistan, does the U.S. have assurances that their nuclear arsenal is secure from terrorist threats like Al Qaeda? [SEP] Well, addressing Pakistan first, and echoing my colleague's earlier point, we're generally satisfied with their nuclear security protocols. However, complacency is not an option for any nation, including ourselves. Remember the incident with nuclear-tipped missiles on a bomber? Secretary Gates acted decisively then. Every nuclear power must constantly improve security. Pakistan is no exception, nor are we. That's the core principle behind this summit. As for sanctions, a significant number of Security Council members support them. Negotiations are always complex, and I'll push for strong, consequential sanctions against Iran if their nuclear program warrants it, and in a timely manner. I won't speculate further on the specifics at this juncture.
label: General

sentence: Q. So, both approaches are on the table? [SEP] Or, perhaps, a combination. Are you two working together on this question? Please, proceed.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. President Obama, regarding Mexico's human rights record and the ongoing drug war, will you proceed with certification? How will the Merida Initiative be affected, especially given the security risks for President Calderon and the visa challenges? [SEP] Unfortunately, I didn't receive the translation. It seemed like a crucial question. Is the translation ready? Please proceed with your question.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you definitively state that the $600 weekly supplement will continue? [SEP] Let's just say we're exploring all options. Details are still being finalized, but rest assured, we're aware of the need.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. ——thought process.One is, you've talked about this as low-level drug offenders who got mandatory minimum sentences, but about a quarter of the commutations you've granted also had firearms offenses. Given your overall philosophy on firearms, can you reconcile that for us? [SEP] Sure.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, are you becoming the very thing you criticized – an imperial President? [SEP] The Constitution is my guide. I'm bound by the Constitution; I'm bound by separation of powers. I prefer working with Congress, but when they're stuck, I have a duty to act where I can. Congress has the power of the purse, for example. I would love to fund a large infrastructure proposal right now that would put millions of people to work and boost our GDP. We know we've got roads and bridges and airports and electrical grids that need to be rebuilt. But without the cooperation of Congress, what I can do is speed up the permitting process, for example.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the situation south of the border – the human rights situation, the drug trafficking problems, the Merida Initiative, the potential threats to President Calderon, and the visa backlog – what's your take? [SEP] I must confess, I didn't quite follow all of that. Could you perhaps break it down a bit? I want to give you a thorough response.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, gentlemen. I have one question for the two of you. Canada has announced it's pulling out in 2011; South Korea is already gone. In that context are you concerned about the level of international support for the war here, and are the 20,000 additional U.S. troops enough to bring this conflict to a close? [SEP] Yes. Well, first of all, as you know, I've always relied upon our military commanders to make the recommendations necessary to achieve the objectives we've set forth. We have added troops during—twice during my Presidency—obviously, in the initial move in and then we added troops to that. I've announced we're going to send in more troops. And then, of course, the Obama administration will be analyzing the situation, and it sounds like that they intend to expedite the—sending more troops in.So—and why do we do that? Because this is what our generals suggest we do. To answer your—this is just going to be a long struggle, first of all. This doesn't end tomorrow. Ideological struggles take time. As a civil society whose firm political institutions begin to develop, extremism begins to wither; it gets marginalized, and then it withers away. And so it's going to take time. I can't tell you the troop levels we'll need; all I know is our generals said, this is what we need now. And they—I listened to them, and I'm confident President-elect Obama will listen to the commanders as well. We are already very grateful to all those countries, nations who have come to help Afghanistan, and who have already helped Afghanistan. Canada is among the countries that's the frontrunner in assistance to Afghanistan. Their plans to withdraw their troops by 2011 or '12 is not in contradiction to the understanding that we have with them. They will continue to assist us in various other forms in Afghanistan.What is important here is that while we are continuing to fight terrorism and to bring the institutional strength and stability to Afghanistan, with an improved economy and improved governance and service delivery by the Government, we also work on enabling Afghanistan to eventually stand on its own feet. The Afghan people don't want to be a burden on the international community forever. And we are grateful already that the international community is helping us in blood and their taxpayers' money.We are grateful to Canada. We are grateful to all other countries, as partners for building Afghanistan, for fighting terrorists who are the enemies of all of us. So we are happy in any form of assistance other countries give us and will be grateful for it.One—pick up one more question, Mr. President? You'd like to continue? All those who want another question, raise your hand. [] I guess so, Mr. President.[] Hold on a second.[] I respectfully disagree with you. The Taliban was brutalizing the people of Afghanistan. And they're not in power. And I just cited the progress that is undeniable.Now, is there more work to be done? You bet. I never said the Taliban was eliminated; I said they were removed from power. And I said girls are going back to school, and boys are flying kites, and health clinics are opening, and the number of university students is dramatically expanding, and the number of schools around the country is growing, and there's a ring road built. Yes, there's no question there's a Taliban that wants to fight back. Why? Because they want to regain power. They can't stand the thought of a free society. And they're lethal, and they are tough. No question about it, no question about it.So therefore, is the suggestion because they're tough that we just withdraw, that it's too hard work? Not as far as I'm concerned. I think it's necessary work. And it's in the interest of the United States that we not allow Afghanistan to become a safe haven again for Al Qaida. Al Qaida is greatly weakened since 2001. As a matter of fact, they at one point declared the most central front in the war on terror in Iraq, where they're doing very poorly.And they're not doing so well here either. Now, they can hide in remote regions. They can hide, but we will stay on the hunt, and we will keep the pressure on them, because it's in the people—the peaceful people of Afghanistan's interest, just like it's in the interest of this country.And so is there still difficult days ahead? Absolutely. But are the conditions a lot better today in Afghanistan than they were in 2001? Unquestionably, undoubtedly, they're better.[] Mr. President. Steven Lee [Steven Lee Myers, New York Times].
label: Implicit

sentence: Is this just a temporary setback, or is the relationship with Afghanistan deteriorating? [SEP] These things are never easy. There will always be challenges. The key is to maintain our strategic focus and work towards our long-term goals.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you haven't mentioned oil companies. Are you confident that American oil producers are maximizing their output, including offshore drilling? Also, regarding Iraq, will you sign an interim agreement with Prime Minister Maliki on American operations, leaving a more permanent agreement to your successor? [SEP] Let me begin with Iraq. We are actively engaged in crafting a strategic framework agreement with the Iraqi government, encompassing cooperation across various domains: diplomacy, economics, and justice. Integral to this agreement is a security component. The Iraqi government seeks an aspirational timeline for transitioning to what we term 'overwatch.' 'Overwatch' signifies that the U.S. will transition to a training mission, providing logistical support and special operations capabilities. For our troops to operate within a foreign nation, a clear understanding with the host government is paramount. This necessitates defined authorities to operate and guarantees for the safety of our personnel. We are currently negotiating these aspects concurrently. This must be finalized before the end of the year, unless the UN mandate is extended. Therefore, the agreement has two distinct facets, which are often conflated. We are addressing both simultaneously. Let's see here.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. You've long talked about the importance when the Federal Government is involved in an effort, spending money and resources, of measuring success, accountability, as Peter said. Now you've set some benchmarks on the Maliki Government. You've said that you're expecting him to make tough decisions. Can you tell the American people how you plan to measure his success in reaching those benchmarks, and what happens if he doesn't hit those benchmarks? [SEP] David, the first objective is to develop benchmarks that the Government agrees with and that we think are important. You can't—it's really important for the American people to understand that to say, Okay, these are the benchmarks you must live with, is not going to work nearly as effectively as if we have—when we have buy-in from the Government itself, the sovereign Government of Iraq.And so the step is to say to the Maliki Government—which we're doing—let us work in concert to develop a series of benchmarks to achieve different objectives. And the purpose of that is to assure the Iraqi people that this unity Government is going to work to—for the improvement of the Iraqi people. In other words, it will be beneficial for the Government to say to the Iraqi people, Here is what we intend to do, and here's when we intend to do it.It will also be beneficial for the American people to be able to see that this is going to make the difficult decisions necessary to move forward, to achieve the goal. And that's what we're talking about when it comes to benchmarks. It's—again, I repeat: One should not expect our Government to impose these benchmarks on a sovereign government. You'd expect us to work closely with that Government to come up with a way forward that the Government feels comfortable with. And there's probably going to be some bones of contention during these discussions, but nevertheless, we'll respect the fact that the Iraq Government is sovereign, and they must respect the fact that we've got patience but not unlimited patience.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Prime Minister Netanyahu's recent statements seemingly walking back his commitment to a two-state solution, what specific actions could he take to demonstrate a genuine commitment to peace, and is there any validity to the claims of Israeli espionage during the Iran nuclear talks? Furthermore, President Ghani, what gives you hope for reconciliation with the Taliban, and do you seek U.S. involvement in those discussions? [SEP] Let me address the espionage allegations first. It's my policy not to discuss intelligence matters publicly. As for the Iran agreement, we've kept Congress and our allies, including Israel, informed. Any final agreement will be transparent, allowing scrutiny. If it's a solid agreement preventing Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons, it will benefit everyone, including American and Israeli security. If not, there won't be an agreement. Regarding Israeli-Palestinian relations, the key issue is the belief of both parties in a possible solution. Prime Minister Netanyahu's pre-election statements suggested no Palestinian state under his leadership. While he later clarified, the conditions he outlined seem unattainable. The question isn't about immediate statehood, but about a framework offering Palestinians hope for a secure state alongside Israel. His statements make this vision difficult. My evaluation concerns the future of Israeli-Palestinian relations, not our commitment to Israel's security. We must be honest about the dim prospects for a two-state solution to maintain credibility. This isn't a personal issue between Prime Minister Netanyahu and me; it's a policy difference with significant consequences. We believe in two states, while Prime Minister Netanyahu has a different approach. It's about navigating this policy difference for the benefit of both countries and the region.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, if Donald Trump had not run, would you have still decided to seek re-election? [SEP] Yes, I believe I would still be running even if he wasn't. I know him well, he's not hard to know, as you know. You know him well, too. The question is whether or not we can finish the job. We have an opportunity to put ourselves in a position where we are economically and politically secure for a long time.
