There's still a contest between autocracies and democracies, and we're the leading democracy in the world. It's something I know a fair amount about, something I care about, and something that I have found a willingness of an awful lot of our allies and friends to follow. So I think that we have to finish the job and nail it down.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, you announced last week that Secretary Rumsfeld would continue in his role. What makes this timing appropriate, and how much did the election outcome influence this decision? [SEP] Indeed. Before the election, you and others asked about Rumsfeld and the Vice President, and I said they would stay. I didn't want to introduce a major war-related decision during the campaign's final stretch. That was the simplest way to respond. However, I also hadn't yet spoken with Bob Gates or had my final conversation with Rumsfeld. Rumsfeld and I had been discussing the need for new perspectives. He recognized that progress in Iraq wasn't happening quickly enough. We were constantly evaluating the situation and whether we had the right personnel and strategy. We frequently adjust our tactics, which necessitates ongoing assessment. He and I concurred that I should accept his resignation. Thus, the decision was made. I anticipated a positive election outcome, but regardless, Bob Gates would have been the nominee.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, will there be a third summit between our nations? [SEP] Their primary demand was the total lifting of sanctions, which we couldn't agree to. They were prepared to denuclearize a considerable portion of the areas we wanted, but we couldn't relinquish all sanctions for that. So, we continue to negotiate, and we'll see what happens. But we had to reject that particular offer.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, considering the UK's concerns about Gary McKinnon's extradition, and Prime Minister Cameron's advocacy, might a more lenient approach be considered? [SEP] This is under discussion between our nations. I don't want to interfere with that. We recognize the seriousness of the charges against Mr. McKinnon. I've spoken with the U.S. Ambassador and the Prime Minister about this. Cybersecurity is a growing concern, and we must cooperate on it. The President doesn't get involved in these matters. My team will follow the law and work closely with our ally. I trust we'll find a solution that respects the seriousness of the issue and our strong relationship.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, you suggested Dr. Birx was 'taking the bait' from Speaker Pelosi. Could you clarify that statement, especially given that Dr. Birx was presenting factual information about the current state of the pandemic? [SEP] Look, we're doing a fantastic job, better than any other country, frankly. If you look at what's happening, especially with these flare-ups in other nations – and remember, we're huge, second only to India and China. China's got a massive flare-up right now, India's struggling, other countries are having problems. But you never see that on the news, do you? Nobody talks about what's happening in other countries. They're having big flare-ups, countries that thought they were done with it. Like Florida – we thought we were over it, and then boom, it came back. But we're doing great. I told Dr. Birx that myself. She's someone I respect a lot. Nancy Pelosi, on the other hand, has treated her terribly, very nasty. I just think they should acknowledge the incredible job we've done, whether it's ventilators or testing. We've tested over 60 million people – nobody else is even close. And a lot of those tests are rapid-fire, giving you results in minutes. Nobody else has that. We're doing very well.
label: Deflection

sentence: Are you leaning towards withdrawing the troops? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, did those protesters say anything against you? [SEP] I have no idea. Didn't ask. Could have been about anything. It was outside the White House, on the other side of the fence. You know, the new fence is very strong. But it was outside. The Secret Service will have a full report soon.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with respect to Meng Wanzhou, is her case destined for prolonged delay, or might the U.S. consider abandoning the extradition proceedings? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you repeat the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. North Korean leaders apparently today warned South Korea against joining international sanctions, saying South Korea would pay a high price if they did so. Are you still confident that South Korea and China will implement the full force of the U.N.-passed sanctions? And what happens if North Korea continues to thumb its nose at the world? [SEP] I believe that—first of all, I've been briefed on this subject recently by the Secretary of State, who just came back from the Far East. She met with the Japanese, the South Koreans, the Chinese, and the Russians. Her report is that all countries understand we must work closely together to solve this problem peacefully. And that means adhering to the latest United Nations Security Council resolution that was passed.The leader of North Korea likes to threaten. In my judgment, what he's doing is just testing the will of the five countries that are working together to convince him there is a better way forward for his people. I don't know the exact words he used, but he is—this is not the first time that he's issued threats. And our goal is to continue to remind our partners that when we work together, we're more likely to be able to achieve the objective, which is to solve this problem diplomatically. And so I would report to you the coalition remains firm, and we will continue to work to see to it that it does remain firm.Baker [Peter Baker, Washington Post].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the Supreme Court's decision, what specific legislative actions will your administration prioritize to protect abortion rights at the federal level? [SEP] That's a matter for Congress.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that these benchmarks lack teeth. They say without clearly defined consequences for failure, the Maliki government has little incentive to comply. How do you respond to these concerns? [SEP] Look, I understand the skepticism. But let's be clear: we're not naive. We have a range of options at our disposal, and we're not afraid to use them if necessary. But our priority is to work collaboratively with the Iraqi government to achieve our shared goals. We believe that a cooperative approach is more likely to yield lasting results than a confrontational one. We're going to hold them accountable, but we're going to do it in a way that respects their sovereignty and promotes stability in the region.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, a growing number of troops are serving multiple tours in Iraq, and there are increasing reports of low morale. An infantry commander shared that troops are questioning their mission. Does this surprise you? Are you aware of this sentiment? Is it widespread or isolated, and does it worry you? [SEP] I'm hearing from commanders that the main concern is with the families back home. Our troops have volunteered and are prepared to serve repeatedly, but their families are anxious. That's why I make a point to thank them. You're speaking with specific individuals, but I'm in contact with commanders who provide me with the on-the-ground situation. I'm aware of concerns on the home front, but I haven't heard significant concerns about troop morale in Iraq.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And you're trying to get—[inaudible]—in Afghanistan. So the way the deal is being worked out, what would be India's role and Pakistan's role in the region? [SEP] Well, I think India would like to see it happen. I spoke with Prime Minister Modi today, and I think they would very much like to see them—see it happen.And we're pretty close. We'll see what's going on. We've got 2 days now under our belt without violence or, I guess, a minimum of violence. And we'll see what happens. But people want to see it.And it's very interesting, that one is. Everybody is happy about it. Even people that are normally against me, like 99.9 percent of the time—[]—because we've been there for 19 years, and everybody would like to see it happen. I was actually surprised. I thought the Schumers of the world would say whatever the opposite is, you know, because that's all they can do. Cryin' Chuck. But people are really—they're really happy to see that we're trying very hard. You know, we're bringing it down to 86—8,600. And from there, we'll make a decision as to what the final outcome would be.But there's been tremendous praise for the fact that we're doing something. You know, other administrations have tried to do something. In particular, the previous administration, for a long time, they were never able to get anything done. And we're really serving not as a military force as we are a police force. And we're not a police force. They have to police their own country. We're not a police force. It's like law enforcement. And that's the way it is.So we'd like to, after 19—I can tell you, after 19 years, we'd like to bring our young people back home. Bring them—that's where they want to be. And we'll always have intelligence there; we'll have other things there. But we'd like to bring them—for the most part, we'd like to bring them back home. We want to watch the area. The area is a hotbed of problems.And when we bring them home, we'll let them know that if something happens, we will hit them so hard. And we could win that easily if I wanted to kill millions of people. I don't want to kill millions of people—innocent people. We could win that very easily. We don't have to act as a police force. We could act as a military force to win, not a military force to just take care of things in that very, very difficult part of the world. It's a very difficult part. It's a very dangerous part of the world.So let's see what happens. So far, so good. So far. But I'm very impressed with the kind of kudos we're getting.Yes, please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding your recent comment calling President Xi a dictator, did that complicate relations with China? And on India, what's your message to those who say your administration is overlooking human rights issues there? [SEP] The answer to your first question is a simple 'no'. When dealing with allies and partners globally, including India, I won't shy away from stating what I believe to be the facts about our relationship with China. I've maintained for some time that the hysteria surrounding our relationship with China is overblown. We had an incident that created some confusion, as you might say, but Secretary Blinken had a successful trip to China. I anticipate meeting with President Xi soon, and I don't believe my comment had any significant impact. And what was your second question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, aside from Huawei, are there any other Chinese technology companies that are being evaluated for potential bans on operating within the United States? [SEP] Huawei is really the primary focus, isn't it? It's not operating here, and I'm ensuring it remains that way. We've communicated to European nations and others, such as Australia, that Huawei isn't coming here. And we've cautioned countries contemplating using Huawei that intelligence sharing will be suspended. They've all backed away. Consider the U.K.; they appeared to be heading in that direction, but they've since changed their minds.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Russia, the Democratic candidates appeared to lack knowledge about Dmitry Medvedev. What's your assessment of him and his power relative to Putin? Critics argue you misjudged Putin. What cautionary advice would you give your successor about Russia and its new leader? [SEP] Frankly, I'm not deeply familiar with Medvedev either. Observing who represents Russia at the G-8 will be informative, shedding light on their foreign policy direction post-Putin. I can't provide a complete answer at this stage. Maintaining relations with Russia is crucial, particularly on issues like proliferation and Iran. Putin's proposal to supply enriched uranium to Bushehr was a positive step. We must collaborate with Russia on Iran. Missile defense in Europe is another area where dialogue is essential. We need to assure Russia it's not targeted at them but at genuine threats. Therefore, cooperation is necessary. I aim to ensure my successor can engage with whoever shapes Russian foreign policy. It's in our nation's interest, even amidst disagreements, such as on Kosovo. Collaboration remains paramount.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Were you informed about coronavirus cases—positive cases—in the White House today? [SEP] About today?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, with respect to the bill concerning voting rights for D.C. and an extra seat for Utah, considering your strong stance on democracy in places like Iraq, what's your take on this? Would you back it, or what? [SEP] Look, I'm not really sure what you're talking about. This is the first time I've heard about this bill coming up in the lame-duck session.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Bush, given the complex issues in Africa, what concrete steps should African leaders prioritize, and how will the U.S. provide meaningful assistance? Furthermore, what do you hope to accomplish on this trip, and why undertake it so late in your presidency? [SEP] Thanks. I made sure to visit Africa early in my presidency as well. This is my second trip to the continent, and I'm here to emphasize that it's in our interest to help African nations combat diseases like malaria and HIV/AIDS, to foster trade, and to invest in education. Seeing it firsthand in Ghana makes a real difference. It's more impactful than just giving speeches back home. Africa has made positive strides during my time as president, largely due to the efforts of African leaders themselves. We've played a role in resolving conflicts, such as in Liberia, where we supported the election of the first female president. Democracy is advancing, thanks to leaders like John Kufuor. Our aid program now emphasizes good governance, like fighting corruption and investing in education. I believe in holding African leaders to high standards. The leaders I'm meeting are dedicated to their people and to honest governance. They prioritize education over personal gain. That's why I'm here, and I'm grateful for the hospitality of my friend. Let's see, John McKinnon from the Wall Street Journal, a very insightful publication.
label: General

sentence: Governor Bush's response to the Oregon shooting was, and I quote, 'Stuff happens.' Your thoughts? [SEP] I think the American people are smart enough to know what to make of that statement, especially considering how often these tragedies occur. My team is looking into every possible way to enforce the laws we already have and keep guns away from people who shouldn't have them. But let's be clear: the only way we're going to see real change is if the politics change. That's why I'm going to keep talking about this, because doing nothing is a political choice in itself.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, if Dr. Tedros steps down from the WHO, would you consider rejoining the organization? [SEP] We're looking into the WHO situation very carefully. There are serious concerns about their handling of the pandemic and their relationship with China. We need to see real reforms before we can even consider rejoining.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. Obama, considering the human rights situation and the drug war in Mexico, will you certify them? What's the future of the Merida Initiative, particularly with the threats to President Calderon and the visa issues? [SEP] Apologies, I didn't catch the translation. It appeared to be a significant inquiry. Is the translation available now? Please, go ahead.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia's recent ban on food imports, a $1.3 billion hit, coupled with Secretary Hagel's warning about troop movements near Ukraine, doesn't this suggest the current sanctions are ineffective? [SEP] Well, the efficacy of the sanctions remains to be fully determined. The intention behind these sanctions is to exert considerable pressure on the Russian economy, and the evidence suggests they are achieving this objective. The markets reflect this, with capital flight estimates ranging from $100 to $200 billion. Investment is stagnating, presenting President Putin with a choice: pursue diplomacy in eastern Ukraine, respecting Ukrainian sovereignty, or continue on the current path, which will ultimately harm the Russian economy and its people. We are aligned with our allies in this approach. However, the situation is unresolved, with ongoing conflict and civilian casualties, including the tragic loss of Malaysian Airlines flight. A return to serious discussions is crucial to ensure all Ukrainians are heard and represented, with reforms implemented to protect Russian speakers and decentralize power. Only then can we consider the problem truly solved. In the interim, the sanctions are functioning as intended.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. President Duda, briefly, is Russia an ally or an enemy? [SEP] Is that question directed at me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. But will the United States recognize it? [SEP] I suggest you study the Ahtisaari plan. Not to be, like, the, you know, grumpy guy. Well, how to get— how do we get more peacekeepers into Darfur? Of course, what has been delaying getting more peacekeepers has been the lack of understanding between the U.N. and the Government of Sudan on the status of forces agreement. Now that one has been signed, I think it has cleared the way. There are many volunteers, and as Chair of the African Union, we certainly seek out more and more volunteers as they are needed. We use our good offices to see more and more African countries contribute. We have volunteered to contribute one battalion. If there is need for another one, we will certainly do that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to the Senate trial, would you rather see a swift conclusion or a comprehensive examination of the evidence? What are your thoughts on the clash between Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler? And is John Bolton's testimony completely off the table? [SEP] That's quite a few questions there.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Senator, are you confident that this legislation will be enacted within the first year of your term? [SEP] The process is moving this first year, and I'm going to be moving it as quickly as I can. I've been accused of doing too much. We are moving full steam ahead on all fronts. Ultimately, I don't have control of the legislative calendar. And so we're going to work with legislative leaders to see what we can do. Andre Showell [Black Entertainment Television]. There you go.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the recent intelligence leaks regarding U.S. surveillance of South Korea, can you confirm whether this matter was discussed during your meetings with President Yoon? Furthermore, did President Biden offer any specific assurances regarding future conduct? [SEP] On that particular matter, we are engaged in ongoing communication with our South Korean counterparts, and we are committed to sharing relevant information as appropriate. As you know, an investigation is currently underway in the United States, and there are numerous factors at play. We must allow time for the investigation to conclude. We intend to maintain open lines of communication on this issue. Next question, please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Regarding Kosovo's independence, what is the timeframe? [SEP] A fine?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the timing of the next meeting with Shanghai Media Group, could you provide any insight into whether it's likely to occur soon or be delayed? [SEP] Look, I wish I had a crystal ball on this one. The truth is, I can't give you a definitive answer. It could happen next week, it could be months down the line. I'm hoping for sooner rather than later, believe me, but there are a lot of moving parts.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you. The Attorney General acknowledged yesterday that there were mistakes in the firing of prosecutors. What is his future in your cabinet? Do you have confidence in him? And more importantly—or just as important—how effective can he be in Congress going forward when he's lost a lot of confidence among Democrats and doesn't have any defenders among Republicans? [SEP] I do have confidence in Attorney General Al Gonzales. I talked to him this morning, and we talked about his need to go up to Capitol Hill and make it very clear to members in both political parties why the Justice Department made the decisions it made, making very clear about the facts. And he's right: Mistakes were made. And I'm frankly not happy about them, because there is a lot of confusion over what really has been a customary practice by the Presidents: U.S. attorneys and others serve at the pleasure of the President. Past administrations have removed U.S. attorneys; it's their right to do so.The Justice Department recommended a list of U.S. attorneys. I believe the reasons why were entirely appropriate. And yet this issue was mishandled to the point now where you're asking me questions about it in Mexico, which is fine. I mean, if I were you, I'd ask the same question. This is an issue that—and so Al—let me just say, Al was right; mistakes were made; and he's going to go up to Capitol Hill to correct them.I appreciate the fact that he's taken some action, because anytime anybody goes up to Capitol Hill, they've got to make sure they fully understand the facts and how they characterize the issue to Members of Congress. And the fact that both Republicans and Democrats feel like that there was not straightforward communication troubles me, and it troubles the Attorney General, so he took action. And he needs to continue to take action.
label: Explicit

sentence: Are you confident that Germany will support sectoral sanctions, particularly in the energy sector? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, sectoral sanctions are a multifaceted issue. Energy is a critical component, of course, but there are numerous other sectors to consider. We're working closely with our European partners, including Germany, to explore all available options. Our goal is a comprehensive package that effectively deters further aggression. We're hopeful that sanctions won't be necessary, but we're prepared to act decisively if needed. Germany is a key ally, and we value their input.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you. What was the one thing—if there was one thing—that changed your mind about the convention? And did Florida officials ask you to cancel it? [SEP] No, they didn't. We're dealing with them, but they didn't. I would just say safety. Just safety. I just—you know, I could see the media saying: Oh this is very unsafe. This is—I don't want to be in that position. It's safety—not because of the media, but that's what they would say.And we'll have a very nice something; we'll figure it out. It will be online, in some form. Maybe it will be something even a little bit different. We have time. You know, we're talking about the end of August. But I think it will be something that will be exciting, but there can be nothing like having 25,000 people.We had a tremendous thing planned in—and a tremendous convention planned in North Carolina. And it would have been very good, but a much smaller version in Florida. But then, we saw what was happening. Pretty quickly, we saw that the virus was coming up that coast.Rise in Coronavirus Cases in Florida/School Reopening Efforts
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. But you definitively believe Iran wants to build a nuclear weapon? [SEP] I think so long—until they suspend and/or make it clear that they— that their statements aren't real, yes, I believe they want to have the capacity, the knowledge, in order to make a nuclear weapon. And I know it's in the world's interest to prevent them from doing so. I believe that the ian—if had a nuclear weapon, it would be a dangerous threat to world peace.But this is—we got a leader in who has announced that he wants to destroy Israel. So I've told people that if you're interested in avoiding world war III, it seems like you ought to be interested in preventing them from have the knowledge necessary to make a nuclear weapon. And I take the threat of with a nuclear weapon very seriously, and we'll continue to work with all nations about the seriousness of this threat. Plus, we'll continue working the financial measures that we're in the process of doing. In other words, I think—the whole strategy is, is that at some point in time, leaders or responsible folks inside of may get tired of isolation and say, This isn't worth it. And to me, it's worth the effort to keep the pressure on this Government.And secondly, it's important for the ian people to know we harbor no resentment to them. We're disappointed in the ian Government's actions, as should they be. Inflation is way too high; isolation is causing economic pain. This is a country that has got a much better future; people have got a much better—should have better hope inside than this current Government is providing them.So it's a—look, it's a complex issue, no question about it. But my intent is to continue to rally the world to send a focused signal to the ian Government that we will continue to work to isolate you, in the hopes that at some point in time, somebody else shows up and says, it's not worth the isolation.Yes, ma'am.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you just said there's not a lot of excess supply out there. Some energy experts think we may have already passed or be within a couple of years of passing the maximum oil pumping capability. In other words, we may be close to tapping all we've got. Do you think that's the case? And if you do, why haven't you put more resources into renewable energy research, sir? [SEP] Wendell, we've put a lot into ethanol. And we're—matter of fact, the solution to the issue of corn-fed ethanol is cellulosic ethanol, which is a fancy word for saying we're going to make ethanol out of switchgrasses or wood chips. And we're spending a lot of money along those lines.But energy policy needs to be comprehensive. And we got to understand, we're in a transition period. The problem is, there's been a lot of focus by the Congress in the intermediate steps and in the long-term steps—the long-term steps being hydrogen; the intermediate steps being biofuels, for example, and researching the biofuels and battery technology—but not enough emphasis on the here and now.And so you ask—you say that people think we can't—there's not any more reserves to be found. Well, there are reserves to be found in ANWR. That's a given. I just told you that there's about 27 million gallons of diesel and gasoline that could be—from domestically produced crude oil that's not being utilized. And not only that, we can explore in environmentally friendly ways. New technologies enables for—to be able to drill like we've never been able to do so before—slant hole technologies and the capacity to use a drill site, a single drill site, to be able to explore a field in a way that doesn't damage the environment. And yet this is a litmus test issue for many in Congress. Somehow if you mention ANWR, it means you don't care about the environment. Well, I'm hoping now people, when they say ANWR, means you don't care about the gasoline prices that people are paying.Yes, sir. Rog [Roger Runningen, Bloomberg News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to Iran, following up on your earlier remarks, what concrete steps do you envision Iran taking to alleviate current tensions? Given your previous diplomatic engagements with North Korea and Russia, would you entertain a meeting with President Rouhani? What specific conditions would need to be met for such a meeting to occur, and have any preliminary discussions taken place? [SEP] Let me be clear: I'm always willing to engage in dialogue. As they say, talking is better than fighting, especially when the stakes are so high. Our engagement with Chairman Kim has yielded tangible results – a cessation of missile tests and the return of American citizens. My meeting with President Putin, regardless of the media spin, was constructive for global stability and economic growth. And NATO is now on a firmer financial footing thanks to our efforts. So, yes, I would consider meeting with Iran if they demonstrate a genuine commitment to resolving the issues. The previous agreement was a catastrophe, a complete failure. They are currently facing challenges, but I anticipate that they will eventually seek a meeting. I am prepared to meet whenever they are ready, not from a position of dominance or vulnerability, but from a position of pragmatism. If we can forge a substantive agreement, unlike the previous charade, I am certainly open to the possibility.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, you promised to forgive $10,000 in student debt. Is that still happening, and when? Also, now that you've addressed the Bull Connor remarks, will you contact Republicans like Mitt Romney about fixing the Electoral Count Act? [SEP] Yeah, I'm always up for talking. I've chatted with Mitt before. And, by the way, I reached out to the minority leader when he gave his speech. So, I'm happy to talk to any Republican, anyone at all, and I've made that clear. Look, I've been traveling a lot lately for funerals and memorials, and I've had Congressmen and Senators come along. I don't have the exact number, but maybe 20 to 25 Senators and Congresspeople have traveled with me. You should ask them about it. We sit together for hours on those flights, talking and asking questions. I've learned a lot. But as President, I don't get to do that as much as I'd like. And one thing that's clear to me, based on the polls, is that people don't want me to be a Senator-President. They want me to be the President and let Senators do their thing. So, if I've messed up, and I'm sure I have, it's because I'm used to negotiating. I've been pretty good at it in the Senate, even as Vice President. But being President is different. Anyway, it's almost 6. See you at the next presser. Thanks.
label: General

sentence: Q. I have two really simple questions. I promise. You campaigned on canceling $10,000 in student loans. Do you still plan to do so and when?And then, my second question is: Now that you've clarified the Bull Connor comments, do you plan to reach out to Republicans like Mitt Romney to talk about reforming the Electoral Count Act? [SEP] Yes, I'm happy to speak out. I've—I've met with—I've talked to Mitt on other occasions. And by the way, I reached out to the minority leader as well at the time that he made his speech. And so I have no reluctance to reach out to any Republican and anyone who—and I've made it clear.Look, I've now had the opportunity to travel because of funerals and eulogies I've made and attended—and Congressmen and Senators who have come along with me. I don't—don't hold me to the number, but somewhere between 20 and 25 Senators and Congresspersons have traveled with me.And I find—you should get the list of them and ask what—how we, you know, sat for the 2, 3, 4, 5 hours that we've flown together—sit back in the—in that conference table and talk to them, ask them questions; they ask me questions. I learned a heck of a lot. But as President, you don't quite have that ability to do that as often as I'd like to be able to do it.And one of the things that I do think that has been made clear to me—speaking of polling—is the public doesn't want me to be the President Senator. They want me to be the President and let Senators be Senators.And so, if I've made—and I've made many mistakes, I'm sure. If I made a mistake, I'm used to negotiating to get things done, and I've been, in the past, relatively successful at it in the United States Senate, even as Vice President. But I think that role as President is a different role.Folks, it is now almost 6. With all due respect, I'm going to see you at the next conference. Okay? Thank you.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Vice President Biden's comments about a 30 percent chance of failure, could you shed some light on the topic of that discussion? [SEP] You know, Joe and I have a lot of conversations. I don't recall the specific instance he's referring to. But let me say this: any time you're dealing with challenges of this magnitude, there's inherent uncertainty. I wouldn't put a number on it, but the point is, no single action is a silver bullet. As I said before, not everything we try will work perfectly. We're facing unprecedented circumstances. Economists have a general idea of the path forward, a consensus on the need for a substantial recovery package, a balanced approach of tax cuts and investments. But even if we get all that right, we still have to address the financial system, get banks lending again, fix the housing market, and create a regulatory system that prevents future crises. These are complex issues. So, I don't know if that's what Joe was talking about, but it highlights the broader point.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. As you know, a growing number of troops are on their second, third, or fourth tour in Iraq. There have been a growing number of reports about declining morale among fighting men. I spoke personally to an infantry commander—tough guy, patriot—who says more and more of the troops are asking, questioning what they're doing here. Does this come as a surprise to you? Are you aware of this? Is it a minority opinion? Is it a growing opinion? And does it concern you? [SEP] I am—what I hear from commanders is that the place where there is concern is with the family members, that our troops, who have volunteered to serve the country, are willing to go into combat multiple times, but that the concern is with the people on the homefront. And I can understand that. And I—and that's one reason I go out of my way to constantly thank the family members. You know, I'm asking—you're obviously talking to certain people—or a person. I'm talking to our commanders. Their job is to tell me what— the situation on the ground. And I have— I know there's concern about the home-front. I haven't heard deep concern about the morale of the troops in Iraq.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. What is your level of confidence that if you are able to reach a comprehensive deal with the Speaker, that he will be able to bring his members onboard and get it passed? Essentially, do you still trust Speaker Boehner in this process? [SEP] There is no doubt that the Speaker has challenges in his caucus, and I recognize that. I'm often reminded when I speak to the Republican leadership that the majority of their caucus's membership come from districts that I lost. All right? And so sometimes, they may not see an incentive in cooperating with me, in part because they're more concerned about challenges from a Tea Party candidate or challenges from the right, and cooperating with me may make them vulnerable. I recognize that.But, goodness, if this past week has done anything, it should just give us some perspective. If there's one thing we should have after this week, it should be a sense of perspective about what's important. And I would like to think that members of their—that caucus would say to themselves: You know what, we disagree with the President on a whole bunch of things. We wish the other guy had won. We're going to fight him on a whole range of issues over the next 4 years. We think his philosophy is all screwed up. But right now what the country needs is for us to compromise, get a deficit reduction deal in place, make sure middle class taxes don't go up, make sure that we're laying the foundations for growth, give certainty to businesses large and small, not put ourselves through some sort of self-inflicted crisis every 6 months, allow ourselves time to focus on things like preventing the tragedy in Newtown from happening again, focus on issues like energy, immigration reform, and all the things that will really make a determination as to whether our country grows over the next 4 years, 10 years, 40 years.And if you just pull back from the immediate political battles, if you kind of peel off the partisan war paint, then we should be able to get something done.And I think the Speaker would like to get that done. I think an environment needs to be created within not just the House Republican Caucus, but also among Senate Republicans that say, the campaign is over and let's see if we can do what's right for the country, at least for the next month. And then, we can reengage in all the other battles that they'll want to fight.
label: Implicit

sentence: Why can't you cooperate while subpoenas are being issued? [SEP] What cooperation are you referring to?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, if these allegations against Postmaster General DeJoy prove to be accurate, specifically regarding the reimbursement of GOP donations, would you consider that acceptable behavior? [SEP] Well, I'm not intimately familiar with the details. I saw something briefly this morning. He's a well-regarded person, supposedly approved by both sides, or so I understand. I'll need to get the full story. I only glanced at it this morning, same as you all.

sentence: So, about your cabinet appointments? [SEP] You want my opinion? Be my guest.

sentence: President Bolsonaro, beyond the extra-NATO alliance discussion, are you actively considering allowing a U.S. military base or presence in Brazil to address the situation on the Venezuelan border, and was this specifically discussed with President Trump? [SEP] Yes, we talked about the possibility of Brazil becoming a great allied extra-NATO. Recently, we requested that food was sent through Boa Vista, the capital of Roraima State, through our friends from America, so that humanitarian aid was provided to .At this point in time, this is where we stand. So for as much as it is possible for us to do together to sort out the issue of the n dictatorship, Brazil will be more than willing and ready to fulfill this mission and take freedom and democracy to that country, which up until recently was one of the wealthiest countries in South America. But nowadays, people are starving to death; they are suffering violence, lack of medication. They're—it's something terrible that's going on in there. And we need to put an end to this issue, which is pervasive to the whole wide world. . Mr. President, please.

sentence: Q. So why not commit to going? [SEP] I don't know. Don't keep talking, because I may—you may convince me to do it. []

sentence: Q. Do you still think Hillary Clinton will be the nominee? [SEP] I'm not talking about politics.

sentence: President Obama, given the TPP's congressional difficulties and the deals announced with Boeing and GE, will you adjust your strategy for TPP approval? Should the agreement be revised to address currency manipulation? Also, can you comment on Mullah Mansur's death and Pakistan's concerns, and whether this signals a new offensive in Afghanistan? [SEP] Well, on TPP, I've learned in the Senate that trade deals are always tough, especially with multiple parties. Everyone wants a better deal, and in an election year, some will play politics. But I'm confident we'll get it done because it's the right thing to do. It's good for America and the world. This is the fastest-growing part of the world, a huge market for us. They sell to us with low tariffs, but ours are higher. Removing 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods is good for business and workers. Historically, trade deals opened us to lower wages and worse labor practices. TPP commits countries to raise labor standards and address environmental problems. I haven't seen a credible argument that TPP will hurt us. We're demonstrably better off. The politics will be noisy, like with the Korean, Colombian, and Panamanian deals, but we got them done. On currency manipulation, TPP has transparency provisions. Some wanted enforceable provisions, but it's hard to determine manipulation. Binding others on monetary policy would mean binding our Fed, which we won't do. But we've strengthened provisions to monitor competitive devaluations. Finally, Mansur's death confirms he targeted U.S. personnel. This isn't a shift in approach. We're not re-entering combat. Our job is to help Afghanistan secure itself. But we'll protect our people. President Quang...
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: The results are being interpreted as a repudiation of your leadership style in some quarters. I wonder what your reaction is to that. And do you—should we expect a very different White House? Should we expect a very different leadership style from you in these last 2 years, given that you have a whole new set of partners? [SEP] Well, Jim, I'm still going to speak plainly about what I think are the important priorities of the country, and winning this war on terror is, by far, the most important priority. And making sure this economy continues to grow is an important priority. And making sure our children have a good education is an important priority. Obviously, there's a shift in the Congress, and therefore, in order to get legislation passed, we've got to work with the Democrats. They're the ones who will control the committees; they're the ones who will decide how the bills flow. And so you'll see a lot of meetings with Democrats and a lot of discussion with Democrats. And in terms of the election, no question Iraq had something to do with it. And it's tough in a time of war when people see carnage on their television screens. The amazing thing about this election, and what surprised me somewhat—which goes to show I should not try punditry—is that this economy is strong. And a lot of times, off years are decided by the economy. And yet obviously, there was a different feel out there for the electorate. The economy— the good news in the economy was overwhelmed by the toughness of this fight and toughness of the war. And so, Jim, look, I understand people don't agree—didn't agree with some of my decisions. I'm going to continue making decisions based upon what I think is right for the country. I've never been one to try to fashion the principles I believe or the decisions I make based upon trying to—kind of short-term popularity. I do understand where the people—the heart of the people. I understand they're frustrated. I am too, as I said the other day. I wish this had gone faster. So does Secretary Rumsfeld. But the reality is, is that it's a tough fight, and we're going to win the fight. And I truly believe the only way we won't win is if we leave before the job is done. Yes, Jim.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, many believe you strategically avoided addressing gun violence during your first term and in 2012, despite supporting the ban on semiautomatic rifles. Given the numerous instances of horrific gun violence during your presidency, where has your attention been directed? [SEP] Jake, let me assure you, I've been fully engaged as President, navigating the worst economic crisis since the Depression, rescuing the auto industry, and managing two ongoing wars. My days have been far from leisurely. We all must reassess our priorities in Washington. The safety of our children is paramount. It's a wake-up call that demands immediate action. I am committed to ensuring their safety. This involves many facets, including healthcare, education, and job opportunities for parents. These aren't secondary concerns. I'm confident that Vice President Biden will dedicate himself to this issue in the coming months. Thank you.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on your perspective regarding Russia's influence on NATO, specifically concerning missile defense systems and the potential inclusion of Ukraine and Georgia? [SEP] Look, those Soviet-era flags you saw yesterday? Don't read too much into it. It's an interesting debate. Every nation assures me Russia won't have a veto over Bucharest's decisions, and I trust them. That's the right approach. I'm committed to Ukraine and Georgia joining MAP. It's in our, NATO's, and their best interests. On missile defense, I've clearly told President Putin it's not aimed at Russia. They could easily overwhelm it. It's for threats from the Middle East, like our Far East systems protect us from single or dual launches. We need to ease suspicions, but we're making progress. Ukraine's NATO membership is about national interest, not targeting anyone. Our history shows collective defense is vital for sovereignty and integrity. Joining MAP is the best response for Ukraine's future. Debates in Europe shouldn't create obstacles. We're on the right track, acting within our sovereignty. The open-door policy shouldn't be replaced by a veto from a non-member. The discussion is overheated, lacking respect. Wisdom should prevail. I want calmness, stability, and security for Ukraine. We want to discuss Ukraine's presence in the world and internally. Those are my motives. Some political forces disagree, which is natural. The red flags represent a tragic past, famine, oppression, and deaths. We might need another Moses. I want to show my vision and ideology.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. The G-20 group today discussed the importance of tax fairness and consistency among countries. For you, how much of that discussion was centered on the Apple case and the EU's decision? And how do you balance your efforts here to ensure global tax fairness with your need and desire to protect U.S. companies and their shareholders? [SEP] Yes.
label: Dodging

sentence: Given your administration's designation of Iran as part of the axis of evil and Syria as a state sponsor of terrorism, under what specific conditions, if any, would you be willing to collaborate with these nations to achieve strategic objectives in Iraq? [SEP] The world expects them to assist Iraq, and we've communicated that clearly. Regarding Iran, we have numerous concerns. First, their willingness to support Iraq's young democracy. Second, their support for the Lebanese democracy under the Siniora Government, which we prioritize. The most pressing issue is Iran's potential acquisition of nuclear weapons. Our position is clear: isolation is not the path forward. We will continue to emphasize that their actions, including sponsoring terrorism, will lead to further isolation. We are actively engaged in diplomatic efforts. The Iranians are aware of our position on Iraq, and more importantly, they are aware of the Iraqi position. We are supporting a sovereign government, and the Iraqis have conveyed to Iran: help us succeed by not interfering in our internal affairs. As for Syria, our message remains consistent: do not undermine the Siniora Government in Lebanon; assist Israel in retrieving the prisoner captured by Hamas; prevent Hamas and Hezbollah from plotting attacks against democracies in the Middle East; and provide assistance within Iraq. They are fully aware of our position.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President——Travel Restrictions/Coronavirus Containment Efforts  Q. At what point would you be considering loosen the travel restrictions regarding China? [SEP] When we're at a point where we don't have a problem. You know, we're not going to loosen the travel restrictions. That's what saved us. Had I not made—Mike alluded to it—had I not made a decision very early on not to take people from a certain area, we wouldn't be talking this way. We'd be talking about many more people would have been infected.I took a lot of heat. I mean, some people called me racist because I made a decision so early. And we had never done that as a country before, let alone early. So it was a, you know, bold decision. It turned out to be a good decision. But I was criticized by the Democrats. They called me a racist because I made that decision, if you can believe that one.We have to all work together. We can't say bad things and especially when we have the best team anywhere in the world. And we really gave it an early start. We gave it a very early start.
label: General

sentence: Q. Looking back, Mr. President, is there anything you believe you could have handled differently? [SEP] Regarding which specific situation are you referring to?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding your meetings, was Canadian stimulus discussed? And for both of you, what's the 4-year outlook for Canada-U.S. relations? Auto sector? Border security? Carbon market? [SEP] Hold on a second! You're asking a dozen questions at once. Were you directing that to Jonathan?
label: Clarification

sentence: President, given the election results, are you willing to concede that perhaps the voters are not as enthusiastic about your agenda as you previously believed, and will you be making any significant changes to your staff or policy proposals? [SEP] Well, let me be clear: The American people have spoken, and we hear them loud and clear. They want action. They want results. And they want Washington to start working for them again. Now, the election results are what they are, and we're going to analyze them carefully. But I remain convinced that the core principles of my agenda – creating jobs, strengthening the middle class, and investing in our future – are the right ones for this country. We're always looking for ways to improve our approach, to refine our strategies, and to better connect with the American people. So, yes, we'll be making some adjustments, both in terms of personnel and policy. But our commitment to the American people remains unwavering.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, Jimmy Carter unleashed some fairly harsh criticism of you over the weekend. Were you surprised by this, and do you take much stock in what he said? [SEP] Steve, you know, I get criticized a lot from different quarters, and that's just part of what happens when you're President. And I will continue to make decisions that I think are necessary to protect the American people from harm. I will continue to make decisions based upon certain principles, one of which is my strong belief in the universality of freedom.We're at war with an enemy that is relentless and determined, and it's essential that the decisions I make protect the American people as best as we can. And it turns out, my Presidency is such that we talk about how—with strong allies—how to defend ourselves. I firmly believe that in order to protect America—we must go on the offense against radicals, extremists, murderers in order to protect not only ourselves but our allies.And I also realize that we're involved in an ideological struggle, that these murderers, these radicals, these extremists have got a point of view. If you want to find out what their point of view is about, look what happened in Afghanistan under the brutal relationship of the Taliban and Al Qaida. On the one hand, if you're a woman and spoke out or a woman and tried to advance, you were suppressed, in brutal fashion sometimes. And in the meantime, an enemy that hates America plotted and planned.And so look, I understand some people are—may not agree with the decisions I made. But what the American people need to know, I'm making them based upon what's best for this country.And, anyway, thank you all for coming. It's—what was the word?
label: Implicit

sentence: Was it right for the U.S. to drop a nuclear weapon on Hiroshima and Nagasaki? [SEP] Wait, remind me, were there two or three questions?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. How do you interpret last night's results in terms of deciding whether you want to seek another term? Is it now more likely that you will run? And what's going to be your timeline for consideration? [SEP] Well, first of all, Jill and I have—and by the way, this is my wife Jill—[]—who's a hell of a lot more popular than I am in the Democratic Party too.But at any rate, all kidding aside, our intention is to run again. That's been our intention, regardless of what the outcome of this election was. And the fact that we won—we—I didn't win, run—the fact that the Democratic Party outperformed anything anyone expected and did better than any off-year Presidency since John Kennedy is one that gives everybody, like, Hoo—sigh of relief—that the mega Republicans are not taking over the Government again, et cetera.And so my judgment of running, when I announce—if I announce—now, my intention is that I run again. But I'm a great respecter of fate. And this is, ultimately, a family decision. I think everybody wants me to run, but they're—we're going to have discussions about it. And I don't feel in any hurry one way or another what—to make that judgment today, tomorrow, whenever, no matter what the—my predecessor does.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the unresolved issues from the Pinochet regime in Chile, and the claims of U.S. involvement, will you assist in investigations into the deaths of Allende and Frei? And will the U.S. apologize for its role in the events of the 70s? [SEP] We're open to helping Chile get more information about its past if they ask. It's important to understand history, even though U.S.-Latin America relations have had their ups and downs. But we can't let the past hold us back. Chile has made great strides in the last two decades, with our support. I can't comment on past policies, but I can say we're committed to democracy, fighting poverty, and supporting inclusive development. We're strong supporters of Chile's economy. We need to learn from history, but we also need to focus on the challenges of today and tomorrow.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the evolving geopolitical landscape, how would you characterize the most pressing threats facing the United States today, and what specific strategies are you implementing to address them? [SEP] The biggest threat is always the possibility of an attack on our own soil. There are still people out there who want to hurt us, and we have to be vigilant. North Korea remains a concern, especially their nuclear program. We need to make sure they honor their commitments and allow for strong verification. Iran is also a problem. We have to work with our allies to contain their destabilizing activities.

sentence: Mr. President, there is a perception that your meeting with Kim Jong-un, without prior concessions, provides him with undue legitimacy on the world stage. How do you respond to critics who argue that this meeting rewards North Korea's bad behavior and undermines international efforts to denuclearize the Korean Peninsula? [SEP] That's just the fake news. We got three hostages back. We paid nothing. They're home with their families, happier than ever. We haven't given up anything. The haters say, 'Oh, you're giving him a meeting.' Give me a break! This has never been done before. And what's been done before hasn't worked. I can't stress this enough. Look at tariffs. Previous people should have handled it. The same with . This should have been done years ago.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, that doesn't answer the question. Do you believe homosexuality is inherently immoral? [SEP] I respect the diverse viewpoints of all Americans. My priority is the effective functioning of our armed forces, and 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' allows us to maintain that focus.

sentence: Q. Earlier in the Oval Office, before you did your meeting with President Duda, you were quite critical of Germany, as you talked about possibly moving troops from Germany to Poland. Do you think that doing a move like that will put pressure on Germany to meet their defense spending requirements? [SEP] No, I don't think so. I just will tell you very strongly that I think Germany is making a tremendous mistake by relying so heavily on the pipeline. And I think it's a tremendous mistake for Germany. But again, Germany is running their affairs. And they'll do just fine.But I was critical. I had been critical of it. It's a tremendous amount of their energy will be supplied by that pipeline.At the same time, having nothing to do with Germany, Poland said that we would like to build a facility, a great facility, and we'd like to have you come to that facility. So we're going to be there with a limited force, but we'll be there. And we appreciate Poland doing what they're doing. It's a great location. It's a tremendous—it's a tremendous plant, tremendous facility. And we—it's our honor to be there.Poland has been a tremendous friend of ours for a long time. And when Melania and I were there not so long ago, it was a very special day. I think it was a special day for Poland, also. But it was a very special day for our country. So I appreciate that. And our relationship is just a very strong one.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you provide an update on the possibility of a renewed assault weapons ban? [SEP] We're working on it. More details to come.

sentence: Mr. President, despite Judge Kavanaugh's previous background checks, wouldn't an FBI investigation help to clear up any remaining doubts? [SEP] The FBI says they don't really do that, Jon. They've already done six background checks. He's an incredible person, smart, with a perfect record. I feel bad he's going through this. It should have been brought up earlier, during the hearings. Why didn't Senator Feinstein bring it up then? The Democrats are just obstructing. He's a great man. We should go through a process, shouldn't be a doubt. They should have done this months ago. Hopefully, the woman will come forward, state her case. He will state his case. Then they'll vote. I feel terrible for him, his wife, and his daughters.
