sentence: Sir, are you actively encouraging all governors to mandate mask-wearing? [SEP] Each governor has to make their own decisions based on their state. We've provided them with the facts, the best information available. Some are very pro-mask, others are not. It's a state-by-state thing, really.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You mentioned your progress on COVID-19. I'd like to ask you about some of the other issues facing your Presidency. One of the defining challenges you face in the coming months is how to deliver on your promise to Americans on issues like immigration reform, gun control, voting rights, climate change. All of those right now are facing stiff, united opposition from Republicans on Capitol Hill. How far are you willing to go to achieve those promises that you made to the American people? [SEP] Well, I'm going to—look, when I took office, I decided that it was a fairly basic, simple proposition, and that is: I got elected to solve problems. And the most urgent problem facing the American people, I stated from the outset, was COVID-19 and the economic dislocation for millions and millions of Americans. And so that's why I put all my focus in the beginning—there are a lot of problems—put all my focus on dealing with those particular problems.And the other problems we're talking about, from immigration to guns and the other things you mentioned, are long-term problems; they've been around a long time. And what we're going to be able to do, God willing, is now begin, one at a time, to focus on those as well, and—whether it's immigration or guns or a number of other problems that face the country.But the fundamental problem is getting people some peace of mind so they can go to bed at night and not stare at the ceiling wondering whether they lost their health insurance, whether they're going to lose a family member, whether they're going to be in a position where they're not going to be—they're going to lose their home because they can't pay their mortgage, or that millions of people are going to get thrown out of their homes because of the inability to pay their rent.So we're going to move on these one at a time, try to do as many simultaneously as we can. But that's the reason why I focused as I have.And here's the deal: I think my Republican colleagues are going to have to determine whether or not we want to work together, or they decide that the way in which they want to proceed is to just decide to divide the country, continue the politics of division. But I'm not going to do that; I'm just going to move forward and take these things as they come.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, which specific individuals within the GOP should embrace a more inclusive approach, in your opinion? [SEP] Look, I'm afraid that after a defeat, the temptation will be to look inward and impose rigid ideological tests. This party will recover. But the core message must be that diverse perspectives are valued. Consider the immigration debate. It's clearly a contentious issue. The problem with the initial debate was that some people concluded, 'Republicans don't like immigrants.' Whether that's accurate or not, that's the perception. And if the perception is that we don't like immigrants, then others might think, 'Well, if they don't like immigrants, they probably don't like me either.' So, my point is that our party must be compassionate and broad-minded. I recall the 1964 elections. My father was running for the U.S. Senate and was swept away by the Johnson landslide in Texas. It wasn't just George Bush who lost; the Republican Party was decimated. At least, that's how the pundits saw it. But in '66, there was a resurgence. The same thing can happen this time, but we have to ensure our message is broad and compassionate: That we care about people's lives and have a plan to improve them.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, if I may, I'd like to change the subject. You've spoken about closing racial gaps within the government. How does criminal justice reform fit into that? What gaps remain for you to address? And what is the significance of your upcoming trip to Kenya? Finally, will you revoke Bill Cosby's Medal of Freedom? [SEP] You've asked a lot of questions there, April. Let's just say...
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, if you could, will the conflict end by the time you leave office? And do you approve of Israel's conduct? [SEP] I'm aiming for a sustainable cease-fire. That means Hamas has to stop firing rockets into Israel. If they continue, a sustainable cease-fire is impossible. The choice is Hamas's. To ensure a sustainable cease-fire, we're working with Egypt to stop arms smuggling into Gaza, which fuels Hamas's rocket attacks. Countries supplying weapons to Hamas need to stop, and the international community must pressure them to do so. Hamas must stop arming. Countries bordering Gaza must stop the smuggling. It's tough, with tunnels and opportunities for those wanting to disrupt democracy to provide weapons. What was the second part of your question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, it's not just about Dr. Tedros, but about systemic changes within the WHO? [SEP] It's about accountability. It's about fairness. And it's about ensuring that the WHO is truly serving the interests of global health, not just the interests of one particular country.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. The World Bank says about 85 percent of the increase in corn price since 2002 is due to biofuel—increased demand for biofuels. And your Secretary of State said that—indicated yesterday that she thought that might be part of the problem. Do you agree with that? And what can the United States do—what more can the United States do to help make food more affordable around the world? [SEP] Yes, actually, I have a little different take. I thought it was 85 percent of the world's food prices are caused by weather, increased demand, and energy prices—just the cost of growing product— and that 15 percent has been caused by ethanol—or the arrival of ethanol.By the way, the high price of gasoline is going to spur more investment in ethanol as an alternative to gasoline. And the truth of the matter is, it's in our national interests that we—our farmers grow energy as opposed to us purchasing energy from parts of the world that are unstable or may not like us.In terms of the international situation, we are deeply concerned about food prices here at home, and we're deeply concerned about people who don't have food abroad. In other words, scarcity is of concern to us. Last year, we were very generous in our food donations, and this year, we'll be generous as well. As a matter of fact, we just released about $200 million out of the Emerson Trust as part of a ongoing effort to address scarcity.One thing I think that would be—I know would be very creative policy is if we would buy food from local farmers as a way to help deal with scarcity, but also as a way to put in place an infrastructure so that nations can be self-sustaining and self-supporting. It's a proposal I put forth that Congress hasn't responded to yet, and I sincerely hope they do.That would be Jim [Jim Axelrod, CBS News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to Postmaster General DeJoy and the alleged campaign finance violations, if these allegations are proven true, will you take action? [SEP] Honestly, I just heard about this. The Postmaster General is a very respected person. I'm not sure what the story is. I'll have to get back to you on that. I will know more soon.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with regard to Syria, do you believe President Putin has been forthright about Russia's intentions? Should Russia target U.S.-backed groups, will the U.S. military intervene to protect them? Furthermore, can the train-and-equip program be salvaged, or should we consider alternative strategies like a no-fly zone? [SEP] Let's be frank about Syria. It began with peaceful protests against Assad, which were met with appalling brutality, escalating into a civil war. This isn't a conflict between the U.S. and anyone in Syria; it's the Syrian people against a ruthless dictator. Russia and Iran have consistently supported Assad, making their current actions merely more conspicuous. I conveyed to Putin that the only resolution is a political transition that includes all parties except Assad. I'm prepared to collaborate with Russia if they can broker this transition, but a military solution is untenable. We share a common objective of defeating ISIS, but Putin's inability to differentiate between ISIS and the moderate opposition is a fundamental flaw. We're holding technical talks to avoid aerial clashes. Concerning our support for opposition groups, they are vital for a future political transition. The train-and-equip program has fallen short of expectations because of their preoccupation with Assad's attacks. We're evaluating successful approaches, such as our partnership with the Kurds. Putin's intervention in Syria is indicative of weakness, not strength. His coalition comprises only Iran and Assad, while ours includes the rest of the world. We're willing to work with Russia and Iran on a political transition, but it necessitates a change in government. Their airstrikes against the moderate opposition are counterproductive.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Well, I wanted to ask for your thoughts, your views on support for Africa, which will be negatively affected by global warming. Do you have any plans for supporting Africa? [SEP] ——starts with understanding that babies are needlessly dying because of mosquito bites, and therefore, wealthy nations ought to step up and provide mosquito nets, DDT, as well as medicine. My concern for starts with knowing that too many people are dying of HIV/AIDS. And that's why the United States Congress joined the administration in supporting a $15 billion effort to help people get antiretroviral drugs, help orphans get help, and help put a—effective prevention program in place. The amount—number of people who have gone on antiretrovirals today has grown from 50,000 to 1.7 million people.I'm concerned about people going hungry. And so we'll be very constructive in the dialogue when it comes to the environment. I care about the environment. But today, there's too much suffering on the continent of , and now is the time for the comfortable nations to step up and do something about it.U.S. Economy and Monetary Policy/Energy/
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, to be perfectly clear, are you suggesting that a 'minor incursion' by Russia into Ukrainian territory would be tolerated without significant repercussions from the United States? [SEP] [] I appreciate the inquiry.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, many workers are anxious about returning to their jobs. What specific steps is your administration taking to guarantee their safety and well-being? [SEP] Look, the governors are on top of it. They're smart people, they know what they're doing. They'll make sure everything's safe, believe me. Companies can do tests, temperature checks, all sorts of things. We're not going to be stuck like this forever, folks. We're going back to normal. We're going to have packed stadiums, restaurants full of people. I don't want to see this empty room with reporters spread out. It's not a good look. We're going back. People will shake hands again, maybe not everyone, but most. I even started shaking hands when I ran for office. So, the governors will handle it. They're doing a great job.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, regarding the eligibility of Kamala Harris for the Vice Presidency, can you confirm or deny the validity of the claims questioning her qualifications? [SEP] I've only recently heard about this. I have no idea if there's any truth to it. One would assume the Democrats did their due diligence.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Concerning the economic landscape, what is your outlook for the future? Do you perceive this trend as beneficial or detrimental? [SEP] I hope we move away from protectionism. I was disappointed we couldn't get the trade bills for Colombia, Panama, and South Korea through Congress. I was hopeful, but they didn't pass the House. I worry about protectionism. In tough times, there's a temptation to protect our own and not compete. That sentiment was there even in good times. We barely got CAFTA through Congress. It would be a mistake to become protectionist. The Bush Center at SMU could remind people about the benefits of free trade: for our workers, overseas workers, development, and lifting people out of poverty in third world countries. Trade is the best way to enhance economic growth and give people a better future. I hope the country doesn't become protectionist. April, you had a question?
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, reflecting on the past year and acknowledging the challenges, particularly with the healthcare rollout, what do you consider your biggest mistake in office? [SEP] Are we talking about mistakes related to healthcare specifically, or are you asking about my biggest mistake in general?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, you've spent the last two days emphasizing the U.S.-Japan alliance and outlining a vision for a free and open Indo-Pacific. Yet, in two days, you'll be in China, a nation that's neither free nor open. So, how can the U.S. champion freedom and openness in this region without inevitably coming into conflict with China? And Prime Minister, the President has often spoken about wanting Japan to take a stronger role in its own defense. He'd like to sell Japan military equipment, and there have been reports that the President was disappointed that the Japanese didn't shoot down the North Korean missile that flew over Hokkaido. Did this subject come up? And what did you tell the President about the role you want Japan to play in its defense? [SEP] Let me just add to what the Prime Minister said. He'll shoot them down once he finishes buying all the great military equipment from us. He'll easily shoot them down, just like we did in Saudi Arabia. Amazing shot. Now, the Prime Minister is going to buy massive amounts of military equipment from the United States, and he should. We make the best, by far. Whether it's the F-35, the greatest fighter in the world, totally stealth, or missiles of all kinds, it's jobs for us and safety for Japan and other countries buying from us, countries that weren't buying a year or two ago. As for China, my relationship with President Xi is excellent. I like him a lot. He's a friend. But he represents China, and I represent the United States. We have different views on some things, but we're pretty aligned on trade. The problem with China is that for decades, it's been a very unfair trade situation. I'm being kind to previous administrations. Our trade deficit is massive, hundreds of billions a year, not even including intellectual property. We've started discussions with China because it has to come down. It has to come down to free, fair, or reciprocal trade. I prefer reciprocal. When you explain that you're going to charge tariffs to equalize things, some people don't get it. But when you say it's reciprocal, that we'll charge the same as they charge us, they understand. It's much more understandable. Reciprocal trade is very important to me. We have countries charging us a hundred-percent tax while we charge them nothing. I've been against that for a long time, and you'll see us do something about it. It takes time, with statutory limitations and notices. But you'll see strong action against countries that have been treating the United States, the American worker, and our companies unfairly. It's already started, but the legal foundation is done. You're going to see a big difference, very soon. The United States has been treated very unfairly when it comes to trade. Thank you very much.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Do you believe the Saudi government was involved in Jamal Khashoggi's murder, and if so, what repercussions should they face? [SEP] We're investigating the situation very thoroughly. I'm consulting with various parties, and I'll have a more informed perspective in the coming days. It's a serious matter, and we're taking it seriously.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Some adjustment on which side? The corporate? The individual? The President. Some adjustment, yes, to make it possible. But I would love to see a tax cut for the middle class. Now, that's going to be their decision. They're going to have to make that decision.As you know, if we bring it up to the Senate, we'd need Democrat votes—10—and we don't have those 10 votes. Q. And just because the markets would want to know, sir, some adjustment, would that be 1, 2, 3 percent on either side? [SEP] Oh, I'm not telling you that. I'm just saying, I would be certainly willing to do a little bit of an adjustment.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: If the clinical trials demonstrate clear efficacy, will you commit to supporting an accelerated approval pathway for this drug? [SEP] Look, I'm not a scientist, and I haven't seen the data myself. It would be irresponsible of me to speculate on something like that without all the facts. Let's wait and see what the experts say.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, were you aware of any positive COVID tests within the White House earlier today? [SEP] I'm having trouble hearing you.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Senate trial, do you favor a speedy end or a complete investigation? What's your opinion of the spat between Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler? And is John Bolton's appearance before the Senate entirely out of the question? [SEP] You're asking me multiple questions at once.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, what concrete steps do you hope President Putin will take under your leadership? [SEP] I'll be discussing that with him before I discuss it with you. If something positive comes of it, that would be great. If not, I'm not going in with high expectations, but we may come out with some very surprising things. Relationships are very important. Having a relationship with Russia and other countries is a good thing. I've been saying that for years, especially during my campaign. The NATO meeting yesterday was incredibly significant. We turned an unfair situation into something unified. They were energized and committed. They need approval from their parliaments, but they're ready to increase their contributions. Stoltenberg is doing a terrific job. He said yesterday that because of me, we've taken in $34 billion more for NATO. I think the number is actually much higher. My opponent wouldn't have done that. The numbers were going down; now the number is way up, and going higher. He will tell you that was because of me.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Prime Minister Maliki, is there a deadline for achieving these objectives? You emphasize the U.S. goal of combating Al Qaeda. Does this imply that addressing sectarian violence in Iraq is solely the responsibility of the Iraqis, and that U.S. troops will not be involved in quelling it? Also, Prime Minister Maliki, could you explain why you canceled last night's meeting? [SEP] Remind me of the first part of that question again?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. But there were phone calls, sir? Mr. President, there were phone calls? [SEP] Numerous calls. And as I have said before, there were communications that went back and forth over the last 2 days, as recent as last night. And not only with Steve; there were calls with other people too.Just so you understand: China wants to make a deal. Now, whether or not we make a deal—it's got to be a great deal for us. You know—and I told this to President Xi, who I really respect. I really do. I have great respect, and I like him too. And he's a tough guy, but I have a lot of feeling for President Xi. He's very outstanding in so many ways.But I told him very strongly—I said: Look, you're starting up here, and you're making $500 billion a year and stealing our intellectual property. We're down on the floor, lower than the floor. You can't make a 50/50 deal. This has to be a deal that's better for us. And if it's not better, let's not do business together. I don't want to do business. Forget about tariffs for a second. We're taking in tremendous amounts of money. Forget that. I don't want to do business.Now, when I raise and he raises, I raise and he raises, we can never catch up. We have to balance our trading relationship at least to an extent. And they were unwilling to do that, and we'll never have a deal if that happens. But it's going to happen, because they have to have a deal.And as far as phone calls are concerned, Secretary of the Treasury and other people have been receiving many calls—not receiving—back and forth, many calls.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, will you call President Xi and ask him to let the WHO investigate COVID? [SEP] We have a business relationship. That's all. I'm dealing with China on many things, and we'll see about the WHO. But we're not 'friends'.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given Russia's communications with both the U.S. and Guaidó, what message do you have? [SEP] Look, don't sweat it. We're on top of things. We're fully informed and deeply involved. Everything's going to be fine. Thank you.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, realistically, do you believe Speaker Boehner has the ability to get his caucus on board with any deal you might strike? Do you still have faith in his leadership? [SEP] The Speaker faces significant hurdles within his own party, that's no secret. Many of his members represent districts where I was unsuccessful. They might prioritize avoiding challenges from the right over working with me. But I hope that recent events have given everyone a renewed sense of perspective and a desire to compromise for the good of the nation.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You've heard from a lot of Latin America leaders here who want the U.S. to lift the embargo against Cuba. You've said that you think it's an important leverage to not lift it. But in 2004, you did support lifting the embargo. You said, it's failed to provide the source of raising standards of living, it's squeezed the innocent, and it's time for us to acknowledge that this particular policy has failed. I'm wondering, what made you change your mind about the embargo? [SEP] Well, 2004, that seems just eons ago. What was I doing in 2004?
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Xinjiang situation and the alleged use of slave labor by the Chinese Communist Party, why hasn't your administration implemented a full regional ban on products from Xinjiang? And are other countries joining us in addressing this issue? [SEP] We are taking this very seriously. We're looking into the reports, and we'll have a clearer picture in the next few days. Then we'll decide on the appropriate action. Next question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding NSA surveillance, a judge has stated that the government hasn't shown that bulk metadata collection has stopped any attacks. Can you give us specific examples where it has, and explain why it should continue? [SEP] Let's take a broader view first. The independent panel I set up has given me 46 recommendations, which I'm carefully considering. I want to thank them publicly for their work. They were tasked with looking at our security structures and programs to make sure they balance our need for security with the rule of law and privacy concerns. I'll make a clear statement in January after talking with people both inside and outside the government. The 215 program, which is about collecting phone numbers and exchanges, has gotten a lot of attention. The NSA thought it was important to track calls from known terrorists outside the US to the US. While there haven't been claims of the NSA misusing this data, people are worried about the possibility of abuse. We need to see if we can achieve the same goals with more public confidence. I'm confident the NSA isn't spying on Americans, but we need to adjust to new technologies. We also need to give the international community more confidence. We have many laws to protect Americans from being spied on, but international rules are less clear. We need to apply our values more consistently beyond our borders.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the complexities of missile defense and Russia's concerns, what are the potential risks and rewards of pursuing a cooperative approach to global missile defense? [SEP] The risks are that we could face resistance from some quarters, both at home and abroad. But the rewards are potentially enormous. A cooperative approach to global missile defense could enhance our security, reduce tensions, and foster a more stable and peaceful world. It's worth the effort.
label: General

sentence: Madam President, considering your campaign promises centered around specific policy changes, and acknowledging the recent electoral setbacks faced by your party, do you feel compelled to reassess your legislative priorities for the remainder of your term? Furthermore, what adjustments are you prepared to make within your administration to better address the concerns voiced by voters? [SEP] Look, folks, the message from the American people is crystal clear: Washington's broken. They see the gridlock, the infighting, and they're fed up. As the one elected to lead this nation, I take that responsibility seriously. My job is to find common ground, to bridge the divides, and to deliver results. Now, when it comes to specific policies, let's be clear: some things are non-negotiable. We're going to fight for working families, for affordable healthcare, and for a clean energy future. But I'm also willing to listen, to compromise, and to work with anyone who's serious about solving problems. We'll be reaching across the aisle, engaging in good-faith negotiations, and focusing on areas where we can find common ground, like infrastructure and job creation. It's time to put aside partisan politics and get to work for the American people.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you met a lot of leaders here; many were angry about the NSA story. Have you fixed the relationships with these leaders? And the second question is, many are shocked by the extent of which the NSA collects private data. Today we heard in the New York Times that you plan to end the systematic collection of data of Americans. But can you address the concerns of the Dutch and the rest of the world about their privacy? [SEP] Well, first of all, we have had a consistent, unbreakable bond between the leaders of Europe over the last several decades, and it's across many dimensions: economic, military, counterterrorism, cultural. And so any one issue can be an irritant in the relationship between the countries, but it doesn't define those relationships. And that continues to be the case, and that has been the case throughout the last couple of years.As I said in a speech that I gave earlier this year, the United States is very proud of its record of working with countries around the world to prevent terrorism or nuclear proliferation or human trafficking or a whole host of issues that all of us I think would be concerned about. Intelligence plays a critical role in that process.What we've seen is that as technology has evolved, the guidelines and structures that constrain how our intelligence agencies operated have not kept pace with these advances in technology. And although, having examined over the last year, year and a half what's been done, I'm confident that everybody in our intelligence agencies operates in the best of intentions and is not snooping into the privacy of ordinary Dutch, German, French, or American citizens. What is true is, is that there is a danger because of these new technologies that at some point, it could be abused. And that's why I initiated a broad-based review of what we could do.There are a couple of things that we did that are unprecedented. In my speech, I announced that, for the first time, under my direction, that we are going to treat the privacy concerns of non-U.S. persons as seriously as we are the constraints that already exist by law on U.S. persons. We're doing that not because we're bound by international law, but because ultimately, it's the right thing to do.With respect to some of the aspects of data collection, what I've been very clear about is, is that there has to be a narrow purpose to it, not a broad-based purpose; but it's rather based on a specific concern around terrorism or counterproliferation or human trafficking or something that I think all of us would say has to be pursued.And so what I've tried to do then is to make sure that my intelligence teams are consulting very closely at each stage with their counterparts in other nations so that there's greater transparency in terms of what exactly we're doing, what we're not doing. Some of the reporting here in Europe, as well as the United States, frankly, has been pretty sensationalized. I think the fears about our privacy in this age of the Internet and big data are justified. I think the actual facts—people would have an assurance if—that if you are just the ordinary citizen in any of these countries, that your privacy, in fact, is not being invaded on. But I recognize that because of these revelations, that there's a process that's taking place where we have to win back the trust not just of governments, but more importantly, of ordinary citizens. And that's not going to happen overnight, because I think that there's a tendency to be skeptical of government and to be skeptical in particular of U.S. intelligence services. And so it's going be necessary for us—the step we took that was announced today, I think, is an example of us slowly, systematically putting in more checks, balances, legal processes.The good news is that I'm very confident that it can be achieved, and I'm also confident that the core values that America has always believed in, in terms of privacy, rule of law, individual rights, that that has guided the United States for many years and it will continue to guide us into the future. Okay?Thank you very much, everybody. Thank you again.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, following up on the Israeli strike in Syria, can you offer any insight into the target, the U.S.'s position on the matter, and the broader implications for the region, considering the tensions between Syria, Iran, and Israel? Could this draw the U.S. into the conflict? [SEP] That's not something I can discuss at this time. Moving on.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, have you discussed the issue of possible inspections to North Korea's nuclear sites during your negotiations? [SEP] I didn't hear you clearly. Where are you reporting from?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, can you give the American people a straight answer: are you planning to seek reelection? [SEP] Let me be clear, I'm focused on the present. I've always believed in taking things one step at a time. I'm a firm believer in destiny.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. The word torture. What's your definition? [SEP] That's defined in law, and we don't torture.
label: Dodging

sentence: President, have you chosen your Federal Reserve Chair nominee? If not, what's your thought process? It's late in the game. Are you worried about the timeline, especially if Powell isn't renominated? [SEP] No, no, and no. I'm not going to talk about it. It's being handled. We'll announce it quickly. It's been in the works. We'll have enough time to get everyone approved. I've thought about it a lot, met with my advisors. We have good options. But I'm not going to speculate. Nancy, CBS, you had your hand up?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, in layman's terms, what's next? [SEP] Well, the immediate need is to get more people back into their homes, to ensure they have a place to live. The systems are in place for the ongoing reconstruction of New Orleans. Some have criticized the Federal response as slow, but I must point out that 30,000 people were rescued from rooftops immediately after the storm. I personally thanked the helicopter pilots and Coast Guard for their heroic efforts. While improvements could always be made, to call the response slow is to disregard the efforts of those who saved so many lives. Furthermore, I was deeply moved by the reactions after the election, seeing people with tears in their eyes expressing disbelief at the election of a Black president. It highlights the progress we've made as a nation regarding race relations, but there is still work to be done to address the prejudices that remain in people's hearts. I am optimistic about the future and the historic moment this represents for our country.
label: Deflection

sentence: What are your thoughts on the flak your successor is catching? [SEP] Honestly, President Bush was incredibly kind and helpful during my transition. My focus for the next two months is wrapping things up. Then, Michelle and I are escaping for a vacation – some much-needed rest, time with the girls, and a chance to write and think. I want to respect the office and give the President-elect room to present his agenda without constant interference. As an American who cares deeply about our country, if core values are threatened, not just legislative details, and if I think my voice is needed, I'll speak up. But first and foremost, Michelle and I are going on vacation.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, to be perfectly clear, will the sanctions currently in place remain so? [SEP] Sanctions are in effect, period. The media's narrative that we've given up ground is simply inaccurate. I foresee a very positive future with Chairman Kim and North Korea, a nation with incredible potential. The crux of the issue was sanctions; they wanted them gone, but weren't prepared to offer the necessary concessions. We're talking about significant issues here.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Russia says it's pulling back near Kyiv. Is this the beginning of the end, or just a trick? [SEP] We'll see. I'm not buying it until I see it. Let's see if they actually do what they say. They're talking in Turkey and other places. I met with France, Germany, and the UK, and we all think we should wait and see what they offer. But we're keeping the sanctions strong and sending weapons to Ukraine. We're watching them closely. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Yushchenko, if NATO says no to Ukraine's membership in Bucharest, what's plan B? [SEP] Even if it doesn't happen, I'm confident we'll succeed because of our strong arguments and commitment to international debate. We're making progress every day. I thank President Bush for his public and private efforts. We know this is important, and we're working hard for a positive outcome. I believe our EU friends will play a key role. We need to convince those who still have doubts. Frankly, I see no other path for Ukraine. Whether we join MAP or not isn't the final goal. We've already decided to join NATO. Why should Ukraine be denied this right? Let's join MAP, then explain NATO to the nation. If politicians care about Ukraine, they'll support this. The nation is wise and will vote yes in a referendum. Support for NATO has grown from 17% to 40%. The parliament's attention has helped. So, everything will be fine. Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Regarding the coronavirus outbreak, what benchmarks need to be met before you'll consider relaxing travel restrictions from China? [SEP] When the problem is gone. Plain and simple. Those restrictions were a lifesaver. Without them, we'd be dealing with a catastrophe. I was attacked for it, called names, but I stood my ground. It was the right call. We need unity, not division, especially when we have the best people in the world working on this.
label: General

sentence: Q. I have a question to the President and then a question to the Chancellor. Mr. President, now Germany tries to have a new action of the Middle East Quartet. And the debate always is how can European powers influence a superpower like the United States? Whether Germany objected Iraq or Tony Blair got along in Iraq, they had not much influence, the pessimists say. Can you give us one example where you changed your mind after talking to a European leader?And, Mrs. Merkel, there are actually few successes of the Quartet over the past time. Were the efforts so weak or are the problems so great that they simply have not been able to achieve progress? And what does this mean? What does this spell out for renewal of efforts? [SEP] I don't know if I'd call this change of mind, but one thing that my European friends have taught me is that the United Nations is an important body in order to be able to convince parliaments of hard work that needs to be done. For example, getting resolutions on at the United Nations is important for a country like Denmark or Holland, in order for them to go to their parliaments and say, We have U.N. approval.As you probably are aware, I've really never felt like the United States needs to get United Nations approval to make decisions necessary for our security. But I have come to realize that other countries do rely upon the United Nations, and I respect that a lot. So there's an area, for example, where I have been taught a lesson by my allies and friends.I listen to Angela Merkel a lot. She has got a lot of wisdom. I don't know if this helps her or hurts her for me to say this, but nevertheless, my consultations with Angela are very productive and very important.The United States needs to have good relations with Europe in order for us to achieve big objectives, whether it be trade or peace or security, it's—the relations between Europe and the United States are vital. And sometimes the relations are—can be difficult. Not every country agrees, throughout Europe. And yet Angela always gives me good advice as to how to deal with the common problems we face in order to make sure that our alliance works for the common good. And I appreciate that very much. I simply think that we ought to try time and again to achieve some sort of results in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Looking at another field, for example, the adoption of the resolution on Iran, after all, we were able, looking at the past months, to forge a uniform position of the international community and have that reflected in a resolution of the United Nations Security Council. I think that's an enormous success, although things went obviously more slowly than if the EU and the United States, for example, had negotiated together.But by including Russia and China time and again in these negotiations, what evolved out of that process is an international community that is credibly being able to show Iran where there is a redline. And I think it's essential to see that the European Union, the United States, China, and Russia need to pull in the same direction on a number of other international issues.And I think it's very important that that goes for the Quartet, for example, too, because that's where I think that we will be able to make—it's an ideal forum where we can actually be able to make a difference and in a coherent fashion.If that Quartet were to be more active, therefore, in the future, the Presidency and also the Commission would obviously also have to meet a very specific task in fulfilling that—its part of the mandate. We need to make it clear, particularly to the not so constructive parts of Hamas, that they cannot play us off each other—us, that is the EU and the United States—but that we pull in the same direction, that we move in concert.And I must say I am a strong believer in this multilateral effort in these international fora, because it shows clearly where the redline is to those who do not wish for democracy. And this is what we need to do, time and again make it clear to them where the limits are, where the redlines are. No back rubs. []
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. And President Erdogan: President Trump sent you a letter on October the 9th, urging you not to launch a military action into northern Syria. He said, quote: Don't be a tough guy. Don't be a fool. You ignored that letter, and you went ahead, and you launched a military action into northern Syria. Can you explain why you ignored the President's warning? [SEP] Well, this letter was re-presented to Mr. President this afternoon. And I've also underlined the fact that a terrorist such as Ferhat Abdi Sahin should not be considered as an interlocutor by a country such as the United States. And this individual, Ferhat Abdi Sahin, has been instrumental in the killings of hundreds of Turkish civilians, and he is a person labeled as like a son for the terrorist leader who is currently incarcerated in Turkey, Abdullah Öcalan.So a person like this should not be welcomed by a country such as the United States. And similarly, this person was welcomed by a country such as Russia. So it's very difficult for me to understand these when we're trying to fight terrorism on a global scale. If we're going to sustain our fight against terrorism in a healthy fashion, we need to be much more sensitive than we currently are. It happens to us today, and it will happen to somebody else tomorrow is a saying that goes in our language.We have also provided information and the document thereof to our interlocutors in the White House, including Mr. President. And I have also submitted a document produced by CIA, pointing out to the fact that this individual is a terrorist, to Mr. President.And, as I've said before, I have shared them with His Excellency, Mr. President. And we gave back the letter that we have received. President, please.[ spoke in English as follows.] For me?
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, you mentioned raising concerns about corruption with Prime Minister Najib. However, critics point to your own administration's ties to individuals with questionable financial dealings. How do you reconcile these apparent contradictions, and what steps are you taking to ensure ethical conduct within your own administration? [SEP] We hold everyone in my administration to the highest ethical standards. We are committed to transparency and accountability in all that we do. Any allegations of wrongdoing are taken seriously and investigated thoroughly. We are focused on serving the American people and delivering results. We're not going to be distracted by baseless attacks from the opposition.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, given the impending indictment of Prime Minister Netanyahu on corruption charges, do you have any message or thoughts you'd like to share with him? [SEP] Well, I just think he's been a great Prime Minister. And I don't know about his difficulty, but you're telling me something that, you know, the—people have been hearing about. But I don't know about that. I can say this: that he's done a great job as Prime Minister. He's tough, he's smart, he's strong. He is very defensive. His military has been built up a lot. They buy a lot of equipment from the United States, and they pay for it. Of course, we give them tremendous, as you know, subsidy, also. Four billion dollars is a lot each year. But they are—they've been very good. They've been incredible, actually, in many ways.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, the public is clearly confused about the government's response to the coronavirus, particularly regarding mask guidance and testing protocols. Despite this confusion, you've stated you're satisfied with your team. Why are you resistant to making changes at the CDC or other relevant agencies to improve clarity and consistency in messaging? [SEP] The evolving nature of the science is the primary driver of any perceived confusion. Scientists are constantly learning new information, which necessitates adjustments to recommendations. While the CDC's communication capabilities have been scrutinized, it's important to remember that the Director is a scientist, not a public relations expert. This is a novel virus, a completely new challenge. We're learning as we go, much like we did with polio. This is an ongoing process. Consider the remarkable speed with which we developed a vaccine that has saved countless lives. Did we get everything perfect? Of course not. But it's been an extraordinary achievement.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, you promised to close Guantanamo two years ago, but it's still open. What's the hold-up? [SEP] Clearly, we haven't gotten it closed. The primary reason for closing Guantanamo was to keep Americans safe. It's a key recruiting tool for terrorists. They use it in their online propaganda. I believe we can protect Americans and aggressively pursue terrorists. My administration has been very aggressive in that regard. Al Qaida is more weakened than they've been since 2001. Their funding and operations are diminished. It's important to uphold our values. Closing Guantanamo is about that. It's a symbol. We can house them somewhere else. I won't comment on a review I haven't received yet. We've been trying to put our fight against terrorists within a legal structure. The biggest problem is what to do with dangerous people who are enemies of the U.S., but are hard to try in court. Releasing them could endanger Americans. We need to ensure they have lawyers and can challenge their detention, but we can't release those who could harm us. Balancing security and our values is difficult. The more people remember what makes America special, the stronger we are. I don't want to lose that weapon.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, considering the Kurds' vital role in combating ISIS, what concrete measures will the US implement to support them outside of Syria? [SEP] We're looking at the situation, alright? We've started to look at it. But remember, the Kurds, they helped us big time with ISIS. Everyone knows that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering Mayor Bowser's recent directive for DC, which excludes federal properties, would you advocate for federal entities, including the White House and military bases, to adhere to similar guidelines? [SEP] A decision will be reached within the next day. The public will be informed of our decision once it is made.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, you're not ruling out prosecutions, but you're also not actively pursuing them? [SEP] My focus is on setting a new standard for transparency and accountability in government. We'll review any credible evidence of wrongdoing, but my main goal is to ensure that such mistakes don't happen again.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Afghanistan, when will our troops be withdrawn, and will you reverse the media ban on covering the return of our fallen? [SEP] First, let me express my condolences for the American service members who tragically lost their lives in Iraq today. Signing letters to the families of our fallen heroes is the most somber responsibility of this office. As for the media policy, we are currently reviewing it in consultation with the Department of Defense, so I cannot offer a definitive answer at this time. Afghanistan presents a complex challenge. While Iraq has seen progress, Afghanistan's government remains fragile, and the threat of the Taliban and Al Qaida persists. We require a concerted effort to eliminate their safe havens. General Petraeus and Special Envoy Holbrooke are conducting a thorough review and developing a regional approach. We must enhance coordination between our military, diplomatic, and development efforts, working closely with our allies. We must remember that this region served as the launching pad for the 9/11 attacks. We cannot allow Afghanistan to become a haven for terrorists. I cannot provide a specific timetable for withdrawal, but I assure you that we will not allow Al Qaida to operate with impunity.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But, Mr. President, do you believe in climate change? Do you believe in climate change? [SEP] At the same time—at the same time—you weren't called.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, the LGBTQ+ community is facing a barrage of attacks at the state level. Parents of transgender children are terrified. What specific federal actions are you prepared to take, beyond symbolic gestures, to protect these vulnerable families, and how do you respond to the argument that these are state matters? [SEP] First, let me say to those parents: I understand your fear, and I want you to know that this administration has your back. If you can get me their information, I will personally reach out. We've made progress – ending the ban on transgender troops, passing the Respect for Marriage Act – but this is a battle against prejudice that's far from over. What's happening is an appeal to fear, and it's ugly. It's wrong that someone can be fired for being gay, that violence against LGBTQ+ people is rising, that extreme politicians are targeting transgender children. These are our kids. They're our neighbors. It's cruel. We're announcing new initiatives: strengthening physical safety, addressing civil rights violations, expanding mental health support, and working to end LGBTQ+ homelessness. Congress needs to pass the Equality Act. LGBTQ+ Americans, especially children: you are loved, you are heard, and we will protect you. Now, concerning AI, it's a double-edged sword. We need guardrails, just like with climate change. We're working with other countries to mitigate the risks. The pace of change is rapid, and we need to act urgently. And now, if you'll excuse me, I'd like to call on the BBC.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Do you have a time? [SEP] I won't get into timing right now because Mr. Johnson is going to go ahead and do that review. Tamara Keith [National Public Radio].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Shanghai Media Group's inquiry about the timing of the next meeting, could you provide any insights into whether it's anticipated to occur soon or might be delayed? [SEP] Look, I wish I could give you a definitive answer, but the truth is, I'm not at liberty to say. It could be just around the corner, or it might be further down the line. Your guess is as good as mine. Naturally, I'd prefer it to be sooner rather than later, but there are no guarantees in this business.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Therefore, you're refusing to comment on the drone strikes in Yemen? [SEP] I'm not going to discuss any specifics regarding military actions. Ed Henry.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, are we aiming to simply degrade ISIS, or to utterly destroy them? Furthermore, is it realistic to expect the Free Syrian Army to achieve this in Syria, given the limitations of airstrikes? [SEP] The situation demands more than mere containment. We cannot allow an organization that wreaks such havoc to continue unchecked. Our objective must be the complete dismantling of ISIS. Consider the example of Al Qaeda: we pushed them back, systematically weakened their capabilities, constricted their operational space, and eliminated their leadership. Over time, their capacity to launch attacks diminished significantly. While remnants may persist, we will relentlessly pursue them. Our goal is to dismantle this network, preventing them from posing a threat to us. And I am encouraged by the unanimous support of our allies in this endeavor. We will not deploy U.S. ground troops in Syria. We must identify and empower effective partners on the ground. The moderate coalition presents a viable option. They have been outmatched, and we must bolster their capabilities. When U.S. forces and our allies apply pressure from the air, ground forces can achieve remarkable results. This strategy is evolving, and we are consulting with our partners. We will take whatever measures are necessary to ensure that ISIS does not threaten the United States or our allies.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the anticipated outcome of the House vote regarding Iraq, and considering your Press Secretary's expressed apprehension about the message being transmitted to our enemies, would you agree that a vote of disapproval serves to embolden them and undermine the efficacy of your policies? Moreover, what specific initiatives are you undertaking to dissuade the Democratic leadership in Congress from imposing limitations on your ability to allocate funds to the Iraq campaign? [SEP] Yes, thank you. A couple of points to address: Firstly, I recognize that Congress intends to express its opinion, and the position of the Democrats, along with some Republicans, is quite clear. I am aware that they disagree with the decision I have made. However, I want to emphasize that this does not imply any judgment on their character or patriotism; they simply hold a different perspective. I have considered their viewpoints, but I remain convinced that their approach would not lead to a nation capable of self-governance, sustainability, and alliance in the war on terror. Secondly, my hope is that this non-binding resolution does not transform into a binding policy that prevents our troops from carrying out the mission I have assigned to them. It is somewhat paradoxical that, on one hand, there is unanimous support for David Petraeus, yet on the other hand, there is reluctance to fund the very strategy he deemed necessary to his job, a strategy he presented before the Senate. I will make it abundantly clear to the Members of Congress, starting now, that they must provide adequate funding for our troops and ensure the necessary flexibility to accomplish the task at hand. Furthermore, I find it interesting that there is a condemnation of a plan that has not yet been given a chance to prove its effectiveness. Again, I understand; I understand. What was the other component of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, the communique emphasizes voluntary cooperation, not binding commitments. Realistically, how likely is it that nations with longstanding disagreements will now cooperate effectively, and how can this be enforced? [SEP] Consider Ukraine. For a decade, we've urged them to remove or convert their highly enriched uranium. This conference spurred them to act, committing to complete this soon. These commitments predate the communique, showing strong global consensus on this issue. We have international conventions, though some need ratification, including by the U.S., on nuclear terrorism and trafficking. This plan is ambitious. We're already seeing progress on issues delayed for years, even since the Cold War, finally materializing at this summit.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Some of your longtime advisers are leaving the White House, and new folks are coming in. Others are taking on new roles in the West Wing. As you reshape your team a bit, how does that change the dynamic here? And how does it impact what you think you can accomplish going forward? [SEP] I just had lunch with Pete Rouse, who is leaving me. And that's tough.
label: Dodging

sentence: Do we know the weapon type? [SEP] I am not privy to that information at this time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, the White House is pushing the NIH and FDA to expedite this, correct? [SEP] Well, if the numbers are as impressive as I'm hearing—and I'm hearing over 50 percent, which is fantastic. We've approved things at 31 percent, which is also acceptable. It's had a significant impact. But, honestly, you're telling me something new, and I'll look into it immediately.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Iran deal, critics suggest the 'negotiable implementation' clause is a loophole allowing Iran to avoid crucial concessions. Specifically, will you guarantee no inspections of military sites and no immediate lifting of sanctions upon signing? [SEP] Look, we've got a framework, alright? A strong framework agreed upon by Iran and the P5+1. Some things, like cutting down centrifuges at Natanz or changing Fordow, are locked in. Others are about what we *intend* to do, but the details matter, folks. And those details? They're gonna be negotiated, believe me. Nobody on my team ever said it's all done and dusted. We have a framework that, if we do it right, stops Iran from getting a nuke. But the details are key, and we'll fight for them. I said that from day one, and I stand by it. Remember the JPOA? Same back-and-forth. But we got a great deal, even the Israelis admit it worked. Now they want to keep it! As for Cuba, didn't get into those nitty-gritty details. The State Sponsor thing is coming to me. Congress gets a look too. The embassy? Cuba's probably nervous, hasn't dealt with us in a while. We're ready to go, though, for better talks and a better future for Cubans. And to our friends in Latin America, thank you. Panama, thank you. This region is amazing, and we're lucky to have you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with North Korea's continued nuclear development and China's assertive actions in the East and South China Seas, what concrete steps will the U.S., Japan, and South Korea take to ensure regional stability and prevent further escalation? [SEP] Let me tell you, we're taking this very seriously. North Korea is a major threat. We're working with Japan and South Korea to address it. As for China, we have concerns. But this summit, it was about our relationship, about deepening cooperation. We want a peaceful Indo-Pacific. It's a big deal, folks. A historic meeting. We're building a long-term structure. Believe me, it will have a phenomenal impact.
label: Dodging

sentence: Regarding criticism of your successor, sir? [SEP] Look, President Bush was incredibly gracious to me during the transition. My plan is to focus on finishing my job for the next two months. Afterwards, Michelle and I will take a vacation, get some rest, spend time with our daughters, and do some writing and thinking. I want to respect the office and give the President-elect space to present his platform without constant commentary. As an American citizen deeply invested in our country, if issues arise concerning our core values and ideals, beyond specific legislative details, and if I believe my voice is necessary, I'll consider it. But first, Michelle and I need that vacation.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, is Charlotte still under consideration as a potential destination? [SEP] We're exploring several options, and Charlotte is certainly on the list. We'll let you know as soon as a decision is made.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: On the topic of chemical weapons, do you possess intelligence suggesting Putin is poised to use them? And what military retaliation would the U.S. or NATO enact if he were to deploy them? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to share intelligence matters. Be that as it may, we would retaliate if he uses them. The form of retaliation would hinge on the specifics of their use.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And that was thumpin' without a g, correct? I just want to make sure we have it right for the transcript. [Laughter] You said you were surprised; you didn't see it coming; you were disappointed in the outcome. Does that indicate that after 6 years in the Oval Office, you're out of touch with America, for something like this kind of wave to come and you not expect it?And on a somewhat related note, does Nancy Pelosi look much like Bob Bullock to you? [SEP] [] That's an inside joke; I'm not commenting on it.Secondly, I'm an optimistic person, is what I am. And I knew we were going to lose seats; I just didn't know how many.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Where is your line in the sand? [SEP] Well, look, I've got a whole bunch of lines in the sand. Not making the tax cuts for the wealthy permanent--that was a line in the sand. Making sure that the things that most impact middle class families and low-income families, that those were preserved--that was a line in the sand. I would not have agreed to a deal, which, by the way, some in Congress were talking about, of just a 2-year extension on the Bush tax cuts and 1 year of unemployment insurance, but meanwhile all the other provisions, the earned-income tax credit or other important breaks for middle class families like the college tax credit, that those had gone away just because they had Obama's name attached to them instead of Bush's name attached to them.So this notion that somehow we are willing to compromise too much reminds me of the debate that we had during health care. This is the public option debate all over again. So I pass a signature piece of legislation where we finally get health care for all Americans, something that Democrats had been fighting for, for a hundred years, but because there was a provision in there that they didn't get that would have affected maybe a couple of million people, even though we got health insurance for 30 million people and the potential for lower premiums for a hundred million people, that somehow that was a sign of weakness and compromise.Now, if that's the standard by which we are measuring success or core principles, then let's face it, we will never get anything done. People will have the satisfaction of having a purist position and no victories for the American people. And we will be able to feel good about ourselves and sanctimonious about how pure our intentions are and how tough we are, and in the meantime, the American people are still seeing themselves not able to get health insurance because of preexisting conditions or not being able to pay their bills cause their unemployment insurance ran out.That can't be the measure of how we think about our public service. That can't be the measure of what it means to be a Democrat. This is a big, diverse country. Not everybody agrees with us. I know that shocks people. The New York Times editorial page does not permeate across all of America; neither does the Wall Street Journal editorial page. Most Americans, they're just trying to figure out how to go about their lives and how can we make sure that our elected officials are looking out for us. And that means, because it's a big, diverse country and people have a lot of complicated positions, it means that in order to get stuff done, we're going to compromise. This is why FDR, when he started Social Security, it only affected widows and orphans. You did not qualify. And yet now it is something that really helps a lot of people. When Medicare was started, it was a small program. It grew.Under the criteria that you just set out, each of those were betrayals of some abstract ideal. This country was founded on compromise. I couldn't go through the front door at this country's founding. And if we were really thinking about ideal positions, we wouldn't have a Union.So my job is to make sure that we have a north star out there. What is helping the American people live out their lives? What is giving them more opportunity? What is growing the economy? What is making us more competitive? And at any given juncture, there are going to be times where my preferred option, what I am absolutely positive is right, I can't get done.And so then my question is, does it make sense for me to tack a little bit this way or tack a little bit that way, because I'm keeping my eye on the long term and the long fight--not my day-to-day news cycle, but where am I going over the long term?And I don't think there's a single Democrat out there who, if they looked at where we started when I came into office and look at where we are now, would say that somehow we have not moved in the direction that I promised.Take a tally. Look at what I promised during the campaign. There's not a single thing that I've said that I would do that I have not either done or tried to do. And if I haven't gotten it done yet, I'm still trying to do it.And so the--to my Democratic friends, what I'd suggest is, let's make sure that we understand this is a long game. This is not a short game. And to my Republican friends, I would suggest--I think this is a good agreement, because I know that they're swallowing some things that they don't like as well, and I'm looking forward to seeing them on the field of competition over the next 2 years.Thanks very much everybody.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. So you haven't made the request yet? [SEP] Well, he hasn't asked me to make the request yet. And I don't intend to make the request unless he specifically asks me to make it.He is—you know, I've had my third conversation with him, and I genuinely mean what I say. I wish him all the very best. I have found him to be a very smart and engaging person. And that lunch the other day was interesting—to have two guys who are nearly 85, two 62-year-olders, and a 47-year-old—so kind of the classic generational statement.And one common area, in at least the four of us—we all had different circumstances and experiences, but one thing is we've all experienced what it means to assume the responsibility of the Presidency. And President-elect Obama is fixing to do that. And he'll get sworn in, and then they'll have the lunch and all the deal up there on Capitol Hill. And then he'll come back and go through the Inauguration, and then he'll walk in the Oval Office, and there will be a moment when the responsibilities of the President land squarely on his shoulders.Toby [Tabassum Zakaria, Reuters]. Yes, we'll get everybody here.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the exemption granted to the U.K. expiring at midnight tonight, and considering that 17 Schengen zone countries have fewer coronavirus cases, while the U.K. added 208 cases in the last 24 hours, why does the U.K. merit this exemption? Will you reconsider adding them to the travel ban list? [SEP] Well, I relied on the advice of experts on this one. We're closely monitoring the situation, especially given the recent surge in numbers. It's possible we may need to include them on the list, or perhaps even add a few others. Conversely, we might consider removing some countries as well. It's a fluid situation.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Concerning Afghanistan, what precise requests did you make regarding the situation and the U.S. troop deployment? [SEP] In fact, he brought up Afghanistan, hoping we could keep the peace. I told him it's largely up to him. He said he'd help with Afghanistan, but I won't get into details, and also with Iran and other things. We then told him what we wanted to do to bring stability and security to the people of Syria and Libya. That's what we talked about.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Bush, your administration's response to Hurricane Katrina was widely criticized for being slow and inadequate. What specific mistakes were made in the handling of the disaster, and what steps did you take to improve disaster preparedness and response capabilities in the aftermath? [SEP] Hurricane Katrina was a terrible tragedy, and we learned some important lessons from it. We worked hard to provide assistance to the victims, but there were clearly things we could have done better. We took steps to improve coordination between federal, state, and local agencies, and we invested in better disaster preparedness and response capabilities.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering your efforts to improve race relations during your presidency, what specific initiatives do you believe had the most tangible impact, and how do you think future generations will remember your administration's approach to these sensitive issues? [SEP] I'll leave the legacy assessments to the historians. What I focused on was leading the country through this issue. I wanted to get all of us to understand the difficult history of race and encourage people to listen to each other. The passage of the Civil Rights Act or my election didn't erase the legacy of slavery and Jim Crow. Things have improved, but we have more work to do. I tried to encourage practical solutions that can reduce racial bias. I hope my voice has been true and positive. It may not fix everything immediately, but it surfaces problems and allows us to wrestle with these issues. This perspective may lead to continued improvement so that future generations can experience a more just and equal country. It's not going to happen overnight. We plant seeds, and someone else may sit under the shade of the tree we planted. I'd like to think I have been true in speaking about these issues.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the proposed Oracle/TikTok agreement, are you prepared to give it your blessing, even if the Treasury Department doesn't see any financial benefit? Furthermore, does this deal adequately address your administration's national security concerns? [SEP] Well, they are currently providing me with comprehensive analyses of the proposed agreement. It is imperative that the agreement meets the highest standards of national security. As such, I am not yet prepared to grant my approval. I must first thoroughly examine the details of the deal. We require robust security measures, particularly in light of recent events. Security is paramount. I anticipate receiving a briefing on the matter tomorrow morning, at which point I will be in a position to provide you with an update.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering that three-quarters of the surge troops were deployed during the July report period, will you maintain the surge regardless of General Petraeus's assessment if Iraq fails to achieve substantial political progress by September? [SEP] With all due respect, that's a hypothetical scenario. I'm not going to engage in speculation. Let's wait for General Petraeus's report.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the situation with Russia and Ukraine, back in June, you expressed the belief that President Putin didn't desire a cold war. However, since then, we've witnessed a significant troop buildup near Ukraine, your Secretary of State has warned of a potential imminent invasion, and there have been cyber attacks alongside demands for a Russian sphere of influence. Do you still maintain that Putin doesn't want a cold war? Has your perspective on him shifted? And if he does invade, would you consider a return to a containment policy akin to what you experienced in the Senate? [SEP] Look, I still don't think he wants a full-blown war, let's be clear. Will he test the West, the US, NATO? Absolutely, he'll push as hard as he can. But mark my words, he'll pay a price, a steep one, that he's not anticipating right now. He'll regret it. Now, let's be frank, he sees the fall of the Soviet Union as a tragedy, the loss of empire, the near abroad gone, all that. But consider what he has: vast territory, resources, but he's stuck between China and the West. So, I'm not entirely sure he knows what he's going to do. My gut tells me he'll make a move. He feels he has to. And I've told him directly, he wants two guarantees: Ukraine never joins NATO, and no strategic weapons in Ukraine. We can talk about the second one, depending on his actions. The first one, well, we have treaties about choosing your alliances. But let's be real, Ukraine joining NATO anytime soon? Not likely, given their internal issues and the doubts of major Western allies. So, there's room to negotiate if he's willing. But he's going to push it, as usual. I probably shouldn't say more.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, reflecting on the past five years of conflict, what salient lessons will inform your approach during the remaining two years of your administration? [SEP] It is imperative that we analyze the shortcomings encountered. The sectarian violence within Baghdad has demonstrably impeded progress. It constitutes a significant challenge to our efforts to assist the Iraqi government in achieving stability. Our strategic planners are focused on mitigating this violence and empowering the Iraqis to suppress it. The conflict encompasses distinct theaters of operation. Baghdad, characterized by brutal sectarian strife, and the campaign against Sunni extremists. Progress is being made in that latter endeavor. Tensions also exist in the south, primarily of a Shi'a-on-Shi'a nature. However, the most formidable challenge remains within Baghdad. We have not achieved our desired level of progress in enabling the Iraqi government to effectively govern and defend itself. The attack on the Samarra mosque represented a deliberate attempt to incite sectarian discord. Success in Iraq necessitates a confluence of military, political, and reconstruction efforts. A parallel political process and a comprehensive reconstruction strategy must proceed concurrently with a revised military approach. We are critically evaluating areas where expectations were unmet and where outcomes diverged from our initial projections.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the recent turmoil in the financial sector, do you believe American banks are fundamentally sound? Furthermore, does the government's intervention with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac establish a precedent for future bailouts, potentially encouraging excessive risk-taking by large institutions? [SEP] Let's address Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac first. Many Americans may not fully grasp their significance to the mortgage market. It's crucial that people maintain confidence in these markets and that they remain stable. That's why Secretary Paulson unveiled a plan this past weekend, requesting authorization from Congress for a line of credit for these institutions, if necessary, and the authority to invest capital, if needed. The primary goal was to reassure everyone that we understand the importance of these institutions to the mortgage markets and to alleviate any anxieties. By outlining this plan, we actually reduce the likelihood of needing to use this authority in the first place, which, I want to emphasize, is only temporary. Now, regarding the banks, if you have a deposit in an American commercial bank, it's insured by the Federal Government up to $100,000. So, if you hear concerns about your bank's condition, depositors should understand that the FDIC is there to protect their deposits up to that amount. I recall witnessing a bank run in Midland, Texas, where someone was shouting, 'Your deposits are good! We've got you insured!' But people were still nervous. My hope is that people will take a breath and realize their deposits are protected. So, these are two distinct issues: the mortgage markets and the banking sector.
label: General

sentence: Q. And what about yourself and Congress? Would you abide by the same benefits package? [SEP] You know, I would be happy to abide by the same benefit package. I will just be honest with you: I'm the President of the United States, so I've got a doctor following me every minute—[]—which is why I say this is not about me. I've got the best health care in the world. I'm trying to make sure that everybody has good health care, and they don't right now.Lynn Sweet [Chicago Sun-Times].[] The President. Oh. [] Well, I said Steve Koff, but he [Steven Thomma, McClatchy Newspapers] just stood up, huh?

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to Canada, you've raised numerous points. Perhaps we could break them down individually? Which aspect of the relationship is most pressing in your view? [SEP] Wow, slow down! That's like five questions rolled into one. [] Remind me, which one do you want me to tackle first? []

sentence: President Duda, following your discussions with President Trump about potentially hosting a permanent American military base in Poland, could you share his immediate reaction and whether you currently have reservations about the state of U.S.-Russia relations? [SEP] Indeed, I discussed with Mr. President the various aspects of a permanent U.S. military presence in Poland. However, let me be clear: such bases should not be interpreted as a provocation that would lead to increased Russian aggression and militarization. Russia has been systematically militarizing areas like Kaliningrad for over a decade. From Georgia in 2008 to the annexation of Crimea, their actions speak for themselves. The U.S. presence is a guarantee of security and defense for our part of Europe, for the free world. We seek both U.S. and NATO forces to protect our interests. The President and his advisors will consider all factors, but the arguments for a U.S. presence are strong, given the ongoing violations of international law. Deterrence is the most effective way to prevent war. President Trump also mentioned Poland's willingness to contribute financially, reflecting his focus on burden-sharing. He believes wealthy nations should contribute to their defense, a point he's made repeatedly within NATO, resulting in increased contributions. We are considering this from both a military and cost perspective.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the alleged Chinese hacking of the Pentagon computers, how much more complex does this make the relationship with China? [SEP] Look, cyber vulnerabilities are a reality. The real question is, what are we doing to defend ourselves? Are we aware of the risks? Are we investing in the necessary expertise and technology? The answer is yes. We're addressing it.

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia and Ukraine, have you assessed whether President Putin intends to invade or further encroach upon Ukrainian territory?
