sentence: President Obama, in light of the congressional stalemate surrounding the Trans-Pacific Partnership, what contingency plans are in place to ensure its eventual passage, and is there room for negotiation regarding currency manipulation clauses? Furthermore, what implications does the recent targeted killing of Taliban leader Mullah Mansur have for the future of U.S. involvement in Afghanistan? [SEP] Look, on TPP, I've been doing this long enough to know that every trade deal is a dogfight. Everyone wants a better deal, and with so many countries involved, they're going to nitpick it, debate it to death, and in an election year, try to score some political points. That being said, I'm still optimistic we'll get it done, because it's the right thing to do. It's good for the country, good for America, good for the region, good for the whole world. This is the fastest-growing part of the globe, a huge market for the United States. Most of these countries already sell their stuff to us with relatively low tariffs. Meanwhile, tariffs are much higher for U.S. goods being sold over there. So a deal that eliminates 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods in the largest, fastest-growing markets is a no-brainer for American businesses and workers. One of the biggest complaints about trade deals historically has been that they open our markets to countries with lower wages, unfair labor practices, and weak environmental protections. But if you're signing up for TPP, you're making legally binding commitments to raise labor standards, give workers a voice, and address environmental problems. That gives us the opportunity to engage with countries like Vietnam and work with them on all those fronts. I haven't heard a single convincing argument that we'll be worse off with TPP. It's clear as day that we'll be better off. American workers and businesses will benefit if we get this deal passed. The politics will be messy, just like they were with the Korean, Colombian, and Panamanian free trade agreements. But we got those done, and we'll get this done too. Regarding currency manipulation, we've got provisions in TPP that improve transparency and reporting. Some people have argued that we should have enforceable rules that allow us to impose tariffs on countries that devalue their currency too much. But the problem is, it's really hard to figure out why a currency is going down and whether it's actually being manipulated. And frankly, forcing other countries to make commitments about their monetary policy would mean we'd be tying the hands of our own Federal Reserve, and we're not going to do that. We have strengthened the provisions that will allow us to put countries on notice that we think are engaging in competitive devaluations. Finally, about the Taliban leader, Mr. Mansur, it's been confirmed that he's dead. He was the guy calling the shots, specifically targeting U.S. personnel and troops in Afghanistan. This doesn't mean we're changing our strategy. We're not going back to day-to-day combat operations. Our job is to help Afghanistan secure its own country. But when we've got a high-profile leader who's been consistently involved in operations and plans to harm U.S. personnel and who's been blocking peace talks, then it's my responsibility as Commander in Chief to step in and send a clear message to the Taliban that we're going to protect our people. President Quang.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding TikTok, the Commerce Department has essentially provided you with a post-election window to finalize a deal. Do you anticipate resolving the TikTok situation before or after the upcoming election? [SEP] Well, things are progressing nicely. We're in talks with some fantastic companies, as you know. Oracle, Microsoft – they've all shown interest. We'll see if they're still at the table. And Walmart, a truly great American company, is very keen to get involved. So, we have several promising options. Hopefully, we can satisfy everyone while ensuring the security we need. We can't compromise on security, especially concerning China. But TikTok is undeniably a popular platform. If we can strike a balance, I'd be very pleased. The whole thing could move very quickly, very, very quickly.
label: General

sentence: Q. First of all, for you, Mr. President, the Saudis, in about 10 days, will be hosting a summit on oil prices and supplies. Prime Minister Gordon Brown has said that he will go to this. With four-dollar-a-gallon gasoline back home, would you go? [SEP] You know, I'm going to go back home and take a look at the intentions and purpose of the meeting. There will be a high-level official, for certain, from my administration. We ought to be at the table as producers. My call on Congress is to recognize the seriousness of the problem and pass law that encourages exploration for oil and gas in the United States so that down the road, an American President will go as a producer, not a consumer.And our policies frankly have been—are now coming home to roost. For 8 years, I have been saying to the Congress, we ought to be exploring in ANWR; we ought to be drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf. And the Democratically led Congress has prevented that from happening. And now the prices of gasoline are high, and the American people don't like it, and I can understand why they don't like it. In the interim term, we'll—we need to be finding more oil and gas. In the longer term, we ought be diversifying away from our reliance upon oil.And so yes, I'm interested in the meeting. I said it's an interesting idea. And I'm going to get home and take a look, and we'll send somebody high level there.Thank you. Thank you very much. And now to the Italian journalists. Firstly, we have a journalist from Channel One news, our Susanna Petruni.
label: Explicit

sentence: But how do you get him out? President Trump. Well, we'll have to see what happens, you know? I'm not bad at doing things. If you look at what I've done compared to what other people have done 160 days in, there's nobody even close, I don't believe. So let's see what happens. But this was an Obama disaster. And I think if I were President then, he would not have taken over Crimea. During the Obama administration, he essentially took over Crimea. I don't think he would have done that with me as President, John.Russia's Annexation of Crimea/North Korea  Q. You—I have a question for the Prime Minister. But if I could follow up, you have taken on many things, you say, you were left with by the Obama administration that you say that you have fixed. This is something that you inherited from the Obama administration: the occupation of Crimea. How do you fix it? [SEP] Look, we'll see what unfolds. It's a process, okay? If I had a magic bullet, I wouldn't be sharing it with you, because that's a strategic disadvantage. We'll see how it all plays out. But let's be clear, Crimea was a bad hand dealt to me. I also inherited North Korea, and we're making great progress. You saw the letter, right? No nuclear testing, no missile launches, no rocket launches. Some sites were dismantled. And we got our hostages back even before I left. Good things are happening, and there's a positive vibe. It's a process, probably a longer one than anyone wants, but I'm used to that. We haven't lifted the sanctions; they're having an impact. Crimea, though, that's something I inherited, John. Not much to say except we're looking at it, just like all the other messes I've taken over. I'm fixing them one by one. And I know how to do it, okay?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, I apologize, but could you please specify which international news organization you represent? [SEP] Who do you work for?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Compromise with two. Following mass shootings, there's often a lot of talk and little action. So I ask you today: What specific pieces of legislation or legislative framework will you propose to lawmakers following the Parkland shooting? [SEP] Well, we're going to do a lot, but we are going to be very strong on background checks. I've spoken with many of our people in Congress—our Senators, our Congressmen and women—and there's a movement on to get something done. We want to be very powerful on background checks.When we're dealing with the mentally ill, as we were in this last case—he was a very sick person and somebody that should have been nabbed. I guess they had 39 different occasions where they were able to see him or potentially see him. We want to be very powerful, very strong on background checks and especially as it pertains to the mentally ill. We're going to get rid of the bump stocks, and we're going to do certain other things.But one of the feelings that I have, and you probably heard me in a speech this morning—very, very important that we have offensive capability as well as defensive capability that's within the schools. Because when you have a gun-free zone, you're really inviting people to come in and do whatever you have to do and, oftentimes, get out.Now, I was the one that brought up the fact that these shootings, on average, last 3 minutes, and it takes anywhere from 6 to 10 minutes for the police to get to the site. And I want to have people in the building. And, in many cases, you have ex-marines and ex-Army and Navy and Air Force and Coast Guard—you have them in the building, and they can have concealed weapons and still be teachers, or they could be in the building in a different capacity.But we have to have offensive capability to take these people out rapidly before they can do this kind of damage. But we'll be putting in strong language having to do with the background checks, and that will take place very quickly.I spoke with Paul Ryan this morning, with Mitch McConnell, and people are looking to really energize. I know that you've had—this has been going on for a long time. Many, many years. And you've had people in my position, and they would mention things, but not a lot of things got done, obviously. We take it very seriously. We want to put an end to it.And if, by the way, the bad guy thinks that somebody is in this room with a weapon that's going to be pointed at him with live bullets, he's not even going into the school. It's the one way you're going to solve it. You're not going to solve it with gun-free spaces, because they'll get in there, and they're going to be the only one with a gun. So we need offensive capability, and we're going to be doing something about it. We're dealing with Congress right now.Thank you. Thank you.
label: Implicit

sentence: President, could you detail what you discussed with Prime Minister Najib regarding the corruption allegations? [SEP] On the refugee issue, the Paris attacks are still fresh in our minds. People are naturally concerned, and that's shaped policy. However, we must remember the rigorous vetting process refugees face, often taking up to two years. The House bill, while seemingly straightforward, could undermine the refugee program, hurting those who need it most. My 'values' comment was about the notion of favoring certain religions or fearing defenseless children. Regarding Prime Minister Najib, I generally avoid commenting on ongoing investigations, particularly in foreign nations. But I did emphasize the importance of transparency, accountability, and combating corruption, which are vital for development. I also stressed the role of civil society and a free press. Countries develop at different speeds, but these principles are essential. Myanmar's elections are a positive development, and we aim to support such progress through initiatives like the Open Government Partnership and TPP. Our goal is a world where people are treated fairly, with rule of law, transparency, and equal rights. These are American and universal values.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you specify which NATO allies have definitively committed to spending 2% of their GDP on defense, and what mechanisms are in place to ensure they follow through on these commitments? [SEP] Well, many are stepping up, really stepping up. They understand the importance of burden-sharing. Some are already at 2%, and others are working towards it. It's a process, a negotiation, but we're making great progress. They know they need to do it, and they will.
label: General

sentence: Q. ——economic environment. What do you think the future holds for that? Do you think the trend is a good one or a bad one? [SEP] I hope the trend is bad against protectionism. A disappointment— not a mistake, but a disappointment—was not getting the three trade bills out of Congress on Colombia, Panama, and South Korea. That was a disappointment. I actually thought we had a shot at one time, and then I was disappointed that they didn't move out of the House.And I am concerned about protectionism. In tough economic times, the temptation is to say, well, let's just throw up barriers and protect our own and not compete. That was the sentiment, by the way, that was in place during decent economic times. After all, we got CAFTA out of the Congress by one vote. And it would be a huge mistake if we become a protectionist nation.And that might be a good thing for the Bush Center to do at SMU, is to remind people about the benefits of free and fair trade: benefits for our own workers, benefits for workers overseas, and benefits when it comes to promoting development and helping lift people out of poverty, in particularly, third world countries. The best way to enhance economic growth in a third world country and to give people a chance to realize a better future is through trade. It's been proven; it's a fact. And I'm hopeful that the country doesn't slip into protectionist policy.April [April Ryan, American Urban Radio Networks], yes, ma'am.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Sir, in your estimation, is Hillary Clinton likely to be the nominee? [SEP] Excuse me?

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the impending House vote on Iraq and your Press Secretary's cautions about the message sent to our adversaries, do you believe a disapproval vote emboldens the enemy and undermines your policy implementation? Also, what are your efforts to persuade Democratic leaders against restricting your spending power in Iraq? [SEP] Well, I acknowledge that Congress will voice its opinion, and the Democrats' stance, along with some Republicans, is clear. They disagreed with my initial decision, but that doesn't mean they're unpatriotic—they just have a different opinion. I considered their views but felt they wouldn't lead to a nation capable of governing itself, sustaining itself, and being an ally in the war on terror. However, I hope this non-binding resolution doesn't become a binding policy that prevents our troops from doing what I've asked them to do. It's inconsistent to unanimously support David Petraeus and then refuse to fund the strategy he deemed necessary, as he testified before the Senate. I'm making it very clear to Congress, starting now, that they need to fund our troops and ensure we have the necessary flexibility to get the job done. Also, it's interesting to see a declaration against a plan that hasn't even been given a chance to work. Again, I understand. Now, what was the other part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, to follow up on mail-in voting, many states have successfully implemented it for years. What specific changes in Nevada's procedures make it uniquely vulnerable to fraud now? [SEP] These states that have been doing it for years, they're a disaster! Nobody knows what's going on. Nevada is the worst, they're sending ballots to dead people, to dogs, to cats, it's crazy! And the Democrats are behind it, they want to steal the election. It's a disgrace!

sentence: Sir, should the NHS be on the table during these negotiations? [SEP] What was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. ——a member of your Government appears upset enough tonight about the abolition of the 10p rate to consider resigning. Isn't it time for you to at least consider unraveling that particular change? [SEP] False, if you didn't hear me. Now, we got a great relationship. And it's—we're working on a variety of issues. Listen, our special relationship has been forged in common values in history, and we're making history together. And we're dealing with a lot of problems. The most severe problem, as far as I'm concerned, is the willingness of people to murder innocent people to achieve their political objectives. I mean, this is the fundamental threat facing civilization in the 21st century.And Prime Minister Brown sees the threat. I mean, he had to live through the threat. And so it's—our relationship is very special, and it's—I'm confident future Presidents will keep it that way. There's just such a uniqueness in the relationship. That's not to say you can't have other friends, and we do. But this is a unique relationship, truly is. And I value my personal friendship as well as our—the relationship between our countries.Look, if there wasn't a personal relationship, I wouldn't be inviting the man to a nice hamburger or something—[]—well done, I might add. I'm very proud to be here today to celebrate a special relationship. In 1941, Winston Churchill met Franklin Roosevelt and inaugurated what is the modern phase of that special relationship. And Churchill said at the time, Same language, same hymns. He said, Same ideals, same values, something big is happening. And what was big that happened was that never before has a relationship yielded so much in the 1940s against—in the fight against fascism and the cold war that then followed, where we worked together. In the fight against terrorism, we're—as Tony Blair said, we stand shoulder to shoulder with the American people and with And I continue to stand shoulder to shoulder with him in rooting out terrorism wherever we find it, in any part of the world which puts freedom, democracy, and justice at risk.And what I think is fascinating is that over the next few months, we will be developing that special relationship in new ways, a special relationship of peoples as well as of governments: more cooperation between our universities and more exchanges between young people in Britain and young people in America; more scientific cooperation; more cooperation in the fight against cancer, whether a joint project—the Human Genome Project—where we're working together; environmental action, where the institutes in Britain and America are agreeing this week to have more cooperation; and right across the board, as we take the English language, Britain and America, and make it a gift and then offer it to the rest of the world to make it possible for millions of people in different parts of the world to learn the English language.So this is a special relationship not just of governments, but of peoples. And I look forward to its enhancement at all levels in the years to come. And I will work as hard as President Bush to make that relationship as strong and as enduring for the future.You asked also about our economic policies. We have low inflation; therefore, we've brought down interest rates. We have low debt; therefore, we can afford to spend more.We've made a major tax reform. And you ask about the 10p rate. Let's not forget that this April, the tax rate in Britain, the basic rate of tax is going down from 22 pence to 20 pence. We've virtually doubled child benefit for families over the last 10 years and raised it again this year, and we'll raise it next year. We're raising the child tax credit. We've got a new winter allowance addition for pensioners so that they can meet the fuel bills. And every area where the 10p rate has affected people, whether it be low-paid workers or pensioners or whether it be families with children, we have acted to see that we could do the best by people in our country.Now, of course, a tax reform is a big thing, but when you're reducing the basic rate from 22 pence to 20 pence—the first time it's been achieved, the lowest tax rate, basic tax rate for 75 years—it is an important thing to do. And I'm satisfied that once people understand the scale of the good things that we have been able to do in reforming the tax system and making it bet-ter—and that we're tackling poverty, as they do in America, by introducing and increasing tax credits for the poorest people—then whatever questions people have about these changes can be answered.Yes, they're important changes. They move the British economy forward. We have just seen this week that despite all the world difficulties, we have the highest employment rates at any time in our history. We have lower unemployment than at any time for 30 years. We have more vacancies in the economy, and that, combined with low inflation, a stable economy, lower interest rates—as we've managed to achieve over the last few weeks—means that the British economy is well positioned to face the challenges of the future and will continue to be so.And my answer to people who say what is happening domestically is, we are taking the right long-term decisions for the British economy, whether it's on nuclear power or on housing or on planning or infrastructure. And of course, at some times, people ask questions about whether you're doing the right thing. But we will see these long-term changes through, and these are the right long-term changes for Britain and for the British people. You guys want to sit out here for the afternoon or—[]. Thank you, Mr. Prime Minister. Thank you very much. Yes. Thank you. Thank you.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, are you concerned that the Speaker's position is too precarious to ensure the passage of your agenda? [SEP] I have confidence in the Speaker's commitment to working with us. The rest is up to him and his caucus. I can't speak for them.

sentence: Sir, critics argue that any unilateral easing of sanctions would undermine the international pressure on Iran. How do you respond to that concern? Any adjustments to the sanctions regime will be carefully calibrated and contingent upon Iran meeting its obligations under a verifiable agreement. We are committed to ensuring that any deal serves the interests of the United States and our allies, and that Iran is held accountable for its commitments.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, the public is curious. After General Pace's statements regarding homosexuality, do you personally consider homosexuality to be immoral? sentence: Q. I'm wondering how much confidence does this give you to control the virus in the United States. And do you see the data China has been sharing with the United States has been helpful? They're really looking very good. We're very happy about that. We are sharing data, yes. In fact, we're sharing quite a bit of data, including the fact that some of our pharmaceutical companies are working over there right now with large groups of people.

sentence: Mr. President, to be frank, did President Biden acknowledge the spying incident and offer any form of apology or commitment to prevent future occurrences? [SEP] Look, we're talking. We're sharing information. The U.S. is looking into it. It's complicated, okay? We gotta wait and see what they find. We'll keep talking. Next question, please.

sentence: When NATO leaders convene in Chicago this May, do you anticipate an agreement on a transition strategy in Afghanistan? Furthermore, are you worried that the Koran burning incident and its aftermath might impede your ability to negotiate effectively with our partners? [SEP] Look, the transition policy, as you know, was hammered out and agreed upon in Lisbon. We've been sticking to that plan, which involves handing over more and more responsibility to the Afghans, with the aim of ending our combat role by the end of 2014. Our allies are on board with this, and that's still the plan. What we'll be doing at the NATO meeting, and in the next couple of years, is making sure that this transition isn't a sudden drop-off. We're talking about setting benchmarks and taking steps along the way, just like we did when we scaled back our involvement in Iraq. It needs to be gradual, so the Afghan security forces can build their capacity, and we can partner with them effectively. We also need to make sure the support structures are in place for the whole thing to work. Now, the Koran burning situation is a concern, no doubt about it. It highlights the challenges on the ground, and it underscores the need for us to transition. The violence directed at our people is unacceptable, and President Karzai has acknowledged that. But he's also keen to take on more responsibility, and we're going to find a way to make sure the Afghans feel their sovereignty is being respected and that they're taking a bigger role in their own security. That's in their interest, and it's in our interest. I'm confident we can pull this off, but it won't be a walk in the park. There will be bumps in the road, just like there were in Iraq.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. But not about the media, sir. But, sir, real quickly—not about the media, but what about with Congress? [SEP] Yes, please. Go ahead.

sentence: President Obama, regarding Chile, while you praise its economic management and democratic transition, some wounds from the Pinochet dictatorship remain open. Critics suggest the U.S. bears responsibility. Will the U.S. collaborate with investigations into Allende and Frei Montalva, and will you apologize for the U.S.'s role in the 70s? [SEP] Regarding cooperation with the Chilean government, we will certainly consider any requests for information about the past. It's important to know our history, and U.S.-Latin America relations have been rocky at times.However, while understanding our history is important, we shouldn't be trapped by it. Chile has made extraordinary progress in the last two decades, fully supported by the U.S.I can't speak to all past policies, but I can speak to the present and future. As President, I know our commitment to democracy, eradicating poverty, broad-based development, and open markets in Chile is firm. We strongly support the work of [Pinera] and [Bachelet].Again, we must learn from our history but not be trapped by it. We have many challenges now and in the future.

sentence: Mr. President, the travel restrictions from Europe remain a point of contention, especially when compared to the situation with Turkey. Given your administration's emphasis on data-driven decisions, what specific data points are preventing the lifting of the ban on European travelers? And what is your message to European businesses contemplating relocation due to these restrictions? [SEP] Look, it's a complex situation. We're constantly monitoring the data, and the COVID team is working diligently to assess the risks. The Chancellor raised this point directly, and I assured her that we're taking it seriously. We're aiming for a swift resolution, but we need to ensure any changes are based on sound science and won't jeopardize the progress we've made. I'll have a more definitive answer for you shortly. Now, if you'll excuse me...
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Are you at all uncomfortable that there could be different rules in different States, you know, and for somebody to make the argument that that's what we saw during segregation? [SEP] Chuck, I think what you're seeing is a profound recognition on the part of the American people that gays and lesbians and transgender persons are our brothers, our sisters, our children, our cousins, our friends, our coworkers, and that they've got to be treated like every other American. And I think that principle will win out. It's not going to be perfectly smooth, and it turns out that the President--I've discovered since I've been in this office--can't dictate precisely how this process moves. But I think we're moving in a direction of greater equality, and I think that's a good thing.Julianna [Julianna Goldberg, Bloomberg News]./Job Growth/Tax Reform/Trade/Boeing Company

sentence: Q. ——right now, with mostly unaccompanied minors. There are kids that are sleeping on floors. They are packed into these pods. I've spoken to lawyers who say that they—some of these children have not seen the sun in days. What's your reaction—what is your reaction to these images that have come out from that particular facility? Is what's happening inside acceptable to you? And when is this going to be fixed? [SEP] Is—that's a serious question, right?Is it acceptable to me? Come on. That's why we're going to be moving a thousand of those kids out quickly. That's why I got Fort Bliss opened up. That's why I've been working from the moment this started to happen to try to find additional access for children to be able to safely—not just children, but particularly children—to be able to safely be housed while we follow through on the rest of what's happening.That is totally unacceptable.Ken [Ken Thomas, Wall Street Journal].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, many are concerned about potential conflicts of interest arising from your continued involvement with your businesses. Can you assure the American people that your decisions are solely based on national interest, and not personal gain? [SEP] Look, that's a question that's been asked and answered many times. We're moving on.

sentence: Mr. President and Prime Minister, I have a two-part question. First, did you discuss Canada potentially increasing its economic stimulus? Second, what are your predictions for the Canada-U.S. relationship in four years, specifically regarding the auto sector, border regulations, and the implementation of a carbon market? [SEP] You've managed to pack an impressive number of questions into that one. Did you coordinate with someone beforehand?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. There are some people that say that now the Republican Party is seen as supporting White nationalists because of your rhetoric. What do you make of that? [SEP] Oh, I don't believe that. I don't believe that.I don't believe—well, I don't know. Why do I have my highest poll numbers ever with African Americans? Why do I have among the highest poll numbers with African Americans? I mean, why do I have my highest poll numbers? That's such a racist question.Honestly, I mean, I know you have it written down, and you're going to tell me. Let me tell you: That's a racist question.

sentence: Mr. President, what is your response to the reports that Iran is close to developing nuclear weapons? [SEP] I see what you're doing there. I'm not going to give you a soundbite on that. Appreciate the effort, though.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Given your emphasis on state sovereignty as a fundamental principle of international relations, how do you reconcile this with the 'responsibility to protect' doctrine, which was previously considered essential for safeguarding vulnerable populations? [SEP] Excuse me, how do I reconcile that with the responsibility to protect, which used to be what?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. So Republicans and Democrats on Capitol Hill have both said they want to see more money for testing. They want to send billions of dollars to the States so they can do more testing. And you probably saw Mick Mulvaney the other day said that his kids, it took them a week to get test results back. He said this is simply inexcusable given where we are in the pandemic. Do you think we have a problem with testing in this country right now? And are you in favor of more money for testing? [SEP] Well, we've done more testing, by far, than anybody. Some of the tests—because it is massive volume—it takes longer. Others of the tests, as you know, are very quick; they're 5 minutes and 15-minute tests. And those are, frankly, the ones that I prefer.But we're doing massive numbers, and the numbers are coming down. And as we go, as an example, there are thousands and thousands of kits being made right now which give you a 15-minute and a 5-minute test. So we'll be able to get those numbers down. Those numbers are similar in other places. They're also doing massive numbers, numbers like nobody thought possible. But those numbers will be coming down. I agree. I think it's a good thing if we can do that.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, you seem to have shifted your stance since earlier this week, when you suggested the current Brexit plan would hinder a trade deal with the U.K. Given our 'special relationship,' is publicly criticizing the Prime Minister's policy and her personally the behavior of a friend? [SEP] Well, I didn't criticize the Prime Minister. I have great respect for her. There was a story that didn't include my positive comments. We record these things now, so we have proof. It's called fake news. The Prime Minister will decide what to do. I just hope we can trade without restrictions, as we're their biggest partner. We could double or triple that. If they go a different route, I hope they can still trade with us. I believe it's possible after speaking with their representatives. Trade is a bit tricky, but I think we'll manage. And she's doing a terrific job.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Is there a particular outcome that you would look for from this initial talk to judge whether you think things are going well? The President. Well, I think the minimum would be relationship. You'd start at least a dialogue. Because, you know, as a deal person, I've done very well with deals. What you want to do is start that. Now, I'd like to accomplish more than that. But at a minimum, I do believe, at least, we'll have met each other. We will have seen each other. Hopefully, we will have liked each other, and we'll start that process.So I would say that would be the minimal. And the maximum, I think you know the answer to that. But I think that will take a little bit of time.Okay? Yes.North Korea  Q. How long do you think that it will take you to figure out whether he's serious about giving up his—[inaudible]? [SEP] That's a good question. How long will it take? I think within the first minute I'll know.
label: General

sentence: With more and more soldiers facing multiple tours in Iraq and reports of dwindling morale, an infantry commander shared that troops are increasingly questioning their mission. Is this surprising? Are you aware? Is this a widespread feeling, and are you concerned? [SEP] The word from the top brass is that the families are the ones feeling the strain. Our soldiers, who signed up to serve, are ready to head back into the fight, but their loved ones are having a tough time. I get that, and that's why I always make sure to thank them. You've been talking to some folks, maybe just one. I'm talking to the guys in charge. Their job is to tell me what's going on out there. I know there are worries back home. I haven't heard any big complaints about morale from the troops in Iraq.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, considering the precipitous decline in housing starts, to what extent are you apprehensive about the potential for this housing recession to propagate throughout the broader economic landscape, and what supplementary interventions are being contemplated to forestall such a contagion? [SEP] I am encouraged by the prevailing inflation rate and the sustained growth in employment figures. We have achieved a record-breaking sequence of consecutive months of job creation, and our fiscal deficit is demonstrably contracting. However, I readily acknowledge the current softness within the housing market. Our Gross Domestic Product growth is attributable, in significant measure, to export activity, which underscores the existence of positive elements within our economic framework. The central question before us is how best to assist homeowners. I do not advocate for the provision of bailouts to lending institutions; rather, we must implement policies that empower individuals to retain ownership of their homes. The FHA modernization bill is of paramount importance in this regard, as it will broaden the reach of the FHA and facilitate refinancing opportunities for a greater number of citizens. The securitization of mortgages has engendered complexities in accessing refinancing assistance. We must endeavor to enhance public understanding of mortgage instruments and streamline the refinancing process. Secretaries Paulson and Jackson are actively collaborating with the private sector to address these challenges. Furthermore, we must reform the tax code to eliminate the disincentive associated with refinancing. Ultimately, market forces will dictate equilibrium as the supply of housing adjusts to meet demand. While I refrain from engaging in economic forecasting, I maintain a positive outlook on the overall economic indicators, while remaining vigilant with respect to the housing sector.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to Afghanistan, when can the American people anticipate the return of our troops, and will you overturn the media ban on covering the return of our fallen soldiers? [SEP] First and foremost, let me extend my heartfelt condolences to the families of the American service members who tragically lost their lives in Iraq today. The signing of letters to the families of our fallen heroes is the most somber and humbling responsibility of this office. Concerning the media policy, we are currently undertaking a comprehensive review in close consultation with the Department of Defense, and I am therefore unable to provide a definitive answer at this juncture. Afghanistan presents a complex and multifaceted challenge that demands our unwavering attention. While Iraq has demonstrated notable progress, Afghanistan's government remains fragile, and the persistent threat of the Taliban and Al Qaida continues to loom large. We require a concerted and comprehensive effort to eliminate their safe havens and ensure the long-term stability of the region. General Petraeus and Special Envoy Holbrooke are diligently conducting a thorough review and developing a comprehensive regional approach. We must enhance coordination between our military, diplomatic, and development efforts, working in close collaboration with our valued allies. It is imperative that we never forget that this region served as the launching pad for the devastating 9/11 attacks. We cannot and will not allow Afghanistan to become a haven for terrorists who seek to harm our nation. While I am unable to provide a specific timetable for withdrawal at this time, I can assure you that we will not allow Al Qaida to operate with impunity and threaten the security of the United States of America.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, are you planning a direct meeting with Iranian officials to discuss these matters? [SEP] The core question, as I understand it, is whether a direct engagement with Iranian counterparts is on the horizon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your policies have alienated minority communities. How do you reconcile this criticism with the positive economic indicators you cite, and what specific steps are you taking to address concerns about social justice and equality? [SEP] The numbers don't lie. African American, Hispanic American, Asian American employment is at an all-time high. We're creating jobs and opportunities for everyone. The polls reflect that. People are seeing the results of our policies. As far as social justice and equality, we are working every day to ensure that all Americans have the chance to succeed. We are working with the states to provide them with the resources needed to restore order.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Lesley, to be blunt, about Cuba, did Fidel Castro have any involvement in the talks, and are you prepared to fight Congress on the embargo? [SEP] I'm going to have to cut you off there, Lesley. We have other important matters to discuss.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are there steps your administration can take now to build confidence that the U.S. will, in fact, meet its deficit reduction targets in the medium and long term? [SEP] I'm sorry. Could you repeat the question? Put the mike a little closer to you.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, following North Korea's recent ballistic missile tests, what tangible actions will the United States undertake, and what constitutes an absolute red line regarding North Korea's nuclear program? [SEP] First and foremost, those missile tests were a clear breach of UN Resolution 1718. We are actively consulting with our partners and allies. Should they opt for further escalation, our response will be proportionate. However, I am also prepared to engage in diplomacy, provided that the ultimate objective is the complete and verifiable denuclearization of North Korea. That is our current focus as we consult with our allies.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea's potential nuclear test, can you detail your conversations with President Xi on this? How much influence does China wield over North Korea, and what repercussions would a test have on U.S.-China relations? [SEP] Look, it's tough to say definitively how much control China has. I've made it plain to President Xi that they should discourage North Korea from these tests. And I've also stated that if North Korea proceeds, we'll take defensive measures. These aren't against China, but they'll send a message to North Korea. We'll protect our allies and ourselves. Whether China can stop them, I don't know. But I'm sure China doesn't want escalation. I've been clear we'll defend ourselves and allies like South Korea and Japan. This might create friction with China, but it's about North Korea's actions. We have teams working with their Chinese counterparts. We won't solve everything, but I don't see a new Cold War. I want to be clear with Xi Jinping that I mean what I say. Misunderstandings are the biggest danger. The meeting was long, we covered a lot. He was direct. Understanding each other is key. I think you all are going to swim after this.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, looking back at your time in the Oval Office, what was the most challenging aspect of adjusting to the role of President, and did you offer any advice on this to President-elect Trump? [SEP] It took me a while to get my bearings, that's for sure. This job is truly unique. It's a non-stop flow of information and problems, even more so today because of how connected the world is. Things that used to be isolated now have global effects almost instantly. The speed of information and the need to react quickly are unlike anything else. I shared these thoughts with the President-elect, stressing the importance of having the right people around you, especially the Chief of Staff, National Security Advisor, and White House Counsel. You need a good system for getting information and making choices. I've been lucky to have an amazing team, which has helped me make good decisions. I also talked about the need for unity and representing everyone, like he said on election night. His first actions and how he comes across will be key in setting the tone for his presidency. After a tough election, gestures matter. Reaching out to those who didn't support him and listening to their concerns can help bring the country together.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. The election of two Muslim women, one veiled, to the House is historic. Do you see this as a rejection of your message? [SEP] I'm not quite following. Could you repeat that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. I'm a reporter from South Korea, and I appreciate your effort to advance denuclearization in Korean Peninsula. And could you elaborate on the options and the various ways that you discussed with Chairman Kim to advance denuclearization? Could you specify? [SEP] We discussed many ways. And the denuclearization is a very important—it's a very important word. Become a very well used word. And a lot of people don't know what it means, but to me it's pretty obvious: We have to get rid of the nukes.I think he's got a chance to have one of the most successful countries—rapidly, too—on Earth. Incredible country, incredible location. You're right between—if you think of it, you have, on one side, Russia and , and on the other, you have , and you're surrounded by water and among the most beautiful shorelines in the world.There is tremendous potential in North Korea, and I think he's going to lead it to a very important thing, economically. I think it's going to be an absolute economic power.Yes. Go ahead. Please. Go ahead. Yes.
label: Deflection

sentence: Are you suggesting the temperature isn't rising? [SEP] I'm keen to hear President Putin's take on their recent discussion. My main interest lies in whether he continues to share my concerns. Back in Australia, he reiterated that it's not in the world's interest for Iran to possess nuclear weapons. They've been helpful at the UN, and we're collaborating on a potential third resolution. That's where my focus is. I'm not concerned about the photos. I understand the purpose of their meeting. I'll continue to work with Russia and other nations to send a clear message that Iran will face isolation if it persists with its nuclear ambitions.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given the recent events in Afghanistan, is it accurate to say the war is concluded and the Taliban is now in control? And concerning Congressman Ratcliffe, could you address the prior concerns that led to his initial withdrawal from consideration? [SEP] Look, Ratcliffe is a great guy, a real asset. People leave, people go. As for Afghanistan, it's been a long road. We're working with everyone to find the best path forward. The Taliban has made commitments, and we're holding them accountable. It's a complex situation, but we're doing everything we can to ensure a stable and secure future for the region.
label: General

sentence: Given Senator McConnell's recent statement regarding the CARES II package, specifically its exclusion of your proposed payroll tax cut, do you still believe the package is optimally designed to address the current crisis phase? [SEP] Well, ideally, yes, a payroll tax cut would be beneficial for working families. However, securing Democratic support for such a measure proved unattainable. It seems their priorities lie elsewhere. Therefore, while I advocated for its inclusion, the reality of the political landscape necessitates compromise. We must proceed with what is achievable, while remaining open to future opportunities to address the needs of the American worker. So, in a pragmatic sense, yes, it's tailored to what we can realistically achieve at this moment.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, during these debt negotiations, would you consider tax breaks to stimulate the economy, even if they increase the deficit? Also, regarding same-sex marriage, since many states are moving towards it, do you personally support it, regardless of state decisions? [SEP] I won't be making any announcements on that front today. Nice try, though.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Are American oil producers tapping all sources, including offshore? Will you sign an interim agreement with Prime Minister Maliki on American operations in Iraq, leaving a permanent agreement to your successor? [SEP] We are working on a strategic framework agreement with Iraq covering diplomacy, economics, and justice. This includes a security agreement. They want a timeline for transitioning to 'overwatch,' where the US provides training, logistics, and special ops. For our troops to be there, we need an understanding with the Iraqi government. We're negotiating that now, and it needs to be done by year's end unless the UN mandate is extended.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, do you anticipate any significant economic changes before your term concludes? [SEP] While I'd like to see immediate improvements, I'm realistic about the pace of change. The economy is growing, though financial uncertainty persists. People need assurance that their bank deposits are insured. It's a period of uncertainty, with numerous events unfolding simultaneously. However, we can enact legislation to expedite the recovery, such as housing legislation. Congress needs to act. Another signal would be to explore domestic oil production. While we transition away from hydrocarbons, we should wisely utilize our resources. A concerted effort to develop oil shale reserves would relieve pressure on gasoline prices. Furthermore, we haven't built a new refinery in decades, which is nonsensical. Permitting is incredibly difficult, discouraging investment. We import a significant amount of refined product. We can also promote trade. The decision on the Colombia free trade agreement is baffling. Colombia enjoys preferential treatment, yet we don't receive the same. Our exports have supported the economy, so expanding trade opportunities makes sense. Turning our back on a courageous ally like Uribe is senseless. Politics is hindering progress. We should also pursue free trade agreements with Panama and South Korea. It's in our national interest.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the recently announced oil price cap by the G-7, aimed at addressing the elevated gasoline prices affecting American drivers, are you certain this measure will provide tangible relief at the gas pump? And what's a realistic timeline for American consumers to see a decrease in prices due to this war? [SEP] I didn't quite catch the first part of your question. Could you please repeat it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, can you outline the potential military repercussions for North Korea if it reneges on its promises? Could military intervention be a possibility? [SEP] Well, I don't want to talk about—yes, I know. That's a tough thing to talk about because I don't want to be threatening. I don't want to be threatening. They understood that. And you've seen what was, perhaps, going to happen.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning North Korea's denuclearization pledge, what mechanisms are in place to verify their compliance and prevent them from simply paying lip service to the agreement? [SEP] Let me be clear: we're going to have a very robust verification process. The best verification process. But can I guarantee 100% that they won't try to cheat? No. Nobody can guarantee that. What I can tell you is that we have the smartest people working on this, and we're going to do everything we can to make sure they live up to their commitments. It's going to be a great deal, a tremendous deal, for the world.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. You raised this: transparency on the coronavirus origins? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Do you believe that a deal could have been reached without Israel's agreement to temporarily suspend annexation? [SEP] Could you say that again, please?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, looking ahead a year, is it your assessment that Assad will still be in control of Syria? [SEP] The cessation of bloodshed and a nonsectarian path forward for Syria hinges on Assad's departure. He's lost the confidence of a significant portion of the population. The question is, how do we construct a political bridge that ensures the equities of Assad's allies – Russia and Iran – are respected, and that minorities like the Alawites are protected? That's the crux of the matter. If Assad had made a different choice earlier, prioritizing his country over himself, this transition would be far easier. Now, it's more complicated. However, John Kerry is making excellent progress. The Russians, after some time, are realizing that their deployment isn't significantly changing the situation. As I anticipated, bombing alone can't quell a nation when its people are so opposed to their leader.
label: General

sentence: With all the talk about Chavez, Mr. President, could you clarify if you believe his regional influence is being overstated or not? [SEP] My opinion is on what subject?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, beyond Huawei, are there any other Chinese tech firms facing potential bans in the U.S.? [SEP] Well, look, Huawei is the main concern, right? They're not operating here, and I've made that clear. I've also warned European countries and others about using their technology, even telling some that intelligence sharing would be affected. Many have since reconsidered. Take the U.K., for example; they seemed to be leaning towards Huawei, but now they've backed away.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, Director Clapper's assessment seems to contradict your stated policy. Are you saying his assessment was purely technical and doesn't reflect the administration's actual expectations for Libya's future? [SEP] Look, the Director's job is to provide the best intelligence available. My job is to make policy based on that intelligence and our values. We believe Qadhafi's days are numbered, regardless of his current military capabilities. We're focused on the long game here.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, after a year of divided government, you initially expressed optimism about finding common ground with Democrats. However, your remarks today suggest a less positive outlook. How would you assess your own efforts to work with Democrats this past year? How effective have you been in achieving bipartisan cooperation, and do you believe you've succeeded in finding common ground? [SEP] We're finding common ground on Iraq. I recognize there are people in Congress that say we shouldn't have been there in the first place. But it sounds to me as if the debate has shifted, that General Petraeus and Ambassador Crocker's testimony made a difference to a lot of Members. I hope we continue to find ground by making sure our troops get funded. We found common ground on FISA. My only question is, why change a good law? The way that law was written works for the security of the country. That's what the American people want to know, by the way. Are we passing laws that are beneficial to the American people? This law is beneficial because it enables our intelligence experts to find out the intentions of Al Qaida. Now, the law needs to be changed, enhanced by providing the phone companies that allegedly helped us with liability protection. So we found common ground there. Hopefully, we can find common ground as the Congress begins to move pieces of legislation. The reason I said what I said today is, there's a lot to be done. As you recognize, I'm not a member of the legislative branch; probably wouldn't be a very good legislator. But as the head of the executive branch, it makes sense to call upon Congress to show progress and get results. It's hard to find common ground unless important bills are moving. They're not even moving. And not one appropriations bill has made it to my desk. How can you find common ground when there's no appropriations process? We found common ground on a trade bill--trade bills, really important pieces of legislation, as far as I'm concerned. One of the reasons why is, exports helped us overcome the weakness in the housing market last quarter. If that's the case, it seems like it makes sense to continue and open up markets to goods and services. And yet there hadn't been one--there haven't been any bills moving when it comes to trade. Veterans Affairs is an area where we can find common ground. I've called in--I asked Bob Dole and Donna Shalala to lead an important Commission, a Commission to make sure our veterans get the benefits they deserve. I was concerned about bureaucratic delay and the--concerned about a system that had been in place for years, but this didn't recognize this different nature--a different kind of war that we're fighting. I don't like it when I meet wives who are sitting by--beside their husbands' bed in Walter Reed and not being supported by its Government, not being helped to provide care. I'm concerned about PTSD, and I want people to focus on PTSD. And so we sent up a bill, and I hope they move on it quickly. There's a place where we can find common ground.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, could Charlotte be the destination? [SEP] We're weighing several locations. The decision will be revealed shortly.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with Republicans poised to challenge your executive action through funding restrictions, what mechanisms will you employ to guarantee its potency? And has your estimate of those affected shifted to 2 million or higher? [SEP] The executive action is designed to be resilient. The details will be forthcoming, and I'm confident we'll have the means to implement it effectively. As for the numbers, we're still assessing the situation.

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the location chosen for your Presidential library, funding is now a key issue. Reports suggest a fundraising target of $200 million. Can you confirm this figure? Furthermore, do you believe the American public has a right to know the identities of such significant donors to a sitting President? Will you commit to disclosing contributions as they are received, and will there be any limitations on donor types or donation amounts? [SEP] Look, let's be clear. First, the budget is still being finalized. Second, as the foundation chairman, Donnie Evans, has stated, we'll adhere to all disclosure requirements. However, some donors prefer anonymity, which we'll respect. Third, what was the other part of your multi-part question? It was a real doozy.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding preemptive pardons for your administration officials involved in, say, enhanced interrogation or the dismissal of U.S. Attorneys, is this something you've considered, and can we expect such actions? [SEP] Let me be unequivocal: the topic of pardons is not on the agenda for discussion in this forum.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, about that conversation, is there a transcript available? [SEP] You know, I'm not sure if a full transcript exists. Maybe someone took notes? If you find something, bring it to my attention.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you. I'd just ask what do you say to those critics who argue you're trying to sow distrust in democracy and deliberately trying to sabotage the Post Office—to undermining mail-in voting, which a lot of people need? [SEP] Yes. I say the Democrats are sabotaging the Post Office because they're not approving $25 billion that was requested. So they're sabotaging the Post Office and they're not allowing the Post Office to function properly and they're certainly not allowing universal mail-in votes if—when they do that.But equally importantly they're not allowing $3.5 billion in funds to do voting that they'd like to do. Therefore all of this—and all of the tremendous mistakes that were made with regard to mail-in voting—all of these tremendous mistakes you can't even—you can't even do it. I would imagine the courts—you know this is in many courts right now. They're showing all of the disasters that have taken place just in the last short period of time—in the last 2 months—with respect to universal mail-in voting. It's just like a total catastrophe what's happening. And we can't let that happen.Go ahead real fast. Go ahead.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. On North Korea, did you discuss nuclear site inspections? [SEP] Speak up, please. And what news organization are you with?
label: Clarification

sentence: Given your past associations, do you anticipate Ghislaine Maxwell's testimony implicating other prominent individuals? [SEP] I haven't been following the case closely. I simply hope for the best for her. I knew her from Palm Beach, but I'm not familiar with the details of the Prince Andrew situation.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Regarding the progress of Asian countries, when can we anticipate an announcement about easing restrictions, and what metrics are being used to assess their progress? [SEP] Well, some are doing well, some aren't, as you know. But some are making progress. When they get to the right number, we'll be opening it up. Some are moving very fast. We hope to open things up as soon as possible. Go ahead.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Do you believe the recent election signifies a return to decency and a break from the divisiveness of the past few years, or is the 'fever' still lingering among a significant portion of the Republican Party? [SEP] Well, the super-mega-MAGA Republicans, I don't think we'll break the fever for them. But they're a minority. Most Republicans are decent, honorable people. We disagree on issues, but they're honest and straightforward. I worked with them for years. The world is watching us. At the first G-7 meeting, after I was elected, I said, 'America is back.' And someone asked, 'For how long?' They're concerned about our stability, whether we're still the democracy we've always been, whether our institutions matter.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, President Funes.Mr. President, on Libya, coalition partners can't seem to agree on who will take the lead in the next phase of the military campaign. Can you today still assure the American people that the U.S. will be in charge for only a matter of several--a few more days?And also, we also learned today of two American pilots who went down in Libya. We're assured that they're safe. But have you sufficiently prepared the American people for the costs of war--of course, the human costs, but also the financial costs? [SEP] Let me first of all say, obviously, we were extraordinarily relieved to find out that these two young men were safe in American hands. As the Pentagon indicated, this appears to have been a malfunction in the aircraft, and it is a testament to our military that we had fully prepared for any contingency, including something like this, and they were able to recover these individuals rapidly.And in fact, as part of the planning effort leading up to this, I specifically had discussions with Admiral Mullen and other of our military personnel to make sure that we had the kind of standard recovery efforts in place, because there are risks involved. And on the day that I indicated that this was a possibility, and then on the day that I indicated that we, in fact, were moving forward, I said that there is no military operation that does not entail risk. And that's why this is always the most difficult decision that I make as Commander in Chief and as President of the United States.Now, I have absolutely no doubt that we will be able to transfer control of this operation to an international coalition. I had discussions with Prime Minister Cameron and President Sarkozy today. In fact, NATO is meeting today as we speak to work out some of the mechanisms for command and control. I would expect that over the next several days you will have clarity and a meeting of the minds of all those who are participating in the process.We're already seeing a significant reduction in the number of U.S. planes that are involved in operations over Libya, because, as I said initially, our job was to take our unique capabilities and create a space to shape the environment so that the operation of a no-fly zone could operate effectively and to make sure that our immediate humanitarian goals could be met.And I just want to emphasize to the American people, because of the extraordinary capabilities and valor of our men and women in uniform, we have already saved lives. In Benghazi, a city of 700,000 people, you had the prospect of Qadhafi's forces carrying out his orders to show no mercy. That could have resulted in catastrophe in that town. Qadhafi's forces have pulled back because of this timely intervention.And obviously, there are always risks involved in this kind of operation, but for us to be able to structure something where we bring our unique capabilities to bear to fulfill a mission that is supported by the international community against somebody who was about to direct his armed forces against his people in the most vicious of ways is something that, I think, the American people, and certainly our American military, should be proud of.I said at the outset that this was going to be a matter of days and not weeks. And there's nothing based on how we've been able to execute over the last several days that changes that assessment.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, critics argue the timing of the Puerto Rico aid package is politically motivated, coming so close to the election. How do you respond? [SEP] The timing is dictated by when we could finally get the Democrats to stop obstructing. They don't want to see Puerto Rico succeed, plain and simple. But we persevered. This package is huge, it's fantastic, but what I'm most proud of is that we're bringing back the pharmaceutical companies. They were destroyed by bad tax policy, and we're going to make Puerto Rico great again!
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, thank you. You acknowledged that this is a message election on the war in Iraq. And so the American public today, having voted, will want to know what you mean, in terms of course correction on Iraq. And particularly in light of this fact, that last week the Vice President pointed out that you and he aren't running for anything anymore, and that it's full speed ahead on Iraq. So which is it? Are you listening to the voters, or are you listening to the Vice President? And what does that mean? [SEP] David, I believe Iraq had a lot to do with the election, but I believe there was other factors as well. People want their Congressmen to be honest and ethical. So in some races, that was the primary factor. There were different factors that determined the outcome of different races, but no question, Iraq was on people's minds. And as you have just learned, I am making a change at the Secretary of Defense to bring a fresh perspective as to how to achieve something I think most Americans want, which is a victory.We will work with Members of Congress; we will work with the Baker-Hamilton commission. My point is, is that while we have been adjusting, we will continue to adjust to achieve the objective. And I believe that's what the American people want.Somehow it seeped in their conscious that my attitude was just simply, stay the course. Stay the course means, let's get the job done, but it doesn't mean staying stuck on a strategy or tactics that may not be working. So perhaps I need to do a better job of explaining that we're constantly adjusting. And so there's fresh perspective—so what the American people hear today is, we're constantly looking for fresh perspective.But what's also important for the American people to understand is that if we were to leave before the job is done, the country becomes more at risk. That's what the Vice President was saying. He said, If the job is not complete, Al Qaida will have safe haven from which to launch attacks. These radicals and extremists have made it clear they want to topple moderate governments to spread their ideology. They believe that it's just a matter of time before we leave so they can implement their strategies. We're just not going to let them do that. We're going to help this Government become a government that can defend, govern, and sustain itself and an ally in the war on terror.Yes, sir.
label: Explicit

sentence: North Korea appears poised to conduct another nuclear test. Can you detail your discussions with President Xi regarding this? To what extent do you believe China can influence North Korea, and what implications would a test have on U.S.-China relations? [SEP] It's difficult to assess China's precise level of influence over North Korea. I have communicated to President Xi the importance of discouraging North Korea from conducting further nuclear tests. Should they proceed, the United States will be compelled to take defensive actions to safeguard our allies and our own interests. These actions would not be intended as a direct response to China, but rather as a clear signal to North Korea regarding the consequences of their actions.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Biden, you've been a vocal supporter of vaccinations. However, the under-5s are still waiting. What assurances can you give to worried parents, and what's causing the delay? [SEP] The scientists are still working on it, ensuring its safety. We had the same issue with the 7-12 age group, remember? They need to be absolutely certain. It's coming, but I'm not a doctor, so I can't give you a date. We recognize the urgency.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, are you still considering invoking the 14th Amendment, or is that option off the table? Also, how do you respond to critics who say your actions and the G-7 will cause more global instability? Finally, is a deal with Congress the only way forward, or are you still looking at unilateral or executive actions? [SEP] Well, let me just say that we haven't found any unilateral actions that could work in the next two or three weeks. That's the crux of the matter.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. By end of the year or early next year? Or, what's your thinking? [SEP] Well, I—my guess is—I hope Jill and I get a little time to actually sneak away—[]—for a week around—between Christmas and Thanksgiving. [] And my guess is it would be early next year we make that judgment.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Bush, with the economy faltering, how severe do you anticipate the recession will be, and what specific measures are being taken to mitigate its impact on Mexico, particularly given its heavy reliance on exports to the U.S.? [SEP] Well, first of all, we're not in a recession. We're in a slowdown. There's a difference. And we're taking action. We passed a pro-growth package that will put money back in the hands of the American people. That will help. And President Calderon is a strong leader. He'll do what's right for Mexico. As for Colombia, President Uribe is a great friend. We need to support him. A free trade agreement is essential. It's a matter of national security.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, why did you mislead the American public? And why should we believe anything you say now? [SEP] Look, the question itself is framed in a very unfair manner. I didn't lie. I conveyed the message that we needed to remain calm, avoid panic. I was aware of the existence of those recordings, a series of phone conversations, primarily phone calls. Bob Woodward, a name I've long respected, though not deeply familiar with his work, I considered it worthwhile to engage with him in these calls. Whether that was a wise decision, I'm unsure. I don't even know if the book is accurate, but surely, if he perceived any harmful intent in my statements, he would have reported it. He didn't, because he didn't see it as harmful. Nobody did.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, there's a bill potentially coming up in the lame-duck session to extend voting rights to D.C. and give Utah another seat in Congress. You've been a vocal advocate for democracy in Iraq. Why not here in D.C.? Would you support this bill? [SEP] Well, I'll be honest, that's news to me. I wasn't aware it might be brought up during the lame-duck session.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering your vision for a 'free and open Indo-Pacific,' how can the US effectively promote these principles while simultaneously engaging with China, a nation with a vastly different political ideology? And Prime Minister, did President Trump express any dissatisfaction with Japan's missile defense readiness, and what steps are being taken to enhance Japan's defensive capabilities? [SEP] China's a competitor, but we can still do business. We're renegotiating trade deals to make them fair. Japan is a strong ally, and they are investing heavily in their defense. We're selling them the best military equipment in the world. We're working together to ensure security in the region. It's a win-win for everyone.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. You talk about setting an example on Jacksonville. But I just wonder: Some people are going to take away from this the lesson that you're pushing too far, too fast. It seemed, for a while, the numbers were going up in Jacksonville, and you were going to have a problem there. This comes up at a time you're pushing for schools to reopen, you have the opening of the Major League Baseball season. Isn't the example of Jacksonville that we're pushing too fast? [SEP] Well, baseball, as an example—we were discussing it a little while ago—you're going to be at an empty stadium. I've agreed—Randy Levine is a great friend of mine from the Yankees, and he asked me to throw out the first pitch, and I think I'm doing that on August 15 at Yankee Stadium. And I say, How's the crowd going to be? And you know, it's like you don't have a crowd; there is no such thing.It's going to be interesting, Mariano. He's not used to that. I've been at many games. He walks in; the place goes crazy. I think it'd be just as good without the crowd. You were just born with it, you know. Some people are born with it.I don't know if—this is only for the baseball players, but I've never seen a pitcher throw a ball where so many bats were broken as Mariano. He's got the alltime record. I said, How do you do that? He said, Parents. Great parents, when you get right down to it. Right? How do you do that? It's called parents.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Okay. Mr. President, a follow-up on UNGA. Ambassador Kelly Craft recently said that you—or she's hoping that you might be able to deliver the speech in front of the U.N. General Assembly in person, even though other leaders will be sending in their video recordings. Can you confirm that? [SEP] Yes, I'm thinking about going directly to the U.N. to do the speech. A lot of people will not, because of COVID—will not be able to be there, as you know. But I'm thinking—I think it's appropriate. If we can do it, I'll do it directly. And again, this will not be like in the past, because some countries won't be able to escape the problems they're having. You know, countries are having a tremendous problem with the China virus. So we'll see what happens.But I would prefer doing it. I can do it the other way. I can do it viral, as they say. I can do it in that form. But I'd rather be at the United Nations—deliver it.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. To clarify, how does your emphasis on national sovereignty align with the 'responsibility to protect' doctrine? [SEP] Wait a second, you're asking about sovereignty versus... what exactly was that doctrine again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, regarding testimony about the warrantless wiretap program, did you send officials to John Ashcroft's bedside for approval? Is that appropriate? [SEP] Kelly, there's speculation; I won't comment. It's sensitive. The program protects Americans, still needed due to ongoing threats. I must protect civil liberties. Congress was informed. It's crucial. There will be discussion, but I won't discuss classified issues. The program is necessary.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, are you saying a deal couldn't have happened without Israel halting annexation, even temporarily? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, is Syria involved in the discussions? [SEP] We are discussing regional stability.
