sentence: Mr. President, are you refusing to either confirm or deny the existence of US drone strikes in Yemen? [SEP] I won't be commenting on any operational issues.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Yes, my name is Moon—[inaudible]. I'm affiliated to Dong-A Ilbo Daily Newspaper. I have a question for President Moon: Between Korea and the United States, I think one of the most important diplomatic challenges would be to overcome—to resolve the nuclear problem of the D.P.R.K. And you gave a foreign press interview; you talked about bringing balance and diplomacy, and you talked about resolving nuclear problem and the close cooperation between Korea and the United States, and you talked about the China's role.Are you referring to the balance between the U.S.—balance of Korea between U.S. and China, or are you referring to something else? And you have had a third summit meeting at the summit meeting you just had. You said that you have agreed to bring permanent peace to—[inaudible]—on the Korean Peninsula. And what kind of role are you expecting the United States and President Trump to play with regards to settling peace on the Korean Peninsula? [SEP] Yes, on the bringing balance in our diplomatic approaches, this is not about our stance vis-à-vis the United States and the China. We are trying to bring a solution to the nuclear problem—D.P.R.K. nuclear problem—and to bring permanent peace on the Korean Peninsula.And moreover, we would like to promote peace, stability, and prosperity of the Northeast Asian region. So we would like to expand our diplomatic efforts in this regard. And that should include our efforts for China, as well as ASEAN and Russia and the EU. I believe that we should diversify efforts—diplomatic efforts—so that we can pursue a more balanced approach. So that was the intention of making such comments.And to establish permanent peace on the Korean Peninsula and to overcome and to resolve the nuclear problem, I think there's role to be played by the United States and China. And when it comes to the United States, a very strong sanctions and pressure is being put by the United States. The U.S. is leading efforts, and I am very sure that substantive results will be realized through such efforts. And China has also faithfully implemented the U.N. resolution to impose sanctions on D.P.R.K. So we have heightened the pressure and sanctions on D.P.R.K., and I think this will also contribute to resolving the n nuclear problem.And if our international society's efforts bear fruits—if such efforts bear fruits—and if we can really make a turnaround, then I'm sure that we will be able to bring to the table of dialogue. And through such dialogue, I am very confident that we can freeze the nuclear program and ultimately dismantle the weapons program of the D.P.R.K. entirely. And in this, I believe that cooperation from the U.S. and China is essential.And on the establishing a permanent peace on the Korean Peninsula, I don't think it's the right time even that we talk about this issue. Now we should focus on bringing an end to the D.P.R.K. provocations and bringing D.P.R.K. to the table for dialogue. This is the impending challenge that we must address now. So we must focus on the sanctions and pressure. And when there is a turnaround—when the turnaround finally comes—then we should certainly make efforts to further consult each other—Korea and the U.S.—for settling peace on the Korean Peninsula. . I want to just say that President Xi—where we will be tomorrow, China—has been very helpful. We'll find out how helpful soon. But he really has been very, very helpful. So China is out trying very hard to solve the problem with . We hope that Russia, likewise, will be helpful. We also hope that other countries—and we know for a fact that other countries have already started. And we've had great dialogue with many other countries, as you know, and they're really helping a lot.So if we get China, if we get Russia—and we have some other countries, but we want to get most of them—we think that things will happen, and they could happen very quickly.This is a problem, by the way, that should have been done over the last 25 years, not now. This is not the right time to be doing it, but that's what I've got. That's what I've got. This is a problem that should have been taken care of a long time ago.Thank you. Thank you. The United States second and final question will go to Ali Vitali from NBC.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Have you ever made racist remarks? [SEP] No. No, I would never do that, and I don't use racist remarks. And you know what? If I did, you people have—you would've known about it. I've been hearing there are tapes. For years and years, There are tapes.Number one, I never worried about it, because I never did. I never used racist remarks. I have never used racist remarks.Okay.Political Polarization/
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. What about the payment to the Treasury? [SEP] Well, we're going to see about that. Amazingly, I find that you're not allowed to do that. You're not allowed to accept—and I said: What kind of a government—what kind of a thing is? If they're willing to make big payments to the Government, they're not allowed, because there's no—there's no way of doing that from a—there's no legal path to doing that. And I'm saying: Wait a minute. They're willing to make a big payment to the government, and we're not allowed to take the money? When does this happen? How foolish can we be? So we're going to—we're looking into that right now. You understand that.In other words, I said: No, I want a big chunk of that money to go to the United States Government because we made it possible. And the lawyers come back to me and they say, Well, there's no way of doing that. You know why? Because nobody has ever heard of that before. Nobody has ever said that before. Nobody has ever said, Well, we'll approve the deal, but we want a lot of money to go to the Government because by approving the deal, we're making the deal valuable. They've never heard of that before. Okay? Can you believe that? Right? Hard to believe.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, your critics often point to specific instances where they believe your conduct has been inappropriate or divisive. Can you address these specific concerns and explain how your actions are consistent with the responsibilities and expectations of the presidency? [SEP] Those are just fake news. The media is always trying to make me look bad. But the American people are smart. They know what's really going on. It's a political activity. There are exceptions for political activity.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Considering the challenges of the past year, which many consider the most difficult of your presidency, and the current low approval ratings, and acknowledging the issues with the healthcare rollout, what would you consider your most significant misstep in terms of decisions or actions? [SEP] Just to clarify, are we focusing solely on healthcare, or are you asking about my biggest mistake in a broader sense?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, can you elaborate on the rationale behind including firearm offenders in your commutation decisions, considering your broader policies? [SEP] Each case is assessed on its own merits, taking into account a range of factors.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Sputnik News here. Did you discuss North Korea nuclear site inspections in your talks? [SEP] Sorry, I didn't catch that. Where are you from again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Roxham Road, the agreement has been finalized for a year. What caused the delay? And regarding the 15,000 migrants Canada will accept, why is the number so low? What concessions did we offer the U.S. in return? [SEP] Well, this is a very difficult circumstance, the idea of how do we deal with what's going on in , where gangs have essentially taken the place of the Government, in effect. They run—they rule the roost, as the saying goes.And so I think that what the Prime Minister has spoken about makes a lot of sense. The biggest thing we could do, and it's going to take time, is to increase the prospect of the police departments in having the capacity to deal with the problems that are faced. And that is going to take a little bit of time.We also are looking at whether or not the international community, through the United Nations, could play a larger role in this event, in this circumstance. But there is no question that there is a real, genuine concern, because there are several million people in , and the diaspora could cause some real—how can I say it?—confusion in the Western Hemisphere.And so—but I think that what the Prime Minister is suggesting, and we are as well going to be contributing, to see if we can both increase the efficiency and capacity of the training and the methods used by the police department, as well as seeing if we can engage other people in the hemisphere, which we've been talking to, and they're prepared to do some. So it's a work in progress.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So that was recorded? [SEP] No, they didn't record it. I don't think they recorded it. Are there any recordings of it? I wish there were. Because it is interesting stuff.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But sectoral sanctions will only happen with European approval? [SEP] No. I didn't say only, never, when. I said this is our strategy. And I want to emphasize, every time I address this question, there is a diplomatic path to resolving this issue. The Geneva statement pointed towards how we could resolve this statement. What it asks of the Russians is hardly onerous: Make a public statement that those militias need to lay down their arms and exit those buildings; participate with international observers and monitors, rather than stand by while they're being bullied and, in some cases, detained by these thugs; negotiate with the Ukrainian Government and engage in some confidence-building measures. I mean, these aren't heavy lifts if the Russians are sincere in wanting to resolve this problem. So far, we haven't seen that, but we're going to keep on raising the consequences of Russia rejecting that path towards diplomacy.With respect to the statements by the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers—for our Malaysian audience, this is a sports team, basketball team, in the United States. The owner is reported to have said some incredibly offensive, racist statements that were published. I don't think I have to interpret those statements for you; they kind of speak for themselves. When people—when ignorant folks want to advertise their ignorance, you don't really have to do anything, you just let them talk. [] And that's what happened here.I have confidence that the NBA commissioner, Adam Silver, a good man, will address this. Obviously, the NBA is a league that is beloved by fans all across the country. It's got an awful lot of African American players. It's steeped in African American culture. And I suspect that the NBA is going to be deeply concerned in resolving this.I will make just one larger comment about this. We—the United States continues to wrestle with a legacy of race and slavery and segregation that's still there, the vestiges of discrimination. We've made enormous strides, but you're going to continue to see this percolate up every so often. And I think that we just have to be clear and steady in denouncing it, teaching our children differently, but also remaining hopeful that part of why some statements like this stand out so much is because there have been a shift—there has been this shift in how we view ourselves.And like Malaysia, we constantly have to be on guard against racial attitudes that divide us rather than embracing our diversity as a strength. And I know that the people of Malaysia are committed to wrestling with those issues as well. We have to make sure that we stay on top of it, and we will.Even though it wasn't directed at me, I am going to say one thing about TPP, this notion somehow that some protests here might indicate U.S. bullying. Keep in mind, I've got protests back home from my own party about TPP. So there's never been a trade deal in which somebody is not going to at some point object because they're fearful of the future or they're invested in the status quo. And I think it's just very important for everybody to wait and see what exactly is the agreement that has been negotiated before folks jump to conclusions. You take an issue like drugs, for example, the United States does extraordinary work in research and development and providing medical breakthroughs that save a lot of lives around the world. Those companies that make those investments in that research oftentimes want a return, and so there are all kinds of issues around intellectual property and patents and so forth.At the same time, I think we would all agree that if there's a medicine that can save a lot of lives, then we've got to find a way to make sure that it's available to folks who simply can't afford it as part of our common humanity. And both those values are reflected in the conversations and negotiations that are taking place around TPP. So the assumption somehow that right off the bat, that's not something we're paying attention to, that reflects lack of knowledge of what is going on in the negotiations.But my point is, you shouldn't be surprised if there are going to be objections, protests, rumors, conspiracy theories, political aggravation around a trade deal. You've been around long enough, Chuck. That's true in Malaysia, it's true in Tokyo, it's true in Seoul. It's true in the United States of America, and it's true in the Democratic Party.So I continue to strongly believe, however, that this is going to be the right thing to do, creating jobs, creating businesses, expanding opportunity for the United States. And it's going to be good for countries like Malaysia that have been growing rapidly, but are interested in making that next leap to the higher value aspects of the supply chain that can really boost income growth and development. I'd just like to echo what President Obama said. Emphatically, in no uncertain terms, we went to the TPP on our own accord. We were not bullied into it. And I can attest to our commitment towards free trade as to principle and philosophy, because we have entered into 13 separate FTA agreements with other countries.So Malaysia is a great believer in free trade. But we also understand that the benefits of free trade like boosting trade, creating wealth, jobs—those are the good things. But there will be some losers in the process; there will be winners and losers. But overall, the benefit, I think—it's important for us to show to the people in Malaysia that the benefits far outweigh the disadvantages of a free trade agreement.And this is what, in a final analysis, what we have to do, because the underpinnings of a free trade agreement would be acceptance by the people. And we are committed to that process. We'll engage with the public, and we'll also present it to parliament.So we are working out around the sensitivities and challenges, which I alluded to in my discussions with He fully understands our domestic sensitivities, and we will sit down and try to iron this out with the intention of trying to work out a deal in the near future.
label: Dodging

sentence: PM Lee and President Obama, what are your thoughts on the future of the U.S. rebalance in Asia? And Mr. President, hypothetically, if you had another four years, what would be your focus in developing ties with Singapore? [SEP] Fifty years is a considerable timeframe. We aim to strengthen this partnership. It hinges on both nations maintaining stability and prosperity. Should America remain a dominant economy, and Singapore sustain its success, we can find common ground. Regarding a more isolationist U.S. leader, this isn't the venue to discuss U.S. politics. We'll collaborate with any U.S. administration. Singapore often acts as a stabilizing force, facilitating cooperation and de-escalating tensions. The Asia-Pacific region will continue to expand. The U.S. will retain a significant interest in remaining an Asia-Pacific power and fostering strong trade, scientific, and educational ties.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Biden, in relation to the recent announcement regarding the acceptance of citizens from Venezuela, Haiti, Cuba, and Nicaragua, what is the anticipated timeline for this initiative? Are there plans to increase the number of accepted individuals or incorporate other countries into this program? Moreover, what is the total investment earmarked for technological advancements within the United States? President López Obrador, how will Mexico prepare to receive the migrants being expelled from the United States? Could you elaborate on the function and purpose of the new migration center in southern Mexico? Following this summit, can we expect significant shifts in migration policies and the treatment of migrants? Finally, President Biden, concerning fentanyl, what specific measures will be implemented to combat its production and distribution? What impact has the capture of Ovidio Guzmán had on the Cartel of the Pacific, a significant fentanyl producer? Also, were the energy sector consultations under the USMCA/T-MEC agreement discussed with Prime Minister Trudeau? [SEP] We're working with our partners in the region to address the complex challenges of migration. It's a shared responsibility, and we're committed to finding solutions that are both humane and effective. We're providing assistance to countries in need and working to address the root causes of migration. As for fentanyl, we're taking strong action to stop the flow of this deadly drug. We're working with our partners to disrupt drug trafficking networks and hold those responsible accountable.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given your previous use of federal contracting to advance policy goals, would you consider a similar approach in this instance? [SEP] I'm not going to pre-announce anything. We're evaluating our options and will share our plans when we're ready.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, General Mattis has described China as a revisionist power, yet you maintain a positive relationship with President Xi. Is China a friend or foe? And regarding North Korea, if sanctions prove ineffective, are all options still under consideration? [SEP] Well, regarding North Korea, we'll just have to wait and see. I'm not going to reveal my strategy at this time. However, if the sanctions do not work, we will have to move to phase two, which could be a very difficult and unfortunate situation for the world. We are hopeful that the sanctions will be effective. We have tremendous support from around the world for our efforts. North Korea is truly a rogue nation. If we can reach a deal, it would be a great achievement. If not, then something will have to happen. So, we'll see.As for General Mattis, he holds that view, and many others share it. China is a formidable nation, growing stronger, largely due to the financial gains they have made because of poor leadership in the United States. The United States leadership has allowed them to get away with murder.That being said, I believe we can establish a truly great and balanced trading relationship with China. Hopefully, that will come to fruition. And hopefully, the relationship I have with President Xi will facilitate that. Only time will tell.I can confirm that President Trump and President Xi see eye-to-eye in every respect. The respect they have for each other is evident at the meetings I've attended in the region, such as the East Asia Summit and APEC. It's the most important relationship, characterized by respect, frankness, and clear-sightedness.For our part, we see China's rise as overwhelmingly positive for the region and the world. The critical factor, of course, is maintaining the rule of law.There are those who want to portray the United States and its allies, like Australia, as being against China in some sort of rerun of the Cold War. That is not accurate.We need to ensure that the rules of the road, the rule of law, and the rules-based system are upheld, where big countries can't push around little countries; where, to quote Lee Kuan Yew, you don't have a world where the big fish eat the little fish and the little fish eat the shrimps. Maintaining that rules-based order is what we are committed to, and we all have a vested interest in doing so.The President's personal presence in our region at the end of last year sent a powerful message. The regular visits by Secretary Tillerson, Secretary Mattis, and the presence of the United States Navy are so important to maintaining that rules-based order. It has been the foundation of our success, prosperity, and security for the last 40 years.I don't think we've ever had a better relationship with China than we do right now. The only thing that can get in its way is trade, because it's so one-sided, it's so lopsided. And the people that stood here for many years in this position should never have allowed that to happen. It's very unfair to the United States, and it's very unfair to the workers of the United States.Even today, it's extremely hard on companies that want to do business in China, because the barriers are incredible, whereas the barriers coming into our country are foolishly not. I believe in reciprocal trade. If they do something to us, we do something to them. Well, that never happened, and it's gotten worse and worse over the years. But we'll correct it. That can be the only thing that can get in the way of a truly long-term, great relationship, because we have all the ingredients for friendship.From the Washington Examiner, Gabby [Gabby Morrongiello, Washington Examiner].
label: General

sentence: Sir, regarding the Mayor's order, will you encourage federal properties to follow it? [SEP] We're looking at it. We'll let you know soon. Okay?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, the question of Ukraine: is any territorial concession from President Zelenskyy acceptable in order to achieve a cease-fire with Russia, or is that completely unacceptable? And also, your opinion on Russia's continued membership in the G-20? [SEP] On the latter, yes. But it's a G-20 decision. I discussed this earlier today. If Indonesia and others disagree, then we should propose allowing both Ukraine and Russia to participate as observers. Now, remind me of the first question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, it's been a busy week for you on the international stage. You're leaving this summit here in Singapore having determined that Kim Jong Un is a talented man. You left the G-7 summit a few days ago in Canada having determined that Prime Minister Trudeau is weak and dishonest. What do you say to America's allies who worry that you might be jeopardizing our long-term alliances and who worry that you might be treating our historic friends as enemies and our historic enemies as friends? [SEP] Well, first of all, I think it's a very fair question. I had a very good meeting with the G-7. And I left the meeting. And, I'll be honest, we are being taken advantage of by virtually every one of those countries. Very, very seriously. Now, the United States, because of bad management at the top, because of Presidents that didn't care about trade or didn't understand it or whatever reason. For many years, with China being, obviously, the most successful at it, but the European Union is second—$151 billion we lost. They were represented at the meeting. And we're being taken advantage of on trade.Canada does have very big advantages over us in terms of trade deficits. We have a big trade deficit with Canada, I was reading, where, oh, it's actually a surplus. Not a surplus. It's either 17, but it could actually be 100. You know, they put out a document. I don't know if you saw it. They didn't want me to see it, but we found it. Perhaps they were trying to show the power they have. It's close to $100 billion-a-year loss with Canada. They don't take our farm products, many of them. They charge what was 270 percent, but somebody told me the other day that a few months ago they raised it to 295 percent for dairy products. And it's very unfair to our farmers, and it's very unfair to the people of our country: the workers, the farmers, the companies. And we are not able to trade. They have tremendous barriers up. They have tremendous tariffs.So when I put in a countervailing tariff just to get us up a little bit so the balance isn't so much—it's like this—they said, Oh, that's so terrible. I said: What's terrible? We have to catch you a little bit. We have to have a little balance. Even if it's not complete, we have to have a little balance. I say this with many countries.Anyway, we came—we finished the meeting. Really, everybody was happy. And I agreed to sign something. I asked for changes; I demanded changes. And those changes were made. In fact, the picture with Angela Merkel, who I get along with very well, where I'm sitting there like this, that picture was we're waiting for the document, because I wanted to see the final document as changed by the changes that I requested.That was a very friendly—I know it didn't look friendly, and I know it was reported like sort of nasty both ways. I was angry at her or she—actually, we were just talking, the whole group, about something unrelated to everything, very friendly, waiting for the document to come back so I could read it before I leave.Anyway, I left, and it was very friendly. When I got onto the plane, I think that Justin probably didn't know that Air Force One has about 20 televisions, and I see the television. And he's giving a news conference about how he will not be pushed around by the United States. And I say, push him around? We just shook hands. It was very friendly.Look, countries cannot continue to take advantage of us on trade. The numbers are out. Over the last couple of years, and over the last many years—but over the last couple of years, this country has lost $800 billion on trade with other countries, the biggest one being China. Eight-hundred billion dollars. A hundred fifty-one billion with the European Union. They don't take our agricultural products, barely. They don't take a lot of what we have, and yet they send Mercedes into us, they send BMWs into us by the millions. It's very unfair, and it's very unfair to our workers. And I'm going to straighten it out. And it won't even be tough. Okay? Thank you.Go ahead. Go ahead.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. ——using faulty intelligence to provoke Iran? [SEP] Well, no, I heard your question. And I told you, I was confident that the Qods Force, a part of the ian Government, was providing weaponry into Iraq. And to say it is provoking is just a wrong way to characterize the Commander in Chief's decision to do what is necessary to protect our soldiers in harm's way. And I will continue to do so.Bret [Bret Baier, FOX News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, some might argue that your unwavering stance on the debt limit is contributing to the impasse. Are you willing to consider any compromises to avert a potential crisis? [SEP] We're always willing to negotiate in good faith. But we won't be bullied. We won't be blackmailed. And we won't allow the other side to hold the American economy hostage for their political gain.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. U.S. intelligence has said that Russia tried to interfere in the last two Presidential elections, and that Russia groups are behind hacks like SolarWinds and some of the ransomware attacks you just mentioned. Putin, in his news conference just now, accepted no responsibility for any misbehavior. Your predecessor opted not to demand that Putin stop these disruptions. So what is something concrete, sir, that you achieved today to prevent that from happening again? And what were the consequences you threatened? [SEP] Whether I stopped it from happening again—he knows I will take action, like we did when—this last time out. What happened was: We, in fact, made it clear that we were not going to continue to allow this to go on. The end result was, we ended up withdrawing—they went withdrawing Ambassadors, and we closed down some of their facilities in the United States, et cetera. And he knows there are consequences.Now, look, one of the consequences that I know—I don't know; I shouldn't say this; it's unfair of me—I suspect you may all think doesn't matter, but I'm confidence it matters to him—confident it matters to him and other world leaders of big nations: his credibility worldwide shrinks.Let's get this straight: How would it be if the United States were viewed by the rest of the world as interfering with the elections directly of other countries, and everybody knew it? What would it be like if we engaged in activities that he is engaged in? It diminishes the standing of a country that is desperately trying to make sure it maintains its standing as a major world power.And so it's not just what I do, it's what the actions that other countries take—in this case, —that are contrary to international norms. It's the price they pay. They are not—they are not—able to dictate what happens in the world. There are other nations of significant consequence, i.e. the United States of America being one of them.Detention of n Opposition Leader Alexei Navalny/Syria
label: Implicit

sentence: President Lee, following up on North Korea, if they proceed with the missile launch despite international warnings, what specific actions will South Korea take, beyond expressing condemnation? What concrete sanctions are you prepared to implement, and what is the current status of discussions with the U.S. regarding extending South Korea's missile range? [SEP] Let me be clear: a launch would be a clear violation. The international community is united in urging them to reconsider. They will bear the full responsibility. Domestically, they may hope to achieve some objective, but they will only deepen their isolation. As for the missile range, we did not discuss that today. Officials are working on it. We must look at this holistically. We will remain calm and rational.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, to ensure market stability, what concrete actions will your administration take to credibly meet the deficit reduction targets, both in the short and long term? [SEP] I'm sorry, I didn't quite catch that. Could you speak up a bit?
label: Clarification

sentence: Now that the library location is set, is it true you're seeking $200 million in donations? Will you reveal who's donating, and will there be donation limits? [SEP] We're in the initial planning phases. We'll follow all legal guidelines on transparency. The specifics of the fundraising are still being determined.

sentence: Regarding the recent outreach to Cuba, what is your understanding of Fidel Castro's involvement in the talks? When you spoke with Raul Castro, did Fidel's name come up? How is he doing? Given Republican opposition to lifting the embargo, will you personally lobby them to prevent blocking funds for a new Embassy? [SEP] I'm going to have to cut you off here. This is consuming too much time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I want to go to--start with Libya. You had said that you want to see Qadhafi leave power, leave office. Are you prepared to use any means necessary in the United States Government to make that happen? And if not, why not? I know in the cases of some of these other uprisings there's been a careful consideration not to take sides, let the Libyan--let the people in those countries make this decision. But in this case, it does seem we have taken sides. So what--what's the red line here? [SEP] Well, first of all, let's take a look at what we've already done. My first priority obviously was getting out American citizens and Embassy personnel out of Libya, and we got that done. The very next day, we had already instituted the largest financial seizure of assets in our history. And the day after that, we'd imposed sanctions and we had mobilized the international community through the United Nations so that across the board we are slowly tightening the noose on Qadhafi. He is more and more isolated internationally, both through sanctions as well as an arms embargo.In addition to that, we've provided a host of humanitarian aid measures to make sure that people are not adversely affected as they cross the borders into Tunisia or Egypt. And we will continue to do that.And what we've done is we've organized in NATO a series of conversations about a wide range of options that we can take, everything from 24-hour surveillance so that we can monitor the situation on the ground and react rapidly if conditions deteriorated, to further efforts with respect to an arms embargo, additional efforts on humanitarian aid, but also potential military options including a no-fly zone.NATO will be meeting on Tuesday to consider a no-fly zone, and we've been in discussions with both Arab countries as well as African countries to gauge their support for such an action.In addition, Secretary Hillary Clinton will be meeting with the opposition in the next several days, and we have determined that it's appropriate for us to assign a representative whose specific job is to interact with the opposition and determine ways that we can further help them. And so we're going to be in close consultation with them.So the bottom line is, is that I have not taken any options off the table at this point. I think it is important to understand that we have moved about as swiftly as an international coalition has ever moved to impose sanctions on Qadhafi. I am absolutely clear that it is in the interest of the United States and, more importantly, in the interest of the Libyan people for Mr. Qadhafi to leave. And I have not foreclosed these options.Now, I do take very seriously making sure that any decisions I make that involve U.S. military power are well thought through and are done in close consultation with Secretary Gates, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Admiral Mullen, and all relevant personnel. Any time I send the United States forces into a potentially hostile situation, there are risks involved and there are consequences. And it is my job as President to make sure that we have considered all those risks.It's also important, from a political perspective, to, as much as possible, maintain the strong international coalition that we have right now.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, many troops are on multiple tours in Iraq, and reports suggest declining morale. An infantry commander told me that troops are questioning their purpose there. Does this surprise you? Are you aware of this? Is it a minority or growing opinion, and does it concern you? [SEP] Commanders tell me that concern primarily lies with family members. Our troops volunteered and are willing to serve multiple times, but their families are worried. That's why I thank family members. You're talking to certain people, but I'm talking to commanders who tell me the situation on the ground. I know there's concern about the home front, but I haven't heard deep concern about troop morale in Iraq.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: You've now served longer during wartime than George W. Bush. If you finish your term with troops in Afghanistan, Syria, and Iraq, you'll be the only two-term president to do so. How do you reconcile this with your campaign promises? And should Americans accept a state of perpetual war, even if it's not the large-scale conflicts of the past? [SEP] Alright, that's a loaded question. First off, the State Department's a mess, I'm worried about it. The problem is information overload. Emails, texts, smartphones – it's a tsunami of data. It's handy, I get info instantly, but it's overwhelming the department, trying to sort it, classify it, protect it from hackers. If you over-classify, the information's useless. Kerry's working on it. It's a problem across government. FOIA requests are through the roof. It's worse for national security. We're trying to fix it. As for war, when I came in, we had 180,000 troops in Iraq and Afghanistan. Now it's way less. They're not fighting, but training and advising, except when we're hitting ISIS with Iraqi and Syrian help. It's a different kind of war now. But you're right, dealing with terrorists in weak countries means working together to secure borders and stop them. Afghanistan takes time. They're fighting, getting better, but need our help. We could pull out, let the country fall apart, and go back in later. Or we can keep a small presence. We can't have a surrender ceremony with terrorists. We beat al-Qaeda in Iraq, tried to build a democracy, but Sunni anger let them rebuild in Syria and come back. Some say we should have stayed. But the Iraqi government didn't want us, unlike Afghanistan. I can't risk our troops if they're not protected. So, I'm trying to build a system that focuses on partnerships, weak states, solving conflicts, local help, and targeted strikes. It's a mix of everything. The good news is there are fewer wars between countries, almost none between big powers. But this small-time threat can do real damage and scare people. We need to do better. I released data on civilian drone deaths to show we're responsible. It's not perfect, but we're improving. Whether it's the NSA, drones, or Guantanamo, I'm confident I'm making things better, more legal, more in line with our values. But there's more to do. I think about this a lot. It's better than when I started. Thanks.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea, if Kim Jong-un remains unwilling to negotiate and take required actions, will the U.S. intensify sanctions and exert further pressure? [SEP] I'm not going to delve into that. We already have very strong sanctions in place. I don't want to discuss increasing them. They're substantial. There are many good people in North Korea who have to live there, and that's important to me. My perspective has shifted since getting to know Chairman Kim. They have their own viewpoint. So, I'd rather not comment further. Hopefully, for the sake of South Korea, Japan, and even China—President Xi, a respected figure, understands the danger of a nuclear state nearby. He wants this resolved too. Now, I'm heading back to Washington, DC. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Senator McConnell's office says the new relief package is 'precisely tailored,' yet it omits your proposed payroll tax cut. Do you agree with his assessment? [SEP] Look, I wanted that payroll tax cut. It would've been great for the workers, put more money in their pockets. But the Democrats, they weren't having it. They don't seem to care much about the working class, I guess. So, I told the Republicans, who worked hard on this, that we probably wouldn't get it through. We need Democrat votes, and they weren't going to budge. So, yeah, I'd like to see it happen, but if they're blocking it, we have to move on. Maybe something will change.
label: Implicit

sentence: Regarding the timeline for availability, Mr. President, could you provide a more concrete estimate of when the public can expect to access it? [SEP] Well, let me just say this: we're moving with unprecedented speed. The moment it's ready, we're ready. We're talking about immediate distribution, folks. It's going to be tremendous.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, did you raise bringing Russia back into G-7 during your meetings? And when have you last spoken to Vladimir Putin? Do you expect to meet him in Vienna this summer? [SEP] Yes, I have not spoken to Vladimir Putin in quite a while. It has been discussed. We didn't do votes or anything, but it has been discussed. Some people like the idea of bringing Russia back in. This used to be the G-8, not the G-7. And something happened a while ago, where Russia is no longer in. I think it would be an asset to have Russia back in. I think it would be good for the world. I think it would be good for Russia. I think it would be good for the United States. I think it would be good for all of the countries of the current G-7.I think the G-8 would be better. I think having Russia back in would be a positive thing. We're looking for peace in the world. We're not looking to play games.Okay. uestion? Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Iran's accelerated uranium enrichment, as reported by the IAEA, and President Ahmadinejad's defiant stance, coupled with the detention of American citizens, what's your take on where this is all headed? Is it time for serious UN sanctions, and do you think Russia and China will get on board? [SEP] Iran is always on the agenda at these things because they keep ignoring what the world wants when it comes to nukes. Everyone's said no to nuclear weapons programs, but they just don't listen. I think we need tougher sanctions. I just talked to Condoleezza Rice, and we're going to work with Europe to come up with more. And I'll talk to Putin and Hu Jintao about it too. They need to get that Iran with a nuke would be a disaster for everyone. It's in their best interest to help us isolate them. I feel for the Iranian people. They're stuck with a government that's doing something the world hates, and it's hurting their economy. They're a great people with a great history who deserve better. So, we'll keep the pressure on. And grabbing innocent Americans is just wrong. We've told Iran that we won't stand for it.
label: General

sentence: Which other Chinese tech companies are you considering banning from the U.S.? [SEP] Huawei is the main concern. Huawei is not allowed here. I've advised European countries and others against using them. Australia, for example, has been great. We've told countries that if they use Huawei, we won't share intelligence. They've all backed away. The U.K. seemed to be going that way, but now they've changed their mind.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the stalled progress on your domestic agenda and your declining approval ratings, would you say this has been the most trying year of your presidency thus far? [SEP] Julie, I don't look at it that way. Five years in office, two years campaigning before that, there have been ups and downs. I'm focused on whether we're moving the ball forward for the American people, giving families more opportunity, more security. There have been frustrations this past year, Congress should have moved more aggressively. But even when Congress doesn't move, we're still doing things. The ConnectEd program, wireless capacity in every classroom, will make a huge difference for kids and teachers. A manufacturing hub in Youngstown will create innovation and connect universities, manufacturers, job training. We're producing more oil and natural gas here than we're importing. That's a big deal.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. China will be there? You're confident? [SEP] Well, the--we are confident right now that the international community is unified around 's misbehavior in this area. How China operates at the Security Council as we pursue sanctions is something that we're going to have to see. One thing I'm pleased about is to see how forward leaning the Russians have been on this issue. I think they clearly have seen that hasn't been serious about solving what is a solvable dispute between and the international community.All right? I'm going to make this the last question, and I'll take somebody from the back. Yes.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the Attorney General's chief of staff testified that Gonzales knew more about the U.S. attorney firings than he let on. Now, how can the American people have confidence in an Attorney General who is not completely forthright? How long does he have to repair the damage? And can the damage be repaired? [SEP] Attorney General Al Gonzales is an honorable and honest man, and he has my full confidence. He is providing documents for Congress to find the truth. He will testify in front of Congress, and he will tell the truth.The U.S. attorneys serve at the pleasure of the United States President. I named them to 4-year terms; they served their 4-year terms. And I appreciate their service. I'm sorry that this—these hearings and all this stuff have besmirched their reputation. That's certainly not the intent of anybody in this administration. But I will remind you, there is no credible evidence that there has been any wrongdoing.
label: Dodging

sentence: President Bush, were you successful in convincing France and Germany to support Ukraine's NATO membership, and how did your visit contribute to that decision? [SEP] Thank you. We've been working with all NATO nations for a positive outcome, because I believe NATO membership for Ukraine and Georgia is in our organization's interest. I've personally spoken to several leaders, Secretary Rice has spoken to her counterparts, and Mr. Hadley has been doing the same. There are ongoing discussions, and I wouldn't prejudge the outcome. The vote will be in Bucharest. My visit here is a clear signal that I mean what I say, that it's in our interest for Ukraine to join. But take more from my visit than just a signal on NATO. I was impressed, like most Americans, by the Orange Revolution. Many Americans were touched and pleased by what took place here. I told the President that Ukraine has caught the imagination of many of our citizens over the last decade, and that you'll have good friends. The key is to have a government that's open, transparent, noncorrupt, and listens to the people. This is a good trip, and I'm thrilled to be here. As the President said, it took me too long to get here, but better late than never. I want to thank you for your hospitality.
label: General

sentence: Sir, regarding deficit reduction, what specific steps are being considered to ensure we meet our targets? [SEP] I'm sorry, I didn't quite catch that. Could you repeat it, please, making sure the microphone is positioned correctly?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You recently launched your reelection campaign. You've said questions about your age are legitimate. And your response is always, Just watch me. But the country is watching, and recent polling shows that 70 percent of Americans, including a majority of Democrats, believe you shouldn't run again. What do you say to them? What do you say to those Americans who are watching and aren't convinced?You've said you can beat Trump again. Do you think you're the only one? [SEP] I may not be the only one, but I know him well. And I know the danger he presents to our democracy. And we've been down this road before.And with regard to age, you know, and polling data, I noticed the polling data I keep hearing about is that I'm between 42 and 46 percent favorable rating, et cetera. And—but everybody running for reelection in this time has been in the same position. There's nothing new about that. You're making it sound like Biden is really underwater. And—number one.Number two, when the same polling data asks whether they think—what kind of job I've done, it gets overwhelmingly positive results, from 58 percent thinking everything from the CHIPS Act and the—all the things we've done.You know, we've created—like I said, we've created 12 million new jobs. We've created 800,000 manufacturing jobs. We have economic growth moving. We're in a situation where the climate—we've invested more money and more help in dealing with the climate crisis than any nation in the world.And so, things are moving. And the reason I'm running again is there's a job to finish.The other thing is that—look, you know, think about what I inherited when I got elected. I inherited a nation in overwhelming debt at the time, number one—in the hole for the 4 years that he was President.I inherited a nation that had a serious loss of credibility around the world as America First and——You know, the first meeting I attended—the G-7—I said, American is back. And one of the world leaders looked and said: For how long? For how long? There was a great concern about the United States being able to lead the free world. And we're doing that again.And those same polls you look at—you take a look at the polls that are saying whether I pulled together NATO and the European Union, as well as the Asian partners. I think we have. But there's more to do.And with regard to age, I can't even say—if I guess how old I am, I can't even say the number. It doesn't—it doesn't register with me.And—but the only thing I can say is that one of the things that people are going to find out—they're going to see a race, and they're going to judge whether or not I have it or don't have it. I respect them taking a hard look at it. I'd take a hard look at it as well. I took a hard look at it before I decided to run.And I feel good. I feel excited about the prospects. And I think we're on the verge of really turning the corner in a way we haven't in a long time.I know you're tired of hearing me say we're at an inflection point, but we really are. What happens in the next 2, 3, 4 years is going to determine what the next three or four decades look like. And I have never been more optimistic in my life about the possibilities of the United States.
label: Explicit

sentence:
Mr. President, in recent months, numerous members of your own party in Congress have faced scandals, often deflecting blame onto others. Why do you believe so many in your party have failed to uphold the standards of accountability? [SEP] Richard, anyone, regardless of party affiliation, who fails to meet high standards should be held accountable. Trust in Congress, the White House, and government as a whole is essential. Democracy requires that people trust their elected leaders. I fully expect individuals to be held responsible for wrongdoing, just as I expect corporate executives and individuals throughout society to be held accountable.

People must take responsibility for their actions. I take responsibility for my decisions. Those in positions of authority have a duty to bring honor to their offices. While people may disagree on opinions, high standards and accountability are crucial for the country and democracy to succeed.

Thank you for your time. See you on the campaign trail.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Sir, will you hope, or do you think that maybe when you are in Poland in September you will make the announcement? [SEP] I think it's a very good idea. Thank you very much for giving me that idea. []
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, in the event of a default, do you believe you possess emergency powers that could be utilized? [SEP] We've already been using emergency measures. Secretary Lew has employed extraordinary measures to keep paying the bills. But those powers have limits, and time is running out. I worry that some Republicans, and even some Democrats, think we have more options than we do. If the Treasury can't sell Treasury bills, we won't have enough money to pay our bills on time. It's that simple. Some have suggested using my powers under the 14th Amendment to ignore the debt ceiling. But even if that were legal, the legal controversy would damage confidence. Strategies like minting a coin ignore the fact that what matters is what Treasury bill buyers think. If they're not sure the bills are valid, they'll be nervous. There are no magic bullets. Congress needs to vote. Speaker Boehner says he doesn't have the votes, but he should put it on the floor and let everyone be on record. Let them vote to keep the government open and pay our bills. If they vote no, voters should know who to blame for the consequences.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the recent election results, which many see as a rejection of your policies, will you consider a course correction for the next two years? What specific adjustments will you make within your administration and in your dealings with the Republican party to address the concerns expressed by the electorate? [SEP] The message I'm hearing is that people want action. They want results. As President, I'm focused on delivering those results. We'll work with Republicans where we can, on issues like trade and infrastructure. We'll continue to advocate for policies that help the middle class. It's about finding common ground and moving forward.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So your confidence in him wasn't shaken by him walking away from the big deal he said he wanted? [SEP] These things are a tough process. And look, in fairness, a big deal would require a lot of work on the part of Harry Reid and Nancy Pelosi and myself to bring Democrats along. But the point is, is if everybody gets in the boat at the same time, it doesn't tip over. I think that was Bob Dole's famous comment after striking a deal with the President and Mr. Gingrich back in the nineties. And that is always the case when it comes to difficult but important tasks like this.Last question. April Ryan [American Urban Radio Networks].
label: Dodging

sentence: Regarding the cabinet, sir? [SEP] Spit it out, I'm all ears.
label: Clarification

sentence: Was he armed, Mr. President? [SEP] That's what I've heard. I'm not certain. You'll need to ask them about that.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: They—both of them, both of them. The President. There's a question as to whether or not we're supposed to or whether or not we legally have to. I don't care. I think it would be great to have China involved and also, of course, South Korea. Okay? Q. Thank you.The President's Meetings With Chairman of the State Affairs Commission Kim Jong Un of North Korea  Q. Is there a transcript of your conversation? [SEP] Huh?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Can you give an idea of what kind of steps? [SEP] Well, I think, for example, how we are gathering data, for example, on guns that fall into the hands of criminals and how we track that more effectively, there may be some steps that we can take administratively, as opposed through legislation.As far as people lining up and purchasing more guns, I think that we've seen for some time now that those who oppose any commonsense gun control or gun safety measures have a pretty effective way of ginning up fear, on the part of gun owners, that somehow the Federal Government's about to take all your guns away. And there's probably an economic element to that. It obviously is good for business.But I think that those of us who look at this problem have repeatedly said that responsible gun owners, people who have a gun for protection, for hunting, for sportsmanship, they don't have anything to worry about. The issue here is not whether or not we believe in the Second Amendment. The issue is, are there some sensible steps that we can take to make sure that somebody like the individual in Newtown can't walk into a school and gun down a bunch of children in a shockingly rapid fashion. And surely we can do something about that.But part of the challenge that we confront is, is that even the slightest hint of some sensible, responsible legislation in this area fans this notion that somehow, here it comes and that everybody's guns are going to be taken away. It's unfortunate, but that's the case. And if you look at over the first 4 years of my administration, we've tried to tighten up and enforce some of the laws that were already on the books. But it would be pretty hard to argue that somehow gun owners have had their rights infringed.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Sir, how would you define the term 'torture'? [SEP] Define what now?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with unemployment remaining high, what specific new measures are you considering to stimulate job creation? [SEP] We are focused on creating an environment where businesses can thrive and create jobs. That means reducing unnecessary regulations, promoting innovation, and investing in education and job training. We are also working to expand access to capital for small businesses and entrepreneurs. We believe that by fostering a pro-growth environment, we can create more opportunities for Americans to find good-paying jobs.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the potential use of chemical weapons, do you have concrete evidence suggesting Putin is preparing to deploy them? Furthermore, what would be the U.S. or NATO's military response if he were to use such weapons? [SEP] I'm unable to disclose specific intelligence details at this time. However, let me assure you, any use of chemical weapons would be met with a response. The nature of that response would depend on the specifics of the situation.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, about Ukraine: If this cease-fire sticks, will you and Europe drop sanctions? Or do you keep them on anyway? Also, what's the US putting into the Rapid Response Force – how many troops, what gear, more than you said in Warsaw? [SEP] We're hoping this cease-fire works, but we're also not holding our breath, given what's happened before with the separatists and Russia. We need to see it in action. The Europeans are still figuring out their sanctions. I think Poroshenko's plan will take a while to get going. So, keeping the sanctions on for now, but saying we'll lift them if they follow the plan, is the best way to make sure they do it. The only reason we're even seeing this cease-fire is because of the sanctions we already put in place and the threat of more, which are really hitting the Russian economy and making them an outsider. Russia can come back into the fold if they respect international law. The fact that we're all – the US and Europe – standing together behind Ukraine and using sanctions shows how seriously we take the idea that big countries can't just push around little countries. I'm happy with how we've handled this Ukraine thing, and the US has been a leader. As for the Rapid Response Forces, I said we'd put in $1 billion in Warsaw. A big chunk of that is going to the readiness plan. We've already got more troops rotating through the Baltics, and we're doing air patrols and stuff in the Baltic and Black Seas. This plan adds to that, makes it all work better together, and gets other countries to pitch in more. It's NATO saying, loud and clear, that we mean what we say about Article 5, especially after what Russia's been doing. Having more boots on the ground is the best way to keep Russia from getting any ideas.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Well, I'm wondering, looking back at the campaign and previous campaigns, do you think that it's been harder to pull the country together after the election by making such partisan attacks about national security? [SEP] Richard, I do believe they care about the security. I don't—I thought they were wrong not making sure our professionals had the tools, and I still believe that. I don't see how you can protect the country unless you give these professionals tools. They just have a different point of view. That doesn't mean they don't—want America to get attacked. That's why I said what I said.Yes, Jackson [David Jackson, Dallas Morning News].
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And on TikTok, sir, if you don't—if you don't mind: The Commerce Department essentially gave you a runway today to strike a deal after the election. Do you expect the TikTok deal before the election or after the election? [SEP] I think it could go quickly. We have great companies talking to us about it. You know about Oracle; you know Microsoft has been involved, and let's see whether or not they're continuing to be involved. Walmart is truly a great company. They are very much involved; they want to do something.So we have some great options, and maybe we can keep a lot of people happy, but have the security that we need. We have to have the total security from China. Just know we're not going to do anything to jeopardize security.At the same time, it's an amazing company and very, very popular. So if we can do a combination of both, I'd be very happy doing that. It could go very quickly though. It could go very, very fast.
label: General

sentence: Q. Yet over the last several months, we've seen many members of your own party in Congress embroiled in one scandal or another and all too ready to blame somebody else, whether prosecutors or Democrats or even the media. So I'm wondering, why do you think it is so many people in your own party have failed to live up to the standards of the responsibility era? [SEP] If any person in any party fails to live up to high standards, they ought to be held to account, Richard. It's important for there to be trust in the Halls of Congress and in the White House and throughout government. People got to trust elected leaders in order for democracy to work to its fullest extent. And I fully expect people to be held to account if there's wrongdoing, just like I expect corporate executives to be held to account for wrongdoing, just like I expect people throughout our society to be held to account for wrongdoing.People do have to take responsibility for the decisions they make in life. I take responsibility for the decisions I make. I also understand that those of us in positions of responsibility have the duty to bring honor to the offices we hold. People don't have to agree with somebody's opinion—there's all kinds of opinions here—but in order to make this country work and to make democracy succeed, there's got to be high standards, and people must be held to account to achieve those standards.I thank you for your time. See you on the campaign trail.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, would you unequivocally advise Israel against a military intervention in Iran? And do you foresee Iran pursuing nuclear weapons after your departure from office? [SEP] I have consistently communicated to all stakeholders that diplomacy is the optimal path forward. The most effective means of achieving this is through concerted international pressure, making it clear to Iran that continued enrichment will lead to isolation and economic hardship. My collaboration with President Putin on this issue was instrumental, promoting a civilian nuclear program under stringent international supervision, with Russia providing enriched uranium and managing spent fuel. We will continue to prioritize diplomatic efforts.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, should Americans be going out getting protective equipment such as masks and so forth? And if so, what is the U.S. doing to boost production of masks? [SEP] Well, we can get a lot of it. In fact, we've ordered a lot of it just in case we need it. We may not need it; you understand that. But in case—we're looking at worst-case scenario. We're going to be set very quickly.But we—I don't think we're going to ever be anywhere near that. I really don't believe that we're going to be anywhere near that. Our borders are very controlled. Our flights in from certain areas that we're talking about are very controlled. I don't think we'll ever be anywhere near that.Please, go ahead.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your policies have disproportionately benefited certain groups while neglecting others. How do you address concerns about inequality and inclusivity? [SEP] Well, that question—I can only say this: If you look at the employment and unemployment numbers for African Americans, for Asian Americans, for Hispanic Americans, they're at a historic high. A poll came out recently where my numbers with Hispanics and with African Americans are the highest—the best they've ever been. That had—that took place 2 or 3 days ago, the poll. I have the best numbers with African American and Hispanic American that I've ever had before. And you saw the same poll. So I can say that. I can say this: You look at median income, you look at all of the employment and unemployment numbers, they're doing the best they've ever done. And it reflects—it really is very reflective in the polls.
label: Implicit

sentence: So, was he on the guest list, sir? [SEP] Beats me. I'm not in charge of scheduling these things. But I do know that they work hand-in-glove, and they've got a solid working relationship, and that's what matters.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, to be clear, considering your remarks about President Xi and the human rights situation in India, could you please restate your position on the concerns raised about the treatment of religious minorities in India, particularly from within your own party? [SEP] The answer to your initial query is no. When dealing with allies such as India, I won't shy away from stating the facts about our relationship with China. The China hysteria is exaggerated. We experienced a minor setback, but Secretary Blinken's trip was successful, and I anticipate meeting with President Xi in the near future. What was that second question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your administration's energy policies are too focused on short-term gains and ignore the long-term consequences of climate change. How do you respond to these criticisms, and what steps are you taking to ensure a sustainable energy future for our nation? [SEP] Well, let me be clear, we take climate change very seriously, and we're committed to reducing our emissions and transitioning to a clean energy economy. We're investing in renewable energy technologies, promoting energy efficiency, and working with other countries to address climate change. But we also need to be realistic about the challenges we face. We need to ensure that we have a reliable and affordable supply of energy to meet our nation's needs, and that means utilizing all of our available resources, including fossil fuels. We're working to strike a balance between our energy needs and our environmental responsibilities.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Canada's economic stimulus, did you discuss the possibility of them increasing their efforts during your meetings today? Also, what is your vision for the Canada-U.S. relationship in the next four years, particularly concerning the auto industry, border security, and carbon markets? [SEP] Wow, you managed to pack a whole lot into one question! Were you consulting with someone before asking that? Is that--?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Can I ask you just to be clear, and for future Presidents: Is abuse of power an impeachable offense? [SEP] Well, you've got to talk to the lawyers about it. But I will tell you: There's nothing here. I had a very innocent conversation with a very fine gentleman from the Ukraine, and it was based on that. People don't even want to talk about the conversation. I got to watch glimpses in between all of these meetings that I just told you about. I got to watch glimpses of what is taking place, wasting time, in Washington.And I watched—they don't talk about my conversation. They don't talk about my transcripts. Remember this: When Schiff made up the phony story, and he repeated it to Congress and the world—and it was a totally phony story—then I released the transcript. There was supposed to be a second whistleblower. What happened to him? There was—wait, wait. Otherwise, I won't do your show. [] Wait. There was supposed to be an informer. What happened to the informer? All of these people disappeared. And when they saw this transcript, they said, We've got problems. But they went ahead because they were already there, because they had a phony, concocted story made up.So here's the story: Did nothing wrong. It was a perfect conversation. It was totally appropriate. The best lawyers in the world have looked at it. The Department of Justice has looked at it, given it a signoff. There was nothing wrong.They never thought I was going to release the conversation. They probably didn't think we had transcribers or we had it transcribed or taped. But they never thought we were going to release it. When we released that conversation, all hell broke out with the Democrats, because they say: Wait a minute. This is much different than Shifty Schiff told us.So we're doing very well. I got to watch enough. I thought our team did a very good job. But honestly, we have all the material. They don't have the material.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Bush, what concrete outcomes did the Baghdad conference yield, and what are your expectations for future meetings, particularly regarding Iran and Syria's commitment to stabilizing Iraq? [SEP] I like to see action, not just words. If Iran and Syria want to help, they can stop the flow of weapons and suicide bombers into Iraq. That's how we'll know they're serious. The conference was positive. It got everyone talking about helping Iraq. It also gave the Iraqi government some confidence. They're learning about democracy. And Secretary Rice will be at the next meeting. That's a step up.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the pledge to avoid competitive currency devaluations, what concrete impact will that have on China's actions? What are your expectations? And do you believe the Democratic Party would benefit from a change in leadership in Congress? [SEP] From the moment I took office, I've been clear that we welcome China's rise. Their remarkable growth has lifted millions out of poverty, which is ultimately good for the world and for America, because it means that China has the opportunity to be a responsible partner. It means that China can be an enormous market for the United States, for Korea, for countries throughout Asia and around the world. And it's just good to get people out of poverty and give them opportunity. What I've also said is that precisely because of China's success, it's very important that it act in a responsible fashion internationally. And the issue of the RMB is one that is an irritant not just to the United States, but is an irritant to a lot of China's trading partners and those who are competing with China to sell goods around the world. It is undervalued, and China spends enormous amounts of money intervening in the market to keep it undervalued. And so what we've said is, it's important for China in a gradual fashion to transition to a market-based system. Now, this is something that China has done in the past. And China has also acknowledged that it needs to transition to a more balanced growth strategy internally, where they're focusing on their enormous domestic market and giving their people the opportunity to buy goods and services and consume, all of which will promote their growth, but also will reduce some of the imbalances around the world. And so what this communique, I think, communicates, not just to China, but to all of us, is letting currencies reflect market fundamentals, allowing your currency to move up and down, depending on the role that you're playing in the international trading system, is the best way to assure that everybody benefits from trade rather than just some. And the communique strongly communicates that principle. My expectation is that China is going to make progress on this issue. President Hu is going to be visiting me in Washington in January, and our hope and expectation is, is that we will continue to see progress on this front. It means some adjustments for China. And so we're--we understand that this is not solved overnight. But it needs to be dealt with, and I'm confident that it can be. Regarding Congress, what we will naturally see is a whole bunch of talented people rise to the top as they promote good ideas that attract the American people when it comes to jobs and investment and how to grow the economy and how to deal with our challenges. Speaker Pelosi has been an outstanding partner for me. Harry Reid has been a terrific partner in moving some very difficult legislation forward. And I'm looking forward to working with the entire leadership team to continue to make progress on the issues that are important to the American people.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the repeal of 'don't ask, don't tell' and the broader issue of same-sex marriage, could you elaborate on your stance, particularly in light of Commandant Amos's expressed concerns? [SEP] I prefer not to disclose the specifics of discussions held in the Oval Office with my service chiefs. However, I can say that Jim Amos conveyed the same concerns to me privately that he articulated publicly during his testimony, namely, the potential for disruptions. My response was that I was confident that these concerns could be managed, drawing on the historical precedent of racial integration and the inclusion of women in our Armed Forces. This confidence was further substantiated by attitudinal studies conducted prior to the vote. Furthermore, Commandant Amos and all the service chiefs assured me that, despite their concerns, they were confident in their ability to implement this policy without compromising military cohesion, discipline, or readiness. I take them at their word. Since the vote, they have reiterated their commitment to implementing this policy swiftly and effectively, with minimal impact on our military effectiveness. I am greatly encouraged by this. I also wish to commend Bob Gates and Admiral Mullen for their leadership in guiding this process in a manner that safeguards our primary responsibility of ensuring America's safety while upholding our values. Regarding the issue of same-sex marriage, I have addressed this matter recently. As I have stated, my views on this subject are continuously evolving. I find myself grappling with this issue. I have friends and colleagues who are in committed, long-lasting same-sex relationships. They are exceptional individuals, and this issue holds great significance for them. At present, my position is that strong civil unions, affording them the same protections and legal rights as married couples, represent an appropriate baseline. However, I recognize that this may not be sufficient from their perspective, and I anticipate that this will remain a subject of ongoing debate, and I will continue to grapple with it personally.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, thank you. How do these negotiations affect negotiations or talks with Republicans about raising the debt limit? Because it would seem that they have a significant amount of leverage over the White House now, going in. Was there ever any attempt by the White House to include raising the debt limit as a part of this package? [SEP] When you say it would seem they'll have a significant amount of leverage over the White House, what do you mean?
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, just to clarify, are you suggesting that President Zelenskyy might need to concede territory for a ceasefire, and are you in favor of removing Russia from the G-20? [SEP] Regarding the latter, yes, conditionally. It hinges on the G-20's consensus. I proposed today that if unanimity is unattainable, perhaps we should extend invitations to both parties to observe. Now, remind me of the initial question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you. I wanted to ask you if you have learned more about the circumstances of Sergeant Bergdahl's capture and whether he could face any punishment given that the Pentagon has concluded that he left his unit? Also, could you respond to congressional Republicans who say that you violated the law by not notifying them 30 days in advance and that the release or the transfer of the Taliban prisoners could put Americans at risk? Did your willingness to go around that 30-day requirement signal a new urgency to close Guantanamo now that you're ending combat operations in Afghanistan?And also, President Komorowski, can you say whether the steps that President Obama outlined today to increase the U.S. military presence here in Europe are enough to mitigate whatever threat you see coming from Russia, or do you want more from the United States? [SEP] The United States has always had a pretty sacred rule, and that is, we don't leave our men or women in uniform behind. And that dates back to the earliest days of our Revolution.We have consulted with Congress for quite some time about the possibility that we might need to execute a prisoner exchange in order to recover Sergeant Bergdahl. We saw an opportunity. We were concerned about Sergeant Bergdahl's health. We had the cooperation of the Qataris to execute an exchange, and we seized that opportunity. And the process was truncated because we wanted to make sure that we did not miss that window.With respect to the circumstances of Sergeant Bergdahl's capture by the Taliban, we obviously have not been interrogating Sergeant Bergdahl. He is recovering from 5 years of captivity with the Taliban. He's having to undergo a whole battery of tests, and he is going to have to undergo a significant transition back into life. He has not even met with his family yet, which indicates, I think, the degree to which we take this transition process seriously, something that we learned from the Vietnam era.But let me just make a very simple point here, and that is, regardless of the circumstances, whatever those circumstances may turn out to be, we still get an American soldier back if he's held in captivity. Period. Full stop. We don't condition that. And that's what every mom and dad who sees a son or daughter sent over into war theater should expect from not just their Commander in Chief, but the United States of America.In terms of potential threats, the release of the Taliban who were being held in Guantanamo was conditioned on the Qataris keeping eyes on them and creating a structure in which we can monitor their activities. We will be keeping eyes on them. Is there the possibility of some of them trying to return to activities that are detrimental to us? Absolutely. That's been true of all the prisoners that were released from Guantanamo. There is a certain recidivism rate that takes place. I wouldn't be doing it if I thought that it was contrary to American national security. And we have confidence that we will be in a position to go after them if, in fact, they are engaging activities that threaten our defenses.But this is what happens at the end of wars. That was true for George Washington, that was true for Abraham Lincoln, that was true for FDR, that's been true of every combat situation, that at some point, you make sure that you try to get your folks back. And that's the right thing to do.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, on the topic of busing and its potential role in school integration, and considering your upcoming policy, is this a strategy you envision as a practical solution? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, busing isn't a new concept; it's been utilized for quite some time. The reality is, there aren't countless alternatives for transporting students to schools. It's a method that's been implemented, sometimes effectively, sometimes less so. Now, if Vice President Biden had articulated his position on this matter with greater clarity, the outcome might have been different. They certainly challenged him aggressively on that point. But, to reiterate, it remains a prevalent means of facilitating student transportation.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Do you have confidence in them?
