[SEP] Let me—I'm almost through with the first one; I'll come back to the second one.And so I'll continue to urge the Iraqis to show us that they're capable of passing legislation. But it's not just us; it's the Iraqi people. And what really matters is whether or not life is improving for the Iraqi people on the ground.And yes, I've got confidence in them, but I also understand how difficult it is. I'm not making any excuses, but it is hard. It's hard work for them to get law passed. And it's—sometimes it's hard work for people to get law passed here. But that doesn't mean that we shouldn't continue to work to achieve an objective, which is a government that is able to provide security for its people and to provide basic services and, as importantly, serve as an ally against these extremists and radicals.Yes, sir.I. Lewis Scooter Libby
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with Netanyahu's recent statements confirming the Israeli air strike in Syria, could you shed some light on the target, the U.S.'s stance on the operation, and its potential impact on regional stability, particularly concerning Syria, Iran, and Israel, and the possibility of U.S. involvement? [SEP] I'm afraid I must remain silent on this delicate matter. Next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Libya, could you specify the timeframe for transferring command, and is NATO the preferred entity to assume responsibility? Furthermore, what concrete outcomes are you aiming to achieve through your vision of an alliance among equals with the peoples of the Americas following this trip? And President Pinera, what is the core essence of this partnership in terms of achieving regional objectives? [SEP] Look, with respect to Libya, the situation is, as you know, constantly evolving. The speed of the transfer will depend on the recommendations of our commanding officers, once they determine that the initial phase of the mission has been successfully completed. As I've stated before, our primary objective was to neutralize Libyan air defenses, allowing a no-fly zone to operate effectively and ensuring the safety of coalition aircraft and pilots. We're also focused on addressing the humanitarian needs on the ground. We anticipate this transition to occur in a matter of days, not weeks. The Pentagon will keep the American people and the press fully informed. NATO will play a coordinating role, given its exceptional capabilities. However, I'll defer to Admiral Mullen and those directly involved in the operation to provide the specifics of the transfer process. Now, concerning this new partnership in the Americas, I don't want to give away all the best parts of my speech just yet! But what I find most exciting is the fact that countries like Chile have so much to offer us. Chile has been doing some truly innovative work in clean energy, which is why we've established a clean energy partnership. We believe we're making great strides in alternative energy sources, but there may be initiatives taking place in Chile that we can learn from. In the realm of education, we have a long and proud history of public education, and our universities are among the best in the world. But we want to ensure that American students are not just looking inward, but also outward, especially in today's increasingly interconnected world. That's why a broad-based exchange program with the Americas is so important. Security cooperation is also critical, given the scourge of narcotraffickers in the region. Colombia's success in bringing security to a country ravaged by drug wars offers valuable lessons. How can we apply those lessons to smaller countries in Central America that are facing similar challenges? Collaboration between Chile, the United States, Colombia, and other countries in training effective security operations in Central America would be far more effective than if the United States were to act alone. So, across the board, what will define this new partnership is the fact that it's a two-way street. It's not simply a case of a highly developed country assisting a poor and impoverished country. It's a collaboration between an up-and-coming regional power with a strong voice in international affairs and the United States, working together to promote greater peace and prosperity in the region and the world. There's no doubt that we're lagging behind in integrating the Americas. Just look at what happened in Europe. After two devastating World Wars, they had the wisdom and courage to abandon the old ways and embrace the Maastricht Treaty. Leaders like Adenauer, De Gasperi, Haussmann, and Schuman built what we now know as the European Union. In America, we're far behind. Twenty years ago, President Bush Sr. proposed a free trade area from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego, which generated a lot of excitement, but it never came to fruition. The time is now, because Latin America has been the continent of hope or the future for too long. A continent can't be a promise forever. We're ready to fulfill our mission. Latin America's main task is to make up for lost time and tap into its full potential. We have much in common with the United States: vast territory, hardworking people, and fewer racial and religious conflicts. Latin America is called to commit to its own destiny. We're looking forward to 's words. We're both left-handed, we both studied at Harvard, and we're both sportsmen. continues to play basketball, and I did in my time. The First Lady of the United States is very good-looking, and has said the same about the First Lady of Chile. We have many coincidences, but the most important one is what we'll find this afternoon. Modestly, I suggest to that we aim for a Partnership 2.0, one with shared responsibilities, not an existential alliance. Existentialism alone is not enough to face major problems. We need a partnership of collaboration between Latin America and the United States, sharing values, principles, and a common vision. This alliance should be comprehensive, encompassing democracy, freedom, rule of law, and human rights. We need to improve the OAS democratic charter. It should also open the doors to free trade of goods and services, faster than before, and include education, science, technology, and innovation. These are the pillars for Latin America to leave poverty behind. We have so much to learn from a country like the United States, which has demonstrated innovation and contributed greatly to the progress of mankind in its 230 years of independence. Latin America and the United States have much to gain from this alliance, but it must also address the major challenges of the 21st century: energy, with clean, safe, renewable sources; and water, which could become scarce due to global warming. We must also face organized crime, terrorism, drug trafficking, global warming, and world security together. We need a new international order to replace the one that emerged from Bretton Woods, one that is adapted to the needs and challenges of the 21st century, where change is the only constant. The time is right to recover lost time and initiate a new era of collaboration, frankly, effectively, and concretely, to solve problems and seize opportunities. The knowledge and information society is knocking on our doors. Latin America was late to the Industrial Revolution; we can't be late to this revolution, which is so much deeper. It has been generous to those who embrace it and cool to those who don't. No child should be left behind, as has said. And in Latin America, we say, no country should be left behind. Thank you.
label: General

sentence: Considering the apparent rifts within the Republican Party, how optimistic are you that Speaker Boehner can rally his members behind a comprehensive deal, and do you still have faith in his ability to lead? [SEP] The Speaker clearly has challenges within his own party, and I recognize that. Many of his members come from districts that I lost, so they may not see much benefit in working with me, fearing challenges from within their own ranks. I understand that. But recent events should give us all some perspective. We need to focus on what's important for the country. Even if we disagree on many things, we need to compromise to reduce the deficit, protect middle-class taxes, and promote economic growth. Avoiding self-inflicted crises will allow us to tackle important issues like preventing tragedies like Newtown and focusing on energy and immigration reform. If we can put aside partisan politics, we can work together for the good of the country. I think the Speaker wants to do that. We need to create an environment in both the House and Senate where Republicans prioritize the country's interests over political battles.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the human rights situation and the drug war in Mexico, and considering the Merida Initiative, will you certify Mexico's progress? Also, what are your thoughts on the threats against President Calderon, and the visa issues? [SEP] I'm afraid the translation wasn't clear. It sounded like a very insightful question, though. Could you repeat it? Perhaps with a bit more...clarity?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. But he said—then, just to conclude—today, he said that Russia would be ready to hand over cyber criminals to the United States if the U.S. would do the same to Russia and an agreement came out of this meeting coming up. So are you open to that kind of a trade with Vladimir Putin? [SEP] I—yes, I'm open to—if there's crimes committed against Russia that, in fact, are—and the people committing those crimes are being harbored in the United States—I'm committed to holding them accountable. And I'm—I heard that; I was told, as I was flying here, that he said that. I think that's potentially a good sign and progress.Thank you all very, very much. Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Good morning. President Bush, Prime Minister Olmert said that peace is unlikely as long as Gaza militants continue their attacks on Israel. How do you see President Abbas getting control of Gaza?And you, Mr. President Abbas, how do you intend, actually, to get control of Gaza, and do you think this is feasible by the end of the year and by—at the end of Mr. Bush Presidency? [SEP] First of all, Gaza is a tough situation. I don't know whether you can solve it in a year or not. But I know this: It can't be solved unless the Prime Minister—the President has a vision that he can lay out to the people of Gaza that says, here's your choice: Do you want those who have created chaos to run your country, or do you want those of us who negotiated a settlement with the Israelis that will lead for lasting peace?There is a competing vision taking place in Gaza. And in my judgment, Hamas, which I felt ran on a campaign of, we're going to improve your lives through better education and better health, have delivered nothing but misery. And I'm convinced his Government will yield a hopeful future. And the best way to make that abundantly clear is for there to be a vision that's understandable.See, the past has just been empty words, you know. We've—actually, it hasn't been that much—I'm the only President that's really articulated a two-state solution so far. But saying two states really doesn't have much bearing until borders are defined, right of return issues resolved, there's—Jerusalem is understood, the security measures—the common security measures will be in place. That's what I'm talking about. I'm talking about a clear, defined state around which people can rally.And there's going to be no—there will be no better difference, a clearer difference, than the vision of Hamas in Gaza and the vision of the President and the Prime Minister and his team based here in Ramallah. And to me, that's how you solve the issue in the long term. And the definition of long term, I don't know what it means. I'm not a timetable person. Actually, I am on a timetable; I've got 12 months. [] But it's—I'm impressed by the President's understanding about how a vision and a hopeful future is—will help clearly define the stakes amongst the Palestinian people. Gaza is considered a coup by us; we consider it a coup d'etat, what happened in Gaza.[] Now with a call to prayer—we consider it a coup d'etat. [] And we deal with Gaza at two levels. The first is that we deal with the people as part of us, and we take full responsibility that is necessary towards our people. We spend in Gaza 58 percent of our budget. This is not to—it is our duty towards our people that we provide them with all they need.As for the issue of Hamas, we said that this is a coup, and they have to retreat from this coup, and they have to recognize international legitimacy, all international legitimacy, and to recognize the Arab Peace Initiative as well. In this case, we can—we will have another talk. Thank you all.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. ——and can you give that to us? [SEP] Yes, we'll be verifying. It will be verified.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, you're not considering any immediate measures to alleviate the pain at the pump for American consumers? And you're not prepared to criticize Saudi Arabia or other oil-producing nations for their role in driving up prices? [SEP] We're exploring all options to bring down gas prices, including working with our allies to increase global supply. But the long-term solution is to become energy independent and to develop clean, affordable energy sources right here in America. That's what we're focused on.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, thank you. I have two questions: one on the Ahmaud Arbery case and one on the coronavirus. With regards to the coronavirus: given the Vice President's reported self-isolation measures, what's your message to Americans concerned about their safety and the government's reopening plans? Furthermore, why is testing not yet universally accessible to all Americans who desire it? [SEP] Well, the Vice President, let me assure you, has tested negative, both yesterday and today. He's in excellent health, so that's not a concern. Regarding testing for Americans, everyone who wants a test should be able to get one right now. That's the issue with these questions. We just announced that we're number one in the world, by far, in testing – two, three, even four times more than other countries – and then I'm asked, 'When will everyone be able to get tested?' If someone wants a test, they can get one. Now, concerning the incident, it's a terrible tragedy, and many people are looking into it. I've spoken to several people about it. I saw the picture of him in his tuxedo; he looked so handsome. A wonderful young man, with a bright future. It's just awful. They're investigating the case thoroughly, interviewing everyone involved, and we'll see what the outcome is. It's a very sad situation. I've spoken to people closely involved, and I'm following it closely. It's heartbreaking. The video was just terrible. But many people are looking at it, and hopefully, we'll have answers soon. It's truly heartbreaking.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. May I just follow? James Baker has himself said that he believes the U.S. should work with Iran. So would you be willing to work with Iran in a way that allows some sort of negotiations in Iraq, even if they don't come to the table in the P-3 and P-5 negotiations? [SEP] Jessica, Iran has a chance to come to the table with the United States to discuss a variety of issues. And the way forward is one that I had made clear at previous press conferences, and that is, if they would verifiably stop their enrichment, the United States will be at the table with them. In the meantime, they understand our position, and they understand, more importantly, the Iraqi position about their interference inside their country.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, you've spent the last 48 hours reaffirming the U.S.-Japan alliance and laying out this vision of a free and open Indo-Pacific. Yet, in 48 hours, you'll be in China, a nation that's neither free nor open. So, how can the U.S. champion freedom and openness in this region without inevitably coming into conflict with China? And Prime Minister, the President has often spoken about wanting Japan to take a stronger role in its own defense. He'd like to sell Japan military equipment, and there have been reports that the President was disappointed that the Japanese didn't shoot down the North Korean missile that flew over Hokkaido. Did this subject come up? And what did you tell the President about the role you want Japan to play in its defense? [SEP] Let me just add to what the Prime Minister said. He'll shoot them down once he finishes buying all the great military equipment from us. He'll easily shoot them down, just like we did in Saudi Arabia. Amazing shot. Now, the Prime Minister is going to buy massive amounts of military equipment from the United States, and he should. We make the best, by far. Whether it's the F-35, the greatest fighter in the world, totally stealth, or missiles of all kinds, it's jobs for us and safety for Japan and other countries buying from us, countries that weren't buying a year or two ago. As for China, my relationship with President Xi is excellent. I like him a lot. He's a friend. But he represents China, and I represent the United States. We have different views on some things, but we're pretty aligned on trade. The problem with China is that for decades, it's been a very unfair trade situation. I'm being kind to previous administrations. Our trade deficit is massive, hundreds of billions a year, not even including intellectual property. We've started discussions with China because it has to come down. It has to come down to free, fair, or reciprocal trade. I prefer reciprocal. When you explain that you're going to charge tariffs to equalize things, some people don't get it. But when you say it's reciprocal, that we'll charge the same as they charge us, they understand. It's much more understandable. Reciprocal trade is very important to me. We have countries charging us a hundred-percent tax while we charge them nothing. I've been against that for a long time, and you'll see us do something about it. It takes time, with statutory limitations and notices. But you'll see strong action against countries that have been treating the United States, the American worker, and our companies unfairly. It's already started, but the legal foundation is done. You're going to see a big difference, very soon. The United States has been treated very unfairly when it comes to trade. Thank you very much.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, if we default, do you have any tricks up your sleeve, any emergency powers you can use to get us out of it? [SEP] We've been pulling out all the stops already. Lew's been doing everything he can to keep the bills paid. But we're running out of time and options. Some folks think we can just wave a magic wand, but that's not how it works. If the Treasury can't sell bonds, we can't pay our bills. Plain and simple. Some people are talking about using the 14th Amendment to ignore the debt limit. Even if that's legal, the fight would scare everyone. And these crazy ideas, like making a giant coin, they don't matter. What matters is if the people buying our debt trust us. If they don't, we're in trouble. There's no easy way out. Congress has to vote. Boehner says he can't get it done, but he needs to try. Let everyone vote and show where they stand. If they vote to default, the voters need to know who to blame.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Can you say who your favorite is at this point? [SEP] Honestly, I like them all
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. Trump, given what's happening with Major League Baseball and now, today, the Rutgers football team is quarantined, how can you assure people that schools will be safely reopened? [SEP] So can you assure anybody of anything? I do say, again: Young people are almost immune to this disease. The younger, the better, I guess. They're stronger. They're stronger. They have a stronger immune system. It's an incredible thing. Nobody has ever seen this before. Various types of flu will hurt young people more than older people.But young people are almost immune. If you look at the percentage, it's a tiny percent of 1 percent. It's a tiny percent of 1 percent. So we have to have our schools open. We have to protect our teachers. We have to protect our elderly. But we do have to have our schools open.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Trump, are you maintaining all existing sanctions against North Korea? [SEP] Absolutely. The sanctions are fully in place. Some people are saying we conceded something, but that's fake news. We have a fantastic relationship with Kim Jong Un, and North Korea has incredible potential. We're watching closely.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, back in July, your budget office projected a 7.7 percent unemployment rate for the fourth quarter of 2012. Will this new package lower that projection? And will it stimulate growth and create jobs more effectively than the Recovery Act? [SEP] This package isn't as big as the Recovery Act, but the situation is different now. Back then, we were staring down the barrel of a potential Great Depression, with unemployment possibly hitting 15 or 20 percent. Thanks to the Recovery Act, stabilizing the financial system, and the Federal Reserve's actions, we avoided that disaster. We're not facing a double-dip recession now. The economy is growing, companies are making profits, and we're seeing some private sector job growth, but it's not fast enough to bring down the unemployment rate, given the 8 million jobs lost before and as I took office. This package provides an extra boost, more significant than most economists expected. Some are already suggesting faster growth and more job creation because of it. The payroll tax holiday will help, and unemployment insurance will likely have the biggest impact in sustaining and accelerating the recovery. Overall, economists agree this will boost growth and create jobs in the coming months. That's what guided my decision. We need to remember, especially my fellow Democrats who care deeply about middle-class, working-class, and low-income families struggling in this economy: the best jobs program is a growing economy. The best anti-poverty program is ensuring people have jobs and the economy is growing. We can do other things, but without a growing economy and faster private sector hiring, we'll keep struggling, no matter how many programs we create. That's why, considering our options, another 3, 4, 5 months of uncertainty would hurt those seeing smaller paychecks and those relying on unemployment insurance to pay bills and keep their homes and cars. It would also damage the overall health of the economy.
label: Implicit

sentence: Do you hold a different view from P.J. Crowley on this matter? [SEP] I believe I've already addressed the core issue at hand.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So you're inclined to pull the troops out? [SEP] Say what?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning your $447 billion jobs bill, after two months and numerous speeches, tangible results seem scarce, limited to the veterans jobs bill and executive orders. Are you conceding the likelihood of entering the 2012 election cycle without further legislative action on job creation, facing a 9% unemployment rate, and potential doubts about your leadership? [SEP] Well, I think the American people are currently more concerned with the congressional leadership's failure to pass the jobs bill, despite the fact that the majority of Americans, including many Republicans, support its components. This is a significant reason why the American people are currently dissatisfied with Congress. Typically, in politics, when the overwhelming majority of the population is unhappy with your actions, you adapt your approach. However, this hasn't occurred in Congress, particularly among Republicans, who don't seem to share the same sense of urgency regarding the need to create jobs. I will continue to advocate for this bill. I anticipate that we will achieve some progress now, and I will persist until we accomplish all of our objectives. This may extend until November or require a new Congress. The individual components of the bill, such as tax cuts for middle-class families, tax cuts for small businesses that hire veterans or the long-term unemployed, and the reinstatement of teachers in classrooms, are crucial. For example, here in Hawaii, students are attending school only four days a week due to budget constraints. How can we compete in the 21st century when our children are essentially attending school part-time? The jobs bill would alleviate these budget pressures at the state level. Furthermore, rebuilding our infrastructure is essential. Every world leader I speak with emphasizes the importance of having a first-class infrastructure. When you travel through the Asia-Pacific region, you observe airports and ports that surpass ours. This will impact our capacity to conduct business, trade, and export U.S. products made by U.S. workers to the fastest-growing market in the world. Simultaneously, we could create numerous jobs. So, I will continue to push forward. I anticipate that we will gradually make progress. If you're asking whether I expect the Republican leadership in the House or the Senate to suddenly acknowledge that I was correct all along and adopt all of my proposals, the answer is no. However, I hope that they will eventually recognize that inaction is not an option. This should also be their hope, because if they fail to do so, I believe we will have a different set of leaders in Congress.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, given the political gridlock in Congress, what is your Plan B if a debt ceiling agreement cannot be reached by August 2nd? Are you considering any executive actions to prevent a default, and what legal authority would you rely on to justify such actions? [SEP] My focus right now is on getting an agreement with Congress. That's the responsible thing to do. We need to work together to avoid a crisis. But I'm also exploring all of our options. I'm consulting with my legal team, and we're looking at all the possible scenarios. I'm not going to speculate about what we might do if we can't reach an agreement. But I want to assure the American people that I will do everything in my power to protect the economy and prevent a default. That's my responsibility as President, and I take it very seriously.
label: General

sentence: To be clear, are you suggesting that Vladimir Putin was responsible for the hack? [SEP] I've given you my answer. What else do you have?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. ——around November 5. Would you recommend negotiating an increase in the debt ceiling as part of these budget negotiations on spending caps? And also, does the Speaker's race complicate these negotiations? [SEP] I'm sure the Speaker's race complicates these negotiations [] That was a rhetorical question [] It will complicate the negotiations But when it comes to the debt ceiling, we're not going back there Maybe it's been a while, so let me just refresh everybody's memory [] Raising the debt ceiling does not authorize us to spend more, it simply authorizes us to pay the bills that we have already incurred It is the way for the United States to maintain its good credit rating, the full faith and credit of the United StatesHistorically, we do not mess with it If it gets messed with, it would have profound implications for the global economy and could put our financial system in the kind of tailspin that we've—saw back in 2007, 2008 It's just a bad thing to do So we're not going to negotiate on that It has to get done in the next 5 weeks So even though the continuing resolution to keep the Government open lasts for 10 weeks, we have to get the debt ceiling raised in 5 You've got a shorter timetable to get that doneBut here's the bottom line: Mitch McConnell, John Boehner, myself, Nancy Pelosi, Harry Reid—we've all spoken and talked about trying to negotiate a budget agreement And yes, Speaker Boehner's decision to step down complicates it But I do think that there is still a path for us to come up with a reasonable agreement that raises the spending caps above sequester to make sure that we can properly finance both our defense and nondefense needs, that maintains a prudent control of our deficits, and that we can do that in short order It's not that complicated It's—there's—the math is the mathAnd what I've encouraged is that we get started on that work immediately and we push through over the next several weeks and try to leave out extraneous issues that may prevent us from getting a budget agreementI know, for example, that there are many Republicans who are exercised about Planned Parenthood And I deeply disagree with them on that issue, and I think that it's mischaracterized what Planned Parenthood does But I understand that they feel strongly about it, and I respect that But you can't have an issue like that potentially wreck the entire US economy, any more than I should hold the entire budget hostage to my desire to do something about gun violence I feel just as strongly about that, and I think I've got better evidence for it But the notion that I would threaten the Republicans that unless they passed gun safety measures that would stop mass shootings I'm going to shut down the Government and not sign an increase in the debt ceiling would be irresponsible of me And the American people rightly would reject thatWell, same is true for them There are some fights that we fight individually They want to defund Planned Parenthood, there's a way to do it Pass a law, override my veto And that's true across a whole bunch of issues that they disagree with me on, and I have—that's how democracy works I've got no problem with thatBut you have to govern And I'm hoping that the next Speaker understands that the problem Speaker Boehner had or Mitch McConnell had in not dismantling Obamacare or not eliminating the Department of Education—[]—or not deporting every immigrant in this country was not because Speaker Boehner or Mitch McConnell didn't care about conservative principles It had to do with the fact that they can't do it in our system of government, which requires compromise Just like I can't do everything I want in passing an immigration bill or passing a gun safety bill And that doesn't mean, then, I throw a tantrum and try to wreck the economy and put hard-working Americans who are just now able to dig themselves out of a massive recession, put them in harm's way Wrong thing to doPeter Alexander [NBC News]
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. With the NHS? Should the NHS be part of the trade deal, sir? [SEP] Excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, will your response to North Korea's cyberattack on Sony be one of the movies you watch? [SEP] I don't share my personal viewing habits. However, the FBI has confirmed that North Korea was behind the attack. Their assault on a movie studio over a satirical film is outrageous. We will respond proportionally, at a time and place of our choosing. We must also work with the international community to establish clear rules for cyberspace.

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Yemen, you made ending the war a priority. However, the UAE is now requesting the Houthis be re-listed as a terrorist organization. Will you comply, and what is your strategy for ending the conflict? [SEP] That matter is currently under review. And, of course, the cessation of hostilities necessitates the cooperation of all parties involved. It will be a challenging endeavor. Indeed.

sentence: Mr. President, some interpret the election results as a rejection of your message. Do you believe this outcome reflects a shift towards a more inclusive, multiethnic America? [SEP] Well, let's look at the facts. The employment and unemployment numbers for African Americans, Asian Americans, and Hispanic Americans are at historic highs. A recent poll showed my approval ratings with Hispanics and African Americans are the best they've ever been. I have the best numbers with African American and Hispanic American that I've ever had before. You've seen the same poll. Median income is up, and all the employment and unemployment numbers are incredibly strong. These numbers speak for themselves and are reflected in the polls.

sentence: Mr. President, looking ahead, regardless of which party controls the House, what are your top legislative priorities for the next two years? We have a lot of work to do, but we're going to get it done.

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Russia's announcement to reduce military operations near Kyiv, do you perceive this as a sign that the war is nearing its end, or is it merely a tactic by Russia to gain time? I convened a meeting with the heads of state of France, Germany, the United Kingdom, and the United States. There appears to be a consensus to await their proposals. We shall maintain robust sanctions and provide the Ukrainian military with the means to defend themselves. We shall maintain vigilant observation of the situation. Thank you.

sentence: Q. Could we get an update on—— Q. But if it were here or there, would you envision having an audience for that speech? [SEP] Plenty of space, either way. Hey, John Roberts, weren't you outside? Did you say you heard gunshots earlier?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you seemed to suggest, yesterday, that you're essentially committing to not spying on North Korea. Is that what you meant? Were those comments interpreted accurately? If so, why? [SEP] No, it's not what I meant. It's what I said. And that's—I think it's different than maybe your interpretation. I think we're going to do very well with over a period of time. I'm in no rush. The sanctions are on. We got our hostages back. Our remains are coming back; you saw the beautiful ceremony in Hawaii with Mike Pence. We're getting the remains back. There's been no nuclear testing whatsoever. They'd like to do something. I did get, you know, a very—as I said yesterday, a very nice letter from Chairman Kim. And I think we're doing very well.When I took over as President, I will tell you, it looked like it was going to be war with . You know that. Everybody knows that. And it was going to be quite brutal. A strong force. We're the strongest force in the world, but that's a strong force.And we started off a very rough relationship, and I think we have a very good relationship right now. So we'll see what happens. I'm in no rush. I'm in no rush.But there's been no nuclear testing whatsoever. And when I took over, it was nuclear testing all the time. And if you look back to the last 4, 5, 6 years—but really go back further than that. In all fairness to President Obama, go back 20 years, 15 years. It was, really, a very dangerous situation. I consider it to be different now.Now, I may change. And if I change, you will know it very quickly. I will be very quick to tell you exactly what's going on. I may change. But right now we have a good relationship, and I think, probably, better than we've had for maybe 25 years, maybe forever. You know, they've been there a long time—the grandfather, the father, the son. And they've been there for a long time, and nobody has done anything except me. And so we'll see how it all turns out. I hope it turns out well for you and for everybody.Poland-Russia Relations/
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, could you explain the rationale behind your commutation decisions, particularly since a substantial number involved firearm offenses, considering your position on gun control? [SEP] Let me think...
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. A question going out to President Lee. Mr. President, President Lee, you said that passage of the KORUS FTA will be one of the most important aspects of reviving the Korean economy. Do you, sir, despite the opposition within the U.S. Congress, do you expect the KORUS FTA to be ratified within the U.S. Congress? And if so, when do you expect the KORUS FTA to be ratified?Additionally, with regards to the Dokdo issue, we already see the conclusion of this issue, but, however, we still have the question of the naming issue because Dokdo is still referred to as Liancourt Rocks. What kind of dialogue did you have with President Bush during the summit meeting regarding Dokdo naming?Lastly, did President Bush request President Lee to dispatch troops to Afghanistan? [SEP] You sound like the American press. [] As for the last question, I think President Bush should be answering that question.As for the KORUS FTA, it benefits both Korea and the United States, and this is my firm belief. It will help the Korean economy revive itself, and the KORUS FTA will be an opportunity for us to upgrade Korea's economy up a notch. It will improve our competitiveness internationally, improve our productivity, broaden our trade base. And also, through the broadened trade base, we will be able to create new jobs for Koreans. So these are all reasons why I fully support and why I believe that the KORUS FTA must pass.And also, the KORUS FTA has a lot of implications in terms of improving and strengthening the Korea-U.S. bilateral relationship. And so that is why I recognize the significance of the KORUS FTA.Today President Bush and I discussed and we agreed that we will continue to do our best so that the KORUS FTA will be able to pass by the end of this year. We promised each other we'll do our best. I will, on my part, continue to convince the Korea National Assembly for ratification, and President Bush said that he will continue his strenuous efforts to try to convince the U.S. Congress that they ratify the U.S.—the KORUS FTA.As for the Dokdo naming issue, this is not a Korea-U.S. issue, this is a Korea-Japan issue. So—well, I told President Bush—I thanked him, of course, for correcting swiftly the naming issue within the United States. But for the remaining issues, this is an issue that the Korean Government must take up in terms of the justifiability, the historical right that we have over Dokdo, and all the data that we have managed to accrue.And so we will continue our efforts to try to correct this and to tell the international community of our sovereign rights regarding this Dokdo issue. So we'll be very consistent and continuously let people know—and tell the international community and let them know that this is a sovereign land belonging to South Korea. We have Korean nationals living there, and we have exercised control over these islands for many years. And so this is our position, which has always been consistent. And so we have—we're confident that we'll be able to correct this.As for Afghanistan and sending Korean troops, I think, again, President Bush should be able to answer that. But I can tell you that we did discuss this issue. We discussed it. I thanked the President for the contributions that Korea has made to Afghanistan. And the only thing I talked to him about was noncombat help. I asked him to consider as much noncombat help as possible to help this young democracy.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. A new year. Why are you trying so hard in your first year to pull the country so far to the left? [SEP] Well, I'm not. I don't know what you consider to be too far to the left if, in fact, we're talking about making sure that we had the money for COVID, making sure we had the money to put together the bipartisan infrastructure, and making sure we were able to provide for those things that, in fact, would significantly reduce the burden on the working class people but make them—they have to continue to work hard. I don't know how that is pointed to the left.If you may recall, I—you guys have been trying to convince me that I am Bernie Sanders. I'm not. I like him, but I'm not Bernie Sanders. I'm not a Socialist. I'm a mainstream Democrat, and I have been. And mainstream Democrats have overwhelmingly—if you notice, the 48 of the 50 Republican—Democrats supported me in the Senate on virtually everything I've asked.Yes, sir.
label: Dodging

sentence: President Dilma, considering Brazil's ambition for global influence versus the U.S. perception of it as a regional power, how do you bridge this gap and foster a mutually beneficial relationship? [SEP] We see ourselves as a global partner, and we believe the U.S. recognizes the importance of Brazil's role in addressing global issues. Our collaboration is essential for a more prosperous and secure world.

sentence: Mr. President, would you be amenable to signing an immigration agreement that ultimately omits funding for the border wall? Or is that a non-negotiable condition for you? President Trump. No. No. Q. No? [SEP] Absolutely not. It must include the wall. We need that wall for security, for safety, to stop the drugs flooding our country. I'm confident that the folks in that room, Democrats and Republicans alike, will find a solution to the DACA problem – it's been dragging on far too long – and maybe even address broader immigration issues. But any solution, and I mean *any* solution, has to include the wall. Without it, the whole thing falls apart. Look at Israel. They built a wall, and it solved a major problem. We need the wall. It's essential for our security. Security is paramount. So, the answer is a resounding yes, we have to have the wall. Thank you. And please remember that.
label: Implicit

sentence: But are you concerned about the recent increase in violence and instability? [SEP] We're monitoring the situation closely. We're working with the Afghan government to address these challenges. Our commitment to the Afghan people remains strong.

sentence: Mr. President, under what conditions would you consider lifting the travel ban on China related to the coronavirus? [SEP] When we've gotten this thing under control. Look, those travel restrictions were crucial. They protected us. If I hadn't made that tough decision early on, we'd be in a much worse place. I took a lot of flak for it, some even called me a racist. But it was the right thing to do. We need to be working together, not undermining our efforts.

sentence: Your opinion on Boris Johnson and Michael Gove? [SEP] Boris, I've known Boris for a while. I like him. I think he's got what it takes. Jeremy, I know Jeremy as well. I think he's capable. Michael, I don't know Michael. Jeremy, do you think he'd do well? Good. Okay. Thank you all.

sentence: In light of the UK's continued efforts to extradite Gary McKinnon, do you believe his Asperger's and the potential severity of the sentence justify a more compassionate resolution? And Prime Minister Cameron, could you restate your views on this matter, particularly if it was a topic of discussion with the President today? [SEP] David and I touched on this. There's an ongoing conversation between our countries, and I don't want to interfere with that. We understand the seriousness of the hacking charges against Gary McKinnon. Cybersecurity is a growing problem, and we need to work together on it. While traditional espionage is still a concern, the greatest vulnerabilities now lie in breaches of our information systems. We take this very seriously, and so does the British Government. The President typically avoids involvement in prosecution or extradition decisions. My team will follow the law but will coordinate closely with our unparalleled ally. I'm confident this will be resolved in a way that underscores the importance of the issue and our collaborative relationship. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering the discrepancy in coronavirus cases between the UK and other Schengen countries, is the UK exemption justified? Will you consider imposing a travel ban on the UK? [SEP] Look, I rely on the advice of experts, okay? They suggested this approach. Now, if the numbers change, and they are changing rapidly, we'll re-evaluate. We might add them, we might not. We're also thinking about easing restrictions elsewhere. It's a constant balancing act.

sentence: Q. Does that mean that you expect the Chinese company to pay the U.S. Treasury directly or are you talking about—[inaudible]? [SEP] Either way. Whether it's Microsoft or somebody else, or if it was the Chinese, what the price is, the United States could—should get a very large percentage of that price because we're making it possible. Without us—you know, I use the expression, It's like the landlord and the tenant. And without the lease, the tenant doesn't have the value. Well, we're sort of, in a certain way, the lease. We make it possible to have this great success. is a tremendous success, but a big portion of it is in this country.

sentence: What constitutes torture in your view? [SEP] Of what are we speaking?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the leak of the Hadley memo before your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki, did you or your Chief of Staff order an investigation? Furthermore, if unauthorized, do you suspect internal sabotage of your Iraq policy or the meeting itself? [SEP] Look, I'm trying to recall if I specifically ordered an investigation. Honestly, I don't remember issuing that order. What I do remember is being pretty ticked off about all the leaks going on. You guys in the press, you dig around and publish stuff, and I get that's your job. But when classified documents are leaked, that's a problem. It's been a problem for this administration, and it'll be a problem for any administration trying to run the country. We've had a ton of leaks, and frankly, I don't even know where half of them are coming from, so I'm not going to start pointing fingers. The truth is, you almost never find the leaker. It's a perk of your job, I guess. We can complain about it, but finding the people inside the government who are handing over classified documents to newspapers is like finding a needle in a haystack. There might be an investigation happening right now; I honestly couldn't tell you. If there is, it's not something I'm actively thinking about. But I do think it would be a good thing if we could actually catch someone leaking classified information and hold them responsible. Maybe if there were real consequences, people would think twice before leaking.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given your administration's focus on the Asia pivot, some suggest your reception in the region was lukewarm. Also, with only four months left in your term and 60 prisoners remaining at Guantanamo Bay, will the prison remain open when you leave office? [SEP] Well, as far as I can tell, my reception here has been terrific. Have you talked to people in Laos? They seem pretty happy about my visit. Everywhere we've gone, we've had a great reception, like in Vietnam, where millions lined the streets. So, if this theory about my reception and my rebalance policy is based on me going down the short stairs in China, I think that's overblown. Any reasonable person, especially in the region, would be puzzled as to how that became indicative of our work. If you look at the remarks of leaders and ordinary people, and the concrete work we've done on everything from economic programs to development programs, to legacy of war issues, to promoting civil society and young people, the concern I've heard is not that what we've done hasn't been important and successful. The concern is, will it continue? Other leaders ask me if America's interest and presence and engagement will be sustained. I hope my successor will sustain this engagement because there's a lot happening here. You've got countries taking off, one of the most dynamic and youngest populations in the world. This is where the action will be when it comes to commerce and trade and creating U.S. jobs. That's the feedback I've received, not just from leaders, but also from local newspapers and people. With respect to Guantanamo, I'm not ready to concede that it may still remain open, because we're still working to shrink the population. I believe Guantanamo is a recruitment tool for terrorist organizations, clouds counterterrorism cooperation, and is not necessary and hugely expensive for U.S. taxpayers. Is there strong resistance in Congress? Absolutely. But as we shrink the population to 40 or 50 people and maintain a multimillion-dollar operation to house them, Americans should ask why we're spending this money when it's not necessary for our safety and security. Because of the politics in Congress, it's a tough road. But I expect to work hard over the next four and a half months.
label: General

sentence: Senator McCain has been quite vocal about his stance on Vladimir Putin, suggesting a more assertive approach. Do you believe his assessment is accurate, and how would a change in leadership in Russia, or the lack thereof, impact our relationship? [SEP] With all due respect to Senator McCain, my approach to international relations is predicated on engagement and direct communication. I have consistently sought to cultivate a rapport with President Putin that allows for candid dialogue, even on contentious issues. While we may diverge on matters such as the freedom of the press, we have found common ground in areas such as counter-terrorism and nuclear non-proliferation. It is my firm conviction that effective diplomacy necessitates maintaining open lines of communication at the highest levels. Regarding the internal evolution of Russia, it is imperative that we encourage the adoption of democratic principles and the establishment of robust checks and balances. This is a complex and multifaceted relationship that demands careful stewardship.
label: Deflection

sentence: Just a little something about the region or the countries? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to say anything further at this time. The official announcement is coming soon, I promise.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President, if Kim Jong-un continues to resist negotiations, will the U.S. escalate sanctions against North Korea? [SEP] I'm not going to comment on that directly. We have strong sanctions already. I don't want to talk about increasing them. There are people there, good people, who have to live. And I've gotten to know Chairman Kim, and they have a point of view. So, I'm not going to speculate. Hopefully, for the sake of South Korea, Japan, China... President Xi understands the problem. He wants it solved too. I'm heading back to Washington. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, following China's expulsion of Wall Street Journal reporters, what retaliatory measures is your administration considering? Are you contemplating restricting access for Chinese journalists in the United States, for example? [SEP] I haven't had a comprehensive briefing on that situation yet. We're going to take a look at it. It's something I don't like to see. I don't think it's fair, because we provide very good access. Some might even say *too* good. I don't agree with that. I believe we provide excellent access, so this feels unfair. But we'll make a decision on this relatively soon. Okay? Thank you. Good question. Next, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But would you consider any for a post? [SEP] It's tough enough for those people to have a loss.
label: Dodging

sentence: Given the potential environmental risks and limited impact on US gas prices, why continue to advocate for the Keystone pipeline? Isn't it primarily a benefit to Canadian oil companies? [SEP] Let's be clear, the Keystone pipeline isn't some magic bullet for our economy, nor is it solely about benefiting Canadian companies. It's about North American energy security. While the direct impact on US gas prices might be nominal, the project creates jobs, stimulates economic activity, and diversifies our energy supply. We're also committed to mitigating any environmental impact, ensuring responsible development.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Thank you. Turning to the border issue, but first, a quick question on busing. Do you consider it a feasible approach to school integration? And how does it connect to your upcoming policy announcement? [SEP] Well, it's been a long-standing practice. There aren't many alternatives for transporting students. So, it's been implemented. Sometimes it's been done aggressively. But it's a primary method. If Vice President Biden had responded differently, the outcome would've been different. They really attacked him on that issue.
label: Partial/half-answer
